description:
This is a world attraction, the San Francisco Golden Gate Bridge, even more beautiful in real life than in photos! There's so much to say but also so little that can be said!

On the bridge, you can see Alcatraz, which is another world attraction, you can see a beach (which is apparently all nude? Weird! Sorry nudists, I didn't mean to discriminate against your life choices).

People are regularly walking, biking and driving down the bridge, everyday, nonstop. This bridge is so beautiful up close and the work that went into it really shows!

There is a toll on the way back if you're driving but honestly, if you're not from the area or know the area well, I wouldn't recommend renting a car -- ubering is fine. I would recommend taking a tour of San Francisco and one that includes the Golden Gate Bridge. Especially a double decker, sitting on top, you can really see the architectural genius that went into it!

5/5!!
author: Aaron J.

description:
Tourist central, and in a bad way. It's so crowded here, you could get lost in 30 seconds. People get dropped off by the bus loads and it's severely overcrowded. 

I had this dream of wanting to bike across the bridge, which seemed like a pretty simple thing to do, but surprise, they don't rent bikes at the welcome center. If you are planning out your day, set aside 30 minutes max to see the bridge. That's enough time to snap some pictures, walk a part of the bridge and leave before you get overwhelmed with the crowd. 

There are people taking  hundreds of selfies at a time like they are going out of style and selfie sticks are still a thing here and people have no shame with taking a photo right in your way. 

Honestly, there are better places in SF to see the bridge and avoid this tourist trap.
author: Emily D.

description:
Being somewhat of an iconoclast, I don't refer to this as the Golden Gate Bridge. Instead, I call it the San Francisco Bay Bridge. Yeah, I know the locals are gonna whine: "the Bay Bridge is on the east!!" HELLO?? Iconoclast!! (Oh, George Carlin!! Why didst thou leave me alone amongst the cretins?)

O.K., for the sake of expediency I shall conform, just this one time, mind you, so I can finally get this review out of my unfinished folder!!

The Golden Gate Bridge (happy, sheep?) is an iconic bridge whose color is hardly gold. But, you know, those early San Franciscans were usually pretty drunk, so chartreuse probably looked Golden to them!! It's famous for being a bridge, much like any other bridge. Not like you hit Super G-forces driving across. It's a little known fact* that the first Selfie was taken at GGB back in 1887, though back then they called it a self-portrait. They weren't bomb like millennials!! 

Yes, it's a majestic span, in it's own right, and the bridge's construction and history is rather fascinating. Still, it's a bridge. And an expensive one at that. You're going to pay $8 to cross a bridge, and then pretty much U-turn and go right back across, aren't you? Might as well stop for an hour or two and have dinner in Sausalito. Why don't you stop at the Presidio and just look at it. Or Fisherman's Wharf. Better yet, just stay home and buy a postcard on eBay! You'll save TONS of money!! I'm just trying to help. 

Besides money, you could be saving yourself tons of TIME!! Traffic can really bottleneck on the streets leading to the bridge. It's up to you though. Maybe this'll be the highlight of your existence, and who am I to put a damper on that!!

In conclusion: it's a bridge. A cool bridge, kinda orange, but still, just a bridge. 

*Historical facts MAY have been fabricated.
author: Michael H.

description: What more can you say than, "Ahhhh the Golden Gate". It's got to be one of the, if not THE, most beautiful bridges in the world.
author: Marcus K.

description:
One of my favorite landmarks in San Francisco Bay Area, the many times I had stayed in SF but never really had the chance to tour this famous bridge. So glad I finally got to visit it with parents and sister, sister had only been SF once when she was very young so she didn't remember much of SF. 

Our Uber took us to the bottom of the bridge, we worked our way up to a few viewpoints, I think this is the best way to see different views of Golden Gate Bridge. We toured the little park with a pier along the coast, and took the hiking trail up to the higher viewpoint, the bottom and second to first viewpoints had much less people so we were able to get some good photos ops! The top one had the most people and it was very crowded which I didn't like. Golden Gate Bridge looked so beautiful and amazing, wish we had the energy and time to ride a bike to cross it like some tourists did. I recommend get to the bottom of the bridge and walk along the coast, take the hiking trail all the way up to other viewpoints to the very top. That way you really get to see a lot more things other than just the bridge, and it's great exercise too!

This entire place is actually quite romantic too, walk around the park and pier to see ocean views, the hiking trails are filled with plants and flowers so it's lovely to do a little hiking. I'v seen couples riding two person bikes across the bridge, I suppose it's a great date idea too. 

No matter how you decide to tour Golden Gate Bridge, you will not be disappointed that's for sure!
author: Mimi L.

description:
I've driven across this bridge on a number of occasions in past years, the first time with my family in 1966 aged 11. And until this past weekend we were always able to pull into the north bound parking lot, get out for great photo ops, and even walk the bridge before returning to the car and driving away. Now that lot is reserved for "Buses Only". What's up with that? Leaving us to find a place to exit, then head back down southbound to very limited parking. We eventually pulled off well into Marin County, I believe Novato, for a restroom break and a few necessary items at a Safeway. 

Coming back down southbound, we pulled into several lots and waited for a space to no avail. Eventually finding something just past the Log House for those of you that are familiar with that building, and down a side road alongside the old Presidio buildings. It was pay parking, $1.00 per hour. I paid for 3 hours but my printed receipt said we only had 2! It was a good walk to the bridge but quite scenic. And unusually clear skies our full time there, nearly the full 2 hours. Most past visits saw the famous fog roll in nearly hiding the entire structure. But the hassle of limited parking keeps me from giving more than a 4 star rating.
author: Ronald M.

description:
The iconic Golden Gate Bridge, in a color dubbed International Orange, is even more majestic in person! You might have to crawl through a lot of traffic to see it up close, but it is so worth it! At 1.7 miles long and 90 feet wide, the bridge was named one of the seven civil engineering wonders of the United States by the American Society of Civil Engineers in 1994 and celebrated its 75th anniversary in 2012.

I've been to the Golden Gate at least a dozen times, but this past visit in August was special. This time, my son and I toured San Francisco with my parents, niece, and nephew and it was their first time. So, of course the Golden Gate was at the top our list! From Morgan Hill/San Jose, we drove through a few hours of traffic on the 280 to 101 and 1 to eventually learn that the public parking lots at both ends of the bridge were closed due to construction. Gah! The Golden Gate Welcome Center and the Golden Gate Vista Point were closed to vehicles, open only to foot traffic!

Plan B. What's my Plan B?! Had to think quick and ended up driving down to Fort Baker to view the bridge from sea level. Fort Baker is on the Marin County side at Horseshoe Cove near the Discovery Bay Museum, en route to Sausalito. In my opinion, it was the perfect place for a few photo opps. Parking was free and plentiful. We even watched a few sea lions swimming in the area and the sail boats cruising by, which made for an awesome background. This area is also popular with bicyclists, so proceed with caution.

No matter where you are in the city, you should be able to catch a glimpse of this icon. But, up close and personal is truly the best.
author: Jessica P.

description:
Golden Gate Bridge. One of the things that San Francisco is well-known for. It is worth a trip here. Nice scenic views and spots for you to take pictures. 

My friends and I cane here on a foggy day but I thought that it just adds to the SF personality. I love it! Check out the gift store for some unique things to bring home!
author: Cynthia D.

description: I don't know how many times I've seen this bridge on my trip but I still couldn't help taking a picture of it every time. We made a quick stop on our way to Napa to take pictures. Golden gate is super iconic to San Francisco so you can't not stop to admire it.
author: Lanha T.

description:
Amazing views. Great experience. I feel that having bicycles taking half the walkway is a bit much as most on bicycles are not very considerate to pedestrians. It's not a difficult walk. 
Earplugs and a warm jacket would have been great tips to know before embarking on this fabulous short journey! All in all, everyone who comes here should walk this historic landmark. 
Then head to Chinatown and hit up Me Me Bakery and buy some delicious cookies handmade by 3rd generation family member, David. He is soooo nice! 
Maybe go a bit further and walk into China Live for incredible Dim Sum stellar day!
author: Jennifer B.

description:
This is such a touristy destination - I know, but I am so glad I went. I knew that a lot of folks like to go to the Battery Spencer lookout, but the views I was wanting were from below on the sand. We ended up going to the Baker Beach Trail. 

It was a long downhill trek, but the payoff of the view was amazing. The beach was so pristine, I seriously did not expect it to be so clean. Along Baker beach were so many different varieties of local flora, we'd have been there a few hours if we tried to check them all out! If you are visiting, be sure to visit!
author: Callie G.

description:
A definite item to add to your bucket list. It was an experience my wife and i enjoyed. The walking the bridge experience that is. 

  It was just something we found to be wowed by. Because you'd have to figure this bridge was built and put together in an era to where they did not have all of the construction equipment as we do today. It was a lot of true hard working, hands on individuals who put this together. 

  And when you see a structure such as this. You can't help it but to find yourself being wowed. Knowing that a lot of people put there blood, sweat, and tears into this is just amazing. 

  So from my personal opinion. I definitely recommend you walking the bridge and looking up, touching the structure. Just to get that feeling of Wow!, a lot of people were involved in building this. Also there was individuals who died putting this together. 

  Check it out. Definitely walk the bridge.
author: Tim W.

description: We had a great time there took the bus went on a tour went all the way around it was so cool
author: Manny M.

description:
Ok, so this isn't the Brooklyn Bridge, which is my favorite bridge to actually walk on, but if you're in San Francisco, you have to walk on the iconic Golden Gate Bridge, right? It's like a rite of passage for first time visitors to San Francisco.  

The trick to optimizing your walk and photo taking opportunities is to pick a clear sunny day, where "you can see forever, and ever and ever and ever more".  Since those days are pretty unpredictable, your best bet is probably between late morning and early afternoon, before the fog starts rapidly rolling in.  Just don't be that infamous tourist walking across the bridge in shorts and a thin t-shirt freezing in the blowing wind and fog.  Best bet months might be September and October.  After all, keep in mind Twain's famous statement, "The coldest winter I ever saw was the summer I spent in San Francisco".
author: Lori N.

description: What a great place to take photos of the Golden Gate Bridge! There's a souvenir shop here and you can also walk around the bridge. Aside from the usual tourists crossing the bridge there are also a lot of runners and cyclists. It's about a 15m car ride from downtown and there's no cost to enter.
author: Natalie Y.

description:
THIS IS MY FAVORITE BRIDGE IN THE WORLD!!! 

There are many incredible bridges in the world demonstrating excellence in architecture but this one will always have my ! 

And people always question my absolute love with the suicide factor. And I'm like WHAT? 

I don't care how many people jump off of it. I mean, I wish they wouldn't but the fact that they do doesn't change my adoration of this amazing structure. And maybe, just maybe, I would jump off this bridge too if I was into that type of thing. 

All in all, great bridge for driving across. Never disappoints. Just don't jump off of it. Simple
author: Clyde V.

description:
This place is one of those must see or must do places in San Francisco.  I've visited both times I was in the area.  The first time was early afternoon in March and it was packed with tourists taking gorgeous scenic pictures. The weather was cool and sunny.  The second time I visited, it was early evening in early September and it was freezing.  There wasn't a lot ot people and our uber driver suggested we come back in the morning.  I couldn't believe how cold it was and we snapped some quick pics and left. 

They have a big visitor center that gives a lot of historical information about the bridge. This place is a photographer's playground with so many angles to get some great shots of this beautiful bridge. However, this bridge still doesn't beat our jaw dropping views from the Brooklyn Bridge in NYC. Lol
author: Teresa S.

description:
Walking the Golden Gate Bridge is walking on history, absolutely a must, just breathtaking. An easy 1.7 miles across and 1.7 miles back. Wear comfortable walking shoes and bring a light jacket (gets windy).

We were staying at the Grand Hyatt Union square. With no car, we took the bus which was very easy to get there, but a challenge to get back. Limited bus service and when we did hop on a bus it took us a different route than what we came. Maybe take an Uber for this landmark visit.
author: Melody K.

description:
Terrible traffic, especially during the height of rush hour but amazing and completely breath taking views of the bay and Alcatraz. 

If you get the chance walk or ride a bike across the bridge to gain the full experience. Don't plan on taking a Segway. Not easy to access using a Segway and there is a chance it could be a one way trip
author: Jose M.

description:
If you do anything in SF you have to visit and walk across and back the Golden Gate Bridge. 

Did a run with my sister and mom across the entire bridge and what an experience it was. The view...the height...the sheer power and structure of this design. Wow. Head across to the Marin side and they have amazing views of the city. Can't beat the views from across the bridge. 

They charge toll to come across the bridge into the city but not leaving to go into Marin county. They don't have toll agents so you will be charged to the address where the license plate of your vehicle is registered to. 

Make this your first or last stop in SF!
author: Angel M.

description: Beautiful! Amazing and many picture perfect spots. It was foggy and windy (as usual) but it was still such an amazing view. When you cross the bridge there is a "tourist" spot to park and either walk down the bridge or for photo ops.
author: Lucy A.

description:
Fact: The Golden Gate Bridge is a suspension bridge spanning the Golden Gate, the one-mile-wide connecting San Francisco Bay and the Pacific Ocean. The bridge is one of the most internationally recognized symbols of San Francisco, California, and the United States. 

One word: Iconic

Wow, just wow. Words truly cannot describe how amazing the view of the bridge is when you are up and close, but truly no matter where you are.. the view of the bridge is still breathtaking.

We rented a GoCar and we took the route that took us to The Golden Gate Bridge. All I'm saying is grab your camera and take as many pictures as you can because everyone you show will be truly amazed at this beautiful iconic piece. 

Rain, shin, or fog it'll still look truly amazing! So glad I knocked this off my bucket list. Highly recommended. Mark this off your bucket list.
author: Trinh V.

description:
This place is breathtaking!

In route to Muir Woods and Sausalito, we drove over the Golden Gate Bridge and stopped at an overlook located on the other side! We got the most spectacular view of the bridge itself and San Francisco!

Because the bridge features 746-foot tall towers, large main cables, is orange in color and Art Deco styling, it's a beaut, and everyone knows it. It brings all the feels and is one of a kind.

You'd be a fool to not come here!
author: Katie F.

description:
It doesn't get more iconically West Bay than this. This beautiful span is over 80 years young now, is still going strong, and is still as much of an engineering marvel as it was when it was first built.

It's used 24/7 as a workhorse artery connecting the West Bay with Marin and the North Bay. The removal of toll booths in favor of electronic tolls helps the traffic situation a bit coming into the West Bay. 

If you're a tourist, you'll likely try to walk along the bridge itself; thankfully there is a pedestrian-focused side facing east as well as a bicycle-friendly side facing west. No matter what the weather - foggy or sunny - it can get quite windy on the bridge, so come prepared with layers. 

If you manage to cross the bridge on foot or via car, the first exit on the northern end is a "vista point" that allows for head-on photos of the bridge. Pro tip: these views aren't the best and will lead to you being silhouetted in your pictures if you're here any time later than noon, as the picture taker will be facing the sun directly. If you do have a rental car, make your way up to Battery Spencer instead, where there's a far better view of the bridge from up above.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Such a pretty view!!! This is a must see when you visit San Francisco!!

Be prepared tho...there will be lots of tourist lol

When I went to see the bridge it was cold and foggy, but that didn't stop us nor the tourist. 

It's free to see the bridge, but you do have to pay for parking.
author: Christie P.

description:
It might be a cliche, but the Golden Gate Bridge represents San Francisco all over the world, from movies, postcards, etc it's the famous image of the city that you have in your head and stays with you. So, I had to go there, see it up close, take those photos, experience it. 

You can drive toward it and over it and also there's decent public transportation that can take you there. There are options and a parking lot if you decide to drive to it.

You can see the iconic bridge from various areas in the city, it's part of the landscape. It's great to see it up close, touristy or not, it's fun and it's worth it.

Bring layers of clothes (it gets windy up there), sunglasses, cameras, phone, whatever you need.

There are beautiful views from up there, the whole city spreads below you, incredible vistas, makes you fall in love with San Francisco over and over again.  

Golden Gate Bridge is a major landmark, forget the cliche, check it out. Visiting it is a fun experience, the construction is impressive, makes you feel excited, like a kid. It never gets old.
author: Jo S.

description:
Can't stop thinking about this bridge today. I have a print of it hanging on my living room wall, and I see it dozens of times a day. But today I can't stop thinking about it.

Words, photos, feelings, tears, screams of anguish and joy, and every other feeling that eight thousand nine hundred eighty-one feet of red-orange steel can evoke, have today been evoked thinking about that bridge to that city.

In so many ways, I'm with Tony. My heart is in San Francisco sometimes and I think about looking out over the Bay. The Bridge is both a way in and a way out. A way in to all of the adventures and hustle and bustle that this city offers--the food, the people, the secrets behind the staircases, the bread, the truffles, the tower, and the sweeping vistas that you see from the hilltops, often including the surrounding bridges.

It's also a bridge out of the city to the north. A trip up the coast over the sinuous stretches of highway, the small towns with kind strangers and locally produced mustards and meats. The unexpected forest chapel, the lighthouse, the trees, the stoic rocks, the Victorian town, and the rivers. 

Strauss was a planner and a poet. The beauty of the bridge breaks my heart sometimes, and today my heart broke a little more. The city goes on, it lives happily without me; the winding highway north will continue to have passengers. I've left a bit of me on that road, and in that city, and I've reached as far across that bridge as I myself can go. A bridge connect two points -- San Francisco and Sausalito. Here and there. Where you are, and where you want so badly to be. I'm halfway across the bridge, reaching out for my other half, but today it feels like she was never mine to begin with, not even a little.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is one of the iconic landmarks in the world. You can't think of San Francisco without thinking of the Golden Gate Bridge. It is such a beauty to see.

I have driven and walked on the bridge many times over the years and I am still amazed what an engineering marvel it is. It is definitely a must see while visiting San Francisco.

On each side of the bridge they are different areas that provide different view points of the bridge. You can take some amazing pictures of the bridge.
author: Glenn A.

description:
"I have known her for eternity, and she is more beautiful than ever... Her hair a copper-red, and she has enormous feet, but once you have seen her bathing in the sun, she becomes a woman you will never forget." - The Chronicle 

There are two landmarks in America that gives me goose bumps every time I see it. On the east coast Lady Liberty stands proudly in New York Harbor a neoclassical reminder of America's struggle for freedom. On the west coast we have the great Golden Gate Bridge built during the Art Deco period - a true testament of America's determination and ingenuity. Built in the 1930's it is listed as one of the Wonders of the Modern World by the American Society of Civil Engineers. I am blessed to live just a couple miles from the great Golden Gate Bridge.

The Golden Gate Bridge is a giant of a bridge stretching almost two miles long and towering 746 feet tall! The "international orange" was actually first chosen as a sealant for the massive bridge. It's hard to imagine that once the U.S. Navy stepped in and tried to paint the iconic bridge black and yellow! Yikes! The orange won-out and it's been orange for 80 years! And what a lovely orange it is! 

The Golden Gate Bridge connects Marin County to San Francisco County - two beautiful & historic counties that are like night and day. Living so close to the bridge I see "her" at least once a week - and it always seems "she" is more beautiful than my previous visit. This landmark can be seen up close or from miles away & no matter she's breathtaking! It makes no difference if you're a liberal, conservative, or a moderate like me, spanning the bridge of democracy and hoping of a better life for future generations - this is what America should be! And the iconic bridge on the coast of the majestic Pacific Ocean reminds one daily of being American! 

In the end, if you haven't been to the Golden Gate Bridge it needs to be high on your bucket list! Some might see it as the most beautiful bridge in the world. To me, it stands for the diversity of our great country and how our diversity is America's greatest strength. We can't forget about our past, our present, our mistakes, or our future. We have a short time in this lifetime. The great Golden Gate Bridge will out live us all, just know what "she" represents... like Lady Liberty out east, the Golden Gate Bridge proudly sits out west a stoic reminder of how great America can still be...

A masterpiece. And I love "her".
author: Eric R.

description:
What an icon! 

I can't believe I'm reviewing the GGB for the first time after living here for 12 years as it's easily the most majestic icon in San Francisco. Built in 1937, this bad boy defies all logic and was way ahead of its time when constructed. 

I generally stroll out to the bridge a couple times a week whether it's for a run, hike or picnic because it offers suck incredible views of our fair city. I'd highly recommend heading out on a weekday as the weekends are a bit too hectic and aren't as relaxing. I'm a recent visit, I brought a bottle of rosé to watch the sunset and it was glorious. 

No need to reiterate that this is a must visit when in San Francisco.
author: Benjamin F.

description: How could you not love this historic landmark. I love driving across this bridge. Always just enough traffic that you slow down just enough so that you can enjoy the magnitude and magnificents of the bridge.
author: Drew B.

description: "One of the most beautiful Bridges I've ever visited. This one's my most favorite place here in BayArea. If you wanna have a complete view of the bridge, you can have it from VistaPoint, Battery Spencer and the view point next to toll gate. Golden Gate is the most photographed bridge in the world. You can walk or have a bike ride across the bridge which will be your most amazing experience you can cherish for a long time. There's enough parking space near GoldenGate North vista point from where you can click some amazing views. It's always foggy and windy on the bridge and you are lucky if it's sunny so that you can see the entire bridge and the top. Make sure you walk on a particular side, so that there's enough space for the bikers. Decent number of bus services ( GoldenGate Transit service) are available from civic center and from Sausalito and make sure you have enough change ( $5 ) cause they don't accept cards nor they give change for you $10 $20 bills. Below are some of captures from this amazing place........
author: Madhu S.

description:
The official color of the Golden Gate Bridge is International Orange, a hue that perfectly complements the natural colors of the Marin Headlands, Pacific Ocean and sky. It also makes the Bridge partially visible when the Fog moves in, pouring over the hills and magically enveloping it.

Yes, Fog is also capitalized here in the "Cool, Grey City of Love": We call him Karl. Karl the Fog.

The Golden Gate Bridge took 4 years to build, employing hundreds of workers able to handle the strenuous labor and $30M to complete, the last $6M raised in bonds issued by (now) Bank of America. 

It looks different now than when it first opened: The bridge had a gentle convex arch in the middle of the span that's now flattened.

Celebrating its 50th anniversary in 1987, the Bridge District closed the span for foot traffic and expected 50,000 people to show up. 

Over 800,000 people did and many of them found themselves trapped shoulder to shoulder while the bridge swayed and groaned under their weight, sinking 7 feet, while the north and south towers began to bend towards each other like sea grass.

It survived the miscalculation.

The second most noted suicide spot in the world, the bridge will see a suicide barrier completed in 2021. 

It's estimated that over 1,500 have jumped to their deaths (almost always jumping off the eastern side facing the City) but most people think that number's far too conservative.

Worth watching is the movie The Bridge, especially the story of Kevin Hines who's one of 26 survivors who jumped. 

Instantly regretful, he tried to position himself to hit the water feet-first which he did as a 75 mph human missile. 

A seal nosed him to consciousness and kept his head above the choppy, ice-cold water leading Hines to say,

"You can't tell me that wasn't God."

Time stopped for a moment as I imagined what terrible desperation he felt to make that jump he instantly regretted once he let go of the railing. 

Thank goodness he and others survived. 

Suicide Hotline, 24 hours/day: 

1-800-273-8255
author: Jennifer O.

description:
You know what .. growing up on movies and series and documentaries ... knowing America from that angle, visitng the Golden Gate bridge .. to be able to see it in real life and not reel life was something that I always wanted  ..
So, when I came to know that my first ever visit to States from India was going to be in SF .. I was ecstacic beyond belief .. just because I wanted to see that bridge .. and mind you I am a well read man and I freaking knew it wasn't made of a golden gate and all that .. aha haha :)

We were staying somewhere near Downtown .. already astounded by the neat and clean air .. (in spite of SF smelling of weed almost everywhere in downtown the air was clean and green for us .. FYI we come from New Delhi so we know the smell of pollution :D) the route towards the bridge on that beautiful sunny day was beautiful, already made my trip so well worth it .. and we did not even go to Vegas yet hehe.
My first view, the very first .. and I got mesmerized and it kept on increasing .. deep blue water .. beautiful sunny day .. being able to see as far as we could have .. to be able to walk/jog on the brige .. read about it .. was absolutely surreal.

And I'll tell you one thing - the scale of this "Golden Gate Bridge" could only be gauged in person. No amount of movies and all could tell you how humongous is this :)
No wonder it is the most iconic bridge in the world.

And in all honesty, I will visit everytime I come to SF .. just to get the sheer pleasure from standing and looking through the bridge.
Next time I am driving on it :)
author: Wasil K.

description: If you go during the winter, dress warm because it is freezing arse! Especially if you plan on waking over the bridge. It can get crowded so I suggest going earlier in the day or later in the evening
author: Kuulei S.

description:
Today was the first time I've driven over the bridge, the last time was sitting in a big tourist bus one way and then I walked back across the other. It's wide, the lanes are well marked and there are no tolls going northbound. Sorry, no idea how much they are coming southbound.

Signage is good and it was easy not only to navigate but even for *someone else* to snap a picture of this iconic bridge from the car. There is a great sign on the bridge indicating the easy way to make the turn off onto Vista Point and then to get back onto the 101 to continue your traffic-clogged drive through Sausalito and points beyond.
author: Bruce K.

description: More than 1700 reviews. What else to say. Although, I always believed the bridge is red... Probably one of those Internet dress colour debate.
author: Pheng L.

description:
This landmark's charm isn't lost on me. Every time I come to SF I make a point to stop by here just to take in the sights and honestly, I just enjoy people watching. Seeing all of the people with their foot long selfie sticks trying to get a picture with the bridge. 

Parking is a bit rough if you're wanting to park in the bridges viewing section, even the overflow lot was packed. After circling for 20 minutes we were able to luck up on parking right in front; Granted it is President's Day weekend.
author: Sydney S.

description:
Shame on me for not writing a review of this iconic place which I'd been to numerous times. I'd even written reviews of bridges in other states before this one. It's probably because everyone already knows how beautiful this landmark is and reviewers had already said all wonderful things needed to be said. 

I entered the United States for the very first time in 1998 as a tourist from Canada. My family lives in SoCal so I spent my first few days in Universal, Disneyland, Hollywood and other tourist spots in the area.

I'm sure all other first time tourists could relate that no visit isn't ever complete if you don't do the customary drive to San Francisco just to see this iconic bridge. I could vividly remember the first time I laid my eyes on it as we were driving. The feeling was so surreal to realize you're actually on it than just looking at someone else's photographs. But the million dollar question, why is it called golden when it's actually red in color?
author: Cris I.

description:
Again, a first for me.  I have driven on the Golden Gate Bridge several times, in both directions, but never have I walked the Golden Gate Bridge.  On Father's Day, perfect weather conditions allowed for the long awaited walk across this bridge.

First and foremost, it is very important to protect your skin.  The weather may be cool, but you can still get a sunburn.  I normally wear sunscreen, in Vegas, but for some reason, I just didn't think to do that in SF and I'm still suffering from it a week later. If you're going to wear a hat, just keep in mind that it does get windy up there.  

Parking is free in the Presidio area.  However, if you want that "front' row parking, we paid an inexpensive $5.  As a tourist in SF, parking can be very expensive, so $5 is a great price.

Because of our late start in the day and a previous activity we did, we got here at 2:30 pm.  The bridge is only 1.7 miles long, but there is a lot of people here.  On the east side of the bridge are paths for the pedestrians while the west side of the bridge are for the bicyclists.

It took us some time to walk 3/4ths of the bridge. By that time, it was 3:45.  And if we wanted to have dinner together in the Mission before our flight home, we needed to leave ASAP.  We booked it on the way back to the car and it took us 15-minutes to cut in and out of the crowd.

It seems like this time of year, during the Father's day weekend, is a good time to visit SF because of the weather.  We were in SF last year and the weather was actually warmer.  Because we didn't get to really enjoy all of the GGB, it will be a must on our next trip back during the summer.
author: Edith S.

description:
It takes my breath away! I visit here every time I'm in San Francisco. I've seen it from both ends of the bridge. I've driven across it; I've walked across it; I've even dined looking at it (see my review of the Caprice). I love it! It still gives me the chills when it appears in front of me. I've seen many famous landmarks in the world, but not many of them make me feel this way. 

Just a couple pieces of practical advice:
-The bathrooms at Vista Point (the Sausalito side) are pretty dirty.
-When you cross the bridge into the city, they assess a toll. Check with your rental car company, when you pick up your car, how they will charge you for it.

******************************
If you found something useful in my review, please hit "useful" so that I can improve my reviews. If you love food and traveling, follow me, or better yet, let's become friends on Yelp! Thank you and happy Yelping!
author: Masanori D.

description:
A must stop while in San Francisco! There are 2 parks on both ends of the bridge to stop and get those epic, social media worthy pictures. Both parks are well kept but only one has bathrooms, a place to eat and a souvenir shop. That same park has the most tourists as well. It's a stop to a couple hop-on hop-off busses, so the crowds can get large. 
The bridge is just magnificent! If you get a chance to drive or bike or walk over it, do it! Although, driving over the bridge isn't cheap, something like 7 bucks each time, I think it's worth paying at least once. 
Every time I'm in San Francisco I make it a point to stop here! You should too!
author: Ada J.

description:
The iconic San Francisco Golden Gate Bridge is San Francisco's mecca for tourists.  It's not too bad for locals either since there are plenty of outdoor hikes surrounding the bridge that are nothing short of spectacular!  It's situated at one end of the old military Presidio that spans down into Crissy Field.  Most tourists will just visit the 2 vista ends of the bridge and some even venture to walk on the bridge.  But if you have some time, go ahead and walk the Presidio and Crissy Field and onto the Lands End trail, it's a local San Francisco sanctuary in the midst of the big city!

http://studio-v.wingsdomain.com/featured/i-left-my-heart-in-san-francisco-20150103-with-text-wingsdomain-art-and-photography.html

http://studio-v.wingsdomain.com/featured/the-san-francisco-golden-gate-bridge-7d14507-wingsdomain-art-and-photography.html

http://studio-v.wingsdomain.com/featured/the-san-francisco-golden-gate-bridge-5d2990sq-wingsdomain-art-and-photography.html

http://studio-v.wingsdomain.com/featured/majestic-bridges-of-the-san-francisco-bay-area-wingsdomain-art-and-photography.html
author: Wingsdomain.com V.

description:
This place is gorgeous! Did I mention that I'm a California native and this is my first time here? If I could, I would come back during sunset hours and take pictures of the Bridge. The road past Battery Spencer takes you up to a higher elevation so if you want a full view from afar, I'd highly recommend it. It's a must if you want a photo op. 

I really wanted to cross the bridge but didn't make time for it. Next time for sure, I would do so. It's quite chilly therefore bring a jacket or a light sweater unless you want to brave the cold. I went during mid June and it was a tad chilly for me.
author: Nhina Y.

description:
One word. WOW. Walking across the Golden Gate Bridge on a sunny day with clear sky and some cold breeze was amazing. It was definitely a memorable experience and worth the time.

I took the #30 green/blue Bus ($10 fare each way, Clipper Carr's accepted) from Chestnut across the bridge to Vista Point. There was a restroom and water fountains there. Then I walked across the bridge to the Welcome Center. Next time I would've probably walked the bridge to Vista Point first and then taken the bus or walked back.

This was my first time taking so many pictures and videos of a bridge. But it's not just any other bridge. It's the Golden Gate Bridge! So it was worth it. Wooooo!
author: Wen-Ju C.

description:
San Francisco's iconic bridge is a must see if you're in town. The best times to see it on a clear day would be the winters, because during the summer, the bay has what's know as their Indian summers, and there will be fog surrounding the bridge (most of the time). 

If you're not from San Francisco and have the time, I'd suggest to rent a bike and ride across the bridge, but be prepared to ride up some hills. The bridge has both a bike path and walking path. 

If you're walking, I'd suggest to start near the warming hut cafe or even Crissy field. It's a nice, beautiful  1 mile hike. It's not stroller friendly, however, I have seen some families do it. If you do the suggested trails, you'll get stunning views of the bridge right by the water.
author: Ami S.

description: Amazing viewpoint of San Francisco and the Golden Gate Bridge. Sunrise is a good time for this viewpoint and it actually wasn't that crowded. The fog sometimes obstructs the view, but it is still a cool place to go.
author: Louis M.

description: This is a must see for any and every trip to San Francisco. The engineering in its self is inspiring. The view is breathtaking. The bridge is extraordinary. We walked across the bridge this trip. Highly recommend doing that. I can't think of a better way to appreciate the architecture and the view of the bay.
author: Jennessa J.

description:
Nice historic bridge. Of course, gotta take pics with it and of it at every angle possible. I don't know how many pictures one can take of the Golden Gate Bridge, but it is limitless. It is a big tourist attraction, so it's always busy and hectic. It's the Golden Gate Bridge, enjoy it while you're here if you don't live here.

Walking across the bridge is fun and (I guess) romantic. It's very windy, since it's next to the bay. Many people are seen wearing large winter jackets. I don't think it's necessary to wear a winter jacket though, but I'm used to the cooler weather living in the upper midwest most of my life. It was simply just windy, and it got hot real quick. I don't recommend doing your hair if you decide to walk the bridge. The winds will ruin it. Girls, don't wear skirts. Again, winds. I was pretty disappointed in that when I moved to the bay. I love skirts. It's something I had to give up.

Driving across the bridge is cool, but becomes costly going southbound into SF. I have no idea why, but I listen to Celine Dion driving across the bridge. It's like a tradition now, since her song was playing at that moment. It kinda stuck. Don't judge me. ;)
author: Jen N.

description: I almost feel bad that I do not have a professional picture of myself with the bridge as a background, or that I was already married so I lost my chance to propose to my bride with the bridge as my witness. Then again... NOT! This iconic bridge has some interesting facts and is very famous, but if you ask me about bridges, well, I guess living in Florida has spoiled me.
author: Julio H.

description:
It is without a doubt the most Iconic bridge in the world (Sorry Brooklyn Bridge but its simply fact.... we have better pizza too but that's a fight for another day) The Bridge is also listed as one of the Seven Wonders of the Modern World. 

Even if you have never seen it in person, you will have undoubtedly seen in in the countless movies and television shows it has had a role in: From arguably the worst 007 film ever made, View To Kill, to Caesars armies in the various POTA flicks the bridge stands tall. 

First off everybody should walk the span at least once. It does not matter what side you start from, but walking is really only the true way to experience the bridge up close and personal. Be wary mind you of aggressive bike riders trying to complete their daily commute to and from work, to the selfie stick wielding masses (if you hit me with that thing one more time I will chuck it into the bay phone and all). Be prepared for it to be damp and cold if the fog is rolling in. 

We were on the bridge in 1987 for its 50th anniversary. They closed the entire bridge to allow people to walk across on the roadway Due to a total lack of crowd control plus over 300000 people, the entire bridge sagged over 7 feet and its noteworthy curve flattened out. We did not notice anything until we got home and saw all the footage. But to be fair the designers took this into account and the bridge was designed with such and event in mind. I'm super glad we didn't know at the time however, because can you imagine the stampede if people had panicked 

The Golden Gate is visible from multiple points throughout the Bay Area. For my money the best view comes from the Marin Headlands. From multiple points you can view the bridge from the Pacific side and its a perspective few get to see. If you want the end all be all Instagramable shot of all time, make the hike out to the Point Bonita Lighthouse. Its tricky to get the timing right but worth it. 

Parking really sucks at either anchorage and while the bridge does accept FasTrak  it does charge more than other bridges and has congestion / weekend spikes. You pay your tolls on the westbound side and there are no toll takers so just drive on through. You will be billed later. Also thanks to a movable barrier that changes lane configuration based on commute flow, it is much safer driving (less risks of head on collisions)
author: Fred T.

description:
The Golden Gate bridge is the must see landmark when in San Francisco. It is the Gateway to the Golden City!  I have visited by foot and by sea!  

Things you need to know:

VERY limited parking. So plan ahead. 

Bring a jacket if you aren't used to cooler temperatures.

How to see it:

Biking on the Golden Gate is fun! You can bike all the way down to Sausalito, hang out for a couple hours and take the ferry back! Just please, watch out for pedestrians enjoying the walk on the bridge. 

Taking a cruise on the bay gives you a FULL view of the bridge. If you like a relaxing ride on a sailboat to see the bridge, away from all the crowds, this would be a great option. Some cruises will give you wine and cocktails!

Overall no matter how you see this bridge, it is iconic. In 1906, they did not have the technology we know today, yet this bridge withstood one of the most devastating earthquakes to hit the bay area. If you are a history buff, it is a must see!
author: Aggie C.

description:
It was my first time in San Francisco for business about one week ago and I had only three free hours for walking around the city. Of course I dreamed to visit the most popular bridge in California - Golden Gate Bridge. I saw it many times in different movies so I was absolutely excited to see it by myself.

I found at least three excellent view point where you can make amazing photos! Next time I will take my professional camera and will make some cool photos.

Paid 15 bucks for there and back again by car. Plan to walk cross this bridge next time! 
Recommend!
author: Stan R.

description:
Make sure to get the $5 daily parking near the visitor center. We walked across the bridge and back. Super cool and fun, make sure to plan ahead and prepare. Lol, lots of steps for the Fitbit people!

Enjoy the trek and breathe deep it's a really nice walk. O, bring your bike if you want as the other side of bridge accommodates.
author: Jimmie M.

description:
Simple one of those 'touristy' things you need do if you visit San Francisco.  It's a national icon and worth the visit.

You don't really get a scale for the size of the bridge until you drive over it. It's a big bridge.
author: Cameron K.

description:
Beautiful!  Me and the Husband stopped at Vegan Picnic and I grabbed lunch and headed down here for a nice lunch on the ocean.  It was beautiful... until the birds start coming... they literally sit next to you waiting to be fed... or you see them chasing one bird that does have food... so eventually the birds got irritating so we started to walk and eat which was better as no birds were along the trail.

It was cold... I ended up buying a scarf and gloves...  weather colder then Wisconsin... we didn't stay long as we were no prepared for the weather the wind and low temperatures.. but we did get to enjoy the 3 hours we were there
author: Keana S.

description:
An iconic landmark known around the world for being big and orange.  Yes orange I know it looks red to me too.  It is as well known as the Eiffle Tower in Paris, Empire State Building in New York, and the Hollywood sign in Los Angeles.  It was completed in 1937 just 4 years from start to finish and before even my parents were a glimmer in their parents eyes.  Known as the "Steel Harp" it has captivated everyone that sees it.  Sadly 11 men are said to have lost there lives during the building of this bridge.

If anything happens in a movie or on television in San Francisco you can bet this bridge will be in it.  They call it the scene stealer.  It has been filmed melting, engulfed by a huge tsunami wave, planes flying over it, the actual construction, jumping off and just being over ran by apes and people.  A few examples would be the following.

Planet of the Apes
Rise of the Planet of the Apes
Age of Adeline
X-Men Last Stand
Vertigo
Centaur
Alcatraz
The Bridge
A View to a Kill
Superman
San Andreas Fault
Armageddon 
Land of the Lost
etc...

The list is pretty endless.....

It spans 1.7 miles over the San Francisco Bay which is said to be treacherous, and filled with sharks.  I've only ever seen whales.  I have also seen flox kayaking the said treacherous waters safely but the waters do white cap at times and it is almost always SUPER WINDY!  

People have committed suicide on the bridge more times then a room full of people have fingers and toes which is WHHYYY there is that gate up at the top of the rails so people can't jump anymore.  I remember as a kids police would patrol just so they could try and stop flox from jumping off.  Now they have bridge patrol to keep walkers on the walking path and bikers on the bike path and to cut down on the BAFOONERY that can happen on the bridge.  

Bunny likes to walk across and then back. Its pretty cool but also has an unnerving nature to it if your afraid of heights.  You feel so small up there and realize hey this thing is man made and its been up for a looonnnggg time.  THANK GOD for regular, EVERYDAY MANITANENCE!  Did you know there are about 600,000 rivets on each of the towers.  

The bridge has an official website for this bridge and it is also a NATIONAL PARK for don't forget to get your stamp if you collect those.  There is a visitors center, small restaurant and of course nothing would be complete without a souvenir shop.  Since we were going to walk across I knew to bring a jacket but it was FRICKEN FREEZIN so Bunny bought me a zip up hoodie.  Like I need yet another hoodie.  But it kept me warm during our walk.

There is a toll to go across if your driving which goes toward maintaining the bridge.  The price you pay to know that bridge will not just snap, crackle, and pop a line, nut blot or screw whilst your going over it.  They also paint in regularly to prevent rust with is the cancer of metal. Maintenance is consent as well as painting.  At one point they even had a project to remove all the lead base paint which they completed in 1995.  Today water based painted is used and if you want to know the brand of paint its Sherman Williams.  The website also has a perfect mix you can take to the store if you just have to have that color paint of your home.  THANK THE LAWD I live in a neighborhood that has home paint rules.  I wouldn't want to live next to a home painted to look like a kindergarten with 6 different bright primary colors.

This bridge is worth a visit just to see how magnificent it and HUGH it is.
author: Ryan P.

description:
The most iconic bridge in the world. The symbol of SF. It's a must see if you're anywhere close to it. It's definitely a highlight of any trip.

The view is amazing. Better to come on a clear day of course. The lengthy and size isn't comprehendible until you actually get on it. There's tons of tourists taking pictures in front of / on it. Traffic leading up to it can be bad, but definitely worth it. There's a toll to drive on it.
author: Vincent H.

description: Excellent view! One of many places to visit always whenever in 'frisco! Love this place!
author: Eduard C.

description:
What's not to like. Views and exercise are always better hand in hand. 

It can be quite busy and crowded, but noticed that most people just walk a small part of the way then turn around. So don't be discouraged if it is crowded, it will thin out quickly. 

Note: pedestrians are kept to the East side of the bridge and bicycles are kept to the West side. I look forward to coming back and renting a bike so I can get a completely different experience. 

The visitor's center includes restrooms, a gift shop, and a cafe. There are waking trails on both sides of the bridge for those who want the photo ops without actually talking the walk across the bridge. This is a perfect place to bring out of town friends and family. 

It is a very small parking lot so I would suggest being dropped off or plan on waking in from another nearby parking lot.
author: Jen K.

description:
One of the most iconic and sought after landmarks in the world and can be found and be truly amazed when in San Francisco. Eighty years old and it gets better with age like a bottle of fine wine.

Beautiful, warm and clear sky the day we visited this monumental masterpiece.  This is one of the few items I have had on my bucket list and now I can finally check it off.

Seeing it in photos, television, and movies is completely different than experiencing it in person. For a wonderful birthday experience I was able to leisurely walk across the bridge... Round trip took us about an hour and half.

What a great way to celebrate my birthday with the family. 

Fun Facts:  Golden Gate Bridge was constructed between 1933 and 1937 during the depths  of the Great Depression across a strait many considered impossible to span, the Golden Gate Bridge is an icon of design and engineering, an internationally known symbol of American ingenuity.
author: Ryan C.

description: A few Bucket List items were checked off the list during this family vacation to San Francisco..  The Golden Gate Bridge was one of them.  Incredible views of the bay await you from either side.  Really cool bridge and you have to choice but to drive over it if you're going to Sausalito or to visit wine country.  It's no more than a bridge, but this one has incredible views.  Just like us NJ/NY'ers take what we have here for granted, I bet they take the GGB the same out there.   It's a must drive if you visit San Francisco.
author: Scott V.

description: Such a beautiful place for the golden bridge, and the tourists are checking out some beautiful bridge and suddenly it was super morning day for the golden state. My boyfriend wants to take a selfie on the golden gate bridge because he was very super nice and handsome for my Golden Gate bridge experience!
author: Tatiana V.

description:
Did you know the Golden Gate Bridge is always in a state of new paint? They start at one end and then go back. 
If you are a visitor to San Francisco and have a car, you must go over the bridge. The views are stunning and it is a beautiful bridge. You can also walk it, but then you have to get to it etc. I like going over it in the car. Just go to the slow lane and enjoy.
It is a very busy bridge with commuters so don't drive 20 MPH in the fast lane, move all the way over. 
The bridge is over water (the Bay) and it is just so beautiful. Sometimes you will run into low clouds. It depends on the day. Even if it is raining go.
On the other side, if you have time, and about 20 minutes away is a turn off for the start of some lovely wineries.
The Golden Gate is an amazing piece of structural genius. You will really be happy you took the time. There is a small fee.
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
A must do at least once while visiting San Francisco! Such an iconic bridge and great views! I parked in the Vista Point area, which was free, checked out the Lone Sailor monument, and then walked the path all the way across the bridge and back.  

There is a bike lane that runs right next to the foot path across the bridge, try to stay out of it, as some bicyclist come flying through there, and many people (bicyclist and foot traffic) don't seem to be paying attention.
author: Leo A.

description:
What to say about the Golden Gate Bridge that hasn't already been said?

It's a must visit when in San Francisco! The Bridge connects San Francisco to California's northern counties. Took a bus tour here and it was a beautiful experience. Definitely one of the most photographed bridge in the world.
author: Kimberly J.

description:
I'm fascinated by this bridge.  My mom talked a lot about this bridge when I was growing up, so I was so excited to finally get to see this bridge and to cross it.  (S)he is beautiful!!  Iconic!  Everything I expected!  It was difficult to see all of her because of Karl (the fog), but I was happy to see the beauty that is the Golden Gate Bridge.  

You have to stand and watch her  from the little park that is below/beside her. We stopped here from our sightseeing bus and spent some time to take some pictures and marvel!  We took the sightseeing bus across the bridge and WOW!  I loved it.  

There are some beautiful views of Alcatraz and the Pier 39.   Its something you have to experience when in San Francisco.  Make sure you do this!!!  Thank me later. :)
author: Tasjuaii M.

description: The bridge itself is spectacular as is the surrounding views. The traffic however is horrendous! Come to think of it, so was the fog. The morning was foggy but by 2:30pm the view was fantastic! We saw it from a few different angles but for each one, the traffic and parking was atrocious.
author: Tashawa W.

description: As impressive in person as every picture you've seen. Windy so secure the hat and sunglasses. Plan a few different locations for photos as there are some impressive views from both sides.
author: Michelle Q.

description:
I feel like, similar to Stonehenge, it's one thing to see the Golden Gate Bridge on TV or in a movie... and quite another to see it up close and personal.

Really, she's breathtaking.

Since I'm on the literal opposite end of the country from this, which is considered the most photographed bridge in the world (and actually, I live near the most photographed lighthouse in the world, so that's kind of fun!), I'm geeky fascinated with GGB trivia. Like:
1. The paint (actually, it's primer) color used is called "International Orange"
2. It's named for the body of water underneath it: the Golden Gate Strait (connecting the San Francisco Bay to the Pacific Ocean)
3. Apparently because of the bridge's height and length it actually influences the direction and shape of the fog
4. The bridge has been closed due to weather (severely bad wind) three separate occasions
5. And, no: there isn't someone whose full time job is to paint the bridge one end to the other and back again; i\t's touched up as needed.

I've seen it from Baker Beach - stunning.
I've seen it from the Golden Gate Bridge Welcome Center (SF Side) - stunning.
I've seen it from the Golden Gate Bridge Vista Point (Sausalito side) - stunning.
I've seen her in fog, on sunny days, under torrential rain - stunning, stunning, stunning.

Definitely one of those monoliths of architecture that feels as though it's watching over the city somehow. Don't be too cool for school like I was my first time in SF and miss it; this is definitely one of those things you *want* to see at least once!
author: Steff D.

description: I've seen the GGB from the city, Angel Island and Vista Point (all good) but you must probe deeper for alternate and more striking views. Try these three vantage points in one visit : Drive to Fort Baker and walk out on the Moore Road Pier, then go on Conzelman Road under the bridge to Battery Spencer, park, then walk to Hendrik Point. It is very windy and colder than you think but worth it. Finally, drive to the sailor statue at Vista Point, park the car and walk across the bridge. Even if you go halfway and back, it is still amazing. You must stand under the supports and look up to truly appreciate this structure. The best part? All three vantage points are free. Enjoy.
author: George W.

description:
One of the most iconic things about San Francisco is great to both drive across, or walk onto.

I love those foggy days when The bridge pokes through the fog cover and is so jaw dropping beautiful that it's just amazing. They have installed new suicide prevention nets which I guess are helpful and they don't hinder the great views.

It's a great experience overall for both the travellers that are tourists and those that are locals alike.
author: J Austyn B.

description:
It's so iconic that songs about San Francisco mention it.  The twin towers of the Golden Gate Bridge with their distinctive dark orange coloring are recognized by millions.

We drove over today on one of those warm Indian Summer days that most S.F. Bay residents relish for the chance to enjoy the outdoors ion t-shirts and shorts, instead of down jackets and long pants. 

Scores of people were out walking the span.  Their view included a cruise ship in port, sailboats galore, and a clear view of the city skyline.

An overlook is available on the Marin side.  There you can view tourists seeing that vista for the first time, or the hundredth.  It doesn't get old!
author: Lianne K.

description: This bridge is pretty cool looking it spans from one side of San Francisco bay to the other. Traffic wasn't so bad on a Sunday but it can get pretty crowded once you cross over the bridge to Vista point to get a nice view of the city. There is a lot of amazing spots to take photos of the city from Vista point once you cross the bridge also. I would recommend renting a bike and riding it across the bridge
author: Robert W.

description:
A true must in your visiting the big city. Every visit I make to the Bay Area, I have to stop and take at least 1 photo at the bridge. Unfortunately, it was overcast (again) when I went, but still can't get over how beautiful it is. I once ran a half marathon over the bridge twice for the SF Half Marathon and it was so cool to run! There are so many visitors that walk, run, and bike the bridge. There are even 2 way lanes so you know where to go. There is security/ police that frequently patrol the bridge so it is safe at all times. Use a tour when you cross because I believe there is a fee to cross the bridge, and it's ALWAYS traffic. 

We walked about a half mile, took photos, and walked back to the welcome center since we were on a time crunch. No matter where you go, there is always a good photo op of the bridge and looking out to the city.
author: Maria C.

description:
San Francisco is well-known for a lot of its iconic photo-worthy locations. The most popular destination for tourists is The Golden Gate Bridge. It's a functional bridge that is well-traveled by people entering and leaving the city. However due to its rich history, it's more than just a gateway into the big city. This is one of the most photographed bridges in the United States due to the sheer beauty that it possesses. 

You can't miss the deep orange hues of the bridge. On just the right day, you might think it's red! The dense fog in San Francisco wraps around the bridge during different times of the day. The fog adds a little bit of drama to its appearance, resulting in some fabulous photos. 

People come from around the world not only to see the bridge but also to travel across it as well. You can walk, bike, or drive across The Golden Gate Bridge. You'll have to pay a toll to drive across the bridge. If you have a FasTrak corresponder with an account, it's slightly cheaper. Otherwise, you can pay the toll online.

Some people prefer to see it from the deck of a boat. It's not uncommon to see ships and smaller boats sailing by to give people an up close view of the bridge. Either way, from land or sea, you will be in complete awe when you see the bridge.

If you stop by the visitor center, you can pick up some nifty souvenirs. Then take a little walk outside to snap your photos. You can get some breathtaking photographs from here. Also, don't limit yourself to the visitor center. There are other nearby vantage points for you to capture that perfect shot. 

I love The Golden Gate Bridge because it's absolutely beautiful. It has withstood the tests of time, maintaining its classic beauty. I've traveled across this bridge a few times and loved looking straight up when I'm in the passenger seat of  the car. Like I said, it's absolutely gorgeous! We have bridges all over the U.S. but nothing compares to The Golden Gate Bridge!
author: Michelle T.

description: Lived in the Bay Area my entire life, yet I've never walked the Golden Gate Bridge. Since it was on my bucket list, and it was a beautiful day, decided to go! It was a great walk, about 11,000 steps if you park at the bottom. The bridge is clean, and it wasn't all that crowded considering it was a beautiful day. If you don't park at the bottom and walk up, I would assume that the parking at top was insane(by the looks of it anyways). Anyways, if you are a Bay Area local, you should take the time to explore what our area has, especially if you are a tech person who never goes outside....it's really just beautiful!
author: Angel G.

description:
Every time I visit the Golden Gate Bridge, I'm reminded of its timeless mystery. It creates a kind of poetry for each visit and from my experience never two visits are alike. The International Orange color of the bridge is crucial, I think. It is at once simplistic and profound, powerful and peaceful, soaring and deep. Basically containing all the aspects of a work of art but one that serves a very functional purpose outside in the elements, among headlands, turbulent waters, gusty winds, chilly fog and the roaring of passing cars. 

I haven't seen all the great bridges of the world but something tells me none are as timeless as this masterpiece.
author: Wally B.

description:
Reviewer # 1539

A wonderful and Icon landmark. The beauty is breathtaking. I've been over this bridge many times in my lifetime via automobile and have walked it once. You can see Alcatraz from the bridge. 

The bridge is iconic in and of it'self and then add the beauty of ol mother nature and you have yourself one amazing combination. 

The fog rolls in pretty heavily oftentimes, and it's pretty cold and windy year round, so I suggest you wear layers. 

BE AWARE--! There is a toll of $7.50 (as of 7/2017). Oftentimes there IS NOT anyone at the toll gate and they will snap a photo of your car and send you a bill. You will have 10 days to pay it, once you receive it in the mail. If you're on an extended vacation, or don't check your mail often, it will go up to $37.50-- this happened to me for being one day late. 

Check out Baker Beach once you've explored the Golden Gate Bridge. It's the ocean front under the bridge!
author: Greg D.

description:
One of the world's remarkable accomplishments sits here in California. It is iconic and describes one of humanity's progress on the evolution of life and science. Although the name itself doesn't really describe it well, it describes more of the history of how California got it's own start. Get your pan/buckets because we are going to cross the bridge or rather just take tons of photos of the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco.

Located in San Francisco on the 101 Freeway, you will notice something Red/Orange, but it wasn't GOLD as you thought it would be. The Golden Gate wasn't named because of the "Gold Rush", but rather the strait where the Golden Gate crosses. Still it is a perfect name to match both the spirit of California with just the name of the geological location of the Golden Gate. The Hollywood Sign and the Golden Gate Bridge both represent CA in their Southern and North Divisions, respectively.

Parking is quite difficult here with the many various tour buses and hundreds of cars with many guests trying to get in. While the main lot is full, there is another lot just under the bridge close to the CHP/Toll Station, where you can park and walk through the tunnel. Again, there will be a lot of traffic trying enter/exit. If you are not stopping at the Visitor Center, but simply driving through prices will vary. If you have FasTrak, it will $6.75. If you don't it will be $7.75 via PhotoToll with your license plate. You'll have a nice mile drive across the bay.

The Golden Gate Bridge host millions of guests everyday and probably has one of the most photogenic backgrounds. There are trails that lead you south of the bridge as well as the infamous walk across the bridge. My wife and I had a picturesque day for my birthday weekend. We wanted to stay there together and enjoy the view on our married adventure. We saw many boats travel under the historic landmark. I have seen many bridges, but I always my home state bridge. I saw many guests take out their selfie sticks and take millions of photos as if there was no tomorrow. I saw some working out and running/hiking at the Golden Gate. Why stay in a building when you have this majestic structure as your background.

There are restrooms, but beware that there is a long line. There are two food service places to grab food/snacks after enjoying a long and eventful day at the Golden Gate Bridge. Oh yeah, you can never forget shopping at the Gift Shop. Yup, for every landmark, there is a Gift Shop. You will see a lot of memorabilia as well as Golden Gate replicas you can take home. There was some snow globes that had a fog roll in. I guess they were called Fog Globes. They were absolutely wonderful to take home since it doesn't really snow in San Francisco.

The Golden Gate Bridge is on the Top 10 of historic and monumental part of U.S. History. I know today we can build a bridge in shorter time span than the era of the Golden Gate, but the lives and many of the technological disadvantages of those time made it beyond belief. I hope one day that the Golden Gate Bridge may be open to walks above the bridge. You can feel the vehicles cross the road while you feel the cable wires and the wind push you around. Well, then again, the Golden Gate Bridge is powerful itself. I'd be on the wait list in an instant. Now I would be on top of the Golden State!

Your Yelp Story is not just a review for some, but a story for many. You write today and share a future for tomorrow. Each letter, word, sentence, and paragraph brings life, not to just the business, but to yourself. Make your story and share it today!
author: Ryan M.

description: Come on, it's the Golden Gate Bridge -- does this really need to be reviewed? I will say that it's often hard to see a clear shot of the bridge because it's foggy a lot, but if you're near the bridge when the sun is out...very nice place to relax.
author: Mike F.

description: Awesome place to hangout and watch the awesome view of the Golden Gate Bridge and the Alcatraz. Truly amazing view.
author: Jess G.

description:
Golden gate bridge, it's like a life force, you need to check the fog if you want to get a good pic. We walked over it, very easy walk and not scary.  Very windy, but that is to be expected.

If you want a view from the Vista points, the lots will most likely be full early in the morning.
author: Anne W.

description: Beautiful bridge! Wish we had a car so we could have drove over it. Next time we'll do just that. Probably check out the cafe/restaurant that's at the welcome centre.
author: Sarina S.

description:
This is one of those bridges that people can't stop taking photos of. I'm guilty of it for sure! We traveled to San Francisco on a whim trying to act like a tourist. Actually we just wanted to get out of Sacramento to get away from the triple digit heat. We got away from the heat all right! No complaints there!

Hubby wanted to walk the bridge but of course I wasn't prepared for that impulsive idea so honestly we only walked a portion of it. As we got closer to the middle that strong wind picked up literally! I read that there has been times they had to close the bridge bc of the wind. Imagine that?

At least we got some phenomenal pics bc surprisingly it wasn't foggy that day. It was wonderfully sunny. So we were pretty stoked! The Golden Gate Bridge is a glorious bridge yet magical especially if you get a chance to walk on it. Something you never forget as the views are just stunning, spectacular & unforgettable! 

I looked up to see what date they completed the Golden Gate Bridge as it took over 4 years to build. It was May 27th of 1937. The first day it was opened people walked, danced, ran & roller skated across it. The next day automobile traffic was then started. Wow it had just celebrated its 80th birthday. Cool! 

Hope you all get a sunshiny day too like us! Just check the weather report beforehand bc that marine layer can sock in & spoil your pics. Plus be prepared for crowds as tourists all want to do the same thing. Get that perfect selfie pic! Not the unmentionable (suicide) jumping.

On a lighter note know it for being one of the seven wonders of the modern world! Go see it, take your selfie pics & enjoy! I know we did! Finally!
author: Karen K.

description:
Look at what God allowed man to do!

Man, what a wonder.  There should be a list of "man made wonders of the world".  This bridge tops those in New York.  The red majesty against the ever-present fog is a sight to see.  SF did it right when they put parks on both sides of the bridge for pictures.  The fact that you can walk this bridge is a plus.
author: Dev R.

description: I always wonder why people get excited exploring this bridge until I experienced it myself. By just staring from the bridge to capture the beautiful sunset & swayed by a cool wind gives you an instant peace & joy. Parking is quite a challenge though with $8 toll fee.
author: Terr M.

description: Epic! Must see if visiting SF. Probably the most famous bridge in the world. Great views different angles in the surrounding area. You can actually walk on to the bridge. However out is noisy due to the road noise and wind but it is quiet spectacular to do so.
author: Andrew P.

description:
Ok, so how does one rate or review a bridge?
Let's see here.

1 star because it didn't fall down 
1 star because the paint was all nice and fresh red.
1 star because of the structure engineering of this thing!
1 star for having a large foot traffic area.
1 star for having photo opportunities sports

Well, there you go 5 stars! It really is pretty amazing driving across the bridge. I have seen it on TV before but you really don't get a scope of how big it really is. A lot of design was really put into it, just to make sure it was functional and looked amazing. The giant cables appear to vanish in the sky. It was very cloudy this day and made for a view that just felt epic because you could not see the top. It appeared to go so high into the clouds. 

If you ever get the chance to cross this bridge, Just do it! Turn left and go up the hill for some really great views! Also a really nice hike can be found up there.

Here is a good tip, the toll isn $4.75 but only when you are traveling north. South side does not have a toll.
author: Mike D.

description:
Breathtaking! It's definitely amazing how immense this bridge is! There are many lookout points and plenty of places where you can take pictures. 

There are two restaurants and a souvenir shop at the bottom by the parking lot. Parking is not free but it is very cheap. Tons of tourists and many bicyclists trying to get around you. It can be a little hectic. 

Beautiful bridge and so worth the trip!!!
author: Christa M.

description:
Every time, I'm home in California, I drive over this bridge at least twice, to visit and then return from the visit with my in-laws. And every time, I'm in awe. It's truly a special bridge. 

For me, it's best on a clear day when you can see out to the Farralons, Alcatraz, and to the other SF bridge, The Bay Bridge. But it also nice when Karl the Fog is around, with his swirling misty air and he's usually around. 

It's also amazing to walk. On a clear day, the views of San Francisco from the bridge is breathtaking. Though whether it's clear or foggy, it is usually windy. You have to be really lucky not get the wind. 

If you're feeling really adventurous, you can walk from SF all the way to Sausalito across the Bridge and then take a ferry back into city. Most people take a car or a tour bus to the viewing spot on the Sausalito side and just walk a small section. 

Regardless, it's a SF icon. If you're in SF, you must head there to at least that the requisite picture.
author: Corissa L.

description:
Still good. No complaints.

5/5
author: Joshua M.

description: Who doesn't love the golden gate!? Come check it out but check out the visitor center don't drive and take pics while on the bridge and cause an accident lol.
author: Addison M.

description:
Very disappointing. Sad.

This "bridge" was neither golden nor a gate. I can understand why some people might find it useful for commuting, however it is just not for me. In the future I will choose to swim across the bay.
author: Colby W.

description:
Definitely run this bridge if you get the chance
My husband didn't think I could but guess what it's so easy
It looks much bigger on tv. 

I like the view on land, there's some weird people on this bridge though
But definitely if you can 
Put on your sneakers and run!
author: Marissa Z.

description:
It was an awesome experience to go with family and friends. 
There are many ways to get there and have views. Loved the view from the top.
author: Shahid ..

description:
As with other great bridges around the world, I recommend seeing it in every way you can.  

For the Golden Gate Bridge, this means seeing it in the area around the Golden Gate Welcome Center; walking across; driving across (you'll pay a insane toll); taking a Golden Gate Bay Cruise (which goes under the bridge); Fort Point (a great under-the-bridge view without the RCHP song vibe); China Beach; Crissy Field (great wide shot); Baker Beach (the famed rock view right below it); Land's End (cool, farther off view); Coit Tower (the bridge and the city); and the famed up-on-the-hill view from Battery Spencer.   If you can dedicate a bay to the bridge, you can do all of it.  

I most recently went through the visitor's center. A lot of good history, but very touristy and parking is limited. But you forget all that when you see the view!
author: Drew B.

description:
BEAUTIFUL!

I was a student at USF for four years in San Francisco and I was lucky enough to enjoy this beautiful landmark whenever I pleased!

I ran the San Francisco Half marathon & the Rock n Roll Half Marathon both which run across the entire length of the bridge! So if that is one of you goals make sure to sign up for one of these half-marathons.

You can also get to the bridge via the muni which I highly recommend because parking is very limited and utter chaos due to high amounts of tourists!

If you are not used to San Francisco weather or the fog I would recommend to come in layers! Even when the sun is out the wind coming of the bay can be freezing cold!

There are also a few trails you can follow on foot or on a bike which you can rent. They also lead you to Crissy Fields.

When walking around be aware of cyclists!
author: Nathalie M.

description: We walked it.  It's much higher than you expect.  It's bouncier than you expect, especially when you're away from the towers.  It's like walking on a moderate earthquake.  It's pretty and an experience I'll never forget.
author: Jim P.

description:
The spectacular alone is magical. The history, the magic, the craftsmanship. 

Walking up on the bridge in all its majesty is trumped only by walking across. I'm not a big fan of heights and this is up there so my legs were shaking and so was the bridge. It was windy!!! A few other friends were also a big spooked by the edge too, so stand a bit away from it once you pass the gating. 

If you venture across by foot, stay to the right no matter what direction you're going. Nobody likes a horn, but the and left side is a commuter lane for those transporting themselves by bike. Steer clear. 

No matter what your level of fear, take the bull by the horns and make the trek. You're literally walking across history and it's totally worth it.
author: Taylor S.

description: This is probably my favorite bridge in California. You know why? Just look at this! Absolutely perfect construction which you can watch in a lot of movies and tv shows. There are many amazing view points for your photos. We paid about 7 dollars for one-way-Road along this bridge. Next time I want to have a walk by my small mousy foots through it :)
author: Mandy L.

description:
