It is sometimes hard to review iconic landmarks such as the GGB. They have a lot of hype and can sometimes be disappointing. The Golden Gate Bridge was not that way. When you think about the history and time period this bridge was built, it is incredibly astonishing. I was blown away by how few days out of the year the people of SF can actually see the bridge. The fog covers it up the rest of the time. The second time I went, I couldn't even see the towers from the beginning of the bridge. Between that and the extreme waters and temperatures, I am even more in awe of what it took to build this amazing structure.

I won't give away all the facts so you have some for this tourist spot. But I was also amazed to learn that they are constantly going from one end to the other with red paint making sure it keeps that beautiful color we all know. I was also curious to know just how big it really was after seeing it in the pictures. But only walking to the first tower and staring up shows just how massive it is. Although it is touristy and we have all seen the pictures, this is a must visit for a trip to San Francisco.
author: Will B.

description: One of the seven civil engineering wonders of the world, the Golden Gate Bridge never fails to impress me even after nearly fifty years since the first time I gazed upon its magnificence. It's awesome.
author: Robin S.

description:
Icon of our mist city!!

Still obsessed about finding different angles of this bridge.. it's always beautiful!

Especially if you are driving on a convertible with your roof off! Weather permitting
author: Deebs M.

description:
Ah, one of the iconic landmarks of the Bay area. I had been to SF before, but it was years ago. We had seen the Golden Gate Bridge on numerous occasions while driving by (to other destinations), but I only recently got to walk across.
 
I was in town visiting a friend, and we had a jam-packed Saturday filled with activities - mostly touristy ones, but hey, it was okay because SF is one of those cities I hadn't really spent that much time in before. So we actually took some time to Uber closer to the Golden Gate Bridge and to walk across.
 
I had no idea how expansive the bridge truly was until our Uber pulled up closer. We first went to the Visitor Center/office to browse a little, and then we walked about halfway across the bridge and returned back. Thank goodness it wasn't a windy day! There were tons of others walking across the scenic bridge for the views, but there were actually a lot of joggers there as well who went for exercise. It felt really surreal to walk across, even if we didn't go the entire distance.

What I also really liked is that there are many other side paths in the park so you can explore them and get good shots of the Golden Gate Bridge in the background - they may turn out quite differently from that signature tourist picture, thanks to the different angles. I got some pretty cool shots from the park paths we were on. After visiting the bridge, we were able to continue walking down one of the paths - and it was really neat. It took us past Crissy Fields and continued onto Ghirardelli Square and Fisherman's Wharf, which is ultimately where we wanted to end up for dinner. The only reason why we didn't walk all the way across the bridge was because we knew we had a long trek ahead of us to get to Fisherman's Wharf and the other sights on our agenda. One day, I still want to walk across the entire thing! On a clear day, the views are gorgeous and you can get nice, panoramic shots of the city.
author: Kelli S.

description:
DD calls it the Golden State Bridge.  Why is it called the Golden Gate Bridge instead of the Golden State Bridge? Being that it's not gold, the latter seems to make more sense.  Was it once adorned in golden hues, but weathered to a rusty-red? After decades of wanting to come here, I finally made it and aside from the "Please don't fall over, because you can't swim" thoughts, this was pretty much what I was thinking the entire time.  But as the Bard would likely say, a bridge by any other name... 

So I ignored the name and I tried to ignore the weight of the crisis hotline posting (I'm glad it's there, but these things are heavy for an empath) and focused on celebrating the fact that, through all the drama it took to make it, we were there! Not only were we there, it was a clear and beautiful, picture-perfect day.  Glazing upon this stoic beauty brought many emotions. It truly is a beautiful piece of work.  We were pressed for time so we didn't get to walk across the bridge. That means I'll need to return to SFO soon to complete that mission.
author: Tigra C.

description:
Maybe I'm a little salty, but I'm not that impressed with the bridge. It's huge, but that's about it. It's constantly foggy & windy, & it's a huge tourist trap. 

It's definitely something you should see at least once, maybe even walk across. But it's just a bridge lol.
author: Daniel M.

description: Great! We were able to get many views while visiting the welcome center area. There is not a ton of parking and we came on a week day. I cannot imagine the weekends! The bridge is an awesome landmark and it really sets the stage for San Francisco viewing!
author: Rebecca D.

description: This was my first time walking on the bridge and the views did not dissapoint. It was cold and windy so make sure you dress warm! The pull off section to view has restrooms and incredible views! Parking was very easy and free.
author: Erin B.

description:
My wife's first time ever seeing the GG in person. She absolutely loved the views!
Can't wait to come back so we can walk it.
author: James F.

description:
A great landmark to see when you visit San Francisco!

I got a chance to see the Golden Gate Bridge on top of a tour bus several times while visiting San Francisco. The view of the Bay Area from the bridge is beautiful and is definitely one of the better places to spend your time when you visit here. Our bus stopped on the opposite side of the Bridge towards Sausalito where we got a chance to get out and snap some great pics. 

If I had more time in San Francisco I would've biked across the bridge.
author: Edmund L.

description: Iconic and a must visit. We walked over and it was a busy and windy day but we still enjoyed walking along the bridge, would love to come back on another trip and bike all the way across and do some exploring on the other side.
author: Miranda R.

description:
The first time I passed through the toll plaza it was about a buck fifty, riding with my family to the city, those days have come and gone, a different time and millennium - it's now life in the fast lane. 

Automatic drive thru, don't stop, slow roll through as the camera snaps a shot of your license plate or scans your electronic pass. Either have Fasttrac or by the plate and a card on file with them, and they digitally charge your account 7 bucks - no more human interaction. 

No human toll takers, those days are gone - just keep moving and don't stop - then jockey for position to get to the lane you need for your particular destination. Coming or going it's all the same, for better or worse - it's called progress. 

Still iconic and always open, it is what it is - now just another annoyance in your travels as you move through the flashing green light open lane. 

3 Stars - it is what it is and serves its purpose 

00465
author: Ray F.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is an iconic national landmark! It was my first time visiting San Francisco so this was a must-see. After 3 failed attempts the fog fiiiinally cooperated with us and I was able to actually see the famous 4,200-ft red suspension bridge before leaving Fog City on July 4th. A sunny day ON the Fourth of July?! God Bless America! I couldn't imagine a  better way to celebrate America; however, the struggle to capture the moment is real. When you aren't battling the moody weather and fog hiding the bridge from view, then you will be battling all of the other tourists trying to nab a parking spot before you. Of course, there are other ways to experience the Golden Gate Bridge like walking, biking, or driving across. But my goal was to be that cliché touristy girl who poses for an instagram-worthy photo with the bridge in the background.

Parking tips: Drive up Conzelman Road to find parking on the side of the road. There are several parking spaces available but they fill up quickly. Cars are allowed to park along the hillside but please follow posted signage. Patience is a virtue. If you reach the roundabout continue driving up to the left side of the road where there is more parking possibly available. Worst case scenario would be driving back down the hill to wait and see if anyone is leaving yet.  

Best photo op locations: Either walk down to Kirby Cove for a chance to maybe swing (if it's still there) and get the ultimate picture OR settle for walking to the view point/vista point. I recommend snapping a pic above Battery Spencer for the more daring-wind-loving-types. 

No matter how far away you parked, how long your walk is to the desired photo op spot, or how long until other people are out of your perfect shot, it will be a great feat to look back on the day you could see more than fog out in the distance.
author: Jennifer G.

description: Awesome!   The walk across was surprisingly easy.  Biking looking a bit hazardous with all the walkers.  We lucked out and had Gorgeous weather.
author: Kelly W.

description: Meh, its an ok bridge. Its red when its called the GOLDEN gate bridge
author: Carson W.

description: Love it!  Pictures don't do it justice. If you are in San Francisco, go see it. It is a beautiful site to see. We were lucky to have awesome weather and saw it from the old military base nearby. It is a peaceful place to be and has the tranquility that lets you get lost in your thoughts. If you have your walking legs with you, you can walk across it...
author: Brian M.

description: Another awesome way to view the Golden Gate Bridge is from Baker Beach. Walk across the beach to the far end and over the rocks and you'll be right underneath it.
author: Taido N.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge earns a five star review. 

Food: Incredible, as you are in charge of the picnic you'll be bringing with you. Be sure to pack biodegradable party ware (Mother Earth thanks you,) a blanket you're willing to sacrifice to the wind, and something warm in a thermos is advisable. 

Service: Self-serve mostly. Self-parking, when you find something as both the SF side and Marin side can get full rather quickly as the day wears on. Self-guided walking tour across the span, and stick to the Eastern side as that's the only side humans are allowed to walk on. 

Cost: Northbound - Free! Cars (Southbound only)
$7.50 (Pay by plate), $6.50 (FasTrak), $4.50 (carpools during peak hours, FasTrak only). 

Overall: An experience that's not to be missed. She's gorgeous, and so is the view surrounding her. As with any tourist spot anywhere in the world, be mindful of your surroundings, and don't leave valuables or anything enticing in the car. Walk the span, and enjoy it. Pray that Karl The Fog takes a day off, but plan for the wind regardless. Don't litter, or scratch her up with your initials inside a heart because you feel you have that right as a tourist. You don't. Take pictures - panos, selfies, portraits - and treat her like the bridge she is. Unique.
author: Shirley B.

description:
AMAZING! Great to visit definitely worth your time!
Cool to see and a memory that none in your party will soon forget. The view is amazing and if you go when it's a little foggy it is breathtaking!
author: Gabrielle A.

description:
- Visiting or local the Bay area all the while in search of a way to occupy 2.5 - 3 hours of your time?

BOEY, DO I HAVE JUST THE PLACE FOR YOU!

- Got a thing for 24K's? ...While San Francisco may be "home of the golden shower", perhaps you'd rather just engage in something a bit more kid friendly with Spring Break just around the corner.

PACK A SACK LUNCH FOR YOUR ANKLE BITERS & PRE-TEENS! This is one of those occasions whereas "the early bird gets the worm" and leaving one hour too late could add another TWO hours onto your time spent "sitting".

- Tired of viewing knock off GGB art at Target and Wally World?

PACK YOUR CAMERAS AND/OR CHARGE YOUR CELLIES!!! There's no substitute for the REAL THING! Take your own pix' and spruce up your living room without giving someone else's artwork the credit.

Sidebar: Don't go knocking golden showers til' you've tried it em' (joking!).

Ladies and gents-, I present to you:

THE GOLDEN GATE BRIDGE!!!!!!

Sannie' Frannie's rust colored calling card to the world, linking San Francisco to Marin County ...... ONE TOLL AT A TIME. 
__________________________________

While I've no clue exactly where this bridge ranks on the "National Wonders of the World" hierarchy, by far does it grace the "to do" list of most visiting this Manhattan-esque seaside town and you'd be crazy not to wake up with the roosters just to jot a check mark next to it upon your note pad at the end of your day.

Having survived the drive across and back (5-6 miles total), by far can I attest towards this being something you do ONCE - simply to rid your system of it in order to brag to friends and family on how cultured you are later on.

* The cascading fog rolling in directly over blue hued water is by far enough to conjure everyone's innermost romantic. --- Try streaming jazz on Pandora while en route; it's actually quite amorous.

* The rapid decrease in temps as sunny skies make way for wind and haze render one's trip all the more perfect an opportunity​ to further embrace the ambiance. --- Pack a parka and some hot cocoa. For the most part, you can do so year round.

* While there are 6 lanes for traveling; 3 coming and another 3 going - know in advance that it's probably best you bike ride out. --- Gridlock is typically so severe that a one way trip takes over an hour and regrettably, .... swimming back does not qualify as an option.

Upon ridding your system of "Frisco Fever" (see what I did there? I punned disco fever..... lol), you'll be all the more inept to recap on the epic beauty you've just laid eyes upon for years to come.

FINALLY.....

 As a parting gift, plan in advance to receive a "Notice of Violation" within the mail as your VIN number and/or car tags are traced for failure to remit payment of the unposted/obstructed $7-9.00 toll simply to re-enter the city of San Francisco.

(sighs.....)

Just like jalapenos. This town gets ya' coming AND going!
author: Kenny G.

description: People might say "what's special about a bridge?" But there is something magical about the Golden Gate Bridge. On a clear and warm day, I could sit near the water for hours. I would recommend taking the trail/stairs down for a better view. I know some people might think it's a long hike or unsure of where the trail goes but it goes right to the shoreline. There's better view points on the trail where you can get awesome pictures.
author: Bianca J.

description:
This is obviously one of the most iconic landmarks in the state of California and just another of a million reasons why San Francisco is the best city in the existence of the universe. I very much enjoy running across the bridge for the sights, the exercise, and just the fact that anyone can!

On a dark note, it's so beautiful that more than 1,500 people have jumped off this bridge. There are crisis phones scattered around the bridge. Life is precious.

On a positive note, this 1.7 mile-long suspension bridge is a marvel of engineering and has been declared one of the Wonders of the Modern World by the American Society of Civil Engineers. Humans are interesting.

Anyway, SF is king!
author: Marlon T.

description: Great part of American history, stunning on the rare blue sky day here in San Francisco.
author: Lovely L.

description:
No way you can come to San Fran (esp for the first time ) and not visit the Golden Gate Bridge.  It was a lot of people on the bridge (on a Saturday afternoon day).  The span is amazing.  You can see downtown San Francisco, Alcatraz  and the Bay Bridge in the distance.  The bridge has a sidewalk on each side of the road.  Don't get me wrong, it is nice but seven wonder of the world - why? Because of it's color.  Nonetheless.  a very nice tourist trap.

Grade: A
author: Steve B.

description:
This place is a must-see when visiting the San Francisco area. Access to this bridge requires a drive through the norther portion of downtown SF. From there, it is a straight drive north, through the bridge, and into Marin County on the other side. There are stops on either end of the bridge, and you can bike and walk across from these stops.
The bridge is very picturesque, and is a major landmark in this NorCal city. The best views of this bridge are seen from Battery Spencer.
It helps to have FastPass when driving through the Golden Gate Bridge, or any other bridge in SF.
Come see this great landmark for yourself!
author: William G.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is one of those iconic US Landmarks that you must see in person.  I have been here before..but this the there was no 'fog' so I was able to enjoy it so much more this trip.

Hearing the history of the bridge & how it got it's name & color helped me enjoy it much more (Google It...Lol)

Of course I took a few pics & enjoyed the view of the bay.
author: Shane J.

description:
#21 of 2017

Beautiful landmark of San Francisco! Must see! My boyfriend and I came here and loved the scenery and the views. It's definitely cold but great to walk among and enjoy the views.
author: Bijou N.

description: I was in San Francisco years ago, and the image of seeing the Golden Gate Bridge is still etched in my mind. It is not only one of America's most iconic landmarks, but people around the world flock to SF to see this gem.
author: Matthew H.

description: Literally breathtaking. I've never seen anything quite like this bridge anywhere else in the world. It is otherworldly gorgeous. I can't wait to bring my family to San Fran for a visit to see this in person. TV, movies and photographs don't quite do it justice. I imagine that locals take it for granted, but it truly is amazing. We didn't have a chance to walk the bridge on our recent visit, but we did drive over it a few times and take pictures from another area. It is truly phenomenal.
author: Kari C.

description: Such a beautiful and history-filled walk to take. It is great if you can avoid the crowds, but the views are spectacular nonetheless.
author: David V.

description: Great day to visit. We got here by bus and it was very easy got dropped off right in the parking lot of the Golden Gate Bridge. We wanted to rent bikes to ride across but could not find a place here. We got to take a bunch of photos. Walked about half of the bridge and went back. The bridge is very long. It is also very high. Very cool walking on this giant structure. While walking it split in two for going and returning walkers as well as bikes. Always have to be aware of bikes to avoid getting run over by one. No bathrooms on the bridge so go before you start walking. Iconic redish orange bridge. Free to walk on it.
author: Estefania C.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is one of San Francisco's most iconic and enduring landmarks. Add it to your list of must-see attractions - but for the best views, allow an extra 1-2 hours to drive across to the Marin side and view the bridge from the cliffs overlooking the historic gun emplacements.

Remember, California's coastal weather is COLD in summer, MILD in winter, WARM in spring and fall! Layers, my man.
author: John H.

description:
This is another stop in San Francisco that is definitely a must see. We found a good spot to park and take pictures with the kids. The little one forced us to take many pictures of her in front of the Bridge so she could show her dad later lol.

Depending on what time of the year you come it can be very cold, so make sure to come prepared especially with kids. 

It sometimes can be difficult trying to find spots to park around here with traffic so watch out and watch out for pedestrians. Some people really don't pay attention. Also driving here at night in the rain, oh man no bueno. That happened to us a couple of years ago and it was pretty bad. Just prepare yourself, but the visit is worth it.
author: Graciela P.

description: The Golden Gate Bridge is the must stop landmark to visit and to see in San Francisco. It is one of the most popular photographed bridge in the world. My family and I visited this beautiful bridge several times when I was a kid. This time I got the chance to visit San Francisco with my boy friend. It was his first time and he loved it! I walked the 4,200 feet long bridge with my family when I was a kid and one day I hope that I get to walk the bridge with my boy friend as well. Hopefully next time when we come back! I love the fact that you can also go to different hot spots to take photos and to view the Golden Gate Bridge such as Fort Point and The Presidio Park. Fun trails to hike as well if you would like to go exploring!
author: Natasha N.

description:
Who doesn't know the look of the picturesque Golden Gate Bridge.  It photographs beautifully, it is an iconic California structure and being on the bridge and being able to take pictures from one of the beaches in the city just doesn't do it justice.  It is absolutely beautiful.  The landscape around the bridge is beautiful and driving across, you can see such beautiful views.  It is one of the nicest bridges I have been over and it really lives up to the hype. I am so glad I got to drive over the bridge multiple times.

I never saw a sign for a charge going over the bridge but my rental agency ended up charging about 9 dollars each time I went across.
author: Angela D.

description:
2017 is HAPPY 80th ANNIVERSARY Golden Gate Bridge!!!  Let's WALK IT to celebrate!  Construction began 1933 and opened in 1937.  80 years later, this architectural marvel has endured many things yet still stands strong!  Okay first things first... Why is it called "Golden???"  Cuz it sure don't LOOK golden!  Well turns out this opening that the Golden Gate Bridge spans to the San Fransisco Bay is a strait and it was dubbed Chrysopolae (Latin for Golden Gate) Strait by California Explorer John C. Fremont because it reminded him of a harbor in Istanbul (or at the time Byzantium) called Chrysoceras (Golden Horn). So definitely no golden hue is seen, it looks red, yet it's color is not even called "red," it's actually the color "International Orange."  Well there you go!  Never "completed," it is continually being modified to strengthen its inner workings so we can continually enjoy its existence. 

To visit this world renown masterpiece, it's certainly crazy during the summer.  First of all there is a dense fog you have to contend with all morning that blankets the top of the 2 towers and kaboshes any opportunities for decent pics to show off.  There's a prime time for pics and it's around 1p-6p IF you're lucky.  How do you park your car because it is insanely busy with minimal parking?!!?  Well you can Uber, Lyft, use one of those hop on/hop off tours, or have family drop you off and wait around for you. We actually found a spot in the employee parking on the West side of the bridge for $5. Yay!

So my family of 5 with 3 kids actually WALKED back and forth across entire 1.7 mile length of the Golden Gate Bridge.  YUP!!!  We were here on a Sunday so the nice thing about the weekends is that no bikes are allowed on East side walkway.  One less thing to worry about if you have kids.  With a leisure stroll it took 1hr 30 min to go south to north end because we're Asian and take hella pics. Nyahh!  Then going back with a same pace took about 40 minutes to return with minimal pics taken but still enjoying the sites.  Even had a whale siting!  So a good 4 hours to spend to fully explore the bridge, including traffic to deal with entering the area.  Fun times.  Kids didn't complain about being tired at all.  Definitely dress to be prepared for cold wind gusts. ;)

EASY RECOMMENDATION :)
author: Dave A.

description: What's not to like about this landmark?  There is a nice parking and viewing area just across the bridge in Marin County.  Lots of parking and public bathrooms.  On the SF side there are a few smaller but free parking places at the old battlements.  If you want to, you can walk all the way across the bridge.
author: Scooter B.

description:
Great experience!

After a little over 37 years living in the Great State of California and driving across the Golden Gate Bridge multiple times I can say that I've finally crossed the bridge ON FOOT and on Christmas Day. Although it was a cold and very windy day in San Francisco it was a clear afternoon and no layer of fog in sight! Parking was horrendous and we drove somewhere and found parking at the Presidio. We entered the bridge from the North end where the Welcome Center is located. The beginning part of the bridge had safety wire fencing and I love it when I see lovelocks on bridges. Took a few photos of them. That extra safety wire fencing does not cover the whole bridge, though, and it is pretty scary looking down.

We had a clear view of the suspension bridge from one end to the other with a nice panoramic view of the City, Alcatraz Island and even the Red and White Fleet sailing across the Pacific Ocean. Walked past the first tower then the second tower until we reached the Sausalito side. We were not the only ones who braved the cold, we were with plenty of other tourists, young and old, and folks on their bicycles. Beautiful views including witnessing the sun set during our stroll... we were still on the bridge when we heard of George Michael's passing. I loved the 80's and he was totally one of the icons during that generation. So sad.

Overall great first time experience. Will do it again on a warmer day in San Francisco. Did you know that Golden Gate is the bridge with the highest number of suicides in the world? About every two weeks, one person jumps off the bridge. The east side, looking at the city, is more popular for committing suicide. Imagine the ghost stories... 

Review #0631 (and 1,475th review for the business)
author: May A.

description: We came on a very windy day the scenery was so beautiful the bridge was a lot bigger than we expected we enjoyed our time by the bridge taking photos.
author: NelIna O.

description: What more is there to say?  It's the best bridge in the world.  The world!  Most beautiful construction, most beautiful views. Whether you're on it, going under it, walking, or biking, it doesn't get much more awe-inspiring than this. Daylight, night time, it's all wonderful. Must-do for visiting relatives. Walk across it--walk halfway across it and back. Hang out at Fort Point and imagine you see Jimmy Stewart and Kim Novak in Vertigo there.
author: Kati P.

description: The Golden Gate Bridge is a must when in San Francisco. It's even more beautiful than in the pictures.
author: Alan H.

description:
One of the most memorable experiences of my life, just getting here with public transportation was such an awesome adventure, we got to drive through a lot of cool streets with incredible architecture and beautiful sights. 

The bus dropped us off at the welcome center, from there you can take a short hike up to the bridge, they have a walking trail and a bike lane, five minutes of walking gets you up to the bridge, I walked about half way through the bridge, Even though we went in July on a sunny day it was still pretty windy and a bit cold up there so bring sweaters

So many picture perfect views of the city and its landscapes. Can't wait to go back with more friends and family.
author: Tony D.

description:
If you're in San Fran then this is one of the typical spots you'd hit up. And no, the gate is not gold. Lol. Just thought I'd put that in there since my friend said a lot of people expects it to be gold. 

Park at the souvenir store (or down the road at the small lot) and there will be a trail sign across the road from the store. You will arrive at the welcome center/gift shop. There will be plaques and information tidbits for you to read about. The facts will provide an understanding and insight as to why this is a historic landmark. 

You can walk across the bridge and say that you were on it; there was also a walkway under the bridge as well.
author: Andrea M.

description:
What an absolutely beautiful experience. 
I love San Francisco so much, from the crazy beautiful city, to the transportation, to the amazing Chinese food, to the gross, sad crack heads. 
This city has so much to offer. 
But now to write about the bridge - not gonna lie I did not walk across much of it. 
I came here what seems to be just a few years ago and don't remember the ugly chained gate that has been placed to reduce the harm provide a little extra safety (also pretty sure to stop idiots trying to take selfies on the original barricade). 

Regardless, absolutely nothing could ruin this little historic national park. 
I almost wish I was a local so I could do a  daily walk here or go on a cheap date here or maybe just come and think about life overlooking the calm bay. 

I can't wait to go back.
author: Steve S.

description: Love this place!!! If you go to the good lookout spots you'll get excellent pictures and it's not as crowded.
author: Norma G.

description: Gotta do this once in a lifetime. I love walking the Brooklyn Bridge but the Golden Gate is a whole different amazing experience.  Definitely worth putting up with the wind is worth it. The views are amazing, of course.  Pick a really clear blue sky day and go!
author: Alexandra C.

description:
I am joining in on the five star reviews!

Drive it, walk it, bike (try all three) and enjoy the beautiful views of the Bay Area! If you are lucky, a cargo boat will be traveling under the bridge when you are walking on it and you will see how perfectly they have to time that passage!

As a Bay Area native, I cannot believe it took me this long to finally walk the bridge with my husband (I know I look young so how long could I have possibly lived here, right? :) 

The side where people walk gives perfect view of SF. On a clear day, you can see the Bay Bridge and even the Dumbarton if you squint. People are generally aware of one another and polite about letting you pass if you are walking faster than them. We did not walk the other side as it looked like it was just for bikers. Not sure if that was because of Memorial Day weekend or if that is a regular thing. It was nice not having to worry about maneuvering around bikers though.

There are nice photo op points on each side so you can get some great shots for the holiday photo and be the envy of the rest of your family. I highly recommend a nice saunter across the bridge with the significant other and taking some time to enjoy the view, the pics and the company.
author: Kathleen A.

description:
There's something really great about this bridge that is so iconic of San Fran. It might sound crazy, but I've been wanting to get a view of this bridge for quite some time now. I was so excited to book a flight to San Fran and this was one of the first places I've bookmarked.

The bridge itself is massive. I really want to go onto the other side next time.
author: Anh L.

description:
VIEWS....VIEWS....AND MORE VIEWS!!!

This historical orangish glowing wonder known as the Golden Gate Bridge stands 746 ft tall with breathtaking beauty. 
Constructed and built in the thirties, the Golden Gate Bridge is an attraction for MILLIONS of people that come from all over the world. 
San Francisco is so unique and diverse. And the bridge gives added character to the Bay Area.
Living in the North Bay, there is just something about when you pop out of that Robin Williams tunnel as you head south. And as you pop out of the tunnel, "POOF" the bridge and a beautiful view of the city magically appear. There is nothing quite like it. And for me, never gets old. 

I would however, would like to walk across it again. Its been a minute since ive done that. Maybe on a monday when it is less crowded?
author: Stephanie A.

description: Breathtaking views. If you take a trip to SF this is one sight you need to check out.
author: Samuel S.

description:
Awesome views!

Well worth a visit, awesome views.
We E biked across to the village the other side, just remember 100's of others are doing the same! when arriving at the other side of the bridge there are steps alongside (not very well signposted - easy to miss) with an area to run the bike down alongside the steps, instead of taking the road!
author: Rain B.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is one of the Top Ten Engineering Wonders of the World!

It's a popular tourist attraction and a major landmark!  Many people identify it with the City of San Francisco!  It's one of the most photographed bridges in the world!

After a few years of construction and many fatalities, it opened on May 27, 1937.  It is 4,200 feet long and 220 feet tall.

If you cross it by automobile, get ready to pay a toll!  You'll get a bill in the mail if you don't have the automated charging system attached to your car!  Don't worry - they will find you!

So, just drive slowly as you near it so you can pull to the side at one of the parks.  Then snap away with all of the other sight seers!
author: Nadine C.

description:
A visit to San Francisco cannot be complete without seeing one of the modern wonders of the world - Golden Gate Bridge. Chances of the bridge being enveloped by fog is higher in the afternoon. It can be a clear and bright sunny day but once the winds start up around late afternoon, one can see the fog rolling in from the Pacific Ocean across the bridge. Count your blessings if the day is clear and crisp. There is a $6 toll to cross the bridge in your car when entering San Francisco from Sausalito. 

Just across the bridge is a vista point on your right which is usually blocked off on the weekends to control traffic and crowds. One can also take the first exit just after vista point, make a U turn at the stop sign, go under the freeway, then turn sharp right to drive up the hill to get some fantastic pictures of the bridge and the city from a higher elevation. Parking is free but finding an open spot can be challenging on weekends. But the view from there is worth the drive up. While crossing the bridge, if you are in luck, you may be able to see this huge zipper machine which moves the center divider like a zipper to the left or right to provide an extra lane for peak hour traffic. If you have 2 hours to spare you can even walk across the bridge and back. Do take a jacket and water as well as sun tan!
author: Raj G.

description:
Bigger In Real Life!
The Golden Gate Bridge is a staple landmark for the state of California. It is truly a beautiful piece of architecture. SF often gets very foggy so just be aware that if the fog is in, you may not be able to see the entire bridge. 

Traveler Tip #1: Check the forecast. Depending on your photography style, I'd make sure the weather is matching that type of photo you are looking to get. 

Traveler Tip #2: SF gets a brisk breeze that often runs through so bring a jacket and warm clothes. 

I'm a fellow traveler so I appreciate when other people have given me tips/recommendations while in a new city. If this information is helpful, please let me know by hitting the like button. Even if this review helps only one traveler then it's worth it to know I'm contributing towards making someone's experience better, giving to the global community, and paying it forward. Safe Travels!
author: Neo N.

description:
Review #500! Whoop-woo! 
So, this historic and iconic landmark is definitive a heavily visited tourist hot spot, but with good reason. This red bridge is a master of engineering innovation and is one of the hallmarks of San Francisco. 
Having driven over it too many times to count, it was last weekend we decided to walk across. Parking in one of the many dirt lots (free), we walked over to the walking path that wraps around and up to the pedestrian walkway. Breezy and much, much cooler than down on the walk path, even on this spectacular sun-drenched say so rare in SF, it was still sub-glacial up on the bridge. Wear appropriate clothing! 
Walking across is free and a great experience, wear your jacket and earmuffs, but it's a fun little outing.
author: Danielle G.

description: Such an iconic place!! Whether it's sunny or foggy this THE place to be. It's so breathtaking and romantic I adore this place;) I also recommend cruises at night by the bridge. You will enjoy sunning views!!!
author: Sophie B.

description: This past weekend was my first visit to SF so walking down the Golden Gate Bridge was #1 on my list. As a kid growing up on Full House, I always wanted to visit the bridge and painted ladies. This part of my trip did not disappoint and was hands down, my favorite memory of this vacation. Unfortunately, my phone decided to die right when i reached Vista point (great view point and place to take pictures), but this just gave me more of an opportunity to enjoy the moment. We got here around 4 PM and it took us a good hour or so to walk it with picture stops (3.5 miles). If you're going to stop a bunch of times and take pictures, you can spend a good couple of hours here. It's a beautiful and enjoyable walk. Luckily, it was not too windy/chilly/ or foggy out. However, the transportation was a nightmare. We did not want to deal with parking so we took the Muni. Google Maps estimated it'd be a 20 minute drive from our hotel but with all the crazy traffic and merging, it took over an hour to get here! It was worth it but it's good to keep in mind that SF traffic, especially around this area, is bonkers. The worst part was probably leaving--people are stealing taxis, Uber drives are pissed off at incorrectly pinned locations, buses are not on time, and just overall utter chaos. It took us wayyyy too long to get home but still this trip was 100% worth it. Just be sure to plan accordingly considering the transportation difficulties.
author: Maysa M.

description: How can you not like the Golden Gate Bridge?! From what I heard it's the second most visited and photographed attraction in the WORLD (second to the Eiffel Tower)!!! It's so beautiful on both sunny and gloomy days.  I love visiting here and taking in the air and watching what's in the water surrounding it.  It's nice seeing all the ways people cross this bridge whether it be by car, on foot, or on bikes, etc.  There are different ways you can enter, park, and take in the view, some you'll have to pay, others you won't have to.  It's definitely worth the hassle and traffic to get close by!
author: Anna L.

description:
The Gold Gate Bridge is a historic iconic landmark in SF.  It is a widely visited attraction that is featured in many motion pictures.  For example to name some: The central span of the bridge gets destroyed by Godzilla, it gets destroyed by the kaiju in Pacific Rim, it gets sliced in half by a tsunami in San Andreas, and the final battle takes place on the bridge in Rise of the Planet of the Apes.  There is no cooler landmark that gets this much free publicity.

One can take stunning photographs of the bridge from different vantage points and get the best viewing from the following locations: 

-Across the bridge from the scenic point after you get off the bridge in Marin.
-From Fort Point
-From Lands End Trail
-From Battery Spencer in Marin
-From Hawk Hill in Marin
-From Fort Baker in Marin
-From a boat tour around the bay
-From Alcatraz Island

The Golden Gate Bridge spans across approximately 1.7 miles making it ideal for a nice walk, run, or bike ride.  I love coming here for a run or bike ride regardless of what the weather conditions are.  This bridge is a must visit if you are a tourist or resident.  The more you see it the more you will appreciate its magnificent beauty.
author: Peter C.

description: No trip to San Francisco is complete without a trip over the Golden Gate Bridge. Even though it's just a bridge, it's iconic. Since we were going to Muir Woods we didn't walk the bridge, we just drove it.  Make sure you take in the best views from the park too.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Iconic, beautiful whether shrouded in fog or crystal clear, and incredible.

Many people think of the Golden Gate Bridge when thinking of San Francisco, and what a way to be thought of. It's such an incredible landmark with its huge towering pillars, mountainous connecting side and ability to stretch on nearly out of sight.

Not much more to say other than you have to see it to appreciate it.
author: Adam S.

description: A great place to take pictures and learn a little bit about the Golden Gate Bridge :)! For sure 5 stars
author: Maria V.

description:
TIPS:

1. You don't have to drive across the bridge and have to pay that dreadful toll. You can park around the Golden Gate Bridge Welcome Center (you can try the Bridge Round House, the little eatery there, in your GPS if that helps). 

2. Parking is limited, but if you circle around enough, you will probably find something at some point. Have your credit/debit card or change available to pay. To do this, you go to a nearby machine, pay, and then take your receipt and display it through your car windshield.

3. Weekends and holidays are understandably more crowded, so if you can, try to do a weekday. Even then, the place is still of course gonna be packed--it's the Golden Gate Bridge, for crying out loud!

4. I think the best photo op is next to the Welcome Center on a little raised platform, but that's just me. I think you get a great view of the adjacent hills and the bay water along with SF's classic fog and the beautiful red tinge of the bridge.

5. It takes me about 20-25 minutes to walk the bridge each way. It's about a mile and a half long, or 2.4 km for everyone basically not in the U.S. (and I guess Liberia and Myanmar). 

6. It's COLD, as is basically everywhere in San Francisco. The wind is really exaggerated here due to its super close proximity to the SF Bay. Bring a jacket!!

7. Yeah, you can bike across, and you will see plenty of tourists doing so. I personally don't think it's that worth it over just walking--especially since you're dodging people all the time.

8. There are bikers who seem to be regulars and locals, and for the most part, they do their thing. The past two times I've been here, though, I've had two guys (maybe it was the same guy...) absolutely scream at tourists for not staying to the right side of the sidewalk. They were really jerks about it--these people are here to enjoy the beauty of the view and the bridge, not to be yelled at by some moron who makes San Francisco look bad. I understand that you have a place to be and that these people are cutting into the efficiency of your very tight fitting cycling uniform, but realize for one second that you are biking across one of the most crowded bridges in the United States much less the world; it should be no surprise someone is in your way.

9. It's kind of loud with all the wind and cars driving by. If someone is afraid of this kind of environment, prep them.

10. If you're afraid of heights, you're gonna have a bad time. There are vast sections of the fencing that are about five feet high. You won't fall over unless you try, but try telling that to someone with a fear of heights.

11. If you are thinking about the unthinkable, I'm here to say that there are countless resources both at the bridge--people with pamphlets willing to hear you out, countless tourists who want to get to know you and your stories, phones at select points--and before the bridge--24/7 hotlines, informational websites, people like me (seriously, message me) who care about you. It gets better.

With these tips, you too can conquer one of the best sights of the entire world!
author: Tremaine E.

description:
Definitely a must see! You will be amazed at how beautiful it is. The GG bridge is surrounded by a park like setting, and the views with he water are amazing!
It gets a little windy, so don't forget your jacket.
author: Keli B.

description:
The bridge was impressive to me because of the history behind it. Otherwise its a really long and high bridge. There were several areas to get some amazing pictures of the bridge and scenery around it.

There are several cafes where you can grab a bite to eat or a coffee for the cold mornings. Restrooms are readily available. 

For whatever reason, I think I would like to visit the bridge again. The atmosphere and the environment is very pleasing.
author: Sam N.

description:
Parking: terrible, not enough. Shame on SF not able to build a parking lot or structure for the tourist. Detour us to public parking about 100 spaces and it is impossible to find a spot on holiday

SAD
author: Pham T.

description:
I finally made it to this historical bridge. I've been to SF for quick stop overs, but never had the time to visit or cross the bridge. This time I was on a road trip up the 101 and had the opportunity to stop and cross the bridge on the way to Santa Rosa.

It's is no doubt a large, beautiful historical bridge and the gate way to the Golden State of California. With construction commencing in 1933 and completion dating back in 1937, the bridge has become a United States landmark and one of the many things, San Fransisco is known for. It if definitely place to check out for tourist and locals a like.

Having flown over it a few times, did not give it justice to its awe inspiring towers and feat of engineering. The bridge's one of a kind international orange certainly allows it to stick out and let one know it's there, not to mention its sheer size of 1.7 miles of "total" length and with a total weight of  894,500 tons.

What struck me the best was the view towards the Pacific and then the view back into the city. Both were quite memorable and well suited for a snap shot. Always bring something warm. I visited in the middle of July and it was quite cold.
author: Jack M.

description: Driving here is one thing but walking around this view is much more magnificent! Great for a bike ride or a fabulous walk !
author: Daisy D.

description:
Every time I visit San Francisco I look forward to seeing the bridge since that first time back in the 70's.  Sometimes it's covered in fog.  Sometimes it's gleaming in the bright sun.  I've seen the lovely bridge many times from a distance but rarely walked on it.

You can walk across on one side while bikers get the other side.  Love the reddish color they use on the bridge.  Reminds me of redwood trees.
author: Soo H.

description:
We wanted to cross off our bucket list item of walking across the Golden Gate Bridge. We took the ferry to Sausalito on a Saturday afternoon for $10. After visiting the cute posh town of Sausalito, we began the uphill trek to the bridge. 

After making the uphill climb out of the town we were left on a dirt path towards the bridge. Make sure you stay to the left to avoid the super busy highway leading to the bridge.

The path brought us past several beautiful spots overlooking the bay. We started to descend downhill towards the bottom of the bridge. This area had a historic fort and parking. We took some pictures at the bottom of the bridge which was the perfect picture spot. After going under the bridge we began a half mile uphill climb to the top. At the top of the bridge were two walking paths. One is for bicycles, one is for pedestrians.

The walk across the bridge had little elevation. Bring a jacket because the walk is very windy.

On the San Francisco side of the bridge is a park. We were ambitious and thought we would walk back to Pier 39....ha. We were instantly able to find an Uber driver at the park to bring us back to the hotel.

Overall the walk across the bridge was enjoyable with breathtaking views of San Francisco.
author: Becky K.

description: Amazing place that one everybody must visit one day. It's famous and complex engineering construction. At a little store it's possible to buy souvenirs as magnets, cups, t-shirts...
author: Maya L.

description: I enjoy the GGB every fall when the Fleet Week is happening.  I always walk across the bridge and hang out at the Vista Point area to view the festivities and then walk back across the bridge back to SF.  I always  have a great time.  Not only are the airplanes super entertaining, but also the fleet of ships are continually amazing.   Everyone who lives in SF or is a tourist should always take a walk on the bridge!  Just be aware of the bicyclists if they are on the same side of the bridge that day as you because they can run into you!
author: Norah M.

description: The bridge just..... sat there.  It didn't do anything.  I thought it would be more fun.  They put nets on the sides to prevent people jumping off to go for a nice, cool swim.  Didn't realize we were living in Nazi Germany.  1 out of 5
author: Jared L.

description:
This is it. One of the most remarkable, and sensational landmark that California has it's one of their original trademarks of all time. The Golden Gate Bridge brings the consumers (mostly drivers) are traveling this bridge to any particular destinations between San Francisco and North Bay every year; anytime. 

Officially opened on 5/27/1937, the Golden Gate Bridge has promises to make it historic by giving the details and structures of this well-constructed decade-old bridge. Painted in red with a golden touch, the color never fades it out. The materials, are never worn out which it will remains untouched for many generations to come.

The bridge is a perfect idea for riding a bike back and forth especially walking by in the bridge too, so you can do your daily morning activities in a breeze. For driving, it can be less complicated, but it does give a smooth factor as you've passed the toll plaza in a flash which you can pay the toll if the mail comes in to pay it back. Tried it after my first attempt, and I have no problems at all.

Since my family and I were a tourists from Sacramento, we did enjoyed visiting to the Golden Gate Bridge for quite sometimes for the past 2+ decades. We did enjoyed taking pictures on every taken poses a lot which means it can be valuable for us in a thousand words right in our family photo album. It's endless and memorable to visit. There's also a gift shop near the bridge, so you can own the Golden Gate Bridge memorabilia at home. I did bought the GGB picture book back in 2008 which it contains full pictures of professional photographed pictures of the bridge. Very jaw-dropping to see it after I bought it.

If you want to see the bridge without passing it, there's a challenge. You can park at the nearest small lot if it's available although it gets packed, so go there early as you can. Otherwise, you can also ride a bike, walk, or use public transportation easier without the hassles.

To conclude, the Golden Gate Bridge is the most original, historic landmark bridge that California brings after established a state back in 1850. A must visit for tourists and residents alike near and far! A well, worthy visit! My rating: 5 solid stars.
author: William L.

description: Pro Tip: Park your car anywhere along 19th ave in the neighborhood and take the bus (28) if you want to hike and explore the bridge.
author: Kryssia C.

description:
Most beautiful sight in the Yay! If you're commuting across town by way of vehicle, bicycle or foot travel the Golden Gate is one of the most amazing & renowned landmarks in the state of California; a must see when visiting San Francisco. Travelers flock here from all over the globe to experience this astounding structure...why shouldn't you be one of them? (rhetorical)

Certainly a bucket-lister, we all deserve to be photographed at the Golden Gate Bridge. Drive up the mountains or take the low profile view from Crissy Field. Capture during the day among the gorgeous blue skies or at night well illuminated. 

YOLO,
~Christy
author: Christy A.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge

I am the thing that men denied,
The right to be, the urge to live;
And I am that which men defied,
Yet I ask naught for what I give.

My arms are flung across the deep,
Into the clouds my towers soar,
And where the waters never sleep,
I guard the California shore.

Above the fogs of scorn and doubt,
Triumphant gleams my web of steel;
Still shall I ride the wild storms out,
And still the thrill of conquest feel.

The passing world may never know
The epic of my grim travail;
It matters not, nor friend or foe -
My place to serve and none to fail.

My being cradled in despair,
Now grown so wondrous fair and strong,
And glorified beyond compare,
Rebukes the error and the wrong.

Vast shafts of steel, wave-battered pier,
And all the splendor meant to be;
Wind-swept and free, these, year on year,
Shall chant my hymm of
author: Igor O.

description:
Declared one of the Wonders of the Modern World by the American Society of Civil Engineers.

January 5, 1933    Construction started

May 27, 1937         Opened

746′ Height

8,981′ Length

The bridge is maintained by 38 painters who touch up the paintwork where it becomes seriously corroded. What a cool job! You get to be outdoors everyday and climb around all the parts of the bridge nobody else is allowed to.

It was a bit overcast with some lingering fog, making the top of the bridge look mysterious. The wind was brisk, the walk helped to warm us up. I was glad for my hat as it covered my ears and kept them toasty warm.

Parking, well we got lucky and found a spot relatively close by. There is a self service parking station in the lot, after you pay it spits out your parking pass to display inside your front windshield.

The views make the whole trip well worth it, as even on an overcast day the Golden Gate does not disappoint. It inspires, evokes a beautiful serenity within.

On September 5th, 2014, black-tailed deer made their way across the Golden Gate Bridge during the evening commute. Traffic stopped in both directions while the deer made their way from San Francisco to Marin County. Love this video!

Watch a video; http://goldengatebridge.org/research/funhppngs.php
author: Margaret A.

description: And another one off the bucket list, I jogged across the golden gate and never felt more alive  this was an experience that can't be Explained.
author: Laurita M.

description: The most photographed landmark, and each day, someone is always adding to that number! It is a beautiful bridge, and I've always wanted to see it in person, and I finally did! There is a gift shop there in the vicinity, and it's not too pricey. Got some souvenirs and will visit again if I go back. I would've loved to stay in the Golden Gate Bridge area longer next time. A lot of tourists though, but beautiful scenery nonetheless.
author: Wendy T.

description: The GGB is an iconic landmark that people all over the world can recognize. The bridge is 1.7 miles long, so it is walkable. I walked part of it once when I came to SF for a field trip in 6th grade. I remembered being scared because I'm scared of heights and it was windy. One side of the bridge was for walkers and the other side was for people on bikes. There's also the Golden Gate Bridge Welcome Center that visitors can check out.
author: Helen H.

description:
I've crossed this bridge so many times over the years, by car, by bike, and walking. I am always so blown away by its massive scale and epic location. It is truly a work of art and the fact that it was built  in the 1930's is mind boggling to me. No computers to help crunch the numbers, just pen and paper, and a LOT of hard work, WoW!

    My favorite way to cross the bridge is by far on a bicycle. If you are from out of town, there are plenty of places that rent bikes in the city. I would recommend renting near the ferry house in the pier 39 embarcadero area and riding over the bridge to the cute little town of Sausalito. There you can grab some lunch and then take the ferry back across the bay to where you started out. It makes for an awesome day in the city. I don't remember the exact milage but I would guess that ride is about 6 to 8 miles and there are some hills so you should be in decent shape to attempt this but it is well worth it.

   Now if you are a cyclist and you have your own bike, then I would say go the extra few miles to Tiburon. That's is an 18 mile ride and you can also catch the ferry from Tiburon back to the ferry house on the Embarcadero. That ride is not much more work though as the section from Sausalito to Tiburon is pretty flat.

    Walking the bridge is also quite fun. You can take the last SF exit and park near the presidio and walk as far as you feel comfortable. The nice thing about walking is the slow pace really let's you enjoy all the subtle details of the bridge. You can see and feel all the rivets in the walls of the towers. You can see the huge support wires up close and touch the suspension wires as you walk. Oh and don't forget to look over the edge at the massive height. It's all just so awesome...

   If you are a local or from the other side of the world, a trip across the Golden Gate Bridge is surely a memory you can cherish forever. I highly recommend it!
author: Mark F.

description: How anyone could give this less than 5 stars, I fail to understand. I walked to the edge of the presidio and took the 28 bus for $2.50 through the presidio and walked across the bridge and back. What a breathtaking experience as well as wonderful workout. I had the fortune of beautiful sunny weather and watched elephant seals sunning their bellies below as well as enjoyed watching many sailboats tipping gently forwards on the sea, in addition to the incredible views of the Marin headlands, SF city, Alcatraz, and Bay Bridge. Visiting GG bridge is like an incredible glass of wine...it only gets better with each visit over time.
author: Laila D.

description:
It's just a bridge but it makes for such beautiful pictures and breathtaking views. I don't know how it's possible but wow one can stare out into the water and stare at this bridge for hours. 

Only downside is the area going up isn't really maintained. You can park on the side for free which is great and hike up but then you walk across some brush path and then this area of rust, rotten smelly toilets  and broken metal structures :/ revive this place and it may draw more crowds. Wish there were more benches too so you can sit and stare out but then there may be too many people stopping by.

 But still it is a good picture spot for the bridge and water before you enter and drive through it. A must see here in SF. But the toll to cross, wow $7 and they bill you later :)
author: Grace L.

description:
What a beautiful experience to walk across this iconic landmark with 100s of other people. 
Yes it was busy but the scenery sure was pretty. Great view of Alcatraz and of the city. 

It's not a long walk but we found that a lot of people only walked to the first pole and went back!! It's really not that far to just walk the whole thing people!! 

We discovered that it's bikes on the left and walkers on the right side of the bridge (when walking from the discovery centre). We wanted to walk back in the opposite side but decided not to try and dodge all the bikes. Plus you can get a fine if you're caught.
author: Rowena B.

description:
You can't go to San Francisco and not cross the Golden Gate bridge at least once.
What I did not know is that there is a toll to cross which will run you over $7, not a fan.
Trying to avoid tolls will cost you well over an hour of your time, so if you are in a rush it is well worth it.
The views are gorgeous, great photo ops of the city and surroundings, best is to take a walk from one end of the other as you see a ton of people doing, much easier to take everything in than driving.
Beautiful landmark that everyone should get to see at least once in their lives.
author: Nijole T.

description: I'm so happy I brought my kids here. We had such a great time in San Fran thanks to my bff Bobbi. We were only in SF for a few hrs and got to see a lot. Of coarse the bridge was the highlight of our trip. Also got to visit Fishermans Wharf, Ghirardelli, and Lombard Street.
author: Dora F.

description:
Parking is tough to find around the welcome center but when you do find a its $5/day. Walking paths and bike paths can be easily accessed. Very diverse crowd of people, young and old with the same objective, sightsee and walk the bridge. 
Walking this bridge has been on my bucket list and what better time than now. It's about 3.5 miles give or take round trip. It was foggy, windy and cold but worth it. Would I do it again? Maybe on a clear, sunny day, yes! 
Do I suggest it, of course!
author: Janelle S.

description:
Make sure you pay your toll online
www.bayareafastrak.org

Worst customer service. I don't understood why they have customer service number when they can't help you.  
Customer service is closed on Sunday.
author: Cindy C.

description: Lovely bridge and nothing hasn't already been said about its beauty, but I wanted to offer a few tips and suggestions from a photographer's perspective. First, of all public transportation there is the cheapest way to get there but depending on where you are an Uber isn't a bad idea. Two GGT buses would have gotten me from the Union Street area to the South Gate for about $3 in an hour, instead I Ubered (Uber Pool) it for about $7 in 20 minutes. To get to the North Side, it is about $25 + since there is a toll involved. Although I believe there are public transportation options to get to the North Gate as well. Keep in mind on some days, such as Sundays, there may be limited transportation there. So for the best views of the bridge it depends on what you are going for. Its very cloudy and foggy, especially during the Summer months. If you are lucky enough to get a clear, sunny day, go in the morning and use the eastern light to get a evenly lit view from the South Gate/Side of the bridge. You can go in the late afternoon or early evening to get an evenly lit view from the North Gate/Side. This is due to the bridge's curve. Also, be mindful that pedestrians are only allowed to walk on the east side of the bridge so again, the morning eastern light will light up the entire bridge nicely during this time. There are also many shooting spots, but some require a bit more walking (if you are not driving - I hear parking is very limited) than most. For example the trek from the South Side's Welcome Center down to the Fort Point area is a half mile walk through some dirt paths/paths which didn't seem to be well lit, so be careful going at night. There are other great vantage points on both sides which other photographers have found but many are off the beaten path in unlit and steep areas so be careful when venturing out. I would suggest you spend a few days getting different angles at different times of the day. Be safe and happy shooting.
author: Jason P.

description:
The most famous site in San Francisco. 

If you want to take pictures, park at the pavilion and walk to the bridge.

Driving through the bridge is a good once in a life time thing you do and you can hang out in Sausalito. There is a toll to get back to SF. 

There is a lot of fog in SF so there is a high possibility you will not see it.

Touristy but a must see!
author: Kevin W.

description:
Bucket List: Walk over the Golden Gate Bridge? Check!

We lucked out and had an absolutely gorgeous day to walk over the bridge. I've been told that the bridge is often foggy and cold, but not for us! We were there last week (mid March). If you have a couple of days, make sure to choose the sunniest one. In actuality, the weather channel told us it would be mostly cloudy, but San Francisco weather is often very unpredictable, and it worked out in our favor.

It's about a 1.7 mile walk each way and free if you're walking/biking. If 3.5 miles seems a little much, you can always go halfway and turn around. There were a lot of people biking, but I don't know, it seemed easier to walk with the high density of traffic and pedestrians who often accidentally get in the way. 

The bridge overlooks a yacht club, Alcatraz, and of course large expanses of water with rolling mountains. Seeing the bridge from afar is nice, but nothing beats being in the center of the bridge and looking out at the water.
author: Nicole T.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge how can you not like it?  It was chilly and a lot of cloud cover partially obstructing this magnificent iconic landmark that gives San Francisco its identity.  I have seen this bridge dozens of times, but  when in San Francisco how can you not go to see this landmark that so identifies San Francisco.  Wether it's sunny, cloudy or foggy this structure is synonymous with San Francisco.  The structure spans from the northern most point of the San Francisco peninsula and stretches across to Marin County on the other side.  The opening between the Pacific Ocean on the west & the bay on the east.

We went there at night the one of the days in our recent trip, but everything but the base was obscured by fog.  Even though I have seen the suspension bridge many times before and we were only in San Francisco for 3 days I felt a necessity to see this magnificent structure.  We drove up on Sunday which proved to be a nightmare with congestion, too much traffic and very limited parking, still we were determined to see bridge before we left.  The traffic approaching the bridge was like a parking lot moving very slow or just sitting still.  We were going to cross the bridge going north, but because lack of time & the need to meet up with other people we got off on the bay side at the last parking area before hitting the toll gates.  

Even though there was still cloud cover @ 1pm we were able to see most of the bridge except the tops of the 2 suspension towers.  I can now die happy (NOT).
author: Phil S.

description:
I give it a 1 stars because I am not able to give it less.
This FasTrack company seems to be in the business of tripling their toll charge by not having a reliable well designed website to pay the toll within 48 hrs.
I am so shocked that there is NO warning ahead of time that not only there is a toll but that you can go on their poorly designed website to pay  the golden gate bridge.
Come on!!!! one of the most visited town in CA, called the Silicon Valley they do not have a mandatory field for the email address???!!!!
I had to inquire as to where could I pay and my payment was never processed because supposedly I reported my licence plate in North Carolina instead of CA???? in addition I couldn't be notified that my payment therefore didn't go through as their customer service said I didn't populate my email address. What kind of software would take your Credit Card info online and not request a valid email address in order to process the payment.
It is clearly a case of tripling their benefit by charging foreign and out-of-towners the late fees.
This bridge as beautiful as it is should be boycotted.
I am far from being impressed and appalled to see that this company is taking advance of tourists more over with those who do not speak the language.
author: Fabienne P.

description:
Crazy up here! I live for adventure so when I hiked up, the weather was cold and the wind was so strong as it was gusting my body from every direction. Just my luck on picking the windiest day of the month to do a rambunctious hike. Nonetheless, fun hike from the San Francisco Aquatic Park... check! Fortunately, It's warm up here on most days.

This is definitely the most popular touristy thing to do aside from visiting Alcatraz which I haven't done yet even though I've lived my whole life in the Bay Area. In the mean time, it's always nice taking pictures, with a backdrop as stellar and monolithic to see in person, of this Bridge.

Equally nice picture worthy views are from the Battery Spencer/ Marine Headlands hiking trail which looks at the Bridge from the opposite end.

5 Stars for a bridge that's awe striking and as iconic as it is beautiful.
author: Andy L.

description:
Alright maybe this is sacrilegious but I think the Golden Gate Bride is super overrated. The bridge itself is HUGE but very plain. They pedestrian side is tiny. More crowded than the BK bridge and I didn't know that is possible. 

But as they say: Location, location, location. The bay is beautiful and it really carries the bridge. The parks and beaches near it are all beautiful.
author: Andrew B.

description:
Duh, why wouldn't I give the Golden Gate Bridge a 5 star rating??

(I would only rate it a 4 star due to the fact that if you are driving across the bridge you will be billed for the toll fee seeing as there are no toll workers to get your fee for the bridge. )

*Be prepared to have a fast track to take it out of your account immediately. OR expect a bill in your mail. 

The most iconic bridge of the United States history known to the whole world. Thousands of people flock here everyday to commute through the bridge, or join the tourists in taking their maybe once in a lifetime photo next to it. 

Need I write more on this yelp review???

Gosh.. I love San Francisco. One day im gonna have my engagement photos next to this thing. :D
author: Michelle M.

description: Overrated. It takes forever to park and is super windy. Most of the time you can't even see the city. Also the traffic is scary wizzing by you.
author: Colin L.

description: Amazing!  We walked all the way across and back.  Had a great time and then took a boat ride under the bridge and around Alcatraz.  The bridge is amazing.
author: Jesse L.

description:
How can you NOT rate the Golden Gate Bridge 5 stars?  

Yes, this suspension bridge is an integral part of the San Francisco Bay transportation system, spanning the Bay between the Northernmost tip of the San Francisco peninsula and the Marin Headlands, which you can cross by car, on a bike, or on foot, but it's much more than that. It's an icon.

To much of the world it doesn't just REPRESENT San Francisco, it IS San Francisco.

I lived in the East Bay for several years, so I've driven over the bridge quite a few times, not really thinking about the significance of it.  The most memorable trip was the last one I made a year ago while visiting my old stomping grounds in the Bay Area.  I moved to Bakersfield 18 years ago and I was showing a Bakersfield native around that had only been to the San Francisco Bay area once or twice and desperately wanted to see its famous bridges close up.  We drove North up the East side of the Bay, crossing over to Marin via the San Rafael Bridge, drove South into the city via the Golden Gate Bridge, then returned via the Bay Bridge.  The Golden Gate Bridge was most definitely the Queen of the Bay outshining all the other bridges by quite a bit.

The Golden Gate Bridge is not golden in color, but is painted International Orange, a color that was selected because it blended so well with the surrounding hills.  It was named after the entrance to the San Francisco Bay that it spans.

This is a toll bridge, as are all the bridges that span the San Francisco Bay, but like it's counterparts it only charges  a toll in one direction, South.  As luck would have it, this is the direction in which we travelled.  I believe the toll was about $7, which is a pittance to travel across what amounts to a living piece of history.  Nowadays the toll is paid electronically so there is no stopping of any of the lanes to hold up traffic.  You can open an account online to pay the tolls or they will send you an invoice that you can pay later.  Talk about convenient!

Later that day we took a day cruise around the Bay which passed directly under the bridge.  It was quite an awesome sight to behold from below, towering above us majestically.  I understand that you can park at either end of the bridge for photo ops, but I haven't done that yet.

Yes, you can take the girl out of the Bay, but you can't take the Bay out of the girl. I'm pretty sure I left my heart in San Francisco, and I found it again somewhere in the middle of the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Mimi J.

description: What can you say? The best bridge in the world . Walked across for the first time... 1.8 miles each way.
author: Mitchell K.

description: It really is a beautiful sight to see the Bay Bridge and to walk across it but it really is a scary experience for many reasons. For one, the Vertigo - Two, being asked stupid questions by your friend if you think you'd die jumping off the bridge. Don't go with anyone who's emotionally off even the slightest bit lol. I was holding onto that friend with dear life, not that I thought anything would happen but just because my anxiety kicked as it appears very easy to fly over the bridge. If you do decide to walk the bridge the cars driving across are speeding and zipping through which adds to the anxiety. Plus winds. It's almost prettier to just watch it from a distance in awe.
author: Marmar Q.

description:
How did I review the Bay Bridge but not the Golden Gate Bridge? :(



"Whatever happened to predictability...."


Golden Gate Bridge, or Hwy 101, is one of the more iconic figures of California. It connects Marin County to San Francisco (and vice versa). It, of course, has a toll on the bridge (sigh), but usually (actually always...) when I've come up, we've exited the road before the toll and waited in a long line to look at the bridge. You might be lucky, you might not be lucky. It depends on Mother Nature and her mood. You might get a perfectly beautiful sunny day, or you might get clouds and fog. If at night, you can come here for the sunset, dayum I would think that would be a beautiful picture.

Hopefully there'll come a time when I shall have time to walk it as a pedestrian, instead of just looking at it from aways (although, I've been under it, if that counts). Don't think of the dark history, just keep walking, just keep walking......

Oh yeah, and one day, I also need to cross it :P The Golden Gate Bridge has been the furthest north I've been driving on the western side. :( Never passed it. Sigh :/
author: Raymond L.

description:
California Trip # 11

I am the thing that men denied,
The right to be, the urge to live;
And I am that which men defied,
Yet I ask naught for what I give.

My arms are flung across the deep,
Into the clouds my towers soar,
And where the waters never sleep,
I guard the California shore.  

--Joseph P. Strauss, Chief Engineer (excerpt of The Golden Gate Bridge)

When you have grown up hearing about the Golden Gate Bridge (GGB) from the other side of the country, that moment when you actually see it in person, and then stepping across the bridge is quite extraordinary. I knew if there was one thing I *had* to do while in San Francisco, GGB was it. I left my hotel room that morning very early so that I could arrive at Crissy Field in order to welcome the sunrise (http://www.yelp.com/biz/crissy-field-san-francisco-2?utm_campaign=www_business_share_popup&utm_medium=copy_link&utm_source=(direct)). It was a magical experience and I highly recommend you plan for that if you get the chance. 

Parking at Crissy Field is free, and it's a great walk to visit GGB. As a hobby photographer, the sights are abundant as you make your way to the bridge. Make sure you stop by the Pavilion as well--clean restrooms and a great gift shop (http://www.yelp.com/biz/golden-gate-bridge-pavilion-san-francisco-2?utm_campaign=www_business_share_popup&utm_medium=copy_link&utm_source=(direct)). I ended up walking the whole bridge, which is 1.7 miles long. Do it, people! If you're only going to visit once in your life, then walk the entire way and say, "Damn it! I walked across the Golden Gate Bridge!" I did regret it a little bit later, but that was because I tried to walk to Fisherman's Wharf (FW) after. Don't be like me. Focus on the bridge! 

Halfway across the bridge, I stopped. Looking at the view of the Bay and Marin Headlands, I couldn't believe I was actually there. My mind put a huge check on my travel bucket list while feeling euphoric. That will always be an amazing memory to treasure.

One last thing, as a tip to "tourists": Please pay attention to the traffic on the sidewalk. Walkers go on one side and bikers go on the other. And, please--for the love of God--do not stop on the other side to take a picture when bikers are coming at you. Don't act like an idiot!! Use your brain, pay attention, and be respectful. 

I love you, GGB! Until we meet again...
author: Carissa K.

description:
This would be second time to see the bridge, but I did this around was to actually walk onto it for the first time.

The Golden Gate Bridge visiting center was busy with crowds from all over the world. It amazing how something like this bridge can be such a monument for everyone.

How we ended up at the bridge started with walking all along Embarcadero through all the parks at the end, until we decided to call A Lyft driver to take us the rest of the way.

Once we were there, it was perfect! The sun was setting, it was clear skies, there were boats on the harbor and everything was just amazing.

The experience of being on the bridge, watching the city light of San Francisco start to light up like fireflies on the coast is just something to watch and take in

Enjoy San Francisco my friends! 

:)
author: Ryo Hanalei Z.

description:
They need to put a toll booth back on the bridge.  I paid my toll online as directed by the signs at the Golden Gate Bridge visitor center within 48 hours.  Received a confirmation number and fasttrack rep. states all is good.  One week later receive a charge from rental company for toll plus additional fees. 

Fastrack did not process payment because they state that the plate on my car did not cross the bridge.  Contacted rental company and they transfer me to E-toll don't know if they are affiliated with fastrack and they show the rental car crossing the bridge at the exact time i said.  They agreed to reverse charges due to misunderstanding.
author: Neal D.

description:
This bridge is truly iconic and is definitely worth driving on if you never have before. It is truly a magnificent man made structure that has great views of the San Francisco bay.  I have been on this bridge many times in a car but have never had the opportunity to walk it as many tourists do daily. 

Although being that the bridge is long, I can imagine it takes triple the amount of time to get across with walking versus driving.  I bet I would end up with sore legs if I ever consider it.  But anyhow, driving on the bridge, you can see the harbor, the bay and the towering structure. It is truly amazing.  However, I have always wondered why it is called the Golden Gate Bridge when this iconic structure was painted a dark orange.  Could it be named after California, being the Golden State?

Pros:
-an iconic man-made structure 
-great views of SF Bay
-has an amazing history
-I think walking the bridge is free but I am not sure

Cons:
-has a toll fee that keeps on rising every year for drivers.  I think it is about $10 now so it is not worth it for a daily commute.
author: Irene S.
