description: The GG Bridge is iconic to San Frandisco.  If you've ever thought of anything to represent the city, it's definitely this. I mean, it's practically painted all over everything, everywhere, by everyone!  One day I would like to climb to the top of the towers and squirrel jump off that bad boi and fly away into the sunset, but today is not that day.  There's a beach and some other junk around here too. Probably some good bars, too, where you can feed your hunger for alcohol and then walk across this bad boi. Just do it man!!
author: Michael S.

description: Gorgeous! My husband and I took my mother in law here when she came to visit. We walked across the bridge and it was an amazing experience. There's a cafe just over the bridge (SF side) that we had lunch at and then walked back. Nice daytime activity.
author: Ashleigh L.

description:
Yes, I know everyone else has reviewed the iconic Golden Gate Bridge, but not Margaret Cho of Yelp!

I remember when this bridge was $1, and I'm sure others remember when it was 50 cents or less.  Who doesn't love this bridge?  I do regret not going to the 75th Anniversary of GGB, one takes it for granted when living here, especially growing up in SF.  I never woke up with the sudden urge of walking, biking, or driving over the GGB, like it was an outing.  I complain more about the GGB these days due to the toll hikes.  Clearly, there are no more live toll takers...things that make you go hmmm?  Wassup with the toll hike?  Don't even think about charging pedestrians & bicyclists each way...that's just greedy!

I do look forward to the 100th Anniversary; hopefully, I will still be able to walk and see the fireworks.  I'm glad I'm alive to witness the moveable median barrier being installed.  I always thought how dangerous the North & Southband lanes were without a barrier...many collisions have occurred.  Nowadays, with cell phones, more drivers are distracted and taking photos of the GGB.  The moveable median barrier decreases such accidents, can't say the same about the suicide jumpers.  Please don't build an ugly barrier to prevent suicides, if one wants to jump, they'll find a way to jump, or go to another bridge.

Overall, the GGB is indeed a beauty, and we're forever grateful to those brave men who lost their lives building this amazing bridge!  Read some fun facts about the GGB, enjoy =)

http://www.history.com/news/6-things-you-may-not-know-about-the-golden-gate-bridge
author: Christine R.

description:
Bicycling across the Golden Gate Bridge is a must whether you are a tourist in SF for the first time, come here frequently or live here and commute on a daily basis.  (This is a for bicyclist only).  I do not need to tell you how spectacular the views of and on the bridge are.  There are several places to take your picture of yourself and the bridge and the towers are impressive to shoot photos in all kinds of conditions.
As you bike across the bridge try to keep in mind your safety and those of others.  Do not:
1) Film yourself as you are riding and wobbling across the bridge on your Blazing Saddle rental bike or any other bike for that matter. 
2) Ride side by side. Single-file only!
3) Walk on the same side of the bridge that is open to cyclist (sometimes this is not possible, but check before you get on the bridge). Plus (if you have to walk the same side as cyclist), walking in a meandering path makes it hard for cyclists to get by you.
4) Take photos of the towers or yourself and friends without being aware that bikes are coming from both directions. 

Enjoy the bridge it is gorgeous in the fog, at sunrise, sunset and when large ships pass under.
author: Derald C.

description: I love walking across this bridge it is so beautiful and I live in Marin County and I go across this bridge all the Time to go home to Redwood City this is a very ancient beautiful bridge San Francisco Golden gate Bridge come here if you want to go for tors and just walk across the bridge I recommend it !!!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
You see the red bridge and you know that that's the SF bridge. 
It is the entrance of the San Francisco Bay from the Pacific Ocean. it took over 4 years to build. in it's lifetime the bridge has been closed only 3 times due to weather. 

I've always got close enough just to be able to take pictures of if in the background whenever I visited SF but it wasn't until renting a bike and riding across it did I truly realize how amazing this bridge truly is. Riding across it allowed me to see and just take it all in... in a way driving through it couldn't give me. So if you could I would highly recommend biking it. If time or health doesn't permit then definitely walk it if possible. 

often times the weather in SF is pretty cold and chilly. cloudy and overcast is a norm. i've taken pictures of it both in sunny weather and when there's an overcast. either way it still makes a great picture and a great landmark to see. 

Overall, it's a must see if you're not a local. You gotta make a stop and visit this wonderful big red bridge.  

tips:
*there's a website you can check out. 
*there's a toll when you drive through it.
author: Lisa D.

description:
Ah, the Golden Gate Bridge! Not only is it an icon of San Francisco but also of the United States. Even though it is one of the most photographed spots of all times, I think you would still impress to see this beautiful engineering marvel in person, so don't miss it.

Just a few logistics :
1) While northbound is free, southbound requires a toll that is paid only via mail. If you have a rental car, the toll is between $7.50-$11 depending on your rental car agency.

2) At the south end, Golden Gate Bridge Welcome Center is a convenient, well-maintained facility with a decent view. However, the best view with terrific vantage point is Battery Spencer at the north end, but the facility is not maintained well and requires crossing the toll booth if you need to return to SF.

3) Battery Spencer is the best viewing spot especially during sunrise, but to get closer to the bridge or learn some information blurbs, Welcome Center is the better choice.

Anyway, no matter where you see this, don't forget to snap a selfie with the bridge! Otherwise, who would believe that you went to San Francisco?
author: Jay Y.

description: This bridge is an iconic symbol of Northern California and the Yay area. I love any spot in the city with a view of this bridge. Going over the bridge can be annoying because of the toll and tourism traffic but it is 100% always breathtaking. I've seen the bridge hundreds of times but it never ceases to amaze me. It is larger in person than it appears in pictures and the color is repainted every few years to maintain its signature red coat (though I think the color is called orange with the paint manufacturer). I always look at it and wonder how engineers and architects figured how to make this bridge so many years ago. Most bridges are very generic looking but the Golden Gate Bridge is unique and recognizable across the entire world. I am proud to show off the bridge when out-of-town visitors come visit me in the bay area. Different areas where you can view the bridge include Lands End (good for a stroll/hike with the pups), Golden Gate State Park, Crissy Field (where E-40 performed at the free Budweiser music festival), Baker Beach (dog friendly, nude friendly beach area), Coit Tower and the opening intro in Full House (for those trying to view it at a home that isn't in SF). The Golden Gate is definitely my favorite bridge in the world (and I am living in NY now so it isn't a bias or anything!).
author: Brenda L.

description:
I mean this is obviously not just a major San Francisco landmark but a major California landmark and a must see. Great photo opportunity. My mom and I took the bus tour that went to all the major landmarks and ended at the bridge. I would highly recommend doing this. It's super touristy but if you're an East Coast girl like me and you don't get out to Cali often, I think it's worth it. 

The bridge is just overwhelming and beautiful. We spent a lot of time just taking pictures. Definitely bring a jacket, a coat even,particularly if you are going to ride on top of the bus.
author: Jasmine T.

description: Awee what else can I said loved this bridge ! Since I was little ..i didnt like from the last time I visited that they added a fence . I was not able to walk it all the way because  it looks soo getto  with the fence ..what they have to do to keep people of it . Other than that is a nice place to take pictures and enjoy the views of the city .
author: Sara A.

description:
After living in the Bay Area my whole life, the Golden Gate Bridge has kind of unfazed me. I use it more as a way to get from Sausalito to SF and back home in the East Bay, rather than a destination.

As a bridge (and not an attraction) it's alright. It can get pretty backed up on both sides, and it's a little pricey, but you can still get across it pretty fast.
author: Casey S.

description: This was our first visit as husband and wife and it was spectacular! From the views to the walk down to the cafe to the historic site it was clean and fun and just a day well spent! A must do in San Francisco. Only thing I would recommend are better road signs for out of towners to be able to drive to the bottom where the cafe is located. We had no clue and drove around quite a bit before just giving up and parking at the main parking.
author: Priti K.

description:
I don't know what else I could possibly say about the iconic Golden Gate Bridge that hasn't already been said. The bridge is breathtaking from any area in the SF area.  It opened on May 27, 1937, after 4 years of construction. It's a steel, suspension bridge that spans 4200 feet and is arguably the most photographed bridge in the world. 

I had the opportunity to ride on the bridge via a hop-on-hop-off bus tour that drove over the bridge. We had a few photo opportunities after turning into the Golden Gate visitors center. Dress warmly because despite the sunny skies, this part of the city is cooler due to the ocean swell.
author: Trina D.

description:
Definitely come visit this bridge if you're in San Francisco. It's not the longest or biggest bridge but its still iconic and has a vibe and feel all of its own. Come on a clear day to be mesmerized and overwhelmed by the bridge and the scenic and amazing views of the Bay Area. And come on a foggy day to see the bridge enveloped in fog and experience how it feels you're walking into a mystical world. The Presidio and Fort Point are also in the area so it makes the bridge that much worth visiting. Its really a marvel to admire and HIGHLY recommended. Its super touristy but its one of those touristy things that are totally worth doing.

PROS: Everything about the bridge and the surrounding area

If you're biking, I believe there's a bikers only lane that opens up

CONS: Its filled with tourist and its gets ridiculously packed, as you can imagine.
author: Near M.

description:
HOW CAN YOU NOT VISIT THE GOLDEN GATE BRIDGE WHEN YOU'RE IN SAN FRAN?! It is THE icon for San Francisco.

I've actually seen a similar bridge about two months before I visited the Golden Gate Bridge. It was April 25th Bridge in Lisbon Portugal made by the sam ABC company. Okay, so I thought, that bridge looked really nice, guess this one is going to be the same. Y'know, like a bridge with a nice city view behind it. Like, still it's JUST a man made bridge.

EEEENT (wrong buzzer sound). The Golden Gate Bridge was PHENOMENAL. Y'know why?! There was fog EVERYWHERE and it made it look absolutely stunning, as if the bridge were literally in midst of clouds and San Francisco was a city in the sky. It reminded me so much of Hayao Miyazaki's film - A castle in the sky, Laputa. 

Literally, it was like a fog machine that exploded loads and loads of fog in an indescribable manner. The fog grew stronger and stronger as nighttime arrived. 

I definately recommend crossing the bridge amd having a view of the glory on the other side. I dont think it has fog everyday, but when it does, MAN, it's gorgeous.
author: Kristy N.

description:
Yes, this is the most touristy spot you can visit, but it's filled with people for a reason right? I don't think I will ever tire of this view. I may be biased though, since I was born and raised in the city.

Make sure to come on a clear day for beautiful pictures. If you have the time, bike across the bridge. If you're more pressed for time, at least walk a bit of the bridge. The view is breathtaking! I wish I knew someone so I could go to the top. I've seen gorgeous pictures from people who have been up there early morning to see the bridge surrounded by Karl the fog.

All in all, even if you're local, come visit every couple years. I do greatly enjoy Baker Beach or Crissy Field's views, but there is something magical about seeing the bridge up close. I've definitely left my heart in San Francisco.
author: Kristi T.

description:
Wow, such a trademark of San Francisco and a must see! I got to see this incredible bridge from three very different view points.

First:  We drove across the bridge then parked in a nearby pull off and walked about a quarter of the way. Great views of the bay, Alcatraz and fisherman's wharf. This is very popular with all the other tourists, parking can be difficult.

Second: Then drove up a nearby mountain to have spectacular aerial views of the entire bridge. Lots of winding turns with more pull off for lots of photo opportunities.

Third:  The last view was below the bridge at fort Point, and old Civil War fort with close up views beneath the bridge. Very windy, but some of the best views!

*** You do have to pay $7 when you are driving into San Fran***
author: Kelly S.

description: Beautiful bridge and with the lane splitting divider on the bridge traffic is easier! The views are great from this bridge and it's always fun to see the people walking the bridge and tourists out for a viewing. The toll is average for the bridge and is only one way, going into SF.
author: Zoe M.

description:
This bridge is an amazing sight to behold. But I had to review it so low to warn others.

Do NOT bring or leave any valuables in your car for any reason! 

Car was broken into around 8:30-9:00am with plenty of people walking and biking on the adjacent trail.  Stole a purse that was put in the trunk. The police informed us that it happening a lot more lately since a new law passed makes theft a minor infraction with a fine.  They didn't file a police report the same day so we couldn't get any information from local pawn shops.  The golden gate police were also less than helpful.  I identified a camera pointing at our car 50ft away and they refused to answer if the camera caught anything or not.  

The impression I got was that our situation was one of hundreds and they couldn't be bothered.  This is the responsibility of the police, bridge officials, and park rangers.  Stop treating people like they don't matter.
author: Abraham C.

description: Another must in San Francisco is the Golden Gate Bridge. Unfortunately, it is very very long and after a while, it becomes redundant. Fortunately, you can choose how much of it you want to walk (remember you have to walk back too!) I walked to the halfway point where there is a lookout over the bay and the city of San Francisco. It was windy when I went and San Francisco's climate is generally cool all year round, so remember to bring a light jacket or sweater. I've heard that biking across the bridge is also a cool experience, but I am not a very big biker and wanted to save on money and time so choose to walk instead. There is a visitor parking lot right at the entrance to the bridge walkway so taxis can bring you curbside.
author: Priya S.

description:
Ah the pinnacle landmark of a San Francisco experience!  Even though I am a local, I still am in awe of structure.  Come from the north or south side of it is a great view.

I recommend taking a boat cruise to get the view from the water or renting a bike to cross the bridge.

Make sure to bring your jacket on cold days! and a camera!
author: Michelle T.

description:
When in San Francisco, you visit the Golden Gate Bridge. No trip is complete without it. Cross it off that bucket list of American landmarks to visit! 

You can bike it, walk it, drive it or just take a picture of it. I got my snapshots at Fort Point on the south side of the bridge, which proved to be a great view, but there are tons of places to see it! 

If you look close enough and from the right angle, you can catch a glimpse of it when you're flying in/out of SFO. 

The Golden Gate is worth the hype and worth the visit - it's simply stunning!

*It's technically more orange than golden. Just sayin'.
author: Katie U.

description: This place is packed but it's still worth a visit.  I loved crossing this bridge and visiting this infamous place.  Expect nothing but crowds.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Awesome view!!!  We saw it by foot, car and boat.   Not sure which was the best but it is a must do when visiting San Francisco.    By foot is somewhat crowded by people walking and on bikes but it was worth it.
author: Sheila D.

description: Absolutely breathtaking. My future husband and I are getting married in 47 days and before we take the big leap, we celebrated with a trip to SF, big sur, Santa Barbara and LA. SF was such an adventure...especially when we had our uber driver take us to the Golden Gate Bridge (my first time). It was stunning. it was a gorgeous day and we both enjoyed relaxing to music while we visited the bridge and drove all around it! It is an amazing memory!
author: Jackie K.

description: This bridge has great views and is beautiful. It was nice but my ears were popping. This was amazing.
author: TropicalNights ..

description: One of the must see landmarks in San Francisco. Yes, it is just a bridge but it is gorgeous and  makes for a great photo op. My friend and I walked across the bridge and loved the views over the water. Also, right before you go on the walkway, there is a nice little visitor center you should stop inside dedicated to the history of the bridge.
author: Tyler L.

description:
I love it Love it Love it..... you need to stop its like little New York I took a Uber so dont know any parking regulations but Its worth it to come up .

Its very clean and safe so come and have fun.
author: John C.

description:
You'll be amazed at the Golden Gate Bridge when you see it. We went to the visitor center and got close enough to the bridge as possible without going near the sand and water. I know you can drive onto the bridge and get a good view from Kirby Cove Campgrounds! 

They have a store, restrooms, I think they have a place to grab food as well.

Take lots of pictures! Seeing the bridge is breath taking! If you come early enough you can see the fog surround the bridge.
author: Cecilia P.

description:
Beautiful bridge overshadowing some fog when we visited. 

Busy traffic is loud but still adds some livelihood to the bridge. Vista area is a wonderful place to park your car and walk across the bridge. It can be little windy and cold but it's worth the view.
author: Nomin D.

description:
Yep, San Francisco's most iconic site/sight.  I walk across each time I'm visiting -- nice walk, good exercise, and great views of San Francisco, the bay, and parts of Marin county along the walk.

I also got shots from the Batteries to bluffs trail at dusk, in the Presidio, and another afternoon walk from Fort Point to the Marina Green and back.
author: Tim L.

description: Such a fun sight to see. So pretty. All tourists in SF should have a chance to see this bridge.
author: Shenna J.

description:
Majestic, Marvelous, Grand --- whatever you want to call it, this San Francisco icons of all icons is a must-visit in San Francisco! Reserve a good 1.5 hours to visit the pavilion area, take photos from all angles and, most importantly, to walk the bridge! One thing is for certain, there are PLENTY of angles and areas to take photos from once you approach the scenic area and there are tons of tourists along the way. 

One word of advice, if you plan on parking in the pavilion parking lot, try your luck somewhere else along the path to the bridge. The parking lot tends to always be full and is a very tight area. You can easily get stuck there for 10-15 minutes trying to get out, however there are parking spots on the curvy road down from the bridge. Some drivers tend to pass right by it without knowing that. 

Other than that, take in the breeze, views and enjoy the scenery!
author: Chris E.

description:
The beautiful iconic Golden Gate bridge; of course you must visit this when you're in San Fran. 
It's fun driving across the bridge especially when you are on the top deck of the double decker bus, its almost like a rollercoaster ride.
There are vista points before and after you cross the bridge for a beautiful photo
author: Katelyn T.

description: The morning we visited the Golden Gate Bridge it was cool and foggy and that's exactly how I always pictured my arrival at this glorious architectural gem to be.  The saddle and cables stretching up into the clouds... I couldn't get enough of 'er.  We walked over the bridge about half way and took in its grandeur.   Explored the structural elements underneath.  And finally made our way through the park to capture it in its entirely.  Each view point was better than the last.  An absolutist must see if visiting San Fran.
author: Alyssa R.

description:
She is like an annoying lady :) Covering herself with her fog grey scarf and letting you suffer to see a side of her face. 

We visited between July 28 to August 1st, 3 attempts, all failed. So I think if there is no bright and clear weather on her on any month, for sure, do not bother getting so close to it. Just check from a distance

We tried once at 9 AM from Vista point, another day at 3-4 PM from Forth point and at 8 PM when sailing with a sunset tour. Briefly, she broke my heart so I let her go :) Until next time golden lady!
author: Ceren A.

description:
Ahhhhh the beautiful Golden Gate Bridge.
Been here twice. The first ti.e I had seen it I took a Firetruck tour over it and the lady told us she tap danced across it breaking a Guinness book world record.

This bridge is amazing as it is HUGE! You can walk across it....it's really high-746'
Great photos to be taken, cool place to visit.

The best views of this structure is at Fort Point.
author: Lori W.

description: What's not to love? Walking the span of this amazing landmark is a pleasure. Take the time to come visit!
author: Ron R.

description:
Loved it.

Some bikers go super hard, and are pretty ridiculous with trying to be competitive riders w all the tourists/pedestrians around...still, we couldn't believe the views, the vastness, and the overall vibe. 

We rented a tandem bike from park ride, and covered a ton of ground. Highly suggest getting a bike, just don't expect to be going super fast (like some annoying bikers lol).
author: Kadian M.

description: A total sightseeing attraction. That being said, I've lived in SF for the last 32 years and to this day when I cross the Golden Gate Bridge I find myself staring up at it's magnificence. It may be overcrowded with tourists, and covered in bird crap, but there is an almost mystical reason all these people are drawn here. If you like historic landmarks you need to stop by and take it in for yourself. If you're expecting an amusement park like some previous reviewers, you're probably better off at Six Flags.
author: AJ T.

description: Went on a little adventure here... nice place to go for a bike ride or just walk the whole golden gate bridge, the middle has some historical info. Enjoy the scenery as you walk until the end of the bridge. It's so windy here!
author: Yennie L.

description:
Beautiful? Yes. Overhyped? That too. We tried stopping at the Bridge viewing area instead of having to actually cross the bridge but that place was a total ZOO!  Tour buses and RVs and hundreds of cars...it was dangerous.  We did get across the bridge (by car) and it's big and long and red.  The only good pics I was able to get were while we were actually on it (oh and the hazy one I took from Pier 39).  People walk/bike it.  If I knew how to ride a bike, that may actually have been fun.  Walking?  It was too hot for that, not to mention we had no idea where to park our car in order to trek over it.

The toll situation is a nightmare.  We crossed the bridge, thinking the toll would be billed to us via snail mail.  It's true, we did get our toll bill in the mail but we also got a $25 violation fee on top of that.  I called them to ask what the violation was for.  Apparently, we'd gone through the Fast Track lanes and we didn't have a Fast Track pass.  They told me we had needed to stop in the "cash" lane to pay our toll.  In the end, the lady on the phone waived the violation fee and I paid the $5 toll with my credit card. They need to have more cash lanes; it was extremely unclear as to what needed to be done prior to crossing.  Maybe we were just confused tourists....
author: Jennifer S.

description:
so, yeah, i've lived here for over a decade and have yet to walk across this baby

i have ridden a bike across and down to sausalito to catch the ferry back to sf

driven across hundreds of times

get a fastrak and you save $1 !!
author: Charlie B.

description:
I'm pretty iconic if I must say
To cross the water, I'm the way
Rain or shine, still I stand
Forever red, that I am!
Above the water, there I stay
But I can't swim, fly, or even move, no way!
author: Alex C.

description:
In all the years that I've been a host to all my friends and family visiting San Francisco, this is the one that they ultimately, want a picture with!!  What a landmark for San Francisco and such a beauty. It is the most unique bridge in the world. I suggest walking all the way back and forth if you can especially on a clear day. Once on the other end (towards Marin County side), you will get a chance to take a breathtaking photo of the San Francisco side. With more than 1,000 plus reviews, I'll keep this short, you just have to come here and see it for yourself! It's that amazing and welcome to my home city!!

Until then, Cheers! ~ :p
author: Edwin R.

description: This is my favorite place to go to wherever I'm in CA. The sunset is so amazing, the views and so are the foods! Whenever I'm in town I never missed to visit Pier 39 and Golden Gate Bridge (of course). I'm still trying to figure out where is that swing where you can still see the bridge though. It was an amazing experience every single time.
author: Cristina M.

description:
Ok I have to say I screwed up. I took the photo from the South side. Big mistake. One of the reason because we saw a sign and thought that's the best place to turn into for pictures. But again if you go and take the picture from the North, you would have to pay for toll again. And yes you would have San Fran in the background which is a lot nicer. 

Traffic was crazy there. So many people. Even the bathroom lineup was crazy. Because my friends have taken their photo here, I got out of the car and took the picture with my selfie stick and ran back in. Parking is so limited so I believe this is the best move. 

If you come here you must take pictures of Golden Gate Bridge. Its iconic to San Fran. You won't be disappointed.
author: Denise W.

description:
I ride Golden Gate transit daily and have to change buses since I work in the civic center area and GGT can't seem to schedule the Civic Center bus correctly. Regardless, there's no better place to stop and take in the view than the Golden Gate Bridge toll plaza where we are dropped off. Gorgeous views and a very safe area! Lots of people changing buses so there's always activity. Looking out over Alcatraz is of course the added bonus! When driving northbound, it can be frustrating that there is a huge bottleneck at the tolls. Makes my ride home that much longer! But aside from all that, this is a very excellent spot!
Kudos to the Golden Gate Bridge staff!!
author: Sandra P.

description:
Why bother reviewing the GGB when you cross it quite often? Simple, it's an iconic staple of Northern California and I guess it makes sense to give it a little love!

Been crossing this landmark for over 20 years and it never gets old. Yes, the bridge is beautiful, but on a clear day you can see the city and the entire bay and it is beau-ti-ful! Not to mention all the sail boats and large tankers that can keep you distracted for quite some time if you hit the bridge during peak hours. I'd suggest if you have the chance, take a walk or cycle across the bridge if you have never done so. Might want to take advantage of that on a nice cool clear day though, possibly during the early hours of the day when it is not packed by locals and tourists alike. 

Now if I really had to be picky about the GGB, I'd point out the cost to cross the bridge, but I figure for the two to three times a month if that when I cross it, it is not too bad. I can only imagine that it will go up in time, but hey everything does in life so no use in complaining about it honestly. To turn a negative into a positive though, all of the years handing over quite a bit of money paid off for me when they opened the non stop lanes. Simply drive through and let the cameras snap a picture of your license plate and pay the bill online a few weeks later when you receive a invoice in the mail. To sum it up, most of us take the GGB for granted, but it is a historic landmark and needs a little love now and then.
author: Ryan A.

description: Awesome national landmark. I've been wanting to come here for years so I was ecstatic to finally experience this iconic structure in person with my girlfriend. We got an Uber ride to take us to the north end and we walked back to the south entrance. The walk way has heavy traffic and bikers could be careless so watch out. Views are amazing as is the weather.
author: Juan M.

description: The iconic gold gate bridge. I prefer viewing the bridge from Marin headlands. In all my years living in the Bay Area I only walked the bridge once. Make sure to bring a coat as it can get windy and chilly on the bridge. If you are a tourist I recommend checking the weather before choosing which day to visit as the fog can cover the beautiful views. Definitely plan to go later in the day after the morning fog has burned off. Worth visiting
author: Amber V.

description:
This is awesome if you find the parking and it will be yours the best day. Very cold even in July due to the wind, bring some head wear.
Prepare to a huge crowd.
author: Dennis K.

description:
For whatever reason the Golden Gate Bridge never impressed me much, maybe bridges aren't my thing? But it was clear when doing research before my trip that this was a stop that had to be made so I went along with it. 

Turns out bridges are pretty impressive (and humbling) and if you head to either of the look out stations (one on either side) you'll get some amazing pictures that will make all your friends envious! 

I had some lofty goals of walking across the whole thing, but after a long trip with quite a lot of exercise, combined with and strong cold wind I was content with getting my pictures at the look out point and calling it done.  Good thing my brother pushed me to actually walk and said he was ok with just reaching the first tower (which is a common turn around point).  Must note my brother did go back the next day after I had left and achieved his goal of walking the whole thing! 

So yes, this is a MUST see in San Francisco! The look out areas have parking so you can head up there, park and walk across (or bike if you have that option).  We uber-ed so need to park, but there did seem to be some spots available.
author: Savanna M.

description: Synonymous with San Francisco, crossing the bridge is a must.  Amazing with a breathtaking view of the city and bay. You can either walk, bike, or drive across the bridge. Driving will cost you $7, ridding a bike $4.50 - but well worth it.  You can find parking near both ends of the bridge for a photo op, a visit to SF is not complete if you don't visit the Golden Gate Bridge!  I was lucky enough to cross on a bus tour, so I was inundated with tons of cool facts, I will leave you with one...if you decide to jump off the bridge (dumb move), you will be in the air for 9 seconds, ONLY 3 jumpers have survived this otherwise perilous fall.
author: Chris G.

description:
Visited San Francisco this summer and was able to encounter the bridge on multiple occasions.  I went on a great food tour that made a stop at Golden Gate Bridge.  I was also blessed to have the chance to run across the bridge twice while running the San Francisco marathon.  

Maybe its because I am not from the area, but to me,  there's just something quietly majestic about seeing and crossing the Golden Gate Bridge.  It feels like this perfect marriage of the human spirit and human ingenuity.

Its one of those things that's breathtaking no matter the weather or temperature.  It has this sleepy feel during the early morning, it also can be a bit spooky and eerie when surrounded by the fog no matter the time of day!  Then, it has a way of looking grand and stately all lit-up at night.

What more can I say that hasn't already been said so eloquently by our fellow yelpers?  Just like the Grand Canyon, Niagara Falls, or the Rockies, you have to see it for yourself.  There's truly something transformative about the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Trey S.

description:
Why is it called "Golden Gate Bridge" when in fact its Red. Should it not be called the "Red Bridge" instead? R patiently explained that a certain part of the day, when the Sun hits it, it turns golden. True? Whatever reasons why its called "Golden Gate" , it cannot be denied that it's BIG.

My first time in San Francisco and I was very happy to have such greatness friends who picked me up from the airport and took me to a tour at the Golden Gate Bridge. The weather was very nice when I got there but around 3 pm while we where having fun taking pictures and enjoying the view, the fog came and it suddenly got too cold. 

It would have been really nice to walk from one side to the other like what I usually do in Japan. Hopefully when I get to visit San Francisco again, I will have this chance and maybe i can see the reason why it's called Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Ideru C.

description:
My absolute favorite spot in the world. Nothing beats a visit to the Golden Gate on a clear sunny day. Even when it's foggy, it's still a site to see. I've walked it, biked it, driven it and it still brings a smile to my face every time. 

There are plenty of buses that can take you here or just take a cab/uber (~$12 from downtown). Take your time to enjoy this beauty.
author: Roll N.

description: So we brought our kids to show them the infamous Golden Gate Bridge.  Afterall,  SanFrancisco is known for this.  We are from Washington,  so basically we're just from the US but we're still tourists not locals of San Fran. we drove there and luckily found one parking spot knowing this is a busy tourist area.  WE decided to climb this cement structure where people pose and take photos and behind them is the great view of the Golden Gate bridge.  Mind you,  the Golden Gate is colored Brick,  maroon kind.  Lol.  Nothing golden at all.  But the view surrounding it is magnificent!  I dont know why the city didnt maintain the tourist clean,  but the structure itself was hard to get up to.  Pretty accidental prone.  It was pretty nasty and dirty.  They should clean it up and make it tourist ready.  Be prepared and come in warm clothing.  It's extremely windy.
author: Cynthia G.

description:
Not only is it home to me, but it's a very beautiful, majestic bridge, especially on a foggy morning. There's no bridge quite like it, avoid it sometimes in the summer if you don't like our cold and windy summers, however, on a clear day, or at night, it's breathtaking. 

You can go up on Marin Headlands (from SF first exit on 101 N) and take amazing photographs and walk along the many trails. Also, the visiting center is on the right side and somewhat crowded. Also, you can go to Sausalito and grab a bite to eat by the waterfront.
author: Carolina S.

description: Majestically breathtaking... No wonder this bridge is one of the most photographed bridges in the world. It is truly impressive and a MUST when visiting San Francisco. Plus, you can go through it for free and visit Muir woods!!
author: Michelle M. C.

description:
Went here this morning and parking is not too bad especially on a holiday.  Parking is only $1 for an hour should be good to get glimpse of the bridge and walk halfway thru the magnificent bridge. They have public restrooms and souvenir shop which you could avail a little something to bring home to.

Driving from socal to bay are is  no joke  but once you get here you would  not regret a single thing.
author: Roland C.

description:
Iconic. What else could you say?

Lots of friendly tourists but not surprisingly crowded even on the weekends. Even if there is a crowd, it will dissipate quickly as tourists are moving on to other features. It's a different feeling from driving across the bridge or seeing it from afar to actually stand at the foot of the bridge and walking across it.

Parking though, is such a hassle. But parking in SF is always a hassle .__. No tips from me other than taking a right when you get to the entrance to the bridge and park in the Presidio Park area and walk over. Less than a mile!
author: Lucy Z.

description: There you are my friend.  Missed you and the comfort of seeing you each morning.  Back when I was a kid, I recall how so many mornings you broke through the morning fog and glistened in the sunlight.  So comforting knowing you are still there like a Sentinel guarding the entrance to the Bay.  Now that I am in San Francisco occasionally on business, I enjoy watching you from my office; a quiet moment of reflection to center my soul.  So iconic, regal, and a symbol of our historic pinnacle of the Industrial Age, just watching you calms me and prepares me for the day.  Thank you Golden Gate for being there for us(and for me); a reminder of what this Nation can do when we put our hearts and soul into something constructive :)
author: Christopher C.

description:
I'm trying to think what I can add to the extensive reviews of this amazing SF site--probably not much other than some practical things to maybe aid a visitor.  For example, I recommend you get to the bridge the following way: Take the Bart to Powell St stop and walk to Mission and 5th by the old Mint building.  You want the stop in front of the Mint Building (the one on Mission st not 5th) and you will be looking for the Golden Gate Transit.  Now, you'll want to jump on the 10, 70, or 110 buses and don't worry about having the exact fare (about 4.50 at the time of this review) because you'll get a card with your change if you overpay (like putting in a 5 dollar bill).  The GGT buses are very nice and clean and you'll enjoy the ride down to the GGB.  

Once at the terminal on the SF side of the bridge, you can use the facilities, take some pics, or visit the shop before you walk over.  Walking across the bridge is a must-do event--it's very windy so bring a hat and jacket if you don't have a lot of padding.  Once you cross the bridge to Marin County side you can again find restrooms and water fountains to break for your return walk back across the bridge.  Hop back on the bus by walking under the pedestrian tunnel and grab your GGT bus back to Mission and 5th.
author: David D.

description:
Very pretty bridge! I mean, really, what more can I add to the 1500 reviews already here? Even though it wasn't my favorite thing we did on our trip, it's worth a stop. Here are some tips for tourists that will make your trip smoother:

1) Check the webcam online for fog before you go. If it's a foggy day (which happens quite often), all your efforts will be for naught since the bridge will be almost completely invisible.

2) Dress warm. It's very cold and windy, even in the summertime. Part of why I chose not to walk the bridge was due to how cold and miserable I was. I recommend bringing layers.

3) Ladies, don't wear a skirt or dress! Unless you want to have Marilyn Monroe moments all day. I wanted to look nice for pictures...boy was I wrong.

4) The bridge is surprisingly hard to get to if you're trying to get there on your own. The BART doesn't go anywhere near it. We had to take the BART to the Embarcadero, walk several blocks to a bus stop, and take the 10, 70, or 110 bus (the Golden Gate Transit) over, which took forever due to traffic downtown. Fare for the bus is $4.50, and they don't take credit cards, so make sure you have cash on you. The cash is loaded onto a bus card (really annoying if you don't have exact change, because what are you going to do with extra money on a SF bus card after you leave?). The whole process took a couple of hours. I'm sure there were closer bus stops we could have taken but it was surprisingly hard to find out information on it. For a major tourist attraction, I was surprised at how inaccessible it is if you're not traveling by tour group.

5) Definitely consider biking across it. My boyfriend and I weren't feeling up to it that day, but upon seeing everyone whizzing by on their bikes, we were so jealous. There's plenty of places within the city to rent bikes. The Presidio is also a fun area to bike around afterwards.

Hope that helps people!
author: Katie H.

description:
When I look at the bridge, I get a rush of positive thoughts. I think of the way it was financed and the 1920 engineering involved and the great nation and leadership that made it possible - like the Hoover dam. 

I also think of my Dad's generation and how often they sang and danced to that song - I left my heart in San Francisco. It's probably the most beautiful city that I've ever been to. So much so that I thought about the what if's - what if my parents settled here as opposed to Chicago. Nothing against Chi-town by the way. I'd be a 49er fan, I'd be driving a Prius and working for Google, I'd be......but we digress. 

The bridge is so beautiful as the waters glisten underneath it on a sunny day. Sure the fog gives it a different character. It's just wonderful to see, whether you're driving in from Lake Tahoe or coming up from SFO. Or even by foot from Chrissy field. I'd always throw in a 12 mile round trip jog from Fishermans wharf after work - there are some nice pics that you can take from Fort Mason. 

There are also a bunch of nice views from all the vantage points. Especially while you're having dinner from one of the piers. To really enjoy the bridge, I'd park and walk the entire length and back. The cute little gift shop is a lot of fun too. If you are fortunate, you'll see the workers actively fixing the bridge. Heck, come back often, it's a great place to reflect.
author: Gerry T.

description:
I just found out that you can rate bridges... FANTASTIC! Very happy to state that this bridge did not collapse while I crossed it. 

Well this bridge has a special place in my heart as I learned to ride my bike on this bridge. Fair warning, IT IS NOT FREE TO CROSS! Theyll charge you anywhere between 5-9$ to cross the bridge.
author: Maxwell M.

description: A must see when in the Bay Area and one of the greatest bridges in the USA.  We hike to the bridge from Miran and the views along the way were breath taking. A national historic bridge for all to see when there in Northern California.
author: Gail H.

description: This structure never gets old. Always a treat to cross this national landmark. Regardless of the time or weather.
author: Peter C.

description:
Wow......seriously Wow!!! I had not visited the Golden Gate Bridge since I was a young child, but those distant memories paled in comparison to what I experienced while driving across on this crystal-clear day.

The Golden Gate Bridge is considered by many as one of the top ten construction achievements of the 20th century. This amazing steel suspension bridge, which was built in the mid-1930s, spans the Golden Gate strait, which is a one-mile-wide, three-mile-long channel between San Francisco Bay and the Pacific Ocean. The bridge links the city of San Francisco to Marin County to the north, via Highway 101.

If the weather is clear, you can look off to one side of the bridge and see the city of San Francisco and Alcatraz Island. Off to the other side is the Pacific Ocean. The views were simply breath-taking. On many days this bridge is shrouded in fog, and the long, lonely blasts of the foghorn are the only thing reminding you that you're near the water.

Depending on time of day, the traffic can be a bear, but just relax and realize that you're on the freaking Golden Gate Bridge, Dude!

Fun facts that you should know about the Bridge....

* The famous International Orange color of the bridge was originally used as a sealant for the bridge, but the bright orange color became popular, and is now available for sale from Sherwin Williams Paints.

* The architects of the bridge drew their inspiration for the Art Deco design elements and the graceful suspension design from the Manhattan Bridge in New York City.

* On the south side of the bridge a 36.5-inch-wide cross-section of the suspension cable, containing 27,572 wires, is on display.

* The movable median barrier between the lanes is moved several times daily to conform to traffic patterns. On weekday mornings, traffic flows mostly southbound into the city, so four of the six lanes run southbound. Conversely, on weekday afternoons, four lanes run northbound. During off-peak periods and weekends, traffic is split with three lanes in each direction.

* And as my dear friend Michelle M. pointed out in her review, this is the 2nd most popular suicide spot in the world. After a fall of four seconds, jumpers hit the water at around 75 mph. Most of the jumpers die from impact trauma. *SPLAT*

Please enjoy this marvel of engineering and tourism for what it is, and leave the high-diving exploits to the professionals.
author: Steve E.

description:
Such a beautiful landmark! It is very easy to see why it is considered to be one of the seven modern wonders of the world.

During my visit to the bridge I was able to find very reasonable parking in the dirt lot close to it ($1 an hour I believe), there were also public restrooms which were decently clean. Between the parking lot and the bridge (which is a quick walk) there are many great photo opportunities. 

My friend Flor and I walked to the first stanchion (we had a lot to accomplish in a short amount of time, and she told me that walking the full bridge takes about an hour), and took advantage of some wonderful photo opportunities. 

Basically: the bridge is a SF institution. You can not visit this city and not make a quick stop at the Golden Gate.
author: Zoie H.

description:
Majestic Fortress

Breathtaking Sight To Behold

Our Golden Gate Bridge
author: Donna T.

description: Most beautiful scenery from this bridge. Great for walking across but be prepared for the winds.
author: Julie Z.

description:
I've biked the bridge and have taken about four Golden Gate cruises; the view never gets old! I almost ended up moving to SF, interviewing for Google and a couple other tech firms a few years ago, but decided to stay in the midwest as my family needed me there. I come to visit friends in the bay area annually just in case my girlfriend and I decide to make the move later on. The Golden Gate is an iconic landmark, just west of Ghirardelli Square. We haven't tried driving across the Golden Gate, as the tollbooths are automatically operated and there's a strict process in place for rental cars, but plan to next year to see the redwoods. Such a beautiful city, going to be trying out the sunset dinner cruise on my next visit.

Best,
Charlie
author: Charlie K.

description: This place was an amazing experience. My husband and I very much enjoyed our day there. The views are spectacular and one of a kind. The diversity of people you encounter is incredible. Definitely a must!
author: Margarita P.

description:
Love driving through this bridge especially if you're on the top deck of one of the bus tours! If you're lucky you can get some wonderful views of Alcatraz Island and the city. Sometimes you can even see the fog rolling down the hill! If you're on a big bus tour or convertible you'll want to bundle up or cover your nose because when thay fog starts rolling it's very chilly :-) 

Crossing the bridge is approximately  $7 and there are no cash tolls on the way back to San Francisco, so be sure to prepay or get the Fast Trak.
author: Nasha W.

description: Awesome bridge across the Pacific ocean waters enter into the mainland. Worth walking across or driving over it. Its night view is more beautiful to watch.
author: Omar H.

description:
Do you like fog? Then boy are you in for a treat! This is a fog lover's dream! Every once in a while a giant red thing gets in the way but other than that, you get all extreme fog action you can handle!

Let's look at the deets:
You got gray fog
you sometimes got grey fog
you got low hanging fog
you got fog that creeps in like a ninja
you got scary movie fog
you got fog on fog action (not for the squeemish)

All in all, EXCELLENT VIEWS.
author: Norman S.

description:
The first time I saw the Golden Gate I was disappointed in the color. I must have just been 6 years old. I was expecting a gold color. If you don't want to let your children have a huge disappointment of their life you might want to give them a heads up. 

Tourists say that the thing they enjoy most about SF is driving over the bridge on a bike.  They say it a way to really soak it all in. It is too slow by foot... too fast by car and just right on a bike.

I wouldn't know first hand. I've never done the journey by bike but from what I hear it is sort of thrilling. You feel the wind and are not isolated from everything the way you are when your in a car. I hear the cross winds can be strong so do be careful.

No matter what method of transportation you choose this is a beautiful place to be. The views are stunning. Even on a foggy day you will still enjoy your limited views. On a foggy day the top of the bridge is sort of covered with fog and it is just a sight to see somehow.

One fine photo opportunity for you instagram folks here. While your in the area be sure to get a photo of the six painted ladies and Lombard St. 

Warning: you need fast track to enter the city.
author: Stefan T.

description:
A must visit while in San Francisco.

Free to travel on by foot or by non-motor vehicle on the east side. We rented bicycles to cross. (See here https://www.yelp.com/biz/sports-basement-san-francisco?hrid=PIehI7Ypw86e9U5TbTJymw&utm_campaign=www_review_share_popup&utm_medium=copy_link&utm_source=(direct))

Beautiful views from both the south sides and north sides of the bridge. Bikers use the left side of the east side and walkers use the right side.

It can get windy.

Bring your camera and enjoy the views.
author: Rawlins R.

description: A must-see in San Francisco. We walked the bridge in the mild rain and heavy wind. Our hair was a mess, but we did not care what we look like, it was an obligation as a tourist in the city! It was totally worth all the hassle! I'm very impressed with this huge construction and will definitely come again if I have a chance.
author: Anita T.

description: Crossing the bridge from the fort point to the other side is a really beautiful walk. However suggest doing this on a pleasant sunny day. We did this last weekend and it was too foggy and too cold so coming back to fort point was a struggle. It was more windy coming back also because you are facing the cars going the other side and it was really loud because of the traffic so I didn't enjoy the way back but certainly it's a must.
author: Heliana M.

description:
One of the most iconic bridge in the world!

Every time I come here to show family members who are out of state/country, I can't help but take a picture of it.

I've drove on it several times, walked across it once, and I will bike it one day!
author: Angela L.

description:
For the people that say it's just a bridge, why did you go out of your way to see it then? The Golden Gate Bridge is special because it is a landmark the represents the city of San Fransisco. It has been seen in many movies and TV shows and is known as one of the most archetypal bridges in the world. One thing that comes to mind every time I visit is how incredible it is that man can create something so strong and exceptional. 

The bridge itself is fully functional. You can skate, bike or drive across the bridge any time of day. You can enjoy the crisp fog in your face or reap the beauty from one of the many viewing points. 

If you're reading this you're probably thinking about visiting so make sure you have cash because this is a toll bridge. If you're wondering if it is worth the visit-it is. The Golden Gate Bridge is something everyone should see at lease once. 

Check it out!!!
author: Nicole B.

description: What a beauty! Cross the bridge either by car, bike, or foot. Cross under the bridge by boat. Fly over the bridge by helicopter or plane....whichever transportation you choose, its always a great site and adventure. Yes, many of us have been living in the bay, we all have traveled over it once, but sometimes we don't appreciate it as many people that travelled from all over the world-like a tourist. Lol...so, this time around after many years of seeing this beauty, I'm still amazed at the angles of this bridge. Yes, you heard me right....angles and lines. Wow!
author: Jennifer G.H. W.

description: Beauty at it's finest whether driving or walking on the bridge. I hardly ever pass by the bridge in all honesty but whenever I do, I always enjoy it's view. I honestly fine the bridge to be a it's finest when it is a clear sunny day in San Francisco. It's amazing how many people visit this bridge no matter what the weather conditions may be, but, it's to be expected since it is one of San Francisco's tourist spots.
author: Stacey M.

description:
The best birthday trip to Golden Gate Bridge for the past two years.

It is the most amazing, yet beautiful scenery.
Relaxing, fun, and great road trip vacation.

Definitely worth the drive for a memorable birthday as always.
author: Julie N.

description: The Golden Gate Bridge is a monument to California culture
author: Amanda C.

description: Amazing spot to get a picture of the Golden Gate Bridge. Nice souvenir store , that also sells coffee and hot chocolate.
author: Cathy F.

description:
How can anyone give the Golden Gate Bridge fewer than 5 stars?

One of my favorite places to run across and back, when in SF and getting some exercise - iconic!
author: Kenneth B.

description: Such a beautiful bridge. We rented bikes near Ghirardeli Square and rode the bikes across the bridge, to vista point and back. I recommend doing this. It is the best way to see the bridge, in my opinion. If you decide to do this, there is free 4 hour parking close to the San Fran Maritime Museum on Beach St.
author: Mailoha A.

description: The Golden Gate Bridge! What's not to love? We were at the nearby sutro baths(also recommend seeing) Which had a nice trail to hike on our way to see a wonder of these United States! A must see if your visiting San Francisco.
author: Chase H.

description: It was a lot of fun walking across the bridge. It was my first time and I didn't expect so much fog (San Diego native here). Who knew! But nonetheless, our trip to SF wouldn't have been the same without visiting the GG bridge. So many tourists, and parking wasn't too bad. Don't park at the welcome center instead park on the presidio park side and walk there, the view is amazing and parking is cheap.
author: Grace L.

description:
I was curious if anyone left any negative reviews for the GGB and not surprisingly, there were a few. The funniest one was "The bridge uses too much paint, is expensive, and is a hazard to people's health. It should be closed." LOL! Are you kidding me?! 

Anyway, my last visit to the bridge was probably the 5th or 6th time. It never fails to take my breath away, this beautiful and majestic man-made creation. Yes, it is a terrible tourist thing to do but the bridge is synonymous with the beautiful town of SF.
author: J T.

description:
Even if I'd never set foot on it, I could give this bridge 5 stars.  It just looks perfect sitting there.

It's color stands out just enoph,  but the design is amazing.

You can get to the bridge many ways.  I'm guessing most get here by car, ready to drive across.

Being the most famous symbol of the city.   Many tours at least include a quick visit if not a crossing.

I usually take a MUNI bus.  There are other busses, but with MUNI I already have a ticket.

One there I look at the views.  Walking on the bridge is free and has great views.  I always am glad I came.  

So from near or dar, I give it five stars.
author: Mark B.

description: Wow! A must see, absolutely stunning piece of architecture and breathtaking views of such an iconic bridge. It's definitely a must see in your travels
author: Brenden B.

description:
Well today was my first time going on this amazing landmark of ours! I've lived in California all my life and of course been to SF, but never went on the Golden Gate Bridge. Crazy, right!?!

It actually wasn't even a planned trip to go on it. We were going to Muir Woods and didn't know we had to take this bridge to get there. Lol. Yeah, we don't look @ directions till we leave the house. Also the people I was with, thought there was another way to get there besides going on the bridge.

Well one of my things got checked off my to do list. This bridge is amazing. I know it's just a bridge, but just riding on it and thinking of when it was being built to how much it has gone through, and also how it's one of the top 10 bridges to see, ever! Yeah, it's sorta kinda something big and to be excited about. 

You could also take a walk on there too or ride a bike. There was a lot of people walking. Families, kids, tourists, crazy traffic on that end. I really want to take a walk on here so I could get pics of the ocean and also say that not only have I rode on here in a car, but also walked on it too.

So, when coming from the SF side you don't pay the toll then, it's when you are heading back from say Muir Woods or just that side is when you pay. However I guess they don't charge on the weekends cause we didn't pay the $7 that was required. We just went right through the paying booth. So yay for the weekends and making my first time worth wild lol.  

Once again, it's a MUST to see!!
author: Akemi H.

description: We love visiting SF, and especially talking a walk across the Golden Gate Bridge. There is always lots of people, but on weekends it just gets crazy. So if you want it to be not that crowded, try coming during weekdays. Most of the times it's super windy and chilly on the bridge, so make sure to dress accordingly. But the views are definitely worth it! And of course you get a good exercise.
author: Max J.

description:
I love the Golden Gate Bridge.  My Friday night attitude adjustment drive includes driving to Marin Headlands and taking more photos of the bridge.  Thousands of tourists gather to my bridge and enjoy man-made beauty combined with natures beauty.  I live very close to the bridge and some days drive to and walk across the 4-mile span just for exercise.  It's great to be a tourist and enjoy what's in our backyard.  

Traffic is often bad and tourists battle for parking.  The wait is worth it.
author: Veda F.

description:
The prettiest bridge around.  Love the deco look.

If you're driving and you're an out-of-towner, the "Just blow the toll" thing will be unnerving.  They send you the toll envelope to your registered address.  Not a ticket, just the toll.  You just better hope your registered address is up to date and/or you weren't in a rental car.

And if you walk across, there's a good chance you'll spot some of the abundant sea life.  I've glimpsed whales, dolphins, sea lions and seals from the pedestrian path.  It's a must. Obviously.
author: Anjee D.

description:
Amazing landmark and tourist attraction of San Francisco. Worth the hassle of getting there for sure! Go!!! 

Things to note: CHECK THE WEATHER! The fog in SF can be extremely dense to the point where you won't even be able to see the bridge.
author: Allison J.

description:
Even if obscured by fog much of the time, views of the bridge are so iconic. 

While the tolls and traffic around rush hour are rather big cons, the pros of the immense span and views of the bay out-weigh the bad.  The history of these red arches is amazing, and every time I journey across the bridge on my way out of SF, I am reminded of why this bridge is such a key part of San Fran.
author: Alexis R.

description: It's pretty hard to comprehend how engineers in the 1930s could build such a modern marvel. Seeing the Golden Goldengate Bridge in person is one of the most amazing sights on the planet. Seeing it in picture doesn't do it justice. I was a little afraid to walk across the bridge, but after doing it it was one of the greatest experiences of my life! If you plan to come to San Francisco walk across the Golden gate Bridge!
author: Terence W.

description: Call me a bridge enthusiast as this is my second bridge review.  When you visit San Francisco you have to see this bridge.  As soon as I caught a glimpse of the bridge, the Full House theme started playing in my head.  I walked across part of the bridge and what an amazing view! Bring a jacket with you as it was pretty cool walking across. The Golden Gate makes all other bridges look like chumps.
author: Scott C.

description: We rented bikes from Sports Basement which was perfectly located at the base of the bridge, and the free on-site parking was a nice perk.  Biking the bridge was one of my very favorite adventures during our 3 days in San Francisco.  The weather is constantly changing- I was hot when we first started but then it got cold on our return over the bridge, so I am glad we stuffed jackets into the bike pouches. I had a baby seat attached to my bike carrying out 3yo. My husband rode with a tandem kid attachment with our 6yo and our 8yo had his own bike. It was the perfect set up.  It was quite busy, even on a Wednesday in November and although the path is striped for pedestrians on one side and bikers on the other side, some people were completely oblivious (stopped taking photos in the middle of the path) and it was tricky to mauever at times.  But as long as you're not in a rush, just slow down and enjoy the adventure!!  I would love to do this again!
author: Melissa P.

description:
Worst.  System.  Ever.  

Had a rental car.  Tried online system several times but it said maintenance problem.  

Called.  Waited forever to access a rep.  Asked to add my email after giving my credit card number but rep said she just closed my account and couldn't go back to add an email.  She also said I probably had issues with online because you can't enter a start and end time that's the same.  Enter in half hour increments.  Example 1 to 1:30 pm.  Err on side of over inclusion.   

Called two days later because I hadn't seen a charge.  Tried to access my temp account number but could not. Rep said temp account number can't be accessed by one time payers.  That's not what it's for.  Told it takes 48 hrs to 1 week to get charged.  She apologized about email thing and added it saying it would take 2 days to get a notice I was in the system.  

2 days later nothing. 

Called 1 week after crossing toll and said I hadn't seen a charge to my credit card or a notice to my email.  Told to wait 2 more days because of holidays.  

2 days later nothing by email or credit card.  Called back.  Told to wait another 2 more days and to chill out and that my temp access number was my salvation if rental car agency tries to charge me for violation. 

2 days later nothing by email or credit card.  Called back.  Told it actually takes 10 business days to get something.  Bridge sends photo to dmv. Dmv sends confirmation to bridge.  Bridge contacts these guys who are a third party contractor to charge your credit card.  

2 days later, still waiting.  Is this not the most retarded system ever designed?

11 business days later: still nothing. Called and was told to wait more. I told them I received notice that a vendor's system was compromised so my credit card will be cancelled next week.  I asked if they could please just take my money.  They said no but would transfer me to someone who could change my credit card number.  I was transferred and that person said for sure by now a violation notice has been sent from golden gate to the rental agency. I asked how they could circumvent their department.  She said not her problem. Call the rental car company.  I asked her to update my card number nevertheless.  She refused.  Said it was pointless at this point.  Good grief.
author: Bart D.

description:
Yelp's 365 Review Challenge 2014 #362 - #365

The Golden Gate Bridge is the mecca of all the San Francisco landmarks. What I like about the Golden Gate Bridge is viewing the arches and red cables that loom around the bridge. Crossing the bridge is a fun experience when you're driving towards Golden Gate Park. On a clear day, it's nice to check out the view of downtown and the rest of the city. Lots of people crossing with their bikes or walking around. 

It's nice to see boats crossing under the bridge with their sails and the tour boats full of tourists taking pictures. Indeed, the bridge is a modern landmark and whenever you see a picture of San Francisco, you'll always see the Golden Gate as it's symbol. 

Let's not forget it has been seen in many movies and photographed by professionals. Take your friend, family member, and out of town visitor to the bridge to enjoy the beauty of San Francisco.
author: Paul B.

description:
This bridge is absolutely beautiful. It's one of those things that you'll have to see for yourself to really have an appreciation for it. Words and pictures will never do justice to its beauty. 

My girlfriend and I figured the best way to experience the bridge without having to deal with parking and traffic was to bike across it. We started from near the fisherman's wharf and mostly rode right by the water, on the San Francisco Bay trail, past the Palace of Fine Arts Theatre, and up to the bridge. Going one way, it was about 7 miles or so, to the north end of the bridge. Make sure you wear some kind of sweater or jacket because the winds were extremely strong as we rode across. There was a separate lane for bikes and pedestrians, which was nice and convenient. 

Once you get closer to the bridge, you start to see how enormous of a structure it is. I mean it is gigantic. Truly a marvel of engineering. From it, you get a very nice view of the city, the bay, and alcatraz island. The gift shop is nice with lots of touristy goodies. 

If you want to experience the bridge another way, I highly recommend riding bikes across it. But even if you don't, definitely visit here if you ever get the chance, you won't regret it!
author: Alvin B.

description: We were headed to Northern California and we went acrossd the golden gate brige back on March 2009 and the view was awosome.
author: Ethan H.

description: Absolutely amazing view of the Golden Gate Bridge! Every time I am in town I always have to come and drive over the bridge or walk it. Love looking over the bridge to see one of the most beautiful city's in California! If your coming to visit, I would suggest coming here and take in the view of the city. You can't beat anything like it.
author: Magz K.

description:
Beautiful bridge especially with some fog overshadowing the tips of the bridge 

Cars passing by was loud and super cold today but still loved the scenery and just being on the bridge:) 

Two sides to walk guys! Great to be here today
author: Tiffany S.

description:
As one of the primary iconic symbols of San Francisco, the Golden Gate Bridge is quite spectacular to see. 

We started our hike at Lands End and ended at the Golden Gate Bridge. It was increasingly chilly as we got closer to the bridge with the fog becoming more dense.  There were several areas to sit and have a snack. A restaurant was available for lunch, but we didn't eat there. 

All of the signage was clearly marked and there was ample public transportation to get us back to Lands End.
author: Kate R.

description:
Crossing the Golden Gate is a great way to be overcome by "holy fuck, am I lucky to live here?!" This is true whether it's foggy or clear, but clear enables better views of the blue water of course. 

If anyone wonders why it's so expensive to live here, this is why. Well, one of the reasons. Enjoy!
author: Sue Ellen E.

description: This was an adventure. Beautiful view and the energy is amazing! This was my first time walking the bridge, parking was great and it's easy access. I went alone during the week. It was quite.
author: Maria P.

description:
So beautiful.... omg. I'm lost at words right now.. I'm like about to tear up sofa king bad. Omg..

The engineering structure is amazing... the color.... everything! And the vibe. Omg... I wished every bridge in the US looks the same as the Golden Gate Bridge. Small or big regardless...

Brb. Gotta take some photography.
author: Joey B.

description:
Probably one of the most well known bridges in United States. As an SF resident I have had many chances to witness this beautiful landmark. 
On foggy days you can only witness parts of the bridge, usually missing the top of the bridge which creates a mystery feel to it. During the day,
Many people either walk or bike across the bridge to the Marin lands.

My walking experiences were often morning jogs but it's generally busy with tourists. They close off the bridge by sunset to pedestrians but cars remain open to cross. At night the bridge is lit up as a beautiful master piece. There are also various spots in the city to capture the best angles of this bridge. Parking is limited but there are buses such as the 28 line to run pass it for your convenience. 

As for driving across it... It's $6 on the way back into SF and tolls you by capturing your license plate. (no cash accepted, fast track okay) constructed this way to smoothen traffic flow. 
I always find myself crossing the GG bridge from SF  to places like Sausalito, great hiking spots like Muir Woods, Alemere Falls or even Napa Valley. 

Golden Gate Bridge is pretty the mascot of San Francisco. When you think SF, you think GG bridge.
author: Auden W.

description: It's the Golden Gate Bridge....what else needs to be said. Great views!!! Great walks!!!!! Great price (free). I am sold!!!!
author: Rick T.

description:
We never had to pay a toll!!!  My girlfriend and I had our GPS set to "Hoppers Hands", but we somehow got redirected through Fort Scott and ended up in a parking lot near Battery Boutelle (1900) off Merchant Rd.  We parked the car and stepped onto a trail, and immediately saw a sign that pointed us towards the Gold Gate Bridge!  We followed the trail and ended up on a path for pedestrians to walk onto the bridge (one side was for cyclists only).  The trails takes you under the bridge and to the other side, where you can walk up to the bridge entrance!  We walked to the first tower, took some pictures, and decided to walk back to the car.

It was a foggy and chilly morning, and it started clearing up by the time we left.  We got our fix!

Father.IO: There are no POIs along the trail or on the bridge.  I did capture a few areas near the Battery Boutelle though!  Go Humans!!

Pokemon GO!: There are Pokestops along the trail to the bridge, and more Pokestops on the bridge!  There is also a gym at the first tower that we stopped at.
author: Flo K.

description: Beautiful landmark... worth the drive to take a picture, either at day or night!
author: Lisa S.

description: I have lived in the Bay Area all my life, I couldn't recall a time I actually drove or seen the golden gate bridge besides in pictures.  So getting the chance to drive on it and see it in person, was so awesome.  This is definitely the spot, someone visiting from out of town or state or country should check out.
author: Jenny L.

description: What can't I say about this AMAZING bridge!?!?!? It was my first time visiting, and have to say that the park is set up nicely. I love the informational posts along the trail, and the battery close to the bridge is also something to take in while in the area. I found it funny that the battery near the bridge was build around the time of the civil war to keep the confederate army from attacking SF.. Very pretty!!! and I can't wait to see it with the famous FOG ( I usually don't wish for bad weather)
author: Stephanie K.

description: I managed to view the Golden Gate Bridge while travelling on a ship, driving through it on a car and viewing it through a nearby cliff. This bridge just attracts people like no other bridge I've encountered in my life and there is a good reason why it does it so well. The bridge itself has a stunning red colour with a design and size that screams, "I'm the King of all bridges". Seriously, you just need to be on the bridge itself to experience the awesomeness of Golden Gate Bridge: it's big and wide and it feels super solid for such an old iconic bridge! The coastal location of the bridge is stunning and it's located in beautiful San Francisco!
author: David L.

description:
I am pretty sure this would be a better experience if I come here in the morning instead ...

You know why you are here - San Francisco is Golden Gate Bridge and Golden Gate Bridge is San Francisco. Due to lack of time, our group had to come here during nighttime and night view of the bridge was pretty good (but not super amazing due to somewhat limited view of the bridge). The easiest way to get here is utilizing the Muni bus line 28. 

First thing you see after you hop off the bus is the GG Bridge souvenir shop. Just follow the crowd and you will eventually find a little GG bridge model where you can take your picture with the actual bridge.

The bridge wasn't exactly ... golden (shocking huh?), but you gotta marvel its beauty and is is still a such spectacular engineering achievement considering there were no computers when they build the bridge at the time (construction started in 1933 and finished in 1937).

The GG Bridge is a must visit and make sure to take lots of picture!

P.S. - On a sad note, the GG Bridge has the second highest number of suicides in the world.
author: Luke L.

description:
For those of you, like me, who do not live in the area, it may be good to know that you no longer pay the toll in person; your license plate is scanned and a bill is sent to you. Alternatively,  if you have a Fast Track transponder that will work here.  No more back ups like back in the day.

Amazing views and you should expect a lot of activity going on: joggers and other foot traffic off to the sides so staying focused on safe driving is recommended.  

Surprisingly well-organized and efficient crossing even during evening rush hour, although we were headed INTO the city (I know! Who does that?!)
author: Carlene P.

description: Awesome view of bridge and city. Totally worth it to walk across. Definitely recommend to all.
author: Cecilia M.

description:
...and well you should.  The bridge was originally opposed by the local populate as an obstruction to the view...and ferry companies were very unhappy about it.  But the bridge has attained iconic status and I'm always happy to see it...whether it's on the drive to work in the morning or after returning from a trip elsewhere.

It's worth seeing in various weather states...I love the bridge on a clear day but the classic look is when the bridge is wreathed in our famous San Francisco fog.  It's worth visiting in person too but be aware that it is a LONG walk across it.  I've done it a few times, best was on a hike back from the Marin headlands all the way to downtown.  Even the hike across the bridge is not a trivial proposition...it's worth doing at least once but wear your comfy shoes and budget plenty of time.

Make sure to check out the visitor center on the south side of the bridge, it's got some interesting information and exhibits.
author: Alan S.

description:
Yelp Review #1,300

Bottom Line:  My 1,300th review goes to the Golden Gate Bridge because it is an engineering marvel, a historic landmark, a symbol of progress, a memorial to sacrifice, an American icon, a cultural hallmark, a facilitator of recreation and an unrivaled scenic lookout.

In the early 1900s San Francisco's Ferry Building was not a cornucopia of cheese, bread, wine and vegetables; rather, it was a bustling ferry terminal for people and cars traversing the bay between the city and Marin County. Thanks to the industrial revolution and Henry Ford, a bridge to connect the West Coast's busiest city with Marin County across the San Francisco Bay was much needed.  A bridge was so high in demand that Bay Area citizens used their homes and businesses as collateral for construction of the bridge. The bridge was not just any ordinary bridge but it was an amazing feat of civil engineering.  The 4,200-foot main span between the two towers was the longest for a suspension bridge until 1981 and the 746-foot towers made it the tallest bridge of any type until 1993.  Construction 200 feet above the choppy bay and in a windy straight was not easy and 11 workers sadly fell to their death. 

Fast forward 80 years since the 1937 ribbon cutting ceremony and the Golden Gate Bridge is just as popular and photogenic as ever!  Thousands of cars, cyclists and pedestrians cross the bridge every day and the bridge continues to stay ahead of trends with its 100% electronic tolling system.  (Even if you don't have a FasTrak transponder they will send you a bill via a picture of your license plate). The bridge is one of the most photographed structures in the world and thanks to being featured in television shows and movies like Full House and Terminator, it has become a subject of pop culture.

For the best experience, skip riding in a convertible with the Tanner family and walk or bike the bridge.  The bridge is surprisingly great for recreation because there is only a moderate incline to get on the flat bridge from San Francisco.  Additionally, the bike lanes and pedestrian access is separate from vehicular traffic via concrete barriers for safety.  Traffic on the bridge does make it noisy so immerse your senses in the smell of the salty Pacific Ocean and San Francisco Bay and the sights of the pristine Marin Headlands and the dazzling City by the Bay.   The views from the southern access to the bridge (including the Visitor's Center) and the bridge itself are amazing but even more incredible are the views from the lookout on the northern access to the bridge.
