A great way to enjoy the bridge is to bike from San Francisco across the bridge and then coast downhill into Sausalito to take the ferry across the bay back to San Francisco.
author: Courtney K.

description:
It's amazing ... if you can see it. The fog comes and goes and completely covers the whole gate. But if you wait it out, it's a spectacular view.

Also, there are ways to see it for free but to cross it is a bit hefty for the toll but it's nothing compared to the NYC bridges so that's always a perk.
author: Janice L.

description:
What could I possible say about this bridge that has not been said before? It's a nightmare to drive across. I think it is too cold and windy to walk across. Yet it is beautiful, and I never tire of going across it. 

I am inspired, when no one is the car with me, to sing a couple of songs that includes the lyrics "open your golden gate."
author: Terry T.

description:
"This bridge needs neither praise, eulogy nor encomium. It speaks for itself. We who have labored long are grateful. What Nature rent asunder long ago, man has joined today." - J. Strauss on Opening Day. 

5 stars and definite must for anyone visiting San Francisco. The bridge is painted in international orange so it is easily visible to the ships. You get a classic view of the bridge and the bay. Very often there will be fog, but even then it can make for a dramatic photo opportunity. Parking can be tight, so consider a weekday for this part of town.
author: Salman M.

description:
Came here with a friend on vacation in December.  He had seen the bridge before, but I hadn't.  It is gigantic!  I typically don't visit the tourist structures when on vacation, but i wanted to see this bridge.  It was worth it.

The view across the bay to see Alcatraz and the city was also a different perspective.

We noticed on the pay phone the large yellow stickers to help the desperate people make a phone call.  My friend tried to call one to see if they were legit or dark humor, but it didn't work. 

We found out the hard way that there isn't a toll going N to S but there is S to N.  You aren't allowed to stop.  If you don't have the CA toll pass on your out of state or rental vehicle, then you get to pay fines and fees later online when either the bill arrives in the mail or your rental car company automatically deducts it plus another fee for their inconvenience with your credit card bill on file.
author: Sheri C.

description: nice Bridge, great location. Can get crowded and sometimes hard to park for a great view. A really great view is across the bridge I think its called twin views, Marin  county
author: Rudy P.

description: Take a ride across the bridge and take in the sights. Plenty of views to see and get in a good workout too.
author: Joseph B.

description:
I don't usually like "tourist attractions" but this breathtaking spectacle is one worth falling in love with. There are tons of articles about the best places to take a photo of the bridge, but where is the best place to take a photo WITH the bridge? Yes, there is Baker Beach, but my favorite is (surprisingly) at the bridge itself.

Getting there can be quite a feat because it's so popular, but the best way is public transportation, whether you are a local or a tourist. Just take the 28 bus to get there (Google Maps can tell you about the stops) but beware of going around rush hour time when the sun sets.

It's also a popular activity to walk or bike across the bridge, but however you choose to interact with this beautiful piece of architecture... make sure to include it in your plans for the next time you go exploring San Francisco!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is an impressive part of the city.

I definitely didn't appreciate it growing up (or see the appeal in taking visitors to see it), but let's face it, SF - we're pretty darn lucky.

Just beware the madness that is traffic during peak hours!
author: Claire S.

description: Well I have traveled a lot over my life and seen it all.   I can best describe this as driving in the previous night when I turned the corner and laid eyes on the Golden Gate Bridge I had goose bumps.   Felt like a 7 year old kid all over.   Definitely an American icon.   Just enjoyed it and great places for pictures.
author: Craig T.

description:
We stopped by here on out way to Muir Woods and they have a vista point where you can park for free and walk around as well as get on the bridge.

The view is phenomenal but alas there are quite a lot of fog coming down from the higher areas when we were there. We still had most of the bridge visible. I also enjoyed walking on the bridge and see the metallic structure up-close... 

even the surrounding view is very beautiful. Watch out for the people with bikes as they go very fast on the bridge.
author: Bilal S.

description:
Phenomenal best vacation with  love
Bucket list  finally came and experience San Francisco it was amazing  super packed with tourists but i don't regret it .. walked under the bridge took some epic pictures
author: Nina S.

description: Each visit to San Francisco from Las Vegas, we take a few minutes, if not half an hour or longer, to seek peace, thinking, meditating, and enjoying the views of San Francisco, day or night, fog or shine, at the spectacular Golden Gate Bridge. The trails are exciting as well, especially for the children who wish to run amongst the redwood trees.
author: Thomas Chase Leo S.

description:
When I visited back in September, it was my first visit since my childhood.  I didn't remember much at all from any early visits.

There are few bridges in the world that cause so much interest and two of them are in the U.S.A.

It's easy to dismiss the bridge as just a bridge.  Plenty of people think the same of the Brooklyn Bridge.  I've driven across a lot of bridges, most of which are made from concrete and steel and don't look very interesting because they're just bridging the gap.

Seeing the underside of the bridge, I was amazed at the engineering involved to absorb shocks.  Above, on the bridge, it wasn't just about traffic, but people celebrating their visits with their friends and family.  It seemed quite special that people would feel so much just then.  Could a bridge engender warm feelings, as though it had wrapped its visitors in a cozy blanket?  It seemed so.

Sure, you can bike on one side, and walk on the other, and drive between the two, but is it just a structure for transportation, or has it become more?
author: Nobuyuki S.

description:
Beautiful bridge & a must see. It's a world wide landmark in movies and across the world. 

BUCKET LIST Must. 

Total touristy moment here. Now I was informed of the actually scientific structure of the bridge & its def. interesting. Try googling it, you be amazed at the dynamics and work this takes to maintain. 

A drive through @ night is what we did. It was actually more beautiful @ night bc of lit light that run along the bridge. 

There are different stop points to see the bridge. 

Expect a bill in the mail if you don't have a toll pass. They will automatically send you one in the mail, just in case you wonder. 

It's even more pretty when fog runs through it. 

Tip: try renting bikes & ride them through. I didn't get to. But a must next time.
author: Rose B.

description: I mean how could anyone not love the iconic Golden Gate Bridge! It's only drawback is that not other bridges can compare. It's about 1&1/2 mile walk or you can bike across. Many tourists so expect lots is traffic and stop and photo time.  Fog and wind is to be expected so dress accordingly! An  amazing view of the city of San Fran as you crossing the bridge and appreciate just how beautiful the Bay Area is. Occasionally, you will see whales, seals, sea lions or dolphins swimming in the water. Enjoy it!!
author: Linda D.

description: How can anyone pass this bridge and not stare at its breathtaking beauty?  I cannot even begin to understand how this is considered a tourist spot as every time I was in the numerous viewing spots, there were locals running on it / under it / near it, taking pictures and enjoying it just as much as the tourists.   A visit to San Francisco is not complete without one stop at this bridge.  I think anyone visiting the city for the first time needs to go to a couple of viewing spots and take in this gorgeous piece of architecture as well as at least walking out on it to really appreciate it.  We were fortunate enough to have a perfect clear sunny day when we walked over this bridge and had unbelievable views of San Francisco, Alcatraz and even had the pleasure of seeing some sea lions playing below.  Absolutely amazing!
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Being from Sydney, Australia I already have a bridge that I love but the Golden Gate Bridge is big, red and covered in fog. It is a sight to behold.

When visiting make sure to bring warm clothes as the weather can change instantly and you might be stranded halfway as the white clouds start racing past. There are free walking tours and if the group is small I highly recommend it.

If you are on Lombard St (Marina area) catch the #28 muni, it will drop you right at the visitor center. On the way back catch the #28 again but make sure it is going back to Fort Mason/Marina, otherwise you will end up in Daly City (it does go through Golden Gate Park though so an easy way to do the bridge and the park).
author: Tristan L.

description: What an unbelievable attraction. We were fortunate that we got to see the bridge from a view that not many get, from the deck of a cruise ship. We entered the harbor just before dawn and could just make out the lights. By the time it was light we were passing under. It was a tremendous sight to behold. It was something we will always remember. it does not matter how you see it, just go and see it isn person. You will not regret it.
author: Richard F.

description:
Only $7 to cross on your inbound trip toward San Francisco, and $0 on the outbound. That beats the $13 the NY Port Authority is charging to get into the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels and to cross the GW Bridge!

If you're leaving the city, be sure to stop at both the beginning and end of the bridge to catch the scenery. Parking is free and there are bathrooms, at least at the last stop. Not sure about the first.

From a distance, I found the best view of the entire bridge to be along Fisherman's Wharf.

I also didn't realize it was a pedestrian bridge. Awesome.
author: Adam D.

description: One of the most iconic bridges built to date and I'm so lucky that I only live an hour away. Before you actually go on the bridge there's an area called the pavilion where you can stop and take pictures of the bridge or walk on it. You would just have to pay for parking.
author: Tuyen H.

description:
Visiting the Golden Gate Bridge is one of the most popular destinations in the world for travelers.  Many people come to the special viewing areas in the north or south parking lots, take a few photos and leave, but this doesn't give you the same feel for this beautiful structure as actually walking on the bridge.
We were ready for the wind and fog, but what really surprised us is how noisy the traffic is on the bridge! The steel framework under the modern lightweight roadbed amplifies the traffic noise and there are loud whining and clackety-clack sounds as cars and trucks pass over the bridge's expansion joints.  These joints allow the roadway to expand and contract with the extreme high and low temperatures the bridge endures without buckling or cracking the deck.
author: Gary B.

description:
After you're done taking pictures with it from afar, bike across it. Do it. It's so much fun and great to see the city from the bridge view point. It's pretty windy on the bridge so bring a light jacket. It's also marked for bikers and pedestrians, which is nice, and the width is pretty large compared to other bridges I've been on before. 

There's a bike trail around the bridge area and to the other end of the bridge, if you're interested. Just look up some bike rental places. I enjoyed the trail and while there were two challenging hills, I didn't think the trail was that difficult and was pretty fun with the ups, downs, and straight areas. But my friends found it challenging, so maybe it's not as standard as I thought it was. Whoops!

If you don't bike, there are several points near the SF end to take pretty pictures. Just wander around to find the best spot! I enjoyed coming on the weekend because there are less tourists crowding my pictures :x but there's enough places that if you come on a weekend, it should be alright
author: Jeanne K.

description: Walking the Golden Gate Bridge was on both my husband's and my bucket list, so we decided to go this weekend. We parked on the North side of the bridge, took some photos before heading out and walked to the South side of the bridge, taking more photos along the way. We had already planned to eat at the Round House Cafe for lunch before heading back over the bridge, so after a quick bathroom break (of course, the line was longer for the gals than the guys, but it went fairly quickly and the bathroom was fairly clean), we ate lunch. It was pretty good and the view from the restaurant was nice. We took time to look at the displays on the South side of the bridge before going back over, and it was nice to find out some of the history of the bridge. Going back over the bridge we walked more quickly than the first time because we didn't need to stop and take photos or discuss what we were seeing. It was a great experience, and the views were spectacular. We were quite tired when we got back to our car, but it was definitely worth it.
author: Teresa C.

description:
Iconic, fun, crazy, sentimental, a must see if you're ever in San Francisco. 

Actually came up to visit from LA and had to stop at the Golden Gate Bridge again. I've been here countless times but you can ever say you've been to SF if you didn't visit the GG Bridge. 

No till going northbound to Marin County. $4 toll coming into San Francisco. They have parking and overflow parking for $5. Read the signage and make sure you do pay to park or else you'll find your car with an expensive parking ticket. 

My friends and I ran across the bridge today. I ran going NB and pretty much walked and jogged back to the SF side. About 3.5 miles round trip if you run from the new gift shop. 

The GG Bridge also bolster's a new gift shop. Stop on it and grab some souvenirs or postcards. I love the Golden Gate Bridge!
author: Ticha B.

description: Today was exceptional.  The fog rolled in white puffs while scattered sunlight peeked in between to highlight the bridge's warm glow.  What beautiful views of SF and the North Bay to be had and such mild weather.  Just a great day to enjoy traversing this landmark that stretches across the bay.  Worth any walk, ride, or cycling to be had.
author: Angela K.

description: Wait, people review the Golden Gate Bridge, seriously?? Imma gonna look to see how many stars the Bay has.
author: Brie P.

description: The Golden Gate Bridge is a must for travelers coming to San Francisco. It's one of my favorite iconic sites to go to whenever I visit California. It has spectacular views and the structure is incredible. There are different spots that you can view the bridge from that will all give you a great experience from. Just be aware that if you drive, parking is convenient but limited as there's a lot of people who all want to enjoy that experience. I love driving through it every time I come here and it never gets old. I would one day would like to ride a bike through the bridge. Seems pretty fun as I watch others on tour go through it. Bring a sweater as it can get windy and chilly in the city.
author: Roxanne Lynn T.

description: Overall is nice, but definitely over-hyped.  It's not even gold, but red :p some beautiful sights!
author: Michael J.

description:
Travel by foot, on two, or cruise across the bridge on four wheels.
Check out the Golden Gate's website for their full list of what you can and cannot do to get across the bridge - no roller blades or pets are allowed on the bridge.
Allow yourself plenty of time to enjoy the experience, because it can get very crowded on the bridge. Bring your camera to capture its beauty.
If you have a few hours to spend out at the bridge, rent bikes from a bike shop near Ghiradelli. Ride your bike across the bridge to Saulsilito and on to Tiboron. Once you get to Tiburon you can ride back, or have the ferry take you and your bike back to the Golden Gate Bridge. This route is easy to follow and has plenty of areas to stop and eat/drink along the way.
author: Kim K.

description:
I've lived in San Francisco/Bay Area 24 years of my life.  I've crossed this bridge via car for so many years I had lived in Marin. Don't know why I hadn't walked this bridge sooner?  It's beautiful!  Even in the fog.  We walked to the middle to pay respect to a friend whose ashes were spread underneath.  

Walking it reminds me of the tv show Full House.  It was extra foggy, windy, and spring time cold.  My ears hurt badly from the cold wind.  Hopefully next time I come back for a visit I can catch a nice clear sunny day.  Parking was easy for us to find and it was only $2 for 2 hours.
author: Jill D.

description:
"This bridge needs neither praise, eulogy nor encomium. It speaks for itself. We who have labored long are grateful. What Nature rent asunder long ago, man has joined today." -- Joseph Strauss on Opening Day, 1937

There are so few monuments in the world that are so iconic that they are instantly recognizable the world over; the Statue of Liberty, the Pyramids, the Eiffel Tower, and most certainly the Golden Gate Bridge (GGB) can be mentioned in that same breath. Growing up in the Bay Area I had taken for granted this amazing, functional Art Deco masterpiece because that stuff is for tourists, right? Wrong. I recently had a new found appreciation for the GGB when I walked across it with my out-of-town cousin and my 4-year-old, and I got to relieve its majesty through their eyes. It really is something else, and don't let the "I'm too cool to do touristy shit" attitude get you, because you'll really be missing out. Everyone knows, or has heard, all the usual "fun facts" about the GGB, like 600,000 rivets in each tower; 1.7 miles long; towers are 746' high; etc. Well, I dug-up some really cool little known facts--just for you! Enjoy.

-The GGB's paint color is actually called Orange Vermilion (aka International Orange), and was *not* meant to be the final color--which was most likely to be carbon black or steel gray. It was a primer that was applied to protect the steel; consulting Architect Irving Morrow came to like it, as he felt it gave the GGB a more visible look in the fog and complimented the local topography. The military actually wanted it to be painted in stripes, but that's another story...

-"Only" 11 workers died during the building of the GGB, which was a safety record at the time. Bridge builders just assumed there'd be one death for every one million dollars spent on a project (35 workers was the anticipated total).

-The GGB is the top suicide location in the world with over 1,500 deaths. This topic is explored in the 2006 documentary "The Bridge," which I've seen and highly recommend. This film is so controversial that the GGB website won't list it in their database of documentaries about the GGB. 

There's a multitude of ways to view the GGB, but I'd have to say my favorite is via Crissy Field (http://www.yelp.com/biz/crissy-field-san-francisco-2?hrid=rPxhJO6TYPuOUqESIOo5Kg) and I highly recommend walking and not driving, but there really is no "bad" way. However you choose to take it all in, just try not to take it for granted. It's a special treasure that unifies us, and helps us believe the impossible is possible.
author: John D.

description: Just simply beautiful, the views, the walk, the drive over. They all give you a different perspective on the magnitude of this bridge. Highly recommend visiting if your in town.
author: N And N K.

description: I love the golden gate bridge. However, no blame here, but the last time I visited, my friend happened to be in a bad mood and yelled at my other friends and I.
author: Jane S.

description: The image of SF. On our first ever family vacay, I totally had to take my parents to the bridge so we could snap a pic. The only thing was....finding parking is mind boggling. I'm not sure if we just didn't know where to park, but the tiny lot in front of the information building was definitely not enough for the amount of people there. However, we fortunately found someone who was just about to leave and swooped their spot. The vantage point of the Golden Gate bridge is so nice. It makes everything look so majestic.
author: Liang T.

description: This bridge is impressive. It's so much bigger up close than I ever imagined. On your way southbound, take the exit just before into the park and stop by one of the overviews to snap a photo or just gaze in awe at the huge structure, all of San Francisco below you, and the bay beneath with the sun sparkling on the surface. It really is a beautiful moment. Give yourself a few minutes and soak it in.
author: Kelly J.

description:
Beautiful, iconic, wish you were here.

Perhaps I should not have watched so many disaster movies featuring this bridge - I half expected it to sway and break apart because of course EARTHQUAKE or get overrun by great apes.

Note that as of my visit in June 2015, you no longer pay cash, apparently. It's charged to your fast trak (if you have one) or if you don't, you get billed to the address linked to your license plate. This was very freaky to me since I was so stressed out from driving over 2 hours in horrific traffic to go less than 50 miles, and by the time I rolled up to the entrance via San Rafael, with all the traffic so many signs but none mentioning anything about what lanes to use and how much to pay and where to go and OMG construction and jesus, so many cars and OMG I just drove the entire length of this bridge and didn't pay anything and I'm gonna be fined $756 and ooohhhhh, pretty!

(I'm such a tourist.)

On the drive back to San Rafael, again, no signs that I saw about paying anything.  As soon as I got home, I quickly googled "AM I A CONVICTED FELON FOR NOT PAYING ANY FEES ON THE GOLDEN GATE BRIDGE" and that's when I read about how they were making life all easy for us stupid tourists by just mailing you an invoice for $7.
author: Allie A.

description:
If you lucky, you can see the golden gate bridge. Most of the time weather makes the view quite ugly. It's usually foggy or overcast over there. It's a must see when the sun is out, but is sure windy! It's also a fun experience driving through it, but remember you have to pay to go back into the city. Correct change please, if not.. this will make others ppl cranky! We don't want to wait for you!

Met some locals when I was here two years ago on 4th of july weekend. They chewed me out for saying golden gate bridge... to the peeps there... it's called "The Bridge". haha fun times!

I'll see you on July 28... Running the marathon... please don't be cloudy... I think i'm going to take more pictures than running! lol
author: John T.

description:
Absolutely stunning...
We made our way from the wharf to across the bridge. I honestly didnt expect too much because from afar it's just a red bridge. But while biking through it, you have the mountains, city, ocean, and setting/redish sun (we went around 4ish) all in one sight. It was simply breathtaking and easily my favorite part of my san fran trip!
A few tips:
One side is for walking and the other for biking
It gets pretty windy and chilly (sept/oct) so wear layers. It's especially cold at the end of the bridge.
If you are biking, you can take the ferry back to the other side.
author: Jenni J.

description:
This was an obvious must-visit when in San Francisco. I jogged to one end of the bridge and back and the run was outstanding.

There isn't a lot I can say that hasn't already been said by the thousands of previous posters - so I will just end this review early and post a bunch of my pictures!!
author: Justin V.

description: Take a walk across the Golden gate, breath in the fresh sea air, enjoy the beauty of San Francisco. The scenery changes daily/hourly, so you gotta visit more than once. Enjoy!
author: Douglas F.

description: Everyone should drive thru and come see this bridge when in San Fran. Definetely a highlight of the city
author: Cameron H.

description: Historically significant! Significantly historical! This is the GGB! Absolutely phenomenal. A great monument to hard work and a symbol of modernization. When I arrived, there was still fog over the bridge. I got there around 9:00/9:30 in the morning. The fog was there but it was not hindering my view of the GGB. It was more than just a bridge. Being there makes you feel like you are experiencing life's labor and it's effulgence is a breath of fresh air. No matter, how much time you spend there - walking, running, standing, selfie-ing, - it will just leave within you a feeling of love, hope, happiness, and strength. There were several signs on the bridge that indicated the suicide prevention phone number in case you needed help. Mental health is something that should never be ignored. Thank you California for taking care of people struggling. With that being said, this is something that you have to experience to truly understand it's sheer beauty because words fail to capture the essence of it's transcendence.
author: Zain R.

description:
I love this bridge, whether driving or walking across it. Its definitely touristy, but worth your time walking across the bridge. Its was a symbol of those coming from the west for hope and prosperity. Now, its a symbol of hope and prosperity. From afar, it looks tiny, but its actually pretty massive. 

There's no toll going north. But if you're coming into SF, going south, just keep driving through the toll area. The bridge authority will send you a bill, unless you have Fast Track Pass. 

i like to time my drive north with the sunset. Its an beautiful and inspiring drive.
author: Vicky L.

description: I live so close to the bridge but I don't think I've ever walked all the way across it I do spend a lot of time in the Marin Headlands taking pictures of the bridge such a beautiful sight and I must see if you're visiting California
author: Jimmy P.

description:
One the most majestic places on earth everyone should experience this beautiful landmark at least once I plan on seeing it again in the near future. I walked across the bridge and it was quite a humbling experience this bridge is enormous pictures can't do it justice. 

I drove across this mammoth structure then immediately found a parking stop at one of the look out parks and put on my walking shoes to do the 3 mile plus walk across and back it was an incredible adventure. This is only way to understand the mass undertaking it took to design and construct this massive monument. It was a very patriotic and humbling experience this should be on everyone's bucket list.
author: Dave O.

description: Ok so I guess I'll add my 5 star review of many other 5 star reviews of the GG bridge here on Yelp! It is the most iconic and popular thing when people think of San Francisco and it is what people from traveling from different parts of the world want to see when they come to the Bay Area. I'm sure it's for a reason right?! YES! This bridge is beautiful and even myself as a local am in awe of it whenever I get to see it or cross it. You can walk across it and even bike across it and what you see are amazing views of the bay and of the city, which as you can imagine makes up for a great photography session! There are so many places on either side of the bridge where you can take great photos which is great. Come and stop by and this amazing structure of you are a tourist and continue to admire it if you are a local!
author: Anne R.

description: This place has beautiful views, and there are amazing places to take pictures all around here. While there are amazing places to take photos, there are also a lot of people crowded around popular photo spots, so sometimes you have to wait for a spot. If it is a nice day and you are around here, I would definitely recommend coming here for a visit.
author: Derek N.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is one of the most popular bridges in the world as well as a San Francisco landmark. With it's goldish/orange color it can be seen from miles away on a clear day. This amazing bridge opened May 27, 1937 and celebrated it's opening for a whole entire week! A day before automobiles were allowed to cross this bridge an astonishing 200,000 people either walked or roller skated across, can you imagine all those people?! This is a suspension bridge which held the record for being the longest one of it's kind until 1964. This bridge not only takes you from the San Francisco Peninsula to Marin County but also spans across the 3 mile long channel between the SF Bay and Pacific Ocean.

I've lived in the Bay Area pretty much my whole life and I can count on one hand how many times I've driven across this bridge. I've always seen it on TV and in movies, heard great things about it and would see it while visiting San Francisco.  It wasn't until adulthood and my own curiosity that I finally decided to drive across to see what the hoopla was about and wondered where I would end up. (Mind you I drove by San Quentin and discovered the Richmond Bridge my first time going over the Golden Gate lol). Driving from SF over the bridge you do not have to pay toll which is a plus but on the weekends traffic getting to the actual bridge and going across can be a little slow. It's so beautiful, you can see the beautiful bay, see all the locals and tourists walking across and taking pictures all while trying to take in the amazing color and architecture of the bridge. Some say this is the most beautiful and most photographed bridge in the world and I would have to agree. I absolutely hate going over bridges but this is one bridge that excites me when going over it.

I have yet to walk across the bridge and this is something I'm anxious to do but on a clear summer day so I can take in all the sights and all that the bridge has to offer. The walk across is most definitely an item on my bucket list that I would like to cross off sometime this year! I must say if you live in the Bay Area or in California period and you have not visited this landmark then you are really missing out. Driving across, walking, biking, skating or all of the above are great ways to enjoy the bridge. It is very touristy and really crowded, so plan ahead of time and parking to walk across can be quite tricky but it's so worth it. Come be a part of history!!

*Golden Gate Bridge I plan on seeing a lot more of you!!*
author: Tiffany D.

description: There is a lot of area to just walk around here. Sure...see the main focal point, the bridge, but the entire area around and under the bridge is a great place to just walk, run, and chill out. Even go down lower and get your tan on but I think people nude sun bathe down closer to the beach, so watch out. You can also see the nudies if you're high up on the rocks too, so again...watch out. If you're brave enough, walk the bridge. You can also see Alcatraz and most of the whole city from the bridge and the cliffs nearby. The bridge itself is really magnificent in it's structure and span. It looks to be in pristine condition although it's been there for a very long time. It's still an iconic image in America so be sure to check it out if you're in the San Fran area. It's free, so why not.
author: Josh B.

description: Been living in the Bay Area almost all my life and always go through this bridge especially when the out of family out-of-towners comes to visit. Great bridge with history. The tourist location beside the bridge is nice too. Walking the bridge is windy so make sure to bring a jacket. The toll plaza doesn't accept cash anymore so make sure your car has a fastrac. I believe it's $7 to come back in the city. I have never walked the whole bridge before but one day I will!! They need to repaint the bridge as its already chipping. Great place for picture taking,..highly recommend for you tourists coming to the Bay Area.
author: Edna G.

description:
I lived in the Bay practically all my life, showed all my out of town friends fisherman's wharf, ghiradelli, downtown, and Chinatown but why have I never taken them to the Golden Gate Bridge?? Had another visitor I had to of course show the tourist sites and he wanted to walk the Bridge. How can I deny that??

If you're driving, drive all the way down to the fort and under the bridge (sorry forgot the street name). There's a parking lot at the end of the bridge and you only have to pay on weekends. When I went, it was a gorgeous November day, but quickly turned into a gloomy winter night so bring a jacket... you will freeze your butt off!! Walking across the bridge was a quick and easy walk with a gorgeous view. Took us about 2 hours to walk back and forth and apparently, the only thing to look forward to at the Sausalito side is the bathrooms so hooray! Though we took a while, of course we did all the touristy things like look down the bridge, and take our touristy pictures. One for the scrapbooks! Definitely worth the visit at least once to this historical landmark.
author: Stella Y.

description: Can't get enough of golden gate everrrrr !!! Always a beauty . Whether you want to walk on it , or drive , this bridge will always excite you and make you wonder about technology n mankind
author: Anshul G.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is a must see, must experience in San Francisco. 

TIP#1: Try to come on a non foggy day so you can actually see the bridge!

You can walk, run, or bike it! It's about a 1.7 mile trip from one side of the bridge to the other side, so it's a 3.4 miles round trip.

Don't be afraid to be a tourist. Everyone else is doing it! Take pictures with your significant other, friends, and/or family with the beautiful red bridge. You can get up close pictures and even panoramic pictures from farther away.

Just a few days ago, my friends and I did a 10K run from the presidio to the end of the bridge and back. Although it was raining, we all still had an awesome time :)
author: Lincy H.

description:
Simply fascinating. Nothing to add. I believe that everything about this magnificent landmark has been said.

My recommendation for anybody visiting the Bay Area, making a touristic stop to take a "selfie" or a group picture with this historic bridge is definitely a must. 

The parking in the vista area could be a little hectic because of all he tourist buses, so be prepared to go in a circle around the parking lot a couple of times.
author: Antonio F.

description:
If you give this less than 5 stars, you're a dingus. I am just sayin'

This is staple here in SF, whether you are a local or a visitor. It doesn't get old.

Walked across & back in a little over an hour.
It is really windy so make sure to bring a jacket & GIRLS! tie your hair up! You will thank me later for that piece of advice.

There are markings on the ground that has half of the walkway for bikers & half for walkers but i think it's an unspoken understanding that one side of the bridge is for walkers & one side is for bikers.

There was one bum that was shooting up by one of the big posts, scary!
But I also past an officer on his bike, so I'm assuming her regulated on the guy.

On the walking side of the bridge, you can see the view of Alcatraz in the distance.

Walking across was on my list, CHECK!

All in all, for a Saturday morning, it was busy but not crowded.
author: Camille C.

description:
How can you visit San Francisco and not visit the Golden Gate Bridge?

In New York, what landmark do you think of?  The Statue of Liberty..Duh,
In Rome, what landmark comes to mind?  Most would say the Colosseum,
And at San Francisco, the Golden Gate Bridge of course. 

I've never done SF without hitting up the Golden Gate Bridge.  You can cross the Golden Gate Bridge via car, foot, and bike.  On our last visit, we crossed this bridge through bike.  We were lucky and didn't have a foggy and cold experience while crossing the bridge.  Mother nature winked at us and gave us a free pass to a little sun and great weather.  I had a blast!!

The Golden Gate Bridge is a sight to be seen in person.  You can always view this bridge from the wharf or by car.  But there's no fun in that. I recommend the Golden Gate Bridge by foot or bike.  Yeah Buddy!!


YELP PERSONAL CHALLENGE 2013 - (463/500)
author: Mel C.

description: Great views, nothing else like it in the area, clean, helpful for connecting the bay area communities.  No pot holes so I like good rides and most of the time it's 6/10 traffic so not bad.  Avoid during evening rush hour 4PM-7:30PM
author: Nibia P.

description:
In the SPAN of time I've been in the bay area, I feel like the bridge tolls have gone up. But that issue is just water under the bridge now, because it's an iconic structure that we all love. You'll probably notice almost every single review uses the word "iconic."

On clear days, the view is great and taking out of town friends works well. I've rarely seen traffic too horrible on this bridge. 

I highly recommend pulling over on either end of the bridge and taking in the view. Especially the watch point on the northern end. It has this bronze statue of a stoic sailor looking over the bay. Following his gaze reminds me of the rich history of this bay and the bridge that crosses it.
author: Erik L.

description: As I stood, watching the bridge from afar, it looked so unreal! Make time to STOP and admire the bridge! Like literally, at least for 5 minutes or 10! Take many pictures and walk the bridge!!! Awesome and beautiful experience!
author: Wendy C.

description:
It was such a nice feeling just to be on the bridge and to see the whole city. There are many areas that are good to take good pictures at. Either at the bottom or on the bridge but it's best to go like half a mile away from the bridge at the bottom to take good pictures. 

To get here it was really easy especially the parking it's like right near the bridge for people just to stop and take pics
author: Jannie M.

description:
Of course this is a must see if you're in San Francisco!

I rented a bike from the Fisherman's Wharf and biked it to the Golden Gate Bridge and across to Sausalito. Took the ferry back from Sausalito to the Fisherman's Wharf.

Gorgeous and scenic route!
author: Tina W.

description:
TL;DR - hack the traffic. Any weekend holiday (Easter, Mom's, Dad's, Christmas Eve) will have the traffic brutal by 10.30a, both directions. Plan ahead, and be the early bird that gets the worm. Don't get caught in Crissy Field Presidio traffic, so make sure to see the bridge first, and be headed *out* of the area South, instead of Northwards.

To those jaded about the bridge and sitting in traffic.. this is for you! People spend 5-10 years for a few day vacation to walk across this bridge. It's one of the world's wonders, and it's a feat of brilliant engineering. What's more, it links the National Park of the Presidio with the GGNRA's Headlands... two of the most beautiful places on earth. Stop with being jaded, park your car in the Presidio, go for a walk, and realize we are in one of the most beautiful places in the world. The only thing I ask... have you ever walked across it? You've lived here your whole life and you've never walked across it?!!? Now you... play tourist, park, and enjoy. =)
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: I think it's so lucky to be so close to such a magnificent landmark. People who travel here visit this place and we're lucky enough to have it in our backyards.
author: Maleah M.

description: On a clear day the view is amazing. On a foggy day it's a different kind of amazing. Don't mind the huge crowds and good luck with parking. The walk across the bridge is nice but not a must if time is limited. Do walk out halfway and enjoy the view.
author: Gerald H.

description:
Short story: they have crap-or-zero signs about if/what/how to pay toll.  I cross bridge. It take "FastTrack" SEVEN WEEKS to send invoice, by which time I've left country.  I get back 3 months later to huge fines. I GOT FINES WAVED MAYBE YOU CAN TOO:

HERE'S HOW TO CONTEST/COMPLAIN BY PHONE...  (they make it seem impossible to talk to a person, but follow these instructions in office hours and you will get a person)

* call "FastTrack" on 1-877-229-8655
* say 'english' or press 1
* say 'other information' or press 5
* say 'questions' or press 2
* do one of the following, (depending what they mailed you)
  - say 'invoice' or press 1  (if you just got the invoice)
  - say 'violation' or press 2  (if you got a violation notice)
  - say 'notice' or press 3  (if you got a collection notice)
* (listen through all the stuff about contacting them by web email) THEN 
      - say 'representative' or press 0
* (they ask for your "account number" - ignor that)  
       - say 'representative' or press 0 again.
* (they ask you to verify that you want to speak to a representative) 
      - say yes or press 1

The nice lady waived my "Violation" fines - because I complained that it took them 7 weeks to send FIRST INVOICE - by which time I'd left the country for 3 months, and there was no way i could have known I was even invoiced. I also went on about all my other complaints - bad signage, how was I supposed to know what "FastTrack" means - whey cant they use plain englsh like "Call this number to pay your Toll", why not offer a place to pull over and get a leaflet on how to pay the toll, or offer a box to put your name and address in, so they can send an invoice out right away etc etc.

Good luck!  After you have dealt with your "Violation" fines

THEN COMPLAIN about your bad experience DIRECT TO GOLDEN GATE BRIDGE OFFICE   1-415-921-5858

The more time "FastTrack" and the Golden Gate people have to spend on complaints by phone, the less cost effective it is for them to have such a crap system, and such poor signs and so little assistance for visitors.

I think that they shoudl pay me a "VIOLATION" fee for every extra day it took them to send an invoice after the first 48hrs.  Now that would be real accountability!!

THE BACK STORY:  Horrible confusing badly designed toll system.  I looked everywhere for information as I approached the bridge. couldnt see it.  later told I should have called FastTrack 511 or something, but "FastTrack"? doesnt that mean something about commuters? I'm not a commuter, I'm an out of state visitor.  It didn't say 'CALL 511 TO PAY YOUR TOLL" Why not?  how hard is that? I could have pulled over right after the bridge and done that.   I just went to Google StreetView to see if I can see all the "signage" they claim I sailed past.  Nope. I will post the one feeble sign that I see on Street view, positioned on an on-ramp to 101, with lots of tiny writing, and NO INSTRUCTIONS - barely visible even if you take time to look at it on your computer on the google photo, let alone driving past it in traffic.

Like I say, couldn't figure out what I was meant to do to pay - I'm an english speaker, I'm not too stupid to follow instructions.  There were none.  Wondered if perhaps it would be electronic by plate.  No idea. Doesnt say "We'll snap your plate and send a bill" nothing. 

9/16/15  I cross (violate"?) the bridge .  
a few days later I get home to Oregon and never hear from them.  
10/21/15 I leave the country  (37 DAYS AFTER CROSSING BIDGE). By now I've assumed it was a no-toll day or something.
11/2/15 SEVEN WEEKS AFTER I CROSSED THE BRIDGE an invoice was generated and mailed to me.  YES that is the date ON the invoice.  Not the post mark. But I'd left the country by then, so never saw it.
2/4/16 I return to the US  to a stack of VIOLATION notices, making me a "VIOLATOR"??  and I now have $149 in fines.
2/5/16 I call in per insturctions above and complain and get the fines waved.  I pay the Toll.

So When I call the Golden Gate people (number above) that the invoice is dated 11/2/15.  Golden Gate people are soooo surprised that the invoice was sent soooo late (I read on yelp that this is common) and say it SHOULD NEVER have taken so long, they will "Look into it". "Something went wrong" he said.  

The "FastTrack" woman said it took so long because I live out of state, they have to contact the DMV in my state for my address, and that takes weeeeeks apparently.  APPAULING - they are wasting my Oregon Tax money bugging Oregon DMV for addresses?  I would have gladly just dropped my address in a slot for them if they offered the option.  I'm also going to contact Oregon DMV and tell them to stop wasting OR tax money on processing these CA requests - CA is saving money on toll operators and then shifting costs to OR and other state DMVs to do the work for them.  What crap!
author: Jen C.

description:
If you have a FasTrak, you will go through this toll plaza smoothly.

If you don't, they will send an invoice to your registered address taken from your license plate, and you will be charged a transaction fee.

This plaza is usually not busy so I'm glad it's a breeze!
author: Aj C.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is as iconic in the USA, as the Statue of Liberty and recognizable to people the world over.  A fitting monument to America's ingenuity & industry and a welcoming sight like Lady Liberty for immigrants on the west coast.  The GGB is also featured in movies galore (destroyed multiple times, too) like X-Men: Last Stand, Rise of the Planet of the Apes and several Star Trek movies (so expect it to still be standing in 500 years).

We hiked the 1.7 miles across to Sausalito and back again.  A brisk walk and cold at times, so dress warmly on chilly, foggy mornings.  The fog was like pea soup most of the way across where you can barely see the towers, but had brief clear moments on the Sausalito side to take some nice pictures.  If you own or rent a bike, you can ride across on the west side, while the east side is for pedestrians only.  Of course on the SF side is the Tourist Information Center and Gift Shop where you can sign up for guided tours and buy t-shirts or a red rivet as a souvenir to take home.
author: Chun M.

description: Nice bridge.  We did not drive across it.  We were able to find a place under the bridge where we could take some nice pictures.   It is an impressive bridge and provides a great backdrop for pictures.  This is a must see if you are in the area.  We went to the Presidio to take pictures.  The traffic was light in this area, highly recommend driving to this area.  It is free and fast to get to.
author: Matt S.

description:
There are some extensive reviews on here for this bridge. This won't be one of them. 

It's one of the most iconic bridges in the world and for a good reason. It's a massive bridge and is very unique that mere words will not do it proper justice. They don't have a toll anymore, so expect to receive a bill in the mail if you don't have fast track which I don't. The computers are taking over it seems. 

Still, this bridge offers amazing views and truly is a place you must visit in SF. Get on it!
author: Benny H.

description: View is AMAZING!!! Came here for my second year anniversary with the bf! And definitely can't wait to go back. It was definitely an amazing experience!
author: Daisy M.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is a cultural icon and internationally recognized symbol.  The American Society of Civil Engineers considers it one of the seven wonders of the modern world.  Regardless if you agree, there's no doubt it's a beautiful, marvelous, and awe-inspiring structure.

If you want to get photos of and with the bridge, the two best places to do it are:

1. Golden Gate Bridge Pavilion: http://www.yelp.com/biz/golden-gate-bridge-pavilion-san-francisco
2. Marin Headlands in Sausalito: http://www.yelp.com/biz/marin-headlands-sausalito

Both locations are public and free, and also provide free parking.  Note the pavilion's parking spaces are rather limited.

The pavilion and headlands offer excellent, unobstructed, and stunning views of the Golden Gate Bridge.  The pavilion is directly attached to the bridge, so head there if you'd like closer shots of the bridge and/or would actually like to walk the bridge.  There are less tourists at the Marin Headlands and you get a more top-down and wider end-to-end view of the bridge from there.  Whichever location you choose, you can't go wrong -- there's no denying the bridge's beauty.  If interested, you can read my reviews of the pavilion and headlands for more information.

While the weather in San Francisco is oftentimes unpredictable, the best time to view the bridge is probably in the afternoon.  By then, typically the fog has lifted.  The sun shines more favorably (towards the bridge) in the afternoons at the pavilion.

The bridge is 1.7 miles.  It takes 45-60 minutes to walk across.  If you plan to walk it, wear layers.  It's windy and can get chilly.  A windbreaker is advisable.  You can also bike across.  Bike rentals are available at Sports Basement (http://www.yelp.com/biz/sports-basement-san-francisco).
author: Daniel B.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is iconic. Spanning the Marin Headlands and the city of San Francisco, it is at its most picturesque in the morning as it glows in the fog. When you're on it, you feel like you're in that picture postcard saying "Greetings from Beautiful San Francisco." There are amazing views of the Pacific Ocean&San Francisco Bay rimmed with the cities of Oakland, Berkeley, Vallejo, Sausalito, Tiburon. If you're on the GGB as an alternate route from the Bay Bridge... you're in for a San Francisco treat.

The GGB has been a character of sorts in recent movies- from the latest Terminator reboot (starring a former governor of California, no less), to "Ant-man" where it's an opening shot as Paul Rudd leaves the slammer, it's even in the trinity of product launches/flashbacks that is http://www.stevejobsthefilm.com The GGB was an important plot point in the Roger Moore 007 "A View to a Kill" (though if Daniel Craig plays Gordon Ramsay, it's a view to a grill), and is in the most beloved of the original Star Trek movies, the "Voyage Home."

The Golden Gate Bridge promises to be the iconic San Francisco experience, and it delivers.
author: Chrysanthemum A.

description: The staple image of San Francisco.. such a beautiful and magnificently built bridge! Never get tired of seeing this bridge!
author: Shareen D.

description:
I dedicate my 500th review to the Golden Gate Bridge. To some, this is just another bridge. To others, this beautiful historical landmark adds character to a city that is already full of character and charm. Whenever I'm in the city, I have to stop by and visit the Golden Gate Bridge at least once. 

The breathtaking views of the bridge can be experienced from afar, but nothing compares to walking on the bridge and feeling the chill from wind that passes through. If you keep walking you can feel the bridge move up and down and sway side to side depending on the wind and the vehicles zipping by. You can drive across the bridge and get a nice view of the city's skyline, but don't forget to bring some cash to pay the toll when you return back to the city. http://goldengatebridge.org/tolls_traffic/toll_rates.php

I would have to say my favorite view of the bridge is when the fog that envelops the bridge slowly dissipate to show the bright color of the bridge. It's like watching the sunrise as the bridge slowly becomes more visible. 

In my last visit, I tried a free walking tour of the bridge to learn some of the history. I highly recommend taking SF City Guide walking tour. http://www.sfcityguides.org/desc.html?tour=35  It's free and all they request is a small donation. I'll write more about SF City Guides later. I learned a lot from the tour, the bridge's color is International Orange, it is over 75 yrs old and the 2nd longest suspension bridge in the world. There was also some controversy in the building of the bridge. People have committed suicide on this bridge so you will see signs posted warning people not to do so. 

There's a visitor center, parking and public restrooms available. For those not driving, the MUNI will drop you off and pick you up. Just make sure to check the schedule and have money for the fare. 

For the commuters: This just in, the bridge now has a movable median! 
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/12/us/new-golden-gate-bridge-barrier-draws-sighs-of-relief.html?_r=0
author: Erin V.

description: One of the things you think about when you picture San Francisco in your mind.  It's a grand structure spanning across beautiful scenery.  If you're brave enough, rent a bike and take a ride across.  It's nerve wracking but fun.  I can never get enough of this beautiful bridge when I come to this beautiful city.
author: Anthony G.

description:
I don't want to call myself a superfan, but I did pay actual money to rent the film Mega Shark vs. Giant Octopus. 

Partly because I'm a huge fan cryptozoology, but also because I just had to catch that pretty epic cameo by the Golden Gate Bridge... oh, and there's Debbie- oh excuse me, DEBORAH Gibson and Lorenzo Lamas spliced in there as well. 

Other guest appearances/cameos that I've been a fan of... 
* The West Wing ... when president Jed Bartlett saved it from being blown up by terrorists. 
* X-Men: The Last Stand. Probably my least favorite in the series, but still a damn good flick.
* Rise of the Planet of the Apes ... How much better was this movie than you expected it to be. So good. Totally watched upwards of 3 times and that final throw-down on the bridge is epic. 
* Zodiac ... I'm not big into the Zodiac killer. Ed Gein's much more my style, but to my knowledge, the bridge didn't play a part in that sordid tale. 
* Futurama ... I've got a pizza for I.C. Wiener. 
* Hulk ... swinging on the bridge Tarzan-style. Hell yes. 
* Full House ... Cut.It.Out.

Golden Gate Bridge- You is a star!
author: Candice G.

description:
I made a drive out here to run across the bridge. I found a dirt parking lot in battery east and didn't have to pay because I came after 5PM. 

The bridge is a little less than two miles one-way. Each end of the bridge has public bathrooms. It's pretty chilly and windy so dress accordingly and keep your mouth closed! Occasionally, things would fly into my mouth (so gross I don't even want to think about it) from the wind and all the cars and busses whizzing by. 

The bridge itself is really beautiful and magnificent and definitely worth seeing if you're in SF. When you come to the bridge for jogging purposes, you'll find it hard to run continuously because the view and bridge is so breathtaking that you will be taking many quick breaks to snap photos.
author: Ohhee J.

description: First time was amazing! Drove on it and also stopped by Bakers Beach for a couple of candids!!
author: Nancy D.

description: Great touristic spot and lots to do in the city!
author: Pamela T.

description:
WTF???

Ones side of the pedestrian walkway closed? Crazy european tourists on bikes? Pissed off marin walkers?  These are some of my favorite things.

Seriously the bridge is generally an amazing place to be. That being said avoid it when tourist season is in its heights.

Walk it. Bike it. The views are unbelievable.
author: David G.

description: I like Golden Gate Bridge, you have such a scenery above the ocean! Even though the price has been raised to pass, I very much enjoyed the crossing and site seeing!
author: Mike K.

description:
Though I grew up in the Bay Area, it took until this last trip for me to walk the Golden Gate Bridge. Not only is it awe inspiring but it's ridiculously high in the air and not for the faint of heart or heights - though, I did see some toddlers and a biker using a selfie stick - so I know it can't be that difficult, either.  The view from the bridge is amazing and unbeatable, I'm already itching to go back.


https://bouncykitty.wordpress.com/2015/01/04/oh-snap-gallivanting-through-crissy-field-and-over-the-golden-gate-bridge/
author: Amanda G.

description:
Amazing Sight !! 

If you're ever in San Francisco going to the Bridge is a must !!!
author: Mina G.

description:
0/5 stars was not gold makes no sense???


...I kid. I honestly wasn't expecting GGB to be as fun of an experience as it was. I mean, it's a bridge. But it was the most fun touristy thing I did on my trip to SF. Walking across is an experience!! It's beautiful from any angle...far away, right in the middle of it, one end or the other, it's something to truly marvel at. 

Getting to the bridge is also made lovely by Crissy Field and the beautiful garden path through Presidio. There are flowers growing everywhere and some gorgeous overlooks. It's a lovely walk. 

I can't believe I almost didn't go. If you're in SF, it's an easy trip.
author: Riva L.

description: A trip to San Francisco is not complete without a trip to the Golden Gate Bridge. It's iconic association with San Francisco is matched with things such as the Statue of Liberty for New York and the Las Vegas Strip for Las Vegas. The traffic usually isn't too bad and you could walk or bike across if you really want to. It most definitely is worth the visit and the expeirence!
author: John O.

description:
Took a small family trip to SF and it was amazing. Bridge was easy to get to and most importantly a location for pictures. 
Location was clean and although the weather was not the greatest it was a beautiful landscape.

Great opportunity to organize as a family and capture the moment.

Must see when it town.
author: Jenni G.

description: Convenient way to cross the bridge but absolutely horrible at billing. Took forever to get my invoice and have it sent to the wrong address. Bumping my $5-7?! Crossing fee to $75!!!  Awesome if you have fast trak sucks if you don't.
author: Marilyn C.

description: I went to here with my friends. I saw the Golden Gate Bridge first time in movie which name is King Kong. After that time, I want to see Golden Gate Bridge. Therefore, in winter vacation, I went to the Golden Gate Bridge finally. It was really huge and enormous, so I couldn't took a photo in one picture. I saw tourist who was from Paris, and I can speak a little bit French and I was talked with tourist just like ask her name. I took a lot of funny pose picture with my friends ,also pretty pictures too. I want to go again, but I want to go with my family next time.
author: Soeun P.

description:
Pretty, impressive, telltale red landmark of SF~

Less touristy pics, more walking on bridge next time!
author: Sandee T.

description:
This is a really must see for SF.  Every time I've gone to the Bridge, I've parked at the Welcome Center on the SF side.  Parking is tough, but there's not a lot of choice that I can see off of Lincoln Blvd. in the Presidio.  It's cold and windy practically all of the time, so be ready.  Obvious photo opp is above the Welcome Center where the Bridge starts.  You gotta go walk on at least a part of the bridge to go over the Golden Gate.  Wow. 

It's spectacular.  A must see.
author: Doctor G.

description: I crossed the bridge on Jan. 5th, not being aware of the FasTrak toll fee at all. Received an invoice on April 10th, which was the first time I learn about the fee. I feel kidnapped/raped. I have no problem paying $7.5 to cross the world famous bridge, but felt disappointed with the toll system. My impression of the Golden Gate Bridge went from "awesome" to "not so good" - worst marketing strategy to attract tourists.
author: Jackey L.

description: Absolutely beautiful! No other words to describe it. You MUST come here!
author: Kelsey N.

description:
I love San Fran! The Golden Gate Bridge is must see when visiting because of its rich history & the amazing view.

I went on a foggy day, which made it look even cooler.

I recommend walking on it. You get a great view of Alcatraz, San Fran, & the love locks attached to the fence.




** The Golden Gate Bridge is also a must see for any Full House fan

What ever happend to predictability?
The milk man, the paper boy, evening TV
author: James R.

description:
BEST. BRIDGE. EVER.

I am biased. I know. But the Golden Gate Bridge is so beautiful to me... She's lovely on a clear Summer day or half-covered and hardly visible due to fog. It doesnt matter... She shines like no other bridge.

Though I have moved away from my hometown, any time I go back home to the city, no trip is complete without me seeing my beautiful bridge. My Goldie... I suggest viewing her from Vista point like all the tourists do, from Fort Point and from Marin Headlands.

She's a true landmark. A San Francisco treasure... I've always said the Golden Gate Bridge is a symbol of my childhood. I think many San Franciscans like myself would agree. She is all that and more... See you soon, my dear beautiful Goldie.
author: Chuck D.

description: A great staple of SF, and perfect for photos, especially if you come on a sunny day! There's a little park area you can walk if you want multiple different views of the bridge, and you can also walk the bridge as well! A must-see for visitors!
author: Tashnuva E.

description:
Instantly recognizable from around the world, this is pretty much the symbol of San Francisco.

Try not to park on the bridge deck, or you'll probably get a ticket or towed.

If you want the best shot, take your photos from the N side, NOT the S.  This is apparently a VERY common rookie mistake.  Yes you will have to pay a toll, but trust me, it's worth it.

I was glad to see they've managed to repair the bridge after Magneto ripped it up quite nicely in 2006, and after it collapsed in that Superman movie back in tha day.
author: Edward L.

description: This bridge offers amazing views if you drive over it and IT IS a massave bridge. Must visit if you're in SF because what do you think of when you think of SF?! THE GOLDEN GATE BRIDGE. Add this to your bucket list for sight-seeing.
author: Sophia V.

description: Breathtaking landmark in SF, and it's very popular all the times. Parking was hard to find and it's very windy on the bridge as well.
author: Maruko X.

description:
You are -

*Breathtaking
*Beautiful
*Historic
*An amazing site

I never get bored praising the Golden Gate bridge and coming here again and again. A must visit spot!
author: Vineet S.

description:
So I came here on a Winter Holiday Break on a week day afternoon. Parking wasn't a problem as there was plenty of it, skies were pretty clear, and the area was moderately packed. We took advantage of walking through the bridge and it was a relaxing and fun experience.

Parking:
Going on a weekday, I did not have trouble with parking. Though there was plenty of it, I can see how it can get packed on a weekend. 

Ambiance:
Extremely peaceful. It serves as your typical park and on the occasion, I know events are held near Crissy park. The cars aren't too loud when you pass by.

Feels: 
The walk back AND forth to the Golden Gate Bridge is 3.4 miles. It definitely gave me a lot of reflecting time about life and the whole entire city, like how this bridge got constructed, why are there a lot of suicide rates on this bridge, and all these other things. Not the most peaceful walk because of car noise but definitely a one you can reflect and have bragging rights.

Overall:
4.5 stars. I am amazed how hundreds of tourists come by here each day. I can see why, with the aesthetics of the structure, the view, and the thousands of shows/movies it has been featured in. I would have gave it a five but I witnessed a bike collision and it was not pretty. The victim was mildly injured and as much as I wanted to help the person, there was nothing we really could have done, not even call the ambulance. If the bike and pedestrian paths would be completely separated then that would make it safer for everyone.

Advice:
* For a chance of clearer skies, come around October or November...if you're lucky December
* Wear warm clothes, it gets pretty windy
* If you want to bike, If you are headed towards Marin County, research on how you can start on the left side. Sharing the road with pedestrians can drain the fun from the ride, also even dangerous.
* BEST PLACE to take a picture in my opinion-head towards Marin County end of the bridge to take a picture there. You will capture the bridge AND SF in the background.
author: Leland S.

description: This is really a spectacular bridge. I don't know how many times I've been to San Francisco in the last 20 years, but I'd never taken the time to go photograph the bridge. This time I did and I'm so glad I went. I went at sunset, which is definitely one of the amazing times to see the bridge. I suggest seeing it from multiple angles. At the plaza, on the bridge, from both sides, and from the socks below in both sides. Just gorgeous. You may want to do it on two separate evenings as trying to hit all these spots at dusk will be hard to do before it gets dark. And, seeing it the dark is pretty awesome too!! It's remarkable how "seen" this bridge is and how very worth it it is to take the time to really see it.
author: Dee M.

description:
I absolutely love visiting the Golden Gate Bridge whenever I'm in San Francisco. My favorite thing is to watch the sunset over the water right by the gorgeous bridge. I've been here so many times and it never gets old. You can walk from one side to the other in about 20 minutes. 

**Best on a clear day!**
author: Ray L.

description:
Been here once before, around 7 years ago, but still definitely a place to visit if you're in Frisco.  This time we went towards the North end of the bridge.  I forgot the name of the hill but its a must to visit.  The view of the bridge from there is amazing.  Of course, behind the bridge is the bay which was also a sight on its own right.  Blue waters against the white skies.  Beautiful, beautiful.

If you have more time, definitely go for the Alcatraz tour; but we were on a time crunch so we only took a few pics and off we went for some lunch.
author: Chris H.

description:
I blame the Golden Gate Bridge for my fascination with bridges. It's red, it's in San Francisco, it can withstand earthquakes, you can drive on it, you can bike on it, you can walk on it, it has an amazing view of the city, and it usually has a blanket of fog covering it. What's not to love?!

The bridge gets a lot of traffic whether you're on foot or on wheels. Bikers and pestredians have to share the road, with traffic going both ways, which can feel dangerous at times. Watch out for tourists randomly stopping to take photos and make sure not to bump into them! The local bikers seem get a little annoyed with all the traffic, but I don't blame them. 

The bridge is 2.4 miles round trip, and it took less than 1.5 hours to walk the whole thing. A great way to exercise and enjoy the city!
author: Vivian L.

description: For the fist time in 8 years, I walked through Golden Gate Bridge. It was very fun, twice in 1 day!! The weather does gets cold and windy so if you are walking through the whole bridge do dress warm. However, the view is spectacular. I highly recommend visiting the bridge even if you want walk it. I drive on it everyday and it's most different experience than walking. It was a fun memory to make and will be with me forever.
author: Nuno V.

description:
Seems like there's never a bad day to visit the Golden Gate Bridge.

Whether the sun is beaming down and you can see clear to the other side of the Bay, or the sky is overcast and the two towers of the bridge disappear into the fog above, the bridge is always a grand sight to behold.

The engineering that went into building this 1.7 mile-long bridge in the 1930's just blows my mind. $35 million was budgeted for the project, which was completed ahead of schedule and $1.3 million under budget - which would practically never happen in the modern day!

The bridge carries six lanes of traffic and tolls are collected in the southbound direction. Tolls are now assessed electronically, so either you'll be charged to the FasTrak transponder in your car or you'll receive an invoice in the mail.

I just had the experience of biking across the bridge for the first time. The view was absolutely stunning. The only downside was that the trip across the bridge wasn't longer!
author: Anson W.

description:
One of my favorite parts of the city! I love the Golden Gate Bridge, it is such an iconic part of the city. The history is amazing and the fact that they paint it continuously. Yes, another tourist attraction, but something I think everyone should see on every visit to San Francisco, it is afterall, one of the major things this city is known for. 

This bridge is a sight to see, and is beautiful even on foggy days and many famous photos will show you, we did not get to see any fog on our trip, but we did do the bridge at night while it was all lit up which was a first for me. The view back over the city is spectacular, day or night!
author: Tina S.

description: Like running? Like biking? Like walking? Like driving? Great! You can do each and every one of those across the Golden Gate Bridge. On a bright, sunny, cloudless day, it's a great idea. The bridge is so pretty! I walked across it with some friends a few weeks ago, and the weather was gorgeous! It's a bit windy on the bridge, and I would imagine that it becomes quite chilly if it's a typical San Francisco day (aka cloudy). Standing on the bridge and watching the boats sailing underneath in the water is quite fun too. There's also a great view of the city when you're on the bridge! Anyway, definitely come check out the Golden Gate Bridge if you're in SF!
author: Andrea W.

description:
Just do it!! Walk across on a clear day and you'll be so happy you did! We walked from Sausalito (Scoma) to the bridge and across and it was a hike, but way worth it! Take pictures with a real camera if you can so that you're not distracted by your phone and bring friends to share the moments with you!

*Bring a sweater - it can get windy, but then you'll probably be removing layers then putting them back on 5 min later like I did!
author: Juls M.

description:
Great tourist attraction, though probably not too great when you have to drive across the bridge during rush hour.

There are lots of scenic views of the Golden Gate Bridge and plenty of places to take a nice picture. Biking across the bridge is made easy with pathways on either side of the bridge, where pedestrians and cyclists are separated. For those that like to bike longer than the just bridge, I suggest going from Fisherman's Wharf along the water, across the Golden Gate Bridge, and all the way to Saulsalito. Bike back the same way or take the ferry back to the Fisherman's Wharf if you get too tired.
author: Tunaidi A.

description:
A stupid scam that confuses tourists. I don't own a fastrak and I CAN SEE YOU HIDING! Why can't you just go out in the tollbooth collecting money?!!
The only good thing is good emergency services
author: Nicolas W.

description:
Yesterday, just before ending our one day stay here in San Francisco. We rented out Bikes and decided to ride them through the Golden Gate Bridge to Sausalito. However, when we at the Bridge, they had the other-sidewalk closed, so it made it a bit difficult to ride through everyone was walk walking, running, and riding their bikes back. We were able to make it through, just wished the other side would have been open to cause less traffic and incidents. 
But I am not too sure if there are certain hours that they keep one side closed just because when we left to Sacramento, we drove through the bridge and noticed both sides were open. 
One ting I would recommend it's best if you go in the afternoon oppose to the morning. Less traffic! 

One thing I would like to point out is great to see Police Officers interacting with children and people who were browsing at the bridge.
author: Heather T.

description:
Beautiful place a must see if your visiting. We were staying at Kirby Cove campground and decided to walk it across, it was quite the walk! The views are amazing you can see Alcatraz from it, my boys loved looking over and seeing the boats cross. Luckily it wasn't foggy so we had a nice clear view. It's an amazing structure.
The cons: Too many cyclists they should really open the other walkway for cyclists only. You have them going in both directions, some going slow others are racing like its a marathon. They obviously see you but think they are as slim as those bikes and try to pass you almost knocking you down. If walking with children make sure they are on your left side.
That really ruined my experience...
author: KellyM M.

description: I like it. Great for biking across to the other side or you could run the distance to the other side. You will have to dodge the people that walk 4-5 across the path so they impede faster walkers, runners and cyclists. The one side of the bridge seems to be dedicated to cyclists though. The total distance each way is 1.65 miles.
author: Andrew A.

description: MUST SEE. With the history and the Size of this gargantuan structure, you will love the fact that you visited. The Best Place To View is From along the l Bluffs to the left after you cross the bridge . There's is a nice Sunlight on the bridge with the Main Tip Of San Francisco in the Background as shown in the pic. If You are in San Francisco, don't miss seeing this! Btw, get ready to see large crowds, and heavy traffic and parking congestion at times....
author: Bernie L.

description:
Golden Gate Bridge name orginated from
that people come from Pacific Ocean to 
Golden City San Francisco.

Golden Gate Bridge had been constructed
4years from 1933 and then opened in May 28th, 1937.

When they opened this bridge  San Francisco Chronicle called it as a thirty-five million dollar 
steel harp! 

However, if we build this bridge at this time,
we need to spend over 1.2billion dollars.

The bridge length is 4,200 feet.
It was painted by international orange which had been sustained until1964.
It was repainted whole areas in 1965.
After that this bridge has been being painted certain
area when they need to toch up.

Golden Gate Bridge  is one of the symbols
of San Francisco.

Your feeling will be very different when you see it from under or from above and in the morning or night.
author: Weon L.

description:
This iconic symbol is also the location of one of the greatest short hikes in America, making it an absolute essential for every visitor to San Francisco. Park your car in the bayside lot near Crissy Field and follow the trail to the Warming Hut, where you can grab a hot cup of coffee before starting your hike up to the bridge. Make sure you leave at least a couple of hours before sunset to get back -- the trail to the bridge is steep and definitely not something you want to attempt in the dark. 

If you're interested in taking in some sunset shots, drive across to the Vista Point parking lot on the Marin side or catch a bus from the toll plaza. The bridge itself is a little over a mile in length, but the approach from the San Francisco side will add another steep, uphill mile to that. However you do it, a walk across the Golden Gate is one of the great American experiences, and something that will stay with you for the rest of your life. Don't leave San Francisco without crossing it off your list!
author: Joe P.

description: While it is a beautiful bridge, I feel it is slightly overrated. Driving over it was fun but I personally liked the bay bridge better. Even still it is worth seeing!
author: Tina A.

description: The bridge is recognizable, world-wide.  I couldn't be in SF and not stop to look at it.  Beautiful!  The bike and walking paths are well maintained.  I liked the earthquake display, and being able to walk under/across the bridge.  The park is nice as well although parking was terrible - - I sat in traffic for 15-20 minutes and then rode around and around several times before finding a place in over-flow parking.
author: Debbie H.

description:
Who doesn't think of the iconic Golden Gate Bridge when thinking of gorgeous San Francisco?

Let's skip all the informative facts.  There are hundreds of reviews and websites for that.  Let's talk magic and experience!  I've been lucky enough to drive across the GG Bridge and walking it.  It's a relatively short distance so it's not strenuous by any means.  With the sun, the occasional fog rolling in, and the great brisk weather, it's an easy walk.  Be careful not to be hit by bicyclist.  They just appear out of no where!

Between driving and walking across the bridge, I prefer walking it.  It's nice to just stand around and watch surfers, boats, and the sun set.  Try not to get those morbid thoughts when you look down and think about those who have attempted and committed suicide.  Those thoughts are never pretty.  Instead, think about the positives and be grateful of the amazing view!  Definitely a must-see for tourists and locals alike.
author: Joyce W.

description:
Only four stars because they take my money, and they want to increase it a dollar. Again. (now kiddos, back when I first started driving, bridge toll was 25 cents.... Or maybe $2).

All of four stars because of the amazing views, the lack of backed-up traffic, and the adorable retro (aka old) toll plaza.
author: Dana G.

description: Ahh, what a pleasure it was to finally visit San Francisco's iconic bridge. There are free visitor parking on the ends of the bridge. Arrived around late afternoon and there was plenty of parking. Definitely go to this iconic bridge if you haven't already!
author: Jordan L.

description: we are visiting san fransisco frequently, could be twice a year, but never been there before. When it was time to visit on 2011, amazingly the bridge covered with thick clouds and showering around there.
author: Loena Loeloeh L.

description: The iconic Golden Gate Bridge is a true masterpiece and it surpassed all my expectations. Although the bridge attracts a large amount of tourists, it's beauty makes dealing with all the hustle and bustle all the more worth it. I honestly have no words to express how I felt gazing upon such an icon. I'm from Hilo, HI and never in my life did I think that I'd get to see GGB in real life. I've grown up seeing it on TV and in movies but to see it with my own eyes was truly something special. I think I just stared at the bridge for a good hour before I actually tried to get a decent shot to document our trip. Here's the shot that I got.
author: Kaliko K.

description: A beautiful day on the bridge today. Makes you understand the lines to the song, "San Francisco open your Golden Gate" Great view of Alcatraz too.
author: Diane V.

description:
Best place to go to when you just want to get away from it all, I come here to clear my head and have a nice jog. 

Also a great place to take pictures and learn some history if you have time to take a tour.
author: Wade Y.
