description: Phenomenal land mark. Went to it during a thick fog and then later when it was clear out, both were extremely enjoyable. Crossing on bike was a bit dicey as it is windy and cloudy but well worth it. Great views from every side of the bridge
author: Nick H.

description: Beautiful place, very windy now in march! So you will need a good jacket. Perfect spot for good pictures.
author: Z G.

description: We took an uber across the bridge from downtown for around $28 (public transit available both ways), walked across and watched the sunset. Lovely, romantic, not many crowds when we went. Unforgettable views.
author: Jen J.

description:
Ah, the Golden Gate Bridge!  

How can you not visit it when you are an out of towner or local?!  It's THE ICON for San Francisco!

I love walking on it and enjoying the scenery - it gives me tranquility in my mind.

Go on a cloudless, sunny day - that's when the view is best!
author: Tiffany D.

description: What's big, red and just as shiny as the Yelp Elite badge? Put that stick of Big Red gum away because it just does not compare to this historic San Francisco landmark. You cannot visit the gorgeous city of San Francisco without stepping and/or driving on this famed bridge! It's simply whimsical and so much more beautiful, when you get to see it with your own 2 eyes in person). It's especially breathtaking when all the fog has cleared from it and you can see it in all its shining glory. What's even more amazing is when you actually get to cross it. If you are short on time, at least drive over it, but if you have time, walk, jog or bike on it. Leave San Francisco with the bragging rights that you crossed the Golden Gate Bridge! Coming from someone that grew up in the Bay Area, I am still in awe of the bridge and love, love, love seeing it each time I go home. This still and will probably be until the end of time a heavy tourist spot, so if you plan to walk/jog/bike it, do your research about parking and toll prices, etc. Enjoy it because it is truly a vision, especially once you learn the history behind the construction of it.
author: Rebecca W.

description:
Date: Around March.

There's not much to says about the Great San Francisco Golden Gate Bridge.

We know the view is amazing, if you've never been to CA, its definitely a once in a lifetime experience to check this bridge out! The parking lot is limited/busy during the break/tour season. 

Tip: Good place to Bike.


Clean atmosphere, bathroom is available, a mini gift shop.
author: Vincent C.

description: One of my favorite landmarks in the world! My husband and I would often drive down just to walk across the bridge, get a coffee and visit the gift shop on the other side, and walk back. It truly is one of the most beautiful man-made creations. Beautiful photo opportunities! Early morning runs/walks across the bridge before the crowds of tourists arrive are the best. Just beautiful!
author: Bradley S.

description:
This is a beautiful bridge and landmark.  Spanning the narrowest part of the San Francisco Bay, it is about a mile long and has two incredibly tall towers to support the suspension cables that hold the bridge up.  

The bridge is strong and has withstood numerous shakes and quakes in the Bay Area.  There is a walkway on one side for pedestrians who want to walk the span, and bicycle access on the other side.  The views from the bridge are incredible.  I walked this bridge when I was in high school as part of a field trip and don't regret it.  The vista point on the north end is great, as is a trip up the hill towards the Marin Headlands.  From the top, and at the vista points along the way between the bottom of the hill and the top (Hawk Hill) you can get some really great views of this landmark.  

Toll is five or six bucks now and no cash is accepted.  You can pre-pay online or with Fastrack.  If all else fails and you go across without paying, they will mail you a bill and won't even tack on additional fees for the trouble.  I think that's really nice.
author: Erin K.

description:
We are visiting the GG for the first time next week.  I really can't understand people who give this attraction anything less than five stars.  It's BRIDGE not food.  You are going to complain about the color or the weather?!?!  Come on.  The cyclist complaint I understand. 

I personally can't wait to see thd iconic structure and take lots of photos from GG park welcome center or from fort point or battery Spencer.  This is going to be AWESOME.
author: Chaz S.

description:
When I was little I didn't understand why the Golden gate bridge was a symbol of San Francisco. In first grade, my parents moved us from SF to the East bay, so we never ever took the Golden gate bridge. It was all about the Bay bridge to get us into the city. So shouldn't the Bay bridge be the symbol since we used it so often?!

Now that I'm older and live in SF, I've finally crossed the Golden gate bridge. Most of the time traffic is running smoothly and it's a quick drive across it's 1.7 mile span. Other times, the traffic can be horrendous (like yesterday when there was an accident and there was only one northbound lane), but I realized it gave me more time to appreciate the beauty of the Golden gate. 

I have yet to walk or bike across the bridge, but I hope to walk across it one day. Being from SF, I've haven't done a lot of touristy things. Driving across it yesterday, I realized there's a reason the Golden gate is one of the most photographed bridges and an iconic symbol of SF. It's beautiful! I'm glad I live in the city and can appreciate the Golden gate on a daily basis. 

Side note: They no longer have toll takers (which I was kindly reminded of when I came back from Napa last week without my FasTrak!) so I believe the prices are the following when entering the city: I think pedestrians and bicyclists are still free.

$7.00 - Pay by plate
$6.00 - FasTrak
$4.00 - carpools during peak hours, FasTrak only
author: Elena N.

description: Absolutely breathtaking. There whole scene looks larger than life and makes you feel incredibly lucky to even be able to observe it. If you go on a beautiful, unfoggy day, you definitely won't be disappointed.
author: Ally M.

description: It's simply beautiful! Never thought that I would be crossing the greatest suspension bridge in the world! Bring your camera, relax, and enjoy the magnificent view of San Francisco bay! You can jog or ride a bike while crossing the bridge.The weather is pretty cool at this time so don't forget to bring your jacket. And before you leave, get yourself a shirt or a ref magnet that says "I crossed the Gold Gate Bridge"!
author: Wendy C.

description:
It had been well over a decade siince my last visit here at the Golden Gate Bridge.

This was the year I was going to visit this beautiful city with all its breath taking views.
Yup...on my birthday week baby:)

August is super hot here in So. Cal... NOT up here in the bay area!  It was definitely 
foggy and cloudy in the low 70s!  So LOVED it!!!

I will cherish our time here in Frisco and especially our time here at the Golden Gate
Bridge.
author: Chel R.

description:
Stunning.  Every time I cross this bridge I remember the first time I saw it's grandeur and marveled at the engineering that brought it to life.

I've walked across this bridge, looked at it from the overlook point on the north side, driven over it and even biked over it and it still leaves me without the words to adequately describe it's beauty.

A recent improvement is that the tolls no longer take cash or credit card. Fast pass (or whatever they call their auto pay program) is the only way to pay the $7.00 toll that you will need to get across the bridge.  If you don't have one (I didn't in my rental car) just call 511 and they will be happy to take your payment over the phone.

Best $7 I spent in San Fran!
author: Carol K.

description: I'm glad I got to experience riding across the Golden Gate Bridge during my college basketball days in California. The scenery is truly amazing (especially at sunset). Recently, I was able to sail under the bridge while touring on Fisherman Wharf. Riding across and sailing under the Golden Gate Bridge give guest two cool experiences. I was able to take some great pictures while sailing under the bridge. I'm from Virginia, $5 is steep for crossing a bridge but it's worth it in my opinion. Golden Gate Bridge is definitely a great tourist attraction if you're visiting San Francisco.
author: Dominic B.

description:
Beautiful San Francisco Landmark - The Golden Gate is Spectacular and a Must-See!

My mother and I visited the Golden Gate Bridge on the morning of July 30th. 

We took the BART from the Mission District, where we were staying in an Airbnb apartment, to Civic Center. From there, we rode on a Golden Gate Transit (one-way fare was $5.25 USD) which dropped us off in the parking lot of the Bridge's Welcome Center. The Golden Gate Transit operates buses #10, 70, 92, and 101, which all take you to the same place at the Bridge. 

We arrived at the Bridge shortly before 9 AM and there were only a few other people there. The atmosphere was peaceful and relaxing and it was nice to be able to have almost the entire area to ourselves. 

There was some light fog covering the top portion of the Bridge, but it was still largely visible and beautiful! 

From the Welcome Center, we walked the Battery East Trail, which was a gravel path that winded through some beautiful and lush vegetation down the hill where we eventually ended up at Crissy Field. Shortly after walking the trail, we arrived at a small open area amongst the trees with a few picnic tables. The views of the Bridge from here were fantastic and this was a great spot for photo opportunities! We then continued walking along the trail which had a tunnel going through a small hump/hill in the path. We finally ended up at the bottom of the hill at Crissy Field. After taking some photos of the Bridge from this area, we continued walking along Marine Drive, which was bordered on one side by a tall rocky cliff (where the walking trail is on top of) and by the Bay waters on the other side. It was a gorgeous street! 

At the end of Marine Drive is Fort Point, which is a historical building that is open to the public. Unfortunately, we did not explore the interior of Fort Point (but are planning to next time we are in SF). The views of the Bridge from up close at the dead end of this street were beautiful and picturesque! We also narrowly escaped getting splashed by some huge waves that were coming off the Bay, while taking photos! 

After exploring the area at the base of the Bridge and admiring the views from these places, we hiked back up the walking trail to the Welcome Center parking lot and then made our way to the Bridge, where we walked across the beginning portion of it. The Bridge was so huge and impressive when I was actually on it and it was very high, so the views of the surrounding city and Bay were amazing! At the beginning of the Bridge, there was a telephone and a sign with a crisis telephone number posted, for those needing help and potentially considering suicide by jumping off the Bridge. It was quite sad to see this and tragic to think of how many people have ended their lives here. 

Although we did not end up doing this (but are adding it to the list for next time), you can rent bicycles from a few different local companies to ride across the Bridge to the other side, where the small and hilly Bayside communities of Tiburon and Sausalito are situated. 

I found the that the best views of the Bridge that provided the best photo opportunities were from the picnic tables located at the beginning of the Battery East Trail (from the Welcome Center), Crissy Field and Marine Drive/Fort Point. You can also view the Bridge from Baker Beach. 

To avoid the crowds, visit the Bridge in the early morning (approximately 9 AM). 

The Golden Gate Bridge is an spectacular and iconic landmark in San Francisco and it is definitely a must-see when you visit the city, regardless of how touristy and popular this attraction may be. After seeing the Bridge in many TV shows and movies, it was so amazing to be able to see and experience it in person. Absolutely stunning!
author: Brittany T.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is synonymous with San Francisco. If you go on the website for the bridge, it will suggest that you take mass transit to the bridge because there is limited parking. Ignore that advice. While it is true that there is not much parking right by the entrance of the bridge, there is plenty of parking at Crissy Field which is right below the bridge. On the weekend, parking is free before 10 AM and very cheap after that time anyway. Since I was still on East Coast time when I visited, I was one of the first cars at the parking lot and got a spot right next to the walking path that leads you directly to the bridge. Crissy Field also provides an excellent view of Alcatraz. If the weather is good, I definitely recommend walking across the bridge. When you reach the Oakland side, you can stop at Vista Point which is great for photos. It provides an excellent view of the San Francisco skyline and Bay. The round trip walk across the bridge will take about an hour.

If you are visiting San Francisco and looking for recommendations, feel free to message me through Yelp and I can share my itinerary, which includes my Yelp reviews. The information for an electronic copy can also be found via my Yelp profile.
author: Patrick W.

description:
I've seen a lot of beautiful bridges in my lifetime.

But for some reason, golden gate will always have a special place in my heart.

Whether I'm on a ferry boat, passing through above on a airplane, or just driving across, this bridge definitely make me feel like I'm home.

One of the few places, where I don't complain about the fog ruining my picture!
author: Nika K.

description:
it's iconic but, not very exciting.

more marvelous bridges have been built since this one. 

it's also ridiculously expensive to cross the bridge southbound ($7 ticket sent to you in mail if you're not registered with the toll authority).
author: Roman S.

description:
Golden Gate Bridge is falling down,
Falling down, falling down.
Golden Gate Bridge is falling down,
My fair SF.

Golden Gate Bridge will not fall down, but it is definitely often covered by fog. I will recommend you taking photos of the bridge in the afternoon or early evening. 

Since SF often has marathons, I suggest you googling if there are events close to the bridge before you drive there. Otherwise, you will be spending more than an hour driving in circles due to road blocks like I did.

No matter what the season is and what the weather is, the Golden Gate Bridge is beautiful. While the view of the bridge is not as breathtaking as those of the London Bridge and the Sydney Harbor Bridge, the Golden Gate Bridge is a must-see bridge in the US.
author: May Y.

description: You can't come to San Francisco and not visit the Golden Gate Bridge! The views everywhere around the area are just beautiful! My friends and I rented bikes in Fisherman's Wharf and rode our way all the way to the bridge, taking in all of the amazing views along the path. When we finally made it to the bridge, we rode across, stopping many times along the way to take pictures and enjoy San Francisco from afar. We made it all the way across to Sausalito and stopped by the little area they have directly at the end of the bridge, the panoramic was truly heavenly. It was a bit cloudy the day we went, but even then the views were unreal. Anyone coming here, you MUST do this. You won't see such amazing views anywhere in the city like this. Its just a wonderful experience! Recommend biking it, great workout!
author: Steven P.

description: What is there to say about the Golden Gate Bridge that hasn't already been said? It's one of the great wonders of the world, the quintessential icon of the city, and a must-stop for anyone visiting San Francisco. Whether you decide to walk, bike, or drive across, it is a magical experience. I recommend one of the many bay cruises offered on Fisherman's Wharf, where you can get some increible photos and go right underneath its great span. No matter how many times you look at it, the Golden Gate Bridge still leaves you in awe.
author: Matt P.

description: Pure extortion. 200 in tolls= 2800 in total cost after their dishonest fees. These are criminals that get away with their bullshit because people don't share experiences.
author: Mike L.

description:
I have taken SO MANY pictures of this beautiful bridge! I've driven on the bridge, rode a bike (round-trip) on the bridge, went on a boat UNDERNEATH the bridge, and have walked on it & flown overhead via plane ;) AND I've gotten views from different points... While on Angel Island & Alcatraz, atop Coit Tower, Hawk Hill and the Lands End area - also near the Legion of Honor. I've ran a quarter marathon near it - via Crissy Field and The Presidio. Sightings from other parts of the city, too. And, I've captured sights of this magnificent bridge from the Alameda / Emeryville / Oakland areas as well as while en route to Richmond, CA. There's something about this bridge... It's iconic! Looking at it does NOT get old...

Though beware of Karl the Fog... He'll engulf the bridge... Especially in Fogust.
author: Pina U.

description:
Quite impressive over this man-made structure.  It's even more impressive how the SF locals use this to get to/fr work.  

No wonder our best friends love me visiting them; he whizzes thru the HOV lane lol.  

Picture best taken from the north side though for a 1st timer, any shot is good. 

Been meaning to take that tour boat underneath one day but was quite windy last year.
author: Kenneth N.

description: Came here on Labor Day.  This isn't my first time seeing the bridge, but every time I'm in the bay area, I try to stop here.  The last time, I got here pretty late at night, so I wasn't able to take a good picture, even though it was pretty lighted at night.  So this time, I made sure to stop here first.  We found parking near the base of the bridge.  Got out, took pictures.  It was a nice and sunny day, so you could see across the bridge.  Glad that I was able to see it and take a good picture this time around!
author: Kim L.

description: My wife and I were on a 2 week vacation in California a few years back.Being an Aussie this was my first trip to the USA and one of our goals was to walk across the Golden Gate Bridge while in San Francisco.It was so windy but we did it.....over and back in about an hour or so.The view over the bay was outstanding
author: Michael B.

description: I'm so in love with this bridge and the gorgeous views it offers, both looking at it from afar and while you're standing on it.  My fiance and I were recently there and had so much fun taking silly pictures and just enjoying the beautiful weather on a non-foggy day!  We took a bus that had a drop off there and that's definitely the best option so you don't have to worry about parking or tolls.  We didn't quite walk half way across, but would love to do so someday.  So much history here.  Definitely get some good pictures by the park side!
author: Emily A.

description:
Why 5 stars?  Because this is the coolest place I have ever been to.

   ---   ---   ---

I've yet to leave the country, but this is the most impressive sight I've ever seen.  You have absolutely everything you could possibly ask for in your sight lines:

A Famous Landmark (The Bridge Itself)

A Historic Landmark (Alcatraz)

A Skyline (Downtown SF)

Mountains

Water

This is such an incredible sight, I am in complete awe when visiting and will check out the bridge every time I am in San Francisco.  If you are visiting for the first time, this is an absolute requirement.  I suggest renting a bike to ride across it and into Sausalito.  Walking it has its advantages as well - you can stop more easily for photo ops and it can get quite crowded for bike riders.  Whether you're biking or walking, just make SURE you check it out.
author: Brett N.

description:
Rumor has it there's this really big n' pretty bridge in San Fran. Fact has it it's just as pretty and breathtaking as they say. Whether you bike, walk or drive across this man-made marvel your visit to San Francisco isn't complete without it. 

Driving tends to be quite dangerous for visitors in the sense that our focus is more on snagging *the* photo than actually safely making it across said bridge. Biking makes for a great challenge on a windy day but it's worth it when you roll into Sausalito and think back, "huh, I just rolled across that bad boy on two wheels." Both sides of the bridge have handy (and safe) spots to pull over for your Kodak moments. 

However you choose to enjoy and soak in the Golden Gate, make sure you give it fair time to truly appreciate it's beauty and size.
author: Brittany S.

description: I went to the GGB for my 29th birthday. There's not really much to say about it other than it is beautiful. I guess my only downside is I wish there was different view from where we could see the bridge and take nice photos of it but I took what I could get and Im grateful. The bridge was and is beautiful. We got to drive on it and then we parked to take it all in
author: Vicki L.

description: Loved my view from the beautiful Golden Gate Bridge. Extreme wind and fog advisory. Wear warm clothing, even in the summer time! After walking on the bridge, we finished our afternoon with a picnic on the beach. Perfect ending to any romantic date.
author: Shannon F.

description:
This is the worst system ever designed. First of all, they don't give you any information on how to pay as you are crossing.

I assumed they would send me a invoice to my registered address, but nope that didn't happen. Now their website is the absolute WORST site. What year is this? 1990 when AOL was still a thing? I have to remember what date and exact time I crossed to be able to give you money? Sure let me write that down as I'm driving.

What a pathetic excuse of a system designed to "make our lives easier". 

In essence, GGB association, you are terrible.
author: Fred K.

description: when i traveled across this epic scale bridge i was immediatley taken aback by just how incredible an engineering feat it was! when i got to the other side we pulled into a small encirclment on the east side of the road and made a little hike back and around the northern entrance to the bridge. the photo-op there was inexplicably majestic! the fog had rolled in very thick almost cumulous in nature, and just flooded the ocean with cool-whip with the sun breaking through in small spots like a cheesegrater, it was amazing!
author: Andrew M.

description: To get an incredible and unique view of GGB head to Fort Point. From the top of the building, you can look up and see yourself directly under the bridge. Take a few steps to the corner and you've got the potential for a breathtaking and perfect photo! The whole area surrounding the fort is a photographers paradise!
author: Courtney O.

description:
Review # 700 goes to the most famous landmark in SF, The Golden Gate Bridge.

I think in my lifetime I've only driven across the Golden Gate Bridge maybe 5 times??  Coming from the peninsula, it's so out of my way and surely not my first option to get to the north bay.  It's usually something I just see from a distance.

Whenever I drive on this bridge though, my out-of-town visitors that I take there are usually blown away by it.  I guess I'm one of those locals that shakes my head and keeps saying, "It's just a bridge!!"  My cousins got a kick out of that.

I remember when I was a kid, I was given a task in my 2nd grade class to draw a big picture of the Golden Gate Bridge.  The odd part was that at that time I never had crossed it or exactly knew how it looked like from the details.  In fact I thought it was an exact twin of the Bay Bridge.  I discovered how way off I was when my dad drove me on the bridge for the very first time.  I was really impressed!

It took me a while to realize how beautiful a bridge it is after driving on it a few times a seeing it up close with its International Orange paint job and Art Deco style.  It's truly a remarkable piece of work considering that when they built it there were no computers or high tech gadgetry to design it.

Whether you're a local or a tourist, The Golden Gate Bridge IS San Francisco to everyone.
author: Rodney H.

description:
Having been around so many bridges in my life, it all tends to blur itself together till they all practically look the same. The Golden Gate Bridge in all of its iconic San Francisco glory is one that simply stands out. 

Perhaps it's the red arches, the mind bending visual of driving through or walking through. It might be the view of the foggy San Francisco skyline or the glistening landscape during the summer time. Whatever it is, it is one of the defining landmarks that keeps the Bay and SF in particular, one of the most recognized places in the world.

It has that distinctive look from afar, but I personally enjoy being right in the thick of it. In some ways, it is hauntingly beautiful yet somewhat plain at the same time. Then when you consider its history, the utility of the commutes, and the countless tourists who make time to visit, one can't help but admire its impact on the area.

Couple the bridge with the park and it's certainly one of the most unique spots in the west coast, if not the United States. It is everything: unique, touristy, necessary, romantic, versatile, and an architectural wonder.
author: Jando S.

description: Nice bridge with great views towards Alcatraz, SF, Marin and Pacific Ocean. Expect strong winds and chilly weather at times. Can rent a bike in SF to bike on it too or just walk it.
author: Ivan S.

description:
I arrived here via one of the Golden Gate buses to check it out.     It really is a true beauty and provides so many great views.    It was surreal for me to walk across the bridge and I used the time to reflect again on where I am in life and to be grateful that I'm able to afford the opportunity to visit.    Even though it was cloudy I was able to see Alcatraz and other parts of the city.    I even had a motorcycle cop chat me up for a bit.

Now getting out of GGB was a nightmare but it was a minor hassle.   Overall I was glad to have the chance to check this off my bucket list.   It's a definite must see.
author: Eric G.

description: Walk it, run it, bike it- there's no way you can go to San Francisco and not want to have a little photoshoot on/by The Golden Gate Bridge. I've biked the bridge twice and both times were amazing. I'm sure the people who live here are use to walking it all the time but since I don't, I made sure to slow down on my bike ride and take plenty of pictures. It's a great view of the city! Enjoy it and don't feel bad to stop someone to take a picture of you--they are friendly people!
author: Yeraldine S.

description:
Nice, as Bridges Go

Don't get me wrong, but it's just a bridge.
Yes, it will allow you to get from one chunk of land to another, but it's just a bridge.
Yes, it looks nice, but it's just a bridge.
Yes, it's an architectural wonder, but it's just a bridge.

Just kidding...

It's amazing!  It's iconic!  It's an architectural wonder!  It looks beautiful in the fog or in the sun, or both!
It is so much more than just a bridge!
author: Ted Q.

description: Beautiful. A must see in San Francisco. You can either hike to the Golden Gate Bridge from the Baker Beach side or drive directly to it and park around the various designated parking areas and walk along the pier or on the bridge. I've hiked along the Baker Beach trail and drove directly to it. I would recommend hiking to it if you're up for a mild hike along the water. It's very calming and breathtakingly beautiful. It doesn't matter you do it, you just have to check out the bridge while you're in 'the city.'
author: Faye S.

description:
My family visited Golden Gate Bridge before. I love this place and we keep coming back after couple years. Unfortunately, we've got very bad experience this time.
When we passed the bridge, there's a toll fee station. They requested us to pay cash. We asked for receipt but the guy said it's unnecessary and let us go.
Couple weeks later, an invoice sent to our house saying that we passed the bridge WITHOUT paying. We emailed them, explained the situation and asked them to check their camera (we had date & time). They sent an feedback letter saying that we still have to pay the fee.
It's just couple dollars, but it makes us so disappointed.

PLEASE ALWAYS ASK FOR TICKET after you pay the toll fee.

Sorry GGB, I will give the GGB 5 stars but the toll dept -5 stars.
author: Therese T.

description:
San Francisco = Golden Gate Bridge. An iconic structure that makes San Francisco what it is. One of many beautiful tourist attractions in San Francisco that is a must see. We came on a foggy day. Unfortunately, within an hour later, after we had left, the fog lifted.  The weather is very unpredictable so planning ahead really doesn't work.

There is VERY VERY limited parking in the area. Fortunately, if you can find parking, it is free.  There is a lot of people in the view point areas. Many people are double parked, many are parked illegally, and the buses holding MANY tourists adds to the congestion.

There was a shop that sold touristy things and another area that described the history of the bridge.  There are also public restrooms in the area. Definitely so glad we were able to visit the bridge during our visit.
author: Janet E.

description:
Iconic and beautiful, no trip to the city is complete without snapping a picture of this functional work of art. Snapping a picture will do for some, but for the full experience, bring a jacket and go for a walk on the bridge. Stop and feel and watch the bridge move for a real experience. Explore under the bridge and check out the massive metal that helps this thing survive.

The Golden Gate Bridge actually moves and can move up or down up to  16 feet based on temperature. Crazy, huh? It can also move up to 27 feet side to side. 

The visitor center is pretty cool and money spent there goes to preservation. Parking and bathrooms are available next to the visitor center.

If you are feeling particularly adventurous, you can walk across the bridge and back, but be warned that it gets quite chilly and windy up there, so dress appropriately!
author: Andrea V.

description:
What ever happened to the predictability. The milk man, the paper boy, the evening TV.

Broadcasting live from San Francisco, I thought it only right I give my review of the Golden Gate Bridge.

The first time I made it to San Francisco the Golden Gate Bridge was at the top of my list of sights. The iconic red (some people say orange, I call it a faded red) bridge is a major part of my childhood as I'd see it on my TV screen every day for a good 5 years when watching Full House. I felt like Uncle Jesse, wind blowing in the air as we cruised down the GGB. Ok, I don't have hair...or the Greek-Godish good looks of John Stamos, nor were we in a convertible, but you get the point. 

I shouted at my wife...TAKE PICTURES!! WOW!!! LOOK HOW TALL! TAKE PICTURES!! OH MY GOD, WE ARE HIGH UP...LIKE REALLY HIGH!! AHH DON'T TAKE PICTURES OF ME DRIVING! OK TAKE A PICTURE OF ME DRIVING!! OH MY GOD, WE ARE ON THE GOLDEN GATE BRIDGE.

You see, even my fear of heights won't allow me to rate the Golden Gate Bridge lower than perfect. Not only does the bridge hold a special piece of my heart because of the memories I had seeing it, but it's so impressive in person. It's massive. 

From far the photo ops will be priceless, but actually driving on the bridge might send a chill down your spine. The sheer size of it is enough to leave you with your mouth open : standing at 700+ feet tall. And even though you have probably seen it on screen and in books, you aren't ever fully prepared to be face to face with such a giant structure.

Perfect score for being: impressive, iconic and FREE!
author: Blue A.

description: Alcatraz, fishermans wharf, Chinatown... All standbys in San Fran.... along with a trip to the Golden Gate Bridge! Driving along you see the top peeking up miles before you get there, driving however on this making you respect who built it! It's gorgeous, HUGE and when driving through the fog on it...the sense of mystery settles in. A must do if in San Fran!
author: Ryan K.

description:
Beautiful bridge. Visitor parking on both ends!! Makes it a great location to visit without hassle. 
They have restrooms as well! 
It seems to get very crowded on the weekend, I would recommend walking the brindle on a day during the week to avoid the mobs of tourist.
author: Holly R.

description:
I was driving across the Golden Gate Bridge yesterday when my front tire suddenly exploded. Fortunately, it happened right as I was passing by the toll plaza. I immediately pulled over out of traffic and in to the employee parking lot to inspect the damage. Within 1 minute (I kid you not), a bridge patrol car came to my rescue. I didn't even have to pick up the phone and call AAA. It's like they magically appeared out of nowhere. The officers made a quick call to their roadside service guys, and in less than 2 minutes, a truck was at my side to replace my tire with a spare. 

It was 10:30am and I had an 11am mtg in South of Market. There's no way I'm going to make it in time, I thought. But lo and behold, the guy fixed my tire in 5 minutes flat - free of charge. I was back on the road before I knew it... and I even made it to my 11am mtg with 2 minutes to spare.

I can't thank the Golden Gate Bridge Patrol enough. They were total lifesavers. I got a personal glimpse in to where our bridge toll money goes. Thanks again, guys!
author: Kevin B.

description:
Gorgeous!

Walking on the Golden Gate was definitely the highlight of my time in San Francisco! The bridge itself is an amazing architectural feat, so it was neat to see that up close after having viewed it from afar as we toured San Francisco earlier in the day. The views from the bridge are equally stunning, as you get views of the city, Alcatraz, and just beautiful ocean and mountain scenery. 

We were very lucky that it was a clear day when we visited. Some days it can be incredibly foggy in this area, so keep that in mind! There is a small museum area on the San Fran side of the bridge where we able to park for a small fee. There was also a nice little gift shop available too. 

My party walked about half way across the bridge, but it would definitely would have been simple enough to walk the whole way. Obviously the bridge is flat, so it's not incredibly strenuous. It goes with out saying that you are at a high elevation, so it would not be great for anyone with a fear of heights. There is also high car traffic, so it can be a bit noisy. 

SOOOOOO worth a visit!
author: Steph H.

description: This bridge is very heavily populated abs had great views.  There is a toll to drive on the bridge but it's free from the north end. There's an old abandoned fort here which is really nice.  So there's some military history here as well.  The bridge is actually orange but it looks gold against the ocean and mountain back drop
author: Fazle H.

description: Don't leave SF without visiting the Golden Gate Bridge. There's lots of parking and places to visit at the golden gate.
author: MarcCrystal C.

description:
A must see, must do for any tourist visiting the Bay area. 


Very effing cool. :)
author: Mike F.

description:
It's iconic, it's pretty, and I like it! 

It's windy, so make sure to wear layers.
author: Kemi A.

description:
It has to be done. If you're a visitor to San Fran, get yourself to that bridge and have a look. 'Coz "everywhere you look (everywhere)"... no, I'm going to stop right there. 

One thing I would like to note as this is confusing - if someone sends you to Golden Gate Park, this is NOT NEXT TO THE BRIDGE! Waaah? The park at the base of the actual Golden Gate Bridge is called Presidio Park.  

There's a ton of different ways to experience the bridge. For the time poor/lazy, get a cab to Presidio Park and walk up the hill until you reach the landing. Absolutely perfect spot for happy snaps and taking in the sights as you walk up.

If you're feeling more adventurous, hire a bike, ride up and continue on over the bridge. You can also walk over the bridge, but it takes a little while and you can't of course see the bridge when you're on it - so the best view is from the side. 

Apparently it gets a bit chilly and foggy up here, so pack a jacket unless you hit an absolute jackpot of a day like I did (thanks, SF!)
author: Mel P.

description: I'm not a fan of the color red. Also, the thing is just freakin' huge, ya know. Just take the long way around it.
author: Michael R.

description: Enjoyed a beautiful walk across the golden gate bridge with my family! It was my girls first time crossing the bridge by foot they were so excited . Had a good experience the only reason I give it a 4 is because of so many bikes they did not yield to pedestrian as sign specified. Would reccomned to any to walk it at least once in there life if there in the city !!!
author: Mario G.

description:
Staying/Visiting SFO???

Must visit GGB.

Its an awesome place with a good number of tourists throughout the year.
author: Priya S.

description:
I've never done the touristy thing and rented a bicycle or walked across this bridge. But with the scrapping of the old bay bridge and the construction of a new one, I'm seeing things differently. 

This bridge is one of the modern wonders of the world. So there isn't much more to say. I'm sure it'll stand the celebrate its 100th birthday. But I don't think that I can say the same for the bay bridge. What's shiny and new isn't always what's best. 

There are some amazing views of this bridge to be had if you cross over into Sausalito. Not to mention views of the San Francisco from downtown Sausalito are spectacular too (a photographer's field day). It feels like there are always tourists, but it's worth enduring to see.
author: Venna Q. T.

description:
Although I live in the Bay Area and frequent SF a few times a year, it still really is breathtaking once you get near the bridge and when you're on it.

No more toll takers; toll is automated now. It will take a picture of your license plate as you drive through the toll booths and send you a $7 bill in the mail.  I have my front plate off yet still took a picture of my back license plate.

I've also ridden my bike across the bridge.  Although it is not as narrow as NY's Brooklyn Bridge, there is no designated bike lane.  So try not to bike over the bridge on weekends when it's really crowded!
author: Michelle L.

description: Visited the bridge for the first time and it is something that anyone who visits San Francisco should visit! The traffic getting to the bridge was not bad at all. When we got to one end of the bridge, there was a "rest area" with restrooms and a great view to take pictures at! We walked on the bridge for a bit and it was a lot of fun. Even if you are afraid of heights, I think it is something someone should experience. The bridge does move a little but surely that's normal.
author: Jojo G.

description:
Here's the biggest tip I can give....don't go there on New Year's day (Jan 1st).  It's WAAAYYY to packed.  

I've been to SF a couple times now and never been to the bridge or taken a pic with my gf there.  I was determined to this time, but unfortunately we went on the wrong day.  I thought we would be slick and get there late in the afternoon on New Year's Day.  Apparently everyone else had the same idea because it was super packed at every look out point we went to.  
We decided to try again the next day.

Much better.  It was about a quarter the amount of people at the look out points and we got a perfect picture overlooking the bridge and bay.

if you are going from SF, travel over the bridge and take the first exit to the right.  There is a look out point as soon as you exit, but I didn't like that one.  Continue down the exit and make a left at the stop sign so you go to there other side of the freeway to the better look out points.

You can go very high up on the mountain, but I think the best ones are the first two you pass up.  Any higher up and you loose the city and bridge in the background.  

Be smart and go up to the turn around (not far past the second point) and make your stops on the way DOWN the mountain.  It is very difficult to try and make a u-turn going up the mountain, plus extremely rude to the people behind you.  Yet, not surprisingly, there are plenty of people who try and do this.  Yes you may have to wait a minute since there aren't many spots to park at the lookouts but usually people move quickly.  

Stop, admire the scenery for a minute, take a cute picture and move on.  It is definitely worth a stop and picture but be aware there are a lot of other people attempting to do the same.
author: Robert A.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is one of those iconic spots that I've only seen in movies until a few months ago when I actually came here in March! The bridge is typically packed with people walking one way and bike riders walking the other. It was pretty windy around 5:30PM, but you could see the calm waters and the sunset along the way. It's kind of a place for you to just relax, take a deep breath and let the worries out just a bit.

Whenever I crossed the bridge, the traffic was pretty heavy, but there's plenty of room for you to walk due to the desperation of the road from the walkway. The Golden Gate Bridge is just one of those things that everyone should have on their list for locations to visit in their life, regardless of it's only once. Definitely a breathtaking experience in terms of the historical aspect, and romantic if you just want to hold hands and walk across with someone you care about. After all, it's only appropriate to visit the Golden Gate Bridge since you're in the "Golden State"!
author: Jimmy T.

description:
I can't seem to conjure up anything more iconic than the Golden Gate Bridge every time I think of good ol' San Francisco. This amazingly built bridge, around three miles long, has been placed as a historic icon and one the most internationally recognized symbols of San Francisco. It has also been declared as one of the wonders of the modern world. Pretty impressive if you ask me.

The bridge is not only the most photographed bridge in the world, but also quite functional. With daily commuters, tourists, and locals alike, this bridge is sturdily made for bike riding, walking, jogging, and running, at all times of the day.

It's no wonder that it carries a lot of sentimental value and prestigious awe among many. 

The Golden Gate Bridge remains as a staple of San Francisco amongst its strong gusts of bay winds.

Compared to its old Bay Bridge counterpart, the Golden Gate Bridge shows more promise in its mainstay and its ability to withstand possible future earthquakes here in the bay. 

Prominent and declarative, this piece of history will forever be a part of San Francisco!
author: Ann S.

description: Tourist attraction!!!!!!!!!! Who doesn't love coming here and taking thousands of selfies with the lovely golden gate bridge in the back. Meeeeeee. It's just beautiful and breath taking! The view is outstanding where you stand really. sigh. I love San frannnnnnnnn
author: Christine P.

description: Definitely one of those must see things and definitely a place to stop if you are in the  Francisco area. One thing to really make sure that you do is get there when there is no fog cover because you'll be waiting anywhere from 30 minutes to two hours for the fog to clear to actually see the bridge. Do not drive here either definitely take some type of public transportation or Uber because parking and traffic is really bad in this area
author: Khalil J.

description: The toll plaza is an example of government stupidity, incompetence and fat at the top - no clearly visible signs that explain how to pay the toll or how it works so visiting motorists will have a clue. The city of San Francisco doesn't even benefit from the fact that they have inadequate signage. Most signs just say to keep moving. Within 48 hours of passing through you must visit the Bay Area Fast Track Website to pay. You'll need to enter your license plate, which is what this system captures when you go through the toll. If you don't, a bill will be generated and sent to your car rental company who may charge you large "convenience fees" to pay for the bridge. If you go to the BBB you can see that Bay Area Fast Track has hundreds of complaints, many unresolved and not surprising for an agency that looks like it's horribly run. The big winner in all this are car rental companies.
author: Michael M.

description: The chill in the air, boat horns, seagulls, the fog.  A few of the many sensory experiences that give this iconic, International Orange-colored bridge its charm.  I've seen it many a times, driven on it a few, but have never walked it.  The toll charge wasn't too bad, but we were just travelers taking a day trip over from SF to Sausalito for a spa day.  If you're a local, I'm sure the commute adds up fast.  The three lanes in either direction are pretty narrow and nerve-wracking whether you're driving or a passenger.  The views are amazing.  Add another to the bucket list!
author: Vince N.

description: After years of wanting to visit San Francisco, I was so happy to see this iconic structure. I took an Uber across from Ghiradelli Square, as my driver recommended seeing it from the other side, so that I would be get views of the San Francisco city skyline as well. It was magical! I took a lot of photos, and then just sat and looked out over the water for awhile, relaxing. Obviously, this is a must-do for anyone visiting SF!
author: Jordan T.

description: As something to look at it is beautiful. As a tourist attraction it is highly effective. As an actual part of civic infrastructure I found it to be frustrating as you are actually prevented from paying the toll (NO STOPPING! the signs scream) and apparently are billed later. Since we visited during a move I have no idea when I will get this bill and am concerned about increased fines as I have been informed you have a very short period to make payment. Other payment options have yet to be discovered and iT just seems like a very inefficient system that is myopically designed.
author: M A.

description: Absolutely amazing! Completely a must see in San Francisco! Second time going to see the bridge. Decided to bike from Fisherman's Warf to the bridge. Amazing bike ride along the bay. Did not go to the visitor station cause it would have been way too busy.
author: Kristofer D.

description: Why on earth is there no one here to take money? I live in San Francisco and avoid taking the Golden Gate Bridge like the plague. Why? Because I have some sort of plate account with fastrack and it never works and I can never sign into my account because I can't remember the password of an account I use once a year and when I call I can't get a live person either. Today after screaming at the phone representative representative representative( don't judge you know you have done it too) I finally got a live fellow who clearly hated his job and mumbled through my transaction. This took 15 min and probably twenty of my life online trying to get through the system that would not let me pay!  Then I said yes to an online survey to complain but the recorded instructions of that survey were so garbled I could not use it. I really would prefer a human and cash and a receipt. So I will drive the bay bridge and San Rafael as much as possible. Too bad I used to go over weekly.
author: Leann W.

description: Beautiful,historical....great view,connects the city to rich hippies! Costly to return from....red....or orangie red.Treasure island,wind,Alcatraz,San Francisco bay......a must go A must do!
author: Brian D.

description: How do you write a bad review of the Golden Gate Bridge? If you get there during the daylight hours you can tour the fort and take even more amazing photos. The fort is free but has a recommended donation amount. If you have time to visit twice or 3 times - try to catch it when the fog is rolling in, when it's sunny and at night. all three are breathtaking.
author: Susan H.

description:
How do you review an iconic structure that means so many different things to so many different people? Especially when this architectural wonder conjures various emotions depending on your approach (southbound vs. northbound), the opacity of the brooding fog, or who's crossing the bridge with you. 

Most days, I tense up a bit with overwhelming awe... goose bumps, tingles, the whole bit. Why is the fog so drawn to the bewitching bridge? Why was the GG painted a hue dubbed International Orange? The bridge has inspired many late-night Wikipedia spirals.... oh magnificent one, how you fascinate me.

Some days, I smile widely as I cross into the North Bay... long live the diversity of the Bay Area micro climates! In mere minutes, we're transported to a warmer California.

On other days, I smile in anticipation of my gorgeous city welcoming me back into its arms as I spy the panorama of the bay rushing up to seamlessly meet the skyline. The Golden Gate serves as a dazzling symbol of our beauteous city on the bay, yes?

But once in awhile, I tear up. I think of those who made one final trip to the bridge to end their lives and I grow somber... all that pain; so much deep despair underneath the same bridge that usually brings me so much joy. 

You see, taking in the Golden Gate Bridge is complicated because it's very personal. Everyone has their own story, and that's what makes the 1.7 mile journey across so achingly beautiful.
author: Jelena Z.

description: I'd say its a solid bridge. I really like the fact that you can run/walk the entire span of the bridge over to the Marin side. Something I believe they are working on for the bay bridge... but they might have bigger fish to fry.  Not only can you walk it, but bikers can do their thing on the other side as well. Nothing gives you that San Francisco feeling (whatever that may be) like walking on such an iconic bridge. Some relatives who live abroad could barely point to SF on a map, but recognize the bridge from various movies its starred in lol. Thats when I go "yea thats where I live". Also, makes for great early morning runs before the tourists attack!
author: Thielson D.

description: This adventure i will cherish for the rest of my life.  Never in my wildest dreams did I think I would ride a bike across a bridge.  When i was told we was doing it I was thrilled.  Yes it was a long ride to the bridge and across but the scenery was to die for.
author: Lakiya P.

description: Such a Beautiful bridge and great architecture. It was a bit difficult to find the best location, and we got confused for a bit due to construction but it was great!
author: Ziggie N.

description:
On a marathon, I've ran across it. With friends, we've biked across it. With love, we walked across it. Born in SF and been here for nearly a decade, I have yet walked across. The one thing I've always wanted to do was walk across the bridge, take in the scenery and height, and do it on a gorgeous day with my love. The wind factor was minimal. The sun was beaming and no fog close by. That's the thing about magical moments, you will always remember them with the person you do it with. I want to open the eyes and soul of another and show them how to live. 

Can we do this more often?!
author: Jane A.

description:
This is a breathtaking sight. It seems silly to write a review of one of the most iconic structures in America, so I will give you highlights from my experience.

It is actually quite easy to get to the bridge on public transportation. There is a transportation company called Golden Gate which is a commuter bus. It will take you to the bridge, but is expensive. Look for a Muni bus that will take you there.

Drop by the visitor center and take a look at the unique gifts available.

We walked the bridge at sunset. Start about 30-45 minutes before sunset and walk to the half-way point, you will have spectacular views of the Bay and the sunset.
author: Daniel M.

description: Really beautiful views from the top of the bridge. You can walk on the sides. It gets really chilly though on some days
author: Mohan S.

description:
"Come on now don't be late
That's why I can hardly wait
Open up that Golden Gate
California here I come!"

The symbol of San Francisco, welcoming, majestic, and unmistakeable.  

There are many ways to take in this iconic landmark.  If you choose to walk across it, be aware that the first half is extra crowded due to people turning around at the halfway point, so I would rather make my way down the entire bridge or even just the farther half.  Be sure to watch out for the bikers as they can approach suddenly from behind and the sidewalk is very narrow.  There are some interesting historical exhibits on the more popular side should if you choose to start there.

From other angles, there are many great options.  A bit past the bridge on the Sausalito side is the entrance to some parking lots located on the high ridges looking down onto the bridge, especially lovely right after sunset.  Baker Beach offers an interesting angle from below, as does the battery immediately below the bridge.

Be prepared for very windy weather.  Should there be excessive fog expect to see only half of the bridge towers.
author: Emily Y.

description: We can see one tower from our bedroom window!  (If you really bend your neck!) I love this bridge and the fact that I have walked it front to back seven times! I have been lucky that every-time the wind and cold weren't present. We love living within walking distance from here.. not super close, but I have walked from our apartment to the bridge once.
author: Kirk M.

description:
Walking across the bridge can be a fun touristy thing to do and will get you some great pictures but plan to take a bus or ferry back - once you've done walked the bridge one way you won't want to walk back again. 

Also keep in mind that if it's a foggy day you won't be able to see anything from the bridge and it's probably not worth doing.
author: Jenna A.

description: Must see sf!! Awesome icon!!! Walk across for some exercise or bike! Don't cross with a car because that came be I think $12.00. I would go to crissy field near by, palace of fine arts, and also the old fort just below the bridge. Walking a cross is free and free Parking on the weekends, although a walk can be found by the forts
author: Diane S.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is an icon! 
Deff a must see if your in the San Fran area. I drove across the bridge then turned left and went up the hill to the lookout point (Free to park) and it had amazing views of the bridge and the city skyline. I gatta say though it was Super windy up there so bring a jacket! Was cool to see the fog swirling around in the wind.
author: Autumn S.

description: What more is there to say?! So much beauty! Great views!!! Very serene. It was my first time in San Fran so of course I had to see the bridge. It really was majestic. I was very impressed. Note: extremely windy!!!!!!
author: Vee W.

description:
i would say, i love sfo, victorian houses, new place to go. i mean everything in sanfo amazes me except for TRAFFIC. ill give 3 stars because parking isnt specific, full
of 1 way streets and because the area for where you can get a great shot is over crowded. i wish they have some traffic control officers around.
author: Kate B.

description: Mongo no see gold. Mongo no see gate. But Mongo see big, big, BIIIGGGG bridge! Maybe bridge red? Maybe bridge orange? Mongo see many people. And many, many, many cars. Mongo see ocean. Mongo see mountains. Mongo see sky. It's so pretty on big bridge. Mongo no understand why people jump from bridge. And everybody nice to Mongo.
author: Mongo I.

description:
The bridge itself is truly an icon of America- this is a must see when in SF for the first time. Driving on it is one thing. Walking end to end? Certainly a very good experience.

I started my walk from the Sausalito side (by the Vista Point exit) and proceeded to get some so-so pictures. Depends on the time of day that you go on the bridge, the fog and lighting tends to affect picture angles. On the SF side, there is a larger pavillon and better opportunity (in my opinion) to get better pictures. Why? You are closer to the downtown area to photograph the skyline, and you are able to get a better vantage point of both GGB towers. The results in taking pictures from the SF were outstanding in picture quality.

If there is one thing that I didn't particularly like about the Golden Gate Bridge, its with the attitude of the cyclists. I'm not talking about the casual bicycle rider either. I'm referring to the Lance Armstrong wannabees that push tourists around with their griping. The bridge has its designated bike lane + walking lane (on the right) and while I cannot blame the cyclists for getting mad at some tourists that meander into the bicycle lanes a little bit, there are other cyclists that come remarkably close in knocking someone down despite the walker being in the correct lane. There were three occasions where a cyclist bumped me when I was walking on the right side. I couldn't understand why there were cyclists racing on the bridge when there was an incredible amount of tourist traffic walking on the right side on this day. At the time of my walk, it was between 11:30 AM and 1:30 PM, and the other side of the bridge wasn't opened yet.

My opinion for the city of SF or whatever authority that manages the operation + upkeep of the bridge: keep the left side of the bridge open (the side heading northbound into Sausalito) for cyclists only and the right side open for tourists and casual bicycle riders during touring hours. This will certainly help prevent any cyclist-tourist transgressions or accidents.
author: Eric T.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is a MUST SEE "thing" to do when visiting San Francisco! 

For those who love impressive views or would like to admire classic architecture, the Golden Gate Bridge is something you should NOT sleep on! 

Like any other tourist, it would also be natural to "oooh" and "ahhh" over the breathtaking views. 

Like any other tourist, it would be natural to take photos with your camera or smart phone.

Like any other tourist, it would be natural to take these photos from your smart phone and immediately posting them on Facebook and Instagram ASAP. 

Here are my tourist photos:
1. Amazing view! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/golden-gate-bridge-san-francisco?select=K62sZJLlcx_Lsz9dxiJZFA#NvOqni8lptcDapr2V411rA)
2. The boyfriend and I (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/golden-gate-bridge-san-francisco?select=K62sZJLlcx_Lsz9dxiJZFA#L7CTaxV1tLUHCIjr5rRDgQ)

FYI =
-Parking can be a bit difficult in the area
-Expect a lot of tourists! (I was one of them)
-Try to check out during the mid-day so that the fog won't roll in and block the view of the bridge
-Suspension bridge links you the SF Peninsula to Marin County
-Yes you can walk/bike on the bridge
-Dubbed as "most photographed, bridge in the world" by Frommers travel guide (and I do concur!)
-Declared as "One of the Wonders of the Modern World" by the American Society of Engineers (and I do concur with this too!)

If you are a visitor and you did NOT see the Golden Gate Bridge, then shame on you! For all the locals and visitors who do visit this awesome piece of architecture - KUDOS to you! =)

Yelp 2013 100 for 100 Challenge - Review #100
author: Kristen M.

description:
Before I moved to SF, I lived in San Antonio, and drove past the Alamo every day on my way to work. I don't drive across the Golden Gate Bridge every day on my way to work, but I might soon!

Have driven across several times at different times of day, and there usually isn't much traffic- everything seems to keep moving pretty quickly. I've also gone under the bridge on a fishing trip, which was even cooler than driving across- by far! It looks about a million times larger from that angle, too. 

Great bridge for pictures, and definitely a must-visit for new residents, tourists, and visitors. Various businesses offer photography lessons, bike tours, walking tours, and other activities in this area that take place on or around the bridge, too.

$6 toll going into the city gets old fast though, if you're commuting- so glad they do the automatic plate billing though, because other bridges that only have Fastrack or cash lines don't work for me- I never carry cash and don't know too many people who do!
author: Stefany V.

description:
Oh so pretty and iconic.  This is the postcard image most people have of San Francisco.  Be a tourist in your own city and enjoy your bridge, people come from all over the world to see it and it's in our backdrop every day.   

I recommend walking the whole thing on a nice day.  A foggy day can be too cold.  The wind picks up here so as with most places in SF, layer up.  Stop in the middle of the bridge and look down, on some days you can see the currents moving in different directions.  Stopping along the bridge to take pictures and walking leisurely, it took 1.5 hours to go round trip from the San Francisco side.  Bring a picnic and enjoy the view.
author: Kristi G.

description:
When Execution fails...

A pretty good idea that hatched into a chaotic snafu due to committee planning and unaccountable execution.

Pros
* Hastens toll collection (yeah! No waiting, except behind the 20% of confused summer tourists);
* Saves money by allowing toll-takers' heads to roll (although their % of the GG Bridge District's budget was insignificant);
* License-plate reading & lookup technology is proven and off-the-shelf (shiny new toys!)

Cons
* The money-saving benefits don't allow a toll reduction. Instead, another increase was deemed essential.
* Fastrak hobbles the entire system. RFID tags don't last like license plates. Fastrak works well, when it works.  But Fastrak's automated deposit-incrementing policy is arbitrary yet inflexible. And God forbid you should ever have an issue that requires human intervention. Fastrak customer servants have earned, at minimum, Certifications in Obfuscation, and many possess PhD's in Sophistry. Never try to get the spelling of your name corrected. Just sayin'.
author: Eugene S.

description: Impeccable views!!  One of many great human accomplishments.  SF is an amazing city.  We ran across the bridge and walked it back.  It gets crazy with all the other tourists.  I suggest to bike ride across the bridge if you can.  Or just walk.  It gets windy and chilly!!
author: ViJay K.

description:
I've been around the world and to date, Eiffel Tower included, this is the MOST IMPRESSIVE Structure I have ever seen. 
Pictures, posters and movies do not do justice and are unable to illustrate the scope of this Art Deco Sculpture.
I simply was not prepared for its enormity.
It is GRANDIOSE and AWESOME SKY INSPIRING.
Go beneath it and look up into the sky, you will not believe how imposing it is and how small you feel.
I have a real fear of heights and standing along the waterside looking up almost made me pass out. 
If you have never visited San Francisco, you will have to go, as for me this is one of the REAL Worlds Wonderful Man Made Wonders.
author: D W.

description:
Great place to snapchat/instagram/facebook/tweet.

It's about 1.7 miles long. The toll is $7.25 heading SOUTH into San Francisco.

The best shots to take photos are from the northern cliff, Golden Gate pavilion, or from Land's End.

#ican'tbelieveit'snotgolden
author: Jeffrey Y.

description:
I ran it. 

1.5 miles one way. 

It was beautiful. 

Mission accomplished.
author: Elsie W.

description:
Hi,

I'm a long-time customer off the GG Bridge, for 30 years and I've given your bridge a small fortune over the years, so I'm hoping to be heard.

This afternoon at about 3:30pm (Saturday), it took 30 minutes for me to get from Lombard (at Fillmore) to the bridge.It was an absolute parking lot as usual. I was amazed when I finally got up to the bridge that there were 3 lanes in each direction, yet NO TRAFFIC at all going southbound. It was clear all the way from Sausalito to the toll plaza. Why aren't you serving customers better by reconfiguring lanes to alleviate huge back-ups?

I actually called, which I'll do every once in a while, and I always reach the most uneducated-sounding, rude person who answers your phone. It's super impressive when someone says "we ain't goin' to be changin' the lanes tonight or on the weekends & if you don't like it, you can go on our website to complain".  The person also said that there was traffic southbound - absolutely not true, I saw it with my own two eyes. 

I'd love for the GG Bridge to get an new administration.
author: David R.

description:
Definitely on my list of things to do/see for out-of-town guests. 

It's free if you're headed Northbound out of San Francisco. 

Just note, there is toll coming back into San Francisco, and as of 2013, it is cashless toll now. Please have your Fastrak ready, or call 511 to pre-pay your toll.
author: Charles K.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is absolutely gorgeous and is one of the most photographed bridges in the world!

This magnificent steel suspension bridge spans over the Pacific Ocean and connects San Francisco to Marin County.  This incredible bridge took four years and $35 million to build and was completed in 1937.  Today over 110,000 cars cross the six lanes of the bridge daily.  Pedestrians and bicycles are able to cross the bridge through walkways on either side of the bridge.  

Photographs at this bridge are a must.  You can capture the magnificent bridge with the San Francisco skyline and the Pacific Ocean in the background.  You can also spot the infamous Alcatraz from certain points.  The views are magnificent on a clear day and slightly mysterious on the foggy days.

A dark fact about the bridge: this is the 2nd most popular spot in the world to commit suicide.  Please don't commit suicide on this bridge!  My suggestion?  There are so many great dining options in San Francisco.  Wouldn't it be more enjoyable to just eat yourself to a slow and glorious death?
author: Michelle M.

description:
Fastrak noise: Beep beep. Love being able to sail on through without stopping.

Sure wish they would stop screwing everyone with all those whacked up late notices.
author: Loli L.

description:
We were going to bike this bridge, but my tire fell flat before getting there :( Boo

But we still managed to get a picture with this beautiful bridge! It is a 3 mile long bridge that connects the city to Marin County. A lot of people walk here as well as bike, and of course many people drive the bridge lol. For those who bike the bridge, they have the option to bike the bridge back or take the ferry service back to the city.

For those who were kind of lazy to go to the bridge up close and personal (like us lol), we took a picture of the bridge at Crissy Field; if you bike along the Marina you will definitely hit up Crissy Field which is surrounded by bike/walk paths, a beach, and a great spot to take pictures of the bridge.
author: Felicia L.

description:
Giving the Golden Gate Bridge anything less than 5 stars is just un-San Franciscan ( adopted or born)

This iconic bridge has been around for years and years, it's what the people want to see when in SF and there is an excellent reason for it - it is just great! Whether you drive across, bike across, walk across, or even just stop at one of the many vista points on either side of the bridge to stare for a minute or so, this bridge takes your breath away. 

No matter how many times I've been here, I always enjoy a visit back. Golden Gate, this is the beginning of a beautiful friendship.
author: Emily G.

description:
Went across 3 times, waited forever for the invoice, it comes, dated sent the 1/5/15 due by 1/26/15, from crossings 11/17-11/19, they JUST sent me a notice, and its already 90+ dollars in collection fines. THIS IS BULLCRAP. you call and theres no option to talk to an actual person, I submitted a dispute and will be joining the class action lawsuit against this fraud. my address is correct with the DMV there is no excuse this wasnt delayed in the mail it simply wasnt sent to give me fair notice to pay this bill. its a total scam. I've done it fine in the past but this time they are trying to screw me thanks to xerox and its automated fraud system.

FIX THIS SF this is shameful being that we are in Silicon valley, this system is total garbage.
author: Drew V.

description:
Last year beginning of December I had to cross the bridge and found to my surprise nobody manning the booth..  No idea what to do, I waited for an invoice..  It came and the first notice already had added 25$ penalty for "evading" the toll! Fighting this, doesn't seem to work .. I filed the dispute and I am still waiting to hear back (Message notes that it will take 5 days, and its been 2 weeks now) 
I am afraid, if I don't pay up, they will ad more fees to the dispute..  I feel hoodwinked.. this really is a crying shame.
author: Beatrix F.

description: Given the unpredictable weather in SF, you never really know if the fog is going to take over the bridge so you won't be able to see it. If you can, it's a beautiful sight to see and to drive over into Sausalito. Go take a picture at the viewing area.
author: Natasha K.

description:
6 Stars

There is no other landmark in the world that means more to me than the Golden Gate Bridge of San Francisco.

It stands as more than just a bridge, it is an icon of freedom to me . . . every bit as the Statue of Liberty in New York City.

It is the open mouth, open heart, and entrance to our land of the free and home of the brave.

I have driven or been driven across the Golden Gate Bridge literally thousands of times---I never tire of its beauty and symbolism.

California is the Golden State. The Golden Gate Bridge is the capstone to the pyramid of all things golden.

Golden Gate Bridge . . . You make me want to sing!

Review 0079
author: Fred V F.

description:
Ask someone what comes to their mind when they think of US. Two places a. Golden Gate Bridge b. Statue of Liberty. Need I say more ?? Hallmark of the greatest engineering and architecture of our times and shall remain in eternity.

With so many yelpers giving tons of explanation about the golden gate bridge I'm sure I can't mention something that hasn't been already told, also I don't want to spoil my review by writing tons of information on this unique masterpiece. Go and experience yourself and your perception shall change forever. Kudos to the team that built this.
author: Geetha K.

description: Golden Gate is a must see if you are visiting San Francisco. Although, its always Pretty crowded   it's  always worth visiting with friends and family.
author: Jane D.

description: I just get excited crossing a beautiful bridge! I love the city and the Golden Gate Bridge is the coolest bridge ever.
author: Robin G.

description: The Golden Gate Bridge is the most iconic structure in the western United States in my opinion. It's what connects mainland California to San Fransisco (or at least, the quickest route). As far as the "awe" factor goes, GGB is pretty cool. There is usually a lot of traffic and pedestrians on the bridge at any given time during the day and it is a very big structural bridge. That being said, it is just a bridge, and an extremely busy one at that. Not knowing your local routes can cost you upwards of an extra 90 minutes to cross it heading east. Yes, 90 minutes. It is just so congested and unpredictable that the frustration of its logistics hampers my rating. Overall though, GGB is still one of the most beautiful sites of not only California, but the United States. If you come to SF, you must check out GGB!
author: Adam S.

description:
How can one give this bridge anything but five stars?  Its got you visitor parking at both ends.  Interpretive displays all around.  A book and souvenir shop.   And, yes amazing views.   And if you keep your eyes open as you walk across, you have a good chance of. Harbor porpoises below.  Ive seen them just about every time i walk across.  

So yes, you can walk across it on the East side.  Yea you can also bike (just be sure to watch your speed and the routing.  The side you ride on changes by time of day).  

Huge downside is when they mix pedestrians with bikers on the same side.  Im surprised that there are not more accidents because of the asshole bikers who just speed along.  Of course the pedestrians are tourists and looking at the scenery, not at speeding bikes.  

If you are a local, you owe it to yourself to check this out and walk across the bridge.
author: Marcus K.

description: The views. The VIEWS. It's a great place to get to if you're in the area. You can get free parking at the Battery's (southwest of the bridge / 101). The walk between there and this bridge offers some of the best views of San Fran, Ocean, and the bridge itself. I recommend walking to the center of this bridge for the best pictures!
author: Robb F.

description: Stopped in on the way to the Bay Area based on previous yelp reviews and we were not disappointed wonderful food. Well worth the short trip of I-5 if you are driving through Redding.
author: Orna B.

description:
It may cost you $76 to cross this bridge in toll fees...

You are suppose to get an invoice for your toll, however,  they skip this step and go immediately to the second step of issuing a toll violation notice demanding the toll with a $25 penalty.  The penalty is waived with enrollment in Fastrack, however,  you still have to give up $25 to fund the account.  

Where did I go wrong??   I didn't.   While doing an internet search figuring this mystery I stumbled upon an active lawsuit.  I'm not alone.  In fact, over 290,000 people were erroneously penalized with the bridge district raking in millions.   This concerns me since all the bay area bridges are exploring automated toll collection.   Scam.  Read for yourself.

http://abc7news.com/technology/7-on-your-side-fastrak-customers-unfairly-hit-with-penalties/515536/


http://topclassactions.com/lawsuit-settlements/lawsuit-news/33841-golden-gate-fastrak-fees-rack-class-action-lawsuit/
author: Freddy K.

description: Kinda hard for me to rate a bridge, but it is pretty cool looking as far as bridges go. We went to Marshall's Beach just to take a glimpse of the bridge, and then took the bridge back to where we were staying. Quite nice!
author: Tien D.

description: FIVE stars, no question. The Golden Gate Bridge is an engineering marvel, large-scale wonder, scenic beauty...a SF must-see! Walk it, run it, bike it, photograph it, enjoy it...it's amazing. If you have time, go below it at Fort Point, head to the west side and cross to the north side - all excellent vantage points and perspectives from the different locations. FIVE stars.
author: Patrick L.

description:
Hands down one of the highlights of our trip to the land of the free and home of the brave and, rightly so as according to Wikipedia, the Frommers travel guide considers it to be perhaps the most beautiful and certainly the most photographed bridge in the world.. What can I say? I did my research prior to the trip and isn't a bit of fun fact heaps of 'fun'?

The Golden Gate Bridge links San Fran to Marin County and it stands  between the bay and the Pacific Ocean. Now.. Most of you might say: alright yeah yeah whatever but I love that... the fact that if you're standing on the bridge and facing north, you'd be looking at the Pacific by turning your head to the left and the the bay by looking right. I find this 'significant', don't you? It's like say you went to Invercargill in NZ and you went all the way to the southern tip, facing south; you'd be looking at the Antarctic, with only miles and miles of ocean ahead until you reached Antarctica. Come on, this has got to be exciting, right?

Anyway, where was I? Oh yes, the Golden Gate Bridge is not just a bridge, it's a symbol, a wonder of the world. I wonder if Strauss, Morrow or even Ellis ever imagined that it'd be such an internationally recognized structure when they designed it? 

It's very touristy yes and you'd expect it to be anyway but it's a must-see if you're ever in San Fran. Cross it if you can (it's about 3 miles long but I did it and it was awesome!), it's a  amazing feeling, you'll get stunning views of the bay and you can also feel the vibration patterns when you're on it... Yes, you heard right, the bridge displays vibration modes which means it shakes but there's nothing to be scared of, it's meant to do that as it's a suspension bridge. 

Thinking about it now, I remember seeing locals running and others biking along it, which was really cool. I know I would go for runs along it if I lived in San Fran - certainly beats running along princes park!

There you go guys.. Planning a trip to San Fran or heading there shortly, make sure you add the Golden Bridge to your list; you won't regret it!
author: Kevin S.

description:
What SF is known for, this is a MUST! Beautiful, gorgeous, picturesque - if you don't come, you'll be disappointed!

Come here on a sunny day for the perfect pic. Amazing & breathtaking.
author: Olivia S.

description:
It's the bridge everyone goes to see when friends are in town. Bring some layers because it gets pretty cold over here. There are some buses that go to this side of the city, but it's a little easier if you have a car. My niece ended up finding a spot where you can walk down the steps all the way to Fort Point. The view is pretty amazing and if you're in good company it's well worth checking out at least once.

Parking is pretty pricey and you get two hours at the meter. Probably for a good reason, they don't want you staying all day. On a clear day, this can be a great spot to show out of towners. Sometimes it's ok to be a tourist.
author: Amy J.

description:
I've been crossing the Golden Gate bridge all my life.  I can't believe it's even possible for anyone to make something so bad as Fastrak!  I understand it makes traffic flow smoother, which is good, or would be good, if the rest of their system didn't suck so bad.  It also may or may not work ok for people who have a standing account.  But for the majority of people, here's how it works:

You drive through with no opportunity to pay.  In the old days, it was 10 seconds, and you're done.  Now, you have to wait for mail, and hope that doesn't get lost in the shuffle.  The mail arrives a month after the crossing took place, and has less than 2 weeks before the due date, after which the $7 crossing will be $25.  

There are 2 "payment options."  Online or phone.  Go online, enter their 13 digit invoice # (really, does it have to be 13 digits?  How about making it your license plate plus a number, or something easier to deal with?)  Get to the invoice page, click pay by credit card, enter info...discover system is broken.
