It will not take a payment.  Try different computer, browser, thinking, "surely it's not really broken."  Yes, it's broken.

Call to pay by phone.  It's a weekend.  They only work business hours.  There is no return envelop or payment by mail option.  Try to make a note to call them while working.  

What once took 10 seconds, now takes 10 minutes, if everything goes right.  In my case, much more.  Multiply that by all the number of people crossing the bridge that need to go through this.  The waste of human man hours/work hours/time is staggering!
author: Kelly E.

description: This review is mainly for the photo op of the Golden Gate Bridge. It never gets old seeing it and I love taking everyone that visits here.
author: Vika N.

description: Only good when the weather is clear. Beautiful bridge! Great panoramic views. Got in a good long walk and jog workout back and forth. Glad to live near by.
author: Veronica F.

description: I always love visiting the golden gate. I got lucky and had sunshine for a little bit to take pics.
author: Chas L.

description:
Clap, clap, clap.
As good as it gets.  My heart still skips a beat when returning to SF from Marin.  The view of the GGB and SF after exiting the tunnel is sublime.
author: Thomas D.

description: Must go if your in San Fran. Beautiful and great view. This is one of the things in San Fran that does not cost you and awesome.
author: Pooh O.

description: Always loving Frisco can forget this please brings me a lot of memories,.......................
author: Abner B.

description:
My heart skips a beat every time I see this classic San Francisco icon.  Walking or running it can be scary with cars flying by and the posted signs encouraging potential jumpers not to do it.  But no trip is complete without catching a glimpse of this landmark. Day or night.

It's free, but bring cash to cross the toll if you're driving.
author: Lorraine P.

description: Go in the morning around 10am on a weekday! Not crowded and usually the fog is gone by this time. Taking pictures from here really looks like something from a post card! So beautiful. The only thing I would complain about is the forte that's right next to the bridge... It's supposed to be historical but the smell of pee everywhere and all the garbage ruins the experience.
author: Melissa C.

description: 1* because of all the clueless tourists on bikes, +1* for nice views of the city
author: Luke R.

description:
This place holds a special place in our lives, and so just for that, it automatically gets 5 stars! and hey, it could be a special place for you too!

Parking can be a nightmare if you are trying to get to this place. We have a rental and we got so lucky to get parking on the other side of the street within 5 minutes time. When you do go, make sure you have at least a light jacket and don't wear skirts unless your soul is prepared to unveil to the world the underwear you so carefully chose that morning. It is chilly and drafty. Ya dig?

Of course, photo op is in every corner since this is one of the most recognizable land marks in the world. This bridge is romantic, can also be a good place for a run or a walk, and just looking out at the bay bring some sense of happiness and peace. 

side note***** If you are renting a car, allow your car rental company to pay for the toll - i do have beef with the toll company since we made a one time payment and they have continuously charged our card for that rental- AND it is literally impossible to get a hold of them -- i mean, it has been 3 weeks and i still have not been able to get in touch with anyone. so there! beware of the toll since you now have to do it yourself online and any glitch in the system or any mistakes, it will take weeks to straighten out - if it does ever get straighten out.****
author: Queenie D.

description:
Ironic. Epic. Beautiful. It was a handmade gift to my first wife back in the early 90s as trolls and billygoats were beggining to live and migrate to Marin and S.f.
Did you know you can walk across from one side to another?
And they have phones to convince you not to commit suicide....
and I when I die I want my ashes sprinkled in the water from this height. ;)
author: Michael R.

description:
Love coming here!  There are many wonderful scenic viewing areas for admiring the Golden Gate Bridge!  We've probably been to all of them plus more over the years.  Each official (and unofficial) viewing spot is terrific.

Everytime we come here is like the very first time.  There will always be something we see that we never noticed before.  It does not matter what the weather is....rain, shine, fog, etc....it's all good!!

There is only one thing on our bucket list regarding the Golden Gate Bridge which we have not done yet.  One of these days, we are going to walk across the Golden Gate Bridge!!!

Everyone should visit the Golden Gate!  It is a destination that is not to be missed!
author: PatrickJ T.

description: Take a long walk over a long bridge. Was so fun. We uber-Ed to the other side of the bridge and had the most hysterical driver. Good way to start the day. Was super windy-no surprise-but a must do!  Didn't take very long. Watch out for the bikers. Wear a hat and sunscreen.
author: Veda Loca K.

description:
This bridge is so gorgeous and gargantuan! Its deep red color really adds to its vibrant significance and is so representative of Northern California. Whenever I have driven along this bridge, it is gloomy and cloudy - typical San Francisco weather. But on rare occasions, it's sunny and even more beautiful. The drive is just lengthy enough to get great pictures but not too long to feel bored and annoyed. It overlooks the bay and Alcatraz, that creepy islander prison. 

This is a great spot to take pictures or go for a bike ride like I see a lot of people do along this bridge. You can even go for a stroll and walk it while still getting great photos and a work-out ;) The only thing that sucks is the toll you must pay to come back into the city but you should just get used to it because most bridges have tolls in NorCal and I wouldn't be surprised if they started doing that to freeways, ugh. Anyway, a great tourist attraction and place to visit while in the bay area.
author: Alicia H.

description: Amazing views of San Fran, Alcatraz, and points north. Take a GGT bus for $4.75 if you're at a convenient pick up spot and don't have a car. It's about 1.5 miles each way so it's a healthy walk and an amazing feat of engineering.
author: Landon C.

description: How can you give the Golden Gate Bridge less than 5 stars? It's simply a beaut. Got the chance to take a few great pictures right off the highway at a viewing location. Don't really have much to say because the pictures do all the talking.
author: Shikhar M.

description:
review the Golden Gate Bridge? 
Well I must admit there was a time when I thought giving a rating or review 
for a bridge was dumb, even stupid. I have changed my ways and try now to 
look at things from a higher elevation. Although I have been occasionally driving across this bridge for over 40 years, the thought of reviewing it was not on my radar. For most of the world (remember there are over 7 billion of us) the Golden Gate bridge is something they have never seen, or at best seen it in a movie or TV show. So lets take a short look at one of the engineering marvels of the world. The American Society of Civil Engineers call it one of the engineering marvels of the world! Wow that sounds big. It was the longest suspension bridge in the world till the Verazanno Narrows Bridge was build in 1964. What caught my eye was it was built under budget and on schedule. That to me goes beyond amazing for a project as large as this. It is always a wonderful walk, or drive. It is spectacular to see both up close and afar. If you come to San Francisco, it is a wonderful walk or drive. There are spots on both sides to park and enjoy a stroll. The picture overlook on the north is wonderful, and there are many spot on the south as well. Any way you slice it, the Golden Gate bridge is something to look at, walk on, drive on and enjoy during your trip to San Francisco.
author: Charley C.

description:
Not sure what all these five star reviews are about, this bridge sucks!! International Orange? That isn't even a real color, bridges aren't allowed to invent color names. It's smaller, has less cars, and is younger than the Bay Bridge. I grew up in Marin, went to school in San Francisco, and commuted to San Francisco for several years, so I have probably crossed the bridge a couple thousand times, and it sucks just as much every time. Even worse, they have a monopoly on SF/Marin transportation. The same people that run the Bridge also run the Ferries and Buses! You are all pawns in their game! 

TL/DR: Golden Gate Bridge = Comcast with a better marketing team.
author: Jordan A.

description:
I knew that once I was going to be living in SF for grad school I quickly added crossing the GG Bridge to my bucket list. I didn't care if I walked or biked across, as long as I crossed. However I walked, jogged and biked across to the other side a few times. I love this bridge. I love that's it's a historical landmark that I can now say I've explored. I love that it almost scares me being on it because I am so high up and I love the amazing views of SF that I've seen. 

Biking over the middle can be sort of a pain because of all the foot traffic (you can ride on the opposite side, but you don't have great views) but once you get to about the middle of the bridge, you're clear. There are designated lanes for walkers and bikers, but of course the walkers take over. 

I loved coming here on Saturday/Sunday morning or riding at dusk. I really love this bridge with its gorgeous red/orange rustic aesthetic charm. I never understood any of my fellow students or people that could live in such a beautiful culture enriched city and have never visited the bridge. Shame on you!
author: Court S.

description:
GGB: tetracycle haiku*

(a)
If pictures steal souls
You would long since have been gone;
But here you stand, tall.

(b)
Towers in thick fog
Sentinels of steely light
Guide them home tonight!

(c)
Suspended in time:
All the ones who fell through once
So that you might live.

(d)
Gateway to new worlds.
We crossed here to reach our home:
California.
 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lz7ydUVmsr2DekT9enEhvw?select=mgUApgW9s7SkoXxsa4cqmg

(*) For Sarah W., because she had the courage to ask.
author: Bradley N.

description: The bridge is a beautiful monument of human work, and the accomplishment of what can be done when people work together. You can also see beautiful views of San Francisco and the surrounding areas. It's difficult to walk on the sidewalk due to the overflow of bicycles and pedestrians, but you will be okay if you keep your head up. It was an amazing experience and is definitely needed if you plan on making a trip to San Francisco!
author: Margaret P.

description:
Worst experience ever, they send a invoice to your address, there are two QR codes and neither one of them work, once you go to the website you have to correctly answer 20 pieces of information, and when you hit submit it doesn't actually do anything, it just freezes for many minutes, and then it resets some of your information. Their website is horrible, and it has been the third time that it has been horrible for over 9 months. My wife has had the same terrible experiece. If you don't enter a time before crossing and a date and time "after today's date" (listed as optional, but it is Not optional, and doesn't mention that it needs a future date), you cannot continue.
Using their automated phone system takes 5 to 6 minutes, and if you ever accidentally enter a number incorrectly or choose a wrong option that is not available, it immediately hangs up on you. So you better get your credit card right, and you better get your invoice number which is 12 digits correct the first time around as well. To be precise if it only catches 11 digits it hangs up on you, and if you forget to press the pound sign for 3 seconds after entering your credit card number it hangs up on you, and if you incorrectly enter one of your credit card numbers, it hangs up on you. 
And if you pay your toll on time,  you sometimes get charged for your toll again, and if you do not pay again even though you did not cross you will be heavily fined. And if you dispute the fine, they will only charge you two tolls instead of one.  The price of noticing that they have made a mistake is the same as the price of a second toll. Beware international car renters with imperfect English and little extra time, you are screwed as of right now.
author: Steven B.

description:
DUDE, its the bridge!!  Welcome to the bay where all the players play. 

I recommend coming here in the mid morning after traffic dies down!  At night its a great view also, but I like it in the daytime better.

Sometimes in the evening the fog will roll in and cover the bridge, so you want a nice picture go after traffic time when there is less chance of fog!

This bridge is so awesome that I wrote a extensive guide with pictures if you're visiting San Francisco for the first time and now sure what to do!

http://www.thealldayblog.com/the-choose-your-own-adventure-1-day-all-day-trip-guide-to-san-francisco/

Plus there are lots of other cools places to mentioned in the blog post!

Hope everyone enjoys the bridge as much as I Do!

-Mike Le All Day!
author: Michael L.

description:
One of my favorite places to visit in the Bay Area. It's beautiful all around. Go for a stroll in the park & bring a kite for flying. Walking or biking across the bridge is an unforgettable experience. 

It's an awesome place to bring friends from out of town or visit on a date. Then you can head down to the pier some good grub. Bring a sweater or light jacket because it could get windy. And, be willing to be patient with traffic. Sit back & enjoy the ride.
author: Joseph S.

description:
Unquestionably, it is the most beautiful and probably most photographed bridge in the world!

As prominent an American landmark as the State of Liberty or Mount Rushmore. It's an international symbol of San Francisco, California and the United States.

The Golden Gate Bridge, therefore, is much more than a suspension bridge that connects the San Francisco Peninsula to Marin County. This beautiful landmark opens the city of San Francisco to the Pacific Ocean and the rest of the eastern world. And what a treat for those that either cross the bridge, fly above it or glide underneath it by boat! Its tremendous towers, main cables, great span and unique orange vermillion color makes it visually awe inspiring!

You can enjoy stunning panoramic views from a number of vista points on either side of the bridge.

Nothing, however, can come close to the incredible views you can get of the bridge than on top of one of its towers! Imagine seeing the Golden Gate Bridge with one of the most gorgeous cities in the world or the Pacific Ocean as the backdrop high atop its pinnacle!

I am one of the few that was given the privilege. The photos I shot that day do not do it justice! (see photo inserts) Now, how did I get up there? I'll never tell! Be jealous! :)
author: Andrew K.

description:
Ok it's iconic - I get it. I've been here far too often for my photography class + showing out-of-town visitors. Luckily it's easy to get to via Geary and the 28 Bus. 

Some tips and tricks for any visitors:
+ the whole damn thing takes an hour to walk one way (2 hrs round-trip)
+ you can't walk it after a certain time in the evening
+ you're only allowed to walk on one side
+ the "best" view is on top of a hill in Marin Headlands where you can see the bridge and the city
author: Paul B.

description: The Golden Gate Bridge celebrated its 75th anniversary last year. This is one of the most memorable and celebrated bridges in the whole world that makes San Francisco a one-of-a-kind gem. I have been over this bridge many times and often go to Land's End to enjoy a view. I have sailed under it too on cruises. Golden Gate Bridge, what would I be without you!
author: Denise C.

description:
I've wanted to walk across the Golden Gate Bridge for a while now, so on my recent trip to San Francisco, I made sure to make this one of my first stops. Not even fog or the fact that the 28 bus didn't seem to be running could deter me from my quest. I hiked from Park Presidio and Geary Boulevard with some other people left stranded at the bus stop. 

After about a thirty minute walk, we arrived at the bridge. We made a pit stop at the Golden Gate Bridge Outdoor Exhibition, where I got a mini history lesson on the how the bridge was built and designed. Next we trekked across the bridge, enjoying the spectacular views of the Pacific Ocean, San Francisco Bay, Angel Island, and Alcatraz. 

I snapped some beautiful pictures of the bridge and surrounding scenery on the almost two mile walk. It was well worth the trek and I'm so happy that I finally did this!
author: Natalie M.

description:
TOURIST SPOT: If you come to san francisco, then you must stop here. If you don't want to pay to cross the bridge, exit the last exit before the bridge and you can still get some really nice pictures with the bridge in the background. 

However, it's worth it. If you have time, walk on the bridge, make sure you bring a sweatshirt or jacket. Not sweater, because it won't keep you warm enough. It's very windy, but we have some great family pictures looking so natural with the wind in our hair.

The drive is pretty too. hopefully there's so fog when you go because most of the time there is and it's hard to get a good shot. Enjoy!
author: Ameera D.

description:
100th Review!!

It took me a long time, but I finally came to the conclusion that this would be perfect for my hundredth. :)

Call it coincidence, call it serendipity, call it whatever you wanna call it, but we came to SF at the perfect time! You see... for everyone's birthday for the past few years, the default location would be Las Vegas. Not this time! Being that it also fell on Memorial Day Weekend, we, BSBM, the smart cookies we are, decided to go to SF this time around. To our most pleasant surprise, this also happened to be the bridge's 75th anniversary!!

The Golden Gate Bridge held a wondrous fireworks show fully equipped with a light show and music that complemented the fireworks perfectly. The whole ensemble was enjoyed from the comfort of our very own VIP rooftop seating and glasses of bubbly in celebration of this once-in-a-lifetime occurence (Okay, a bit exaggerated there, but to our defense... we had some type of alcohol and sat on top of my lovely cousin's rooftop. All the neighbors decided to climb onto their rooftops to join the festivities as well!) This was one of the major highlights of this awesome trip. It made this bridge so much more meaningful, to be able to enjoy it with my most favorite people. :D

Here's a video! I found one without screaming people, but this wasn't the actual music that was playing during the 'works. Enjoy!
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kmlHjaixS3I
author: Sidney T.

description:
Being that I've always lived less than 2 hours away from this SF landmark, I've taken it for granted since I've been fortunate enough to come here so many times. I've been able to visit so often that I forget what an iconic spot this is in one of the most famous cities in America.

This is one of tourists' must-see destinations & on a sunny, clear day, it's breathtakingly beautiful. It's a perfect spot to go for a walk, breathe in the ocean air, & take in nature in all its glory. If you can make it here on a weekday you won't have to deal with as many people, but even if you have to brave the crowds, this is definitely worth visiting.
author: Megan M.

description:
I'm
Just a 
Sucker for
Infrastructure.
Crowded pedestrian way with gawkers.
author: Justin L.

description: Cool bridge that you define lately have to see while in San Francisco. Parking can be tricky but the views make it so worth it. It was a little crowded but that's to be expected. Definitely lives up to its hype.
author: Ryan H.

description: No debit cards, its 2015 and i got ticket just because i dont have cash on me. I hate them, making milions of dollars and cant organize it better.
author: Roman S.

description:
A true California landmark. If you're in the city you simply must visit. Drive across from the city and immediately over the bridge you can pull off (to the right) and get a great view of the city and the bridge. 

Stop in the city and rent a bike so you can ride a bike over it, and take the time to walk it as well.

I have truly great bridge karma- it's never been fogged in on any of the umpteem times I've been in the city- I keep hoping to catch it on a foggy day!
author: Barbara S.

description:
Free parking in San Fran! Can't beat that! 

Make sure to get there early to beat all the tour buses and big groups of people.

Parking in the beginning is a nightmare, but roll around to the far side by the buses and you will notice several empty spots.

Some great vantage points for photos and some historical signs to read. There is a bathroom as well.
author: Erica Y.

description:
When a trip to San Francisco came into my future, the GGB was the first thing on my list. 

We walked across it and back. Very windy, but incredible! We saw dolphins swimming below, a beautiful fog, and took some great photos. There are some informational signs at the gift shop/station that really help you appreciate the work put into the bridge's construction. I picked up a national parks passport in the gift shop and got it stamped there as well. Definitely worth the 3.1 mile across and back as the view from the Sausalito side is wonderful. Not overrated, not one bit.
author: Diana R.

description: SCAM ARTISTS. Never received a notice and now 2x $79.00 fees on my DMV renewal. SF local government should be ashamed. Am I paying for a new net or something?!
author: Chris D.

description:
Breath taking landmark at my favorite city by the Bay!

Some friends and I played tourist for the day and decided to cross this historic bridge on our bikes!

It's a beautiful ride from the SF Ferry Building into downtown Sausalito. We grew up in the Bay Area and saw views we've never seen before. WIth just a few hills, it's the perfect way to spend a sunny day.  An easy and breezy bike ride :D
author: Earlene C.

description: The Golden Gate Bridge is the icon of San Francisco just like the Eiffel Tower is to Paris, Big Ben is to London and the Pyramids are to Cairo.  On any postcard, in any movie or on many souvenirs you see this image as it is internationally re-known.  No matter what type of weather conditions are presented, the Golden Gate Bridge is still a beautiful site. I have witnessed it on a gloomy, foggy day to a clear, sunny day and still find myself mesmerized by it's aesthetic appeal.  Even at night the bridge projects a different appeal with the city lights in the background.  I can't help but smile every time I see the Golden Gate Bridge as it reaffirms that I am definitely in San Francisco.
author: Cheryl S.

description:
How can anyone not love GGB!!!!!!
Just as beautiful and grand as seen on TV.
Would love to go here any day !!!
author: Shubha K.

description:
My first memory of this amazing bridge is a fond memory for sure. My father took me to watch the Blue Angels and we stood on the bridge with about 4,000 other enthusiasts. It's a memory that I can grab from the bank when feeling down and it helps bring a smile to my face. 

I've got a lot of family from out of town. My family from El Salvador was in town for a wedding and we asked them what they wanted to do. I had a plan of attack that included lunch at Slanted Door after strolling the Ferry Building Farmer's Market and some other exciting foodie plans. All of that was nixed when my uncle said " Sobrino, we traveled 3,171 miles just to see the GG Bridge. Now take us there so we my wife can take some pictures and use those as Xmas cards."

This iconic bridge is known the world around as the most beautiful bridge in the US and I am truly grateful I can ride across anytime I want to. It's nice, once in a great while, to be a tourist in my backyard and this is slotted as #1.
author: Hector G.

description: What comes to anyone's mind when San Francisco is mentioned...The Golden Gate Bridge obviously!  This place is amazing, not only in the way it is constructed and the magnificent marvel that it is, but to see it in person puts it over the top.  I recently got to visit the bridge on my inaugural trip to this fabulous city and this was the highlight of all of my sightseeing adventures in the city.  A must see if you are in the area.  There is a park at the base of the bridge, which allows you to stroll along the coastline and even has a longer fishing pier to take a jaunt out into the water to see more of the bridge from a lower level.  You can also see Alcatraz and the skyline of downtown from this area.
author: Ameesh P.

description:
Oh the Golden Gate Bridge, the most iconic image of San Francisco, if not the entire state of California. I think this bridge is great, but it doesn't compare to the Brooklyn bridge or anything like that. Personally, I thought that the Oakland bridge looked better, though I did only see the Oakland bridge at night. 

My friends and I rented bikes and biked across it, which I thought was a wonderful experience. I highly recommend biking across it, since walking would take a bit of time. There's a bunch of bikers too, so if you're a pedestrian, you would probably be annoyed at how many bikers there are.

Another thing that I didn't like was just the overall traffic on the bridge. Because it is such an iconic bridge, there was a lot of people on it, which is expected. It wasn't THAT bad, but it was just a hassle at times getting onto and off of the bridge.
author: Helen T.

description:
As my honey and I were driving across the Golden Gate Bridge yesterday afternoon, taking in the beautiful weather and views, I turned to him and said, "I love living here." 

Driving and/or walking across the bridge is a must for visitors to the Bay Area. It is also a must for locals. 

I suggest that you listen to Tony Bennett's "I Left My Heart in San Francisco" as your bridge crossing soundtrack.

(Words by Douglass Cross and Music by George Cory)

     The loveliness of Paris seems somehow sadly gay
     The glory that was Rome is of another day
     I've been terribly alone and forgotten in Manhattan
     I'm going home to my city by the Bay

     I left my heart in San Francisco
     High on a hill, it calls to me
     To be where little cable cars climb halfway to the stars
     The morning fog may chill the air, I don't care

     My love waits there in San Francisco
     Above the blue and windy sea
     When I come home to you, San Francisco
     Your golden sun will shine for me
author: Emily J.

description:
A hundred years ago when I was in college, I hitchhiked from Boulder, CO to SF on my very first spring break.
I had just turned 17 & my friend Peggy talked me into that crazy, naughty adventure.  (It didn't take much talking to get me on board.)

I still remember my first sight of the Golden Gate Bridge.  Holy orange vision of glory, there it is!

Fast forward a few decades to my last visit to SF:  many things had changed, one had not. The first thing I wanted to do was drive across the bridge.
It's also cool to walk across, but there's something about being in the passenger seat & throwing your head back under a ginormous orange tower in a moving car.  Especially if the sky happens to be blue that day.  Orange against grey fog ain't too shabby, either.

To say this bridge is a masterpiece is an understatement, of course.  
It's a bridge that gets you to the other side but makes you want to hang in the middle, suspended in ecstatic limbo.

It's a sexy bridge.  It's powerful, beautiful, alluring, and begs to be photographed.
It's female, right?  
The Bay Bridge is male & the GGB is all girl, dolled-up to perfection, what a head-turner.

As far as personality, she's sure to brighten your day, fill your spirit with awe, leave you inspired & longing for more....of her.
This lady bridge is forever young, playful, unforgettable.  She's like the timeless sun that is orange as it rises & orange as it sets.

She does more than command a room  -  she commands a whole bay, an entire city.  Talk about style and presence, and amazing grace.  What a woman.

Somehow she manages all this without projecting any 'tude, unlike some other architecture I've seen.  I won't mention any names, but some stuff appears just too....complicated.  And much more about the creaTOR than the creaTION.

You are far from simple, GGB, don't get me wrong.  Nor are you understated, obviously.  What you are is elegant, like a lady who knows not to overdo her makeup in an attempt to improve what is already perfect.  
As with Oscar night gowns, less is usually more & it's all about stunning sleekness and show-stopping confidence.

Next time I visit I'll bring my camera so I can add even more photos to your portfolio, lovely GGB.  Not that you need any more pictures (or reviews), but....hey.....who ever gets tired of tributes?

Happy recent 75th birthday, btw.  You don't look a day over....one.
Keep on hangin' on, magnificent girl.
author: Joan S.

description:
Beautiful! I'm the typical Bay Area resident who thinks the Golden Gate Bridge is for tourists... boy was I wrong. I've lived in the bay all my life but took this bridge for granted! It's an absolutely amazing sight, and very powerful in person. I recommend everybody to come to see this bridge at least once when you're old enough to appreciate this man made bridge. I haven't been here since I was 5 years old! The pathways to the bridge gives you access to plenty of areas where you can take a photo with the bridge in the background. You can also see Alcatraz island from bridge! Lots of tourists, but who cares!

We parked near where the souvenir shops were at, free parking towards the back! Lots of cars on Saturdays, so beware for traffic. It gets very cold at the bridge. It was warm in the 70's at Dolores Park but once we got to the bridge, the weather went down to 50's! Windy and cold. You can walk on the bridge. I'm afraid of heights so we only got 1/4 across the bridge before we started turning around. Free parking, free view of the bridge, it costs nothing to see this bridge, just the drive here. 

I recommend biking if the weather is nice out! If it was sunny and less crowded we would've biked across the bridge and explore the northern part of the bay. Recommend!
author: Rita K.

description:
Dear GG, 

Please tell me why you are so breathtakingly beautiful? I always love seeing you. I make sure to bring my relatives from out of state to see you. I know I still have to experience crossing the bridge by foot on you. You are amazing and I will never get enough of you. 

Love,
KR

PS
Someone asked me why you're called Golden when you are red? :P
author: Kevyne R.

description:
If you're into misty scenery and beautiful waters, this is an absolutely lovely spot to take in the sights. Coincidentally, it's also a popular bridge to jump from, so don't visit if you're feeling down.

I biked across the span from Fisherman's Wharf to Sausalito and one hurt butt later, I can still say I loved the experience and the break we took on the bridge.
author: Zenovia E.

description: I had the opportunity to run across it, and it was amazing! It is such a beautiful bridge with a light uphill then downhill, which is rare where I come from (steep bridges). Go walk, run, or bike across it! It's a unique experience.
author: Denny H.

description: Stunning architectural gem. How could this bridge sustain itself for so many years. Engineered to perfection. Breath taking views from this location.
author: Claudia A.

description:
Happy Birthday to you
Happy Birthday to you
Happy Birthday, dear Golden Gate Bridge!

Happy Birthday to you
author: Abby S.

description: Even with all the hype, this bridge is awesome. It was even foggy both times we crossed it, but it was still an amazing experience.
author: Dirk N.

description:
T'was the night before the celebration of the Golden Gate Bridge's 75th Birthday (Anniversary)....
People came from all over.....
Muscian....Performers....Pyrotechnics and the works...
Food....Drinks.....shows...are all being prepared through out the city....
Many very eggar to celebrate the birth of the Golden Gate Bridge...
Yet...this was only the day before....

As the clock ticked....and May 27th was offical....let the celebrations began...
A fun filled day of activities, food and drinks for all....
At dawn as the sun goes down and the moon comes up and the clock strikes 9:30 pm San Francisco time....Let the Fireworks begin....

Many roads leading to the Golden Gate Bridge were closed off to vehicles so we had to hike an hour to our celebration spot.  Attached are some of the photos taken of the firework show.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lz7ydUVmsr2DekT9enEhvw?select=K62sZJLlcx_Lsz9dxiJZFA#IUsNkFpZM861evcrifU3Ng

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lz7ydUVmsr2DekT9enEhvw?select=K62sZJLlcx_Lsz9dxiJZFA#GZOsHO5jd7iG4WrCUsr7Lw

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lz7ydUVmsr2DekT9enEhvw?select=K62sZJLlcx_Lsz9dxiJZFA#FGOh-UrbJfkYg-JdIfSZiw

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lz7ydUVmsr2DekT9enEhvw?select=K62sZJLlcx_Lsz9dxiJZFA#wOEBjDhM2XxsMMr21G6lYA

The Golden Gate Bridge serves many purpose....
a means of travel between SF and Marin
an awesome view....
how can one not enjoy it or appreciate the Golden Gate Bridge.

5 Stars to the Golden Gate Bridge with more to come!!
author: Alan L.

description: Believe me, it looks much better in pictures and film and like many things in San Francisco it's overrated in my opinion. I didn't understand what was so fascinating about it, loads of tourists with there selfie sticks....it's just a bloody bridge! Which was mostly covered in fog. I took a few pictures with my camera and left.
author: Colin D.

description: Totally false advertising. It's Red. If it was called the Red Gate Bridge it would probably be three stars because it's just a little too windy for four.
author: Loren G.

description:
Ahem, un ode à la Bridge de Golden Gate:

Your gold has worn,
but a copper giant you stand,
many feet torn into a bay, into a sea, constantly beating at your plans.

A heavy mist, of Stephen King proportions,
cloaks your arms at all times.
Shielding you from the pollutants of motorists and tourists alike.

Leading us into a land of giant monster trees, Sausalito cookies and winding roads without barriers. Robbing us with your tricky tolling system.

Traffic crawls, along with the walkers, along your lanes, your veins, your arteries to a grander plane. Branded on a postcard or a magnet, you have us dreaming of the hearts we left in San Fran.
author: Carol B.

description: The fact that there has to be such an excessive toll for crossing this magnificent bridge always reminds me of the inherent inefficiency and wastefulness of government, wether federal, state, or local.  When I moved to the Bay Area in '94 I believe the toll was $3.00, and now it's $6.00, and they want to raise it even more.  They of course need more money to spend (80 million) on the feel-good project of building an ugly suicide barrier that will prevent people from jumping off of the bridge, but will do nothing to decrease the overall rate of suicides.  This has been statistically proven at other places.  Someone who is in that mindset will of course find another way to end their lives.  It is unbelievable that a structure that brings in hundreds of thousands of dollars each day is not running in the black.  Welcome to "Tax and Spend California" the beacon of liberal America!
author: Lars S.

description: Bring back the Toll Collector! We are now forced to keep track of another thing...did I get a fast track account where do i Pay...and the fine is hefty($6.00 becomes like $70.00 don't quote me) if you don't follow the rules. I get it..but drivers should not HAVE to pay by plate. And a truly fair pay by plate is this: all tolls are billed on your registration,no additional fees. This is the only fair way.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
Having lived in LA for over 20 years, we travel to the Bay Area fairly often.  I have driven the bridge countless times in both directions, however, until recently I have never walked across.

On my most recent trip, I finally stopped on the Marin side of the bridge and dragged my wife and kids across by foot.  It was windy and a tad chilly, but what an experience!  The views of the bay and city are awesome.  Seeing the different parts of the bridge up close gives you a different perspective.
author: Mark N.

description: Always a must when In San Fransisco or anywhere close by! We took the bay cruise from pier 39 and got the best pictures while in the boat!
author: Brandon C.

description:
As far as bridges go, this one is a really classy brawd.

Painted all up in International Orange and always standing there as if to just beg you to cross her.

I like her from every angle. Kinda creepy how many people jump off it every year -- she recently took home the bronze in the "Best Free Fall Exit From This World" in the last issue of Self-Immolation Semi-Quarterly.

The three best spots I know to see the bridge are:

1) Head North on the 101 and get in the furthest right hand lane because you're going to need to catch the "LAST EXIT SF" mere moments before you get stuck going across the bridge, then having to come back and pay $6 or so on the internet later that night (like a loser).

Instead veer off the road and make a single ring around the parking lot (stopping briefly in the red zone to dump off the family for a quick picture with the bridge in the background and to check out the demo piece of the bridge that shows all the cables inside [it looks like a giant fiber optic cable]).

2) Going over the bridge is pretty damn cool, plus you can walk across and lots of peopl do that.

3) There's a good view of the bridge from the Southbound 101 right before you go over it in Marin

4) If you go to the parking lot in #1, exit on the 19 and pull off when you see some relic barracks to the right. Climb out onto the fort and there's stunning views of the bridge and Land's End.
author: Ryan S.

description: As always, this is such a beautiful bridge to welcome you to the city! Traffic, yeah. Tourists, yeah. Don't be surprised, but you just may be able to enjoy the sight of it if your not too grumpy about things holding you back from zooming across the bridge. It's really a nice ride, try and enjoy it!
author: Ness V.

description: Meh. The fog is the foible. The golden gate bridge is pretty awesome, so I hear. We saw it from afar, and then closer up from the Marina. If you can catch it on a clear day, it is impressive (or so I recall from years ago). Best to go close up and walk or bike. But if it is foggy weather as is so common, the view is not worth the time. See it on a clear day or do something else.
author: Katniss S.

description:
I guess this is one of those things you must do if you visit San Francisco, otherwise everyone you tell about your trip will yell at you and you will feel foolish for skipping it.

I think you also must walk the bridge to fully appreciate the experience. That being said, I have a couple of tips/observations if you are planning on that:

- I highly recommend taking a bus into the beginning of Sausalito, which is just on the other side of the bridge. I am betting that walking the length of the bridge once will be more than enough for you (as it was for me, and I'm all about walking several miles).

- this will allow you to walk back into San Francisco on the bridge. This seems like it would be a much more enjoyable experience. The half closer to Sausalito is nice and quiet, as most tourists give up at about the half way mark from San Francisco and turn back. So this way you get to really enjoy the bridge, and by the time you get to the halfway mark, when you are about sick of it, your fellow tourists will all be in the mix to really make you sick of it and ready to get off the bridge. By that point, you will already have basked in the beautiful scenery and would have taken all the requisite pictures, without a bunch of annoying tourists in the background of each picture.

- even if you don't mind cooler temperatures, you should at least bring a light long sleeve garment. It gets pretty chilly with all of the wind.

- watch out for the extremely annoying bicyclists. There is bound to constantly be one or two trailing right behind you going at a snail's pace since it's clearly a bad idea to bike the bridge as it's so packed.

I wish i had known these things ahead of time, as it probaly would have made for a more enjoyable experience. So you would do well to heed my advice if you are reading this, since I am pretty sure you are planning to visit the bridge if you are looking up reviews for it on Yelp.
author: Mike C.

description:
My first trip to San Francisco was in the spring of 2007; my high school band was there for a competition. Of course, we stopped to visit the Golden Gate Bridge - what better way to tire out a bunch of rowdy teenagers than to make them walk almost two miles? Walking across, a few of us noticed the crisis counseling signs; we knew their purpose, but suicide was a distant concept in our minds - something that happened to other people, but not to the young and invicible. A close friend took a picture next to one. She had a history of trauma and self-harming behaviors and she thought it would be funny. No one laughed, but we understood that sometimes, those who suffer in darkness try to make light of the situation through jokes; perhaps you can laugh the pain away, or if you can demonstrate your ability to joke about the issue, then maybe the weight of your pain can't consume you. Teenagers do not understand much of the world, but there is something hopeful in their naiveté.

My second trip was in the summer of 2014; a lot can change in seven years. On my first trip, the bridge was mostly covered in fog, but I felt like a radiant ball of energy, glowing with youthful hope. Life was beautiful and I was so lucky to be there. The second time around, there was no fog to be seen except the fog found within. I had lost most of that lustre; no longer did I radiate positivity. Now, I was a black hole, consuming everything around me - no light could escape once it had crossed the event horizon of my spinning thoughts. The clear, sunny sky could do nothing to clear the fog in my mind. I walked and came upon that familiar blue sign, informing me that there was hope. Hope was a foreign word those days; I had hope, but not in any conventional sense. I hoped for a painless ending, a way out - I had the kind of hopes that one does not normally vocalize during polite conversation. 

It was a beautiful day and yet the urge to climb over the railing was ever present. I walked quickly, eyes cast down, and made it to the other side without incident. I would be tempting fate by walking across again, but it had to be done. I paused at the sight of a yellow phone. I would not make a call, but I would look at it to serve as a reminder of the time I did not give in to desire.

I recently read an article that interviewed a few who have survived the jump. The consensus? "Everything in my life could have been fixed, except for that I just jumped." This is a daily reminder that others have felt this way, too. Others have made the same decision and, still, in that moment, found that they had reached the wrong conclusion. Everything is temporary; the Golden Gate Bridge may spend much of its time swathed in fog, but it still has its day in the sun.
author: Courtney W.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is incredibly iconic - it is probably the thing you think of first when you think of the city.  And for good reason.  The bridge architecture is stunning and the views of the city from the bridge are absolutely incredible.

As a first time visitor to San Francisco, this was a must-see for me.  My boyfriend and I walked across the bridge and took tons of photos - it was a blast!  When we arrived, it was still a bit foggy, which looked really cool.  As we walked along the bridge, the fog burned off which gave us 360 views of the area - amazing.  Once on the other side, we visited the Vista Point and also hiked up a large hill and explored part of an old fort (possibly Fort Point?).  At the fort we experienced some of the best views of the bridge and took the opportunity to fly kites in the strong winds.  It was pretty surreal to fly kites with the Golden Gate Bridge in the background.  

You must visit the Golden Gate Bridge when in San Francisco - it is practically a requirement! - and I would recommend taking a bus (Golden Gate Transit will take you directly there) to get there because the parking is incredibly limited.  Bring your camera!!
author: Sonya L.

description:
Few landmarks on earth can leave such an impression as the Golden Gate bridge.  I saw pictures of it as a kid and drove over it the first time about 24 years ago.  I was in awe of just how beautiful a structure it was.  We took the first turn off and went back over and did it again.  We were traveling from San Diego to Alaska and just had to marvel at it.
As a private pilot I would fly over it and turn my wing down, so I could look down at the traffic.  Really stunning from any angle.
My favorite picture is of an aircraft carrier passing below the golden gate.  The meaning and symbolism of it still echoes with me...  The ship, passing out of the gate, to go protect freedoms we enjoy within it.  And then when the ship comes home, I know the crew feels awash with excitement to see family when they pass inside.
Always wanted to run it.  Going to have to do it one of these days.
author: Kristina B.

description:
Dear Golden Gate Bridge: 

Every time I think of you I just think:

"What ever happened to predictibility?
The milkman, the paperboy, evening TV.

Eveywhere you look,
When you're lost out there and you're all alone,
A light is waiting to carry you home,
Everywhere you look.
Everywhere you look." Bda da-da. 

Ok Full House nerds out there are you with me? 

The bridge is a beautiful and historic landmark. I only wish that when I was there is wasn't so disgusting and rainy :( The best part though is there is a park right beside it so you can get some killer pics. I thought that was neat! Can't wait to go back.
author: Cindy G.

description:
As a kid you saw photos of it and heard about how it's one of our great landmarks, but it is WAY more than that, it's an American icon beyond words.

When you see it from far away, and catch the first glimpses of it's red towers, you know you're seeing something special, beyond just a sight, it's a wonder of the world.

It's beautiful, it's vintage style and color is timeless. You can see ships and boats sailing underneath it, the bay water shining in the sun, and the pacific ocean stretching outwards forever. It is really a sight you can't get anywhere else, looking out at the ocean from one of the world's great treasures.

Drive it, walk it, crawl it, bike it, whatever you do...just see it.
author: Joey D.

description: This was a really neat bridge to see and just have a picnic closeby. Great views, and we even ran across one morning. There is decent parking closeby, and make sure to walk some of the trails.
author: Chuck M.

description: Golden Gate Bridge --the one-must-see place of San Francisco and the Bay Area. The bridge itself is absolutely breath-taking. It connects the north bay with the San Francisco city and is a part of highway 101. If you are driving, it takes about one to two minutes to cross the entire bridge, but if you are walking, then it's one hour for a round-trip. The location is very tourist-friendly -- it has free 4-hour parking, which NEVER happens in SF, and can be easily reach through public transit. Make sure to bring a light-weight jacket, a camera, and your beautiful smile!
author: Wendy F.

description: I have been traveling in some states of America looking to see where I wanted to settle, I should say so far San Francisco is on top of my list, in such a short time I was able to visit a few of the key point of what SF has to offer and my favorite spot is the Bay Area, clam chowders are my favorite, bay cruise is one attraction any one should not miss and many more. I will go back for sure..
author: David T.

description:
The best way to visit the Golden Gate Bridge is if you can get there on a warm, clear and sunny day.  We stopped on the way back from Sonoma, and took a walk from the parking lot about halfway.  If you're into bicycling, this would be a really fun trip.

The walk from the parking lot isn't far, and parking is free.  I love free things I can do on vacation!
author: Angela P.

description:
OK so first you fire all the toll workers, putting dozens (hundreds?) of people out of their jobs.  THEN, you come up with a great scam where you mail people bills TO THE WRONG ADDRESS.  Then when the helpful post office employees finally get the bill, which was mailed to the WRONG address, to my current house... it is already late.

Twice now.  And counting.  We get our DMV plate renewals at the right address, so how can you get this wrong over and over?  OH YEAH, it makes you money!

I know you're watching.  I know the idea is to coerce everyone into putting money into a state-held account by making it difficult to pay.  How convenient that this lets you hold millions of interest-free dollars in account.

At least Yelp lets me tell the world that you are lame.
author: Mike H.

description: One of the most iconic bridges in history, this bridge is simply amazing. There are many different paths you can take to get a good look at the bridge. There is an old army base if you cross the bridge going to the hills with a tall lookout point. There is also an area before getting on the bridge where you can hike up a bit and also get a good view. Many people like to bike the bridge or take pictures. It is beautiful on a rare, hot and sunny day!
author: Jordan W.

description:
Omgoodness.

It was an amazing, cool, fun, intense, crazy, windy, cold, wow type of experience.

My bf and I walked the whole Golden Gate bridge front and back. It was pretty windy and cold, and at times the wind was pushing me away. 

We definitely made the best of it. Saw a dude on his UNICYCLE riding across it! Who does that?! But PROPS!
author: Ayumi S.

description: My friends and I hiked around San Fran and got great views of this bridge but driving or waking over it is quite the experience. If you have the chance, try to. It's a stunning bridge.
author: Joanna V.

description:
There are several great scenic viewpoints just before the northern toll plaza. I was expecting some kind of a visitor center, or at least a historical marker of some kind, but there is nothing. The bathrooms near the first viewpoint felt like they should part of a terrible Mexican prison out in the desert.

Horribleness aside, the bridge was really impressive. Needless to say, it was a fantastic photo opportunity, so I happily coaxed another tourist into taking some pics for us. The second viewpoint is actually better for pictures, since it gives you the best angle on the bridge.

This is definitely a must if you're driving down the West coast.
author: Jared K.

description:
The view is very beautiful!but the wind is very coooool~~~~
It is the market for visitors must visit when he go to San Francisco !
author: Karen T.

description:
I will keep this one short. This is an iconic image known the world over. Almost anywhere you go if you show them a picture of the GGB they will know it or SF where the bridge is located. 

Interesting fact: As soon as the maintenance crews have completed painting the bridge, they start over at the other end and begin again. This is due to the super corrosive salt water and constant shrouding of fog. If this was not done, the bridge would rust out extremely quickly.

The lanes available change constantly on the GGB. Lanes are constantly reversed throughout the day. It only costs to drive southbound into SF from Marin County. 

The bike lanes and walking/hiking path allow some full blown experiences.

Interesting fact 2: Be careful as there have been more suicides here than any other specific place on earth. So many that they installed special nets to catch the jumpers...

But this place is super super beautiful. I hope you can enjoy it and check it out as many times as I have.
author: Schel H.

description: It's just what you expect and more being one of San Fransisco's most famous attractions. Absolutely gorgeous!
author: Krisinda K.

description:
What is there to say about this wonder?
Go there.
Just go.
Walk, bicycle, or drive over it.
Get anywhere near it and just gaze upon it.
Best views are from the Marin Headlands.
author: Helen B.

description:
I walked across the Golden Gate Bridge for the first time in my LIFE this weekend. Being that I was born and raised in the city, this was quite a big deal to me. 

As I walked across from the Marin to SF side, I realized again how beautiful San Francisco is and how much I love living here. Lucky that it was a beautiful day, the views were spectacular and made me feel proud to spend my day doing something most tourists do on the first visit to the city.
author: Rebekah T.

description: Always beautiful drive across the bay!   Very clean and a nice ride.  Went through SF to Muir woods and had a great experiance.
author: Robbie S.

description: I love this bridge. So much history and so many options that come from it.  You can bike, drive, jog....jump off off...(jk) and enjoy the view.
author: Virginia V.

description: Yep! Its a bridge packed with tourists!
author: Rob L.

description: Getting butterflies as we travel across this beautiful, spectacular landmark.  You'll never get tired of seeing this bridge.  It signifies for me something spectacular approaching....THE CITY!  I remember being imitated by the thought of driving in SF...now, it's always an exciting adventure!
author: Nancy S.

description:
4.5*

I've been coming to San Francisco since 1998 (when I was 12). I've been to Golden Gate park. Until recently, I'd never crossed the Golden Gate Bridge (nor had I really gotten a good look at it). Turns out, when I've come to the city by the bay (whoa whoa who-o-oa)*, I've gone east. Turns out I've spent more time than I've realized in Berkeley. That's what happens when you're friends with a bunch of smart hippies. In any case, I was again in SF but this time I was heading north. For the first time. This meant, 'the Golden Gate Bridge.'

As I realized that I was finally going to experience this iconic modern marvel, I began unexpectedly excited. It's one of those things. You may have seen these engineering wonders in books or on TV but to experience them up close & personal is a moving experience. I smile crept across my face as we neared. The bridge itself is majestic, imposing and beautiful. But adding to the experience is the electricity of the crowd (it's always packed with tourists, locals, commuters, runners, and bikers), the grandeur of the water, the lush invitation of the North Bay's verdant splendor, and the clear skies (not gray or foggy like I imagined) that allowed me to fully enjoy the experience and take many many pictures. 'It's just a bridge; big deal,' some might say. And, I guess that's sorta true. But when you step back, look up and attempt to capture the perfect image to be preserved forever on your camera, the history, cultural significance and wonder of the bridge cannot be denied. Yeah, it's a bridge. But, it's the Golden Gate Bridge. There's a big difference.

*Tower Bridge has my five-star love.
**I've been singing 'Lights' for the past ten minutes.
author: Johnny T.

description:
This really is a magical bridge. I live here locally, and never ever tire of it's beauty. If you have access to a car, drive across. If you are feeling sporty, rent a bike and ride it (plenty of places to do this). If you're feeling sportier, walk it. It's a pretty easy walk, with only a small incline. Round trip is about an hour.

Most tourists don't have the luxury of waiting for a clear day, but if you can do this - it is worth it. The Gate is often socked in with fog, especially in the mornings. This can make it a bit frustrating. There are plenty of places to get some good shots, but my favorite is in the Marin headlands. Exit after the bridge (on the Marin side), hook a left at the stop sign & park in the 2nd lot up. There is a small hike that will get you those breathtaking views you can't get from the city.

Short on time? There is also a speedboat (the Rocketboat) that leaves from Pier 39 and takes a spin around the bay. You can see the bridge from the water.
author: Maureen B.

description:
= San Francisco Landmark =

Yes, I am a tourist, but a visit to San Francisco is not complete if you don't stop by GOLDEN GATE BRIDGE and snap a picture of it.  It's a beautiful bridge with lots of history to it.  Probably famous of the number of suicides too.  Parking at the visitation center is relatively cheap. A must-stop if it is your first time in San Francisco.

Note:  The toll booth is now replaced with electronic FASTPASS.  If you don't have a FASTPASS, I believe you can pay for the toll by searching your license plate online and paying for the toll at a later time.
author: Anita L.

description: I find that as I get older, the more appreciative I become. With that said, the Golden Gate Bridge really is quite beautiful and majestic. It's definitely one of those things that looks tons better in person than in photos. My most recent visit, the day was a bit overcast, so the water was a greenish hue instead of a beautiful blue. It was okay though, 'cause just taking in the views of the gate, bay, and Alcatraz Island was enough and worth the trek. If the day had been less cold and we had more time, we would've gone bicycling down the bridge -- next time!
author: Ivy W.

description: $8.00 to cross a bridge? I crossed it twice on a bus tour for free and even then I wasn't impressed. It's a bridge, for crying out loud.
author: A C.

description:
Great view, great construction. Looks really massive from a distance. Honestly its not a big deal construction in todays world. Somehow I felt this bridge was overrated. I think the history, location and fact that people gave up their lives from this bridge makes it famous tourist attraction.
Bay bridge(Connects oakland and San francisco) is also nice but its very underrated in terms of tourist attracton.
author: Rasesh P.

description:
I am a new resident to San Francisco and was billed for crossing the bridge after visiting Marin County. It seems like the usual thing one might do when moving to San Francisco.

The bill got sent to my old address and was duly forwarded. However the USPS seemingly conspired with the toll plaza to deliver my bill not-in-time therefore bumping my two $7 tolls to $64.

This was out of my hands and a late fee of $25 for a toll is unreasonable. Further the time limit for payment is too short. 

Also GGTP: why do you have toll booths when there is no toll being collected by hand? It is a safety issue. Look into how EZPass does it in the N.Y.C. and D.C. area.
author: Canary U.

description: a new experience everytime in scenery and entertainment. The very large racoons DO NOT CARE if you are there as long as you stay out of their trash! LOL.. Seriously though, we just moved to Mountain View from Orlando/Cocoa Beach, FL It is lovely here :)
author: Gina B.

description:
Back when my youngest step-daughter was in elementary school, her best friend's Father worked as a Toll Taker, and he would regale us with hard-to-believe stories of what he saw and heard as various patrons came through the lanes. I was also surprised on how well that job paid and that unlike my white collar job, when his shift was over, it was really over. 

The Golden Gate Bridge Toll Plaza is a bit dated, but I'll never get tired of the payoff of a view no matter which direction I'm traveling. My most memorable experience was actually walking through the Toll Plaza that one early morning in May of 1987 when the Bridge was opened up to Pedestrian Traffic. There were so many people on the Bridge with me that the road bed flattened, cables swaying freely, and there was no way I could walk completely across. I also still have the commemorative stamped postcard that they handed out at the center of the Bridge on that day. 

Here are few other tips:

- From my East Bay perspective, it's cheaper on my Fastrak budget to drive clockwise. For example, I often drive into the City on the Bay Bridge and sometimes leave via the Golden Gate. That's 1 Toll as opposed to 2 if I came into SF via the Richmond-San Rafael and Golden Gate Bridges. 

- The best driving view of the Bridge and the City is Southbound just after you come out of the Waldo Tunnel. There's also an exit just before the Bridge for Marin Headlands options.

- For views on foot, there are lots of choices. My favourites are the view from the Marin Headlands (especially at Hendrik Point) and underneath at Fort Point. 

- Never drive North or South Bound in the far left lane. For me this is too close for comfort regarding the possibility of a head-on collision. 

- By all means, walk or bike across the Bridge!  And if you're game, continue on to Sausilito.
author: Eric B.

description:
Tourists, if you are reading this, DO NOT walk four abreast, arm in arm, like retarded Sound of Music wannabees.  Bikes share the same space as your ass, so you need to stay next to the rail, so bikes can stay next to the road.  When you stop to take photos, mill about, or generally get in the way, you create a dangerous situation for everybody.  

Otherwise, it's awesome!
author: Rebecca H.

description: Been over it, under it and seen it from afar. If you visit here you need to take some type of tour that tells you the history. It's really fascinating.
author: Mark B.

description:
Why are earth would you give this historical marvel 1 star?!

Well, not coming from a tourist points of view -- this is one expensive and creepy bridge:

1.  It costs commuters from Marin $1200 a year to cross this bridge for work (and that is a $240 discount from FasTrack) 

2.  It is the suicide magnet of the world.  People actually come to jump here from other states, and even countries.  No other spot in the world is that magnetic.  We're closing in on 2,000 confirmed suicides (actual numbers may be a lot higher) from the bridge and no one seems to care.  

In 1993, the founder of Victoria Secret jumped here.

So next time you come across this bridge.  Think of all the souls underneath it in their watery grave.  Then ladies, think of your underwear.  Yup, that soul jumped from where you stand.
author: Jason L.

description: Quick trip this time, and Quick drive over my favorite bridge! :D I drove over in the morning close to 8am, strangely there wasn't much traffic. ? Hmm...maybe I should move to San Rafael instead of Sacramento...commute to the city...hmmm. YAY! Soon I'll be closer to happiness! :D
author: Jenn H.

description: Awesome! Saw some sea lions, surfers and obviously the golden gate bridge
author: Brandi S.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge just celebrated its 75th Anniversary on 5/27/12 and I'm glad I was home that weekend to partake in the festivities! After growing up in North Beach and then moving to LA, I don't get the chance to visit SF as much as I would like.

My brother and I ran the length of the bridge for the first time the day before the anniversary and I was blown away by the breathtaking views (my only other vivid memory being a ferry boat ride under the GGB in the first grade). It was just barely 3 miles across and back, which amounted to an easy 25 minute run with little winds and stunning views of the harbor. Sunday night, my friends and I watched the bridge glow as celebratory fireworks lit up the sky. 

This is why my heart remains, and always will  in San Francisco.
author: Michelle C.

description:
I always consider going over this bridge a special treat.  I also consider myself extremely lucky to be able to come here pretty much when ever I want.

People come from all over the world to visit the Golden Gate and I live only an hour away.

The color is just glowing in the sun light and the fog for that matter.  The surroundings of the bridge are equally as special as the bridge itself.

I have never walked on or across the bridge but driving over is just as pleasant.

When I die I want to be cast in metal and mounted to the side of one of the towers like one of the Figurehead women that used to be on the front of old time ships.

I want to embody the spirit of the bridge and wish all travelers a safe voyage by land or sea.
author: Ivy R.

description:
Now that they've automated the toll-taking on the Golden Gate Bridge, if you cross it and don't have a FasTrak, guess what high-tech method they have for collecting the toll?  You're right; they send it to you in the mail, and they often mail it so late that you'll have to pay a late fee because you receive it at or past the no-late-fee deadline.

I'm all for higher tolls for more expensive cars and people who live far from where they work, but I'm not all for making life less human.  Dangerous jobs should be automated.  Undesirable jobs should be automated.  But if you're automating just to save money, here's a tip:  Just tax the rich.  They stole "their" money anyway.
author: John S.

description:
stunning

Reminds me of the opening of Full House.  

It is just a staple and must see when visiting SanFran.  I have yet to drive over it but have seen it various times from afar and it's gorgeous.  I hope next time I get to drive across it or just get up close, I will make that a goal!
author: Colleen B.

description: I went to see the Golden Gate Bridge at two different times and wow it's extremely beautiful. It's interesting when you take photos and each day it comes out different. I went on a sunny day and a foggy day. I would say my favorite is the foggy day. It's such a touristy thing but who cares. It's the most iconic thing for San Fran! Definitely worth checking out!
author: Jei L.

description:
Happy 75th Birthday, big guy!

Looking good for your age, 
Rain, shine or FOG, always standing tall,
No bad angles (seriously),
Good with people and vehicles,
Bringing cities together.

You're quite awesome, really! You have your little quirks...
(not gonna list them cos it's your big day)
But you're still very much loved!!!!!!!!!!!

PS: I'll tell the seagulls to stay away from you today, but can't do much about the seals.
author: Jade T.

description: The view, the people, the ride everything. I loved it. 1 of the best experiences I've had so far worth the trip.
author: Tay A.

description:
Gave full marks aside from the fact that I am highly petrified of bridges and the thought of Godzilla or giant octopus or any other giant beasts would come swarming in while I'm on the bridge crying my eyeballs out (ok that's an exaggeration, but I did let a little cry out). It was foggy the day we were there and that also played another part for my anxiety to hold on tight to my husband and son's hands. It was my son's first time to actually walk and see the golden gate bridge and he was very ecstatic. There's not a lot of people that day so that was a relief and we actually get to enjoy our walk (my two boys in general). I peeked through the railings 3 times (and actually anticipate seeing something interesting swimming in the waters) while my other foot was actually anchoring the ground and that was it for me. We walked almost halfway the bridge until we decided to turn around because of the fog and wind and my anxiety. 

Nonetheless, I was very relief to have actually walked this bridge with my family and that was a very memorable moment for me. No giant beasts showed up that day and that was another relief. Lol!
author: Joy P.

description: closing the visitor parking on labor day weekend 2016.??????....stupideness idea! !!! idiots,  money hungry scrubs...drive over and pay a toll. ..use public transportation and pay a fee. ..bullshit
author: Scott K.

description: we hired bikes and cycled to the bridge from close to Fisherman's wharf. Then we carried on into Sausalito before getting on the Ferry in Sausalito. Everything was great until we queued for the ferry, which came late, filled up and we couldn't get on
author: Michael W.

description: $6 for one way from Sausalito to SF. Free to walk/bike. Definitely a must-see when visiting SF! Remember to bring your jackets, it's super cold!
author: Berna T.

description:
We reached the famous bridge on a surprisingly rainy day for San Francisco but the beauty of the bridge is unfaltering in the mist. Coming face to face for the first time with the world's 'most photographed bridge', a certain sense of familiarity mixed with a sense of wonder. The pathway to cross the bridge on either side are filled with walkers and bikers. From the top of the bridge, fisherman's wharf, Alcatraz island are within line of sight. What a view! 

Next time will definitely make all the way through on foot on a less windy day!
author: Sharon Z.

description:
Coming from the 'city of bridges' you would think that seeing any other bridge in the world wouldn't impress me.  I was wrong.

To see such a spectacular span made me a bit speechless.  I did the obligatory photo with the bridge behind me and also one while on the bridge.  I wanted to walk the whole span of the bridge, but decided against that.  However I did stop at midpoint and just stood there and took in the view.  Taking in the view was a nice escape from the day.  Standing in the middle of the bridge and just looking out into the water can get yourself centered once again.

It was one of my high points for visiting San Francisco and one of the only things I wanted to do while out there.  It's great too that you can use public transit to make your way out there and back.
author: Matthew U.

description:
What can I say that has not already been said? This is truly one of the most inspiring walks I've ever taken. Walking across the bridge midday you get:
1) intermittent fog - the fog rolls in and out about 50 feet above your head several times just during the short 3.4 mile round trip walk
2) beautiful views of Marin and SF, plus Alcatraz (bring a camera with decent zoom for this one)
3) watching lively dolphins swimming underneath you
4) great sea breezes

I came here with my little sister and my mother during my vacation from Brooklyn, walked the entire way across into Marin to the vista point and back. There is a nice cafe on the SF side with good coffee for about 2$ and a gift store, along with a very nifty physically interactive model of SF bridge to better understand how the suspension works. I will post pics of all this shortly. 

Moving on... Just do it! Walk across the bridge, check out Marin Headlands hike if you have the time. The overall feel and rush of waiting up scenery is awe inspiring to say the least. Brooklyn Bridge's view is incredible as well, but in a much different way. I'd prefer the GG bridge most days - and that's saying a lot!
author: Michael W.

description: The bridge is only 1.7 miles long. Very doable. The views are gorgeous, and it's an excellent way to get some exercise and fresh air. Many people walk it and bike it, even weekdays. It was in the high 60's, but it can get windy. Bring a jacket.
author: stephanie c.

description:
To be a small part in the 75th Birthday Anniversary of our Majestic Golden Gate Bridge bash on May 27, 2012 I feel blessed to have "been there done that". I've walked over the GGB several times and every time the view gets better and better! There is so much to see! I wish the Ocean (West bound) side view was open to bicyclist's AND pedestrians, not just bicyclists. I'm jealous as to what they get to see on the other side. I wanna take a picture of Point Bonita Lighthouse from the GGB, I wanna take a picture of China Beach and Lands End from the GGB perspective.

Went and parked at the Marin vista point and walked GGB to Crissy Field to festivities. Saw the USS Nimitz and all its 3000+ Navy Sailors sail right under the GGB, Saw the Jeremiah O'Brien Liberty Ship also sail right under the GGB....both BREATHTAKING!! To see the GGB from any place in the Presidio is worth taking the 200 or so stairs from one of the trails. There are other routes to take and well guided with signs. Just don't take the stairs at days end. Believe me, my legs HURT once I climbed all those stairs! One single "turn out" area. LOL.
I've never parked on San Francisco side to get to GGB, I find it easier to park on Marin side.
Always windy and always beautiful! You can cross the bridge in about 45 minutes. Now keep in mind that every 50 feet you'll be taking another picture of the Bay, so depending how fast/slow you walk/ride is up to you. I suggest you take your time and also remember to look down. Sometimes you'll be lucky enough to spot a porpoise pod and a sea lion or two. Of course lotsa sail boats and ferry boats too.
I would advise you go early in the am to cross the bridge, less foot/bike traffic. Lotsa runners at that time though. Even if the fog is still rolling out to sea...by the time your ready to go back across it'll hopefully be sunny! Don't forget to check out the gift shop on the SF side, its stocked with so much history books and pictures, clothing and your basic souvenir. 
PUT ON SUNBLOCK UNLESS YOU WANNA LOOK LIKE A RACCOON!
author: Fer R.

description:
The best bridge in the world! And I've been around.

If you don't have a car, the best way to get there is through those guided tours.  Vista point is always a stop for many of the bus tours.

But if you want to walk the bridge, the best way to get there is by car.  Get to the vista point on the north side early to skip traffic, especially if you're not familiar with the roads there.

What I've always wanted to do is rent a bike and take the paths there.  It's probably THE best way to get there if you don't mind the exercise.  With all the eating you'll do in the city, maybe biking should be your way to get there.
author: Vira P.

description: A definite bucket list item! Something I never admitted wanting to do but super jazzed I finally got to do! The walk itself isnt strenuous, when we did it the weather was sunny and temp just right. There were a ton of walkers & bicyclists going back & forth. Can someone please tell me why on Earth they have bicyclists & walkers on the same sidewalk??? Why cant the walkers be on one side & cyclists on the other side?? I saw so many near collisions and it seems logical from a tourist perspective to do that. I saw several cyclists who were very aggressive and didnt seem to think they needed to yield to pedestrians. Unfortunately, thats what the sign said. Anyway, just go do it, enjoy the walk! But wear sensible shoes, man, I saw so many ladies wearing really stupid shoes!
author: Corina J.

description: There's absolutely no people to ask how to pay your toll-so if you don't pay ahead of time via Internet, you end up with a hefty bill in your mailbox.  Awful way for them to be making money off of tourists!!!
author: DeAnna G.

description:
It's the Golden Gate Bridge. People from all around the world have seen this- on everything! I feel honored to live so close. There are a ton of fantastic trails to hike after you cross over from Marin Co- The view, Crissy Field, the actual COLOR of the bridge's paint..these are the things that you just have to see for yourself. It's about 1.7 miles long, we walked back and forth (two children in tote) no problem. The traffic is loud, yes, but the sight of the Pacific drowns it out for me. 
For my birthday, we were going to ride our bikes across this February. I am pretty happy we walked it first. It is recommended you walk your bike, which no one does, and I can see why. Although the walkway is big enough, there are still too many risks (bad biking etiquette, small children) for me! I sure wouldn't mind walking (or jogging!) across it again, and I am certain I will in the near future.
author: Rosemary W.

description:
It's a pretty amazing view on the bridge, to see the tops disappear into the fog, to see downtown SF in the distance, Marin on the other end, Alcatraz in the clear blue waters. Definitely something you have to do once.

It was my first time and it was a much louder experience than I thought, you're right next to the traffic so it doesn't make it a very peaceful stroll. Also pretty chilly up there, even in the middle of the summer, so bring a jacket!

Biking across would be freaking awesome too, I imagine, but the bike path is pretty narrow and you could probably get stuck behind some slowpokes :P

PS -- We saw a biker gang of unicyclers, awesome! Great for people-watching. & I really like waving to the boats passing underneath and seeing if people wave back, and when they do it's like an amazing connection you wouldn't otherwise have had. :)
author: Vivian H.

description: A trip to San Francisco isn't complete without a visit to the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Aileen E.

description: Turning a national landmark into a frustrating scam, congratulations Bay Area. What a lousy way to welcome visitors--send them a notice calling it a "violation."
author: Peter M.

description: The Golden Gate Bridge is an international recognized symbol of San Francisco. That is why it is famous and millions of people travel to SF just to see this bridge. At night it shines like no other bridges and is very an amazing view to see. My bf and I rode bikes on this bridge to get to Sausilito. It sounds fun, and it was fun, but at the same time it was dangerous due to the large crowd. The bike lane was extremely small and it seemed like we were stopping every few seconds. Other than the crowd, it felt great to know that i got a chance to be on the golden gate bridge.
author: Mimi V.

description: Iconic - do I really need to say more.  Take a look at the pic's and all the others of this beautiful bridge.  Walk it, drive it, see it from every angle - the experience is memorable.
author: Jason G.

description: The Golden Gate bridge is an undeniably striking landmark. Its orange color casts a welcoming, familiar glow as it peeks out from the gray clouds of the San Francisco sky. If you are lucky enough to catch it on a sunny day, you'll have on stunner of a view but your photos won't have that special quality that you'll get when there's a thick layer of fog. There are many awesome spots in town to view the bridge (Fort Point is a great viewpoint from below the bridge) but there's nothing quite like driving across it. You only have to pay the steep toll one way but it's worth every penny.
author: Louisa M.

description: On our way back from Sonoma my husband made a point to cross The Golden Gate Bridge.  It never gets old. Luckily, there wasn't much traffic.  We love this bridge!
author: Joyce V.

description:
You appreciate all those men putting their lives in danger to build this bridge once you are on it. Breath taking.
