Walk it (is free) and be amazed of how man was able to do this almost 100 years ago.
author: Prusha S.

description: Such an iconic bridge in SF! You can't leave SF without seeing it. It's absolutely beautiful and its bright red color is magnificent in the bay. Just a beautiful bridge.
author: Jena D.

description: For my 100th review I wanted to do an iconic place. It doesn't get more iconic than this, the instantly recognizable emblem of San Francisco and one of the United States great achievements. A long walk across and back with my camera was one of the highlights of my trip. There is great scenery on and around it. As a history buff, I would have liked something somewhere that talked about the history of the bridge and how, when it was built and there wasn't anything other than a small cafe with tourist trap gifts, so minus one star. Take the time to walk or bike over it instead of just driving and you'll have a great time.
author: Darren F.

description: The Great Golden Gate Bridge! This is an awesome place to come because it's free! So many cool things to do here that is free and the things surrounding this bridge is awesome! Your close to amazing parks and greats views! Walking across the bridge is awesome but can get cold and foggy at times! Driving across the bridge is cool to! Must see place to go to!
author: James L.

description:
Why is it called the Golden Gate Bridge? Maybe they call it Golden cause we're the Golden State? Or Golden means old and when I associate SF I think of Old. Whatever the case may be.. This bridge is the quintessential land mark of Frisco. A.K.A. The CIty. 

*Undeniably, probably the best place to take a memorable picture of your time in lovely San Francisco City. 

** The bridge is red not Gold. True story. Dress accordingly.
author: Justin Y.

description:
***Golden Gate Bridge is a must-visit (or at least a must-see) if you are visiting San Francisco for the first time***

While I haven't explored many national landmarks, the Golden Gate Bridge would rank as the most impressive I've seen so far.  From a distance, it looks nice.  And when you walk on it, the sheer size of it is incredibly imposing.  Also, the bridge looks and feels new (unlike the Bay Bridge, which despite its size, feels kind of depressive looking; I think the Vincent Thomas Bridge in Long Beach has more character).

The walkways are good for visitors too.  They are big enough that they can accommodate groups coming from both directions.  The railings are shorter than I expected so if you are afraid of heights, you may not want to get too close.

I didn't have time to walk from one end to the other end (and back), but I plan to do so on my next visit.

The Golden Gate Bridge is definitely one you need to check out if you find  yourself anywhere in the Bay Area.

Parking is free in the visitor's station and I was able to find a space immediately upon pulling into the parking lot (I visited on a Friday afternoon).
author: Anthony N.

description:
Staycation.

Brilliant colors. Majestic views. Peaceful aura.

Drive it. Walk it. Run it. Marvel at it.

On those perfectly clear and warm day you can gaze at one of the most beautiful sights in the world. She never fails to instill a sense of wonder and awe.

It's one of my favorite reasons to always stay close to my beloved city by the bay.
author: Jason B.

description: I admit it, I'm a bridge nerd. My favorite bridge of all time.  Just marvelling at the great wonders of San Francisco.  I've seen the bridge from both sides now and I have to say that the view from Crissy Field/Fort Point is the best one.
author: Danny N.

description:
Best place in the city of SF.. Such an iconic symbol of this city ... 
My 1 st few times in SF , we walked out on the bridge .. But not across it
My most recent visit this year was the Best ( aside fr the hotel ) ... 
You must have a car in this town , best way to get around for me , we toured places off the beaten path . And the bridge  has a wonderful look out point on the muir woods side ... Waaay up top   Wonderful view 
I will be a forever a SF fan and visitor .. Maybe resident one day

The number one place in SF
author: Debra S.

description:
When visiting San Francisco on our honeymoon, crossing the Golden Gate Bridge was a must-do, and since we planned on visiting Muir Woods anyway we thought we'd kill two birds with one stone.  

For those unfamiliar with San Francisco, be forewarned - there are tolls to enter the city, so if you drive out and drive back in, you're gonna pay.

The bridge was kind of a nightmare returning, but it was our fault for being on it at 4:30 on a Saturday afternoon.  It took us 1 hour and 30 minutes to get from Muir Woods to Alameda.  Oye!
author: Johanna K.

description: Oh wow this is the most historical place it seems and I took many pics over here with my friends and uploaded into my social network sites , this place is so beautiful and awesome , we can't express the feelings about this place in words . I think its the amazing place in sfo to see and I think it does take some years to build this place .
author: Ravinder R.

description: With over 1,000 Yelp reviews, there's not much more to say about the Golden Gate Bridge that hasn't already been said.  This bridge is simply amazing, and pictures that you may have seen in print simply don't do it justice.  If you are ever in San Francisco, I highly recommend that you check it out and enjoy the beautiful view!
author: Erika E.

description:
Love this bridge. Have driven and walked it many times and yet I live close by I never take for granted this historic bridge. It symbolizes SF and often called "The Gateway To The West" it is always chilly here but that adds to the experience. 
When driving from Marin County into the city you feel that you have arrived and the great city of San Francisco awaits your arrival.
author: Darrin H.

description:
Is there really anything that still needs to be said about the Golden Gate bridge? Not really, but I'll say it anyway. It's a beautiful landmark which you can see at amazing angles all throughout the city and across the bridge in Sausalito. And of course the views of San Francisco, Sausalito, the bay and the ocean when you're on the bridge are just amazing. 

The beauty of the San Francisco bay is unparalleled.
author: Bekkah R.

description:
When you think of San Francisco, the Golden Gate Bridge is the one landmark that best represents it city!!

This bridge connects both US Route 101 and California State Route 1.

The bridge also connects the city of San Francisco on the northern tip of the San Francisco Peninsula to Marin County.

If you are driving, be aware that driving into the city of San Francisco on the bridge requires you to pay a $7 toll. 

This is a BIG tourist trap, but it will always be a MUST SEE in San Francisco. The bridge is well worth crossing on foot, but for me personally that will be my next trip up to this beautiful city.

And make sure you take your obligatory snap shot of yourself and the bridge herself on your visit. (See my photo with her on my profile shots)

Five Yelp Stars! =)
author: Albert E.

description: You can walk it, run it, or just drive on it - it's all great! On a rare sunny day though, it's so beautiful!
author: Muzamil K.

description: Really overrated, really difficult bike ride, really windy, really crowded. I wish someone told me to wear ear muffs. I also wish I didn't waste so many hours doing the bike ride. It's a bridge. It's just a bridge.
author: Samantha R.

description: What an awesome experience!  Took a tour bus and went over the Golden Gate Bridge and stopped across where there was a park.  OMG this was very awe inspiring experience.  Doubt if I will ever get to the Golden Gate Bridge again so I am very glad that I was able to cross this off of my bucket list!  Plus, I got to see my YELP friends Ida H & Joe K - the Wizard. Had a wonderful time in San Francisco and all of the fabulous places that we went!!!  Loved it, loved it, loved it!
author: Debbie Z.

description:
Came here in August on a day that was just magic - not a cloud in the sky, sun shining, NO FOG - you beauty !!! It was the most surreal moment standing on the bridge I had only seen in photos and watched destroyed in over dramatised hollywood flicks - such a beast of a bridge and what a bloody view !!! !! Living half a world away, there was NO WAY I would miss walking across this bridge and glad I managed to drag my holiday ass out of bed for it. 

For those who are addicted to their phones and feel compelled to take a million pics, save your battery for the north side of the bridge - great photos op here looking back toward SF. PS: ahhh yeah bring a sweater (or 2) - sun may be shining, but the wind will rip through you like a vindaloo gone horribly wrong !!
author: Maria N.

description:
Beautiful bridge! We visited in the beginning of April 2014. We drove over it twice not knowing that there was going to be a toll, but hey, I guess that's how the city makes their money. 

After driving over it, me and my boyfriend decided to walk across it and back to where we parked. Oh boy was that quite the walk! But it was amazing. To see this bridge in person was just incredible. On the side we parked, it overlooked the water and city. Along the way, there were plaques and history on the bridge. At the end of the bridge, there was a model showing what would happen if earthquakes of different magnitudes would effect it. 

To be honest, I was scared walking over the bridge since I am a little afraid of heights, but I am glad I made the walk. Obviously, if you are a tourist, then you are going to want to drive over it yourself.
author: Reneesha R.

description:
Experiencing this bridge was a very morbid experience. All I could think of the entire time was how many people have killed themselves using this bridge. I was shocked to actually see how low the guard rail was. A suicide barrier is SO needed. And no, the majority of the people who commit suicide by jumping off this bridge would NOT just find another way to do it. It is a proven fact that bridge-jumpers have a more impulsive mentality and, given proper medical treatment and mental intervention, could go on to lead full lives that did not end by suicide.

I recently lost the most important person in my life to suicide, and I wish our society would treat suicide differently. I believe in someone's right to die, and a right to choose how you go, but I believe that a majority of the people who use this bridge to commit suicide would rather get help and be happy than die.

I am grateful the bridge was open to the public, and being able to walk across it into the fog was incredible, but it is a public safety risk. 

Please call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 24/7 if you need someone to talk to. 1-800-273-TALK.

Advice: Do not research the GGB before you go, or else all you will think about the entire time is suicide and death and sadness. Ooops, too late, you're on Yelp right now researching the GGB. Go back in time and don't look it up on Yelp before you go.
author: T. M.

description:
At first thought, it seemed odd to write a review for a bridge. A rather crowded bridge, at that. However, the more I reflected on my experience at The Golden Gate Bridge, the more I realized I needed to let other first time visitors know how to use the bridge! 
Firstly, this is a TOLL BRIDGE. You cannot cross it for free. Secondly, you cannot stop at the toll booth to pay the toll. You will get yelled at on a loud speaker and may cause an accident if you try to stop. Simply drive through and a camera will take a photo of your license plate, you will get a bill in the mail for the toll in a week or so. The toll is $6 to cross into the city of San Francisco. If you are a regular visitor, you can set up an online account and pay easily. 

This is a crowded bridge and the last exit in SF always seems to be congested, so be prepared to wait in traffic if you try to "abort mission" prior to crossing. 

Even still, it's the Golden Gate Bridge. 5 stars because it is gorgeous, iconic and you fail at being a tourist if you don't visit this landmark.
author: Julie S.

description: This bridge is famous for many different reasons. There are two sides to cross for non motorists ( one for bicyclists and one for pedestrians/bicyclists ) and crossing the entire span on foot can feel like quite an accomplishment. There are very nice views from the bridge itself and an outstanding view from the Marin Headlands which is adjacent to the bridge and overlooks it so long as there isn't any fog.
author: Christopher S.

description: If there is a NEGATIVE star that's what I'll give this review. Whoever thought of doing this Fastrak when crossing the Golden Gate bridge should be FIRED! WHAT A STUPID IDEA!
author: John S.

description: What a sight! The closer we got the sheer mass of this bridge became apparent. An engineering marvel! Instead of sitting through the traffic to get on the bridge we veered off to Fort Point, on the southern side at the base of the entrance along the bay. Fort Point protected San Francisco harbor from Confederate and foreign attack during and after the U.S. Civil War. Got some great views and an awesome view of the bridge! I recommend it!
author: An L.

description:
Wow - no words can describe seeing this bridge for the first time.
Magnificent.  Marvelous.  Iconic.  Spectacular.  Awesome. Amazing. Striking.
Its majestic, you don't even realize how big it actually is in real life.  

I was lucky enough to see the bridge for the first time on the 75th Birthday of this landmark bridge.  We made the trek down Crissy Field to watch the fireworks and man am I glad I suffered through the walking and surprising cold.  Any blisters or shivers I received from that evening were entirely worth it once the bottom of the bridge started spewing streams of fireworks. 

The bridge really is grand.  Its beautiful from so many angles and locations.  Taking the ferry to Sausalito and Alcatraz and riding the Powel & Hyde Cable car all granted me different and equally as amazing views of this landmark.

Just amazing.

I wish I would've had time to walk or bike the bridge, but beware bikers/walkers, bundle up, that wind across the bay will get you! Burrrrrr!
author: Jasmine B.

description:
300th REVIEW!!!

I love this bridge. It's the most romantic bridge ever for me. It's awe inspiring and will always hold a special place in my heart. Bay Area residents are super lucky to have access to such a beauty.

The drive thru this bridge no matter how busy is always memorable. I can never get enough of it. 

The view of the bay is always amazing. The walk thru the bridge span should be a part of everyone's experience. Try it once! Go to the overlook when you get to the end of the bridge going north. On a nice sunny day you will experience the breath taking view of downtown SF.

On the way back to SF get your camera ready and take a picture of the bridge with the fog hanging over it. I can assure you that like a photogenic model it will not fail to put a smile on your face.
author: Janet D.

description:
Absolutely one of the most awesome and monumental bridges that is accessible to pedestrians.  I love going across this bridge on foot, motorcycle and bicycle - it's a beautiful bridge and the views are ever changing depending on the weather - fog or sun, boats, ships, kite surfers, airplanes - oh and tall ships!  Best place for watching the tall ships parade at least once or twice in your life - quite a different perspective.

This is definitely a "must see" if you are visiting from out of town - nothing gimmicky or "tourist trap" about it - though you will see many tourists, many of them live here!
author: Jenn C.

description:
Well first if all if you've never been don't expect a golden colored bridge its rust color.  But its a nice bridge.  Usually cold and foggy and the fog covers the tips of the bridge.  that's a pretty view. 
 
The walk across the bridge is not too bad it feels safe and is not very long I walked it across with my 6 year old and he made it all the way. 

The restrooms at the visitor center- dirty  no soap and no wiping paper and the store closes too early.
author: Laila R.

description:
A golden symbol that means you are finally home! I love the Golden Gate; coming here to take pictures just never gets old whether you are a new tourist or a Bay Area veteran. Plus it avoids the typical "tourist trap" because it's virtually free minus parking and the toll. My advice is to park on the south side of the bridge so you don''t have to pay the southbound toll on your way back. 

I've driven across numerous times and stood outside with the wind blowing through my hair on several occassions but it wasn't until I put my mind to it to walk all the way across the bridge that I was able to fully take in all it's beauty. Go walk across with someone you love and it'll feel like a little piece of heaven with amazing views of the city and Bay. Just make sure to bundle up in some warm clothes!
author: Jeanine W.

description: Driving over the bridge is so beautiful!Also the new automatic bridge toll makes it a lot faster to get through.
author: Lydia H.

description: Simple  beautiful!  Our trip to Sanfransico was amazing.  To see the bridge  was truly something to Marvel...
author: Genia B.

description:
This thing is so frustrating... I crossed the bridge on my way to a 10 day cruise.  Before I got home a bill came for my toll.  Literally 4 days later I received another notice.  I went online and opened a license plate billing account. 2 days later I get a collection notice.  I have tried to call over and over and over... I cannot get anyone on the phone.  How can you send someone to collections over a toll and not have someone that I can call to pay?!?  Now several months later I have the license plate setup and I don't know who to pay for the toll violation.  A little more time needs to be given before you send someone off to collections... After weeks of not being able to figure out what to do I filed a complaint with the Better Business Bureau.. Golden Gate Transit didn't even bother to respond!

I sure would like help figuring out how to make sure that the toll violation that I had ends up on my license plate account and not in some collection agency where it will end up on my credit.
author: Brandon A.

description:
When it's zero humans at the toll-booth,
FasTrak is at it's best.
Yay for listening to some high-priced consultant telling you the obvious.
Bay Bridge folks...take notice!
author: Derek N.

description: I really love the golden gate bridge! I love the views, the coastal breeze, as well as the drowning fog at times. There is something about the architecture too that is amazing. This is a must-see SF attraction. Try parking and exploring the areas around the bridge, which enable you to get up close and personal to the bridge and all of it's epic beauty!!
author: Amanda C.

description:
I love my city & all our gorgeous landmarks.

With that said..you probably can't see the bridge at least 1/2 the year because of another SF landmark... our lovely fog. But on a good sunny day, it definitely is worth biking/walking across and great for photos
author: Jenn Y.

description:
I love the Golden Gate Bridge! Despite having lived here my whole life, I still love playing tourist and walking the bridge. I would highly recommend it.
However, one thing to note is, they recently changed the regulations regarding walking the bridge. It used to be that bikers were on one side of the bridge, and walkers were on the other side. But, they decided to put both walkers and pedestrians on a single side of the bridge.... It is a horrible arrangement. The fact that this is a major tourist destination that attracts a ton of people, it makes it difficult to walk safely next to many bikers speeding across the bridge. Also, many people don't follow the rules of which side of the pathway to stand/walk/bike on, causing the potential for many accidents. It was constantly necessary to make sure I wasn't going to get run over or hit!
author: Azinda M.

description:
I really big long bridge. Is that it? No, quite not reader.

You have an amazing view of SF if you walk out to the middle of the bridge. Just taking the walk on this bridge on a nice day will lift your spirits.
author: Luis D.

description: Absolutely beautiful! Bring your camera and don't forget to pay for your parking spot! You can decently take some amazing pictures here!
author: Yaya L.

description:
It's just another bridge to me but I've watched it so many times on TV and in the Movies I've been brainwashed to give it 6 stars (because Yelp maxes at 5) - 

I had to take this bridge when they did work on the Bay Bridge on the Presidents day weekend and it cost 6 dollars. That's 1 dollar more then the bay bridge !! Errr but hey it's for the Golden Gate bridge and it's awesomeness : ) You have to smile for that. 

I do have to admit it has a kick ass view overlooking the bay area !! but so does the bay bridge.. just saying, LoL .. but you don't see the bay bridge get hyped.. unless it was in 89 when part of it's deck went down from the earthquick.. but that's negative hype O_o .. 

If you never been here it's great to cross off your bucket list. I normally come here to show people the sights that has never been here before and knock off my own bucket list !! bucket of KFC !! yeah that was corny !! Sorry,, LoL 

Note: If you have time go park your car and walk/bike the span of the bridge !! Again it's a nice view and it's good for your health !! that's as long as you don't jump off of it !! NOT RECOMMENDED !!
author: Tay D.

description:
Don't read into reviewers' annoyance with the bikers. They are just hatin that they can't ride a bike or are too wide to move out of the biker's way. It should only be a review on the bridge! When I was there they were getting ready for the 75th year anniversary. I can imagine it will be great. 

It's a great way to kill time and enjoy the view. Bring a jacket like a north face. Can be quite windy. 

A food truck may do very well if they were allowed to sell stuff at the parking lot.
author: Chris L.

description:
BEWARE! Obligatory touristy post about the bridge coming your way.

What's a first trip to San Francisco without coming here? I knew this was on my list of places to visit when I was planning my trip. A true landmark of the times and a must-see for anyone. The views of the bay, the city, Alcatraz were amazeballs!

The parking is metered in a lot near the beginning of the bridge. I lucked out and someone was leaving just as my car pulled into the lot! YAY! 

I would put in about an hour and a half or more on the meter if you wanted to trek back and forth on the bridge. I put in only about an hour and boy oh boy was that a mistake. LOL. Ended up running over half the bridge back in fear that our car would get towed or ticketed. Don't make the same mistake!!
author: Kevin C.

description:
I think it goes without saying that everyone should see the iconic Golden Gate Bridge when you go to San Francisco. We were told how lucky we were to have visited on a rare sunny day, but I would have loved seeing it in all of its foggy glory! 

We did not have time to walk across the bridge, but definitely bring a coat if you decide to do so (and if you are a girl, something to pull your hair back from the crazy wind :)
author: Katherine M.

description:
You MUST see the Golden Gate Bridge if you're a tourist in San Francisco. The Golden Gate Bridge is the Statue of Liberty of the West and makes me miss California, every time I see it.

Local Insider Tip: It is FREE to drive across the Golden Gate Bridge if you are driving INTO the city. It costs $6 (Unless you have a FasTrak pass, then it's $5) to drive OUT of San Francisco using the Golden Gate bridge - they want to keep your money in the city.

Local Insider Tip: bring a jacket and a ponytail holder - it is WINDY up on that bridge. You don't want to spend most of your time trying to keep your hair out of your eyes while you freeze your butt off!

Local Insider Tip: Bring a car - you can not walk to the Golden Gate Bridge from your hotel.

It's a beautiful place to take pictures and it's free to walk or ride your bike across. Come early to beat the crowds and wear a decent pair of shoes (not high heels.) 

If you decide to go under the bridge (via a boat tour) bring a coat, and sea legs - it is choppy as all get out.
author: Rachel S.

description: Awesome! Watch out for all the bicycle riders tho. Some of them must think they're in a race , and the bridge is very noisy so you cannot hear them. Windy, as expected. What a view. Seemed more huge up close than I expected. We made sure to tour the civil war fort nestled below. It's a toll bridge if you drive over it, as we needed to do later. It was easy to prepay online for our rented car however.
author: Ken J.

description: When I visited for the first time in December, I pulled over after a obligatory In-N-Out stop and took some pics since the weather in SF was decent (gotta take it when you can, as I've found out). There's a little area where you can park for free near the bridge and get some breathtaking views. I'd like to walk it somehow to get the full effect like the Brooklyn Bridge.
author: Dan M.

description:
Majestic. Beautiful. Stunning. Exceeds all expectations. 
This is the awe inspiring international icon, the Golden Gate Bridge. 

Driving across is an experience in itself but to truly experience the bridge, you need to walk or ride a bike across it. I've done both, on both sides of the span, and it stands out in my mind as one of the most special things I have ever done in my life. The bridge forces the mind to slow down for a bit....you forget about work and unimportant things, you look and see if you can find Alcatraz and then check out the ships. If you're lucky a large cargo container ship passes right underneath you. Or if you're really lucky you get to see an Aircraft Carrier pass beneath your feet. 

If you have read the history of the bridge, you look up at the towers, down at the currents, and you have a new found respect for the men who built this civil engineering masterpiece. You check out the beautiful San Francisco city skyline, you look out at the Pacific and you smile to yourself and say I'm glad I did this!

Bring some water, make sure your camera has plenty of free memory to take pix, and snap away. But most importantly of all...just enjoy the experience of one of America's crown jewels.
author: Shawn J.

description: Worth having a run over the bridge. We parked at Cavallo Point (beautiful for drinks or dinner afterwards). A bit of an uphill at first but knowing everything that goes up must come down, give you some hope. You can easily do about a 3-5 mile from there to the opposite side of the bridge and back. Spectacular views.
author: Thelma V.

description:
One of the most famous places on earth, and is truly breathtaking. If you have time left, go under the bridge. Also, take the sun on the opposite side of the bay, looking towards the Pacific on one of the trails that exist there. Access is under the road.

Visited October 2014
author: Matheus G.

description:
This bridge is dope.  It's the wallpaper to my Iphone.  

http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/QG-_yolT5m4m0e4p0t5OTg/l.jpg

Being born and raised in San Francisco, I definitely take for granted the fact that the Golden Gate Bridge is in plain view almost everywhere I go.  To my surprise it was crowned #1 on Travel Channels "World's Top 10 Bridges".  Beating out the Brooklyn Bridge, London Bridge, this ginormous bridge in Japan, etc...

http://www.travelchannel.com/interests/road-trips/articles/worlds-top-10-bridges

Maybe it's because I see it everyday? But I find that when I actually stop and look at it, it is a really nice bridge.  So thank you Golden Gate Bridge and surrounding landscape for providing panty droppin views to bring my ladies friends too, to be able to fly a kite right next to you, for bridging the gap between nice weather and not so nice weather, and for just watching over our City that we all can appreciate more.
author: Randy N.

description:
One of the finest perks of living on the 510 "nickel'n dime" side of SF Bay is that you can see the Golden Gate bridge from your living room window. Straight ahead, dead on. No ifs-ands-or-buts about it.

At this very moment, the bridge lights are just barely visible through the evening sky. Two moments ago, I checked the view to see if any ships were passing through in the evening twilght. There weren't any. Ships that is. 

Nosedivers (they say) usually take the port side  for exit into the water below. That would be the side facing us. The theory is that they are looking toward the hills. Hoping for that last human contact. 

At dusk, I often say a brief matins for them, the poor departed souls. Try to give their wandering spirits rest. Its the least an East Bay girl can do for those who dream of greater fortune than they are able to acheive.  Try to give 'em the peace they seek. Tell them that the 510 folks will love 'em just for themselves.  

We are like that on this side of the gate.  Open to possibilities. Without judgment. Humble. But proud. 

My favorite memory of a ship passing beneath the Golden Gate was when Queen Elizabeth (that would be the English queen, and not one of her namesakes on Polk Street)...Queen Elizabeth sailed under the bridge on her way to her first official visit to SF. 

Actually, it was a visit to Silicon Valley, but SF grabbed the headlines. That's the way it is around here, you can live in San Jose, El Cerrito, Novato...but few will know where you are from unless you mention San Francisco. 

I digress.

Queen Elizabeth was coming to town. I thought it would be fun to see her arrival from "on high" so I grabbed Muni's 28 bus to get to the bridge. Of course, the bus got stuck in traffic just as it arrived at the toll booth. SO..there were four or five of us who got ringside seats. Above the crowd...watching all of the pomp and circumstance *beneath* us. 

As best I remember, our motley crew included: 

1.) The bus driver, who had been a Black Panther in his youth. This being from his own life-tale. 

2.) A reporter/photographer from some important newspaper like the SFExaminer.

(Examiner? "How the mighty have fallen" )

3.) A fellow on his way to Clement Street. Wearing a beret. Might have been IRA. Perhaps a Green Beret. I'm not sure. 

4.) Me.  Student in the Poli-Sci masters program at SFSU. WIth a host of uppen-coming fellow students. All wearing blue jeans. All hoping for tomorrow. 

5.) Possibly...a sleeping drunk who had climbed on the bus on Lombard. He saw nothing. Said nothing. But (of this I am sure) was somebody's son. 

Being stuck in the bus, as we were, we chatted. Entertained each other with various tales from our pasts. Spent a good half hour watching the world from our bus...a regular Ship Of Fools. 

The Golden Gate Bridge, in her majesty, kept watch. Over the bus, the crowds, the Queen of England. 

In those days, she didn't need painting...her International Orange created just the right backdrop for our retinue. Contrasted beautifully with the green trees, blue skies, and frothing whitecaps below.

(I am referring, of course, to the bridge rather than the Queen. )

T'was a fine moment which will be hard to forget. 

And the bridge now? 

Let me look. Just as I thought. There's a little ship heading out to sea. Its almost eclipsed by the beacon from Alcatraz. But not quite. 

The bridge lights are still shining brightly. As they should be.
author: Dorothy C.

description:
iconic, and worth all the hype. Such a beautiful bridge! 
I've always wanted to run across the Golden Gate bridge and last weekend I did, Only 3 miles roundtrip, but I'm telling you, it was harder than I thought with those crosswinds. Plus, people don't seem to get the concept of keeping to the right, so you will constantly be dodging people. Still, this was a great run, the view of the city and the view of the bridge itself cloaked in fog was almost surreal. 
I shall return.
author: Scott H.

description: This is a total scam. I crossed the bridge expecting to be able to pay like I have in previous years. But today their wasn't a single person their. I figured sence the bridge was going to be closed the next weekend that they might just have it free to those who use it since it will no longer be use able for a few days. Well. I crossed the bridge, tried to pay, and now you want more than what my toll bill should have been? I guess this is how our lovely state is paying its employees. With falsely accused bills and what not.
author: Lyle M.

description:
So a year ago I was in San Fran for work and decided to run across the Golden Gate Bridge.....fanatistic......I recommend it to everyone.

For this visit though, I brought my girl to show her this incredible sight.

As landmarks go, this is in the top 3 for me and no matter what the weather or how many people are there, it is always a treat. 

I recommend driving across it or walking it if possible.  Seeing it from the base is also a very interesting perspective.
author: Michael E.

description:
How come the Golden Gate Bridge is not golden?????
They were suppose to paint it gold, but it looked good red even though that was a primer. I think that's what I learned in school. According to Wikipedia, it says it can be seen through fog hence the color.

The very first time I walked across this, I was 12 years old on a field trip. The second time, I brought my aunt from New Zealand here, I was probably 13 or 14. Today, I came here with my cousin from out of town but we didn't walk across but drove across. The weather was nice and sunny, not typical SF weather.

I remember during that 7th grade field trip it took about 40min to walk across...I'm not too sure. They also have a little SF tourist store on the SF side of the bridge, I remember getting my mom a SF zipper pull/keychain or something with her name on it...or Mom, I don't remember, I hope she still has it. I can't believe I actually remember all of that.

Each experience is different. The people I come with, the atmosphere, the weather...it's different every time and it makes me proud that I'm a San Franciscan.

It is $6 to drive across the bridge (pay towards SF), yeah you heard right, SIX WHOLE DOLLARS. Ages ago, it was only $3 & that seemed like a jip back then.

How much San Francisco can you get from the bridge??? LOTS, you can see Alcatraz, Bay Bridge, fleets going by, Downtown area, radio tower...don't look to the side if you're driving, FOCUS on driving. Yeah, it's hard not to look at so many attractions but your safety & the other people's safety around you are more important.

3 lanes going to Sausalito, 2 lanes going to SF. Not many lanes for a bridge with so many people crossing.

It's always a fun experience, even if you're just driving across.
author: Kylie L.

description:
this is my favorite bridge in the united states. it is indeed an iconic tribute to the second greatest city in America (After NYC of course)

This is one of the most recognizable structures in the world and no trip is complete without crossing the bridge
author: Oculus C.

description:
As I was thinking about what to say (as of the writing of this there are over 770 reviews on Yelp) about this absolute gem and icon of SF, I was trying to remember if there was ever a time that I have been out there that it hasn't been super windy.  I'm sure if I lived there more often, the answer might be yes, but in the few times I've been there, it's always been super windy.

But who cares?  It's just beautiful to look at, and if you're feeling adventurous and aren't afraid of the height, walk out on it.  It's amazing.
author: Stephen H.

description: So beautiful. We ride out bikes from the wharf to Sausalito. Just snoozing views of the bridge on the entire ride   We went to the fort under the bridge walked around then ride bikes over the bridge. The best part you can stop look and enjoy the bridge. At your leisure. The best views of city also. Then a nice ride to Sausalito take ferry back to the wharf
author: Eric C.

description: The is a really cool bridge to walk across and ride a bike across. When you come to San Francisco you must come see this bridge. The is the best bridge in San Francisco.
author: Isaac H.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is a really beautiful structure and is very iconic of San Francisco and probably the Bay Area overall. It looks cool in both sunny and foggy weather. 

It's an obvious first place choice for most tourists but I don't blame them. It has a lovely view of the city and of the ocean. 

Worth visiting but unless you plan on biking, walking, just visiting, then I would say just visit once or a few times in your lifetime.
author: Sofia R.

description:
This is THE bridge! In the sunshine, wonderful! In fog, romantic! In rain, well, one can't have everything.......

The walk over this bridge to Fort Baker is really great!
author: George T.

description:
Edit:  I was sent a check for $4.   It is ridiculous that this person would risk her job for $4.  Thank God for camera's



Today 02.22.12 at 12:51:40 pm, lane three south bound .

I was shortchanged $4.00.

Seriously,  did this person pocket it or is it an honest mistake?  Good question.  It is under review now by the bridge police.  Its not about $4.  It's about the potential that someone could be pocketing money because most folks take the change and leave without counting until later.  Somewhat, Lucky for me as soon as I left I checked and sure enough I was short $4 change.  I paid $20,  she gave me $10.  

I surely hope this is just a mistake but if this person did pocket the cash I hope proper action is taken.

Lesson learned ALWAYS count your change before you take off.  There's no gaurantee the person giving you money can count.
author: Spanky M.

description: Simply do it. This is a must see. The view from the scenic view ( forgot the name) across San Francisco is absolutely amazing. Can't wait to revisit this place in the future.
author: Carlos A.

description:
My final review for 2010 is dedicated to the most beloved icon of the most beautiful city in the world. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lz7ydUVmsr2DekT9enEhvw?select=LrceW2-WBRflFwRKrjeQ3g 

Those who know me closely know that I have a love-affair with San Francisco. There are very few things that take my breath away each and every single time I set sight on it.  The Golden Gate Bridge is the only sight that leaves me in a trance, memorized by its beauty.  

What I love about this bridge is its ability to leave one breathless at almost any point its viewed from.  I've driven across, sailed under, stood at the foot, gazed from afar mountain tops, and through it all, I've never failed to become bored by this sight.  
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lz7ydUVmsr2DekT9enEhvw?select=ENEnM6mXhItjubC8gKrqwg
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lz7ydUVmsr2DekT9enEhvw?select=FptZv38a_vnQ8dsTv7Q-vA

When staring out, I can only imagine just how my maternal grandfather must have felt during his sail under the bridge back in 1940, just three years after the construction.  

To me, the bridge is the icon of freedom is the simplest idea.  Sail under the grand bridge, and you are instantly overwhelmed by a sense of endless possibilities, and a new sense of self for those who have forgotten.

We natives can often take this symbol of America for granted.  Working in tourism, millions of folks from all over the world make it there # 1 point of interest for good reason.  And I'm so proud I can visit the whenever I want to.  

Oh how the Golden Gate Bridge would be the most ideal perfect spot for a future wedding proposal !  A smart man knows I can't deny him here !  *Hint* Lol

*Cheers* To a very Prosperous and Happy 2011 to come !
author: Cass J.

description:
The new personless toll plaza on the Golden Gate bridge. With no explanation, you drive through. We had no idea what would happen. 

About a month later, we get a bill that REALLY has the look of junk mail. Pretty sure they tried their best to make it look like junk mail. The toll is $6 if paid within a couple of weeks (arrived in our mail on 7/5, due by 7/22), if after, it is $31. Geez, good thing I wasn't on a long trip, huh? So I am pretty sure this is a racket  - they send you junk mail, hope you throw it away and pay more. Most people probably don't even know about it until it goes to collection. And I live in Sacramento, so when would we have gotten it if we lived out of state (you know, where a lot of people who cross the Golden Gate Bridge live)? What about out of the country? What if you were in a rental car? How long would it take to make it to you then? The website is of course crap and they don't answer the phone. So yeah. Racket. 

This is some New Jersey assed $h1t! Shameful.
author: Natalie S.

description: I didn't know u can write a review on Golden Gate Bridge on yelp, I would have written it right away! Anyway, it was one of the most amazing experience I have ever done. I biked the bridge down to Sausalito and took a ferry back, and all I could say is that it was perfect beyond words. The scenic view is amazing. There were uphills and downhills which I found it hard since I am not an expert but other than that, it was a smooth way. My advice to those who are planning to bike the bridge to wear their helmets because the way is narrow and hitting your head on the huge metal beams on the side can be very dangerous. One thing we didn't do. We didn't realized the danger until we were up there biking and saw the other bikers with full gears. It is a MUST thing to do if you visit the Golden State.
author: Chatty W.

description:
Touristy thing #2 on my list was to walk the Golden Gate Bridge. 
I did it near the end of my trip but I knew I had to do this before leaving. I mean what kind of chump goes to San Fran and NOT stop to walk this epic bridge. Thankfully it was a sunny and warm day when I did this because I realized 2 things while on here:

1. I still had very much a healthy fear of heights. 
2. That fear is magnified by the fact that there are some strong ass winds on this bridge. 

That being said I steeled myself and walked across. Going was fine, I couldn't help but notice all the phone boxes to crisis hotlines while I was going across. I mean that's a harsh way to go if you want to off yourself. It's a long way down and I was told constantly by people how the Bay does not get warm at all, so if the impact of the fall won't get you hypothermia will. Sorry if that was a bit morbid.

It took me almost an hour to get across but in all fairness I did stop several times to admire the amazing views. It really is lovely up here. If you had just the view of the city without the sound of crazy speeding cars and the treacherous wind at my back I would almost say it was serene. 

Definitely felt a sense of accomplishment when I got to the end. However, there were a lot of people on the other side waiting for buses back so impatience trumped my fear and I ended up walking back too. The ocean side wasn't open to pedestrians but I did notice that bikes were allowed on that side when I was coming in on Sunday. Definitely would be a nice ride if you get the chance. If you're lucky, you may even get to walk on a day when the fog doesn't roll in.
author: Michelle J.

description: Im  a fan but i should have payed attention to the forecast.  Their was tooooo much fog and i dintt get to see anything from the look out point.  NEXT TIME For sure.
author: Hector H.

description:
The bay bridge always looks so beautiful on a warm sunny day. 

I'll never forget junior prom, when we were all on a boat and watched the bay bridge light up at night. The boat passed underneath it a couple times and it was breathtaking.
author: Sophia G.

description: Just walked the entire bridge and back with my girlfriend. An amazing experience. Definitely recommend some good walking shoes and appropriate clothing. We went in the morning and it was a bit chilly but a light jacket should be sufficient. Overall great walk and something I would definitely recommend for anyone to try at least once
author: Salvador B.

description:
I've lived in the Bay Area all my life and if my friends and I are in the city we're always down to go pass or see the Golden Gate Bridge. It's huge and makes me feel like I'm floating once I'm on the bridge. Currently (June 2014) theres a lot of construction around the bridge, I missed my exit for Baker Beach once and ended up having to cross the bridge and going back having to pay toll. 

Always bring a jacket even in the summer time, San Francisco is next to the bay.. it's the reason why it's called the Bay Area. It doesn't ever get too hot in the city so dress in layers, most of the time in light layers. 

The bridge looks spectacular in any weather, though I wish Californians knew how to drive a lot better in rainy weather especially passing the bridge. But whenever you're in the Bay make sure to stop by the GGB, you won't regret it!
author: Elaine M.

description: The views are spectacular of the bridge! We went to the museum side which has really good angles and a cafe so you can enjoy. It's kind of crowded around 10-5. On the next day I took a bike tour that went on the bridge and it was amazing! This is a beautiful landmark!
author: Amir L.

description: Iconic landmark! Must see for travelors
author: Beth F.

description:
Yay. My 100th review! I wanted to review this a while ago but decided to hold out as such an awesome landmark was deserving of my 100th spot.. landmark for a landmark kind of thing.

Being from England I recall seeing the Golden Gate Bridge so many time on TV and in films but never actually thought I would even visit it but now living just a few miles from it I feel very lucky - now I can marvel at it greatness whenever I want!!

Last March finding out my husband was asked to come to the area from London to work for 2 weeks I jumped at the chance to come along and top of my list of places to see was of course Golden Gate Bridge and our first free day we took a drive down from San Bruno.. the drive was nice enough in itself but seeing the bridge appear in the distance really was an amazing sight - 1.7 miles of Steel suspended over the Pacific who wouldn't be impressed??! 

The view while on the bridge is just as awesome - Alcatraz and San Francisco in the distance. There are so many photo opportunities.

Parking can be a nightmare at the closest point to the bridge on the southeast side so if you're going by car - be prepared. There are just 81 spaces which are metered at 25c per 15 minutes or at weekends and holidays there is additional parking available on the southwest side for $5 per day.

The site also offers a Café which is open 9:30 am to 5 pm during winter months, and 9 am to 7 pm during summer months. Food includes Muffins, Sandwiches, Soda, Starbucks, Salads, Candy and Potato Chips

And of course it wouldn't be complete without a gift shop which is packed full of the usual items - T-Shirts, Hoodies, Baseball Caps, Magnets, Cups, Pens ect.. 

No visit to San Francisco will be complete without a trip to Golden Gate.
author: Emmalouise B.

description:
Write a review for a bridge?? well okay. It got me and my car over the water it was fantastic.
 All kidding aside It's something everyone should see in their life time.
author: David C.

description:
Short and Sweet...It's a beautiful place! 

I went this past December and saw it from a totally different view. Everytime I've ever gone to up to SF to view the Golden gate Bridge, I've only ever driven through it. This year I went on a tour group and got to see it from two new perspectives.

First, I got to walk along the bridge and next I got to take the SF Bay boat tour and pass underneath the bridge. Both perspectives are absolutely breathtaking. The bridge's large stature and majestic presence were well appreciated in these two perspectives. 

I can't wait to visit on a foggy day and see the brige from yet another perspective.
author: Rasien I.

description:
Magnifique!! What an amazing display of architecture. The fact that humans can construct a suspension bridge that is considered one of THE gateways to one of the most amazing cities in the world is beyond me.  It is a little unsettling knowing that a quake can strike any minute and this massive structure can violently sway to and fro, but that's just my paranoia psyching me out. The beauty of the design is that is built to handle such natural atrocities.  So worry not. 

Enjoy the view. Takes lots of pictures. Take an evening stroll with that "special someone". Go for a jog. Ride a bike. Fear of heights? No problem. Just walk closest to the road, I assure you it's just as enjoyable. As you're walking this behemoth, take the time to read about the history and the people responsible for this wonder displayed on the plaques along the way. When you get to the first beam, look straight up...it'll make you realize how tiny you really are. Bring a jacket. Even on the warmest and sunniest days in the city, you will be surprised at how quickly the fog can consume this 1.5 mile stretch of steel. 

I often forget that this bridge is readily available for me to enjoy on a daily basis. Not too many people get to enjoy such wonders in their own backyard. Thank you San Francisco!
author: Amber Y.

description: The head winds might set you back but the bike ride from the piers to the bridge is incredible. The views as you get closer to the bridge and cross it are unmatched! Though be prepared to walk your bike a little over the bridge, gotta share the space with pedestrians too. Best part of seeing the city on this trip!
author: Melissa K.

description: Amazing!!  Just think about the men and women in the 30's who build this amazing structure.  Try putting your phone and camera down to take in the views and enjoy the view and beautiful city.
author: Frank C.

description:
The bridge is becoming more of a tourist trap every year. Tolls are increasing and traffic is too, because they have less and less people working the booths with the push of Fast Track but tourist don't have. 

Crossing on foot is dangerous because bicyclist treat the foot path as a freeway. They ride across ignoring the fact there are little children walking too.
author: M C.

description:
This is embarrassing, but I've never walked on the Golden Gate Bridge until yesterday. I've lived in the Bay Area my whole life. Not sure what my excuses are? But my friend asked if I'd like to join her and another gal, on their cardio adventure. I said sign me up. 

Right now, since the other side is closed, you have to share the area with bikers. It is rather annoying, because you can tell they wish walkers were not on the path. Well, the walkers wish the same back. Just try to find a happy medium while walking this amazing landmark. 

What to wear. Okay you can really tell who the tourist are, because they are in tank tops and shorts. The locals are in layers. Wear layers! Hats, gloves, shirt, jacket and vest. If you get warm you can't go wrong. Bring a camera for your epic shots. 

We were talking about when the Blue Angels are in SF, if you can watch them from the bridge. Guessing no? However, you can get some amazing views on this bridge. Looking down is kind of SCARY!!! So I looked ahead. Just really happy I finally did the GGB. : )
author: Michelle M.

description: Never realized how much of an attraction a bridge is to tourists but it got my partner and I to walk from one end to the other. It was a nice and sunny day but forgot that the winds are crazy on a bridge. We loved the light exercise and would recommend it as an experience to try.
author: Joni S.

description:
Let me put it this way. When I moved to America from Ireland, I went to Washington DC. When I first saw the Washington Monument, the Capitol, the Lincoln Memorial, the White House.... I was duly impressed. But after six months, I drove or walked past them without even looking.

I've lived in the Bay Area for EXACTLY one year today. And still, every time I pop out of the Waldo Tunnel to drive across the Golden Gate, I've got a massive grin on my face. A lot of the time, I'll pull off at the headlands for *that* view, even if I'm in a hurry. If the weather's right, I'll chance a few glances out to sea to see if it's a positive Farallon day. To the other side lies the City, the Bay, Alcatraz, with the white dots of sailboats playing amid the whitecaps. Raptors wheel overhead, while at the center of it alll; this gorgeous testimony in International Orange; this personification of all that is the SF Bay area, that mix of man-made beauty and nature's perfection. Shining in the sun, even as tendrils of fog cling to it's towers, it's the Statue of Liberty of the West, a beacon of hope to one and all to announce: You have arrived.

Pisses me off it costs a fiver to get into town though. Cheeky bastards.
author: Gary E.

description: Just beautiful! Of course you have to pay to cross it lol. But, I thought it was nice. Its a historic icon that represents and embodies all that this city is about. You have people crossing it on foot or by bike and I think that is the best way to see the beautiful views that surround the water and city.  I gotta take my kids here one day. One piece of advice... if you are actually using the bridge to get somewhere fast... try not to use it. The traffic crossing doesn't move swiftly. I suppose that is by design though.
author: Leeanna C.

description: Beautiful!  My cousins and I drove along Lincoln Road and onto the 101 for a bit when we found a great viewing spot along a trail known as Battery East.  What a great view of the wonder that is the bridge!  Luckily there was no cloud in sight (we were there at 900am on Saturday 6/29/13) and it made for awesome pictures. Simply amazing!
author: Christianne F.

description: When we got to the bridge, I overheard someone say that we had a good day!  no fog or low clouds so we were able to see the city, bridge, etc.  It was super windy and much cooler than the city though. I would check the weather before going so you can bring the appropriate clothing. I would have liked a scarf and my fleece!  Other than that, it was pretty cool to see it and walk across it. We took a cab but if you can get the #28 bus, it drops you off right in front of the welcome center. there are other buses from the city but I think you have to walk a bit to get to the center and bridge. Yes there is a small parking lot, it was crowded all the time we were there. Not sure how much though. oh if you get a cab going, there are not many cabs standing there waiting so be sure to have the phone number handy to get you back home/hotel. I guess Uber would have worked too.  The Center has general information and souvenirs about the bridge, history etc.  Walking the bridge was fine except be aware of the bike riders and other walkers, it can get pretty crowded in the first part of the bridge. Many people turn around midway.   oh there is a cafe by the bridge, coffee, tea and hot dogs mostly. They ran out of chili and soup that day we were there cause it was windy and cooler than expected! Great view on a clear day. Wear layers! Definitely should visit if you are in San Francisco.
author: Carrie T.

description:
I've lived in the Bay Area my whole life and I've never walked on the Golden Gate Bridge before.  I always thought that it was for out of town people and since my group were located very close to the Bridge trail, we parked a walked a moderate distance on a trail that led to the bridge.  

We only walked halfway across but it was almost an overwhelming amount of stimuli.  On one side, one sees the view of the Bay below with Alcatraz and Treasure Island in the background.  The cars on the bridge breeze by and the high winds blowing in our faces...it was a lot to take in.  Also add to the vibrations that I felt under my feet when walking that kind of unnerved me a bit!  

I saw that they were constructing a new building in the Visitor Center and if it is a restaurant, then I'd be the first in line to try their food and enjoy the scenic views from my table.
author: Ben H L.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is San Francisco's most famous icon (apart from Alcatraz) and is a fairly spectacular sight. As a proud Welshman I think that the two Severn crossings are equally impressive but I liked the self proclaimed world's greatest suspension bridge all the same.

The views of the city and the bay are great so I was thankful that I came on a clear day. There certainly is a big drop from the side so I was surprised that there weren't any higher barriers due to the high suicide rates. A must see for any tourist to SF!
author: Matt B.

description:
i only have a few tips for first time comers.

check the weather. come on a clear day. go to the one with the visitor station. and stay out of the way of bikers lol. and bring a sweater!

the other side is okay. it had some stuff but the view and the walk to the closest arch just isnt that close lol.
author: Somchai I.

description: Be careful of the toll gates on Golden Gate Bridge as you are always bound to have a long wait. Recently, the bridge added automated system to facilitate the traffic, but the end result is that you would have to pay online $6 (and remember to do so as well!) or else you would get fined quite a bit $31. All in all, this is a worthy passage since you get to visit one of the modern wonder of the world, the Golden Gate Bridge. Bon voyage!
author: Sam K.

description:
So I've been traveling to the Bay Area quite often, and for the first time ever, I've driven on the Golden Gate Bridge in BOTH directions! Haha.

Big deal, right? For me, yes. LOL. For the average San Franciscan person... you're probably like meh, it's a toll bridge that's big, orange, and pretty.

I've always admired the bridges of the San Francisco Bay Area for their beauty and for their amazing engineering. 

My biggest fear, wasn't the height at which I'd be traveling over the water, but was not being able to stop at the other end of the bridge to take a photo and just admire the bridge up close. Thankfully, it was a not-so-busy mid-morning and we were able to hop into the rental car and drive on over to the Marin Headlands.

Going Northbound towards Marin County and Sausalito was more of an awestruck feeling that I was actually traveling on the Golden Gate Bridge, the second bridge I've been on in the San Francisco Bay Area (the first being the San Mateo Bridge). On the way back it was just the same, happy feeling that I'm going back into San Francisco by way of this beautiful bridge.

TOURIST TIP: If you're in a Rental Car like me, and you're planning to travel Southbound on the US101-S by way of the Golden Gate Bridge, I recommend that you Prepay your tolls in advance to the Golden Gate Bridge Transportation District (goldengatebridge.org) to avoid video tolling convenience charges + undiscounted tolls charged to your rental agreement. Tolling on this bridge occurs only on the Southbound (way into SF) and it's fully automated/cashless.
author: Daniel B.

description: It's a great tourist site that offers tremendous views of the Bay Area. It's an interesting piece of American history and is free to visit. It's definitely worth going to for any first time Bay Area visitor.
author: Jude W.

description: Being a native New Yorker, I was definitely mesmerized by this beautiful bridge. It was one of the highlights of my trip to California and lived up to all the expectations I'd had.  Crossing over in the fog is a real experience too!  Almost mystical!  Love it and recommend it highly!  I kept looking for excuses to drive across!
author: Violet R.

description: We had beautiful weather our entire trip at end of November/beginning of December.  EXCEPT for when we walked the bridge is was super super foggy.  It did make it an interesting and fun experience though since my kids had never experienced fog.  It was FREEZING though.  I'm not sure it was necessary to walk the entire bridge over and back though.  Also, it wasn't very easy to figure out public transportation there and back.  Good thing we ran into helpful locals along the way.  The hot chocolate after was very nice!
author: Jasmine C.

description: too many tourists to stop but beautiful in every way. I checked out the view from north side..amazing! Then I went back to south side, interestingly nice views, but north is better. Still too many tourists for me to walk across, but a great experience!
author: James W.

description:
I thought long and hard about what I would write for my 100th Yelp review.  Yes, this is just the internet, and yes, this is just a review site.  But for what this site has meant to me over the years, I wanted to make sure that my 100th review was about something special to me.

The beautiful, glorious, awe-inspiring, tragic, remarkable, one-of-a-kind Golden Gate Bridge represents everything wonderful about my hometown to me.  Every time I see it, every time I walk or bike across it, the bridge inspires me to never take San Francisco for granted.  From the perfectly clear San Francisco days where anyone upon its gentle arc can see forever and a mile, to the eerie hours when it is concealed in its entirety by billowing hands of fog, the Golden Gate Bridge is the single most evocative icon in a city full of them.

If you are a cyclist, like me, then you may get the chance to watch the sun set over the Pacific Ocean from the bridge's western side.  I have seen the sun set over many beautiful places in this world, including from the Marin Headlands just up and over the hills to the North of the bridge, but for my money this particular view of day turning to night is the greatest I shall ever see.
author: Nick B.

description:
Ah Golden Gate Bridge! It's orange, historical, traditional, and beautiful! It wouldn't be SF without it! Taking away this bridge would be terrible and a tragedy because it's so well known to everyone whether you're a tourist or a long time Bay Area resident. 

It's your gateway to SF and Marin County or North Bay! 

Some of the downfalls to this bridge are the expensive toll fees (they keep raising the prices up every year), looks like a scary dungeon when driving there at night, and at times the walking/biking path area gets extremely windy! (Bring a jacket)
author: Alyssa C.

description:
ICONIC! Incredible.  

This majestic bridge represents the magnificence of San Fran and all of California.  No trip to SF is complete without experiencing the bridge.  For locals, this is one sight that does not get old.  Ever.  In the rain, fog, or shining golden at sunset - this is one of the most beautiful sights in the world.  The meeting of the mighty Pacific Ocean and the beautiful bay is a spectacular sight.  

You can walk, drive or bike across the bridge.  If time is of concern, drive across and enjoy from the Marin Headlands. 

Most beautiful in the late afternoon and at sunset. The vista plaza can be a bit of a zoo, but offers great views of the city. The best views of the bridge are from the Marin Headlands. Cross the bridge and then take the Alexander Ave exit off 101. Park as soon as you can.

Plan your trip here:
http://goldengatebridge.org/visitors/whattodo.php
author: Sunny C.

description: I love when out of towners are in town because I get to take them to GG bridge! It is not just the history but the views you get off the city, the ocean and the hills makes for a spectacular setting. You have to make a stop at Vista Point and soak it all in. The toll is an arm and a leg but worth it, I am sure those who take the bridge daily feel differently.
author: Sunil R.

description: Out-of-state people beware!  I live in Oregon and cross the bridge once a year in December, and have never received an invoice.   I've had the same address for 15 years and it's accurate on my registration.   Several months ago a collection agency called me about the 2013 crossing and wanted $70 plus dollars, of course I did not volunteer payment.  The collection agency said they could hold up DMV registration.  Nice try, I live in Oregon and it doesn't work that way.   I tried to pay online for my last trip in Dec 2015, but since I don't have an invoice number there is no option to pay.  I called their customer service number and while they are real nice people they cannot pull up my plate numbers or an invoice number so they won't even take my money.  However, they were able to pull up my 2014 trip and waived any late charges and so I was able to pay that.  This is a horrible system.
author: Katie D.

description:
Beautiful bridge.This really is a magical bridge.I think the history, location and fact that people gave up their lives from this bridge makes it famous tourist attraction.
Golden Gate Bridge is also nice.Visitor parking on both ends!! Makes it a great location to visit without hassle.
author: Tom S.

description:
Um...it's windy as heck here!  Bring a windbreaker and sunglasses.

Few options...go up the hill for pictures...go under the bridge (illegal) and roam around the guts of the Golden Gate Bridge...walk across the bridge (it's fun going over...not so fun coming back).
author: Cobra K.

description: So historical. I haven't been to the bridge this much in my life since I grew up in San Jose but I have had a lot of tourists come visit lately. Always great to be at the viewpoints and hike up a little bit to take a picture on the actual bridge. I'm also brave enough to dangle on the railing of the bridge a bit too and take in how high it is. Lovely views of the Embarcadero and Crissy Field and whenever I'm there,  it's not packed with tourists. I would run or walk on it everyday if I lived in the City.
author: Elizabeth V.

description: Nice place, the view is amazing, is cold in there, so make sure to bring a jacket. Is better during the day in my opinion. But the night is really good as well
author: Caio M.

description:
This bridge inspires awe in me whenever I cross it, or catch a glimpse of it.

However, I haven't been able to look at the Golden Gate Bridge in quite the same way since reading The Fatal Grandeur of the Golden Gate Bridge by Tad Friend in The New Yorker and Lethal Beauty (a seven-part series) in the Chron (which convinced me beyond the shadow of a doubt that we ought to erect a suicide barrier on it.)
author: Miriam W.

description: I've always wanted to do this, so I can finally scratch this off my bucket list. Totally sensational views. I'm glad my friends and I rode our bikes here. Unlike the other cyclist, I didn't chicken out. I actually did the round trip from Sausalito back to San Francisco. It was only 19 miles round trip. Not a big deal.
author: Michael F.

description:
Many great places to view it from. Chrissy Field or the Fort on the other side. The US Half Marathon runs across this bridge, the Nike Women's Marathon runs past this bridge with breathtaking views.

I always love telling people about the company that paints this bridge every year...once they're done painting it, they start right again from the other side! A company just to paint this bridge, how about that. :)
author: Esther Y.

description:
Haters will be hating, but this an amazing bridge upon which to walk, run, or bike; driving really doesn't do it justice!  

Most people know that it's one of the 7 wonders of the modern world because of its amazing engineering/architectural feat, so although some seem...errr...underwhelmed by it, if you take the time to understand & appreciate how revolutionary it was, it puts the significance of this bridge into more perspective.  

Another (some would say better) unobstructed view of the bay & bridge is from the vista at the top of the Marin Headlands that can be reached from Conzelman road!  It's definitely worth the 5min car ride (or 30-60' walk) to the top, and it's free (also awesome for viewing the perfect sunset).
author: Bryan I.

description:
Obviously this is THE tourist spot of San Francisco but for good reason. I definitely recommend that you take the time to walk the bridge (or bring workout clothes and run the bridge as I believe many locals were during). This allows you to appreciate the vastness of the bridge as well as the fantastic views.

The walk is about 1.7 miles each way. WEAR COMFORTABLE SHOES. I managed to make my feet bleed attempting the walk in uggs. I know, I clearly didn't think it through. 

Tip: Park a few "blocks" North by the lookout point for 4 hours of free parking.
author: Roxanne G.

description: The bridge was free for me to go on. So I road that baby over a few times. It didn't change my life or anything or make me weep, but the golden..eh.. sort of rust, red bridge was a site to see
author: Rachael C.

description:
A HAIKU REVIEW

Bridge of majesty
Spanning the cold San Fran Strait
Where is it?! (Dumb fog)
author: Jonathan S.

description:
The beacon of San Francisco. This what makes the city so great and grand, because of this amazing Golden Gate bridge (no, it's not made out of gold). The Golden Gate is a suspension bridge spanning the Golden Gate. This bridge is linked toward San Francisco Peninsula, to Marin County. The color of the bridge is officially an orange vermillion called international orange.
 
Everyone should take a stroll here on the bridge at least once in their lifetime. Great for families, children, friends, and romantic dates. 

San Francisco's world famous bridge, is often most photographed and said to be the most beautiful bridge in the world.
author: Jan P.

description: beautiful landmark. there's parking lots available on both ends of the bridge, along with cafes and shops for souvenirs and restrooms. there is no price charge for parking and walking the bridge. there's walk ways on both sides of the bridge that allows pedestrians and bikes. the distance from one end of the bridge to the other is roughly a little under 2 miles. the walk is on a nice flat, wide surface. I would recommend this experience
author: Kathy T.

description:
Here I am writing a review for a bridge! I used to have some clients out in Marin County. Driving home across the bridge with the evening fog rolling in is an absolute breathtaking sight! 

Now that I'm thinking about it, have you ever watched movies that show people driving across? I can't specifically remember which movie I was watching, but the person was leaving SF in the movie and was driving in the wrong direction! He was driving TOWARDS SF... gosh, get it right!
author: Christine P.

description:
BREATH-TAKING!

I was reading reviews prior to coming and everyone is right...how can you give it anything but five stars? This bridge is beautiful! Very touristy, but what else do you expect? EVERYONE wants to see this when they're in San Francisco. Now I'm not sure if I came here on a good day, but it was not busy at all. My boyfriend convinced me to walk across (by the way I'm VERY afraid of heights). I decided to walk faster than him so I could just get to the other side and feel safe again. The only problem is that about 20 feet away from the end of the bridge, they closed to sidewalk off, so your only choice was to turn around or jump off the bridge, or run into the traffic. I decided to turn around. I'm a little disappointed because my plan was to visit Sausalito and catch a cab back, but it's alright, I plan on coming here when visiting again :)
author: Shanel S.

description:
The GGB means so many things to me:
- its a gateway to the north
- its a symbol of the achievement man can make in harmony with our surroundings
- its an ambassador to the world, showing the wonders of our city
- its a welcome sign to the ships returning home, or coming to visit
- and it's just plain cool

Every time I drive across I am nervous because everyone is looking around while driving, even me.  And I grew up around here.

I've ridden across it's span on a bike, walked across it, explored underneath in on foot (areas now closed off), and sailed under it on a boat.  All things I would highly recommend doing even if you are a seasoned SF vet.

re member the time that they closed the bridge to let everyone walk across and there were so many people the span flattened out?  Boy were there some nasty comments in the Chronically after that day.  In my house we have a picture of the China Clipper flying over the bridge - as well as a few of my prints.

Love it, just love it.

So get on your bike (rent one if you need to) and ride across it.  IF you can, keep on going into Sausolito and take the ferry back.  It will be a day that you remember for the rest of your life.
author: Jeff H.

description: Bring a hat. It's so windy you're gonna need it to keep your hair under control.
author: Azaria O.

description:
I like the San Francisco bridge.  It's so nice to look at.  Pretty.  Especially when it's foggy.

Horrible to run on early in the morning.  It's cold as hell! My hands were freezing.  I couldn't even move them.  !!!
author: Emily S.

description:
A must see for iconic San Francisco but don't crowd with the tour groups at the northern end, just to get a half ass small angle photo of the bridge. 

If you have a car, drive down further after the bridge and stay right toward Fort Baker. You will see a hairpin right turn with more signs to the Fort. Follow the roads to the Bay Area Discovery centre and park. Or continue along the dirt narrow street to a hill and here you see spectacular uninstructed views of the bridge. 

The rest can't compare
author: Laura C T.

description: Rad! Go during the week though, the weekends are really crowded. Ride a bike over it instead. The bike riding side of the bridge is empty, so you can stroll and take in the view without the crowds.
author: Sandra s.

description: Amazing bridge! This bridge looks beautiful from afar as well as close up. Decided to take a walk on it. It was pretty foggy and cold and windy so make sure you bring jackets and hoodies and beanies just in case. If your lucky and you catch it  on a nice clear day you get to see beautiful views of the water and city.  Defiantly something you want to visit at least once. One side of the bridge is for walking and the other side you could ride a bike across. Next time I'll try renting a bike looks like fun.
author: Mayra M.

description:
BEAUTIFUL.

It's one of those places you have to vist simply because you've seen it in magazines, movies, etc.  The bridge is an iconic symbol for SF and California so of course we had to go.
author: DJ P.

description:
This was part of my 1 day in San Francisco tour.

I had a very limited time in San Francisco and this was the ONLY thing I didn't want to miss seeing on a one day trip around San Francisco.  San Francisco was on my bucket list if only for this structure alone.  I'm a big disaster movie lover and what disaster movie set in San Francisco does not have a shot of the Golden Gate Bridge in it?  

It was Pure Awesomeness sitting on the upper deck of an open top bus tour driving across with the cold wind whipping at your face, the beautiful moist and cooling fog ascending with the top of the bridge poking through and then the sudden smell of the pine trees once you reach the other side.  And all the time remembering all those wonderfully corny movies you have seen.  THE best hangover cure after a surreal night out with some awesome Yelp people.

A gateway to somewhere beyond those beautiful red gates to places I may never see.  Tantalizing and teasing.
author: Gina H.

description: I always enjoy driving the Golden Gate bridge and have stopped to take pictures many times.  It is just one of those awesome places. I know I will be back many more times as family and friends visit.
author: Kori M.

description:
We took a taxi up to the look out point right next to the toll booths.  The views are great and they have a path that goes down to Fort Point below.  We walked about 1/4 the way across the bridge and if we had more time I would have walked the entire distance.  We were lucky with the weather and it was not too windy  or cold.  

This is definitely a must do while in San Fran.  If you don't have a car you have to either take the bus or a taxi to get there since it is almost impossible to walk to the bridge from the city.
author: Zach P.

description:
You would think this 75 year old would lose some of her luster, but as one of the most recognizable landmarks on the West Coast, she still inspires and awes even long time locals. No wonder she is considered one of the marvels of the modern day!

We plan to walk it the next time we are in SF just to really take in her splendor!
author: Michele P.

description: Wow this bridge is amazing. It is more beautiful in person. We walked across it one way which took us 30 minutes and then another 30 minutes to walk back the other way. The view is something you have to see in person.
author: Anna M.

description:
REVIEW # 700
SOME HATER FLAGGED MY 700TH YELP REVIEW!!!   
We'll guess what.... Its BACK!!!

Biking the Golden Gate Bridge for the first time was amazing!   On Saturday morning (June 19th, 2010), I did just that!   An eight and half mile bike ride from Pier 39 to the Golden Gate Bridge to Sausalito.   This was a great opportunity to experience the power of nature across the ocean gap of San Francisco and Marin.  Yes, it was windy but the view from the Golden Gate is magnificent!  See our pics!!!  Thank you to Omar, Jay, Sonny, Bobby, Icky, Melissa, Nadia, Jackson, Will, Wendy, and the awesome James G for join our very own bike party across the Golden Gate Bridge!

What to bring for biking across the Golden Gate Bridge:
1. Helmet (protect yourself...it's just common sense).
2. Comfortable clothing and athletic shoes for biking.
3. Your own morning breakfast.   
4. Light jacket (it's going to be windy and chilly in some parts of the route)
5. Bring a backpack for light meal, snacks, and water - Stay energized and hydrated.
6. Repair kits / tools (just in case things go wrong).
7. Lock and cables (in case we need to make a long stop or lunch somewhere).
8. Bring cash and your ID.   Just in case you need to get something along the way or get pulled over. 
9. Digital camera with fresh batteries.
author: Walter P.

description: Breathtaking. Hope to return there soon. Gets a bit windy up there so take a light jacket with a hood attached. The views are amazing. The seals down below are quite entertaining!
author: Lisa H.

description:
My 300th Review.  I wrote this poem in high school, and my classmates called me a fraud, saying it must' have come from a magazine. LOL,the greatest backhanded compliment ever. In honor of my dad's recent passing, I thought I'd share it.  Flying over this bridge the first time was a significant change to our family decades ago. It was one memory I will never forget.  My parents left the country of their childhood, and into a new world.  Going to and leaving the Bary Area for his funeral re-kindled that great memory. And, my dad did all of the legal immigration paperwork then, and we were born American citizens. But oh, how I love this bridge even today.  And it saddens me to read the background of those who've jumped off this bridge to their death.  But it's still a rush for the rest of us to see it.

The Great Golden Gate
 by Will M.

Huge orange cables span over the bay
