Standing spectacularly in the day
Night lights so brightly bejewel the lanes
As fog drifts on glasses and window panes.
Cars trucks and walkers on concrete and tar
Gasp at coastal beauty both near and far
It's magic south to San Francisco.
And north to Marin through San Anselmo
The Bay Bridge buzzes to Oakland beyond
And west the Pacific, the unending pond.
You are the greatest bridge ever made
The eighth world wonder as displayed.
Yet there's one purpose it lives so shy
Sad lonely people go there just to die.
author: Will M.

description: Walked the bridge - scared of heights but it was breathtaking and totally well worth it. It's windy and cold and wonderful !
author: Kathy I.

description: I mean really it is a bridge what can you say about it? It is a famous destination for people to commit suicide. You can walk or bike across it which is kind of nice. I made the trip across for the first time early in the morning on a particularly foggy morning so it was not that busy. On my second trip across it was clear and a little later and it was pretty much the 7th level of hell with all the people standing in the middle of the path taking pictures and paying absolutely no attention to the people around them. As far as driving across I like that they have now automated this bridge because it allows people to get across faster. One thing I don't enjoy about driving across is that a lot of people have no idea where they are going so they are swerving lane to lane causing near accidents.
author: Patrick M.

description: What can I say that people don't already know?  It's a very beautiful landmark, and educational.  There are many stops where you can park and take photos and a nice and friendly visitor's center.  There are also picnic areas close by.
author: Yan W.

description:
We were in San Francisco, so of course we had to go see the Golden Gate Bridge. It is worth the drive to see it. If you would like to get a good picture during daylight take it from the San Francisco Viewing side and at night take it from the opposite side to get the optimum picture.
Lynn Rae Moore
Barry R Jones Jr
Adventure Bums
Get off the Path
author: Barry R J.

description: The Golden Gate Bridge is beautiful and majestic! BTW for those that are not aware (based on some of the reviews I've read), the bridge was never meant to be "gold", it gets its name because it crosses the the "Golden gate bay".  The bay gets its name because when the sun is setting it makes the bay waters appear to shimmer gold.
author: Sheila H.

description:
I visited San Fransisco in April 2009 for business.   I have to say, I did not bike, walk, or drive this bridge as others have; I did the typical stupid tourist thing and took a double decker bus.  It was one of those hop-on, hop-off tour busses that you can pick up down by Fisherman's Wharf (or in a lot of other spots in the city, actually). 

Two tips;
1) Go sit in the top/open part of the bus.  You get a 360 degree view and get to really get the full experience.
2)It's colder on the bridge (at least in Spring) than anywhere else.  I swear the temps dropped 20 degrees just while we were on the bridge. 

The good thing about the tour bus is that it goes over the bridge, then turns around and comes back.  If you missed it (for example, if it was foggy) or if you didn't take my #1 tip and were sitting inside the bus, you get a 2nd chance. 

I got lucky and was able to get several good views out over the water (the fog blows in and out rather quickly; keep your camera ready, or keep your eyes peeled).

Recommended.  If you don't go, everyone will ask you how you could have made a trip to San Fran and not seen the bridge!
author: Ken L.

description: The Golden Gate Bridge is one of the most iconic landmarks of the United States for good reason.  It is an engineering and architectural marvel that is aesthetically breathtaking.  Full appreciation for this structure can only be had by an on-site visit.  Traversing it by vehicle or on foot is an awesome experience.
author: Michael D.

description:
I'm a local so I've seen the Golden Gate Bridge over a billion times but it never stops being beautiful.

Now I've walked this bridge many times and I have biked it. I wish it was more like the Brooklyn Bridge (NY) where the ped/bike activities are in the middle of the bridge but its not. Also, the lanes aren't that wide so be careful. The railings on this bridge are short so YOU CAN fall off if you don't pay attention (tall bike riders on the ped side).

They have significantly improved the bike trail from the bridge into the city so you can bike across the bridge from Marin into the visitor center to Crissy Field and into the city. Its definitely an intermediate ride into the city. Kinda windy and creepy hearing the big rigs pass you but it is on a path.

There are many visitor areas that can be accessible to the bridge. 
-The Presidio in the city has one where if you hike onto the path under the bridge (yeah you go under the bridge) you end up at the main center. 
-There is also the original visitor center that has a gift shop and piece of an old span but the parking there can be crazy and its metered.
- Or like me...you can park on the Marin side (exit Sausalito)  for free and walk on the bridge. 

Views of the Bridge:
-Or you can view the bridge up high and go on that same exit ...drive further and view it from the headlands. 
-Crissy Field
-Or of course Baker Beach (Pursuit of Happyness beach)

Either way, its a beautiful sight of nature, architecture, engineering marvel and a perfect view of the city...with clear sky or a little fog.
author: Trishia P.

description: FINALLY! I got to see/walk on the bridge! I'm glad the sun was out too because most pictures I see [from friends] it's always gloomy there. We went on such a beautiful day no clouds and the sky was blue! Lovely spot to go to and loved being able to walk on it. A lot of people were friendly, they offered to take our picture quite a few times.
author: April B.

description:
The best bridge in America! Its been awhile since I've walked on the bridge. Since I was a lil toddler in the 80s. I have photos to prove it. lol

I went here yesterday afternoon in a attempt to watch the blue angels show. It was a disaster. The planes occasionally flew by, but they looked like flys from across the bridge. A lot of tourist people in front of me. Posing with the peace sign and all(Yes, i did see some old ladys from Hong Kong stop other Non Asian people to take a photo with them).It was hilarious the reaction that those people had when asked at first. haha. 

The shaking while on the bridge is what got me all off centered. I am terrified of heights, so the shaking definitely got me a lil more spooked out. We left after about 2 hours squinting to see the planes fly from across the bay. 

At the end, I guess if you're a tourist then its a must to come here and take your picture on this iconic bridge. Other then that you're good to go....
author: Jeff C.

description: Anyone that has anything negative to say about this historical man made bridge has got some serious problems. Setting aside the heinous amount of people that visit this daily, I'd have to say its a must see for everyone whether you visit San Francisco once a year or you've been there once, it really is an amazing site to see! It's nice to sort of just take a look from the bridge across the bay to Alcatraz Island and think about the history of this wonderful city. Really wished I could afford to live here, but until then Los Angeles will have to suffice, and I do love my city.
author: Hailey Z.

description:
i grew up with the Golden Gate bridge hanging above my bed.

We moved all the time - when I was a kid. But one constant  - was the countless massive pictures of San Francisco (my birth place)  and more specifically Golden Gate bridge - hanging in my numerous always changing rooms as a kid.

I was so proud of those pictures. They represented some semblance of a solid "home". Somewhere that I could call mine. 

Once I moved back to San Francisco - a little after college, I used to revel in the fact that I could see the bridge on my walk to the bus stop.

And not too much later - it became my biggest obstacle - as I learned how to drive.  My first driving trip by myself - was a nervous trip across that regal red beacon. 

It was one of my proudest moments - the day I pushed through San Francisco's low hanging fog - draped elegantly on the bridge's reaching high beams - into the most glorious open armed embrace of the North Bay sun. 

All by myself.

And as I drove back by myself, with sweaty palms - clutching the wheel tightly; the dusk now hiding her firm red structure, she somehow seemed even more vivid. More pronounced. Different.

I saw the bridge through childhood eyes. In that brief moment of silent bridge driving.

I saw the "home" above my bed again.
author: Jessica T.

description:
For my 1,000th review, I can think of nothing more appropriate than an architectural model that was built in shorter time than it took me to reach 1,000 reviews. 

Take a walk to see the city view unfold with each step while catching a glimpse of the emerald waters several hundred feet below. There are several cut outs that let you lean over the bridge so you can take picture - take advantage of it and get some beautiful shots of Alcatraz, the city, and the entire Bay Area. 

Definitely something everyone should see at least once in their lives. The bridge is about a $20-25 cab ride from most places near the wharf or north city.
author: Jake K.

description:
I walked on the bridge after walking a couple of miles and hiking on a trail LOL

This is what happens when you let an athletic friend plan a trip. They will decide to park as far away as they can get away with. Lovely!

Nice bridge! A true tourist and must see spot in the Bay area. I wish they didn't allow bikers on it though... but that's another story. 

Glad I finally made it here. Five Yelp stars!!!
author: Rain F.

description:
There's a scene in the movie version of  "Interview With The Vampire" where Christian Slater's character is jumping into his car on Market , hauls ass, and two seconds later he's on the GG. Come on now! Even if you're right at the toll plaza it takes like 5-10 min to get on the bridge. If you're travelling from the other side of town, getting to the GG is one long , sometimes convoluted drive. To this day I still don't know the "optimal" way from say, SOMA. Depending on traffic conditions, I usually try to find my way to Franklin and then snake my way  to Bay, then hit the bridge. Ok I'm digressing.

As hard it is to get to sometimes, it's definitely a must do. For a long time I thought it was too touristy for me and on constant suggestion from my Mom, I finally decided to give in and take the walk across with her. It was a beautiful day, I had a lot of time to kill, and honestly it had been a while since I had a chance to bond with my Mother.

So we take the drive across the city and it turns out it's going to be a clear day.  As clear as it was, I knew it was going to be cold on the bridge, and make no mistake, I was prepared with the requisite jackets and pullovers . You know who makes mad bank in SF? The dude that sells the "I heart SF" sweatshirts for God knows how much to the tourists that show up to the GG in their short sleeve polo shirts, khaki shorts and sockless loafers. Suckers! 

I must say that the group of people that assembled here was one of the strangest  and diverse I'd seen. I guess such a landmark would bring the tourists from every cross section of the world. My favorite was this huge bus that pulled up and unloaded a bunch of  Japanese tourists. I swear they had 3 cameras each, took a gazillion photos in like 5 minutes and then hopped back on the bus. Not sure they really "experienced" anything but they definitely will have a lot of pix that will substitute for memory.

So my Mom and I finally make the leisurely trek, caught up on things, and let the rest of the world move in slow motion around us. Not a bad way to spend a lazy Sunday afternoon.
author: Kim N.

description:
I love this bridge. Walking this bridge makes you feel so alive. The wind gusts and threatens to blow you off the edge, and the floor beneath trembles with you. It feels like the ground is about to give way, but you stay rooted. There's a sense of excitement walking here, feeling unsafe, and testing those boundaries.

The cold stings your skin, the wind destroys your hair and any sense of aesthetic dignity. But I love just closing my eyes here, clasp my hands around the red bars separating me and the sea, and feel the legendary giant rustle away. San Francisco. I'm in San Francisco, the city everyone knows. The city with its amazing history, its beloved people, its beautiful architecture, its liveliness.

I love this city.
author: Chia L.

description:
Breathtaking Bridge:
As a native, I have visited the Golden Gate Bridge many times over the years. Most recently, my cousin and her son visited me. Her son had never been in San Francisco before, so we had to take him to the GGB.

We were lucky to have sunny no fog weather so the views were spectacular. My nephew was impressed with the bridge and the view. He and his friend walked across while his mother and I stayed on the San Francisco side.

On lucky days like that one, you can see across the Bay to Sausalito and out to the horizon of the Pacific Ocean. We did not see any ships, but the ocean view more than made up for the trip.

I highly recommend this visit for natives and visitors alike. Just remember to bring a camera because you will be blown away by the sights. Remember to bring a warm jacket too because the strong wind may just blow you away too, but not in a good way!
author: Audrey C.

description:
On a beautiful day, the Bridge is majestic! Whether you are just driving through or catching a glimpse of it from across the bay, it is a beautiful awe inspiring site.

I've driven through on several occasions, but recently my husband and I decided to stop off on Vista Point. There are several view points but this one is easy to get to and relatively easy to park at. The parking is free if you don't mind sometimes waiting a little bit to get a spot. But you can stay as long as you like, enjoy the breeze and the Bridge and get a few photos in. 

After doing all of the above, we decided to walk across the Bridge, which is easy to do and safe. Just watch out for the bikers.

Enjoy!
author: Carol S.

description:
Before I went here, I thought "Eh, it's a bridge, how impressive can that be?"  But this bridge is truly impressive.  First off, the view is great, especially in the evening with the sun setting over the ocean.  Second, it's a beautiful structure apart from being a bridge, which is something I didn't appreciate until I got close up.  And third, it's something that amazed me with it's sheer size and the engineering challenges that must have been overcome to build a bridge in such a geographically-difficult area in the 1930's.  So I was glad I went.  

Note that it's a little difficult for tourists to get to by public transportation.  I planned ahead and didn't have any problems, but I saw plenty of confused tourists on the buses there and back.  Also, walking over the bridge was more than a little chilly, and I probably should have dressed a bit warmer.
author: Mike W.

description:
If you catch the bridge on a clear day, it's magnificent.  On a foggy day, not as much.

The trek across is only about 15-20 minutes at a leisurely pace. On weekends, if you're with a group, make sure to be mindful of the bicyclists riding by. They tend to be a little impatient if you're not aware of your surroundings.
author: Gina J.

description: An awesome landmark of California. Lovely place to visit and amazing site to see from either end of the bridge. Beauty surrounds Golden Gate Bridge, a great place to hang out at and have fun. Walking across the bridge is an amazing experience. I highly recommend that you try it.
author: Harpreet S.

description: I love the Golden Gate bridge, and the history to it all. I have gone for a walk, stroll, tour guide and showing family, and friends to many time to count. For me the experience is exciting, and never gets old. The view can be limited at different times, because of the San Francisco weather that changes so fast. The morning can be covered in fog, where the bridge is not visible at all. Then later in the after noon, its beautiful and clear. Then again within a half hour, you have a mist on you with fog rolling in so fast. But from land, air, being on the water, or from the lookout area, its a must to see! The beautiful bridge herself, I love so much! When you walk around the bridge area plan for at lease an hour, depending on how fast you walk. There are statues along the way, along with plaques explaining the history of the bridge. You can see an area, where it shows strands of the actual cable used on the bridge, bundled to suspend the road. I have enjoy walking, and exploring the whole path areas around the bridge also. Remember to dress in layers because being close to the bay, usually can be windy and weather changes from one extreme to the other. San Francisco Bay is known for great sailing, because of Bay winds. The Golden Gate Bridge is a beauty, once you see her you will never forget her. Enjoy your memory, and come back when you can.
author: Nancy D.

description:
I love this bridge. Lots a places to take scenic pics and a great way to get some exercise on a vacay. 

The BF and I walked it back and forth to work up our dinner appetite. It was great! I have driven across it a dozen times, but you need to walk it at least once.
author: Bianca W.

description:
I've been over this bridge before, but never huffing and puffing on a bike. I hadn't actually ridden a bike since maybe 2005 (well, before this weekend). But I did the 8-mile run from Fisherman's Wharf to Sausalito, and the best part was biking across the bridge. 

I mean, it was the whole point of happily inflicting a sore ass on myself.* 

The day was gorgeous, which only made the experience even more, to be corny, *magical*. There's nothing like awkward wobbling high above the Pacific when you're being buffeted by a strong breeze. That and cool views of San Francisco and Sausalito. 

As good as it gets. 

*guttersnipes need not apply.
author: Ki G.

description:
Yes. The Bridge is beautiful. 

Majestic. Breathtaking. Inspiring.

 A monument for billions.

The problem is this is only the case if you WALKING the bridge.

Traffic sucks.

The tolls are about $2 above highway robbery.

The lanes are a death trap waiting to happen. Am I the only one who makes it a point not to drive in lanes closet to opposing traffic? I mean... 

I think that makes sense considering the only thing protecting you from a 2000 pound vehicle crashing into you head on are some  flimsy plastic cones in the ground... lol 

And when you add in the distractions of all the sexy women jogging the bridge, you can see how dangerous it is... lol

So... If you want to see history. 

Check out the BLUE ANGELS. 

Watch the Navy sail under the bridge during FLEET WEEK... 

Or commit suicide...

Then this is the spot for you...

BTW... Be sure to use the restroom BEFORE you decide to cross the bridge by foot. There aren't any restrooms on the bridge. And the only restrooms the bridge has at the toll plaza and rest stop ALWAYS have lines about 20-30 people deep...

You've been warned.... lol
author: Black K.

description:
It's a classy mofo!

hey look They're repainting it.

Oh shit, that's right they're always painting it! Now that's JOB security!
author: Darren M.

description:
One of the main reasons why San Francisco is considered my favourite city in the U.S. The people who drive to work over this bridge are quite the lucky ones. 

When I move from Vancouver, I am going to live in San Francisco, whether its for a little while or a long time. 

Equally beautiful during the cool foggy hours just before dawn, when there are barely any souls around. Or during mid-day amongst the frenzy of people snapping shots of their loved ones. The views of the city from the north end are unparalleled to anywhere else in town. 

Sure its a bit touristy, but it has many reasons to be. Its not to be missed when one is in San Francisco.

:)
author: P G.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is one of the most beautiful bridges in the world.  It is an architectural and stylistic wonder of the modern world.  There is so much lore and interest tied to this one bridge, that it's truly one of the greatest landmarks in the united states.

Named after the opening from San Francisco Bay to the Pacific, the bridge crosses the Golden Gate with such majesty that it takes your breath away.  There's something about this bridge that is almost mystical.  Perhaps it's the color and the rumor that it takes five years to paint the bridge and once completed the process is started again.  Or maybe it's the number of people who have jumped to their death from the bridge (9/10 times on the Pacific side).  It could be that it represents the technology of the greatest country in the world.  Either way, it's prominence in San Francisco and the US cannot be ignored.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Pretty cool.

It's no Brooklyn Bridge, though.
author: Peter D.

description:
Man over nature!  One must experience this engineering marvel from as many perspectives as possible: from the Marina, from Pac Heights, from Marin, on foot, on a bike, on a ferry, and yes even in a car.

You may hate the automobile traffic on the approaches and the ever present backups at the toll booths, but it is a small price to pay for traversing this span.  You will love this bridge - it doesn't suck like most other things in life.  It has soul and will remind you that you have one too.
author: John V.

description:
It feels kind of pompous to review a landmark like The Golden Gate Bridge.  I mean, who am I, Henry David Thoreau?  People come from all over the world to view this iconic structure and it's hard to imagine how you can capture it's essence in words, so I'm not going to try.

I will say - it's definitely worth seeing.  Like any landmark you're accustomed to seeing only on TV or in movies (from "Charmed" to "The Rock" to "Full House) and photographs, nothing beats a real life viewing.  It's red, it's massive, it's beautiful (especially on the many foggy days in SF); it is actually almost breathtaking.  

What I will not say is that you should bike or walk across the bridge.  I am a chickenshit, I'll admit it.  It's all I can do not to have a panic attack of epic proportions just *driving* across the bridge.  Being over a huge mass of ocean with land seemingly so far away and only a bridge between me and the cold Pacific is not my idea of fun times.  Visions of the earth swallowing me and other Golden Gaters a la "2012" flash through my head.  You can take your adventurousness and shove it!   The next time I want to visit Marin, I'll have to be a  passenger, heavily sedated.
author: Keisha A.

description: I can finally say I've walked across the Golden Gate Bridge!  It's 1.7 miles, windy, and wonderful photo opportunities. After the first tower, there's less of a crowd which is always a plus in touristy places.  I'd definitely advise arranging a way back if you don't plan on walking it again. Luckily there's a rest stop with clean bathrooms (clean enough to drop your new iphone and fish it out) at the end with random taxis showing up. Definitely worth it!
author: Nicole V.

description:
I'm not a sappy gal by any means. Breakups? Pfff. Hallmark Cards? Barf-o. Weddings? Point me to the open bar. But the *strangest* things bring out the waterworks...

Things that make me cry:
Being away from my dog.
Not fitting into my jeans.
Old eps of Full House (specifically when Papouli died).
Armageddon and Braveheart, amongst others

...and the Golden Gate Bridge.

Yes, the GGB literally opened up my flood gates. I'd been to San Francisco a handful of times for work (which is also a pleasure), but each time I failed to make it to the GGB. Does it really exist? Is is just a myth? Where the heck do they house this mammoth bridge in such a small city? I can't see it from my hotel room!  

...And then a friend brought me out here after last call. To say it was magnificent is the biggest understatement I could ever utter. As soon as I spotted it from a far distance, I shouted and pointed (in an alcohol-induced excitement) and started to cry. And the tears wouldn't stop! What in the ham sammich is going on here?

But the more I sat there and studied it, the more I saw why. It kinda puts you in your place. It was here well before me, will remain well long after - with God's grace - it's historic and knows so many stories, good and bad; it's bold and strong, beautiful and inspiring, and well, red. 

On this particular night, we parked at the nearby park right off the bridge, grabbed a bench and enjoyed a long, 3am convo. I'll never forget it.
author: Farrah A.

description: This is a great place to be. The Gateway to SF or the North Bay. The bay bridge is the work horse of the bay but the Golden Gate is the landmark. This bridge is amazing great to drive, walk, or bike across. I recommend stoping at all the vista points and check out the great views.
author: Sean G.

description: See it.  Drive it.  Walk it.  Touch it. Kiss on it.  Bike on it.  Camp under it (Kirby Cove).  Just don't jump off it.
author: Ron L.

description:
It has been many years since we visited. This bridge is such a Landmark that is a must see and drive over. The views are stunning, the bridge is a bit scarey as it is so large. It was so refreshing to drive and look at the beautiful scenery. The skyline is picturesque, the bay simply beautiful.

As a tourist we did appreciate the speed level on the bridge. It did make me feel better going over it, not having to deal with speeders driving 80 plus. We could not stop to take pictures because it was raining good the day we drove over, but looking at the fog covering the city with the rain pouring down was still just as beautiful. 

This is a great bridge, that is amazing to see, a must for all!
author: MICHELLE C.

description: One of the larger tourist attractions you must do when in SF I suppose. Dress warm as it gets very very windy. Hopefully the day you go isn't foggy and you get a great view of the bridge itself. It's quite an extraordinary piece of architecture.
author: Jason F.

description:
I think you kinda have to visit the Golden Gate bridge if you want to say you've traveled to San Francisco... even if you can't see the bridge because it's always so foggy! 

Brought a friend here since it was her first time in SF. It was actually a nice day in the city (rare), where it was sunny in the Sunset district, Richmond district, Castro, Downtown, etc... EXCEPT at the Golden Gate Bridge. Literally one minute away, it was be sunny, but as you approach the bridge, it's just all fog to the point where you can't see anything. Definitely come on a nice day, but if you're on a time crunch, you gotta do what you gotta do.
author: Michelle L.

description:
what a beautiful bridge. Since I have some family that live out of the area, i always feel like i visit this bridge with them :) 
when it's a nice day out, you don't see more beautiful views from here! It can be cold so dress warm but everyone should try to walk this bridge at least once in their life if they can!
author: Brittany E.

description: Total scam to grab people who are computer illiterate.  The revenue must have gone up 100% with this scam.  I paid online like most will, but what a deal for others who don't or can't figure it out.  Another way for the city to make money like the charge for a paper bag.  Beautiful city, terrible idea.
author: Josh D.

description: OK. What can I say. I'm not saying anything more. I just like this thing!
author: Kislev A.

description:
Traffic might be bad but its worth every moment to cross over this historic bridge.

Great views on a clear sunny afternoon and if you visit in the winter you will likely see the bridge covered with thick fog.

Worth the trip.
author: Jason A.

description: And I thought la was a parking-unfriendly place. Sf is even worse. Very great view though, could try next time to park far away and take the metro here.
author: Bathony C.

description: Friendly and not rushed personal service by friendly staff.   Even verified directions.  ;)
author: Greg D.

description: This bridge is gorgeous! Yes, I'm describing a bridge. We've been on both sides of it several times and had only ever driven over it. Well... I recently made my "30 Things To Do Before 30" List and RUNNING the Golden Gate Bridge was on there. So I went up to San Fran this weekend to mark another thing off of my list. It was the most gorgeous Saturday afternoon. The weather was perfect! The bridge was not fogged in. We parked on the San Fran side, for free! :) I turned on my Garmin watch and off I went. 1.7 miles each way. They need a "running" lane - the pedestrians and bicyclist are annoying as f**k!!!! This is certainly not the place you'd go for anything other than a casual run because no one understands - pedestrians to the Right, bikes to the Left. It is a total cluster! but you can't beat the views. It is by far one of the most stunning runs I have had. The Sausalito side is beautiful, although you have to pay to get back across if you drive over - I highly recommend crossing over and exploring from that end.
author: Candace L.

description: This is a great place to look at the view and sightsee. A must do before you die lol jk. I came here a few times before but my mom and siblings never been here so I suggest we take a walk across the golden gate bridge for experience. It was cold and slightly foggy when we got here. It was sunny at first but the wind and fog started creeping in. We took a stroll with the kids took a family picture and afterwards we went down so we could look across the ocean and let everyone bask in the ocean breeze. I would recommend coming here in SPRING/SUMMER for a warmer experience. I also like how they put the biker lane on the other side because before we had to walk and there would be bikers zooming through it made it unsafe, but they fixed that problem and its safer to walk on the bridge without getting ran over by a biker. Theres also an area where they built so kids and adult could just chill and read the exhibition area. Its pretty neat the place has change with and upgrade but the same bridge experience. So if your looking for something to do come and walk the goldengate bridge check out the great view watch the cars go zooming thru on the highway and just take a stroll.
author: Mary S.

description: Most amazing bridge in America!  Spectacular views and such a beautiful scenic drive.
author: Robyn H.

description:
there's a reason it's the most photographed bridge in the world...

during sunrise to afternoon, the sunlight is harsh on your eyes and pictures because of the reflection of light from the bay
author: Cameron M.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is my 2nd favorite landmark that I have seen to date, with the Mutianyu section of The Great Wall of China being first.

I saw the bridge for the first time in 2008 and I nearly cried. I remembered the time I was just a little girl watching Full House and dreaming of seeing that landmark. And where I grew up, that was looked up as a "dream" to live somewhere else or to travel. Though my individual family never had such life views with limits, many kids growing up in a poorer community have that view. If I would have mentioned that I wanted to see this bridge as a child in school, for example, I would have been laughed at. 

It's a visual masterpiece from the detail of the rivets to the cables to of course its colour. I love how the temperature changes to a crisp cool when you walk towards the middle of the bridge, even amidst the nasty heat wave that was occurring during my 3rd visit this past weekend.

It's a pleasure to walk the bridge as you can create photographs from a different perspective than the from one of the viewing areas at the end of the bridge. One thing to note is that it will be very LOUD as the traffic is always heavy. A semi passed by as I walked with my bestie and we nearly went deaf. Traffic was heavy every time I visited so that is something to note if you are headed to Sausalito, for example.

It really is a beauty and I will never tire of photographing it. I look forward to seeing it and walking it again.
author: Trudy H.

description: Beautiful historical landmark. I was able to take a uber to the Goldengate bridge. He was able to drop me off in a location where I was able to take pictures, enjoying the weather and purchase anything from the gift shop. There's lots of people biking and running that are in the area. Be careful with the bike area, it is colored off so that you don't get hit!
author: Alexandra Linette S.

description: I wil forever be in love with this bridge. Especially on a clear day which is rare.  Even when #karlthefog shows up, he's always a must whenever you visit SF.
author: Criselle O.

description:
I live in Oakland for a year and not one did I bother to really check out this icon of the SF area.  Funny how when things are nearby, they're out of sight and out of mind.  Flash forward to 4 years later; I was back in town for the holidays visiting friends and being an amateur photo enthusiast, I had one mission for a beautiful Fri afternoon...shoot the bridge from bother the north and south ends. 

One nice thing about the bridge is they have made it pretty tourist friendly.  With a few parking lots on both ends, you can park if its not busy and walk the entire length of the bridge on either the Pacific Ocean or Bay facing sides, taking in the amazing vistas of the city and the bay.

The only downside I can say is access to the bridge from the city end cannot be done entirely from freeways.  For out of town tourists, be warned, the 101 freeway will turn into local roads forcing you to drive thru several blocks of city streets before it turns into freeway again leading to the bridge.  If you're on a tight schedule and plan to drive or take a tour bus there, be aware of this.
author: Ed K.

description:
Beautiful bridge. It's nice you can walk over it. The bridge and the area around it will be crowded though, so you might need to be a little patient when trying to get a good picture. 

Parking spots available nearby, walking and biking trail included. I believe this is a bridge everyone should see at least once in their lifetime.
author: John Y.

description:
This is a pretty great place to visit. I've been here three times and each time has been great. Even the time where the bridge was shrouded in fog was cool.

I highly recommend driving to Sausalito (going the long way around) and seeing the bridge from the north side. Then drive south across the bridge and enjoy the park and gift shop. Driving north across the bridge from San Fran is often congested.
author: Southern W.

description:
The plan was set. A walk across the bridge was suggested as a means of helping the body deal with the stupid amount fo food and booze that was surely to follow in the upcoming week. 'We'll be good so we can be bad' was something like the phrase that was used. 

The only problem with our plan (us being me and Annie D) was that we (she) miscalculated the distance between the bridge and our hotel. So we walked from Howard St to the bridge, over the bridge and three quarters of the way back... poor, poor feet. 

So normally, this would just be a case of ouchy feet, but with me being the palest of pale Scottish folk, and it being mildly sunny outside, resulted in my face looking kinda like the same colour as the Yelp banner... ouch. 

This aside, the views were just spectacular. It also gave me the opportunity to say 'Welcome to the rock'over and over again in my best Sean Connery accent. Oh how i chuckled. 

This is the movies. This is all the crappy shows I watched growing up. This is me seeing it in the flesh. I was happy. Burnt, but happy.
author: Chris D.

description:
5 stars for being one of the longest lasting suspension bridges ever, for surviving a couple major earthquakes, and for never failing to be stunning and spectacular. 

If you  choose to cross going south into San Francisco, make sure you've got $6.00 in cash. Stick to the right lanes since they're the ones that take cash. You can get a Fastrak that you can pay a cash value onto or connect it to your bank account and then you've only gotta pay $5.00.

The bridge isn't only for cars, on the Southeast side, there's a pavilion that offers tours which talk about bridge history, there's some really neat interactive elements that show you how the bridge was designed to withstand things like earthquakes, and of course, you can always walk or bike over for some of the most stunning views of SF and the Pacific Ocean. 

It's always awesome to be on the bridge when I ship passes under too!
author: Lily K.

description:
When you visit SF, then this is the place that you want to visit and take a photo of. It's iconic SF, along with Fisherman's Wharf and the hilly streets.

Amazing on a foggy day, amazing on a clear sunny day.

Amazing to drive across and up to (especially from the Marin county side imo), amazing to bike across and amazing to walk across.

Having had many friends visit over the past 18 months, I've been to the bridge many times and it's still exciting(ish) to me. There's really nothing like it.

It takes me back to my first visit in the early 80's, wanted to walk across it but my parents shot me down. Got halfway across in the 90's and finally made it all the way in the 00's!

Ahhh the GG bridge.
author: Nick L.

description: Its funny to watch people who do not know how to pay the toll. Haha The bridge is cool though.
author: Justin R.

description:
I can totally understand why people choose this spot to end it all. I mean, if your going to jump off a bridge, why not choose one of the recognizable bridges in the country?

The Golden Gate Bridge is a really cool structure that offers a walking/biking path as well as 6 traffic lanes. It does cost a few dollars to cross into the city by car. Walking is free. You do have to watch out when walking, some idiots try to fly by on bikes even with all of the people. The crowd really thins out about 1/3 of the way across. We were lucky enough to see a cyclist get a ticket from a cop on a bicycle for speeding. It was hilarious. 

If you go to San Fran, you have to cross the bridge! We parked at Crissy field (for free) and walked along the coast and across the bridge, but be prepared - it's a about 7 miles round trip from the far end of Crissy field, and the wind can be pretty fierce over the Bay. I can't imagine climbing up those cables to paint this thing with that great primer color...

Fun fact: did you know the Golden Gate was name after the Golden Horn in Istanbul a couple of years before gold was even discovered in CA?
author: Kurt C.

description:
It was nice going across BUT YOU BETTER HAVE CASH OR COIN TO PAY THE TOLL. WE DID NOT WE ONLY HAD CREDIT CARD. SO THEY SAID THEY WOULD BILL US.         THEY BILLED US 31.00 DOLLARS 6 DOLLAR TOLL AND 25 DOLLAR PENALTY THIS IS BS. 
        WE WILL NEVER GO BACK ACROSS IT AGAIN EVER!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Jeremy N Phyllis R.

description: Absolutely awesome!! It's so much better seeing it in person.
author: Chris R.

description:
A lot of people mistake the bay bridge with the Golden Gate just because it's near downtown near the skyscrapers. When I walked here twice, I believe, up to the first tower I felt really fortunate to live in a city where everyone wants to be. It has survived many earthquakes most disturbingly many suicides have occurred here.  
It is free to walk it and it is difficult or at least very confusing when coming from downtown SF. 
It gets windy here and very cold, I don't mind because I love this type of weather. 
When the Queen Mary 2 passed under it, it was beyond beautiful. 
Very iconic image of the state of California as well as the U.S.A. even the world.
author: Nadav M.

description:
A San Francisco landmark & must see on any trip to the bay! 

If you're visiting San Francisco you must drive, walk, bike or boat at the Golden Gate Bridge! It's bright red color cuts through the fog and shines in the sunlight. It's the perfect backdrop for photos and perfect for taking in the city!
author: Tara F.

description: I love bridges, and this is one of my favorites.  Being a 5th generation northern Californian, anytime I see images of the Golden Gate, I just think of home.  Not sure when I'll get out there again, but I can always find an excuse to drive across.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Breathtakingly gorgeous.

I was determined on this trip to NOT be kitschy, to forge my own path to discovering this wonderful city, but there are some reasons that some tourist spots are, well, touristy. "It's my very first trip here," I thought to myself. "How can I NOT visit the Golden Gate Bridge?!"

I couldn't contain my excitement as we approached the bridge in my brother's truck that Saturday morning. I'm such a tourist when it comes to pictures, so I started snapping away. I was like a giddy little kid pointing and talking about how symmetrical and fantastic and how, well, red it was!

When we finally crossed to an area across the bridge that people can park and get out, I stepped into the sunniest, clearest, and crispest winter air that morning. The short stone wall and sidewalk all along an edge that looked over to the bay was a perfect view of the city, the bridge, and the darling sailboats in the light blue bay. Every now and then there were little gusts of wind whipping around which made the experience of visiting the Golden Gate Bridge that much more energizing. I could also see people walking, jogging, and biking across that thing. I was really envious of the people biking across it. Next time...

I felt at complete peace. Days, places, and moments like that automatically conjure up reflection, meditation, and joy.

I'm totally content that I jumped on the bandwagon with this one. I came on a Saturday morning about 11:00 am, but my day was packed with outdoor activities my brother had planned out, so I only spent about half an hour here. I really wish I had had more time, but there'll be more trips, you can count on that.
author: Alison A.

description:
I'd give you 5 stars because you open a portal from Crissy Field to Marin Headlands =)

... but you get 4 stars because your automobile toll fees are $$$$ =(
author: Victor V.

description: My husband, baby, and friends walked almost the entire bridge. It was amazing. The views were spectacular, the winds were strong, and the memories are everlasting. This was by far my favorite part of our trip to SF. I would definitely want to revisit the Golden Gate Bridge and walk it again. It was tough finding parking. Probably would be best to go very early, maybe beat the crowds, if that is even possible. We went late, around 1pm and the traffic was horrible! And trying to find a parking spot were nerve wracking. Almost everyone is aggressively driving and scoping out possible parking spots. But once you find a spot and start walking on the bridge....what a beaut!
author: Suzy B.

description:
The reverently historical Golden Gate Bridge: a technical masterpiece that can only be described in superlative terms. The hallmark of superior engineering, it is an impressive sight that stays in your mind like a captured photograph. 

As you drive across the bridge, just take in the magnificence of the work which is a gorgeous commitment of man's colossal creativity. 

The vista points that surround the bridge provide sensational views that make it a great sight to capture this eye-catching orange-red suspension bridge photographically. 

It is an alluring spectacle that is truly marvelous anytime of the day. Dress in layers as this place can get chilly due to the elevation. No visit to San Francisco is complete without visiting this marvel.
author: Tina A.

description:
Seeing this in person is breathtaking. It's beautiful and humbling. 
As a tourist you find yourself taking picture after picture, not being able to look any other way. 

Needless to say this is a must when visiting San Francisco
author: Greshka P.

description:
C'mon! You gotta give up the 5 stars for the grandest and most recognizable structure on the West coast. It's always so awe inspiring just driving on the bridge. This is the icon that exemplifies the San Francisco Bay Area. Remember, it's free going North to Sausalito. Coming back into town you'll have to pay the toll.

An obvious "must" for anyone who's never seen it in person.
author: Brian A.

description: In a boat sailing under it, dauntingly wonderful. Looking at it from any viewable point in San Francisco, iconic. View from the Marin Headlands, arguably the best views. Driving on it.....meh it's alright.  The wonder of the GGB is definitely in its presence and not in it's function.
author: Melissa R.

description: Beautiful view of the ocean.  I have biked across it several times on the bike/foot path.  This is definitely one of the things you have to see when you visit San Fransisco.
author: Milke A.

description: Nice place to go if you want to get away. You can rent bikes at the golden gate park and just bike to the bridge or park near by and bike around the area.
author: Lizzeth M.

description: Well let's see from 2000 to 2007...i flew over the Golden Gate Bridge coming into SFO international airport  about 48 times and let me just say i don't ever get tired of seeing it. There are many bridges in California and the world for that matter...but none compares to the Golden Gate bridge that sits in the bay. I have driven over it...walked on it...and i have photo's you definitely need to see. It is beautiful during the morning, noon, and it looks it's best at night from the hills in San Francisco. It is a true wonder of the world and it's is definitely something you should put on your bucket list. Eat, Drink, and be Merry my friends!!!!!
author: Andre E.

description: How can you not love the golden gate!!  A sight to see... Great back drop for sunsets.  Walk, run or bike the bridge.  Or drive ... This bridge doesn't take payments they will mail you but just in case make sure you past online to avoid penalties
author: Sandra S.

description: Simply Amazing.
author: Sal M.

description: It's a must see if traveling to San Francisco. I would highly suggest renting a bike and bicycling across the bridge to get an appreciation for this man made monument. The grounds area (touristy) is very well-maintained and for once it was nice to not have the bums of San Francisco polluting the enjoyment of a vacation. It's just a bridge so it's hard to break out 5 stars but since it's impressive and very well maintained I've gotta drop 4 stars in the bucket. Check the weather before you come, fog typically covers the view but the locals say around 1 o'clock it usually clears up nice enough to see this magnificent view. The weather is pretty calm at the visitors center but up on the bridge it can be quite windy and chilly so bring a sweater just in case....
author: Jay M.

description:
What an icon! 

Good idea: Walk across the bridge and walk back. 
Great Idea: Bike across and explore the northern area of the bridge 
Amazing Idea: Bike from fishermen's wharf, stop at the southern fort area of the bridge for lunch, bike across it and explore the northern end! 


-A must see area!
author: Bryce A.

description: I LEFT MY heart in San Francisco!  Now who could not give this Bridge a ten! Everything I see it, I think of my father who loved this bridge. I truly miss him.
author: Lucy H.

description:
For those of you biking or walking over the bridge, take earphones! The bridge is really noisy and I found the noise and constant thumping to give me a headache!

I quite loved the view, both the viewpoint and the view from the bridge. All gorgeous and a spectacular reminder of the complexity of engineering and the importance of art and harmony in our lives.
author: Michael J.

description: Ah yes, The Golden Gate Bridge, you can't help but be in awe when visiting this iconic bridge! it has such stellar views of the City by The Bay! You don't have to be a great photographer to take good picture - every angle and every view is captivating. There is just something magical about being here that you just feel at peace. For all you first timers in the Bay Area, you need to come here just to admire the view. I've defintely crossed this one off my bucket list!
author: Monthy C.

description:
We had to drive from Marin to SF and decided to use the GOLDEN GATE BRIDGE. 

Not much traffic at 8:15am on a Saturday, we stayed in the far right lane, and used my fasttrak for payment (highly recommended).

This was such a nice bridge, we took it again on the way home, If you are in SF and need to get to Marin, look no further than the GOLDEN GATE BRIDGE!
author: Mark C.

description: No landmark in the world can compare to the Golden Gate Bridge. This is one of the few rare 5 star reviews I'll ever give out. Words can't describe my respect for this masterpiece. The iconic color coupled with the blue water, THE FOG, and San Francisco in the background is simply the most beautiful view in the world.
author: Kev N.

description:
The most photographed place in California. 

Every few years I walk across it forgetting how loud the freeway is and how many people there are doing just as me but its always worth it. 

The best time to cross it is 45 minutes before the sun rises over the city on a warm day. There are only about two days a year this is possible but I promise you will never forget it.
author: Justin S.

description: Heck yeah I rode my bike all the way to the Presidio and half way across this baby. Such a cool experience, even if it was a bit foggy! Definitely check this out, biking and walking across are so much fun!
author: Sam F.

description: Walking the Golden Gate Bridge is a definite must do when in San Fran. Aquatic Park and the beach nearby is a great place to hang out on a nice day too. Only negative is the hostile & angry bikers. Some day I am going to nail a few in ass with my sons paint ball gun.
author: Annie P.

description:
Went on the bridge, found it to be too windy, quite large and painted like a whore. once i got across i was told there is another bridge to the city any way so its like a total waste. The view of the city was ok, but made the city look funny. We were glad to get the fudge outta marin though, that place sucks, especially out on the coast. I was like, "whats up with that?" Oh well, thats san francisco, the kid rock of cities.
Right?
jm
author: Jordan M.

description: So this is it! This is what makes San Francisco so special. For this ICONIC Bridge, I have moved to SF from London and New York City (well not really) This is a symbol of San Francisco, I spent a long time resenting this Bridge (quite frankly I believe that there are MUCH nicer ones around the world though none in Red) but the views from the Bridge are lovely, EVEN the FOG is lovely. I'd love to see it on a boat from the approach side of the Ocean!
author: Julian I.

description:
Such a beautiful, iconic bridge - I'm awestruck whenever I cross it. 

It's going through some changes lately such as no more human toll takers, but I think it has helped with traffic. I'll be interested to see how the bill for crossing comes.
author: Nicole P.

description:
Running across this bad boy is exhausting.

But it's really fun - especially when you're dodging all the tourists and running around them and then passing them on the way back.

I love you Golden Gate Bridge, and I cry EVERY single time you collapse in a stupid Hollywood movie.
author: Vanessa W.

description: The Golden Gate Bridge is the most beautiful and iconic bridge in California!!!
author: Don G.

description:
Best bridge ever!!!
one of the highlights of San Francisco!!
You have to go right away
author: Brad B.

description:
This is a gorgeous bridge, and walking across it and back makes a fun-filled day!

Not only is the bridge itself impressive, but so are the views of the city from the opposite side.  Great photo opportunities at the beginning, along the way, and even at its conclusion.  Nice boat watching, views of Alcatraz, and we even saw a porpoise and sea lion swimming in the bay!

Plus, there's free crisis counseling at various stations on the bridge.  Who could ask for more?
author: Lisa S.

description: Words cannot describe seeing this and driving on this masterpiece. Definitely a must do when visiting San Francisco.
author: P. C.

description: The new toll plaza process just seems so inefficient. The good points are that it cuts down on traffic, and you don't have to have cash on you. But I really wish they had made sure the system was ready before implementing it. Besides the inefficiency of the mail system, the website is a mess. The design and UI is off the charts horrible, and it is slooooow. The biggest problem by far though, is that the fee goes from 6 to 31 to 79(!!!) dollars. That is a scam. That is ridiculous.
author: Kim A.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is an American icon that must not be missed by any visitors to San Francisco. On a clear and sunny day, it is a perfect backdrop to a great picture either at Golden Gate Park or the Marina. Even on days where fog is prevalent in the bay, the bridge remains mysterious and majestic from afar. 

I took the bridge to Marin City and realized that one pays $6 only southbound trips going to San Francisco. My only regret was not walking on the bridge and stopping at Sausalito at the other side of the bay. I am sure the view would be magnificent.
author: Kwoky L.

description:
I stayed in San Rafael to spend the weekend visit Napa Valley and SF. My boyfriend and I drove to the city at night and we were expecting to pay a toll the old school way (we visited the city 2 years ago so that's how we remembered it worked). Instead, when we were approaching the control we saw a big sign saying DON'T STOP. NO CASH and we didn't know what was going on. Everything was so confusing so I decided to do my own search on Internet and I read on their site that we had 2 days to pay the toll online if we didn't want to get a ticket. We tried to do so but for some reason the page didn't let us to register our vehicle so we couldn't make the payment. We called the number that they provide on their site but guess what - they only work from Monday to Friday, and the next Monday was Labor Day so nobody would answer the phone either. It is ridiculous that they make this process so complicated!

The new system might be convenient for the people living in SF, but it is a pain for the rest of us who are visiting the city just a few days and we don't necessarily want to put our credit information online. At least they should keep one tollbooth with the option of paying with cash!
author: Yael S.

description: Never really understood what all the ballyhoo over this bridge is about. The Bay Bridge is a greater engineering accomplishment built at about the same time, and more beautiful especially with the backdrop of the city.
author: Albert H.

description: I was disappointed at first. You see the postcards & tv shows that make it look amazing...then it's not what it's cracked up to be lol. After the initial thoughts wore off, we enjoyed our taxi ride over the bridge. We wanted to walk it, but it was raining so we decided a taxi would be better. Great views, great pics.
author: Dawn R.

description:
Beautiful colorful bridge (that needs frequent paint jobs BTW) featured in so many TV shows (like "Charmed" and "Full House") and numerous movies, as well as placing first on The Travel Channel's "The World's Top Ten Bridges". One cannot think of the city of San Francisco without this bridge. A good sign of this fact is all the souvenirs.

On our most recent trip (april/may 2010) , my husband had one wish- to walk on this famous bridge. Parking was a challenge. There was lots of construction around, that our GPS system could not detect (this was a first for me too). I think we made it around three times until we found an open spot. Since there was a race going on, the parking fee was waived. There were numerous tour buses with tourists. There was a crowded public restroom. We stopped in the little gift shop as well. As with all souvenir shops, the prices were high, since it was situated at a landmark.

There were some vista points along the way where we stopped to take pictures. We walked along the entire length of the bridge but did it again. It was sunny and windy but it quickly got warm with all the activity. I had to shed the layers. There were lots of active people on both sides of the bridge- runners, walkers with dogs, and cyclists. There were lots of commuters as well. (I think that I've been on this bridge a handful of times when I lived here- not much.) It was nice to finally say that we did this- it's funny, how many things you do not do as a local.
author: Margret C.

description: One should drive over in a lifetime. The views are gorgeous, and you are even able to walk the bridge as well.
author: Angel H.

description: Bike the Golden Gate Bridge, not walk, not drive...bike! Plenty of bike rentals available at fishermens wharf area. It's a more enjoyable way to get to the end and back :)
author: Tracy C.

description:
The only thing not picture perfect about this bridge is being on it, stuck in traffic.  Otherwise, it's absolutely spectacular !

I do my best never to take it for granted so I can marvel at it each time I'm in its presence.
author: Barry Z.

description: SF landmark: a must-see.  There are several different viewpoints/photo opp spots (some involves crossing the bridge and paying toll).  It was chilly and windy that day so my friend dropped us off....i snapped some pix..and left.  On a busy day it's hard to even find a spot to take pix w/o tourists hovering around in your picture. :-)
author: Michelle H.

description: My favorite landmark of all time!! love it. It is a homing beacon to me and always will be. I love walking across it and staring at Alcatraz and Angel Island. AHHHH, so beautiful.....the city by the bay and it's wondrous span.
author: Cindi W.

description:
One of those must sees in San Francisco! Looking on from Crissy Field, it stands above the sea amidst the San Francisco fog with beauty.

It is an absolute must to actually cross the bridge whether it be by bike or walking. By car just does not give enough time to take in the many splendors the bridge offers to its visitors.

Whether it is walking or biking, it seems every few seconds there is a more beautiful view of the bridge then the last. In truth, that is the case because with anything beautiful,; the closer one approaches beauty the more mesmerized one becomes. it hold true for Golden Gate Bridge.

On the bridge be careful, stay to your lane. There are some very fast bikers coming across and are very inconsiderate. There are blind spots around the pillars so again be careful.

Stopping on the bridge, it is hard to ignore the glorious views of San Francisco. What a sight to behold! It is just one of those moments where you stand there with the crisp breeze hitting your very being and realize life is good.

Golden Gate Bridge quite simply is an eye catcher and not for its orange-red exterior.
author: Richard K.

description: I've driven across the Golden Gate Bridge and I've walked across the Golden Gate Bridge but my favorite way to cross the bridge is via bike. The bike lanes are tight so you have to have good control over your bike as there will most likely be many other tourists with bad control of their bikes trying to manage their way awkwardly across the bridge. I hope you have a fog free day when you visit the bridge. Yes, San Francisco is know for being a fog filled city but  the bridge and the surrounding views are best enjoyed on clear sunny days.
author: Oulie T.

description:
If you come to San Fransisco and dont cross the Golden Gate Bridge, it should be considered a crime!! 

The architect of the bridge is amazing, and the view is breathtaking as well. So much culture and history comes along with the Golden Gate bridge it really is mind bobbling. 

Beware of the fog, it tends to creep.
author: Jackie R.

description:
You've not lived till you've driven over this at 7am in the morning when the sun is rising and you have U2's "Beautiful Day" playing on the radio.

 Nuff Said.
author: Michael H.

description: I don't get to see this marvelous piece of engineering everyday, so whenever I get to see the Golden Gate Bridge or go over it, it's a big deal for this Hawaii native!!! Just seeing it from afar brings on a certain kind of charm, an almost strange fascination with it. When you actually get up to it, you marvel in it's sheer size and grandeur... Thinking back to a time when the workers actually made this bridge and just the sheer size of the project is awesome!! It is also an interesting fact how the bridge was built without touching Fort Point! It surely is a beautiful bridge and everyone who lives in San Francisco should be very proud of it... What a magnificent thing to see and drive over!!!
author: Dave F.

description: I was thinking of skipping this on my recent trip.  I've seen it plenty of times when I was younger but we decided to go anyways.  I would love to walk across this bridge one day but since we were pressed for time we decided to drive across and we drove to the top of the park area for a photo-op.  It is a beautiful bridge.  Im glad we stopped by.
author: Chrissie O.

description: I've gone over the "Golden Gate Bridge" northbound and I've gone over the "Golden Gate Bridge" southbound.  I sailed under her leaving California and I've sailed under her returning to California.  Still, it's just a bridge so I'll give it three stars.
author: Dwain C.

description:
Purdy.  

They won't have any toll takers starting in December 2012.  Appreciate those guys now, because we are moving into the future!  What's that, we already have?  FasTrak has replaced humans.  Woops.

If you miss the toll takers, just re-watch Coyote Ugly for John Goodman's performance as a toll taker.  *Golf clap*
author: Erika C.

description:
X my old reviews. 

This is an iconic Bridge! Photo ops like no other. Great views from many different angles whether it be Vista Point, the different height levels of Marin Headlands, from below on a boat or on the Bridge itself, AMAZING~!!!

As my gripes go in the previous reviews, it is the more expensive bridge to pay and at times.. traffic is horrible!!! 

Truly a must see when coming the the Bay Area. Crossing the bridge is fun and honestly it is captivating.
author: Roger A.

description:
This organization is evil. If you take a photo from the Golden Gate Bridge and post it on any online photo sharing site where your photos could be purchased as prints or downloads, they threaten to sue and fine you unless your remove the photo. 

They have adopted a very consumer-unfriendly and tourist unwelcoming policy!

While this applies only to photos taken from on the bridge itself, not around it, we believe this policy is ridiculous. 

Mary Currie, Public Affairs Director at the Golden Gate Bridge District is the person who contacts photographers threatening a $2,000. retroactive fine unless the photo is taken down from one's website. 

How she can live with herself in the employ of an organization that is as visitor unfriendly, is beyond me. 

The bridge district should really re-think this policy as it hurts rather than helps the local community at large and really sends the wrong message to visitors of the bridge as well.
author: John D.

description:
Coming here was the best part of my trip. I couldn't believe it was so beautiful. Yes, it's an engineering marvel and all that good jazz but coming from the flat lands of Florida where a steep hill won't kill you, it gave me chills to be so high up and look over the bay. If it weren't so windy and cold (for a Floridian), I would have come back just to see the sunset.

Warning: $6 toll going back toward San Francisco. Wow, I won't complain about the tolls in Orlando ever again.
author: Thea H.

description: I love the fact that I can rate the Golden Gate Bridge.  Ah yes, this is the grand dame of bridges, the spectacular entrance to a spectacular city.  It's beautiful curves and beautiful location make it breathtaking, whether I'm reluctantly schlepping it north to visit friends, or I am simply enjoying an afternoon walk.  San Francisco without the Golden Gate is just unimaginable to me...
author: Sean M.

description: Came here beginning of November.  Rented a bike to bike from pier 39 to the golden gate to the other side of the bridge to a little cute town "sausalitos" and took the ferry back.  All in all I would say about 14 miles.  It definitely kicked my butt going uphill but it was well worth it if you want to see it all.  My only advise is to do this first thing in the morning.  We made the mistake of starting it close to dusk and ended up biking in darkness right along side automobiles ( scary!!) by the time we got to the other side of the bridge.
author: Shima C.

description: Much fog, so wind, very busy. Must visit this landmark if you are visiting san francisco for the first time but the views are not so great during the summer due to san francisco's famous fog.
author: Beepbob S.

description:
Ok, so the price hike in bridge toll over the past few years SUCKED, but keep in mind this is a major SF icon.  Recently I heard about the plans to phase out toll bridge operators (the people who take our hard earned money), over 30 of them will lose their jobs when the fully pain in the ass automated system will take place in FEBRUARY.  

While I do not want to pay inflated fees to cross the GG Bridge, I also do not want to see people lose their jobs, and for all the rest of us to be inconvenienced with the alternative solution.  We will all be forced to use FASTRAK or be billed by our license plates which we will have to mail in payment (you'll need checks) or go to designated pay places to pay the toll (who is paying for our parking while we wait in line to pay in person?), there will be no more cash paying.

If you want to know more about this, read this article from SF Gate:

http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Golden-Gate-Bridge-to-eliminate-toll-takers-2478321.php
author: Kristina F.

description: The bridge was just like I saw on TV and in pictures. It was massive and beautiful. Looks like it is well kept, you can drive, bike, walk across. It does have a fee of $7 for cars to enter the city.
author: Christina V.

description:
In the 13 years that I've lived in the Bay Area, I've never walked across it.  It's one thing to drive across it but to actually see the work that was put into making this magnificent structure that represents San Francisco is truly amazing.  

Parking on a Saturday afternoon was pretty easy.  There is overflow parking on the other side where you pay $5.  

One piece of advice that I'd like to impart is: 
Check the weather at the bridge.  It was a freezing, windy 51 degrees when me and my girlfriends went so dress appropriately.  I was bundled up in a beanie, scarf, gloves, and heavy jacket.
author: Jen S.

description:
This has always been a spot i wanted to visit when i came to SF. Was totally lucky it was a sunny blue sky day. Even though i was hoping the famous fog would have rolled in early so i could see the Bridge differently, but that will be saved for next time!! 
And yes, i am a huge nerd that is going to do a short and sweet review on this place of interest too!!!

-Plenty of free parking.
-Bring a hoodie or jacket. That wind can be freaking COLD!!
-Great for photo taking.
-Great for people watching.
-A couple of benches to sit and marvel at the sight of the famous GG Bridge.
-For the best view of the bay i would go onto the Bridge. Simply breathtaking!!
-Use caution when walking the GG Bridge that you dont get ran over by a crazy bicyclist.
-Make sure you visit the gift shop to look at all the cute gifts that are sold at way overpriced prices!!

With that in mind, enjoy!!! =)
author: Sarah A.

description: Many places look amazing in photographs, but disappointing in real life. Not this bridge! This bridge looks more Mazing in person than in photographs. I don't even even know how people who drive it regularly can remain undistracted!
author: Johnny A.

description: OMG! Another strike out  for technology making being a human easier! I came across the Golden Gate a couple of weeks ago. Haven't received an invoice and don't want to hand over my bank/credit info for them to hold indefinitely so I tried the "make a one time payment" option. Could you have made making a payment any more difficult? I am furious that there is only ONE payment location in Redwood City and that the website does not say you first have to register online to be able to make a payment here. Also, the website itself is arranged weirdly, I would have felt luckier if I would have closed my eyes and picked an option. Are you serious? This is the best you could do? I give the new system a TWO THUMBS DOWN
author: Robin W.

description: Wow... You can't describe the beautiful view you get from being on the bridge. It's truly amazing and a great way to connect with the history of the U.S. Take full advantage of it now because it is free of charge to walk on the bridge, about a mile and a half, but starting next year for the first time in over 70 years, they will begin charging to ride your bike or walk over the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Gabriella C.

description:
I know, there are at least a zillion reviews of this bridge but it is such a cool place I had to give my perspective. 

I love bridges and this has to be one of the most beautiful. But what makes it really special is that they let you walk or bike ride over it. The two neat bridges where I live, the Jamestown and Newport bridges are closed to bikes and people. What a waste. 

Not only can you bike over it, the bridge has only a little railing on the side so you can hang over and see the insane water far, far below. A great place to loosen a loggie and watch it fall. In fact I always had an incredible urge to urinate off the bridge but that would probably be a bad idea. 

We walked over on one magical, mystic, morning and the fog on the SF was so thick you couldn't see. But magically just as we got half way across, the sun came out. So you could stand in the middle and see complete fog on one side and the sun on the other. It didn't seem real, like something out of a fake picture. 

Once you get over the bridge you enter Sausalito, an amazing Yuppie but still very cool place. They have houses held up by stilts that look like a little push would send the whole thing down the hill. Can't imagine they do very well in an earthquake. 

If I lived out there I imagine I would spend a lot of time just going back and forth across this bridge and probably never get sick off it. A bridge so damn cool that it deserves a zillion reviews
author: Brian S.

description:
6/12/11
Great exercise and am amazing view!

It's truly amazing how enormous and beautiful this bridge is! I really thought the bf was joking when he said he wanted us to walk across it...surprisingly the weather was pretty decent but later in the afternoon it started to get a bit chilly...we covered about 3/4 of the bridge before we turned back due to the cold and the sun starting to set! So much fun...
author: Belle N.

description:
BEAUTIFUL BEAUTIFUL BEAUTIFUL place to jog! If you want inspiration during a good workout, workout here! Can't believe how fast my run was because the scene was just so lovely!
Back and forth, the bridge is just a little over 3 miles.  On the other side of the bridge is Sausalito, which is a homey, romantic place to walk around and sip on a cup of joe at night!
Even if it is foggy, it's such a lovely place to walk!
author: The Fuzzies S.

description:
Avoid like the plague!

San Francisco has eliminated the toll booths on the bridge.  What used to be a fun drive across the bridge to Marin County is now an invitation to hours of entanglement with bureaucracy and especially if you have a rented car.  There are no easy-to-find warning signs on the on-ramp (besides what can you do, drive into the bay?) so when you come back to SF you discover the toll payment booths are all empty (they photograph your license plate).  There is totally confusing website where you can volunteer to pay all the tolls on your rented car for the next month if you do not elect to open an account by paying $20.  Does San Francisco what to drive away visitors?
author: Mary J.

description:
My precious. My love. The gas that renewed my fiery desire to move out west. Words can truly do you no justice.

I understand how it can be "just be a bridge" for those who see it every day, but it gave this Midwestern girl goosebumps at first sight from the marina. There was something about the massive structure draped with low (strikingly contrasting) clouds in the distance that made even a person as chatty as I stare in a tranquil silence for several minutes. 

On a mid July day, the cold winds at bridge level made me question Chicago's "windy city" moniker. While being windblown isn't my favorite feeling, there was a peaceful serenity in feeling nature touch my face with the bay and Mt  Tamalpais on either side.

Until we meet again my dear. Until we meet again...
author: Alexis B.

description:
I've seen my fair share of iconic bridges. I've seen The Brooklyn Bridge, The Tower Bridge, The Millenium Bridge and The Pont De Normandie. None of them compare to the Golden Gate.

I've spend a fair bit of time trying to figure out what makes the Golden Gate Bridge so special. I'm still clueless. I'm getting nowhere. All I know is that I love this bridge. End of story.
author: Yoni D.

description:
What else can I say that 6,000 others haven't said already.
Spectacular structure.  The Art Deco style is simply impressive, and the craftsmanship is something we don't often see in modern architecture.
author: Ken B.

description:
This business is a joke, unprofessional and just simply stupid. I almost get hit by golden gate bus route 72, number 902. The bus driver goes through a red light and almost hits me. I see him look in his mirror and smiles!
I call to complain the stupiud and pathetic secretary can't transfer me properly. I call back and said if you cant transfer to the supervisor i will just call 911. We progress through the call and she baited me and keep taking her time. I said you have 5 seconds to transfer me. I called 911. Do not take this transit unless you have to. Some of the drivers are sadistic and the staff at the home office is incompettent.
author: barabara b.

description:
I absolutely love this place! This bridge is beautiful, and there's just so much history with it! Especially if you make your way underneath the bridge, there's a bit of history that goes along with it. There's nothing wrong with expanding your knowledge!
The bridge itself is a bit scary for me. I love looking at it, and taking pictures of it, but standing on it was a different story for me. I am awfully afraid of heights, so everytime I'm on the bridge, I feel like I could just get pushed off to the side and fall over. There's no fencing towards the middle of the bridge, just a railing that's up to your waist. If you just slightly lean over, you could fall to your death! The worst part is, since it's so crowded, people don't seem to care if you're in their way, they just kind of push you aside. Especially the bicycles! So watch out for bicycles!!
Stay warm, because it gets really cold up there!
Overall, I love this bridge. I recommend it to anyone who is visiting San Francisco!
author: Cathy M.

description:
The 200th review is a monumental event. 

What a more fitting tribute than to write about something monumental as well -- the Golden Gate Bridge. 

I was literally a FOB (or actually, Fresh Off the Plane) when I witnessed the magic of the bridge.  Went here straight from SFO on Nov. 13,1999, at 10 am.

All the thoughts I had about SUNNY California was proven wrong that day.  In 55 degree FOGGY weather with strong winds, you really need more than a thin T-shirt and jeans.  

Looking at a picture taken of me back then, I saw a tanned, stick-thin, teenager with dye-free hair, bushy-eyebrows and a huge smile that translates to: "I'm here in the U.S.!!!"

A lot has changed in the last ten years.  I've plucked my eyebrows, shaved my legs, had highlights/lowlights done and I'm not as tanned or skinny anymore.  But what remains the same is,  I'm still in awe whenever I drive through it, or catch a glimpse of the two towers when I'm in Twin Peaks, or see it from Marin. 

I don't feel the need to keep taking pictures like a tourist to help me remember it by.  I can relive this experience EVERY DAY if I want to.

Because I live here now.  

And I'm extremely blessed.
author: Janice C.

description:
Bundle up. A sweater, scarf, and wind breaker kept me toasty. If that's not enough to keep you warm you can buy a cup of coffee at their cafe or buy an extra sweater in the gift shop (all which can be found in the parking lot area). Prepared to have people walk into your pictures and find yourself walking into others photos as it can be crowded with people. You'll see Asian tourists throwing up peace signs and little kids running amongst their parents around the bridge, scaring them to pieces. I thought bicyclists were supposed to stay on one side of the bridge, and walkers/runners on the other side? Didn't seem that way but maybe i'm mistaken! 

I was trying to take advantage of the beautiful sunny weather this weekend by taking a visit to the Golden Gate Bridge and going for a walk. It's fun blending in with tourists and whipping out my camera snapping shots of the views of the city and of the bridge, all the way until I reach Sausalito. I should have known this popular viewing destination would be packed the day after Christmas. Parking was hectic but I noticed a sign that said "Overflow Traffic Parking" and followed the arrows. It leads you to another parking lot underneath the bridge toll and out onto the other side. It's normally $5 parking all day but it was free for the holiday weekend - score!

Nothing beats the beauty of this city by the bay.
author: Samantha L.

description: the golden gate bridge is san francisco eiffel tower... it's imposing and impressive and where ever you view it, its just magnificent... it's one of the most photographed objects in san fran...  to get a true golden gate bridge experience you need to walk, drive or cycle across it as it will give you a sense of appreciation of mans engineering achievement... a tip if your driving on the bridge away from san fran you will need to pay a toll if your coming back in... so if your budget conscious either walk or cycle across it.. would i go back? in a heart beat...
author: Wil S.
