description: They should take it out because  you can't stop now that they have gone no cash pay. You have three choices now, prepay, Fasttrak  or pay by mail after. If you pay by mail you get the bill to the registered owner so if it is a rental not a good route.  If you like to pay by check this works.  The bills increase from $6.00, going up if you forget to pay so watch the mail. Fasttrak is fast and easy. Costco in some areas even have discounted Fasttrak. Prepaying allows credit card payment. Ok back to the tollbooth. It needs to disappear since it is a dinosaur but until then enjoy the view and speed on thru!
author: H D.

description:
My first time driving over the bridge. Actually my first time going over the bridge period.

As beautiful as this bridge is, going over it scared the living hell out of me. It was like something out of Silent Hill, all foggy while the rest of San Francisco was sunny.

There was alot of traffic too.

Maybe it was a good thing that I was driving rather than being a passenger, because if I hadn't been concentrating on the road, the heebie jeebies would have been ballin' 

I'm glad I got over it, but next time (if there is a next time) I'm just gonna enjoy it from a distance as I have before.
author: Ivy M.

description: It's a huge orange bridge!  No more toll booths, everything is collected with a PayPass now.
author: Justin B.

description: Iconic.  Amazing.  Need to walk across/bike it one day!
author: Mel G.

description:
I thought the Golden Gate Bridge was just an urban legend or something that I made up in my dreams, but I saw it in a book! I'm not the kind of person who thinks that something is real just because it's in a book (evolution, grape juice, companionship, etc.).

Turns out it's real and it's real neat! I think it's made of metal, but I couldn't run the right tests to verify that.
author: Ryan L.

description:
I'm not sure I feel worthy enough to 'rate' the Golden Gate Bridge.
After all who am I? Some almost 18-year old girl from California who's only biked the whole thing and driven over it many times? Well whatever here it is for the record: THE GOLDEN GATE BRIDGE IS AWESOME.

It's one of the most iconic parts of California. First, look at if from a far, like from Fisherman's Wharf or Coit Tower, take your pictures, and then actually go to it. If you have the time, bike it because you'll get a much better perspective on how big it is, but if not, driving it is almost as good! So, so much fun. When we drove over it as part of our road trip, Amanda and Crystal made up a song about it and it has forever been stuck in my head. Golden Gate Bridge... Golden Gate Bridge...

Like everything I guess, it can be an incredibly fun experience if you do it with the right people.
author: Hannah D.

description: I love this thing. It is like my eighth time here with it, er, at it. I never thought to rate it. It was a rainy day this time and I stayed inside.  I didn't run up to it an hug it like I usually do. But we looked at each other from a distance. Yeah. We took a picture together. We're still LIKE THAT. it knows I love it. It knows I'll be back soon, one day.
author: Kelly G.

description: If you have never seen such a magnificent bridge or just want to see breathe taking views, you have to check this place out.  Every bit of it is breath taking.  Make sure to plan ahead when visiting this location because weather can get a little hazy and at times traffic on the bridge is jam packed.
author: Jeffrey G.

description: What can I say, we went to the vista point on the far side of the Golden Gate Bridge just a few weeks before it's 75th Anniversary. Great view, just shows how small an area the peninsula is.  It's a must visit if passing through the area. There's another point with a grassy park and place to get snacks/food as well.  It's really cool to see people joggers, cyclists and all the sorts just using their legs to get all the way across the bridge.
author: John S.

description: It's the Golden Gate Bridge, what more do you need to know? Incredible views, amazing sunsets and an unlimited picture taking experience.
author: Bill A.

description:
I will do my best to shed some light on this most fantastic piece of architecture, but chances are whatever I say has probably been said a million times over... C'est la Vie!

The GGB is a MUST visit when going to or living in SF. This beautiful example of modern architecture sits majestically between San Francisco and Marin County.

- This beautiful bridge has been named one of the "7 Wonders of the Modern World" which is only surprising because of how many items have actually been built!
- Definitely the most photographed bridge in the world.
- Part of U.S. Route 101 and California State Route 1
- Prior to the building of the bridge those wanting to trek across the SF Bay would have to do so by boat
- Total length of 8,981 Feet by 90 Feet Wide by 746 Feet high...yep this thing is HUUUUUGE!
- Opened in May of 1937... 4 years after prohibition ended yo!
- The Art Deco design and color has contributed to the bridge's notoriety
- Featured in mainstream media many times over....heck they even turned this beautiful bridge a light blue on the show "Sliders!"
- Has only been closed 3 times in its history due to weather conditions (extreme winds!)
- There's a toll going Southbound, but not Northbound
- Middle of the day proves best for photos so that the fog has time to dissipate and it is not dark yet!
- Pedestrians and Bike Riders are welcome to cross

There is so much to do in the great city of San Francisco, but make sure that you do not avoid this beautiful structure.
author: Chad A.

description: So disappointed that all 3 times I went when I was visiting, the fog was hiding the Golden Gate Bridge.  Can't wait to come back one day and see the entire thing.
author: Mindy T.

description:
Breathtaking - a work of genius.  

After finishing up at the not so spectacular Japanese Gardens bf and I took the bus to Golden Gate bridge - the fog was just burning off and I couldn't wait to get out and take pictures!

The views are to die for.  All the pictures we took seemed like they were green screened because they turned out so good!  

A must see if in SF - a little tourist-y but for damn good reason.
author: Kristina P.

description: I don't know how to do this place justice, so just listen to everyone and go at least once in your life. It's really a magnificent color against the blue and green of the background. We were also lucky enough to catch it on a pretty sunny day, with very light fog/clouds being blown in briskly by the ocean breeze, which actually made it so much better. Toll on the bridge is $6 (southbound), but it's actually nice even to drive on the bridge. Go, just go and bask in the glory.
author: Chris V.

description: I just traveled to San Francisco, and took in the Golden Gate bridge. It was an amazing sight to tour. We drove over the bridge a few times (our hotel was north of the bridge), and I was surprised at first with how narrow the lanes where. You get used to it quickly though. The lookout on the East side is nice, with a good view of Alcatraz Island and the Fisherman Wharf area. We really liked the lookout on the west side though, which had a hike up to the old military area. This lookout gives a great hill top perspective and perfect view for some great photos. My only gripe was that it was really foggy when we went. It is definitely a must see!
author: Jesse T.

description: Dude, it's the golden gate bridge. THE icon of norcal. It's beautiful and you have to see it at least once.
author: Koko K.

description: Definitely a must when visiting San Francisco.  It's beautiful and very impressive up close.  A word of advice - go to the pavillion and park/picture area at the south end of the bridge to get a great view, but I would recommend driving across instead of walking or biking.  The walk is very cold, windy, noisy (cars wooshing by), and an overall sensory overload experience.  Just drive over it on your way to Muir woods or something.
author: Jesse F.

description:
Yes, it's cold and windy, but didn't we all know that already??? 

I've lived in the bay area most of my life and traveled extensively and the GG bridge can still take my breath away. Living here we sometimes forget how truly beautiful and magnificent this bridge is. Not to mention it's at the opening of one of the best bays in the world. 

I'll admit traffic sucks esp if there any sort of construction or road work being done. And the bridge toll??? Soon they're going to be asking for your first born child before you can cross
author: Laura F.

description: Best place to jog and walk my dog. Could never get enough of this bridge. It could be foggy or nice, hit or miss but still nice either way. Can be a little chilly so dress like somewhat warm. Even summer can be chilly, summer in San Francisco is not the Summer your thinking about.
author: Chi T.

description: I love this bridge! It is beautiful and so well kept. When I was there, it was a beautiful day, not a hint of fog!! My friends and I were lucky. We walked across the bridge one way and then ran back the other. It was a bit crowded, but I expected that. The gift shop is amazing! I could have walked away with a million things, but my favorite purchase was my $1 postcard that says I crossed the bridge. You get to stamp it with the date, too!
author: Tiffiny H.

description: Gorgeous views on clear days. Historic landmark. A MUST see for every visitor!!
author: Maya W.

description:
Absolutely beautiful. It's nice being able to see something bright and red in the midst of a foggy curtain. 

No Toll going out of San Francisco
$6.00 Toll going into San Francisco...

The drive itself on the bridge is only a few minutes max. Next time, I really want to go biking up and down the bridge. Jon didn't want to go because he said it would take too much time but I find the idea itself sort of romantic and wonderful. For another day~!
author: Julie Y.

description: Absolutely spectacular! I was fortunate to be there when the sun was shining and just a bit of cloud. Driving on it was so cool, looking up at it in amazement just wondering how they built it... WOW.
author: A H.

description: There are not many places in this world that combines great architectural beauty with natural beauty. This bridge does with Marin Headlines on one side and San Francisco Presidio on the other. It's almost like it was meant to be. There are so many aspects to this bridge. It's beautiful when clear and beautiful with the fog makes it's way in. On a rare occasion when the fog gets pushed low and fingers it's way below the span. It's like being in heaven.
author: Douglas A.

description:
An amazing iconic spot of San Francisco.

When you go and see the Golden Gate Bridge for the first time, it's one of those, "Damn, I'm actually here" type of moments.

The best view is across the bridge and heading up to the Marin Headlands, where you can get photos of the entire bridge and the City in the background. It's pretty cool.

However, it does get real chilly with the wind so definitely bring a jacket. It can definitely knock you off your feet.
author: Alex T.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is the West Coast's Statue of Liberty.

That is the best way I can put it...

It is such a beautiful landmark...even if you just get to drive across it once in your life.

If you want some AMAZING pictures of yourself and or the bridge here are a couple tips.

Find your way to Fort Mason and the Fort Point Historical Site.  It is on the San Francisco side of the bridge and it is at the base by the water...you are basically standing just feet away from the structure.  I do not have an exact address but just ask someone how to get to Fort Mason Point or put it in your GPS.   

The other spot and my personal favorite is on the other side of the bridge.  Most people when they are driving North on the bridge away from San Francisco pull over at the tourist point on the right side as soon as they get to the other side of the bridge.  Keep driving and exit the first freeway off ramp following that point. I believe it is Alexander Avenue but I could be wrong...just make sure to exit the freeway right after the official lookout and turn left.  At this point go back under the freeway towards the West and follow that road up and around.  You come to a fork in the road, make sure you go to the right and up the hill....I could not tell you exactly how long but after a couple minutes you come to a lookout point.  You should be able to tell because it is where everyone tends to park.  You then walk up a small hill (maybe 5 minutes) and come to the most AMAZING view of the bridge.  It makes for great pictures of both yourself and the bridge.

Don't worry, if you drive past this point a couple minutes later you will come to a point at the very top of the hill where you need to turn around...and if you do that you get an amazing view of the bay.

If you want specifics on this spot just send me a message and I can give you a little extra info.

While the toll for driving across the bridge may cost you a couple bucks it is totally worth seeing an amazing piece of art that says San Francisco more than anything else.  

:0)
author: Eric N.

description:
I have lived in SoCal for most of my life and currently live up here in the bay area.  I have never had to pay so much for a f'n toll before.  Geezus christ, may I pay a dollar more and have the privilege of licking the dirt off the road so it looks nice and spiffy?.  For the volume they get daily and the price of the toll, there should be free road side pampering services for the drivers and the cars they own, like complimentary snacks or free car washes.

While my wallet is getting raped of its monetary contents, it screams in pain every time I pass through this toll plaza and have to lull it back to sleep and promise it that it will hurt less the next day.  

How bout using some of that $ and spruce that place up even a smidge.  Maybe a big marquee above the toll booths letting me know scores of sports games or the latest headlines of events around the around.  Sorry, I think I am starting to pull nonsensical stuff out of my ass right now since I got myself all flustered over this thorn in my side.  I dunno, just do something with the money to make me feel justified of the cost to cross over.  All that money can't be going towards the bridge's paint job can it?

Please excuse me, my wallet just woke up crying from a nightmare again.  I think the toll scared it again.  This trauma could leave a lifelong scar at this point.  I better go find a therapist with the milk money i have left over at the end of the week.
author: David A.

description:
When I was in middle school I ran across the Golden Gate bridge in an attempt to be the first girl in our class to get across the bridge. Looking back, that idea just sounds silly... perhaps it was because I was only 13, it was foggy and I just wanted to get across as quickly as possible but being it was my first time on the bridge, I should have stopped, snapped a pic or two and admired the view. 

I LOVE the fact the bridge is in our backyard and we can bike and/or walk across it anytime. My favorite part is being able to stop on the pathway and see Berkeley, Alcatraz and SF all in one view.
author: Lan H.

description: This is just a completely rip-off. I drove through Golden Gate Bridge in Dec 2014, and today (two months later) I received a bill for $32 including a $25 late fee. These cheaters never sent me anything before and are now trying to overcharge me. If this is your way to run the government, please file bankruptcy. Middle fingers!!!
author: Dan Z.

description:
Stunning.  So much bigger than I ever imagined.

There was a small visitors area that was under construction that added to a bit of the tourist madness... or was it the hundreds of Girl Scouts?  Hmm..  Also so many bicyclists that were quite territorial of their space.  I get the whole "share the road with bicyclists" thing - but man - it was like they expected a clear path at one of the most iconic bridges in the USA... it just ain't gonna happen!

Whatever the case.. you can't NOT see the Golden Gate if you travel to San Francisco.  My fellow friend and I found it funny that it took us nearly two days to see it!  It's tucked away from the city centre so be prepared to navigate via bus or cab!
author: Tony K.

description:
For my 200th review, what better monument to critique than one of the most recognizable landmarks in America?  THE Golden Gate Bridge!!!

Visiting this architectural triumph has long been on my bucket list, and my most recent vacation to San Francisco provided the opportunity.  The best way to experience this bridge is by having someone pick you up and actually driving across it.  Don't mess with a cab--I can't imagine how expensive the fare would be from Union Square to the opposite end of the bridge.  Yes, you can always rent a bike and do the touristy thing...but this particular weekend I was in luck.  

My best bud Simon was in town and picked us up from the Sir Frances Drake for some sight-seeing.  After having a scrumptious breakfast at Stacks, we headed north to the big bridge.  Traffic wasn't bad at all for a Sunday afternoon.  

We've all seen movies of this bridge--it's internationally recognizable--but absolutely nothing will prepare you for the grandiosity and magnificence of this architectural landmark.  it's truly breathtaking.  

I'm not exactly sure what route we took after crossing the bridge, but we ended up at the ideal location for a photo op.  It was serene, almost like the world was holding its breath for this one moment, yet the city continued to pass by...people going about their day and running errands.  I think I've found one of my favorite places in this world.
author: Sarah K.

description: I've visited this bridge twice now, and I've loved it both times. It is beautiful from every point of view, every season, sunny or foggy.. I will likely come back to it every time I am in San Francisco.. and a must see for any tourist in the area, for sure.
author: Lizzy P.

description: came here at night did not get very clear photos as you would in the day time i would recommend coming here when the sun is still up
author: Oscar D.

description: Must Must Must visit this Ginormous Breathtaking manmade structure. Walk, drive, ride, flyover it, do what you can to check it out. I have biked it twice. Once with regular bike and with electric hybrid bike. Electric is totally worth it as you r not tired at end of the day. Comes with self guided map, easy to use and go around. Call shop if you run  out battery power, they deliver it to you. Visit up the northern side up in mountains for view of whole city along with the bridge. Weather is the only killer but you might be surprise how beautiful it looks with low clouds.
author: Vlren P.

description:
An absolutely beautiful landmark/ tourist trap. But the best thing about it is it's majectic crowning of the entrance to the SF Bay. On looks alone it is 5 stars a dozen times over. 

Originally the GG Bridge was meant to make Marin an easily accessed suburb of SF. But add a bridge access to a big city- you know eventually it will be a major freeway access. And a major traffic pain in the ass. The first time I rode a motorcycle across was terrifying thanks to the wind. I was positive I was going to be blown into on coming traffic. Another death defying experience is being on the bridge at the same time as either someone who is drunk and swerving or is a tourist and is trying to take pictures while driving (drunkenly swerving though sober). There is always two idiots on the bridge each time I cross. One going 22 miles an hour, one going 82 miles an hour. 

The toll is fanatstic (not), as are the fines for going too fast (which is what 51 miles an hour?).. But for me the best part of crossing the bridge in January is the fact that I always get to see at least half a dozen tourists in shorts, short sleeves, dresses, high heels, and roller blades attempting to cross. It's cold out there morons!! Dress for the snow!! I love to snap pictures of the under dressed tourists rather than hope to get a decent shot of SF. Much more fun- especially seeing the expressions on their faces as you take their pictures!! :-)

Anyways, I had to take away a star for the fact that any good 30 sec earth quake could swing the GGBridge right into the bay..  Just kidding.. it would take at least 45 seconds according to the experts to knock the whole thing down!!
author: Lisa H.

description: Beautiful bridge, it is easier to walk and enjoy the scene, and at the same time you get a nice workout.
author: Samuel M.

description:
One of my favorite locations to take out-of-town friends when they are visiting.  The view from the south and north side of the bridge are breathtaking.  You can see the SF skyline, Alcatraz, and Angel Island.  

You can bike across or walk across (walking is about hour there and back).  Bring a jacket as it does get windy on the bridge.  

One of my favorite sight-seeing bike rides is across this bridge, into Sausalito, and then take a ferry back to Fisherman's wharf.  

I think Sports Basement is the best place to rent nearby.  Bay City Bike and Blazing Saddles are both more expensive, and I think the bikes at Sports Basement are better quality.
author: Paul L.

description: Amazing & beautiful. A must see if your coming to San Francisco. Better yet come to San Francisco to see the bridge then yelp everything else.
author: Maja O.

description:
This bridge truly is worth the price of admission (heck, I'm sure they could charge 5x the toll and it would still be a cash cow I'd suckle).  

There are few things in this world you should make a point of visiting and experiencing in person, but this bridge definitely makes the list.  Whether it's:::::

(((((DRIVING)))))
The views of San Francisco, the Pacific, the craggily coast, and the bridge itself are awe-inspiring, but whiz by oh too quickly.

(((((WALKING)))))
This can be an adventure.  You never know the weather.  Heck, the bridge has it's own weather.  The onshore flow funnels it's way directly onto the bridge.  Dress accordingly.  You can walk, jog, or bike.  Be sure to walk on both sides of the bridge to get equal doses of bustling and beauty.

(((((SEEING)))))
Even if you don't make it to the Bridge, it's still nice to see the bridge from afar.  I like to spy it from a plane when I'm arriving at SFO.  I like to steal glimpses from East Bay (when the fog cooperates).  A great photo op can also be had from Fisherman's Wharf.  Really there are so many vantage points where one can frame a picture around this icon.

Ms. GOLDEN GATE, you truly are GOLDEN!
author: Corey G.

description:
When you think of California you think about the glitz and glamour of la/Hollywood and the Golden Gate bridge!
This bridge is just awe strucking, even though I've been up here plenty of times this place still is a must stop for me.
I will be back when I am back up here...
author: James S.

description: What could be bad about the bridge?  It's a place everyone should visit if they get a chance.  It's a wonderful experience to see and go to.  We took many pictures of the bridge from various locations.
author: Denise B.

description:
This is the BEST bridge in the world!! If you are a tourist you MUST walk across the bridge to truly appreciate it. I cross this bridge eight times a week and it it always the best part of my drive. 

This bridge is world famous and a true landmark for San Francisco. To see pictures is one thing but to see it up close and personal is a whole new experience. 

Dress warm and bring a camera. If possible and if opened up the Marin Headlands is a fantastic place to view the bridge from different angles. 

Please vote no for the safety nets as well. Lets keep this truly marvelous bridge in original condition!!!
author: Patrick R.

description:
I come from a town of seven bridges, but none as gorgeous as the red-hued Golden Gate Bridge. I actually prefer it red over gold because it sticks out more on foggy days. Absolutely beautiful. The closest thing we have to that in Jacksonville is the Dames Point Bridge. http://bridgepros.com/projects/DamesPoint/damespoint.jpg

My favorite feature of the Golden Gate Bridge is the viewing area where you can take pics or just kickback with the beautiful SF skyline as your backdrop.

This bridge must have left an impression on me bc I found myself absentmindedly doodling it at a meeting recently. =)

http://static.px.yelp.com/photo/YLWZ5zvYerZs2D9VoPjOOw/l
author: Julie A.

description:
Came here on vacation to check out the tourist spot and to see what everyone was talking about. You can drive, bike or run the across the bridge and the east bay view of san fran is amazing.  definitely made me feel like i was in california. 

The only down side would probably be the parking issue and the congestion of traffic from tourist buses.
author: tony t.

description: If you are in San Francisco, going to the bridge is a must! It is one of the most known places of the US. I can say it is much bigger than I though!... And if you go after the  bridge, you can get a Really nice view of the city and the bay.
author: Mariana R.

description: I know it's blasphemous giving the Golden Gate Bridge any less than 5 stars, but the new toll situation is frustrating to out of towners. In case you're not aware, all the toll booths have been replaced with FASTRAK.  If you don't have a FASTRAK, you need to pay online within 48 hours of crossing the bridge. While it's not bad for locals who will opt to go with FASTRAK or tourists who will cross the bridge just once, it's an added hassle for us Bay Areans who might cross once every month or so. The most annoying part, however, was that it was never made clear to us that we had to pay online. When we reached the toll booths, all the sign said was not too stop. Our bewildered reaction at the time: Huh, don't stop? Does that mean we just drive though and get a driving ticket in the mail?
author: Pierre B.

description:
Epic views. Nice walk. All the jazz everyone else has already said and then some. Every picture anyone could take of the bridge could easily be a postcard no matter what angle from which it was taken. 

But seriously, of all the parking meters in the city, I'm glad this one makes a quarter last a whole lot longer (15 minutes as opposed to 5). Huzzah!

A random patron at a diner came by our table to tell us that walking under the bridge was truly one of the great San Franciscan experiences. On foggy days, walking under the bridge can be kind of eerie. In a cool way.
author: Christine A.

description: We had a difficult time trying to park but I guess that's not really the fault of the bridge. Beautiful day...great exercise...historical landmark. Win win win! Totally worked off all those carbs I ate at Lovejoys...well maybe not ALL of them!
author: Alena B.

description: This bridge rocks!!!  Is is because of the color? Is it because of the location?  Is it because tourist also flock here?  Great questions!!!!   I beleive that it is all three answers.   I do photography, that's not how I make a living, but I do make some money from this endeavor.    I prefer getting away from the crowded veiw when you in the Marin County area, drive up the winding road some, and get some pictures from there.     I think some of my all time favorite pictures of this iconic bridge are the tips of the bridge sticking out through the fog.  Enjoy the veiw.
author: Peter J.

description: I love the non-stop toll plaza. All toll roads should function in this way. What a headache it must be to sort out the person responsible for the toll if you don't have a fast track but the in car experience is the best. I have been a long user of the fast track so this defacto/forced participation does not impact me at all and the upside of a few minutes less congestion is very nice.
author: K H.

description:
Just gorgeous - and decent to drive over when it's NOT rush hour.
DOn't miss seeing this historic man-made landmark when you visit the Bay area.

Walk or bike over it - and bring a wind breaker - it can get downright nippy!
author: Karen F.

description:
Dear Arnold, 

I don't know what you did with all the tax dollars, but the bridge was incredibly hard to get to. Once we got there, there were 3 times more cars than parking spaces. The same went for the restrooms. They smell like septic! Yes, I do know what septic smells like. Once I fought off a dozen other tourists for a parking spot and lined up with 2 dozen other men for a spot in front of the potty, I did unload a serious amount of liquid while sucking in what I believed to be extremely toxic fume. (imagine the line on the ladies side) Coming from the rectum of America, I think I will promote new jersey back up to the armpit and demote California to the rectum.

Once I got on the bridge on the pedestrian side, we kept running into bikers. What happened to the biker's side? Where was the enforcer? Do police not exist any more in this city? One female biker charged toward us and politely screamed "FUCK OFF". I now have a new image and sound of the SF city hospitality......some female dog charging on a bike with a constipated face letting loose the aforementioned words.

As we were leaving the park, the traffic was horrible again. We found out that there was a black out in a 2 block radius. People had no idea how to play chicken when traffic lights are off.....and for the hour I was stuck in traffic, no police managed to get to the artery of the city that is just a 4 way pile up waiting to happen.

I highly recommend that you legalize weed and tax the doo doo out of it. Oh and please do send the insane bikers to mental institutions.

Thank you, 

Pig, a tourist who pay more to the state of california than your average tax payers.
author: Jeff K.

description:
I've driven across it plenty of times.  Amazing view.  Cool architecture.  

Then I rode across it.  Wow.  This is the way to do it, folks.  Outing #1 on my SF Bucket List.  It's tougher than it looks but it's worth the sweat.
author: Eric S.

description: Hardly any guard rails at all. Very easy to jump or fall off... So many kids climbing and frolicking. Easily in the top ten most unsafe places i have EVER BEEN TO!!!!! Wont go back without some type of harness and rope system to prevent an accident.
author: Safety G.

description:
There's really nothing I can say that will be any different from the other reviews.

It's huge, it's beautiful.... You just have to stop and stare in silence for a few minutes.

It's amazing just how industrious and inventive we humans can be when we put our mind to it.

P.S.  Skip the crowds of tourists by driving over the bridge and have a gorgeous view from the Marin Headlands.
author: Nicole W.

description:
I've been to SF a handful of times, yet this infamous attraction of SF never ceases to amaze me. 

People want to drive through it, walk on it, and touch it--do all three b/c it is worth it.

There's no toll going (northbound) to the bridge, but going southbound is 6 bux

Take the Vista Point exit--parking is free, and the view from there is absolutely gorgeous--you see the city of SF and the entire GG obviously--makes a gorgeous backdrop for pictures.

Walking the bridge is a great experience--estimated, depending on how fast you're walking- it would take about 30-40 min each going from end to end. You share the walkway with bikers as well, so be careful not to get run over or hit by one, or just move out of the way when you see one that doesn't seem to care to slow down for a walker. You can feel the bridge shake d/t traffic--people drive so fast on the bridge,so there's alot of times you'll hear cars honking at each other like its nobody's business lol. 

I'm sure lots of people have said this, so I'll say it too...you haven't experienced San Francisco if you haven't been to the GG :)
author: Zerrilyn P.

description:
Although the Golden Gate Bridge is phonemically reminiscent of SF tourism, it's still pretty awesome. It's beautiful in the surrounding area, with a few places you can turn off to explore little touristy spots to take pictures and enjoy the view on a rare and sunny day.

Down sides to this place are: 
1. It's hard to find. (If you're Asian and a girl and driving)
2. Expensive bridge toll
3. Traffic
4. People come here to commit suicide.
author: Grace Y.

description: Gosh I feel so horrible giving "THE Golden Gate Bridge" a simply A-ok rating but honestly that is what it is. Yes, it is massive. It is definitely a beautiful piece of architecture rich in history and culture. Not to be insensitive but...that was it for me. It was pretty and I got some great pics but I would have been ok seeing it from a distance. I think this is one site you can cut out from your San Francisco tour. See it from a cable car or Alcatraz...you don't necessarily need to go to the bridge to observe it's beauty and grace.
author: Tracie F.

description: The best of San Francisco! A must to see for tourists. Safe and friendly people on the bridge. A lot of police presence.
author: Lad S.

description:
Every time I head south on 101 past Sausalito, head up the long winding hill, enter the darkness of the tunnel, emerge into the daylight and the perfectly framed view of San Francisco appears before me I am struck dumb by the incredible beauty of our Golden Gate Bridge.

With tears swelling up in my eyes and my heart beating with pride at the engineering feat that created this marvelous piece of living artwork connecting the earth, I wonder  . . . can life really have more to offer than this exquisite beauty?

Then, as I begin to cross the bridge, I see the 1st of several blue & white signs:

"EMERGENCY PHONE AND CRISIS COUNSELING"

As if hit in the chest with the force of Ali, I wonder how the incredible beauty of this place cannot lift the spirits of those who might need phones and counseling here.

And I weap . . . for them.  Every single time.
author: Rachel C.

description: I have to say this toll plaza is one of the weakest toll in the bay area.  Why?  It's confusing for drivers, most tourists when the lanes are either reduced or increased depending on the commute hours.  Drivers get confused and trying to merge lane which causes slow down and create traffic.
author: Chris R.

description: the best and most beautiful things to see in San Francisco. it was a specially fun to see it from Sausalito where it ooks like it was rising of the fog.
author: Tina C.

description: The Golden Gate Bridge is one of the modern wonders of the world. Not only must you see it if you visit California, you should probably have it on your itinerary if you visit the U.S. period. Painted the official color International Orange it stands as the gateway to the San Francisco Bay area. It has to constantly be painted because the paint erodes away quick due to the sea water and salty air. You should read up on the history of it and how it was the first suspension bridge in the world and how many workers gave their lives to build it. It's an appropriate entrance to one of the most beautiful cities in the world. Drive over it, walk over it or ride a bike over it. Just stop along the way to take pictures. There are several places to stop and take pictures, including on the Sausalito side that is an amazing view of the bridge going around the mountain towards The City. I remember I was driving over the bay bridge coming from the Marin side during sunset, just as I passed the Palace of Fine Arts. It was breath taking.
author: Liz C.

description:
For the best photo shots, the far western part of Crissy Field park on the San Francisco side of the bridge gives a dynamic undershot of the structure. For that classic shot of the bridge behind you from above, is a scenic stop at the north bay part of the bridge up on the mountain to the west. For a wide shot of the entire bridge eastern span, venture to Alcatraz or Treasure Island during sunset.

Welcome to the ambitious brainchild of the visionary poet and engineer Joseph Strauss. Featured as one of the greatest wonders of the world and featured in countless media from film to television to video games, I am honored to witness this modern marvel every day when I wake up and look out my window. The story about how this bridge came to be is inspiring. Although this legend comes with many ups and downs being the most captivating symbol of the west coast and the city of San Francisco, it is also sadly home to the suicide capital of the world that even inspired the documentary The Bridge. Hence the nets hanging under the popular jump spots.

The traffic on the Golden Gate gets busy on your typical rush hours. When it's busy, stay in the right lane for quicker results. Driving across into San Francisco there will be a toll charge. Both sides of the bridge contain walkways, but last I heard only the eastern side walkway is open to the public for crossing, tourists and bikers.
author: Terry C.

description:
I really do not understand all the hoopla about Golden Gates Bridge.
It's a bridge and not all that cool or beautiful or anything.
Perhaps I am missing something and so be it, but in all honesty, it does absolutely nothing for me....
author: Vlad K.

description:
Walk on history in San Francisco.  An easy walk seeing San Francisco from the north side.  Words can't describe the GGB.  Go there and walk on the bridge.  Bring your camera.

I suggest parking at Crissy Field because parking is free.  There is parking on the east side and west side.  The east side has more parking.  Walk to the GGB after you park.  The urban hike is easy.  You see great views of the San Francisco Bay and many opportunities to take a pic of the GGB.  The hardest part of the walk is a brief and steep staircase located at the west side of Crissy Field.  There are signs on the west side directing you to the bridge.

Have fun walking!  Bring water and food.
author: Raymond M.

description:
What can I say that hasn't already been said? 

Can you believe they started construction in 1933?!
That alone is amazing!

I've stopped here many times. I usually go to the north side and park there with a sammich and some jager. 

I like this side better, because there's less traffic and you get an incredibly awesome panoramic view of the bay, bridge and city. I've taken some amazing pictures and video here.

Shine or rain, you can't go wrong with this hilltop. 

There's something so majestic and grandiose about this place. You smell it in the air and you feel it in the wind. I'm sure it'll get a sigh and a deep breath out of you.
author: JC D.

description:
Possibly the most beautiful, certainly the most photographed, bridge in the world. 
This is a great and beautiful construction work . 
One of the most popular place for tourists . If you traveling in California you have to go to see this amazing bridge . 
There is no words to explain how big and nice is it . That's why is better to see it once than heard a thousand times .
author: Ilyas D.

description: The most photographed bridge in the world. This bridge is a must see
author: Connie M.

description: San Francisco must-do: walk across the Golden Gate Bridge.  Even though it was foggy and somewhat windy, it was not as cold as expected.  For sure, wear a jacket.  Parking on the south side was a nightmare, there's like 10 spaces.  But fortunately there is a lot of parking down at Fort Point and it is just a short walk from there to the bridge.  We did not go to the north side but there is also parking there (you will pay a toll to get back into the city).
author: Damon W.

description: Been to SF 3 times...each time I was up there, I could have sworn that I purposely drove through the bridge about 10 times each back and forth...I wasted a ton of gas just because of it...SF is so beautiful!!  Next time I am up there, I definitely have to drive up further north to check out Muir Woods...
author: Jaeman M.

description:
Upon taking a job in Marin, I was initially a little afraid of a potential bridge commute nightmare.  Growing up in New York, all of the doomsday 3 hours in bridge traffic scenarios came screaming back to mind.  Luckily I have a reverse commute.  Morning traffic is non-existent and afternoon traffic ranges from non-existent to only moderately annoying.

Traffic anxiety aside, I feel very lucky to have what must be the most gorgeous commute in the US.  Every day is a different scene -- all equally dramatic.  Sometimes it's like I'm driving through Care Bear cloud world in my Care Bear Cloud Car.  Other times it's like the world is on the verge of ending.

There's only one detraction -- and that is the constant fear that I'm going to see some poor lost soul climb over the railing and jump into the Bay.  It lends this macabre quality to the experience that I could do without.
author: Kevin F.

description: I cross it five days a week.  I've ran it several times.  The views are incredible!  Great to have access to such an extraordinary landmark.  Rain or shine, it's great to see it daily!
author: Mario P.

description: Yeah, they should tear this thing down. What an eyesore. Where's Godzilla when you need him.
author: A R.

description: What can I say.. Traversing this guy on a cloudy and overcast day in SF is a must. The most famous landmark, and rightly so. Loved the picture it gave us. A token of the love the city showed us on our vacation!
author: Aaron S.

description:
When we lived in The City you could see just the top of The Golden Gate Bridge's towers from our apartment. Maybe the top section or so. Even that limited view put a smile on my face every time I looked in it's direction. Heck, even when it was foggy and all I could see were the flashing beacons on The Bridge's towers, I still felt lucky to have such a great monument so close to us.

San Francisco on one end, Sausalito and the Marin Headlands on the other, the SF Bay and the Pacific Ocean to the east and west. The Golden Gate Bridge really is a sight to see... and there are so many beautiful sights to see from it.
author: Chris P.

description:
Been here once before and I didn't think it was as cool, UNTIL I saw the documentary called "The Bridge". I brought a fellow yelper and a hot lady here after she saw the flick too. Don't think she was as into it as me, but she put up with me. Anyhow the movie is about bridge jumpers so I'm weird like that and was analyzing everyone on the bridge. On the way out of the bridge we think we had spotted a jumper. Unfortunately, we didn't stick around to see the outcome. Took a picture of him but out of respect I guess I'll leave it off of Yelp.(We went on feb 7th 2009)

This view is great and the day we went there was clear after a days rain before.
author: J V.

description:
It's my hometown landmark, one of many. For the first time ever, I decided to take my walking crew across the bridge for some motivated cardio. Loads of tourists in jeans and tank top-short shorts wearing out of towners were strewn about the walkways like leaves, fast moving bikes sharing the same road weaving in and out like meat bees diving for a turkey leg.  It was windy, it was sunny, it was fabulous.
The walk back was a bit chillier, the clouds were coming into the bay so we got the typical SF weather pattern of sunshine and fog. Not bad for a Sunday!
author: Pauline L.

description:
Here are some pointers on WALKING across the bridge, from the SF side, in August during the daytime:

-free parking around Crissy Field; it's a ~1 mile walk to the bridge on a paved path
-Walk single file! Only one side was open and it was packed on a Sunday. Very difficult for walkers and bikers to maneuver.
-The ends were fairly warm but when you go to the middle of the bridge, amidst the fog, it was COLD and WINDY.  We started the walk in a t-shirt but by the time we hit the middle, we had our sweatshirts on with hoods up!  Not really fun, honestly.
-The bridge is 1.7 miles long.  This makes for a ~4 mile walk total from the parking lots at Crissy Field. Be prepared.
-There was an awesome hot dog stand at Crissy Field and a million people having picnics and such. Seemed like a good place for it.
author: Leslie B.

description:
An icon.

Driving over the Golden Gate Bridge is a must-do for those who have access to a car. Construction of the south side of the bridge tends to bottle neck traffic. There are parking lots and great views on both sides of the bridge; be warned that they get very busy. The north viewing area has great views of the city, and is a good place for family photos with the city or the bridge as a backdrop.

After you get a good look at the bridge keep heading north and check out the town of Sausalito.
author: Monarch B.

description:
The best thing I could say about my experience was that I was going Northbound so I didn't have to pay for the tolls, or struggle through the ridiculousness of southbound passage.

Seriously though, $6 for toll? Or is that $5 with Fastrak? Which lanes are Fast.....oh who cares.
author: Liesl D.

description: My favorite thing to do in San Francisco!!  There is something so beautiful and alluring about the bridge. Walk across the bridge for the best views, it's only 3/4 mile across.
author: Lindsey C.

description:
Aside from maybe the Great Wall of China or the Pyramids, this has to be one of the most recognized/photographed sites in the world. I'm slightly prejudiced since I was born here but walking across the GG Bridge nevers fails to take my breath away especially on a clear day. DH's dad actually was part of the construction crew. How cool is that!

You can walk or bike it besides the obvious of driving. Some days walkers and bikers are on the same side of the bridge which can make maneuvering quite difficult. Much better when they are allowed on opposite sides. The MUNI system goes right out to the bridge parking lot so save yourself the drive. And don't even get me started on the debate to somehow "fence in" all parts of the bridge to prevent jumpers!! Ruin the beautiful view.....are you kidding me?  It isn't the GG's responsibility to protect you from yourself.

Dress in layers, wear good shoes and make sure you take a bathroom break before you head out. There are facilities to use on the Marin side of the bridge. It's an easy walk but is slightly uphill at the crest of the bridge.
author: Eastsac G.

description: They save money by not having attendants and make money on late fees because who is expecting to be billed later for crossing a bridge? The way SF hustles people for tickets is like organized crime. The SF municipality is famously awful, which is why Google refuses to work with them, and their sketch new bridge operation is in typical fashion.
author: Colin C.

description:
Built in just four years
All without a computer
Simply marvelous
author: Observe R.

description: 5. make a wish :)
author: Alvin D.

description:
I've never reviewed a bridge before, and daresay I'm not entirely sure I'm qualified to!

I've driven over it several times, and always make it across the Bay. That's enough for 5-stars in my book!
author: Jenn D.

description:
I'm sorry I wasn't that impressed. I guess I was expecting alot more. I don't know what but this simple bridge wasn't it. I mean I've seen great bridges in Long Beach, the gigantic bridge that connects San Diego to that island. This place even though it was my first time wasn't very awe inspiring. I thought maybe the Oakland bridge might even be more impressive. 

I guess its one of those places you take a picture with to say you've been there.
author: Zan O.

description:
It's a great bridge that takes you from marin to SF & vice-versa. 

It's beautiful (in an industrial kind of way) and it's functional. 

i feel uber silly writing a review about a bridge...

it sucks where there is traffic, stay in the far right lane... it's always faster for some reason.
author: Caitlin F.

description:
Beautiful walk from Lincoln down to the bridge and then across it. My boyfriend and I walked the bridge a few weekends ago. If you are a local, you should try to pick a day that is more clear than foggy. We went down to the bridge twice, once using the 28 Muni and once walking all the way down Lincoln. I would definitely recommend the walk, but it's very long (I estimate that we walked over 5 miles total), so remember to bring good walking shoes. You can also bike the road there, which is probably more practical for most people. Along the way, there are old bunkers in the Presidio. From the top of these bunkers, the view of the bridge is amazing!

From there it's a short walk down to the bridge. The bridge is less than two miles and free to walkers and cyclists. But be careful, because there are a lot of people riding bikes and the walkway is narrow. Otherwise, it's a beautiful place and a must see.
author: Steph G.

description: I mean how can you give the Golden Gate Bridge less then 5 stars?  It is a landmark and the view is superb.
author: Alice E.

description:
Absolutely breathtaking!

It's a little chilly up there but you will love every second of your visit. Dress in layers. 

I could hug the scenery if I could.

Parking was easy and paths were well marked. 

GGB, I will visit you again!
author: Ennos P.

description:
I would give it 4.5 if I could. Only because while it's pretty I dislike all the construction going on around it. Not to mention how freakin expensive it is now! Still remember back in the day when it was $2 and now I think it's $6. I know everyone hates on the toll. :p The only time I come here now is when friends are in town visiting and they want to see it.

Agree the scenery is still nice and an awesome view. Taken so many pictures of the bridge (day and night) from different angles.  

Usually I get lucky and there is no fog, but windy and foggy days it has it's beauty as well. 

Of course, it's a definitely a must see if you're visiting California, or NorCal specifically. Been here so often since I was a kid that I could probably give tours about it. 

AND if you're a star trek fan, the other end of the bridge is where starfleet academy is supposed to be! Lucasfilm is in the presidio right next door too! Come stop by and see the Yoda foundtain statue!
author: Christine C.

description: I had the pleasure of visiting this bridge last week, and boy was I impressed! There is no way that humans created this bridge. I am pretty sure aliens from pluto made this. You want to know why I said pluto, because it was demoted as a planet. Why else would the government demote planet unless there is life there. This bridge is massive!!!! One good thing about this bridge though is there are no trolls that live under it. As a child I haunted, and I mean like the movie grudge haunted. Id give it 5 stars but there are sharks in the water.
author: Justin A.

description:
There is something hauntingly beautiful about this place...Haunting because of the lives who stepped into eternity from here and beautiful because it has become a beacon of welcoming the east to the west and uniting the north to the south.
I have walked across here once- and trust me it was not easy- I was shaking- I practically held on to every inch of the metal rail or paused to slow my breath and even looked elsewhere to distract my fear... I  finally stopped on the center to get a good look below...I still got the vertigo- and my knees started to shake- but I knew I had to finish...to get over my fear of heights... 

I have to admit- that before going- I had the ferry ride that takes you under the bridge. The sun was just beginning to set as we approached the bridge, and the cruise captain said-  " We're going under the GG Bridge- many have made  wishes and many have said they've come true!"  
I am all about getting  every help I could get and well  needless to say- mine did come true...I heart SF :-D

PS-This is probably not your best bet to visit if you have extreme batophobia or havent worked towards alleviating it.
author: Arissa C.

description:
It's a bridge , what more can you ask for . 

But it is something that my relatives who live in the Philippines ask to see when they visit. Something about the iconic orange bridge really makes them shake in there tsinelas ( flip flops) with excitement.

It really is a sight to see at night. The large structure and beautiful lights really makes people opens their mouth like drooling babies.

I'm taking one star off however for the toll just to freaking cross it. It's like double from what it used to be.
author: Eleanor D.

description: It's fascinating every time I drive there because ever since I was little I always go to this bridge:) It is like a part of my childhood.
author: Serena M.

description:
I loved that the public restrooms there are extremely clean. This review is about our visit for Free Tiber/Free Burma rally on the day of Olympics torch rally day, about 3 weeks ago.

I wasn't aware of what was going on in Burma, until the recent natural disaster forced the country to reveal how this government is ruining people's lives there. And then I remembered of movie called Beyond Rangoon with Patricia Arquette about the country and saw people having to flee to Thailand.

That was more than 10 years ago. We have iPhone now but they are still suffering.
author: Kokoro I.

description:
This bridge is San Francisco.

Sometimes magically, and other times tragically so. There is something special here; it draws the glib, the conditioned, the spiritually diverse and the emotionally depraved.

Very much like our fine little City.

As I count down to my final months here in San Francisco and the United States, the Golden Gate is a monumental symbol bridging all that is wonderful and tragic about the City, and ultimately, what is inside each of us. 

I will miss it so.
author: May T.

description:
What more can you say but, ICONIC LANDMARK!!!

There is metered parking (25 cents for 15 min. 2 hours max) and you are allowed to walk across the bridge, but definitely take a jacket or sweater since it can be cold and windy on your walk across. 

There is a plaque commemorating the Golden Gate bridge and a viewing area located on the first support towers on the bridge (about 1/3 of the way in) and a great spot to take in the awesome view of the bay and San Francisco skyline.

It's Free to drive over (towards Sausalito), but you must pay a toll to return back into San Francisco.

As any tourist attractions, get here early (10 am) before the crowds wake up and the tour buses begin to arrive.

**Tip: There is a trail that you can take from the parking area towards the Fort where you can take a much nicer picture of the Golden Gate bridge, but then again any picture of the Golden Gate bridge is pretty cool!
author: Saul A.

description:
"East is East, and West is San Francisco"

-O. Henry

I think this quote pretty much sums it up for the city that gives northern California and the whole west coast a good name. There is just something magical about San Francisco and seeing this bridge, in all of its glory and grandeur just brings you to a moment of awe, a moment of true reflection. It is almost as if it becomes just you and the bridge and now one else. 

You need to walk across this bridge from start to finish in order to appreciate it, in order to have a true moment with yourself and with this icon that is known around the world.

The song lyric, "I left my heart in San Francisco" describes anyone who has walked this bridge. And if you are able to walk this bridge with someone you love you can imagine the power and emotion you would feel. So take a walk here, you don't have to pay the $5 toll then!!!, and experience the wonder of the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Sarah G.

description:
Local Flavor? You're kidding right?

How could the Golden Gate NOT get five stars as "Local Flavor"?

If you're not afraid of heights, take the time to walk across it on the east sidewalk. Some truly spectacular views. Bring your camera. Bring a sweater.
author: TJ P.

description:
I have seen it with a lot, a little, and without fog, been walking and driving on it. Every single time spectacular and still an incredible feeling to say: "I've seen it in so many movies, series and photos - and now I'm actually standing here."

It was especially great to visit during the Fleet Week in October, when huge war ships are passing underneath, and jet fighter planes are flying over. Don't miss this!
author: Conny L.

description:
I love riding my bike over the Golden Gate bridge. You wouldn't think it since I try to ride as fast as I can since the wind is cold and riding into the wind is hard ... but it takes your breath away (and not just cause I'm out of shape!!  Round is a shape thank you very much.)  Clear blue skies, water, mountains ... you can't plan for better feng shui.  

Conveniently, the entire west side of the bridge is a bike lane (no pedestrians) cause I have a hard enough time not falling off my bike much less trying to dodge tourists.
author: Kathleen W.

description:
Beauty of nature .. 
Loved it  Great one .. Nice place to visit 
:)
:)
author: umarkashmiri

description:
If you don't like the Golden Gate you are a fool, and possibly a terrorist. Maybe both ...

I don't drive a car, really, so I just get to ride across this lovely landmark in other people's vehicles. Its still a lot of fun. During the summer you can laugh at the tourists wearing shorts and freezing their extremities off. Ha ha to you!

The design of this bridge is amazing, very Art Deco, but absolutely timeless. The color, the styling, the whole thing IS San Francisco.

This is also a great place to commit suicide, I've been told. This morbid little tidbit is reinforced by the film The Bridge where you actually see a few people plunge to their ends. You have been warned ...
author: Wes T.

description:
Don't tell me you came to San Fran and didn't check out THE bridge. It's like, what ya do here, even if you LIVE HERE! I absolutely love Golden Gate Bridge. I'm not sure why, but I've always kind of thought of her as a, well, her. A strong Venetian goddess almost, rising boldly out of the water with her chest puffed proudly and chin to the sky. 

Unbeatable view of the city. If you're feeling ambitious you can also walk all the way over to Marin County, even if it's just to say you did! 

Wear a jacket, it gets windy, and bring a camera or two!
author: Leigh W.

description:
Simply majestic and iconic. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lz7ydUVmsr2DekT9enEhvw?select=pMy-BIXnMlXoK-je_Sm7ZQ

It stood the test of time, as one can see from my dorm room in Starfleet Academy. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Lz7ydUVmsr2DekT9enEhvw?select=SiUReI54YWOJxUi1tz24Og
author: Kenny L.

description:
It was cool... it was windy... and it was a must see.

I didn't walk the entire length of the bridge, it really wasn't necessary.  You can get some really solid shots of the bridge and of San Francisco itself.

Don't bother driving here.  Just take the muni to and back.  I would say wandering around shouldn't take more than 30 minutes.  It is just a bridge after all.  If you want to walk around more... I'd suggest going to Golden Gate Park.  There's more to do there and you still get a feel for the city.
author: Xuan T.

description: It doesn't matter how many times I visit the bridge, I'm always excited to walk it and watch the beautiful view. =) I believe this was my second time actually walking on it and it was sunny too! That's a definite plus. Some people were on a cruise ship yesterday and they passed below us, they were waving up at is and dorks that we were we waved back! It was exhilerating! =) Coming here never gets old.
author: Nani V.

description:
What can I say, it's the Golden Gate Bridge! 

My husband and I figured out transport on the bus to go see the bridge, and it was super easy! Just be aware that the buses that go to the bridge are super packed. But for $2 (which gives you 2ish hours of free bus riding privileges) it's SO worth it. 

One downer is that we couldn't get the binocular viewer thingys to work. Oh well... It was probably user error ;)

I plan on walking across this biatch on my next visit. I wanted to do it this time... But no time :(
author: Carrie O.

description:
It is just amazing...sometimes we really take the simple things in life for granted.  This was my first time seeing the Golden Gate Bridge and it's just incredible to see up close.  

We walked part of the way on the bridge and the view was beautiful.  It was sort of sad to see the "Don't jump" signs with an emergency call box...Other than that though, you definitely need to take the drive out here and walk out onto the bridge.
author: Kressler N.

description: Obviously a popular tourist location. I love it because it's beautiful. Running on it was an awesome experience. 3 miles there and back. You have to run zigzag to avoid bikes and people who are gazing off the bridge at the water but it is so worth it!
author: Rebekah S.

description:
Some really curious reviews for this bridge. There are a lot of reviewers fixated on the high number of suicides that take place here. Yes, it is tragic when someone gets to the point they feel the need to end their life. But what does that have to do with the bridge itself? Nothing! You cannot stop people who are determined to do something. There are a number of other ways to do it. Should they walk in front of Caltrain instead? 

Another reviewer gave it 2 stars and said "It's too bridgey". I was looking for a laughing icon or an LOL but there wasn't any. Too bridgey? I suppose Lake Tahoe is "too watery"?  I'm going to suggest to Yelp they add another rating item for reviews, in addition to useful, funny, and cool: stupid or absurd. 

The GG Bridge is a masterpiece of Architecture and Engineering. Unlike a painting that hangs in  a museum, or a sculpture that gathers dust, it is a utilitarian piece of infrastructure that is used by and is necessary to thousands of people every day. Yet it doubles as art. The fact that it is an icon and draws hundreds of thousands of tourists from all over the world every year is frosting on the cake and adds to its greatness. I have been fascinated by it since I was a kid. Somebody said it wasn't gold, it is rust-colored---FYI the "Golden Gate" itself is the opening connecting the Bay to the Pacific Ocean, not the bridge. And the Bridge's color was specifically intended by the Architect to be the "International Orange" color, never gold. 

The Bridge also has many different looks and feels. Go out by the visitor center at dusk, just as the sun slips below the Western horizon. The bridge silhouetted against the backdrop of the Marin mountains and the sunset is breathtaking, and becomes incredibly romantic as the daylight changes to night. Or on a sunny, cloudless day with the bright blue ocean and sky all around. When the fog rolls in there is yet another completely different look and feel. It doesn't take a lot of imagination to become captivated by this scene, and if you do use your imagination, there is no limit. 

For those who think the bridge is overrated, go out there on a sunny day...any day...by the Cafe and Visitor center, and you will see multitudes of people from all over the world who came to enjoy, photograph, walk, visit, and marvel at this world-class masterpiece. Ask any of them if they think it's overrated. 

I drop it down 1 star from perfect because it is getting ridiculously expensive to drive on it. They are always looking to raise tolls. I know it cost money to maintain. But the cost is too high. It was paid off more than 20 years ago. Tolls should have gone down.
author: Steve J.

description:
Okay, I'll have to admit as a tourist visiting SF for the first time, I mistook the bay bridge for golden gate bridge. I'm sorry!! Don't kill me!! I didn't know SF has 2 main bridges! Forgive my ignorant, out-of-the-country, touristy ass.

Now that I know which is which, GGB is a wondrous marvel. I walked back and forth once on July 4th 2006. What could be better than to spend this great nation's independence day on one of the country's most beloved landmark? Not to mention it was a beautiful day for a walk.

I'm also glad I know where to go if I have $150,000 in debt and no job.
author: Ari C.

description: Felling Great at Golden Gate Bdg
author: Saurabh M.

description:
An Engineering Marvel and must see/visit.

If you're in SF and don't have a chance to ride a bike or walk across, you should at least drive across.

Knowing that it's the most popular suicide destinations in the world can be eery, but it may also make you appreciate life all that much more.
author: Ayall S.

description:
On our class field trip, I let the kids get out and run/walk across the bridge. Visibility was down due to fog, but quite a few of the kids considered this the highlight of the field trip. 

I would love to be able to climb the towers!
author: William G.

description:
I know you're wondering why the heck I gave the Golden Gate Bridge Toll Plaza a 5 star rating * * * * * when it cost $6 to cross. 

As a matter fact I'm wondering that too but since it is part of the world rennowned Golden Gate Bridge and I rated that  * * * * * 5 stars then this can be nothing less then a 5 star rating as well.

If you are a tourist don't forge to get your receipt for this world renowned bridge.

If you are a bay area resident and you have never saved/stored a Golden Gate Bridge receipt, save your next one. People come from all over the world to see and travel this world landmark and we have it in our own backyard, so to speak!
author: Patricia V.

description: If you ever have a chance, you must take a walk on the Golden Gate Bridge. Its a 1.7 miles each way, and the view is just great! you can either park at the SF side or Sausalito side. Although the toll is $6 but for the price of what its worth.. :) Sometimes you discover new things and meet new friends!
author: Lovetea C.

description: I feel so lucky to live so close to one of the most iconic places in our country. The gorgeous Golden Gate Bridge is inspiring to locals and tourists alike. You have the option to drive, walk or bike across it. I recommend walking it at least once in your life. Its a great photo place and the sheer size of it is impressive. Expect there to be traffic, expect there to be fog (that way when it's gorgeous outside, you'll be extra excited!), and expect it to be packed at all times of the day, but it's worth the effort!
author: Kari G.

description: YOU REALLY NEED TO WALK ACROSS THIS BRIDGE! My wife and I did and loved it! On one side you have San Francisco and the other is a old war type area. You can walk around and take tons of pictures. The war like place looks like it had some serious firepower at one point. You can see where the guns would have been mounted. Soooooo much fun!
author: Jeff R.

description:
What more needs to be said about this iconic landmark of San Francisco, the Bay Area, California, and even the United States? It's simply an amazing and beautiful site to see and visit. The Golden Gate Bridge is one of the features that make me happy about being a native and resident of the Bay Area.

Advice for anyone visiting:
Bring along with you a coat, jacket, sweatshirt, or sweater even if the weather is sunny since this location tends to be extremely windy and chilly.
author: Allen N.

description:
After having the most amazing cycle ride of my life to date, we finally reached our destination.

These were the words that spring to mind about Golden Gate Bridge.

 MAGNIFICENT!
SPLENDID! 
AWESOME!
BEAUTIFUL!
GLORIOUS!
AMAZING!
SUPERB!
BRILLIANT!
STUNNING!
JAW-DROPPING!
MAN-MADE WONDERFULNESS!

Luckily because of the time of year we went (May) the bridge was not packed with tourists, so were able to walk, cycle and take pictures.
I'm definitely going here again. :))
author: Omoraka O.

description: beautiful bridge.  I had fun taking pictures here with my family.  The kids had fun driving over it :)
author: AnneMarie N.

description:
The most beautiful bridge ever!

Have driven/walked over numerous times, but the beauty of this old lady never stops to amaze me! A true San Francisco landmark.
author: Anne N.

description:
I think the bridge, the toll plaza and all that rigging needs to be painted GOLD.  I am just tired over and over again tourists thinking that us living in the Bay Area are COLORBLIND.   Either we rename the bridge Orange Gate Bridge or actually paint the bridge gold. 

In regards to the toll plaza.. six bucks going into the city is going to pay for toll takers, bridge repair and cleanup.   Also from far away, the bridge is quite lovely to look at.. dusk, mornings, evenings, middle of the night, fog or brightest and hottest days.

I also must add that the new approach to and from the San Francisco side of the bridge is coming along and they are working very hard to get that finished in the future.  

Its ok..you don't have to paint the bridge Gold.. Orange will do and yes..keep the original name.
author: Tito Y.

description:
Reviewed on 3/5/2009 

Is this a place for peace?
Is this a place for death?
Is this a place to pray?
Or this it a place to play?

To put it short: it's all of the above, plus many more. 

This bridge (~1.7miles across) is just a short drive from one end to the other, but it's the walk and the time that you spend on it that captures the moment. You get to the middle, stand dead still and just look out as far as you can see.... Suck in a deep breath and take in the views from every angle around you. Best time to go is on a nice early semi-chilled morning on the weekends when there's minimal cars/people/dogs so you can be one with it. Maybe bring along your iPod or something or a sandwich..... maybe throw in a pair of nice binoculars too..... 

Forget about all your worries, forget about all the bullshit that's going on in the World today... it's just you and the horizon. When you're out here nothing else matters, you can easily get lost in it's mesmerizing presence.... time flies and you're still standing still, almost frozen.... it's like you're in a different reality.  Sometimes you might get lucky and the fog will roll out and reveal a massive orange structure, it's strong... it's tall..... it's bold...it's built from the slavery hands of my old ancestors..... it's the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Hungry Dan o.

description:
The bridge is stunning on a sunny day. The bright red-orange paint contrasts beautifully against the deep blue of the water and the bright blue of the sky. The bridge is stunning on a clear night. Lights majestically beam on its towers while the city lights of San Francisco glisten from afar. However, my favorite site of the bridge is when the fog starts rolling in on a clear day. The sky is still bright blue, the sun is still beaming, but here comes the blanket of fog...rolling in low, covering the road but revealing the towers... rolling in fast from the ocean and into the bay. When driving across the bridge, it is an awesome site to EXPERIENCE. You drive through the rolling fog! Feels like we're floating in the sky! You can't help but feel so at one with the bridge...if that makes any sense. I lack the vocabulary to truly describe the feeling I get when observing this. When staring at the bridge from either Kirby Cove or Baker Beach, I'm still taken away by the distance between the towers. 

It's free to walk across from either direction, free to drive across from San Francisco going northbound, but there is a hefty toll to drive southbound back into the city (current toll is $6).
author: Helen L.

description:
Screw the windbreaker - bring your winter coat no matter what time of year you're visiting.

Be prepared to endure some unforgivingly cold wind gusts and you'll be treated to some of the best views of SF and one of wonders of the modern world.  This will be one of the most breathtaking 1 1/2 mile walks that you've ever taken (as long as you're not cursing yourself for not dressing warmly enough).
author: Jenny O.

description:
How anybody could give the majestic Golden Gate Bridge a rating below 4 stars is baffling to me.

This is a national landmark. A treasure, a beauty, an absolutely marvelous sight. With all the high tech companies in Silicon Valley, I doubt most of them could have designed and made the bridge when it was made many years ago.

I love walking across the bridge and the occasional bike ride across it to Sausalito. Of course seeing tourists wear shorts and flip-flops expecting the weather to be warm is pretty funny too.

I will forever take photos of the bridge and enjoy it.

My tip: wear a jacket or hoodie and VERY comfortable shoes!
author: Josh O.

description: Giving the 5 stars says it all.
author: Brinda J.

description: I love this bridge. Of course you have to see it when you come to San Francisco. It's historic and beautiful. I have yet to walk across it despite living in the Bay Area my whole life. I'll have to plan to do that sometime soon.
author: Licia L.

description:
On one of my many visits to "The City", I decided to walk to the half way point on the Golden Gate Bridge then cut across during the morning rush hour, returning to the SF side again.  Since 9/11, I don't think this is possible any more because there are cameras every where and I suspect you'll probably be given a ticket.  Also there are shoulder high fences instead of the knee high barriers, making things a little difficult.  I guess, I am a bad boy and I am ashamed of myself for doing this but I couldn't help it.  Another example, I sometimes drive 56 mph in a 55 mph posted speed zone, I like to live life on the edge, Baby!  Ha Ha!!  Besides there were no signs saying I couldn't do it.
OK, I am an idiot, a retard and I have no impulse control.  

What was interesting was the difference between each sides of the bridge.  The side facing the ocean takes quite a beating from the wind and salt corrosion.  The corrosion exposes the many layers of paint all the way down to the metal, it was really, really thick, about a half inch thick. While the other side shows very little wear.

Another interesting fact is the bridge on the SF side is part of the Presido known as Fort Point.  The water moving out to sea under the bridge is surprisingly strong, like a swift river.  It's also a surf break, waves are created from the wake of large freighter ships passing by. They're weak but surfable.  The pictures I took of the surfers look fantastic.  
There you have it, the perfect iconic picture.  Surfers, on a bright and sunny day riding waves under the Golden Gate Bridge.  Epic!
How much more California can you get?
author: Mark T.

description: Enjoyed the ride.  Foggy but could see over fog in places.  Vista point enhanced the view.
author: H C W.

description:
This is a beautiful, beautiful bridge. The largest portion of my travel across it is via bicycle. Which I do about 3-4 times a week for rides.

You really do have to be in decent shape to cross the bridge on your bike. During the week is challenging for a cyclist because you share the pedestrian side as a cyclist which can be annoying. Bring a bell, air horn, whistle or whatever you need to get pedestrian attention. The good news is that the bikes only side- (west side) is open on weekdays starting at 330pm and all day on weekends.

Please, please tourists and other cyclists- hone your handling skills before you make the trip across. Tourists,  please stop using one hand to take a photo of yourself while making a "thizz face" and steer your bike instead, it would greatly reduce the number of accidents on the bridge.  
Be advised that the bridge can be quite cold and windy to ride across. It really is not a good place to take your kids due to congestion of other cyclists and high winds. 

This can be a busy roadway, please pull off to the left to stay out of the way of other cyclists.

And lastly, please wear a helmet- not just those under 18. Placing your helmet on your handlebars is not doing a thing for your noggin.

Be safe and enjoy!
author: Mistress E.

description: Absolutely beautiful. The view of the San Francisco Bay is breathtaking! The walk is very enjoyable. I say do it. It's not cheesy, I promise. Don't take those dumb double decker tour buses here (they give you, like, 10 minutes to explore. Been there, done that). If you're a visitor, find your way here via public transportation, get off, and walk the bridge. Allocate at least 2 hours for walking and taking 1000 pictures that look exactly the same! Bring a sweater, and if you have long hair -- bring a hair tie. TRUST ME.
author: Veda R.

description: Perfect spots offered for photo ops - well maintained grounds and it is just a fun landmark all together.
author: Cassie V.

description:
Me & my bf went there today and yes it was raining and cold but it was so awesome! I love going over the GG but when you walk it (no matter how far you go) it is just amazing!

Oh and dispite the fact it was brick outside there was a ton of people.
author: Bella B.

description: One of my favorite things about the bridge is how you can see it from so many places in the city, totally without expecting it. My most recent sighting was coming up north from Pacifica. You crest a hill and it's like, oh hello there, my friend. Looks just like coming home and it always has to me, even though I didn't live in San Francisco until this year. Reminds me I haven't walked the bridge in over 15 years and I need to rectify that situation.
author: Amanda P.

description: It's the Golden Gate Bridge.  Great views.  Enough said.
author: Bob B.

description:
Such a beautiful bridge.  Seriously, this thing is amazing.  I love it.

Sad thing about it is all the suicides.  If you feel suicidal at all, on any level...do not walk across.  It is too tempting to jump.  Watch the movie "The Bridge" for more info about some of the suicides.
   
Great for photos.  A must see for San Francisco tourists, if only for a half hour.  I love this bridge.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
I like this bridge because...
1) It gives you a very scenic view of the bay and the city
2) The gift shop sign reads "Gifuto shoppu" and never fails to make me giggle

I don't like this bridge because
1) Orange is overrated
2) Large volumes of tourists and jumpers get in my way
3) It's the most expensive bridge toll in SF
author: Judy C.

description:
Walking across the bridge was priority #1 during my visit last year.  I was in town for an entire week but I chose to do this on my birthday.  Besides being an architectural marvel and an iconic American image, the bridge is a thrill to walk across.  The views of the bay and city are incredible, and the Sausalito side was a pleasant surprise too.  That day was windy as hell, and I have a bit of a fear of heights to begin with, so there was a tinge of alarm underlying the trek which only served to make it more thrilling. 

I wasn't happy that bicyclists got their own side, but could also bike on the pedestrian side of the bridge.  Most of the bikers who passed us were not too courteous despite the facts that we outnumbered them about 100:1 and that THEY HAVE THEIR OWN SIDE where pedestrians are not allowed.  

That was just a small hiccough in an otherwise perfect two hours (we took our time).  I will definitely remember that birthday thanks to the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: David R.
