description: I'm so in love with the Golden Gate Bridge. It is so incredibly beautiful and serene, and will literally take your breath away. I have been walking on this bridge since I was a little girl and every time is like the first. On a clear day you can lookout onto the bay and just let your mind and imagination carry you away. I suggest everyone make it here once in your life, you'll never forget it.
author: Ashley M.

description: What trip to San Francisco is complete without a ride across the Golden Gate? A definite must-go when visiting the city.
author: Christine A.

description: The architecture is obviously brilliant and the views of the city and ocean are breath-taking. But the experience of being around the bridge and walking on it are separate from its historical significance. There's just too many people, too many cars, and too much going on to really enjoy this gorgeous modern wonder. Be warned. You will leave with your head spinning from all the chaos going on. Also, it's about a 90 minute walk if you walk to and from both ends.
author: I G.

description: Honestly, Golden gate is the most beautiful place that I have never seen before. I had a great fun here. I love it.
author: Harry G.

description:
Yes, i'm the hell out of Suckamento and in SF

you can still get your dose of negative ions by being above the water. the air is always refreshing and plenty of tourist to keep you people watching for the entire walk over the bridge.

if you're the tour guide, its always funny to see how far a person or group can go. usually, its not far. i've been there with healthy young friends, parents, and old old ladies that can barely walk. they all go 1/4 mile at most. then complaints start kicking in, hunger, scared of heights, and the cold of course is a great reason to quit and walk back. i think this is a great modern bridge. 

Don't go swimming. you're gonna need a wet suit. a helmet, knee pads, and a neck brace afterwards. that is if the rocks don't kill you first.

Bike and hiking trails are right below the bridge and if you go far enough on the trails there is a big park with beaches and a ton of space for people to play. but truly my favorite is watching the sailboats pass under the bridge. 

always stop in at the souvenir shop on the way down. it's nothing you can't buy at a local Walgreens, but its always nice to say, you got it there.

AHHHH Nostalgia
author: Noy K.

description: Beautiful! From a distance the Bridge is intimidating. For some reason I thought it was steeper but it was such a pleasant walk. The views are unsurpassed and it really is an engineering marvel. Definitely check out the outside exhibits and the gift shop. They often show informational videos and you can get some good material for water cooler trivia.
author: Kristie F.

description:
I love love love LOVE this bridge.

Not only is it absolutly gorgeous but it leads into an amazing city full of amazing people (a few of whom I love very much).  

It's always a wonderful sight to drive over the hill out of Sausalito and see the bridge.  Crossing is amazing.  And i don't even mind paying a toll to cross.  The toll people are usually very nice.  

I walked across the bridge for the first time the other day.  I've always lived near by and I've never done this.  Amazing!  Sad story but there was an accident while we were crossing, didn't have to see it happen, but we did witness some sad scenes.  BUT the South bound lane was empty and Northbound was at a dead stop so we were walking on the bridge, like in the middle of the road.  Word up!  Sorry that people had to get hurt though, i hope they're ok.
author: desiree n.

description:
We crossed the Golden Gate Bridge twice during our lovely trip to SF Bay Area with our rental car. Tried paying the toll online multiple times withing 48 hours but the FasTrak website is down.  Website is saying "
We are moving from Thursday, June 12th-Monday, June, 16th. Access to your account, invoice or violation will not be available during this time.".
Tried calling the Toll Free number (1-877-BAY-TOLL) Customer Service but never getting through. Returned home to AZ and spoke with the representative from Avis Rental Car and they said we will most likely get a letter from Avis but according to FasTrak we have 21 days to pay before a $25 Violation fee per toll crossing. Now we wait and hope for the best.  How stressful and annoying...can't talk or deal with anyone.  Maybe rental car customers should have a longer grace period before the violation fee? So instead of paying $14 for toll we are now waiting for a letter for possible $64.  Thank you, California!
author: Helena K.

description: Great, iconic structure, one of the best and most picturesque in the nation!!!  Great views from the bridge, and of the bridge from many points in San Francisco, especially, Coit Tower, on a clear day...Sausalito in the distance and looking back to Presidio and Fisherman's Wharf!
author: R J.

description:
If you decide to walk the span bring a very warm jacket.  It may be calm on the ends but the center portion is unbelievably windy.

For a unique view of this bridge, go to the south tower visitor's center and walk past the Strauss Statue down to the picnic grounds.  You'll get a great sideways view of the bridge!

Times visited: 4+
author: Amy L.

description:
Having grown up in the bay area, I've definitely driven across the bridge many-a-time. It's pretty much awesome (although I'm yet to walk or bike across it and play tourist). 

Toll sucks, ($6) but Northbound has no toll, which is cool. View is nice, it's a great color... sometimes traffic sucks. They change the number of lanes going in each direction depending on the time of day or the day of the week, hmm... it makes it so you can drive across the bay and don't have to swim or take a boat... that's nice.

I wonder if people travel to California just to go over the bridge. That would be kind of ridiculous.
author: Tiffany C.

description: On a sunny day, it is a great walk across and back. Come in layers as it gets breezy once you get on the bridge. Great reason to stop in for a nice hot chocolate or Irish coffee afterwards to warm down.
author: Trang H.

description: Such a beautiful bridge. After we crossed the bridge by leaving SF, we had to pay the toll on our way back into SF which was $6 for those without a Fastrak. If you have a Fastrak then it's $5. Also, you don't stop. So if you don't have a Fastrak, you pay by license plate by going online and putting in your license plate number and paying that way. You can do it ahead of time if you know you're going to cross the bridge prior to crossing it or you have up to 48 hours after you've already crossed it.
author: Nari L.

description: Rent a bike, cross the bridge and return back to the city on the ferry. Good fun and great views.
author: Joey M.

description: Great place to take relatives/out of town friends for a afternoon walk.  We read up on the history of this magnificent bridge, get great views of the bay and work up some good exercise!  Taking a walk will also save you the $6 (or $7) car fee and you can take in more of the sights.
author: Susan C.

description:
Every time I fly up to San Francisco (which is once a year) I ALWAYS find time to visit The GG Bridge.  Whenever I visit the bridge I am always amazed of how magnificent it is.  I could seriously just sit somewhere and stare at the bridge for hours.  

If anyone is planning on visiting San Francisco this is a must see.  It is easy to get here by public transportation either by bus or by doing a tour.  It is cold and windy when you are on the bridge if you do decide to walk it, but trust me it's worth it.
author: Ku'ulei R.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge was the largest, most grandeur bridge in the world at that time with the art deco design and the international orange color (Orange Vermillion) that looks awesome in the San Francisco bay sky line. Construction began in 1933 during the Great Depression and ended in 1937.

About 41 million travelers pass through the bridge yearly. 

I would recommend everyone to go visit the bridge:

- either you drive across for $6 and park your car on the other end of the bridge and look at the view - go to Marin Headlands. Parking can be really difficult.

- Take a hop on and off tour bus that will take care of the toll and parking for you.

- Rent a bike and bike across the bridge. Start off at the beginning of the bridge at South Vista point to have a post card view.

Jog or walk across the bridge.

This is a spectacular landmark! A must See in the USA.
author: Charles P.

description:
Is this the most iconic bridge in the world? I've been thinking and can't come up with anywhere that comes even close.


 I'm not sure it is actually worth going up on the bridge itself mind you. The view is good I suppose, but there are better views to be had from above San Francisco. The amount of warnings about suicide can be a bit of a downer tooso I prefer to look at the bridge from the water's edge.
author: Chris F.

description: We took the hop on and hop off bus while in SF, and we were extremely lucky since it was Fleet week as well as America's sailboat challenge! For the many days we were in San Francisco, we were able to see the Golden Gate bridge without any fog or rain! It was perfect!
author: Sharon K.

description:
TIP:  parking, go past the first lot and continue through the tunnel up to the 3rd lot.  The first two is metered, the 3rd lot is free for 4 hours.  It's not that far away; easy walking distance but if you have elderly, just let them off on the side somewhere out of the way to the far right on the lower lot.

Wear ear muffs or a hood and bundle up!  Watch out for bike riders and be courteous on the paths.
author: Hermann C.

description:
One of the unnatural wonders of the world. While driving across is fine, walking or cycling it is definitely better. Beautiful and imposing on, off or beside it. At present the west side ( sea side) is blocked off, making cyclists share the east(city side) with pedestrians. Makes it difficult until halfway. Advantage of cycling is you can cycle down to Sausalito for lunch, then ferry back to the embercado or Pier 41. And you even go past Alcatraz on the boat journey back.

To prepare for your walk/ cycle across watch the magnificent documentary : THE BRIDGE about people jumping off it, and the situations that got them there. Moving and sad.

Also remember it's San Francisco and it's going to be cool whenever you cross it . Enjoy the ride.
author: Pantera W.

description:
What can I say?  When one sees or hears about the GGB, they immediately think of San Francisco.  

For years, I have passed over this bridge, zombie-like on my way home from parties in the Marina, and rarely thought much of the large bridge beneath my car.  This came to fruit and to my senses several weeks ago, when my touristy friend begged to walk across it.  

It was not until the third support beam, that one can gaze in belief at the magnitude and wonder of this.....my friend was busy taking pictures and oo-ing and aa-ing.  We never finished the walk, even though I was ready to go forth.  He started to complain that his feet hurt. Booooo!
author: Miika M.

description:
Unmissable. A walk across by foot is a fantastic experience (you can bus across and walk back - it's quite a long way to walk there and back) and there are plenty of vantage points on land to take some iconic photos, too. The beaches on the Pacific side to the south also have some great views.


 What impressed me most was the fact that such a great feat of engineering - it was the world's longest single span from 1937 until 1964 - is also so beautiful, with its Art Deco detailing. (And don't forget, it's in an earthquake zone too).


 I also had fun trying to spot the places where it appeared in the books by 'Tales of the City' by Armistead Maupin. (These books or the DVD of the TV series are also a must before a visit to SF, or make great reading while you are there).
author: David J.

description:
Iconic. Masterful. $6 toll. WTF?

Honestly you need to walk across this bridge at least once in your life. But you will likely have to do it twice because they don't have shuttle from one side to the other and you'll have to get back to your car somehow.  However there are several cabbie eager to pick up wearied tourists on both sides to take them back across the 1.7 Mile expanse.  

Just go on a clear day because otherwise I imagine the walk would be quite miserable. Even on clear days it can be very windy and the constant flow of fumes from traffic, just a few feet away, being blown down your wind pipe really doesn't help improve the situation either.
author: Brandon T.

description: Just an amazing sight. We were part of a tour that drove over the bridge when it was sunny and we also drove over it in our car when there was low cloud and both sights were very impressive. Make sure to see it and take pictures from Fort Point, Fort Baker and from the Marin headlands. All great sights.
author: T J.

description: Must see and a must to drive through, literally cause that's how you get into frisco! Knowing the history and facts of the bridge makes it so much more appreciable ! Never get tired of coming here!
author: Jessica B.

description: This bridge doesn't need to be reviewed. It is too amazing and is a very beautiful California landmark. Breathtaking.
author: Terri L.

description:
Number one of my ten reasons why I still live here in San Francisco, seriously.....naaahhh just kidding.
I love this city, and this bridge makes me love the city even more. 
Golden Gate Bridge is simple but beautiful and majestic.
Here's my still ongoing personal project.
http://www.flickr.com/photos/anakdewa/sets/72157594284497280/
author: toto h.

description:
A few years ago, my husband's (then, boyfriend) company took us on a weekend trip to San Francisco.  Part of the trip, included a morning walk across the Golden Gate Bridge.

Now, for anyone who knows me, you know that I don't do "early morning" *anything*.  However, I used to work at this wonderful company (they would "kidnap" the entire company plus guests every 5 years for a magical long weekend - all expenses paid.  SF was the most recent "Magical Mystery Tour"), and I didn't want to let my old coworkers or my husband down...so I gamely got up, and miserably crawled into the bus to do the walk across the GGB at some ungodly hour in the morning (I think it was 9 or 10.  UGH.  UNGODLY!).

I was so cold, so wet from the fog, and so miserable with the need to crawl back into bed (yet, keeping a chipper smile on my face), that I seriously understood why people lept off of this bridge.  However, just as I was ready to do it - I spied a sign that told me that "THERE IS HOPE".  And at that moment, I realized that I was a mere 100 feet from the end of the bridge (and to where the warm bus was awaiting me!).  So I didn't jump.

Thank you Golden Gate Bridge!  The sign worked!  Also, the promise of food, coffee, and booze, helped with the non-jumping.  Heh.

P.S.  Upon reviewing all the photos we took during that walk, I will admit the view was spectacular and the experience was invigorating.
author: Fenny L.

description: I always love going across this bay area landmark. When I was younger my grandpa and I walked across the bridge and one of the workers gave my grandpa one of the screws he was replacing for the bridge. I always remember walking the bridge with my grandpa.
author: Brian B.

description: Though this is a very famous spot where many people go to kill themselves; the Golden Gate Bridge is an amazing bridge. I took my friend's senior portraits on this bridge on a very cloudy day a couple of years ago. I mean, there is not much you can talk about this bridge if you are driving. Walking, is a different story. You get to see an amazing view and it doesn't seem as long as it is. On the over side, naturally, is overpriced food to satisfy your thirst. Besides that, it is extremely beautiful architecture and breathtaking at night. It is getting 4 stars because well...it's a bridge!
author: Emma H.

description:
THE MOST BEAUTIFUL AND STUNNING BRIDGE! 

I've lived here in the Bay Area for my entire life and I'm in love with this bridge. I've walked it twice with my parents and my brother and it was wonderful! We were lucky and came on a clear sunny day  and it was absolutely breath taking! The view of the ocean was gorgeous and overall the whole thing was very fun. A great thing to do with anyone and a must see in San Francisco.
author: Jackie R.

description:
I've lived in the Bay Area for over 10 years & I have never driven over the GG Bridge, but recently I went on my first run across the bridge! 
It was definitely an experience to have. There are great views all around you when you run the bridge. I suggest to bring a camera & take it all in :)

Downside is that it gets really crowded, people rent bikes to ride across the bridge, and the area isn't that big so I had to always move around people while running.
author: Nicole A.

description:
Ahhh, the iconic Bay Area Bridge. The most beautiful bridge I have ever seen, and I am not just biased because I am from the Bay Area. 

We have yet to walk the bridge, but frequently take drives all over the bay area and when we have a chance on clear days we love to drive through the city to the North Bay on this bridge. On the weekends it is really cool to see all of the people who are walking the bridge. 

A must do if you live in or are visiting the bay area.
author: Nicole C.

description: One of the most beautiful structures in the world!
author: Philip C.

description:
One of the most recognizable landmarks and images in America.  Possibly even the world.

FTW!
author: Greg B.

description:
Beautiful bridge, beautiful sight, beautiful place. and such a nice sensation of riding by the bridge. the other side of it is very cool, too!
A nice Natural park and a nice place to be.
Have you ever been there? I recommend! :o)
author: bruxaod

description:
Ive lived in the Bay Area for 19 months now, and driven over the bridge many times, but today i actually got to walk across it.
The views were spectacular and it is such a nice walk.
Wear plenty as it is very windy, and sunscreen too, as you dont notice the sun in the wind.
I took my dogs with me today and got stopped (luckily on my way back) and was told no dogs on the bridge :(
The west side of the bridge is closed at the moment so cyclists are having to share the sidewalk with pedestrians and it can be a bit crazy.
The SF side there is a small parking lot 25cents for 15 mins, max 2 hours, I believe there is an overflow parking lot available at weekends and holidays for $5 for the day.
There is the usual gift shop and cafe etc on the SF side, but on the other side there is only restrooms.
Now Ive walked it once Ill definitely do it again. I can see why its on peoples Bucket List.
author: sarah s.

description:
Went to Mexico City years ago for work and when someone I was working with found out I was from San Francisco thought I was very lucky because the Golden Gate Bridge is beautiful and I get to see it every day. I guess we take things for  granted.

As a side note, she also pointed out the Spanish version of Alice In Wonderland I bought as a souvenir was actually in French so I must have walked into the French book store around the corner from the office and I didn't know the difference.

I can't look at the bridge the same after seeing the movie The Bridge by Eric Steel, but it's still beautiful.
author: Ronny C.

description:
The Golden Gate bridge walk was one of the most enlightening things I have done.  My love for San Francisco grew more and more as we walked on the bridge yesturday afternoon.  After months of planning and rescheduling due to normal scheduling, we finally set the date to walk on the bridge and finally check this off of my bucket list.  last November a guy I was talking to mentioned walking on the Golden Gate bridge.... little did i know that his statement and/or conversation would eventually lead me to actually doing it.  


Yes its windy, yes its cold.  I brought out my winter gear just for the sake of walking on the bridge. Everything came out of my closet from gloves, a scarf, leg warmers and a beanie. I could've had added warmth if I had worn my ear muffs.  I wasn't even afraid of not making the trek because it was shorter than walking around Lake Merced.  

The only elements that you were up against were the winds, especially on the Saulsalito side, the fog and the occassional biker that wanted you out of the way.  It was pictureseque.  The sites of the bay and the beautiful view of San Francisco mixed with the historical bridge made it a sight to see.  The fog was just perfect enough so you wouldn't get too hot on the walk.  I even had to use one hot hands just to keep warm throughout the walk.  

I strongly recommend if you are in good health to do it at least once in your life.  I have now checked off something off of my bucket list and i can yelp about it.
author: Daphne A.

description:
Despite how I feel about how much it cost for the toll plaza I think the Golden Gate Bridge is amazing. I think if one has the opportunity they should take a chance and walk across it. Me,well I could not do it again because it makes me dizzy(very dizzy). 

Driving across is nice,but if you are a tourist you are more probably to enjoy the view and experience. What I like about crossing this bridge is the fact that Sausaltio(spell check),oops I find wonderful and beautiful. I like the drive up north with views of the oceans and many stops to hike and camp.There is so much to see when you cross this bridge and take a drive up north. Nature is so nice,relaxing and beautiful and I wish more people would like it as much as I do.

I like Humboldt too(winks) 
I like Wine County
I like Mendocino
I love the coast basically...

Nice views and a nice drive on a sunny day up north with many places to stop at and enjoy on the coast...so visit and go through the Golden Gate Bridge after that walk across.
author: Dani D.

description:
My two favorite bridges in all the world.  The Golden Gate and the Bay Bridge.  

What can I say about the golden lady.  The Bay on one side, the pacific on the other.  shrouded in fog.  I used to love driving into the headlands... driving over the golden gate with the wind in my hair on a sunny day... sigh.  i thought it would never end!  but i was wrong.  i moved to dc.  and it's just plain ugly here.  shoulda gone over that ol' girl one more time before i left.

see, the golden gate is not just about the bridge itself.  it's about the surrounding headlands on one side, and the fort below on the other... the wineries above her and the bustling city below her.  It's a state of mind... for which she is the standard.   I miss the golden gate life.  i can't wait to go back when i've made my millions =P
author: paul l.

description: Love love love the walk on this bridge even though my foot got busted because my shoes suck.  The view is amazing especially on a cloudless day.  So beautiful!  Also, the people you meet along the bridge are so fun and happy to be alive and out and about.  My cousin and I had a great time taking group photos for people, out of towners, and cuties from overseas (men and women).  I've lived in the bay for all my life, and this was my first time I've done it.  I wish I did it so many more times!!  It's one of the most beautiful places in the world.  I'm going to do it again.  Love it love it love it.
author: Kristin O.

description:
Okay anyone who lives in SF and doesn't rate the bridge as a 5 star review just needs to move. 

How is this not the best bridge ever? Everyone knows it when you see it. It has a great color and stylish look. Plus you can run across it and be included in countless tourist photos to be immortalized in their memories while wearing your "Fear the Beard" shirt.

Name 1 bridge that is better - I defy you! 

Win-win!
author: Nick B.

description: It stayed up while I drove over it, five stars! It's pretty humbling to walk across this modern marvel, I can't even fathom the intellect it took to create this monster. Awesome.
author: Kevin G.

description:
Tourist spot!! I love the golden gate bridge. One of my favorites, probably because it's my favorite color -RED! =p

Most of the time I've come here, its a little cloudy, but on the day we came it was GORGEOUS!! We came on a weekday afternoon around 3PM in October.
author: Leanne D.

description: It would crazy if this bridge was actually painted gold hence the name "Golden" gate bridge. Hehe... Always a lovely view to see the bridge & it's one of the symbols for SF. Toll is higher here. Went across once so far...
author: Amy C.

description: The symbol of San Francisco. I used to drive across the bridge every day as I would commute into Marin. I can truly say that I never took it's beauty for granted (except when it was completely enveloped by fog). It's a great bridge to sightsee, run across, propose...you name it. Apparently it's a popular place to commit suicide (http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0799954/), but we won't get into that.
author: Carlos A.

description: The Golden Gate Bridge is truly a phenomenon. Absolutely  breathtaking and beautiful!  It is spectacular and don't forget to bring a camera! On a clear spring day you will get great pictures, but may not have as much luck on a foggy day like the day that I went. There is so much to see here sailboats, sparkling blue water, the hills in the background. Don't leave San Francisco without seeing the beautiful Golden Gate Bridge!
author: Nicole F.

description: It's a toll plaza where people eek out a living.  It looks damn depressing.    I look out my bus window each morning into the "command post" and think  "Military Command Post" - the over-weight guys with the coffee cups that lord over those not blessed to be in the room watching TV screens all day.
author: Steve S.

description: What really can anyone say about this bridge that's not shy of miraculous?  Walking and footpath options open vistas beyond imagination and this Golden Gate shines on so many vantage a in San Francisco its hard to ignore the beauty it holds.  Truly a feat of creative engineering worthy of praise!
author: Mr B.

description:
nothing like visiting a location which is a monumental staple in american history.

there is a toll, don't forget to bring cash... but it's such a beautiful bridge. there are so many people on it, walking, riding their bicycles, and driving on it at any given moment, but my is it pretty. 

i really enjoyed visiting this tourist magnet, i had the joy of having a friend in SF to drive me up up up the mountain and getting a better view from a quiet location in the hills overlooking the beautiful city of SF.

loved it. cant wait to go back.
author: Ava M.

description: Beautiful!  Beautiful to see, to drive through, to take photos of..its beautiful!
author: Ami T.

description: I love this bridge.  I am a big fan of crossing bridges and then walking back across toward a city (I'm looking at you, Brooklyn Bridge!).  I've been to San Francisco a few times now and have only gotten to stop at the bridge once before.  I was so happy when my friend was in no hurry either and wanted to stop to walk across.  It got really foggy that morning, but the sun peeked out just enough to get some nice shots.  Talk about micro-climates though!  Hot and sunny in one spot.  Drizzly and humid in another.  Cold and windy in yet another.  We got a double workout from the walk and then the marathon of dressing and undressing!  It was worth it though.  Beautiful bridge. Beautiful views.
author: Julie S.

description:
It's the #1 bridge on countless travel channel specials, but most importantly its such a bay area gem. So much historical value, and it's just gorgeous. I'm a bay area native and I am still in awe every time I see the bridge. 

We parked at Vista Point and actually had a chance to walk on the bridge for a bit. I think the last time I did that was when  I was a kid. It was a beautiful sunny January day and I could cleary see San Francisco and Alcatraz.
author: Lynn C.

description:
Before the war he left behind his wife and 3 youngins, and boarded a big boat bound for San Francisco. The peasants' yacht sailed past Australia, Hawaii and the calm waters of the Pacific until the Golden Gate was in sight. It stood tall and proud through the fog, a beaming orange titan bridging the Old World to the New. Leonard wondered if he had made the wrong decision. Perhaps his wife and son and baby girls were already butchered by the Japanese. Maybe he should have stayed in Taisan. It was too late to go back now. The vessel drifted past Angel Island and anchored into harbor.

Fresh off the boat, he washed dishes in Chinatown, working his way up to office clerk at a dental clinic. He learned how to speak American. He bought new clothes and a necktie. He wore a fedora instead of hair. Leonard dropped the chopsticks and picked up a fork to enjoy prime rib at Lucky Penny. While reading his wife's letters, he savored hot chowder on the Pier to stay warm. San Francisco was his new home. Months and wages went by until one autumn morning- Leonard stood at the edge of the Presidio watching the ships sail through the Golden Gate. A foghorn bellowed as the boat entered the dock. This one held a woman and three children who would make complete the much desired reunion he longed for in his mind.
author: Mico C.

description: The GGB. I live quite close to this place and i walk/biked across it many times. Came with my GF today and we walked across the bridge. They definitely need to make one side of the place for bikers only. We are trying to stroll across the bridge and here are  reckless speeding ass bikers trying to run us over. gg,
author: Frederick A.

description:
This is one of the most recognizable landmarks of the west coast and the world. Paris - Eiffel Tower. New York City - Stature of Liberty Philadelphia - Liberty Bell. Buffalo - uh, I'll get back to you on that one. 

To continue, San Francisco - Golden Gate Bridge. Check out Manabu M's review of the Golden Gate Bridge for more facts than you can shake a stick at. I love the scale of the bridge. It is huge, as in way way big. It is always windy on the bridge and if you are on foot, the wind will cut through your clothes unless you have a warm wind breaker. 

My favorite time at the bridge was when the Queen Mary came to San Francisco. We were late to get parking by the Marina or Chrissy Field, so we ended up at the south end of the Golden Gate Bridge. The Queen Mary was later than expected, so we walked about half way across. Froze to pieces, as we were not dressed for the stroll. It was amazing watching the Queen Mary come under the bridge, wondering if it would fit. The Liberty Ship Jeremiah Johnson looked like a mid-sized yacht as it escorted the Queen Mary to port. A grand vision I shall never forget.
author: Nancy B.

description: The first time I went to San Francisco I was not able to visit the GG Bridge. Finally, after 8 years and near my birthday, I can cross the Golden Gate Bridge off my bucket list and it was everything I expected. Beautiful and had a sense of calmness to the area. We were able to walk half way to the bridge for some nice scenic pictures but had to call it quits because it got extremely cold and windy. Sweater or jacket is strongly suggested because it was windy and cold. We will visit come again.
author: Neang C.

description: This is a 2 hour ordeal to walk to and from. Great experience! Loved it, watch out for the cyclists, they have no mercy!
author: P.S. S.

description:
I have been under and over the Golden Gate Bridge on a motorcycle, and it is a site to see. You can take a car, motorcycle, bike cycle or walk along   Marine Dr. till you see the water crashing against the rocks with the GG Bridge in the back ground. On a warm & windy day there are surfers that ride the wind with a para shoot gadget. Some jump waves as far as 10-15 feet high. Something I've never seen before. You can see in the back grown of the waves some of the para shooters. 

By StacyPoulos  2009 http://www.postcardtravelers.com/
author: Stacy P.

description: I cant stop looking at the Golden Gate Bridge - it's just so breathtaking! On par with the Eiffel Tower with icons you cant tear your eyes from!
author: Grace M.

description:
Golden Gate is my favorite bridge in the world!  (yes, it's better than even the London Bridge)

it's beautiful in the sunshine!  it's beautiful in the fog!  i love it lit up in the nighttime!  it's just perfect.  

what can i say.  i'm in love with this bridge.  i just wish it wasn't so expensive to cross. :)
author: Jennifer O.

description: This thing is amazing!  It will get you from one side of the water to the other without having to use a boat!!!!!!  I remember once when playing the Oregon Trail, we had the option of Fording the River (like a Man), Taking the Ferry, or Caulking our Wagon and floating across.  I'm pretty sure none of these options would have worked here so thank God for the bridge.  Sally and my oxen would have drown on the ford, the ferry would have been too expensive, and I don't think my wagon would have survived the float.  Bravo Golden Gate Bridge... Bravo.
author: Mike B.

description: Ride a bike across.  Spectacular views!  Biked to Sausalito and take the ferry back.
author: DJ J.

description: Definitely a must-see if you come to San Francisco. I live close enough that when I come to the city, I often don't go the Golden Gate Bridge, but I'm always amazed when I do.
author: Barbara S.

description:
i have a kickass bird's eye view of this signature bridge as my backdrop~

it's so much fun to bike over this bridge EXCEPT...watch out for the pedestrians that don't know how to get out of your way....i couldn't brake in time and ended up ramming into the rails to avoid a child...needless to say i was left w/ some bruises but it was still a good experience~
author: Donna S.

description:
I commute 25-30 minutes each way every day and, in addition to gas, it costs me $5 every day! The Golden Gate Bridge is beautiful but I dream of a day when it might offer deals to commutes who just barely cross over it only to pay $5 and drive back at the end of the day... and that's $5 with FastTrack, it's $6 without! $5 is two Starbucks or an udon bowl and seaweed salad from YoYo's or... something more exciting than just a bridge toll!

Luckily, I do have one of the most gorgeous imaginable commutes though. The Golden Gate Bridge is beautiful and surprisingly fast when you are counter-commuting. It's quite a San Francisco landmark and I do truly love it I just don't love that it eats my hard-earned money!
author: Meghan P.

description:
Every time I come to San Francisco, I walk the bridge. (**warning - please bring a jacket.. especially if you are walking the bridge in the late afternoon)

Great views of the city and partially of Marin County. Oh and if you go late enough in the afternoon/evening, you can get a great view of the sunset. Probably one of the best seats in the house lol.
author: Eduardo S.

description:
I judge anyone who gives it lower than 5 stars.

ps: a lot of people who complain about the tourists are tourists themselves.
author: Jenny U.

description: It is hard to find parking, especially if you just want to take a quick picture.  Beautiful bridge.  Bring money for toll.
author: Carlene R.

description:
I can't believe I haven't written a review of this yet. I waited an agonizing 22 years to see this damn bridge, and it did NOT dissapoint! When I drove over it in the middle of the night (entering San Fran) I started screaming and freaking out. When I got to stand in front of it and take pictures I had smiles for miles.

So you may not be as nutty and easily excited as I am, but you still won't be able to help yourself here. Only a black hearted whench wouldn't love this bridge!
author: Erin H.

description: One thing I hadn't expected I'd do when I went to Frisco was walk across (or at least halfway across) the GG Bridge. Very interesting experience, tho I should've worn a hat!! The wind was cold that day & I got a nasty burn on my forehead! But, it was a cool experience. There's a palatable feeling of awe that you get when you pass one of the pillars/towers & you can actually touch it.
author: Tom T.

description:
How the heck can people give this a good rating? Bet your butt you wouldn't be if you DID live on the Marin side and had to go into the city 6 days a week. yeah yeah the bridge is beautiful and the scenery too, but we aren't reviewing the bridge, we're reviewing the TOLL PLAZA! Thats like reviewing your bill at a restaurant. "This is such a lovely restaurant!" 
"Oh wait till you see the check presenter- its truly remarkable."
author: David D.

description: Beautiful View of the city!  Good place to take pictures and get some exercise walking across the bridge. lol
author: Sandy N.

description:
my first reveiw on YELP!
My parents came to visit this summer and I took them to the bridge. it is definitely a right desicion. I was worried they would easily get tired, but turned out they didn't, and they loved it!! What an impressive experience!
For folks who hasn't been there before, bike the bridge would be strongly recommened. rent the bikes from blazing saddles at pier39 (remember there's a 10% discount, you don't mention, you won't get it) and start the tour there, bike all the way to Sausalito and took the ferry back
it's a bit foggy on Tuesday but the view was still great!!! 
Golden gate bridge is the essence of SF!
author: Qifei S.

description:
Awesome. I love driving in from Marin County into SF through the Golden Gate Bridge. Something magical and awing and humbling about the experience. As you downshift and slow your car down to match the speed of the cars in front of you, you're able to steal quick glances to pedestrians, bicyclists, and similarly awe-struck tourists walking along the pathways lining the bridge. 

Driving on this bridge never gets old. 

I love it when the fog rolls in, and you can barely see 100 feet in front of you. Normally, I'm pissed when traffic is slowing me down so that it takes 15 minutes to travel 1 mile, but time stands still while you're driving on this bridge.

Just make sure you have $6 for the toll if you're driving into the city. And this bridge is a photographer's wet dream.
author: Will C.

description: Do we really need to review this? It's the Golden Gate Bridge for god's sake!
author: Marc L.

description: You have to visit the bridge if you are in SAN FRAN.  It is one of the most beautiful things I've seen.  The bridge is pretty long so be prepared, wear comfortable shoes.  I would laso suggest a light jacket because it gets pretty cold up there.  Also, be sure to check out the gift shop, they have pretty cool items in there.
author: Dieunane F.

description:
Can you believe it? As a native San Franciscan, I had never walked across the entire bridge until last month. Instead, I would walk halfway and then back. Figured that would equate to a full trip. Haha... 

Anyways, the BF and his dad wanted to take a nice Sunday afternoon stroll. It was a beautiful sunny day, so the drive through the Presidio to the bridge was quite enjoyable. Save yourself some money and park in the Presidio... there are several lots within walking distance to the entrance of the bridge that are free to the public.
author: Teresa Y.

description: Ridiculous traffic signs and extortion at toll gates. If you go wrong way no option than returning back to bridge and pay the toll again. How on earth a tourist can always get it right and be able to go correct route? When you come out of southside parking, if you want to go downtown their are no fucking signs and the first thing you do as a driver is take a right and it takes you to "No turnarounds" which means do a charity and throw another fucking 7 bucks on their face.
author: Ahj K.

description: I just got a bill in the mail that said I owed $7.00 for crossing the bridge on 11/18/14 the due date is 1/26/15 I went to pay it today 1/14/15 and it is supposedly passed due and I owe $32 dollars what? I tried calling and was on hold for ever I tried disputing it on-line and the invoice would not upload because of the content? I am so frustrated I rather have a person take my money as I cross like back in the day to avoid all the hassle. I sent my $7.00 payment in the with the invoice hopefully nothing bad happens and they correct the problem.
author: Maria S.

description: I've always been impressed by the Golden g. bridge.  But I hate the toll. I heard that it was planned to end soon but then I saw it increasing, increasing, and increasing.
author: Raj S.

description:
I don't think you are allowed to give the Golden Gate Bridge anything less than 5 stars. It's the Golden Gate Bridge after all, a landmark and truly the only Golden Gate Bridge out there. 

I love taking my out of town guest to the bridge! It's fun to walk over to the other side and really stop and take pics as you go. Note you will need coin for the parking meters. You will have two hours to walk across and back to your car. It's enough time if you don't pause too long for each photo opp. If you drive across be sure to stop at both view points so you really get both perspectives and you have to drive up in to the Marin Headlands on a clear day, the view is amazing!
author: Marissa P.

description: Finally faced my fear and walked the Golden Gate Bridge! I told my daughter that mommy was too scared and she said she will hold my hand and it will be ok...how can I not do it after that?!? It was beautiful! So glad I didn't punk out! Plus we could have met Erik Spoelstra... Saw him as we were leaving the ladies room and he was heading towards us.. But I didn't stop the man from answering nature's call.. Should have so the kids could take a pic with him.. but decided to keep it moving, we were here for the bridge, not him lol...so make sure check this place out, you'll love it!
author: Thuy D.

description:
Just 13.5 months ago a friend asked me to shoot her and her fiance's Engagement photos. We ended up here after the Palace of Fine Arts. I was amazed on how this place was here. And so just a couple of days ago I decided to take a friend to show how amazing our Area is.

Not as crowded San Francisco side and the View is amazing. The empty abandoned army bunkers are really cool. Go during the day for the bunker exp, but at night for the view of the light.

It was my first time going here at night a couple of days ago after haven't been here for about a year.

Further down the road going up the hills it will lead you to a one way zig zag road and you'll pass by these other secluded parking spaces next to more abandone bunkers. Park and walk up the steps and you'll freaking know what I mean...I'll pull up some photos I took here to show you what I mean.

Then as you go even more down the road, you'll end up at the beach! Seriously, how can you beat a billion dollar scenary, a little nastolgic Amercian history and ending up at the beach....my gosh...seriously x 1.10101 million times.

Great for a chill time, for any occasions.
author: Gerard L.

description:
Amazing bridge. There are so many angles to view this bridge and still looks spectacular! I guess that is why it is called one of the FAMOUS bridges in the nation. 

Although I drive on it every morning to work. I still love to just sit nearby and around it to watch the city view from Marin County side of the bridge, OR do the same thing from SF side and see the mountain behind it, and the beautiful sailing boats coming out from Marin County sitting on Crissy field beach on a warm and clear day. 

Very relaxing and romantic at the same time.
author: Daisy S.

description: This place is magical.  There is something about he bridge that makes it organic and it  looks as it always belong there.  Tourist usually only walk across or ride across but I can tell you they are dozens of point of view  places to see the bridge and they all offer a unique experience. If you get a chance during a clear night make sure you go to crissy beach sit on a bench and enjoy the view.
author: Manny R.

description:
I can rate the BRIDGE?!
All right, so I don't think this is the most amazing thing since sliced bread. Sorry, the Tower Bridge in London should have scored higher on the Travel Channel countdown. But maybe that's just because I've seen this thing my whole life.
But it still gets 4 stars, it is beautiful & I almost walked part of it. (It's keeps getting bigger and longer...)
Tourists inhabit the place, but I don't mind too much, it gives me a perfect opportunity for a photobomb.
Awesome landmark though, I'm glad people recognize the beauty of SF - even if it's just the bridge leading there.
author: Jessica G.

description: Its a Bridge, Ok it is a good looking bridge but for us, well, the bay bridge was more impressive.
author: Kevin G.

description: Great experience! I've only been once, and wasn't expecting San Fran to be cold, but boy was I wrong.  My husband (boyfriend at the time) and I had to buy some sweaters before we took out bike journey over the bridge from the fisherman's warf and back.  Beautiful view and great ride!
author: Stephanie D.

description:
I dance to the fog, to the bay, and to the city lights,
Only until now I have notice this as my home,
Like your last love who snuck away from you in the night,
This city has not wilted because there is much to roam.

I dance to the fog, to the bay, and to the city lights,
The red bridge is our gateway to a new life,
And you shall dance to the fog, to the bay, and to the city lights,
We pick our selves up again from such an molecular strife.

This fog brings a blanket of mysterious protection,
From the lost miles of the outside world,
The Bay, it brings the world together,
And the City lights keeps our hearts still beating.

We have a destined plan that is far out of our reach,
Something new around every corner to sneak upon us,
But in response, we take up our love and dance,
Dance to the fog, the bay, and city lights.

Through our praise, we are made into something new,
New as in splendid flower first emerging with spring's bloom,
For this city is my first love,
And your heart rests within mine too.
author: Jon-o G.

description: I LOVE this bridge.  I have driven and walked over the bridge. It's a beautiful place to be!  If you have never been here I must slap you upside the face and say, "Why the hell not? GO!" It is gorgeous and fun to tourist watch!
author: Amanda C.

description:
Valentine's Day 2010
A walk with my husband across the Golden Gate Bridge as the sun sets on the golden shores of the West Coast...Priceless!!!
author: Theresa H.

description:
What a great place to be.
I loved everything about San Francisco and the Golden Gate Bridge was no exception.
Really cool is also what's below the bridge. The military fort Fort Point is a great historical place to visit after walking over the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: ricktap

description:
4 Stars

I can't remember ever having walked on the Golden Gate Bridge, but I might have when I first moved to CA and was really young.....so basically today was my first time. It was windy and cold, but fun....next time we'll probably get bikes and ride from one end to the other.
Maybe it's been a while since I've hit a toll bridge, but $6 is more than any toll i've ever paid.....it was worth-it though.
author: Ocee D.

description: Great place for photos, Google the spots to take photos.  You always have to fight for parking if you're in the north bay, if you cross the bridge by car and come back you have to pay a $5 toll.  Tho there's a good spot on the other side if you Google bay museum. Not a lot of ppl go there so there's no problem finding parking
author: Trynh K.

description: pictures don't do it justice. This bridge is stunning especially when you visit in the afternoon when the sun is about to set. make sure you bring a sweater as it can get really windy and cool.
author: Nino B.

description: The iconic Golden Gate Bridge. I've visited twice - once in winter, and once in summer. In winter, the skies are clear and you can see all the way to the top. In summer, it's foggy and it seems like the Bridge disappears into the sky. Either way, Golden Gate Bridge is one of the world's most beautiful man-made structures, and its bright colour and graceful contours shows why it has captivated generations.
author: Cissi T.

description:
San Francisco without the Golden Gate Bridge is like a fat kid who doesn't like chocolate cake, just doesn't make any sense!

One memory I have about this bridge was when I was 15. My childhood friend and I were bored so we decided to bike across the city (from North of the Panhandle) and then to this bridge, which was far from where we started. We were wearing just t-shirts in the cold fog while tourist were all wrapped and bundled looking at us surprisingly. Well we biked the whole span and came back and I could remember that it was so fun. This is a memory that gives me that feeling of wanting to be a kid again .

Built under time, under budget, and during the Great Depression this bridge is a true testament to the American ideal and spirit. It represents the unbound capacity of human imagination and potential and is an example of what could be attained beyond fearful expectations if only we are pushed. 

I have to admit that this bridge radiates a certain splendor that you can't help but enjoy. The Golden Gate is holdin' weight. So beautiful. And that's all I can express lol.
author: Brandon H.

description:
Beautiful bridge.  I think this is the best looking bridge I've driven across. Now if they could paint the Verrazano-Narrows bridge that color, it would be the best of both worlds.

ETA: It also has the best views coming and going:  SF skyline and the Marin headlands.
author: Jean C.

description:
http://www.yelp.com/biz/pacific-coast-highway-san-diego#hrid:VwhCzha1F6nIpKF3Ckk7tw 

I love Art Deco, but orange I can take or leave. It is sort of like, when hubby helps you to decorate outside for Christmas and he runs orange extension cords all over the lawn and on the roof! 

If you visit San Francisco, orange Art Deco will cause your head to turn at the first glimpse of this beautiful bridge, from almost any given point. 

One of the engineering wonders of the world, it is one of the longest suspension bridges ever built and with some of the highest towers of 746 feet. 

Enough history! This baby is orange and I do mean you see it the minute it comes into view. When you cross this bridge from San Francisco you are driving out over the Pacific ocean and connecting to Marin County. 

When you think of San Francisco, visions of this famous bridge come to mind. Millions of vehicles cross this bridge annually and I was one of them. 

This is a work of art and graceful steel at it's finest. I personally would have gone for Teal, but hey orange works into the sunset.
author: DJ M.

description: Great View! Loved everything about it!
author: Bryan L.

description: You won't see the same bridge twice. Combine San Francisco's ever-changing weather with one of the most recognizable monuments in the world, and it's something that must be experienced to grasp just how awesome it is. It's hard to pay attention to the road while driving across, there's just so much to look at. Driving into the city at night the skyline across the bay is amazing. Driving in during the day stoic Alcatraz looms large out in the open water. If it's foggy, then the rise and fall of the bridge itself reminds me of something outer worldly. Add this to one of the top spots of any bucket list and there will be no regrets.
author: Antonio M.

description:
This is a no brainer!  

I love the color, I love the location, I love the technology, I love the engineering, I love that there is a penny crushing machine in the gift shop. 

Best Bridge Ever!
author: Hillary S.

description:
who doesn't love this beautiful suspension bridge. ahh the magnificence and glory of the western gate. I'll admit it's hard to get it on a clear day, but there's beauty in a foggy day too. Now for somethings you probably don't know.
1) If you park right before the bridge you can walk across and back without having to pay a toll
2) Just past the bridge before the tunnel is the entrance to a) Sausalito, b) double backing it right before you get back to the 101 south the hills above where you can get a great view of the entire bridge, c) instead of turning left for Sausalito turn right and go down to the helicopter landing pier for some of the best and easiest crab fishing in town.
3) The top known to the workers as the 17th floor is a tribute to the 17 ironworkers who maintain the bridge.

All you have to do for crab fishing is get put some cut up meat (like chicken or something cheap), put it in a cage and let it drop to the bottom off the pier, then sit back with some beers and good friends and you'll have a fresh delicious late night snack.
author: Jason C.

description: Pretty good bridge.
author: Michael E.

description:
What can you say.....

Seeing this Incredible Giant will Take your Breath Away Every Time.....

It's Bold, Beautiful in the Most Amazing City in the World.....
author: Yelp M.

description:
It seems kind of funny to me that I can review a bridge.  What kind of criteria am I supposed to use?  The overall appearance?  The experience of walking, biking, or driving over it?  The views I get from standing on it?

I'll try to review it based on the entertainment value.  First and foremost, it is VERY windy and cold there, at least when I was there (July), so bring a coat or sweatshirt.  

We took the public bus there, which was a great and inexpensive way to get there.  WARNING: If you plan to walk across, know that it is about 4200 feet across!  A mile is 5280 feet.  It WILL take longer than you think, or at least longer than I thought!!  

2nd WARNING: Once you walk across, there is no bus on the other side!  You must walk back to get back to the other side!  My friends and I almost learned this the hard way (long story don't ask what happened there).

The views are great.  It's basically one of those requisite things to do as a tourist in San Francisco, and goddammit, my friends and I made sure we did it.

You can also bike there from the downtown area (there are a few bike rental places that let you rent bikes for $32 a day per adult), and I have to say that you have to be a decent amateur athlete to do this!  There are some hills that left me huffing and puffing like a fat old man.  And there are some parts in which you have to share the road with cars, which can be frightening.  And there are some steep downhills as well, so make sure to use your brakes!  And pllleeaassee wear a helmet!  You can take a ferry back instead of biking the entire path, which I highly recommend.  The bike shop will charge you $10 per ticket, but if you buy from the ferrymen, it will cost you $8.50.  Just sayin'.
author: Rona H.

description:
Probably the most touristy attraction in San Francisco but once again like Alcatraz it lived up the hype. 

The bridge is divided into 3 areas, 1 for the cars of course, one for walkers and the other side for bikers. This is GENIUS!!! I couldn't imagine trying to ride across the bridge trying to dodge pedestrians. 

The day we rode across it was miserable, cold, windy, and foggy. But it was still an amazing adventure. 

I recently purchased a bike and haven't gotten to ride it yet but because of this ride, I realized how much fun it is. 

The ride was tough with lots of uphills but what makes it all worthwhile is the view on the other side. Sausalito is a city only thought imaginable in dreams, but no it's reality. The rolling clouds seem to fall over the houses. If I become filthy rich I'm moving out here. 

The views of everything is spectacular from here. 

A MUST SEE!!!
author: David N.

description: The repairs to the bridge are spotless. The damage sustained by its use in The Last Stand have since been fixed. Enjoy now before Magneto strikes again.
author: Bo G.

description: A sight to see.  Historical, massive, and down right beautiful.  Whether it be a marathon or on your own, I highly recommend you take a run on the bridge.  The view is spectacular.
author: Richie C.

description:
Golden Gate Bridge is a must visit when in San Francisco, a great beautiful symbol not only for San Francisco but the US representing an ideal of reaching out, something beyond ourselves, a great timeless beauty. 

Reachable on public transit Muni 28 or 76; or free weekday to anyone PresidiGo during 10am-3pm non-commute hours or obtaining a Muni Passport to ride other times from the new Transbay Terminal or Embarcadero BART.

http://www.presidio.gov/tenants/transit/downtown.htm
author: George L.

description:
Growing up in the 415 area, we drove across the GGB tons of times.  Always loved it and really love the rainbow @ the Waldo Tunnel.  Now, I probably only cross the bridge every 5 or so years.  It's always a breathtaking site and impressive to all in tow.  The Golden Gate Bridge experience is well worth a $5.oo toll to pass.

The rest of these bridges?  HogWASH and literal highway robbery at its best!!  More reason to work from home and stick it to fastrak and the fuel gauging!  What's next fuggers!
author: Virgo M.

description:
what can i say? you're pretty impressive.  and also easy to find.  a very underrated quality quite frankly.  

on a 10 hour day tour of san francisco, you were voted the best part of the trip by my family in Colorado.  they also asked why you're not golden, but we'll let that slide.
author: Ronak D.

description:
The mighty Golden Gate Bridge! 

How beautiful you are! 

The only complaint I have is what many others have said: PEOPLE! Stop committing suicide off this bridge! 

SUICIDE IS RETARDED! You are the thinker of your thoughts.... TURN YOUR LIFE AROUND! 

.... Anyways, back to the GGB..... 

The views, the pedestrian/bike sidewalk, the sheer amazing awesomeness of this monument to human creation!... etc, etc. 

5. Big. Stars.
author: Kai S.

description:
Heres a tip for those of you looking to walk the bridge.

Walk it half way, then walk back.  It pretty much looks the same on the second half anyway and you wont get pnumonia.
author: Danny D.

description: What more can be said about this bridge that hasn't been mentioned in the previous 386 reviews.  I've taken family and friends numerous times and everyone loves it.  Recently I ran across while it was raining and still loved it.   What you won't see everyday is my crazy cousin doing a flip on the walkway.  http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/TmFaSmAUuwHwDsdytdd25g/l
author: John L.

description:
GOLDEN GATE BRIDGE=NATIONAL LANDMARK and CALIFORNIA ICON!

The bridge that everybody knows. It can be a busy bridge to cross on. This bridge can be scary to cross over while walking. I enjoy biking on the side. I hate that people would jump off the bridge to end their live. Great view when it is not foggy.
author: Ronald N.

description: Every since I was a little girl I remembered watching Full House and Charmed and dreamed of coming to San Fransisco and see the Golden Gate bridge. I was so excited when my boyfriend  made it all happen for me. It was the best experience I ever had.
author: LU R.

description: I love the rich color of this bridge! I never walked across it because it was just too darn cold when I was there. I got to see it upclose, but only half of it because the fog was sitting on top. Funny thing is when I'm in other parts of San Fran and I'm able to see this bridge, there's always no fog. But the fog isn't that bad it gives the massive bridge more character and a bit of mysteriousness.
author: Sandy C.

description:
I love the theatrics that go into American tourist structures. However, the smoke machine that adds atmosphere to the Golden Gate Bridge was malfunctioning on the two occasions I went there. All we saw was fog. 

It was not all bad though. The Kung Fu Bum that we saw on our walk to the bridge one day was priceless. He sifted through trash in a Kung Fu manner and did a whole routine of manoeuvres when he found something he liked. Brilliant.
author: Chris G.

description:
I don't know if anyone else's impression of the Golden Gate Bridge changed after watching "The Bridge," but I certainly know mine did. I grew up in the Bay Area and have walked the bridge many times, but to find out that people jump off it almost every 15 days... traumatizing!! 

Besides it's unofficial dark reputation as the landmark where most people have committed suicide, it's a beautiful, neat, quintessential "San Francisco" image. Walking across does not usually disappoint, although it's nice to time it right and go there on a sunny day (without Fog) and also without a ton of people. It's a rare combo, but it happens.

I think it's hilarious driving into San Francisco from the North... It's so hot and sunny in Santa Rosa/ Petaluma/ Sausalito and you think, "It MUST be sunny back home in San Francisco!" And then, as you approach the city, you see the disappointing sheath of fog around the Golden Gate Bridge. Such a dependable buzzkill!
author: Amanda C.

description: Five stars, of course. It's a global landmark and a breath-taking experience each time, at least for an LA-er like me. Pictures just don't do it justice. It's a marvel. Inspirational. Makes you think what's really impossible. Can't wait to come back...most likely for an SF marathon!
author: Peter D.

description: It's free and it's awesome!   It's a 1.7 mile across one way!  One side is for pedestrians and the other for bikes...We walked it/round tripped it it is a bit of a time sucker when you are traveling..but we really enjoyed the views!  Good times and great photo ops.. I'd imagine great sunsets and sunrises can be had here..  While we took a local bus from the GG Park (supposedly there's a path/hike that you can walk to get to this.. which would have been fun to do if you have the time as you can easily spend a day between the GG park and all it's offerings and the bridge and Haight Ashbury/Presidio
author: Sopla R.

description: Drive on this thing at night when there's heavy fog...AWESOME! (but a little scary)
author: SoCalSkippy ..

description: The Golden Gate Bridge is amazing, especially on a beautiful day!  I did the Avon Walk for Breast Cancer last year and had the opportunity of walking across this landmark.  It was fantastic!  I can't wait until this years walk so I can do it again!
author: Christine N.

description: Best viewing spot for Golden Gate Bridge is Battery Spencer, Marin County. The days it's windy be careful as this place is open If you plan to watch the sunset then carry a small flashlight or if you have a flashlight app on your phone. It's a 5-7 mins walk to park the car and walk to the main location so walking back in dark can be scary. Car spots get's filled very quickly. Do not even think of fashion here - wear comfortable shoes so you can really sit and relax and enjoy the view. That's right, no one is judging you for wearing comfortable shoes. A must visit if going to SF!
author: Anna A.

description: I hadn't come across this bad boy since I was probably five or so. It was super foggy on one side I couldn't believe how crazy it looked. Definitely have to check it out if you've never been.
author: Joe H.

description: I'm not a fan of San Francisco but Golden Gate Bridge is definitely worth seeing!
author: Olga B.

description:
Best to explore on foot to appreciate the views of the city from the bridge- walking up from Crissy field on the trails to the bridge. But on a beautiful day the bridge will be packed with tourists. 

Then cross under the highway and walk along the coastal trail.
author: Katie S.

description: Watch the weather but is this a true thing of beauty that is majestical!
author: Dan Z.

description:
Who can dislike one of the most amazing bridges in the world!  Seeing the bridge brings me comfort for some odd reason. Maybe its because I am a Native Californian and the site feels like "home" to me. 

I don't cross the bridge that often by car. In fact, I can only remember crossing it once about 12 years ago when I lived in SF and went to visit my friend up in Humboldt. 

Tonight my husband and I decided to treat ourselves and cross the bridge to the Sausalito side by car. We have already walked across it before and that was a fun experience. Certainly not a good idea on a cold winter night. 

The view from the bridge of SF is breathtaking. Definitely a postcard moment with all of the beautiful lights. I smiled all the way cross the bridge (no I wasn't driving--I was the lucky passenger this time!) 

There is a great stop on the Sausalito side of the bridge to stop and take pictures or catch a breathe after walking across the bridge. 

Crossing this bridge by car is expensive ($6) but I am one of the lucky Bay Area residents that lives in San Jose so I never have to cross a bridge or pay a toll to get somewhere in the area. ;)
author: Monica L.

description: This a definite must see when coming to San Francisco! Best of all, it's free!
author: GreenDay R.

description:
The most awesome part of this weekend was driving over the Golden Gate Bridge, which I hadn't had the pleasure of doing yet. Going from San Francisco to Sausalito the bridge was hidden by thick fog making it look a bit creepy. It was awesome to see all the people walking and biking over the bridge, which by the way I AM SO DOING in the very near future!

On the way back from Sausalito into San Francisco the fog had cleared and the sun was shining! Absolutely incredible views! I can see why the Golden Gate Bridge is a National Monument. 

Check out some pics from my journey here: http://www.sanfrancisconoobs.com/10-26-2009/cruisin-over-the-golden-gate-bridge/
author: Casi C.

description:
So I'm in en route from San Rafael to San Anselmo and I almost run over a girl in the crosswalk....

Then I'm apparently driving too slow and my passenger starts acting as if he's on some sort of bad acid trip, yelling "YOU'RE TOO CLOSE TO THE CARS! DRIVE FASTER! WHAT THE FUCK ARE YOU DOING? OH MAH GAWWWWD! OHHH HO HO HO NOOOO!"

When we reach our destination, and I'm instructed to "almost like...parallel park in the driveway so that your car isn't in there at a weird angle."

Ugh. Upon returning to the car, I realize I'm fighting a losing battle with my passenger and that if I drive to San Francisco:
A) I will have a stroke
B) He will be thrown out of my car, and God willing, be run over by a truck.

So I tempt fate and hand the keys over. Which was something I was so glad that I did, in the long run.

Yes, I've lived in the Bay Area for years. And yes, I've been over the Golden Gate. But never at night. It's kind of an awe-inspiring sight to look around you and see the hills covered in beautiful flickering lights as a layer of fog sits gently atop everything around you. 

No, the bridge is not "golden." In any other setting, the rust-color would be off-putting, and maybe even a bit tacky. But the contrast against the fog and the night sky makes it look nothing short of spectacular. 

The $6 bridge toll makes you feel like you're really important and on your way to doing something fabulous. Like arriving in San Francisco, where you're immediately greeted by a welcoming committee of crackheads and hookers! 

Great job!
author: Pamela D.

description: A definite must see place to visit for those who never been to the Bay Area :)
author: Ebony B.

description: From Ft. Baker the bridge rises above you through the fog pulling the two lands together.  From below the silence hides all evidence of cars.  Only the water and the bridge remain.  Gaze inland from the bridge on the silent city with lights shimmering.  All is peace.
author: Walker S.

description:
My husband is going to laugh when he sees I gave this 5 stars.  I was determined NOT to go on this bridge!  I said we could take a picture, but we weren't going on it.  It gets covered in clouds!  What if there is an earthquake?  Our son can't swim!  

My son wanted to go to Skywalker Ranch, which meant we had to cross the bridge.  I was freaked, but I would do almost anything for my son.  I am so glad we did.  I loved it.

You wouldn't think a bridge would be that big of a deal.  There is only one other bridge I have found so intriguing (the Brooklyn Bridge).  The lines of the bridge and the pattern that it makes is amazing.  My son took pictures too.  We were looking at the bridge more than we were around it.

It's beautiful!  Let me just say that those people who walk it though, are NUTS!  I would not want to walk across and back on that bridge :-)  But again, I could always change my mind :-)

Thank you to my son, I would have missed out if it weren't for your obsession with Star Wars!
author: Cyndi S.

description: GGB is just one of those things everyone needs to go see once in their life. It wasn't as crowded or cold as I had anticipated so I was pleasantly surprised. The views were great but I felt a little scared at times from being so high up.
author: Kate M.

description: Its a must see for anyone who visits san francisco. You can walk, bike, jog, drive across the bridge also. Just be careful of traffic especially on the weekends as it gets congested. The views are breathtaking though. Make sure to bring a coat as it gets cold and windy here no matter how hot it is.
author: Robert Y.

description: Eliminating all of the cash tolls was a big mistake! Why not have at least one? Im sure those people who ran the cash toll are most likely out of a job now. But the california DOT would never admit that! They would prob just tell us that their jobs were "redirected"  The biggest problem of all is for visitors of the bay area that cross the bridge. I dont want to invest in a Fast Track and have to remember it in my luggage every time i fly to SF. So now when I cross the bridge and have no option to pay cash and the bill is sent to the rental car company.  Then they have to pay it and then send me the bill with a 20$ surcharge. Great. Not to mention all of the wasted mail and money spent on postage annually for the toll authority to send bills out. GREAT PLANNING!
author: Bob D.

description: First time stepping foot at the Golden Gate Bridge, something about the aura of this bridge that makes you feel and know that you are in San Francisco! I didn't get to walk from end to end of the bridge, however, next time I'll make sure to come here around summertime! ;)
author: Jackie A.

description:
I would like to take this opportunity to thank the Golden Gate Bridge for allowing me to remain silent.  

My profession takes me all over the world.  Europe, Asia, Middle East.  If there's an airport, I have probably been there.  

During my travels I am subjected to various opinions about the US.  I hear that our imperialist government is decaying our global reputation daily.  I hear that our greedy ways and arrogant attitudes lower our dollar and raise global temperatures.  I hear that our culture is shallow and our people are fat and lazy.  

I hear, I hear, I hear.  

To be honest, over time, it's hard to take.  Being a courteous visitor, I remain silent.   

I am silent because I know one thing.  I know that my flight home will be filled with individuals that have expressed said opinions.  And during this flight home, as we approach San Francisco Airport, we will come from the north, bank to the left, and give the passengers an incredible view of the Golden Gate Bridge and the SF skyline.  The next few minutes are my favorite part of every flight home.  Usually the captain gets on the microphone and announces the view on the left side of the plane.  I sit back and watch as a plane full of foreigners climb over each other.  I see the look in their eyes as they stare at views below.  It's at this moment that I realize that while these people may publicly express their dislike for the US, they all privately wish they could somehow be a part of it, if just for a brief period of time.  

The view, the thoughts, the wonder, the bridge, that's their moment.  So I'll remain silent.  Thanks Golden Gate Bridge.  

It's the people, places, and cities that make up this country.  And I believe that the Golden Gate Bridge is one of the greatest icons for one of the greatest cities in the world.  

And you thought I only brought the funny.
author: Archie R.

description:
It was a privilege and a pleasure for this East Coast boy to drive over a piece of American history. So many people were walking and cycling over the bridge that I wished I could have been one of them. 

Only recommended enhancement to the experience would be to install roadway signs advising of the available scenic pull-offs well before their exits instead of "Next Right" a few hundred feet before.
author: David F.

description:
Its big. Its hard. Its long. Some people squeal when they see it, when they feel it, perhaps if they even dream it. No, I am not talking about any of my body parts,... but I thank you for perhaps thinking that. 

The bridge is synonymous with San Francisco. What isn't is so widely known is the suicides that happen here. Phones are distributed all over the bridge, urging the potential jumper to talk before they take that walk off the short part of the bridge. How many days is this bridge painted? Everyday by 100 full time staff. That is all they do, paint this bridge. Yes, that would drive me up a wall, but hey its an interesting fact. If anything see it, walk over it, drive over it, it may only take a moment, but at least when the 5,000,000 people you say after coming to San Francisco for a short weekend trip ALL ask you, "Did you see the Golden Gate Bridge?!" You can say yes.. yes I have....
author: Rob L.

description:
Ever since my old coked-out classmate Scott jumped off this thing, I've been a little hesistant to walk across it.  Not like I'm depressed or anything, but I'm a follower and sometimes shouldn't tempt myself.  Lemmings to a cliff = Janney to a suicide bridge.  You see?

Driving this doesn't do it justice.  You need to experience the shaking of this massive structure on a windy day.  The fear will make you walk the 1.7 mile stretch quickly, running over tourists and gay people on tandem bikes, all the while keeping your body in optimal fat-burning mode.  

Nice form of cardio (3.4 mi round trip), there is overflow parking on the south side of the bridge ($5/day), and beautiful views of the City.

Side note:  Almost every review mentions suicide, maybe our next Yelp event should be a group therapy session.
author: Janney B.

description:
After walking on the Golden Gate and looking at the most breathtaking views of San Francisco, my father-in-law says, "Now I can die happy".

Yeah, that about sums it up.
author: Robin K.

description: Yeah, yeah, yeah, I know it's a little silly to review this, but I'm doing it anyway. The Golden Gate bridge is a modern marvel-- it's been around for ages and is a must-see San Francisco landmark. The views are great and there's just something about it that's just neat, in my opinion. Walking on it is a lot of fun-- but it's super cold no matter when you visit. Have you seen that documentary about it? The one where they have video of dozens of people jumping off of it every year? HAUNTING.
author: Frances L.

description: Its a nice bridge, not long, but okay. Its a national treasure, so that makes it nice. There is a six dollar toll on the way into San francisco. However, after experiencing Millau Viaduct in France, I can say this bridge is not much.
author: Chris M.

description: Come during the daytime, unless you have a kick-butt camera that takes good photos at night. Another tourist attraction but still definitely worth seeing and exploring. As simple as the Golden Gate Bridge is, it's one of my favorite places to visit over and over again.
author: Elizabeth N.

description: Iconic.  Functional.  Beautiful.  We drove to the de Young today from Berkeley and as the bridge towers came into view I was struck once again w/ the beauty of this bridge.  Crossing into San Francisco in the morning there were already people out walking and by the time we drove back in the afternoon the sidewalk was crowded.  No matter how many times I see it or cross it, it still thrills me.
author: Toni M.

description: Its the Golden Gate Bridge....what else needs to be said.  Make sure you walk across it then go to the park opposite the city side to get some amazing pics.
author: Douglas K.

description: This was my favorite of my trip to sf, this bridge is gorgeous and i only walked apart of the bridge and have plans to come back and ride a bike across it to saulito, thanks to the awesome public transporation of sf, i didnt bother wit parking. I was lucky enought to get see this bridge on a non foggy day. Defiantly worth seeing again and again!
author: Linh M.

description:
I've contemplated for days about my 100th review, and I finally decided on an iconic symbol of San Francisco.  Gather around, children, 'cause there's a story behind this one.

I first met the Golden Gate Bridge as a visitor.  I met my step-sister in Sacramento - never been to the Bay Area - and we decided to travel to SF for a visit.  This was several years ago, and  I was firmly rooted in my Colorado mountain home.  I don't know how she did it from Vacaville, but we traveled over the GG Bridge to visit the city  by the bay for the first time.  Oh god.  ...I fell in complete and utter love.  With no thoughts that this would EVER be reciprocated or that I would ever live here - I fell in love with this stupid orange landmark and the city for which it stood.

Imagine several years have gone by, and I have been transferred to the City.  I spend part of each day coming over the Bay Bridge.  Every time, there's this squirmy feeling - "oh god, I work here, I mean I really WORK HERE in San Francisco.  Wow.".  For those of you native to this area, there is no way to describe the beauty that hits those of us who are immigrant to this town.  I cannot explain the feeling, the joy, that comes from this place.  I thought I was in heaven - little did I know...

Fast forward three years and one move from Portland to here.  I'm done.  I cannot hide my love for this place.  I rent an apartment in the city and find I can take the cable car to work every day.  On my second day down Hyde Street, I see the Golden Gate in all her amazing glory - and I fall in love all over again.  I live here.  I LIVE HERE!!!!!  There are no words.

Since that day, I have walked over the bridge several times, taken friends and family up the headlands to take photos and seen her glory in everything including low-lying clouds and bright sunshine.  I am a history major - for me, this place will always hold a tinge of those who worked against all odds to create a dream out of steel and will.  It will always represent that iconic tower thrusting up through the mist on my first visit so many years ago.  And it remains the touchstone of my current life, as a citizen of one of the most wonderful, dynamic, amazing cities - my home.
author: Suzanne B.
