description: My bf and I came here after our trip to Sonoma County to see my parents. The views here are spectacular! Just bundle and get ready to snap a lot of pictures. It's always chilly up there!
author: Melanie B.

description:
What can I say? It's so awesome! Beautiful! And Cool! And hell a lot more bigger than I thought! My friend and I went on the bridge but I 2 out of us 3 forgot to bring out jackets, plus it got too cold and windy to continue, so we only went 1/4 of a way. Oh well, that's what you get if you live in Southern California. We tend to think it's warm everywhere during Summer... 

I noticed something and I found it funny: I saw a phone booth that have 2 uses, one use for suicidal people who wants help, and for people who saw someone about to jump or have jumped. Hah, very effective. I'm surprised that the barrier haven't been put up. I guess the San Franciscans love their view very much... 

Next time, San Francisco, I shall remember to bring a coat and I will laugh in your face (wherever that is...) when I complete the bridge... Muwahahahaha! That was practice...
author: Matt M.

description:
Had I known...

I would've carried him across on my back. But no one knows when your time is up and I didn't know that the Golden Gate would be the last great memory of my brother. Fraternal twins, born 20 minutes apart, our early years were full of brother-sister rivalry and It was only after maturing did we realize how close we really were. So in the last few years, we'd spend our birthdays together in San Francisco. He'd drive down from Oregon and I'd drive or fly up from LA and we would meet each January for a few days of terrorizing the bay area. We were really good at it, true masters of the art blowing the minds of our significant others. We were wild ones, born here in this city and considered ourselves plank-owners. So I should've been suspicious when I suggested we walk across the bridge to Marin and he refused. I thought he was being a wuss for his gf's sake but he said he had a cold and didn't feel like it. I shrugged and did the walk. When I finally got back, he said he wasn't feeling good so we drove back to the B&B and I left the next day. That was the last time I saw him alive. 

I got the word while visiting my best friend in Virginia, a friend dying of cancer, that he had died. I thought it was some mad, cruel joke and I broke down, fell to the floor. He had been in excellent health otherwise, surfed, ran a kung-fu studio and was a police officer. How could he have died? His co-workers and friends all suspected foul play but it turned out to be something called sarcoidosis that attacked his lungs and caused his heart to fail, killing him. It had gone unrecognised by his fucked-up doctor for some time. The chronic cough should have been recognized and a specialist referenced...something was wrong. 

The Golden Gate will always be two things to me. It will always be one of the most enduring symbols of our country and a cherished icon of the city I love so much, the place we were born. And it will always symbolize that great sadness of the very last time I saw my brother standing there over the ocean with San Francisco in the background.

You never know when death will come to someone you love. The Golden Gate reminds me to cherish those moments you share with them because it just might be the last time. My friend in Virginia died of esophogeal cancer twenty days later, a week after turning 49.

I didn't know...

See my Fort Point review for more on the area...http://www.yelp.com/biz/fort-point-san-francisco#hrid:IXaDA_il--mVYliuyizWIg
author: Robin Z.

description:
I'm in a rather sentimental mood today, what with it being Memorial Day Weekend and all. Please don't forget those you can only hold in your heart...and then remember to hold the ones you can.  : )

Up until now, I have been hesitant to post a review of the bridge. My best attempts at finding the right words always fall short. It is symbolic of so much to so many. It's had a special place in my heart since I was maybe five. And as in any life, much has happened. Love. Life. Loss. Bad and good. You know the drill. And then it hit me yesterday as I enjoyed yet another Zen moment quietly riding over the bridge and into the city early in the morning while the sun shown, the city sparkled and the waves crashed. Someone else had worked it out for me years ago...

Maze, featuring Frankie Beverly recorded 'Joy and Pain' at the Record Plant in Sausalito in 1980, which happens to be THE pivotal year in my particular journey. And I cannot help but wonder if they found the inspiration for the title song out there on the bridge.

Yeah, I thought so too.  ; )
author: mnypny b.

description:
I ride a bike. That is one of the reasons I am so cool. Because I wear spandex. Yes, spandex. My bike jersey is orange and yellow. It is Italian. I wear it so people will look at me. I look like a super hero-I call myself "ORANGE MAN!" My friends call my "BIG BIRD!" this is a difference of opinion we have on a regular basis.

So I ride in this orange outfit across this bridge that is also orange. It is like bicycling in camouflage. I am like a Ninja (yes Candice, a   Ninja!). A big orange Ninja. 

My friend Rich and I ride through the Presidio to get to the bridge, and travel through the tourists to get there. It is really beautiful riding along the cliffs and under the bridge.

There is a biking side to the bridge and a walking side, so the bikers do not hurt themselves by hitting tourists. You ride under the bridge and clime up a short hill on the other side to get to the biking side. What is fun at this point is that you come to a blind turn and have to not run into other bikers. This can be worse than hitting tourists. 

Once you get on the bridge, it is very interesting, For one, it can be really cold. I have been on the bridge when it is windy and foggy, and the fog blows across, through the bars and can be really cool looking. Dangerous too because you can get blown over. What makes it even more dangerous is that to get around the towers, you have to slow way down and make really sharp turns. This is another place where head on collisions occur. Also, the worst is the tourists on bikes. If you thought the tourists on foot were scary from my earlier comments, you should see the ones on Bikes. Wow! They sometimes don't wear helmets (which is Darwinian if you ask me), and they stop in the middle of the tower part and look out.

Now, I understand, they need to do this. That is why they rented those bikes with the bags on the handlebars in the first place. But for real, must you stand in the bike lane around a blind corner? It is like standing on the street and wondering why you're getting run over. Y'all crazy!

Anyway, the sights are beautiful, and once you get over the hump of the bridge, you can really race down towards the north bay and pass people. Fun!

On the other side of the bridge, we ride up the Headlands. Once on the top, we can look out and on a clear day see the whole city, with the GG Bridge huge in front of us. It is really cool. Then we ride down the hill, and cross the bridge all over again. The crossing back is pretty much the above in reverse, so I will spare you.

So what did we learn? 

Hitting tourists can hurt. They are not to impressed by it either.

Hitting tourists on rented bikes can hurt more. This is a lose lose any way you look at it.

The GG bridge has an arch to it.

I dress obnoxiously for attention.
author: Michael L.

description:
No need to say anything.

Just B E A U T I F U L!!!
The mystic bridge looks fantastic!
author: Minhan S.

description:
the most beautiful bridge in San Francisco and also the worst speed trap place. 

i used to commute over the golden gate bridge to San Rafael everyday. believe me, when they say speed limit 45 mph -- GO 45 mph. the bridge is definitely a speed trap especially around the end of the month. the CHP loves giving drivers speeding tickets and fines are DOUBLE on the bridge (around $350 per ticket!)

TIP: speed through the bridge in the middle lane (NEVER drive on the fast lane. EASY TARGET) 

BUT when you get near the end of the bridge, slow down because there is always a policeman with his radar gun standing by a pole at the end of the bridge. (I SEEN THIS MANY TIMES. He just stands there and point.)

when he catches a car speeding, he will radio one of his fellow CHP officers parked at a hill right after the bridge or sometimes a CHP on a motorcycle hangs out at the tourist spot. then they will flash their lights and BAM! you are caught. there aren't any excuses to get out of a speeding ticket on the bridge unless if you have a pregnant woman in the car. 

i seen many cars getting pull over because they were going 55-65 mph. i think its stupid how the CHP just hangs out waiting for their prey. 

golden gate bridge is a great place to visit BUT definitely a SPEED TRAP!!!
author: Carol Y.

description: #465 It's not the greatest architectural marvel I have ever seen, but it comes quite close! At this point, I have already been to the Golden Gate Bridge 5 times, which is probably 4x too many. But, I can still enjoy it for what it's worth. Plus, the last time I was there, I finally drove over it to Marin! Another check on my list! I recommend seeing it both in the day time, as well as night, because it's a different experience each time. But, there's no need to linger for too long. Also, try your best not to visit SF during peak season - it's a pain to get the pictures you want, as well as find a parking spot.
author: Stephanie P.

description: There is little I can add to the accolades already bestowed upon it by fellow yelpers, although I scoff at those who criticize it for attracting tourists . . . don't you realize how much this city needs them in order to survive? On a day when the sky is a brilliant blue and the sun is shining brightly, treat yourself to a stroll across this magnificent structure to appreciate fully what a tremendous engineering feat it is. That the toll is levied upon San Francisco-bound drivers is appropriate - who would want to pay $5 to go to Marin?
author: Gourmet G.

description: So it's not Golden of course, but it's still a hella cool bridge. Of course a must see in SF. You can walk across it, bike across it, take pictures of it, go boating under it or just drive across it on your way to the sunnier Marin County. Whatever you do, you'll definitely enjoy your time here. Just be forewarned - it can get really chilly up there ! Also, the crisis intervention signs on the bridge for would-be suiciders is kind of freaky, but don't let that or the cold deter you from having a great time here. Also, go to the park/Presidio area. Lots to do within a stone's through of the bridge. Drive across and check out Sausalito or the majestic Muir Woods, Muir Beach and Muir Beach overlook.
author: Saliha B.

description: This 1.7 mile walk across the bridge was a tremendous amount of fun. And an amazing sight.
author: G M.

description: Number 1 thing to do in San Fran.  It does get pretty cold and extremely windy, and sweater is a good idea even in the middle of summer (I was there in July).  Really the most iconic thing in San Francisco and you should at least walk partway across to get that experience.  Watch out for bikers!
author: Taylor J.

description: I first met this modern marvel in 2005 while on vacation. It was love at first sight. Now I live in the area and still love it. I never get over its beauty , massive size , engineering and especially the men who died building it. I never tire of photographing it and whenever I venture near it , I try to take a different angle. I realize that I am not alone in my desire to visit the bridge and spend time admiring it. That being said you would think I would be giving it 5 stars. Well there are a few things that need to be said to the new visitor of this marvel. Obviously , summer , school vacations and holiday weekends are not the best times to go here if you are looking for an enjoyable , relaxed stress free experience. Then again , when are the vast majority of people in a position to visit but those common times. For those of us with flexible schedules , try your best to go during the week early on in the day. Don't forget that this bridge is also mobbed for commuters going about their life so avoid those peak times as well. The other huge problem that I don't see the parks service ever addressing in the near future especially in this economy is the bathroom situation. Picture literally hundreds of people driving into the Fort Point area only to find FOUR stalls for everybody (this is the ladie's perspective mind you). It just isnt cool and at 2pm that restroom is closed for cleaning so the mob is shifted to share the men's room. And yes , I'm speaking from experience .I'm not sure what factors contributed to this lack of facilities . Now the other side of the bridge where you can also park is equipped much better. On either side on a busy day , you will be waiting to and fighting for a place to park. People get extremely testy on the Fort Point side. Hopefully , you won't have a bursting bladder (again that would be me one day as I chugged a Starbucks venti all the way from Campbell). The other caution is how the space is shared on the walk from one side of the bridge to the other. Due to the recent retrofitting work , the Southbound side is closed to pedestrians . So the Northbound side is extra crowded with this potentially volatile mix : you the happy walker , the run run run joggers , other happy walkers , folks like me who would marry their camera if possible they love to use it that much , Lance Armstrong wannabee cyclists and my personal favorite : the awestruck bike riding skiddish tourists . This mix is intertwined with people who are so amazed by their surroundings that they pay zero attention to anyone . So the potential for mayhem is always there. Use your head , be safe and you will forever remember being on this landmark. Don't use your head and you will forever NEVER remember being here as you will have broke your noggin. Oh and during my first visit in 2005 , my ex husband and I watched a potential jumper get escorted to the nearest ER for a psych eval. So I guess that you should be mindful of the suicide help line call boxes along the way too. Back to the fun .Simply plan to go at a time where you can savor the whole experience , putter in the nice little gift shop ,read the historical placards and definitely take pictures. On your way back southbound , you must pull off and drive up the lookout point which has stunning views of the bridge , an old army battery to explore and some moderate hiking if you desire. Keep in mind it can be windy and very chilly here all year round so do wear layers especially for the lookout points as you wont enjoy fully if you are freezing . (yup done that too ) Oh and do i have to say good comfortable walking shoes ? That's important. There is a $6 car toll when you exit Southbound. The Presidio is another must visit but that review is for another day as this explorer needs some sleep. Cheers !!!! Enjoy your journey !!!!! Enjoy this amazing legacy of man made ingenuity , pride , blood  ,sweat and tears .
author: H A.

description:
Oh, beloved bridge of San Francisco!  

When it's actually nice out, I love taking visitors to SF to this bridge. It's a great one to walk or bike across. And on a clear day, the views are splendid. Park on the SF side, walk down, take some pictures of the SF skyline, and then walk back!  

And now for some USEFUL info: If you don't feel like paying for parking, there are some gravel lots just below the regular ones, which are FREE. At least, I've never seen any request for payment around these spots, ie. no meters, no signs, no slots for you to deposit $. Also the bridge is easily accessible by bus as well -  #28 and #29!

COOL: It's cool and windy - bring a jacket! Oh wait, that was Useful.

FUNNY: I've got nothing.
author: Tinna H.

description: Just a great classy looking bridge. Sure, it costs an arm and a leg to cross it but who cares? It's better than spending that money on some parking spot for freakin' Rite Aid.
author: Alex B.

description:
You HAVE, HAVE, HAVE to go across the bridge. Walk, bike, drive--I don't care, but do it! The views of the bay, San Francisco proper and Sausalito are all SPECTACULAR!

If you're walking or biking, there will assuredly be a nice breeze to cool you off.

Just do it. Seriously.
author: David W.

description:
One of the best "tourist" things to see in the country. Amazing pics can be found from numerous spots on both sides. 

Rent a bike down at Pier 39 and "bike the bridge" for the best experience (they have free maps to show you the way up to the bridge). If you're too tired to bike back, just continue on in to Sausalito and take the ferry back to Pier 39 to drop off the bike. You'll get some more great views from the boat. 

I've been over the bridge countless times and still find it awe-inspiring whenever I'm back in SF.
author: Tristin S.

description:
This is not really a review of the Golden Gate Bridge as a landmark.   It's all been said before - it's gorgeous, it's inspiring, it's the quintessential San Francisco image.  Five stars.  Rather, this is a review of it as a place for me to run.

I hate to run.  That's my story, and I'm sticking to it.  My friends know this, yet some of them charmingly keep inviting me to run with them anyway.  A 10 mile run?  A track workout in GG Park?  Ha ha ha ha ha ha ha ha NO.  But I do run - in secret.  Just me and my iPod.  I don't need to run a marathon ever, but as long as I can run across the Golden Gate Bridge and back, I'm happy.  

So I run across the bridge sometimes.  It's a great place to run, because I get so distracted - I look out at the sailboats, Angel Island, I try to see if I can spot any creatures in the water - ooh look, I'm on the Marin side.  On the way back, I look at Alcatraz, the cargo ships, the SF skyline - cool, I'm back at the toll plaza.  

The best time to run across the bridge is early mornings, preferably during sunrise.  Since I rarely get up that early, I end up running during busier times.  But I don't mind the tourists.  Sometimes they're useful as marks to keep going.  That woman ahead with the fannypack - keep going, keep going - OK, passed her.  The couple in shorts and San Francisco sweatshirts - keep going - OK, passed them.  The only time they're annoying is when they're walking four abreast.  And the bicyclists - sigh.  I try to stay out of their way, and they seem to return the favor.  

The biggest downside: the fumes from the traffic.  I always feel like I'm inhaling some toxic stuff.  Also, it can get very windy, and cold when the fog rolls in.  Still, it totally beats the treadmill!
author: DD B.

description:
It was foggy when I went, but I still enjoyed the walk.
It's funny when the bikers try to get past the pedestrians. There are crisis buttons and I pressed #69 for fun. Guess what happened? Nothing, no crisis line response what so ever. Looks like someone lost hope :( but seriously, fix your lines
author: Ivy L.

description:
This bridge is pretty, sure, but it isn't golden. It's kind of the color of dried blood.

It is freaking cold on the bridge! It can be time-to-get-naked hot in the mission, but it will still be freezing on this bridge. Don't forget to bring ten sweaters if you are going to walk across it. 

Don't walk across it on a weekend, because you will be sorry. I did, and I was constantly either in the middle of someone's photo or about to be run over by someone's bike. I was also freezing.

The GG Bridge is the object that means "San Francisco" to most people. It is beautiful as well as highly functional - a complex task.

As is my preference with animate beings, I prefer to worship this bridge from afar.
author: H G.

description:
I LOVE LOVE LOVE LOVE the Golden Gate Bridge.  I live in Sonoma County and commute to the city 5 days a week.  Going over the bridge everyday just makes my commute so much better... I love seeing it.  I just think it's amazing and beautiful.

I feel like it's different everyday too b/c of the weather.  Sometimes it's so bright and sunny, other days the fog is sooo thick that you can barely see the bridge you're going over.  LoL, it's just an amazing treat and I love it so much.
author: Kay R.

description:
Just a historical note here.  The Golden Gate Bridge was built using steel from what was once the second largest steel manufacturer in the U.S., Bethlehem Steel, of Bethlehem, PA., which however is now defunct, out-of-business, due to competition from foreign steel-making firms.  For the history of Bethlehem Steel:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bethlehem_Steel
author: Nelson R.

description: I feel like this is a crime to dock the most iconic landmark in the world(in my book) two stars. But this review is for the toll booths...how I hate you! They know the recent change of the drive thru charge of $7...to be sent to your mail later...is just going to screw you! $31 dollars later for not checking my mail in time...Gr!
author: Scott L.

description:
Hey stud.  How did you get to be so friggin' handsome?  You're not like other bridges, with that crazy orange dye job and your spectacular shoulders. You're not what I'd call approachable, either--I have to cut thru the Marina or brave 19th Ave to get to you, which can be a lot of work.  

But damn, you're worth it.  No other bridge makes me feel like you do.  Yes, there's that sophisticated dude in NYC, but everyone knows he's really from Brooklyn, and all those extra cables are just trying to compensate. There's a cute bloke down in Sydney, but he's kinda out of style since they built that Opera House.  And that guy around the corner in our city?  What a mess--too much drama!  No, you're the bridge for me, handsome.  

Don't ever change, OK?
author: Kevin S.

description: It's a Marvel of Engineering, features a great view, and it's an icon of the city.
author: Matthew L.

description: when i went on the bridge it was packed with some people walking, and some people who didn't know how to ride a bike, biking. but it is funny how when you go on the bridge you can see it and then it disappears in the mist when you get off.
author: Bandit T.

description:
Look, this review might be controversial and maybe even a downer, but I don't mean any offense.  If you disagree, I welcome that, but I am not trying to start a fight.  Let me start by saying that.

The bridge is not a suicide trap.  Speaking honestly, and not to dampen the mood, I've lost a few loved ones to suicide and subsequently worked for a suicide hotline.   

I don't consider myself excessively morbid, but if someone has made the decision to kill themselves- I mean, really made that decision- the bridge is not going to be the determining factor.  

Yes, I wholeheartedly believe that a suicidal person can be saved, or I would not have devoted years to working the graveyard shift at the hotline, but I just don't think a location or landmark is a blameworthy factor.  Furthermore, I do not think that a tangible barrier, such as a net, will suffice when the problem is within the mind.  The mind is far more powerful.

The Golden Gate Bridge is an architectural and engineering masterpiece and a source of pride for San Franciscans.  It is beautiful and mesmerizing no matter how many times you cross it. And if I may say one more controversial thing, I would think that committing suicide off the Bridge surely is a beautiful and strangely glorious way to go.
author: Christine M.

description: Pretty cool today. Review will change if the net goes up.
author: C L.

description:
You'll never look at the bridge the same after watching the recent documentary on the Bridge. 

But really, It's a graveyard under there... Not to mention in the bridge itself. There are people who fell into the cement while building the structure and never came out. 

It is a massive beautiful piece of art, none the less...
author: Dee C.

description: a must see tourist attraction in san francisco. when driving, for me it is best to go before 9 am on a sunday and walk along the golden gate bridge.  less people and less traffic.  it is nice to see both sides of the bridge
author: Elc C.

description: Lived in SF my entire life and it was the first time I have ever walked across the Golden Gate Bridge. It's great exercise and you get a great view of the city. Bring your camera, watch out for bicycle riders and you're golden. You might want to avoid walking it on really windy days.
author: Adelina W.

description:
the most famous landmark in san francisco. you must take a picture with it if you're here visiting. and if it's a nice day, take a walk or bike across.. or drive across to marin! it does get windy there so be prepared- even if it's a sunny day!
be careful if you're the one driving there because it gets crowded and with lots of tourists driving, there can be some back-up or accidents waiting to happen.
author: Jen S.

description:
10 reasons why I love the Golden Gate Bridge:

1. It's one of the prettiest bridges in the world.
2. One can walk, run, bike and drive across the bridge.
3. It always feels like an accomplishment to run across the bridge, even if it is only a mere 3.5 miles
4. I love being spooked by the loud honking of semi trucks.
5. There is a concession stand in case one feels like a having hot dog or nacho after a run.
6. There is always good sightseeing---this morning I saw a man running in a pair of bright yellow boxer with chili peppers on them...and another man with a tank top that says, "MILF HUNTER"
7. There are over 6 Crisis Counseling phones throughout the bridge, so you won't have to share...
8. I love being spooked by cyclists coming up behind me full throttle...
9. The eager tourists help me to even more appreciate this beautiful city we live in.
10.  From the Marine side of the bridge, the view of the city is even more amazing. There is a giant rock by Vista Point sign...It is by far my most favorite meditation spot.
author: Mimi T.

description: How can this fantastic bridge get anything other than five stars? It's beautiful and iconic! I get happy and excited every time I drive over it to get to the City! Even when it's covered in fog.
author: Felicity W.

description:
my haiku review for the GG bridge:

reminds me of home
colorful san francisco
wind, water, hills, love
author: Sunny D.

description: Bee yoo tee ful.  About a two mile walk, round-trip.
author: Jennifer T.

description: I loved driving across the Golden Gate Bridge and then getting out on the north side and taking pictures of it. So gorgeous! San Francisco is a beautiful city and Golden Gate makes it that much more so. Be aware of lots of fog in the bay... it may ruin those 'perfect' pictures you want of it.
author: Alden C.

description:
I've driven across.
I've walked.
I've biked.
Today I will run. 

Huf...
Huf...huf...
I feel good...I can do this...
I used to run H.S. track...
Huf...huf...
1.7 miles across... 3.4 round trip...no sweat...

Hello tourist with camera...
Should've stretched more...
Huf...huf...

Bridge sign...45 mph
Slight upgrade towards middle of bridge...
Mid-span...220 above water...
746 foot high towers...
Huf...huff...huff...
Huf...wheezzee...huff...

Need a break...
Huff...
No, shut up Weakness!...keep going...you can do it...
Huff...huff...

Get your knees up, keep your knees up...
Ugghhh...
Okay, forget the knees...
Swing the arms...swing the arms like you were born to run...
Urrgghhh...
Forget the arms...
Huf...huf...
Look at the view...enjoy the view...
Serenity now...

Huff...2001...engineering students...huff
...threw a Volkswagen Bug off the edge...
huff..huff...

More tourists...out of my way...
Hufff...wheezzee...hufff
Breathe...don't forget to breath...
Bridge sign...No U Turn...No U Turn? 

Hufff...huff...huff...
Muscles tightening...ugghh...
Is that guy taking my picture?
Look good...chest out for the camera...
No...it's just bridge police...with a radar gun
Hufffff......hufffff.....huffffff......

Almost there...
I can walk back...no one will know...
Almost there...end of bridge...
Vista Point...
Huff...huff...huff...
Feeling good...feeling strong...
Huf...
Finishing strong...
What a beautiful bridge...
What a view of The City...
Que up Chariot of Fire music!
author: Teddy B.

description: Well, ya can't go to San Francisco without seen the Golden Gate Bridge.  I've heard of some nice tours where you rent a bike from the Golden Gate Park and ride across the bridge.  Sounds nice, but I was too effin cold for that. So... I took a few photos and RAN!
author: Rox G.

description:
this is a great bridge but when i'm crossing it. i think  "do i feel lucky?
should i venture into the outer lane to go faster? will another car coming in the opposite direction careen out of control and impact me?

i don't feel so lucky. i stay in the slow lane.
author: Victor G.

description:
What can I add to 219 reviews of our glorious landmark?

No one can walk across this bridge without thinking about jumping.  It has nothing to do with being depressed, or actually wanting to die.  Don't believe me?  Go, walk, stop and lean on the railing, and look at the water below.  You will, without wanting to, think about what it would be like to simply throw a leg over the railing, lean out, and fall for a few seconds.  Whether it's because of the bridge itself, the bridge's history (the most suicided-off structure in the world), or some combination, the thought is inescapable, no matter how happy or well-adjusted you might be.

Why can't I stop taking pictures of the bridge?  It's got to be among the 3 most photographed structures in the city, and yet every time I'm on Marin Headlands or down at Crissy Field, or out at Fort Mason, there I am, taking pictures of the bridge.  [On a camera that uses actual film, because I roll old school, yo.]
author: Ben P.

description:
It's one of the most amazing attractions on the West Coast.  I've never been stuck as traffic seems to flow quite well even if a lane is closed.  The views are breathtaking, and I love driving over in the fog.  

I see teams on the bridge constantly - checking the safety of the structure, keeping it painted and removing graffiti.  

Bravo!  It's an amazing experience to walk, bike or drive.
author: Hunter R.

description:
Tempted as I may be to comment on the bridge itself there are 400 reviews and counting that speak to its grandiose awesomeness.  This review must focus strictly on the Toll Plaza itself:

The rounded contours of the toll booths topped with the big florescent lit clock (at night) provide a cool streamlined aesthetic that stand as the bridges strongest nod to its art Deco influences.  Add a strong blanket of fog and its pretty hard not to feel like a 1930's private "i" when you cruise through.

The color of the toll plaza (and the entire bridge),  "international orange", is a beautiful sun set matching color, if not slightly confusing to the tourist coming out of the gift shop protesting, "But's its not golden, its red!" 

Oh yeah, and there's a toll plaza with a museum and a gift shop that provides one of the most photographed vistas in the world.  In most parts of the country, toll plaza gift shops are located above an interstate and serve as the occasional backdrop for big rig trucker prostitution.

Functionally, you can catch a cab or a bus from here. And all things considered, like the fact that they have to change the lanes of traffic entering and exiting the eastern most booths of the toll plaza several times throughout the day(!!!), the traffic at the toll plaza aint that bad.

Would be five stars, but damn you know our grandkids are gonna be paying a bridge toll of $25 someday.
author: Michael M.

description:
Alas my 100th review! Finalamente- a stepping stone, a momentous occasion, ah- nothing like reviewing such a poignant piece of our city's history. I've noted other Yelpers using this as another monumental review, 100th, 200th, 300th, et al., as well.

Thus, I find it exciting, actually titillating to write a few random facts about this Art Deco masterpiece. If anyone thinks this bridge isn't "all that" as you may see in some reviews down the page, then let them try to erect something of this magnitude across a giant bay of water. 

I love me some Wikipedia, and local random historical tidbits, which lead to the fun facts below:

1. The bridge has over 1,200,000 rivets.

2. The "golden" color of the bridge is actually an orange vermilion called international orange.

3. By the time the painting crews complete their job, a year has passed and it's time to begin painting the bridge again. 

4. It's certainly the most photographed bridge in the world, although some would argue the Tower Bridge in London is also a contender for that title.

5. Since its completion, the bridge has been closed 3 times due to extreme weather conditions, all three being high wind gusts up to 75 mph. 

6. In the movie, X-Men: United, the Golden Gate was destroyed by the forces of Magneto.

7. In the 2005 tele-movie "10.5," the Golden Gate bridge collapses after San Francisco is struck by an earthquake. (That was a hysterical and horrendously entertaining made-for TV miniseries)

8. Scary enough though, various and loose sources around the city have predicted that the bridge would not survive an earthquake much over 8.0 on the Richter Scale, and definitely wouldn't guarantee it's survival with an 8.5 or higher.

9. Joseph Strauss was the Chief Engineer and he spent 10 years drumming up support for the project in northern California.

Fun facts, fun times!!! 

My other favorite thing to do is to walk all the way across and back on  a sunny day. If you haven't done it yet- get out there and go! It's sensational.
author: Braden B.

description:
The most beautiful bridge in the world!

Props to Students for a Free Tibet for flying a big "Free Tibet" banner off the bridge when the city's leaders handed the city over to the totalitarian Chinese for the Olympic torch run in 2008.
author: Adam Z.

description: I'm sure that it is worth morew than 3 stars but it was chucking it down with rain and we didn't see much I'm afraid.
author: Baz J.

description:
Don't jump to the idea of taking a walk on The Golden Gate? Think again. I have lived  within 20 minutes of it my entire life, and never once have I gone on the bridge without appreciating it to the fullest extent.

On the other hand it took me 20 years until I actually walked across it. Many times now since then, and it never gets old. I recommend parking on the Marin side, and walking across. The way it lays out just seems to be more dramatic.

I recommend avoiding the weekends if possible, as it  can be very crowded. I also recommend checking the weather forecast if you plan to see more than 10 feet in front of you on some mornings!

Tip to those who listen: Dress warm even if it looks nice out. If you have the time, and energy, walk from the headlands to Kirby Cove, and be at the beach looking up at an amazingly beautiful view of the bridge and the city, while in some of the most scenic natural settings in the World. 

Never will the Golden Gate be taken for granted by me, as its beauty only becomes greater in my eyes.
author: David K.

description:
It's a rare and amazing thing to experience one of man's greatest achievements.  Connecting San Fransisco with the wine country.  Just kidding.

I saw a program on the Discovery Channel about bridges.  It said that there is a team of painters that work on the Golden Gate Bridge year round.  They paint one side to the end, then switch to the next side and then back.  Over and over.  That fascinated me and spurred my decision to go.

My friend Jacinda and I decided to go while I was out visiting her.  The day was windy and foggy - big surprise!  Weather notwithstanding, we made it across!  The walk was amazing.  You can feel the bridge move when cars cross and you can look down at the water through cracks that are spread out at equal intervals.

I was so happy to mark something off my list of life-long goals that I started crying.  Or maybe it was the rain that started to fall on our way back across.

Next time - Alcatraz!
author: Leslie W.

description: I don't think I can give any review that can give justice to the Golden Gate.   Spectacular views, I would suggest before going on the bridge, turn right and go up to the headlands to get some views from there (from the looks of the pictures, most were taken from up there).  Think it was $5 to cross, but well worth it
author: Jerod M.

description:
A rip off for locals who need to cross it everyday!!!

$6.00? 

That $6.00 toll is paying the salaries of their board of directors who make six figures for working a week each month.
author: Kevin S.

description:
When I come through Waldo Tunnel, and see the Golden Gate Bridge towers, I get a good feeling because my mind goes directly to fond memories from my past.

I've never had a bad experience that included crossing The Bridge.  

When I cross it, it's always for a happy reason; going to work (which I really enjoy - I know; I'm weird), meeting a loved one for some fun in the most beautiful city on this planet, filled with a GREAT deal of really nice people, or the memories I have of my Grandma driving me all the way to Union Square to Christmas shop every year.

On the rare occasion we walk it, we always toss pennies over and watch them splash in the water below.

I love the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Michael O.

description: A truly magnificent piece of architecture.  There are so many view points to see the bridge.  Drive on it, bike on the bridge, take a cruise under, and walk on it of course!  There are tolls when entering San Francisco.
author: Are W.

description:
The "safety orange" of the bridge is a beautiful contrast to the hills of Sausalito and the rest of Marin County and the city of San Francisco.

I always felt proud of living in San Francisco because of this iconic bridge.
author: Kathleen B.

description: The view is absolutely amazing! Nothing beats standing on top by the mountains and staring down while the sun is setting. Breathtaking...
author: M W.

description:
Probably the most awesomely, outrageously *Booo!!!-Hisss!!!*-able remark I ever had the privilege of hearing uttered at me in personal conversation I heard back in 1987 from Glo, my then San Diego-dwelling mother-in-law, a really wonderful woman who just never fathomed my wife's passionate attachment to the Bay Area and everything about it. 

As I was describing the fireworks, and spontaneous be-in festivities surrounding the Golden Gate's 50th anniversary celebrations, and how the weight of the pedestrian celebrants on the bridge had flattened its span for the first time in its existence, Glo sighed and conceded with really, really exquisite condescension: 

"My goodness, .. *they* really *do* love their bridge... I guess...."  (Oh, Glo)

Well, OK, my goodness, that celebration was (whew!) 20 years ago! And Glo, ironically, is now living in Hercules. I dunno if she's ready to take back her remarks.. but whatever..

Our most recent excursion to the bridge was this last Sunday... doing our duty as good Bay Area citizens and host parents to two high school exchange students -- Mohammed (from Tunisia) and Fred (from Korea). It was our first chance since their arrival in September to run up to the City. And how can you take guests on their first visit to SF and *not* take them to the GG? 

Whoa! OK. The day we went was not the ideal day for doing what we had in mind. That day the City and especially the bridge was shrouded in fog. We drove right on thru the fog, across the bridge to the Marin side where you could stand fog-free and in sunlight at the vista point and watch the fog roll in thru the straits a hundred yards away almost but not completely covering the towers and suspension cables and roadway. So our guests snapped their pictures. I imagine within those same 5 minutes 50 other pictures being snapped by other tourists.. but because of the rolling fog, I'll bet none of those pictures show quite the same scene as any other.

Then three of us walked back across the bridge thru the fog. But even in the fog.. I know of no other engineering structure this immense that *invites* you to walk on it... right on its skeleton and sense the immensity of its supporting cables and towers.. I know of nothing else this size that fits in so well with the land and the sea surrounding it... or that allows you to feel, to walk uninsulated thru the wind and the fog, and the rain, and the salt air that constantly assault it. 

And, of course, I know of no other structure this size that serves as such a symbolic gateway between our pleasant urban existence built around the edges of the Bay on one side and the turbulent, untamed, immense reaches of the Pacific on the other.... And then the sulfur lights go on

And so even in the fog, the fog horn booming, the wind blowing, walking in semi-darkness there's Mohammed, the 17 year old exchange student from Tunisia practically bouncing over the span towards San Francisco, yelling, "Man, I love this place.. Man, I love this place!"
author: Weide Z.

description:
Love this bridge. But I'm a little tired of battling with tourists.
I have played tourist guide about once a month since I moved up here almost a year ago. I guess it's my fault for knowing people huh?
Anyway... I love going here and thinking about the movie "The Bridge" ... a little morbid but very real.
author: Grace P.

description:
The Golden Gate.  The Gate to my heart.  The Gate to San Francisco.  Gosh, they all have their own ring, don't they?  This suspension bridge stands as one of the most attractive bridges to my knowledge and is the definition of a landmark.  When I get homesick, I can literally imaging sitting on the roof of my old place watching the fog roll in under the bridge like dry ice in jungle juice, but more classy.  So it is more like dry ice in crystal champagne glasses.

Stay Classy San Francisco.  Okay, back to the subject at hand.  There is nothing like riding a bike across the Golden Gate on a warm Spring day.  You're going to have to keep your eyes peeled for these sunny days...but they exist.  I promise.  On days I bike across the bridge and its not sunny, but windy and foggy I wish I wore goggles.  I never do, but it would help....so I suggest using some sort of socially acceptable eyebarrier.
author: Jenn T.

description:
So i rode my bike across this bridge today! I live in SOMA and rode the whole way there and back.. Took me about 3.5 hours round trip.. Man i was so tired after.. But something you have to do at least once. I think i will do it again.. My only big complaint was man i was so windy. It was hard to ride at times the wind was so strong.

Everyone ride your bike across the bridge it is AWESOME!
Great views!
author: Samantha R.

description: One of our historical places in San Francisco. Love going to see it and drive over it.
author: Dennis W.

description:
My review in a series of Haiku.  Why?  Well.  It's because I love you... :)

Oh Golden Gate Bridge
Solid glorious orange
You greet me daily.

By foot, walk the span
Fierce wind blows me fro, that bitch.
Must wear more layers. 

By car, bay glistens.
Traffic breeds misanthropy...
Bad drivers suck ass.

By sailboat, waves drown.
Damn - my sandwich lost at sea.
Eat Cliff Bars instead.

By kayak, arms tire.
Bridge too far, sea lions mock.
So damn annoying.

By golly, what next...
Bungee, parachute or dive?
Too many choices.

Oh Golden Gate Bridge.
What the frak should I do now?
Too lazy to choose.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Greetings My Fellow Yelpers!

I've been away from the site, due to lack of internet connection so I'm playing catch up now. Currently I'm away from SoCal, to show my Aussie Friend Dingo a great time here in NorCal. One the main attractions of the Bay Area and why all tourists take up a great deal of time is because of this bridge. I wish the Bay Bridge got the same notoriety then again, who would want to be known for a structure that people have jumped off randomly to their impending doom, due to a harsh view of reality.

Despite the negative comment I recently made, this bridge has been here for several decades and continues to be a site to see, to tourists all over the world on a regular basis. For cyclists who frequent the bridge it's to commute and enjoy a short ride from SF to Marin County. For people like myself, Jake and Dingo it's a nice spot to take a stroll some scenic photos and do a little Bboying if you will. 

All in GGB, is the place to be even though their Oreo brownies are $2.50 and you get approached by random Russian tourists to "break dance" for them in front of the camera.
author: Ryan M.

description:
Amazing historical landmark & triumph in design, the GG Bridge is wonderful for taking visitors to SF and the touristy stuff. It also kicks ass when you ride across it or take a stroll. One of my favorite parts about San Francisco (next to the sourdough), but after watching the film "The Bridge" with my roomie...I've decided it needs a high net along the outside of it. Thus, the only reason it loses a star.

For more information on the film:
http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0799954/
author: matt m.

description:
I've probaly thrown away a small fortune throughout my lifetime tossing pennies in various wells and fountains betting on wishes that never came true.

Would you believe within 20 seconds of Honest Abe disappearing into the frothy swells below a wish finally did?

You can't argue with results.
author: Jason M.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is cool as Sh*t Fo Sho!  

The GGT has rhythm with the wind and motion like the ocean. I wanna give you 5 stars but your losing your coolness every time you raise your toll.  You may lose two of stars with the next hike...a dollar a star?  That's fair? Right? 

Sorry old Buddie I love ya, I won't leave ya, cuz I need ya, but I may not feed ya...see ya.
author: Siamak S.

description:
"Whatcha wanna do today?" *yawn*

"Wanna walk across the 'not so golden' GOLDEN GATE BRIDGE?!"

"Hell yes!!"

Thank you, bridge, for fun times on our honeymoon. :)
author: Kimiko S.

description:
"Look honey..."    A man raises a red flake to the sun and shows it to his tween-aged daughter,  "...Paint from the Golden Gate Bridge.  We will take it home with us and frame it.  Soon afterwards, we will place the frame where you used to sit at our table to eat dinner...The Golden Gate Bridge is now part of our family." 

The father, speaking in what appears to be Italian, opens up his daughter's hand and places the red-paint-flake on her palm and then with both of his hands they clasp the paint chip together.  

The father and daughter just had a moment, and 20-years after this day on the bridge the daughter will look at the framed paint flake and think of her kindhearted Pappa.    

-----------
---------
This bridge is amazing, however I do not understand how it inspires people to have these type of moments.  

Call me a cynic but lets not forget, it's just a bridge.
author: Bill B.

description: Parking really sucked at first, but after being here for 20 minutes, parking was plentiful.  Plenty of international travelers admiring the view of San Fran and the bridge.  People watching was enjoyable, and the bathrooms were reasonably clean for being in a park atmosphere.
author: Paul K.

description: Gorgeous gorgeous views of San Fran n of course the bridge. Now u can walk on the bridge but if u cross the bridge n park at the vista point the bridge on that side is closed. They r fixing the sidewalk so if u want to walk the bridge after the toll park on that side n walk across it. Remember it's one side for people n the other side is for bikes! Look up the views r amazing. Btw the toll is 8 bucks
author: Sun M.

description:
I can't believe that every time I go over this bridge, or see it for that matter, I'm amazed like the first time I saw it. Not many landmarks do that for me. 

Some of the best views for picturetaking- from the ferry when crossing between San Francisco and Tiburon or Sausalito, and from the Marin headlands (just stop continually between the highway and the lighthouse). 

To beat the crowds, you can also walk along the Lands End trail - since they cleared out some undergrowth, there are extra opportunities for pictures as you walk along the trail.

The best bridge experience was seeing the Blue Angels buzz past on Fleet Week while standing mid-bridge. Don't think I'll forget that day.
author: Jen D.

description: A must see of San Francisco. Very beautiful in the sun/fog/night. Park just outside of San Fran and take a picture.
author: John H.

description: I can't believe I haven't reviewed this wonderful landmark yet!  After a failed attempt to visit the Academy of Sciences at Golden Gate Park, my boyfriend and I decided to visit the Bridge instead!  It was such a wonderful experience to walk along it.  Given the maximum 2 hours of meter parking, it took us about an hour and a half to finish the walk back and forth along the bridge and take plenty of pictures.  It was freezing beyond belief that day, but it was worth the trip and view!
author: Anne N.

description: It's definitely a must do whether or not you are a tourist visiting San Francisco or a good old Californian who have lived in California their whole lives.  I suggest to come here later during the day, any time after 12 because it tends to be foggy in the morning and may or may not clear up during the late afternoon.  I love walking the bridge and stopping at certain points to take pictures on a clear sunny day!
author: Crystal A.

description:
Called Golden Gate yet is red...

This adds to the mystery and history.
Very well maintained and doesn't look like it will ever lose its color or even collapse like the Bay Bridge.
They have to spend $6/car on something.
author: Realtor Karl B.

description:
I will always remember the first time I drove to Marin in a friend's convertible, with the top down: wow, hah, neat, cool, better than in the movies etc. I will never forget. So what made me finally Yelp this fine bridge of ours after all this time you ask?

Fast forward: I ran to Marin this morning and it was a super foggy day, with no visibility whatsoever. As I am heading back towards the city and running on the GGB, I see a couple of police/bridge patrol cars double parked on the bridge and I suspect a crash due to the heavy fog. But as I get closer, I notice that there is clearly some activity on the sidewalk. I am running, so I've got good music blasting, endorphins in full swings and I am thinking: "This could not be a jumper. It just could NOT be". 

As I get even closer, 4 cops are conversing with a guy and slowly surrounding him,  making sure to stand between him and the water. I see him raise his hands above his head, resigned. I will never forget the look in this guy's eyes. I still have goosebumps just thinking about it.

So yeah kids, this bridge is cool. And those cops saved someone's life today, so not *all* our tax dollars are going to waste.

Another "only in SF" moment!
author: Frederic B.

description:
This is one of the places you put on a list of the everything I want to see before I die.

My one trip on this bridge was before the 89 quake. I wasn't even living in SF.

When I did I preferred to just look at it. It's humorous to think about how so many ppl. confuse the Bay Bridge with the GG.
author: Chuck F.

description: What can I say? It's a staple...
author: Megan C.

description:
I love you bridge. 

You've been destroyed and rebuilt numerous times in recent sci-fi and fantasy memory.

My favorite vantage point is from the light house facing south east, a lesser known view that's not as inundated as the other spots around the bridge.

Hurray bridge!
author: Eddie P.

description: This bridge is the signature of San Francisco.  And how could one not enjoy driving over it... looking up, looking down and all around?  The view is amazingly beautiful.  Crossing the bridge is really enlightening with all of the beauty of the moment.  I love driving toward the Marin headlands, with all of the cliffs and the far stretch out into the Pacific Ocean.  I love that Saucilito is just two exits away and then straight leads into the rainbow tunnels toward luscious green pastures and wine country!  This is a must see and a do over and over again because you could never get sick of this beautiful drive out of the city and into a more natural environment.  This bridge is just another reason I love San Francisco.
author: Michelle N.

description:
On Saturday a friend took me sailing.  I got to drive the sailboat and I sailed right under the bridge.  It was sunset and the bridge and the sky were absolutely beautiful.  Thank you Shannon.

Update:  I was informed by numerous people that, in fact, I did not DRIVE the boat.  The proper term is I SAILED the boat.  Or I PILOTED the boat.  So yeah, SAILING the SAILboat was friggin awesome.
author: Starla D.

description:
Everyday I take this bridge to come to work...

Braving Lombard, I pretend I'm the Stig all the way until I see the familiar cones telling me to merge, and the orange 35 mph sign that dominates that stretch of highway before you hit the toll booth.

Every morning I see people walking/running across this bridge at 10AM... someday I'll be one of those people on a Wednesday morning, taking that long stroll across the water.

Sometimes, when there's thick fog, you can't even see from one suspension to the next. It's as though the boundaries of San Francisco have become fluid...
author: Andy A.

description:
Great bridge! Really, I'm a big, big fan of the Golden Gate Bridge.  

I love how the large public works of the 1930's incorporated art deco elements. For me it makes these large, useful objects, such as this bridge or the Hoover Dam, transcend their function to some extent; they become massive works of art. 

The one thing that I am not crazy about are the yellow lane markers that the bridge crews move from lane to lane for the different traffic configurations. Not only are these a bad method of lane separation, but as a motorcyclist who commutes across the bridge, I've had dozens of close calls with these things shooting out from under the tires of vehicles and flying right at me. I've even taken one off the shin. Ouch.
author: Horace A.

description:
I tried to triangulate my position off each end of the bridge once when I wasn't sure where I was, except my map was inaccurate and I got crazy different readings each time.  It was pretty disorienting being alone at 3am and 25mph winds.

But it's a nice bridge.  And the sunrise at 6am is spectacular.
author: Michael T.

description: golden gate north TRAFFIC SUUUUUUCKS Aaahhhh!!! but a must do in sfo!! we got so stuck in traffic goin over the bridge.
author: Stacie M.

description: Love Driving North on the GG because it is always free!
author: Mrs. Dawn H.

description: Great, must visit place in SF. They have a great pull off spot where you can get some good pictures of this wonderment. Highly suggest visiting if you havent!
author: Dominic C.

description: In pictures it's gorgeous, in person its breathtaking. Walking across the Golden Gate Bridge is something everyone should do at least once during their lifetime. The day we did it happened to be clear so we had breathtaking views of the Marin headlands and the city as well. Driving across the bridge is also not to be missed.
author: Jessie S.

description:
I never did like orange, sorry. Though I suppose it's cool when the fog rolls in and all you can see is the teeny tiny tiptop. 
 
Ranked 5th on AIA's Favorite Architecture list http://favoritearchitecture.org/afa150.php
author: angela n.

description: I don't think there's anything I can say about the bridge that someone hasn't said already.  You just gotta go!  I passed by it my first trip, but I'm glad I stopped by the second time!  Too bad the weather was a little muggy, but the scenery still had a eerie like beauty to it.
author: Jina R.

description:
One of the most historical landmarks in California is the Golden Gate Bridge. When one thinks of San Francisco, please don't say the Giants/49ers, the first image that probably comes across their mind is the G.G. Bridge. It's most appreciated on a clear day, where one can take amazing photos of the bridge, pictures of downtown from the bridge, pictures of Alcatraz, and so forth. Another highlight is that one can go for a stroll across the bridge... great exercise!

In a nutshell, if visiting San Francisco, the Golden Gate Bridge should be a priority.
author: Robert Jr E.

description:
being a tourist, i have to give it five stars. I don't see it everyday like you locals do, so you can pretty much take it for granted. But the first time we came upon the bridge, i was just mesmerized. It was just so beautiful to look at. A Wonder, if you will. 

Sure, i can see the Brooklyn Bridge every day but the golden gate bridge just takes my breath away every time I go there. And if i was one of those tourists who mistakenly wandered onto the road to take pictures, I am sorry.
author: roderick A.

description: It's the mother effin Golden gate bridge! How can anyone give less than 5 stars? were they expecting someone to bring them out a $80 steak and sides? Please it's a big ol' bridge you walk across and enjoy the wonderful views it provides. Its stable, long and iconic. If you give it anything less than 5 stars your a pretentious jerk and need to watch Full house... yea I said it. hahaha
author: Ivan L.

description:
I first saw this symbol of San Francisco when I was eighteen-years-old!  It was so thrilling to see its spires stretching above the fog into skies of clear blue.  At the time I thought, "I wish I could live in this
fabulous city by the bay" ( dreading the end of vacation and return to
nursing school in the sweltering climate of New Orleans ).  Now,
at 62 ( and a Bay area resident for over 30 years ), I eternally feel that 
same sense of delight every time I see the Golden Gate.  I've had the opportunity to do several cruises out of , and into, San Francisco and it is especially thrilling to see the bridge from the deck of a ship.  

On a cruise into Lisbon, Portugal, I awoke early one morning to find myself beside the sister to our Golden Gate - the 25th de Abril bridge, over the Tagus River - while ours is certainly one of a kind, it was a nice surprise to see a close "relative" in another part of the world!
author: Carmen H.

description: Been waiting to see the bridge for the longest time! It is gorgeous in the daytime and nighttime! Take some awesome pictures as a memory! You can walk along the bridge if you please. It's better to go during the day in the morning before all the tour busses come in! Parking is limited so plan accordingly!
author: Cindy L.

description:
A haiku review:

Hi Golden Gate Bridge.
Thanks for the views of SF.
Our city is nice.

Another one:
Wow it's so windy.
Next time use more hair product
To preserve good looks.

Third time's a charm.
I thought the Bay Bridge
Was a grey Golden Gate Bridge.
Nope.  They're different.
author: Morekimchi K.

description:
An amazing landmark to experience.  It's gorgeous from afar and up close.  The views from the bridge are spectacular, whether it's foggy or the sun is shining.  Right now peek down near the north tower and watch dolphins scampering in the waves.

One star removed because during the week, it is very hard to navigate.  Bicyclists, bridge workers & pedestrians are all sharing the same narrow path.  You could get clipped by an aggressive biker while you try to take a leisurely stroll.
author: Lxs S.

description: This past trip to SF we decided to walk on the Golden Gate bridge...what a treat! A totally different experience from driving on it or stopping on the side to take a picture of it. The parking lot was super crowded with tons of tourists, but luckily we scored a spot. It was really windy/chilly (even for June), so a jacket is a must. Loved the picturesque views from the bridge and of the bridge itself! I would highly recommend anyone visiting SF to go for a stroll on the Golden Gate bridge, it's worth it!
author: Amanda Z.

description: I have FastTrak so I get a dollar of the toll charge. Anyway, it's a spot you gotta take your out of town visitors to even if you don't go anywhere else. This place is also famous for something else besides tourism and they made a documentary about it. Suicides.
author: Gerard Y.

description: Beautiful... the simple epitome that symbolizes San Francisco. Needless to say I have a fear of crossing bridges (hm... maybe Loma Prieta had something to do with it?) So I tend to freak out and shit bricks when driving across... But alas... I will gaze at it in the far distance and revel in its glory...
author: Vicky L.

description: Great view of the city, historic walk you can check off your list of things to do.
author: Mari H.

description:
To me this is just another bridge.  When I first moved to San Francisco I was so excited to see the GGB.  Don't get me wrong, it is a beautiful bridge but not worth paying $6/day, 5 x's a week.  It gets expensive. 

I only walked half way across because it was way to cold to walk all the way across and then all the way back.  It was nice to walk and actually see the bay and Alcatraz.  

Its in the perfect spot and so many people come to see the GGB everyday.  So I guess it is kind of a big deal.
author: John K.

description:
An amazing Landmark!

Neither rain, nor fog, nor huge masses of tourists walking next to each other or riding their rented Blazing Saddles bicycles with maps blocking my way will keep me from running the GG Bridge!!!

Love the classic International Orange, views of the Bay, Marin Headlands & City.
author: Abby W.

description:
San Francisco is the Golden Gate Bridge for billions of people. It's absolutely beautiful and I don't know if I'd like to live in a place when I couldn't visit this landmark frequently. Must see.

Note - If you're using this to jump to your death, do us all a favor -- look around for documentary cameras, no one needs to see that.  Actually get help, but ya know -- less funny of a cultural reference to really give good advice.
author: Tyler W.

description:
I ran this bridge yesterday and was so blissful.  It is quite a beautiful bridge and is so even the closer you get to it.  On a clear day all you can do is *sigh*, appreciate the beauty and say a small prayer for those souls that feel compelled to jump from it out of desperation.

As a designer, I do agree that a suicide barrier should be put up.  It is just a little too easy right now.  Despite the easy access to the crisis counseling phone line, etc.

5 stars because it beautiful and "ours".
author: Lauren S.

description:
I like the bridge.

It's a gorgeous design and is so iconically San Francisco.

But there ARE two sides, the other side which should ALWAYS be open to bike riders...  It's terrible to make cyclists and pedestrians have to share such a narrow space.

On a completely different note, there is nothing I love more than coming back to the city from being north...  You come out of the other side of the tunnel, see the bridge & city, and just have that overwhelming feeling of "I'm home..."
author: Jess R.

description:
A rich, ugly, old man was walking with his beautiful, young girlfriend when a passerby comments " The beauty and the beast".
The man pounces on the passerby in chivalrous zeal and says "How dare you call my girlfriend a beast?"

"Beauty", "Beast" etc are archetypes that are part of our collective unconsciousness. Deconstructists like Derrida would categorize them under nomenclatures like "mythos" and "logos". However, the reality is that beauty and beast coexists as One of which the Golden Gate Bridge is a good example. 

The beautiful Persona of the Bridge attracts tourists from all over the world. However, its beastly Shadow attracts those who have no more Joy left in the beauty of Life. For them, the Golden Gate bridge becomes the beast which devours their lives.
author: Kaustav C.

description:
It is the 'Golden Gate Bridge'!!  

OK! it's not GOLD... it's RED!!
author: Julie K.

description:
I am from Boston. I have lived in the Bay area for 13 yrs, of those 13 yrs I have lived in Marin for 8.

Every time I come out of the tunnel (on the Marin side) and I see that first view of the Bridge, I feel so lucky to live in the Bay area.

The view of the Bridge whether you are coming from the Marin side or the City is spectacular! No mater how many times I see it, it always puts a smile on my face.
I do agree that the toll is steep, but to keep the Bridge safe and looking good you deal with it.
All I can say is that I love the Golden Gate Bridge, and I feel very fortunate to live in this great City!!
author: AmyBeth T.

description:
If there is a more beautiful place in the world I don't know where it could be. This is just IT for me. Views, breezes, sights, sounds, smells, peoples and knowing that you love being there. I just love the bridge. 

When you say ' Let's go to the Bridge" what do you automatically think of? There is only one bridge.

In spite of all this, I have never walked all the way across it and after reading the yelp reviews I am going to do it soon before it gets cold outside. I especially like seeing the huge ships going back and forth under the bridge while I munch on a sandwich or something else.

It is THE MOST CROWDED TOURIST place that I have ever been to. People from all over the world travel and plan and scheme to get to a place that I can get to in a hour and still don't appreciate it like I should. It is one of the SEVEN wonders of the world after all. So they must be right to go to all of that work.

Man I am glad I live in the Bay Area and that comes back to me everytime I see the Bridge. It never gets old.
author: Terry H.

description: One of my favorite bridges and I LOVE bridges in general.  If you come at the right time (middle of the day), you won't have horrible traffic.  I especially love the view of the bridge from the park (non San Fran side).
author: Elizabeth R.

description: Love it, but why such a high troll toll? Instead, just get rid of the Ferry.
author: Kyle S.

description:
Ah the world-famous landmark of San Francisco. As far back as I can remember, the Golden Gate had always represented what Statue of Liberty represents for the East Coast: Welcome to the America! It's such a super famous world attraction, not only for its beauty, but its architectural magnificence. Having been opened 70+ years ago, it was a marvel in its day, continues to draw millions of sightseers yearly and "is certainly one of the most photographed bridges in the world (2nd to Tower Bridge in London)."

I actually jogged the entire length of the bridge in 2007 with my, then-roomate and high school classmate, Raissa. It was amazing how a something suspended can hold up so much weight at any given point. Occasionally peering down the roughly 247 foot drop to the Golden Gate Strait (400 feet deep!) gave me chills. I have actually heard that they have created a documentary that spans an entire year of filming the bridge from several angles, witnessing a unbelievable amount of failed attempts of suicides and even some successful ones too... 

I'm still rather irked that the bridge has raised its Fastrak (equivalent to EZ Pass in the East Coast) to $5 for southbound vehicles. Grrr.... 

All in all, one of my most favorite landmarks on this side of the Mississippi. Don't forget to check it out when you stop by the Bay Area.

Fast Fact: Did you know that the GG Bridge has a sister bridge called Ponte 25 de Abril (25th April Bridge) and is located in Lisbon, Portugal?
author: Carloalexi M.

description:
In a sentence, it is an engineering marvel of which I will never tire. A walk across the bridge, even on busy days, is still always a sublime experience. I feel that little tingle of love with each visit, and though it is a manmade monstrosity, it is perhaps the single one that makes me smile.

Today we stood midway in the center span and watched the Queen Mary II float underneath and into the bay. Its valiant passengers waved at us bridgefolk, and we waved back. What a sense of human connection!
author: Daniel C.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is awesome - best suspension bridge on the West Coast (arguably the best in the USA).  Just drove over it w/ my cousin and her mom visiting from Orange County yesterday - WOW, still very impressive.  

Whether by jogging, walking, or via car, People love crossing this American icon.  It's a bit of a bummer that its had its reputation slightly tarnished sometimes with idiots trying to commit suicide on it (kinda puts a damper on the spectacular views and fresh ocean air when some fool tries to jump off the bridge and causes a bunch of commotion.... hmm I wonder if anyone ever got a picture of themselves on the bridge, with some moron jumping off the bridge in the background.. that would be an interesting picture)  I got fastrak, so it cost $5 to cross it yesterday, but it'll cost you $6 to cross today (still $5 toll fee if you have fastrak).  If you live in the Bay Area, and you still haven't experienced or seen the Golden Gate Bridge in person, it's something you really need to add to your to-do list asap.
author: Minh V.

description: This is a place that has to be on everyones bucket list. I think that pictures of the GG do not do it justice. I will visit it every time I am in SF.
author: Nantas S.

description: Came here around noon, surprisingly it's not made out of gold. How ironic. Anywhoo, I didn't have the patience to walk the whole bridge, so I walked to the middle and back. This bridge reminds me a lot of the Brooklyn Bridge back where I live. Nonetheless, the views are still amazing. Great place for photographers.
author: Virginia Y.

description: there is' little to say ... gorgeous and majestic, to visit and travel by car or on foot or by bike! can 'happen to have the sun at the beginning of the bridge and then thick fog toward the goal' and not see his own hand ... fantastic, the surrounding areas, both on the side of the city 'that the other side of the Bay are very nice and cared ... not to be missed.
author: Andrea M.

description:
I have a stunning view of the Golden Gate from my apartment and there is not one day that goes by that I don't look at it and think, "Wow." Call me a cheeseball, but never underestimate the power of a bridge.

I've walked across it, I've ridden my bike across it, I've walked to it , I've driven across it (and in turn helped to have preserve it), I've taken pictures of it, I've seen the Queen Mary and other ships sail below it, etc. I'm always left thinking, "Wow."
author: Julia S.

description:
If you don't like the Golden Gate Bridge, why live in San Francisco?  It's obviously the MAIN attraction of San Francisco!  This is the MOST PHOTOGRAPHED bridge in the world and also the most remarkable bridge in the world.  Well, according to the discovery channel it is:)

I love it!  I've walked it, drove it and rode across it on a bike.  I could never get sick of the view.  Never mind all the people who take their lives by jumping off it.  I guess that gives a whole new meaning to "up close and personal"?!
author: Kat M.

description: Really people $6 is to expensive. One of the worlds most famous bridges and well worth the money.
author: Fronando C.

description:
I loved the Golden Gate Bridge! I was a little bummed because there was a permanent haze over San Francisco the whole time we were there (it was during the wildfires), but the bridge was amazing. 

Walking the bridge was a great experience although it does shake with all the cars and the wind blowing. It's super busy and you definitely have to watch out for the bikers riding by, but you'll get amazing photos no matter where you are.

I took the MUNI to the bridge and it was the best thing I did. Traffic is super crazy because of all the people and I can only imagine how hard it would be to park here.

If you want to see some pictures and read my experience, check out my blog at: http://dog-droppings.com/golden_gate_bridge/
author: Kasia J.

description: A must see for tourists! And best of all, it's FREE to walk across. It's fun to walk across the whole bridge with a group of people and take pictures. Parking is difficult so save yourself the hassle, park far away, wear good shoes, and prepare yourself for a hike--it will be well worth it!
author: Mrs. B.

description: One reason why I love San Francisco!
author: Jennifer P.

description: A must see place for anyone travelling to San Francisco. I enjoy it more during the winters than the summers as the winters are not as foggy as the summers here. I also try to carry a warm jacket at any time of the year as weather can change very soon here. Awesome place to  take a long walk, jog or cycle. Parking is free!!
author: S K.

description: I'd probably like it better if John Stamos drove me across it.
author: Rebecca P.

description: Miraculous to see, windy outside!  Its obviously a must see when you're in San Francisco.  Driving across it during rush hour was painful.  But it was amazing to see and experience.
author: Robert G.

description:
It's a bridge.  It's like a reddish orange.  It's got, I dunno, a lot of wirey things hanging down from big ass cables.  There is a path you can walk on.  Cars drive on it.

Sure this isn't an exciting review...but you have to ask yourself this question:  why in the hell are you reading a review of the Golden Gate Bridge?  You either want to go to it or you don't.  It's not like you're sitting there with your bag of ghirardelli, SFMOMA calendar, and empty sourdough breadbowl puzzling over whether or not you should check it out.  

"Mmm, I dunno honey.  Sure its the prominent feature of every cinematic establishing shot of San Francisco in any movie ever set here, but I can't help but feel that the service might be a little slow.  Let's see what the kids on Yelp think."  Shut up and go look at it.  Feel awed and overwhelmed and overjoyed for a few minutes, realize that it's exactly like you expected, then go do something else.
author: Dave M.

description:
I ride the 28 Muni sometimes. I can't help but smile when I see the expressions of the people crowding the front as they get their first glimpse of this California landmark. 

Recently I watched a documentary about the bridge's construction and I'm in complete awe of the people who made this architectural project a reality. The Halfway to Hell club (people who fell into the net but didn't crash into the cold waters below the structure) and all of the Iron workers must have been brave people to work at such precarious heights. 

The fact that I found fascinating about the bridge that I was unaware of until seeing the short film is that in order to fund this huge project, citizens put their personal assets on the line to accomplish this feat. I doubt few would do such a thing in this day and age and in the height of the Great Depression, people were unduly generous with great faith in the ability of this dream to come to fruition. 

Side Note: I'm looking forward to seeing the film "The Bridge": that explores the more morbid side of this Golden Giant.
author: Jessica D.

description:
Here's why I give it three stars:

It's got too much of "bridgy" feel.

Enough with the orange!

Couldn't they have made it a little shorter?

The "suspension" motif is a little overdone.

Doesn't match well with other popular bay monument - Alcatraz.
author: Evan A.

description:
It's just beautiful!!!  I used to cross this 6 times a week when I went to school out there.  Every time I cross, I fall in love with it all over again!

stinky tofu
author: StinkyTofu S.

description:
So i rode my bike across this bridge today! I live in SOMA and rode the whole way there and back.. Took me about 3.5 hours round trip.. Man i was so tired after.. But something you have to do at least once. I think i will do it again.. My only big complaint was man i was so windy. It was hard to ride at times the wind was so strong. 

Everyone ride your bike across the bridge it is AWESOME! 
Great views!
author: Samantha R.

description:
One of the best bridges I've walked on.

I visted the bridge with my dad during our trip to San Francisco.  When I got out of the car and stood on the bridge it felt like I was floating.  I love that swaying feeling and the mist covering your face when your up there.  It was such an experience to see the bridge on TV and in picture and to finally be walking on it.

I think it's sad that hundreds of people feel the need to commit suicide from it.  That aspect of the bridge kind of makes it ominous.  I hope that they go through with the proposal to but up a barrier.
author: Nicolette O.

description:
A MUST in SF.
You can not come to San Francisco and not visit the Golden Gate Bridge. The best way to experience the bridge is to rent a bike and ride across the bridge. My favorite view is from Fort Mason (http://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&hl=en&q=Murray+Cir,+sausalito,+ca&ie=UTF8&om=1).
author: Kjell B.

description:
[deleted bad-taste suicide joke]

Nice bridge.
author: Geronimo G.

description: The bridge is great but don't drive over it! Just after all the people who worked on the bridge were laid off and electronic toll takers were put in I had the unpleasant experience of driving across the bridge. Although i had cash on me i could not use it. I realized that after you go through the toll that you have to pay online or get the bill in the mail. After trying to pay online and not being able to figure it out, i decided to wait for the bill to come. After not receiving a bill for over a month, i called and was told that I was late and now owed 70 DOLLARS!. They said to dispute the charge that i would have to send the money first and that they would then dispute it for me. I sent the money and got a letter letting me know that my dispute was declined. This is a huge Scam for tourists or those without Fast Trak. If anyone who reads this has contacts to a news station in San Francisco i would love to tell my story.
author: Ryans Y.

description: I was lucky enough to walk across on a beautiful, sunny Monday morning.  I was able to get some great shots of downtown SF as well as Alcatraz.  I wish I had rented a bike though.
author: Francisco H.

description: Seen from afar...never been on it (at least that I can recall), but it brings memories of Full House...you know in the beginning where they are rolling the credits?
author: Jennifer A.

description:
From a commuter's perspective I'd have to give it three stars. They do a pretty good job of keeping the traffic moving on this bridge, but the price goes up every year and they don't have any H.O.V. or motorcycle deals during the commute hours like the bay bridge does. 

Honestly, I don't think that anyone on a motorcycle should have to pay to cross the bridge. One of the scariest things is having to stop at the toll plaza while hoping that the guy behind you can see you and stop in time.
