The bridge also has to figure out a way of separating North and Southbound traffic in a safer way. Too many people have been killed on the bridge in head on accidents. 

I really can't understand why the toll keeps going up. Why should it cost that much more to maintain it then it did the year before. The thing really hasn't changed very much since it was built.
author: Mike M.

description:
Most beautiful bridge in the world.  I can't think of any any other man-made structure that if it were painted International Orange wouldn't look tacky except for this one.

By the way if any of you read the Chronicle's 7-part series on the suicides, jumping off the bridge is one of the absolute worst ways to die.  It isn't always instant and your organs get ripped away from whatever is holding them in your body.  Then you drown and/or get eaten by sharks.  Really sad and enlightening series however.  Definitely some of the Chronicle's best work.

Anyway, I suggest biking across it on your day off from work so it isn't crowded.
author: Zubin D.

description: Standing on the bridge looking out over the water is mesmerizing. I've crossed this bridge by foot twice now, once during the San Francisco Marathon, and last week with my husband for a jog. The first time it was foggy and I felt like I was running through a cloud, an amazing feeling. This recent trip the weather was crisp but beautiful, and staring out over the bay calmed my soul. It brought back memories of taking my Grandfather's boat out on the bay and driving it under the bridge, looking up at all the people looking down, and now the boat is gone and I find myself standing on the bridge 20 years later, looking down. I wonder if in another 20 years I will find myself standing on it again, and had to tear myself away when it was time to leave.
author: OIivia H.

description: I don't even know where to begin. I drove over this bridge twice in a row cause the entire view over everything was just fucking awesome! I'm so amazed by the size of it too. One of the greatest landmarks I've ever been to. It's higher up than I had thought it to be. The breeze is great on a sunny day in SF. I don't care what people say about it being "touristy", cause it's the shit.
author: Scylis A.

description:
Considering that this bridge was built in a time before computers and modern engineering, it is quite an amazing structure from its time (the 1930s). There are longer and better bridges around the world now, but still, it's worth a look, even when you can't see it sometimes thanks to the fog.

Apparently you can walk or bike across the bridge's span. Beware of the strong winds. I got out of the car to see the bridge and...BRR, it's quite windy and COLD (sunny CA? Not always!). Wear a jacket that will keep you warm if you decide to get out and savor the view.
author: Isaiah N.

description:
[nerdalert]
the color of the bridge is "International Orange"
Hex color: #FF4F00
RGB: 255, 79, 0
HSV: 19, 100%, 100%
[/nerdalert]

the orange bridge is amazing no matter what's happening in the fair-weather skies of san francisco.  the peaks of the spans are stunning, poking through the thick fog on a summer day.  the brilliant orange pops out from the green marin headlands on a crystal clear blue sky day.  the bridge looks beautiful against the dark blue water at sunset.

don't believe me?
http://flickr.com/search/?q=golden+gate+bridge&s=int
author: hillary h.

description: The Golden Gate Bridge is nice , but it just sucks that you have to pay $5 to cross it .
author: Eileen L.

description:
Okay, I feel AWFUL for 4-starring the GGB.  If I could, I would give it 4-1/2 stars, which means in "Yelp," I would have to round up, but I really can't bring myself to round up.

There is only one reason why: I don't like walking it. 

It's not quite as specatular walking it.  It's also extremely windy, and will give you an ice cream headache.  There are also better vantage points to see the bridge, outlined in two other reviews (See "Battery Spencer" and "Fort Point") that are more photo op.

However, if your gang is hot to trot across the bridge, then I would sit in the car.
author: David S.

description: Beautiful!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I can't wait to come back! Too bad it was so cold, I only had a light sweater and couldn't stand the icy wind for very long.
author: Karma M.

description:
This is a perfect Review # 600.

The GGB has been a part of my commute for 5 years and 9 months. As of December, it will no longer be my daily drive. 
The bridge means a lot of things to me, esp as I have headed over it, exiting the first exit to get to work in the Marin Headlands - there is no public transit out there on weekdays people.

Some notables, good and bad:
- Seeing it gleam in the sun with the city beaming behind it.
- Carpool
- Painting season - when you can expect red splotches on your car
- Suicide jumpers :(
- Those morning  runners and bikers that I came to recognize 
- Carpool. 
- When carpool decided to sing "CARRRPOOOLLLL" to the toll booth peeps for what seemed like 40 days straight, in hopes that they would know us.
- The month when there was 2 fatal head on collisions. Gnarling traffic and scaring me.
- After said accidents, avoiding the "suicide lane" - which is the center lane, closest to oncoming traffic
- How my car moves 12 feet to the side in a bad winter storm. The wind is CRAZY up there!
- Carpool
- That biker lady that I came inches from killing with my car on the exit off-ramp bc she rode through the stop sign. I hope you $hit your pants lady, and I hope you never run stop signs again.
- Walking across to Sausalito and having an awesome lunch at Cavallo Point with my bf
- Running across while training for the half marathon
AND
- The fabulous bitchfests with my carpool gals on the way home from the office.

But the best view of the bridge is at the Yacht Club in Sausalito.
I will miss so many things about the gorgeous GGB!! However, I can tell you one thing I won't miss AT ALL...... the TOLL!!!!!$$
author: Jessica L.

description: What a cool bridge, not  to many like it in the world. Today they only charged toll one way, but sometimes they charge both ways, so we were lucky. The bridge is beautiful every time. You can even see it from the top of Mt. Diablo on a clear day.
author: John B.

description: The GG Bridge is both one of the most beautiful national icons\symbols as well as my favorite platform diving spots on the West Coast.
author: Michael G.

description: What an amazing, gorgeous bridge.  I lived in San Francisco during it's 50th anniversary (when it actually sagged from the weight of all the people standing on it at the same time), and I must say, the magic of this bridge (and the beautiful city she is part of) never fail to take my breath away.  The art deco columns, the graceful suspensions...I never tire of it.  When I used to live here, I would run across the entire span and back during my training runs, and I would just feel so fortunate to be able to look at such a graceful structure up close.  There are bridges in the world that are bigger  and longer, but I have never seen anything that matches the beauty and grace of my beloved Golden Gate Bridge!
author: Norm G.

description: Wow! So Beautiful. Loved the Golden Gate Bridge
author: Deanna C.

description:
Paris can't outshine San Fran.... I guess it's a patriotic sort of attachment, you know my style, you know what I mean.

Don't be dumb...  the Oakland Bay Bridge has more usefulness than that beautiful Golden Gate one... !!
author: Carl Z.

description:
You absolutely need to walk/bike this bridge.  It's amazing.  I suggest you coming when the sun's setting or rising, it's beautiful during that time.  Everyone's out, it is not a horrible tourist trap, and the view will take your breath away.  Is that convincing enough??

I really liked the Brooklyn bridge, but didn't like how the bike and pedestrian lane were right on each other (causing unnecessary or maybe necessary yelling).  But the bike lane for Golden Gate's on the opposite side, so it's all good.  Plus, it's a fairly long bridge, enough for a good workout/warm up for you professionals out there.

Walking this bridge was on my life list, and I'm glad to have finally experienced such a magnifique journey.

Btw, go to Golden Gate Park on Sunday, when it's closed off so that people can bike/rollerblade/skate around.  You can go to a rental shop nearby or bring your own gear.  You can bring a date to share such a moment with, but be careful of skating off the given course, that can lead to some crashes, or in my case, one crash :P.
author: Lili K.

description: I like driving across the GGB. I like watching the fog roll over the mountains, the cyclists and tourists, and the water on a clear day. It's not so good when there is an accident that closes down 101. Check out my photo.
author: Kevo M.

description:
I've gone across the GGB many times and each time I crest over the hill from Marin and see the scope of the damn thing, I'm humbled beyond belief.
This weekend I got to see the bridge at night from a rooftop deck, the moon almost full above it...it was seriously breathtaking folks.  
I'm beyond lucky to live in this fine ass city!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
This bridge is so awesome, people come from all over the world just to see it. 

I love the multitude of options to travel across it.  You can walk, run, bike, drive, skip...

Hell, I live here, and I still like snapping pictures of the bridge.  You're almost compelled to; it's so beautiful.  Whether it be from the SF side walking along the Ridge Trail or high up in the Headlands in Marin, if the photo op is right, I'll take it!
author: Marsha Z.

description:
If you have any sort of association with the Golden Gate Bridge (you bike across it, you drive across it, you walk across it), rent "The Bridge," the new documentary about the phenomenon of the 20-25 people a year who JUMP OFF of it.  Simultaneously HORRIFYING and CAPTIVATING.
http://www.thebridge-themovie.com
author: Shelley S.

description:
We had some out of town friends in the other day, and as a standard one-stop tourist destination, we chose to walk over the GG bridge.  Now I must say that I've been there more than enough times, and I bike over it when its warm outside, so I wasnt really enthusiastic about going at all.

But holy schnikes, walking half way over and staring at San Francisco is something I could do for hours.  I turned out to be the last one who wanted to leave...well, I didnt want to leave at all.  What a gorgeous, inspiring and FREE thing to do while youre in the city, whether your a tourist or not!

LOVES IT.
author: Cathleya G.

description:
So it's 5 bucks to get across and I think it may even be privately owned. I mean yes, I can say "BASTARDS!" but everytime I leave the Bay and come back home, I gotta drive on this bridge. It is marvelous to me and filled with a lot of memories...

My friend's dad works at the toll booth. Say what's up to Lloyd if you see him.

I once got pulled over and lucked out and got a warning instead of the $1000 speeding fine.

PLUS big stars come right here... I once did something really really funny and really really bad while passing through the toll booth w/ my ex. It made the toll worker crack up so bad she probably peed her pants. HAHA!
author: Angel S.

description:
It's my bridge. And no, you can't have it. :)

My favorite GGB experience: taking a bike ride on my day off -- back when you could still ride a bike on the Bay side -- looking down at the halfway point, and suddenly a US Navy aircraft carrier comes rolling through right below me. One word: AWESOME.

I'm one of the lucky few that can wake up every day, open my bedroom window, and see the Golden Gate Bridge. What a sight to behold. Unless there's fog. Then I just draw a little red pseudo-bridge on my bedroom window using a red crayon and pretend it's a sunny day. But then it's still my bridge. And you still can't have it. It's mine. ;)
author: Gregg G.

description: One of my Yelp friends rated the Golden Gate which amused me.  I mean what is the bridge, to end all bridges, going to give you?  Not good service or food or entertainment, right?  I mean it's a bridge. It just stands there looking beautiful like a model on the runway.  "Look at me and my clothing... aren't I just gorgeous?"  Well yes in fact you are.  Golden Gate with all it's surrounding beauty is one of the few bridges that getting stuck in traffic on, is actually relaxing. I mean what's to complain about when you have the bay on one side and the open ocean on the other. Not to mention the gorgeous mountains all around you.  You approach the bridge and start your journey across and it's like you've just stepped into a yoga class where you are "Om'ing" your way to inner peace.  It's even worse if you happen to ride across. If you climb the mountain from Baker Beach to the Bridge and then go across to the Marina, it's like the bridge is offering you a breather.  Your whole soul just sighs and takes in all around you.  To walk, bike, or drive across this bridge is an unforgettable experience everyone should do in their life.
author: Renata P.

description:
Picture this.

3 AM Saturday Night.  No wait, make that Sunday Morning.

After a night of debauchery in The City, the best girl in the world suggests taking the "Three for one" ie taking the Golden Gate and the Richmond Bridges home (pay for the Bay Bridge, get the other two for free).  Up Van Ness, down Lombard, Doyle, the whole nine yards, or seven miles.  Whatever.  All that's important, is that by the time we reached the bridge, she had to PEE!

So, we cruise up, laugh at the people going the other way paying five bucks...FIVE BUCKS!  And we got to do it for free!  After we cross, we pull off at the Vista Point to take aforementioned pee.  Walking to the restrooms, we see a 6 foot 2 inch drag queen, full regalia.  The best girl in the world smiles at her and says "Hi!" very cheerfully.  

Drag Queen responded "Oh my, there's ALWAYS a story" and kept walking past.
author: Happy C.

description:
After nine years as an SF resident, I finally did the walk across the GG bridge today, with a friend who came to visit me from out of town. I honestly can't believe it took me so long to do. Other reviewers are right in saying there are no words for this trip. I'm humbled by the bridge when driving across it, but walking it was nothing short of spectacular. 

Its a great walk but not too taxing. It's absolutely amazing to see San Francisco from so many different perspectives. And if you are lucky enough to do the walk on a perfectly clear and sunny 70 degree day like we did, then God is smiling on you. 

Definitely put this at the top of any SF Must List!!!!
author: Nissa A.

description:
Day 2, and were onto our first world famous landmark. All the fuss is worth it, and the Golden Gate looks fantastic.

The others go to Alcatraz that afternoon (which they loved), while me and Marie go to meet the local priest, who is so grand that he cracks a bottle of wine with us to welcome us to the area, and after some contemplative conversation, were stumbling down the steps of the rectory.
author: Ed R.

description:
Did someone just take a huge dump off the side of the bridge? What's that thing falling off the bridge in the distance? Oh shit, someone just jumped off!! Super awesome neato! 

See someone jump off the Golden Gate Bridge.... Check that off my things to do before I die.

Its beautiful, majestic, awe-inspiring, yada yada. I'm sure people get the idea that this is a spectacular icon.

Yeah once you come here, you'll never forget it. But you will NEVER be the same after seeing someone jump off and watching the search and rescue (or recover) do their job. How's that for a memorable moment.
author: Rocky K.

description:
Probably the coolest bridge ever built.  I just love to look at it every day.  The best time for a view is right at sunrise. The morning sun lights up the bridge in bright orange/red, while the Marin hills behind it are still cold and gray. A beautiful sight!

Walk or jog down to "Hopper Hands" at the base of the bridge near Fort Point. You may even see some surfers down there and some harbor seals. If you are up for it, walk up near the visitor center and then walk under the bridge to the cliffs and head south. It's a beautiful hike along the coast and goes down to Baker Beach. Enjoy!

OK, question. Has anyone ever seen paint brush put to bridge?? I've driven, biked, and run over the bridge more than 100 times and have never once seen it happen. I don't think they ever paint it and there's pretty bad rust all over the place. I did once almost get run over on my bike by one of the worker's little cars. Seems he was too busy with his newspaper, coffee, and donut to notice me. Dude, get out and paint!!

p.s. Blazing Saddle riders, get outta my way!
author: Dave L.

description:
Yeah yeah yeah. It looks all pretty in the beginning of "Full House", all clear and nice and sunny. 

But the real image, the truly San Franciscan way to see the bridge is surrounded by thick fog.

This is how it looks 90% of the time.
author: Jackie I.

description:
I love it. The most beautiful construction here in town, I love wandering across it, picturing how difficult it must've been erecting such a building, considering that it was one of the first of its kind.
The view on the Golden Gate strait, the city of San Francisco, and the North bay are breath taking. There's even some places in the Sunset, you can see it from. It is like a big bridge monster that has hypnotized me to devour me!
author: Roger W.

description: This is the biggie thing to do in San Fran and my husband and I did it the first day. Well worth it, but be sure to take a good camera, a jacket, scarf and a hat (careful to hold onto it cause it gets very windy on the bridge itself) It will take you about 25 minutes to walk from one end to the other one way. The giftshop is good but pricey. The best pics are on the bridge, looking back at the skyline of the city, and at the pathways behind the giftshop. We recommend doing it the first day to get it out of the way, cause you will feel like you missed out bigtime later on seeing other parts of the city.
author: Jason M.

description:
Worst managed thing in all of SF.  

I'm normally all for human / workers rights, but the people managing this place should be shot for their stupidity..

If you make all the left-most lanes fastrak, the whole bridge clogs up from too many people waiting to pay their toll.

either keep all booths open, except one or two for fastrak, or say left lane fastrak only for the whole bridge.  It will ease traffic for everybody.
author: Dustin E.

description:
We ALL know its not Golden (actually, its "International Orange").  Get over it, people.

I mainly wanted to write a review so I could quasi respond to all the lovely, beautiful, well informed people who give the Bridge a low score because "Its not Golden" (or some variation on the theme).  Go crack a book, ask a tour guide, even go on Wikipedia for Chis sake and the Bridge's namesake will magically reveal itself to you.  Its not rocket science.  Stop being dumb.

Anyway, the Golden Gate Bridge is great for so many reasons its insane.  On a clear day, when I'm standing in the middle of the span, and the entire Bay Area is spread out before me, I remember why I love living in San Francisco, and everything is right with the world.

Also, Joseph Strauss is a lying, credit stealing, sack of sacks.  Just saying.
author: Jesse J.

description: The Golden Gate Bridge is the symbol of San Francisco, and a beautiful one at that. I have spent many days scared to cross it, but when you get over that, the view is great and it makes you happy to be in such a great place.
author: Carlos H.

description: As a standing symbol of our beautiful city, it is this bridge that makes me think of home sweet home whenever I see it pictured anywhere. Sometimes I feel like it's the most breathtaking experience just taking a nice long walk across it, seeing the beautiful views of the entire bay area and that huge open ocean out there. And who can blame tourists from wanting to visit this glorious world symbol that represent one of the greatest melting pots in the entire world? It's just too darn bad they can't afford to call it home (as soon many of won't be able to either)
author: Petra S.

description:
The bus dropped all of us off near the Golden Gate Bridge gift shop. Initially, Hiep and I were disappointed because we thought that the bus was going to drive over the Bridge not drop us off near the toll booths. It was so foggy up there that you couldn't even see the outline of the bridge. Initially, we walked down to the bike path once I saw Fort Point at the base of the bridge. Took a couple of pictures. Then Hiep asked if I wanted to walk a little ways onto the bridge. I figured why the hell not and we proceeded towards the bridge. One thing they never tell you about the Golden Gate Bridge? Besides its enormous size, it's incredibly noisy due to the vehicular traffic that crosses the bridge. It's right next to your ear when you're walking the sides of the bridge. And it's downright scary to walk a bridge of that size. I don't know how suicide jumpers do it. I had this irrational fear that a gust of breeze would blow me off the bridge and right into San Francisco Bay. I had to securely hold my camera because I was worried it would get blown out to sea as well. The bridge is unique for picture-takers because you have to wait for the patches of fog to clear in order to take decent pictures of the Bay and of the Bridge itself. Hiep and I spent at least two minutes watching how the fog moved across the bridge in an eastern direction and determining when would be a good time to snap a picture. I mean, hey, it's not like we're coming here again any time soon. We walked to the first pillar, then turned back and headed to the gift shop. The walkway was fully of people. It was, admittedly, pretty cool.

I got a photo frame and a tee-shirt at the gift shop for my parents, then we boarded a bus back to San Francisco. We only waited about two stops before we got off at Richardson and Francisco St. to go to the Exploratorium. Sadly, the grounds around the Palace of Fine Arts (the big Grecian-designed Rotunda) were fenced off for renovation and so we couldn't walk around there.
author: Henry T.

description: It closes too early.  Brought my brother and his fiance here, so she can see the sites.  It was only 7pm and it was closed!?!? What gives?  It was still a good view of the bay.
author: Ricardo R.

description:
This is, like, a totally good bridge. 

And not just "good" good - it's, like,"sushi grade" good.

In eighth grade the lot of us school tykes marched across it, the culmination of an afternoon or weekend or whatever spent marching around the Marin Headlands. It was pretty rainy and exceedingly windy, such that your standard-issue field-trip rain parka would billow up like a wounded blow fish. Now, Reader, I don't know if you've had much occasion to walk the bridge, but even under normal conditions, on an average day, it feels as if absolutely all of your weight is needed to keep yourself from being lifted bodliy by the Pacific winds and casually dropped to the rocks and crashing waves below. Under these more extreme conditions, in the driving rain, in the howling winds, in the dark of late evening, in a ballooning plastic sheet parka, in the thralls of a fourteen year old's emotions, it's fair to describe the experience as something approaching "harrowing". Now, not exactly "terrifying"; more like how you must feel when you think: "Oh My God, I'm Actually Skydiving". However that feels.

And yet, I still think this is a totally good bridge.

Our German friend Ollie, who crashed on our couch in Berkeley for a few months in '99 or '00 while he was waiting to get deported (lousy Europeans, taking our jobs! Whhhyyy I oughtta.....), regarded a trip to go see the bridge as akin to seeing the Eiffel Tower. To which we locals respond, "Hey, yeah..." and smile and think warmly of ourselves.

Did you see that suicide movie they made, using daily footage they took of the bridge over the course of a year? Sure you did! It was kinda controversial because they didn't tell the Park Service (or whoever runs the land under and near the bridge) what, exactly, they were up to with the cameras. I think they told them they wanted to study the effects of ocean moisture on red paint. Seriously, I'm not making that up. 

Ok, I am making that up. But they totally didn't tell them it was about suicide. Because the authorities might have said, um, no, it's NOT cool for you to film suicides. Which probably wouldn't have been seen by the public as that unreasonable a response.

I think it was even called "The Bridge". Kinda disappointing. It was just about the people who jumped and their particular lives and circumstance, and not about the bridge per se, or the relationship between bridges and suicide, which is the movie I was expecting. They should have just called it "Suicide".

Did I just bring the mood down? My bad. Sorry to mention the whole suicide thing, but it's kinda part and parcel of being a famous bridge, I guess. Like Genghis Kahn, right? Everyone loves Genghis Khan, thinks he was totally cool, but there was a downside too, you know? People got hurt.
author: Ron Rico R.

description:
"just another bridge" 

....NO, great views- a little chilly but, it is an opening to the pacific.
author: Winter Lee S.

description: Of course this is a 5 star bridge! Always open, beautiful views. You meet awsome people from all over the world when you walk accross. Traffic moves well most of the time and it takes you to Marin....it doesn't get any better.
author: Rob T.

description:
Envision a nun in full habit with a grey sweats and running shoes breaking through the mist on her morning jog across the bridge.

Only in San Francisco. 

And since I was a kid I always thought those yellow lane dividers things automatically pop up at the appropriate hour. Then recently I spotted a truck or van in the middle lane with a hand (think Adam's family Thing hand) reaching out of it dropping the little yellow thingies in place.
author: Tanya P.

description: What can I say I have lived in the Bay Area my whole life. For the first time 08/21/10 I actually walked across the bridge been many times just  never on the bridge as a pedestrian. What can I say a enjoyable experience only con it is busy with  little parking and the main lot have parking meters also it's a historical landmark and tourist attraction what to expect so just be ready for many hold with tourist, bikes, runners and lots of picture taking.
author: Norm G.

description: Architectural masterpiece and iconic symbol of SF. I can't even describe how beautiful and majestic the Golden Gate Bridge is. You just have to come and see it in person. I recommend taking the bus here and just walking on it because I know toll is about a million dollars now. But seriously it's a must see when visiting SF!
author: Rochelle I.

description:
My strongest memory of the Golden Gate.  I used to have an apartment where I had a view of the bridge from the kitchen.  This just a month or so after 9/11, the dot-com bust was hitting hard, and the energy of San Francisco was in decline.  One afternoon I was talking on the phone, looking out at the bridge.  Then I saw a plane heading for the bridge.  I swear I saw it, but I couldn't bring myself to tell the person I was on the with what was happening.  It was going to ram into the bridge.  It was on the perfect trajectory for it.   Then about 1000 meters from impact it turned away.  

I'm sure I saw it, but there was no mention on the news about it.   The next few days I would wake up in the morning and go into the kitchen, dreading the possiblity of seeing the bridge broken and burning.
author: Beau G.

description:
The Golden Gate Bridge is a beautiful and complicated object like anything of it's magnitude.

Tad Friend, of the New Yorker, wrote a powerful piece in 2003 that I will never forget about the Bridge and it's infamous appeal. 

Rather than read my hack attempts at being a humorist, I suggest you find this article and spend the next few minutes reading it. I just read it for probably the third time, and it's still moving. Nice work, Tad.
author: Aiden B.

description: We guestimated that he crossed it 759 times while living in Marin. Sunrises are better than sunsets. Not for one second did he ever tire of the magnificence.
author: Michelle S.

description:
My heart swells with pride every time I see this beautiful bridge...it's an amazing place to see the City whether you're driving on it or walking across. And by the way, have you tried walking across it recently? The wind, my god, is sure to whisk you away into the heavens, it's so strong. I love to watch tourists hold onto their hats and bravely face the wind.

At any rate, it's not red, it's International Orange.
author: Charlene L.

description:
Its gusty out there, even on the nice days. Watch out for tourists, they like to stop abruptly on the bridge. If you feel adventurous, just take your bike all the way to Tiburon. Its worth it!

Now for those that don't cross the bridge, also wear wind gear. The views are lovely at night when the fog settles in. The golden orange-red glow is eerie at times.
author: Judy L.

description:
I have lived in this city for 5 years now and you still can't wipe the enormous smile off my face when I drive across this bridge. I remember the first time I crossed it, convertible top down and with the sun out--I won't ever forget that feeling. Seriously. Thinking about it right now even makes me smile.

On the to-do list: bike the bridge, run the bridge, sail under the bridge.

Tips for tourists: don't forget your winter coat :)
author: Cindy P.

description:
I love seeing this bridge from any of the several great vantage points in Marin or San Francisco. What would SF even be without the Golden Gate Bridge? My favorite place to see it is Baker Beach, the best urban beach in the world...ok i'm going overboard with the SF-loving here, but still. The Bridge is awesome.

As for tolls: yes, they do suck, especially when they're going to go up to $6, but that's alright, because it's not like that money just falls into the bay. If anything tolls keep the Golden Gate Bridge from being even more crowded. Take your bike.
author: Alexander G.

description: I'm from San Jose, so just about 45 minutes south from this place and this bridge never gets old. My teacher told me that a lot of locals take our landmarks such as the Golden Gate Bridge for granted. She told me that people come from all over the world to see this place and we act like it's not big deal. Well as a photographer, I come here to shoot this as much as I can when I'm in town. It's always cloudy and windy in SF but if you get lucky, some sun would come in and add some color to the bridge. This place is a MUST GO TO if you ever are on the west coast. I'm telling you it's so worth it.
author: Don V.

description: Golden Gate Bridge is the Golden Gate Bridge. Who hasn't seen it right? Well I had never seen such interesting stuff on the bridge before! There was a sign that said "Crisis Counseling. There is hope. Make the call." WOW! How had I never seen that before? Weird huh? There's also an Emergency Service box (I assume there's a phone inside) and a big red button next to it. What does the button do???????????????? Shock the person trying to commit suicide so that the authorities have time to get to the person? I'm SO curious!
author: CJ J.

description:
What can I say?  This is probably the most photographed and certainly the most famous bridge of all.  You got to visit the Golden Gate when in San Francisco.  If not, it's like going to Disneyland and not seeing Mickey Mouse!

The Bridge is an awesome sight and such an engineering feat.  Driving on it is spectacular itself but walking it is truly amazing.  Not only do you get great views of the beautiful San Francisco Bay and the city but you'll be greeted by cool breezes and sometimes the ever-so-present San Francisco fog.  A romantic spot for couples and people who just want to experience it on foot.  It's picture-perfect!  

I have yet to bike across it!  Just beautiful...

Now if the city can only get rid of the increasing toll cost...
author: Vvn W.

description:
I'm in love with the view from this bridge :).  Having to drive to Marin for the past 2 months, this bridge beats the bay bridge by 100000x! and I really appreciate the iconic symbol of this bridge to SF.  This is such a nice bridge to ride your bike, sail under, walk across, or drive across.

Dont miss the bridge! the pictures dont do it justice!
author: Amelia S.

description: WTF?  $10 toll?  What a rip off.  $2.5 per axle.  FJ+2 axle trailer+toll booth=gouging!  Nice view though.....
author: andrew l.

description:
You know you are in San Francisco when you see this beautiful bridge.  It is simply amazing to gaze at and be inspired.  I'm sure I cant add much to what has already been said, but I will try.

I used to work in Sausalito.  Right across the bridge.  And on my bad days when I was in a bad mood, or just feeling crappy, i would drive across and all of a sudden feel happy.  It has this affect on people.  I still to this day drive across the bridge and stop over at vista point when i just want to be inspired.  Kind of like the statue of liberty, or the Eiffel tower.  Just simply amazing.

If you haven't walked across it, then you are missing out.  Do it.  The views are wonderful, and even if its foggy in San Francisco, usually when you get to the center of the bridge to the Marin side, the fog just disappears.
author: Terence P.

description:
Its my second time to cross this bridge ever since ive been in wonderland. Sometimes i think, up to now, I still play so much the role of Alice.

The first time was pretty much undeliberate. i did not plan on crossing 4 bridges in one single day- thats Richmond Br., Golden gate Br., Bay Br, and San Mateo Br., (it was my 3rd week of driving and for petes sake what do i know.) I was lost from Richmond going back to Hayward and Golden Gate bridge stood out among the other three. I guess it was a funny and awesome experience, not knowing whats in the North or whats in South.... Well "where is North and South" that day was more like it!

So back to my review-- crossing this bridge for the first time is one of my best experiences. it was so fascinating, you just wanna stop in the middle of traffic and watch that body of water glisten underneath it. Whats more--it was nearing sunset that day, how I wish I have a built in video cam that I could click on automatic when I pass through such beautiful sceneries while driving. I cant help but go a little bit slower and worry later about where to go next even if I was lost.--all the other cars just seem to vanish in front of you... if getting lost would be this grand, then I would opt to be lost from time to time--=) =) =)

It was really worth it. Your fee for the three other tolls absolutely wouldnt matter to you anymore..that was how it is for my first.

But today I intended to go back @ sunset. I have some down time after work and ive been googling the directions for quite a while now, so i prepared my toll, put my best music up,
 rolled down my windows for good fresh air ("ahh freedom" moment), and leaned back as I drove across this regal landmark. No glasses please, (dark or lensed) as i wanted to capture each second of this grandiose cruisin--

View was perfect, Golden and sparkling above all else- what seems to be Van Gogh's masterpiece.

Priceless.
author: Athens r.

description:
Coming from living in Seattle for years, and being a victim of too many tourists ruining EVERYTHING.. I hate tourists. I even hate being a tourist in other cities. I refuse to walk around with a giant map and stop in the middle of the street to take pictures of buildings. GO BACK HOME, GAH!!

However, the Golden Gate Bridge is one of those things that you can't help be a tourist around. All my standards of anti-tourism go RIGHT out the window and I start taking a million pictures and acting like an idiot when I'm nearby. It's beautiful, and huge, larger than life and makes me feel so small and amazed by human engineering.

I wouldn't drive across it though, because it costs an arm and a leg.
author: Mindy W.

description:
I think my co-worker said it best the other day.

"Everytime I drive across it, I just get tears in my eyes saying 'OMG CAN YOU BELIEVE THAT??? Can you believe how gorgeous that is?"

I have to say I am simply amazed each time I drive across it. But I don't cry. Ever. Unlike some people I know... Nate.

Remember to drive across with the sun/moon roof open and look up as you pass under the tremendous towers.

Take the first exit and drive through the tunnel that's under the highway. Follow the path until you're on the other side and there's some parking along the side of the road with a dirt trail.

Hopefully you can catch the Golden Gate on a clear day.
author: Jeffrey C.

description: I like to sneak into the trees on the hill next to your southern end, and smoke some ganja. Then I put on some reggae and slowly walk across you, stopping every few feet to marvel in the engineering and materials science, to think the architectural challenges your builders overcame, and the bizarre lack of graffiti on your beautiful rust-red face. Then I get to the other side, get stoned again, and do it all over again. You're my favorite bridge to stumble across west of the Brooklyn Bridge.
author: Soma S.

description: The bridge is simply magic.
author: LBen

description:
How can you not love the Golden Gate? I used to wake up every morning to the view of the bridge and I never got tierd of that. 

Definitely one of the places that I make sure to take visitors. Even if you don't want to walk/bike/drive across is, you can't come to San Francisco without seeing it.
author: Anita B.

description:
It's a bridge! It's a big one, people like to jump from it all the time but it costs a small fortune if you have to drive across it on a regular basis.

It's a great thing to see, it's impressive when there's no fog around it...
I think it's 4.5 seconds from roadway to water. Work with a guy that was almost hit by a jumper while kite surfing....that would have sucked!
author: Rob C.

description:
I LOVE crossing this bridge every time I commute from SF to Sausalito for my temp job. It doesn't matter if I'm stuck in bumper-to-bumper traffic. The view is just beautiful.

....Now I don't have an excuse to cross the bridge as much anymore. I miss you Golden Gate Bridge! :(
author: Serena W.

description: The Golden Gate Bridge is not only beautiful but a testament to human ingenuity and fortitude. One of the truly great engineering achievements of all time. As a native of The City, I am filled with a great sense of pride each time I look at or cross the bridge. Funny as it may sound, one of my prized possessions is a discarded rivet from the bridge's construction given to me by my grandpa
author: Nick R.

description:
Drove over the bridge this weekend and much to my car buddy's delight, a familiar tune popped into my head immediately...

Everywhere you look (everywhere)
There's a heart (there's a heart)
A hand to hold on to.
Everywhere you look (everywhere)
There's a face of somebody who needs you.

When you're lost out there and you're all alone
A light is waiting to carry you home
Everywhere you look.

Chippity ba-ba-dow
author: A W.

description:
Im doin' it.  Im writing a review on the people who collect the tolls as you cross the Golden Gate Bridge.  I cross this bridge about 4 times a week.  I do not have fast track, and I am glad for this.  While saving a buck per pass would be nice - I would have to miss out on the eye to eye connections with the people that sit there day in and day out.  Most are totally pleasant.  Some are downright friendly.  And some, I honestly associate with "coming home".  On late nights, when I drive home to San Francisco - I appreciate the greeting.
Over the years, we get to recognize each other and its pretty cool.
I want to thank all of the toll booth operators, and commend them on such a nice job on being friendly.  I wish the Bay Bridge and the Richmond Bridge had half as much class.  I also wish that these people would not be replaced by automated operators...but Im told this will happen by next year.  Is this a myth??!!
I will enjoy the warm welcome into San Francisco for as long as I am able.
Thank you!
author: M T.

description:
I have never walked it.  It is a long ways to the other side, but it amuses me to see the walkers huddled together fighting the winds and freezing their butts off.

The design is beautiful.  Love the arches and their art deco appearance.

A bit harrowing to drive over since there is only minor separation between you and the oncoming lanes.  Feel lucky that I haven't been involved in a car crash on the bridge because I can see how that can be a real possibility.
author: Femita J.

description:
Okay, I'm torn on this one.  On the one hand, here we have a national landmark and pretty much the symbol of my hometown San Francisco, standing proud and reddish-orange against the (sometimes) brilliant blue skies over the Bay.  Majestic, awesome.  So grand a spectacle it is that it has inspired hundreds to give their very own lives in its honor.  (Or maybe there's other reasons for that, but anywayz...)

On the other hand, why o why do you have to be so !@#$ing crowded on weekend evenings?!?  I got stuck in your incessant traffic jam coming back from an otherwise excellent bike ride in Marin and had to miss my own brother's going-away party!  Then a couple weeks later my buddy and I came back from a cool motorcycle ride to Pt. Reyes and once again you trapped us with your snarl of cars.  Good thing we were on the bikes, because we just lane-shared our way the hell out of there.  But even on this, you are so unforgiving:  Your lanes are way narrower and dangerous to lane-share than those of your lovely host city.  And the wind that you throw at us is heart-breaking!  Not only that, but I've seen your underside, and all I can say is that you need a change of underwear.

Three stars.
author: Chuck W.

description:
I am only putting this up to pass along a helpful tip on ways to view the bridge. See the location map? You want to go to the end of Marine Drive. You get a great view from the underside of the bridge that really can't be beat. 

Check out the view...
http://members.virtualtourist.com/m/p/m/2a4a52/
author: John S.

description:
I love this bridge, its one of the few bridges in the world that I would parked, get down and take pictures with it, I'm sure you guys did the same thing.
Its the real Landmark of San Francisco, with stories, I love stories.
author: Pat V.

description:
Pretty much the most famous bridge in the world. No trip to San Francisco is complete without crossing it - by car, bike or foot.


 On the Marin side you get a great view back to San Francisco, and the view that 90% of the photos are taken from. As far as tolls go, it's free to walk or bike, but by car you have to pay in the direction of San Francisco (like all the Bay Area bridges).


 One quirky, but very notable fact about the Golden Gate bridge is the incredibly high amount of people who chose to end their lives by jumping off it. The number is well into the 1,000s now.
author: Alistair H.

description:
Believe it or not, I get teary eyed everytime I drive thru this bridge. I did it for a year going to work at Greenbrae and boy do I miss it. I still cross it everytime I play tennis at San Rafael.

I compare it the Eiffel Tower...meaning...you know youre in San Francisco when you see it...(duh?) The view is great too from Twin Peaks on a clear moonlit night.

Sorry but the Bay Bridge is hideous. And I must say that I dont agree with the plans of putting barriers on the GG so that nobody would jump. People would jump whether its at the Bridge or not... so why spoil it for everyone.

I have taken many a pictures of this bridge, the first photo I bought from a local artist was the bridge and its hanging in my room.

I love that crimson colored bridge.
author: Malou C.

description:
This is an amazing landmark.  With an even more amazing view if the ocean and sunset if you come on a clear day, which isn't always easy to come by.  Fog many times just hoover over the bridge and beyond to the view.  Even with the fog is still a cool place to be.  I like walking from one side to the other.  The fresh air...strong wind..and mulitiudes of tourist, locals etc.  The many different nationalities. Hearing all the different languages that ppl are talking.  I even one time heard Finnish which is my languages and thats not easy to hear since their is so few ppl that speak it.

I got to admit when you look down i got a bit scared cuz its so far down and the strong wind on that bridge.  Its cool to when ships are down passing the bridge and you look down and see an enormous ship down below.
author: Vesa S.

description: The Bridge is stunning and a true icon, but I would love to know what they need $6 per car for...red paint is not that expensive, trust.  Also on the subject of paint, the north bound surprise! merge after the toll plaza has been unmarked for at least 15 years, causing thousands of near misses daily for unsuspecting first time tourists and seasoned vets alike.  Just paint an arrow, amirite?
author: R C.

description: I love driving through the Golden Gate Bridge.  I must say, plan your route and exits to take pictures.  I made the mistake of passing the first one and ended up having to pay the toll TWICE!  This is such a nice place to take pictures!  Be prepared and some have said...bring 10 jackets because it does get really cold in the winter time.
author: Olivia J.

description: The views are great and the historical background is known world wide. Neither of these are the reason that I give it a solid five stars though. This location is where I asked my girlfriend to marry me and received a yes. I walked onto that bridge a nervous single person and walked off with the most wonderful person I could imagine spending the rest of my life with. The views and moments are magical on this landmark bridge.
author: J T.

description:
Living in SF, one can become immune to the majestic beauty that is our bridge. When you can locate it hidden beneath the frigging fog, that is. 

Freezing location unless it's a gorgeous day (which is probably 5-10 days out of the year), but when it is...my god, this place is fantastic. 

The BEST place to just stare at the bridge is probably not accessible to the general public but it is a commonly known secret that the steps of the Espanade in George Washington High School has the best view in the city.
author: tammy m.

description:
There really is nothing like biking by crissy fields on your way to the bridge. I wish my eyes could take pictures of all the beautiful views i've seen of the golden gate bridge.

When it's not being taken over by fog, it's truly a great experience to be in the presence of such a great structure. Seeing pictures, and video of it is nothing compared to the feelings you get when you get to see and touch it it in person.

I love biking over this bridge, the view of the ocean when you look over your shoulder is priceless. I can't count how many times i've gone over this bridge since i've moved here, but every time, it brings a smile and a warmth to my heart.
author: James E.

description:
AMAZING!

We ran across it this weekend in the light rain.  A great time to be out there - it was so peaceful - barely anyone was about and about.  No tourists. Made me truly happy to be back in SF.
author: Catherine B.

description:
I had a view of the Golden Gate Bridge from my house but unfortunately I have moved and only have fond memories. It is a beautiful structure and a must see for all visitors to San Francisco. It is free to walk, bike or jog across so a great low budget experience.


 I highly suggest walking across it and taking a moment along the way to have a look around and read the historical signs posted along the way. Bring your camera because the view in all directions is great.


 It is the most expensive bridge to cross in the bay area, 5 bucks maybe 6, and if you can, avoid driving over it when possible. It is not easy to get to or from without sitting in loads of traffic and if you are doing it for the novelty, then when you drive across you think I shoulda walked :)


 Oh and yes 24 people jump succesfully to their death each year and loads more are dragged away quite quickly and discreetly. There are policeman who patrol and video the bridge and are able to foil many attempts. If you are morbidly interested, watch the documentary called the bridge. (Warning: it is about suicides off the bridge and has very graphic footage.)
author: deannederego

description: It's a really impressive bulding. Definately worth talking the time to walk from the southern to the northern viewpoint.
author: Jürgen H.

description:
This is another one of those landmarks that some people may be impressed by if you've been there, but in the end there's not much to say about it.
There are some good views and it is a very grand structure, worth a visit or to look upon, but there are far more exciting things to do in the area!
We walked across it. It took bloody ages, was freezing cold and windy as Hell, the main excitement coming from trying not to be tossed over the side. But after about 5 minutes i was bored and wanted to turn around.
Go here, have a look, turn back around and do something else.
author: Weaver

description:
overrated, overpriced, very small and short! $6 one-way is a big ripoff compares to the $5 looong San Rafael Bridge or the FREE double-decker Bay Bridge. 

to get a complete SF tour, visit the city and drive over the Bay Bridge towards Oakland and connect to the 580 to San Rafael Bridge - you will get the most ocean views and better thrills, and LOTS gorgeous beaches and breathtaking views across the city such as Rodeo Lagoon and Muir Beach. and please do go back to SF by taking the Golden Gate so you can feel how overrated that stupid bridge is. 

pro: red color gave it good picture opportunities from the beaches around.
author: Y L.

description: If you have not yet, you MUST walk across this bridge on a warm, sunny day! There's nothing like it! I've walked across this bridge and back at least 3 times already and it's still magical every time. Bring a date because it's pretty romantic and it's a cheap date *shrug* =D
author: Lucky N.

description:
My father served on the USS San Francisco in WW2. He crossed under the bridge many times returning from the battles in the South Pacific (Back then, the ships docked at Mare Island for all you tourists). He loved SF and passed it on to me. So the bridge holds special significance for me, besides SF being my new home. 

And I have the solution to the "suicide barrier" debate: A giant net. 

So if someone jumps, they get stuck laying there having to think about what they just did while waiting for the rescue team. Problem solved.   ;D

Best view:  Heading south from Marin - coming out on the other side of the Waldo Tunnel. Takes my breath away every time.
author: K P.

description:
Luckily on a visit to San Francisco the weather stayed warm, clear and sunny and a trip over the Golden Gate Bridge by bike was just the job. I can imagine that in poor weather it would be hard work, as you are way up in the air and even on a pleasant day there was a stiff wind.


 As other qypers have suggested, hire bikes in San Francisco, cycle over the bridge to get views back of the city from Marin County.


 You could go back across, or carry on with some nice easy downhill riding into Sausalito, for a spot of something to quench hunger and thirst on the waterfront, then catch the ferry back to the city, more views and you go past Alcatraz.


 One Hundred Years of Solitude fans, keep your eyes peeled as the author is a resident of Sausalito
author: macallister

description: This bridge is the reason I moved to San Francisco. What more to say?
author: T W.

description:
When i was 5, i thought this giant red contraption was THEE coolest thing in Frisco (sorry, i know you no cal'rs hate that word).  But after comming back from sausalito, its now a 3.5 star attraction.  One star off for charging 7 Bones.  Yikes.....the bay bridge is only $4.  Another star off for leaving this bridge wide open for suicide jumps.  DUDE... after watching people marching across the bridge by foot, I started to think, how many suicides could've been prevented?  I normally dont make public announcements, and more often than not, I usually say, people have a right to do the hell whateva they want.  But in this case, somethings not right.  How bout some safety nets right below the railings?  Shit, im already forkin over $7., might as well make it an even $10, and buy some friggin nets.  

This message was sponsored by a concerned so cal citizen.

Thank you.
author: Shon T.

description:
The bridge is a big visitor's attraction, however be careful when you go as the fog comes off the coast and can totally obscure your view and you have to pay $5 to get back into town.


 The view from North point when sunny is great.
author: aaron

description: It finally was a nice weekend to walk the span of this massive, impressive bridge! We went on Sunday around 3pm.  If you are coming from the East Bay cross the Bay Bridge and park on the side of Marin (that is, drive over the Golden Gate and then park).  That, way you save money and don't have to pay at the parking lot on SF side.  We already paid for one bridge and didn't want to pay another parking fee.  Although you are literally on the bay, bring enough clothing to your discretion.  It was farily warm when we went so a tank top and shorts did it for me.  But after spending time taking pictures and marveling over the bay view, 2 hours later crossing the bridge back it started getting really windy.  So, I say bring a light jacket just in case.  I defintiely loved walking across the bridge and definitely coming back next time to have a romantic walk during the late evening.  I believe the bridge closes at 6pm weekends 7pm weekdays. So plan accordingly and don't accidentally get stuck when those iron gates close !!! And please, if you need help there are several call boxes for crisis counseling.
author: cheryll t.

description:
The best view of the bridge is from the viewing point at the far end as you leave San Francisco. If you've got a car and are planning to visit other places in California then leave it as the last thing you do, on your way out of the city.


 Otherwise, the view from Alcatraz is pretty spectacular when the mist isn't blocking the view!
author: goldielegg

description:
I was glad to get the chance to say I've seen this. I was on my way back to San Francisco airport. The bus was supposed to stop so we could take pictures but didn't. I got a few pictures taken from the bus as we came on the approach to the bridge.


 My only disappointment was same as the Sphinx in Cairo its not as big as it looks on tv. We were across it in no time at all but still I can say I've seen it.
author: unixgirl

description: OK so I write a lot of reviews of the.GGB and FORT POINT! Mostly to praise and bitch about the beauty the splendor and the  awesomeness of the Bridge itself.But the dark side which I experience way too much almost makes me sad and Upset. So now I surf and stand up paddle under and around the bridge. Not advisable to ride the waves there on a SUP, the locals hate it and for good reason. It can really be dangerous and life threatening for them. But this is about the JUMPERS that take their own lives off the Bridge. I was paddleing around the tower and buoy there. Luckily I saw my Dolphin friends and followed them farther into the Bay. I turn around and again I see a lady climb over the rail of the bridge and jump, belly flop and gone with the ebbtide out the Gate. As I said before, maybe she's the 20th 30th person I have seen take their life there. Please if you want to JUMP the bridge. Look below and DO NOT take out an innocent surfer, paddler, kiteboarder with you. Have some freaking respect. Personally I would take a large amount of some LETHAL DRUG and KILL myself without endangering the public and making a freaking Spectacle of myself! And also do it so no one would have to deal with the aftermath of the mess I made of myself. Go far far away in no mans land with a couple of bullets, gun and a can of gas and a lighter. Douse yourself with gas shoot yourself really fast and BINGO! No mess no fuss for anyone. That is the respectful way. Why let a loved one find you? Why make the public deal and witness your death? I said it almost makes me sad and upset, I have seen, dealt with and witnessed the aftermath of F-ing WAR , suicides, accidents and you name it. IT REALLY SUCKS!
author: Larry Y.

description:
When walking on the bridge, make eye contact with fellow pedestrians, and  talk to people who appear listless, staring out at the water. Notice those who look suspicious! 

Not only is this bridge beautiful and accessible, but people from all over the world come here to commit suicide. Let's do all we can to help redirect those who would die here into living another day. Being demonstratably kind to others-caring about them when we see they are distraught-is what makes this happen. 

 PLEASE do what you can to advocate a Golden Gate bridge with suicide barriers. Let's stop the deaths.

I give the bridge a four star rating because of the lack of suicide barriers for its four-foot railings. Someone I loved jumped from its heights.
author: B W.

description:
It's big, bold and beautiful and we were lucky enough to see it on a clear crisp sunny December day. We walked across the bridge and back and the views were spectacular. Definitely worth the visit.


 Hint: If you are in SF without a car and are mobile enough, definitely suggest walking to the bridge from Fisherman's Wharf. It's a scenic walk and approx 3miles with only two small inclines (one at Fort Mason and the other right underneath the bridge at Fort Point to get to the visitors' centre). 3miles sounds long but in reality it isn't as you are so enthralled in the views that you don't notice the distance. As you walk along the shoreline most of the way you get to see sights and sounds that a lot of visitors would miss out on. If you do the walk make sure you take the slight 5min detour to visit Palais of Fine Arts (where the Exploratorium is housed) and check out of the human sundial on the ground. A beautiful and peaceful walk in what can sometimes be a busy city. A definite must. One of our highlights of the whole holiday.
author: Nathanw88

description:
Get there early and dress warm.

We got there around 9:30 and the crowds were starting to pour in... by the time we left it was too crowded.  If I were to do it again, I would get there at dawn.

We took a city bus to get there, and it drops you off right before the bridge near the bathrooms and gift shop.  From there, the view is breathtaking.  The path to the bridge is beautiful and full of flowers.  There is a wonderful viewpoint that gives you an unobstructed view of the bridge - wonderful for pictures.  

We walked halfway across the bridge (with a toddler and a stroller - that was more than enough).  It's a little dangerous. I was so nervous that my little girl would fall through the sides of the bridge.  It would be a long shot, but you never know with kids.  At any rate, hang onto them tight.  Also, the walking path is shared by bicyclists and maintenance vehicles.  Watch out!  Both the cyclists and the maintenance vehicles will run you over, so you need to constantly look out behind you.  A bit nerve racking with a little one.  However, it's something you need to do.  After all, it's a San Francisco landmark that you came here to see.  So see it, but see it early.
author: Noah B.

description: I have like a dozen pictures with the bridge in the background :D
author: Deezoo

description: Pretty darn cool bridge! I saw it when I was younger but didn't remember much. It's HUGE, red and touristy. It doesn't cost anything to ride if leaving San Fran but the other way does. $6 for those without the toll pass, $5 with. There are pull offs to stop and take pictures before you get on and right when you get off. It's pretty cool to get out and walk on the bridge. It's a far way down!
author: reviewer m.

description:
Every want to know a little more about this amazing bridge?
Every Sunday and Thursday http
SF City Guides gives tours.
and its free.
author: Cathie L.

description:
It's so iconic and awe inspiring - even with the high cost of traversing it I love it every time. Driving over this bridge is pretty freaky with the narrow lanes and little cone things - even after hundreds of head-on collisions they have yet to get a better barrier system in place... As a passenger, walker or bicyclist this bridge is beautiful - the weather around it changes many times throughout the day and all of the water in the bay is swept out to see twice a day beneath it.

You can get the best photo-ops of the bridge from Baker Beach or from the cliffs in the Marin Headlands.
author: Quartknee K.

description: There's a ton of construction by the touristy side, so there's a tractor in a few of my photos.  Oh well.  On a clear day, the bay looks gorgeous.
author: k h.

description:
We arrived in San Francisco the day before and we hired a champagne gold convertible Mustang for a road trip. It would have been a cardinal sin not to drive over the Bridge whilst in San Francisco. 

I spend the first few hours literally going around San Francisco. I struggle generally with my left and right so God help me drive in the wrong side of the car on the wrong side of the road. There are signs posted for the Bridge but I tend to over analysis them! Sign say 'go Right' and I would think to myself 'now or later, in the centre right or right right?!?!' Sign says 'Yield' - What the f*ck?!?! 

When we finally arrive at the Bridge it was just momentous - part relief and excitement. I have passed my first test and it was a good sign that I will survive my road trip. We stopped at Fort Point at the end of the Bridge. Very busy with tourists - all wanting a picture with the Bridge in the background. Oh by the way - its very windy so put on a jumper and keep on to your hats. Parking is free but there is a toll to cross the Bridge ($6.00). 

The views of San Francisco were okay. Nothing special. Sorry to disappoint however the Bridge itself is a masterpiece. I think I will have to come back and walk across the Bridge to really appreciate it. 

Personally I still prefer Runcorn Bridge!
author: Benjamin L.

description: I just drove from my girlfriends in San Rafael to my house in SF.  I was blasting some French Kicks and Maps (fantastic indie rock from Britain).  The sun was setting.  Nothing else mattered except being in the moment and feeling lucky be able to appreciate this spectacular spot that we live.  The $6 toll?  Steep.  That feeling of complete bliss?  Priceless.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
Walk the earth.  Start by walking this thing, and the earth surrounding it.

The energy around this bridge is off the charts.  You have to walk it to appreciate it, though (and maybe be a California native, but that's another review).  I know, many will think "what, walk around, under, across . . . the GG Bridge?  meh."  But seriously, even if you have lived in the bay area your entire life and you have never done this, it is worthwhile.  Do it right if you're going to do it:  Start early in the morning, or at least make a half day of it.  Pack a light lunch and plenty of water, camera, mp3 player loaded with your extreme best collection, comfortable walking attire, and layered clothing for the many weather conditions you will encounter.  

Many locals don't realize you can walk along the water on dedicated unbroken paths sidewalks all the way from SF Giant's Stadium (AT&T Park) all the way to Sausalito.  Walking across the GG to Sausalito is a great day trip btw, and Sausalito has a ton of great lunch spots, not to mention shopping and endless general people gawking and bugging opportunities -- and after spending a few hours enjoying Sausalito one can walk/bike back or even catch a GG transit bus back to downtown SF for ~$5).  That's right:  walk.  Or bicycle.  That makes for a great trip, but you don't have to go that far -- you can adjust the length of your trip as you wish: one can start from Fisherman's Wharf, Crissy Field, simply start at one end of the bridge and walk to the other side, or a number of starting points in between.   Do venture down the paved paths under the bridge on each end though, to experience what it feels like, and take a moment to take in the view of the bay, the entrance to the bay, and Pacific Ocean expanding westward, as you stand under this engineering marvel from another era.  

Now I'm not a big birdwatcher, but the subtle & silent bird show here is stupendous, for those with eyes to see.  Watch the sea birds fly in from around the bay, slowly, slowly, but ever so surely toward the bridge.  Observe as they make their daily trip toward the ocean, and the sea cliffs.  Watch them carefully navigate around the pillars and cables thrust high into the air by this strange monument erected by aliens called humans, as the wind gusts harder and threatens to slam them into the cables.  Follow their path as they pass above, below, and through the bridge and often turn southward, where they will spend hours gliding and soaring, effortlessly gliding from the strong updrafts on the sea cliffs overlooking Baker Beach and endless beaches below.  Some say they are simply looking for food.  Others agree that they are looking for food a bit, but mostly they are enjoying gliding and soaring effortlessly on the powerful updrafts caused when the winds off the Pacific meet the sea cliffs and strong streams of air are forced straight up keeping the birds and your spirit -- airborne.  Welcome to the west coast.  Feel it.
author: Jack H.

description: 5 stars for this bridge for only one reason. Remember the quake? Well I was on my way into the city when it hit. Was halfway across the bridge. Now I have been on it when there has been a very strong wind and have felt the bridge sway back and forth more than once. That day was definetely different. I'm driving along minding my own business when I saw what appeared to be explosions in the city and then my car changed lanes without me turning the wheels. Yaahooooo, talk about a thrill ride. That is one ride I will never forget.
author: Charlie O.

description: I've sailed under it, driven over it, walked across it, and flown over and under it.  It's beautiful, and unique.  A must-see San Francisco icon.  And, as every tourist is quick to note, it's not gold.
author: David D.

description: Spent a nice Saturday afternoon walking on the Golden Gate Bridge this past weekend.. it wasn't too sunny although the weather wasn't bad.. I use to come here alot but just stayed in the garden area next to the bridge to take pictures and enjoy the scenery. My first time walking on the bridge it was a beautiful view of the city..it's nice to come out here if you want to spend some time w/ family friends and want to be outdoors. The bridge is a nice place to take all your relatives from out of town.. they'll be amazed!
author: karenina c.

description: I guess everyone will think I'm real stupid or something to that effect. But, I fail to understand why they call it the GOLDEN Gate Bridge. It looks RED to me. A person would think they would paint it with GOLD paint instead or red, then they could call it GOLDEN.
author: Carlie R.

description: I proposed to my wife on the north side of the Golden Gate Bridge. Prior to proposing, I organized the day to start early am with breakfast at our favorite shop. We followed the agenda and visited every single favorite place we liked when we dated. North Beach, areas near USF, Lombard Street, Haight Ashberry shopping plus Ben & Jerry's Ice Cream, Golden Gate Bridge, second hand shopping, and we enjoyed lunch at the first Past Pomodoro just near Filmore and Chestnut. Pasta Pomodoro is long gone, but we use to have romantic dinners several times a week where we whispered sweet nothings and gazed at each other. Pasta Pomodoro was replaced with Pacific Catch fresh fish grill. I loved this place too much. Next we would walk Filmore street and window shop. My wife loves the San Francisco style hats and such things. I like the memories. We would walk through the Palace of Fine Arts. Anyhow, I proposed to my wife on the north side just to the west of the Golden Gate Bridge. She was certainly surprised when I dropped on one knee. She was so shocked, that she did giggled and smiled with gleaming eyes for several minutes. I waited for "THE ANSWER" that would change my life forever. So I said, "what is your answer?" She said, "Yes, honey, I love you." Man, I love the Golden Gate Bridge. Too romantics and so many memories of a BEAUTIFUL 75 year old work of Orange Metal ART. Cheers.
author: Arnold F.

description: It has to be one of the coolest landmarks I've ever seen up close. Your crazy not to go see it if your in San Francisco. You gotta walk the bridge, I'd recommend doing that over biking it. Enjoy the view, take some pictures and take more pictures. Park your car and take the walk it's worth it and don't forget to wear your hoodie. The wind is strong, but it's not a deterrent.
author: Nicholas J.

description: If you live here and haven't walked across the Golden Gate, shame on you! Take my advice and make it a priority some weekend morning in the very new future. It's awe-inspiring ... and right in our own collective backyard.
author: Gregor G.

description: San Francisco is sooooo cool it has a $5 cover charge!
author: Poochie M.

description:
In my admittedly limited travels, I have to say that I think the Golden Gate Bridge is the most beautiful man-made spot on the planet.  More beautiful than the Ponte Vecchio in Florence, more beautiful than the Statue of Liberty, the Empire State Building, or even the entire skyline of Manhattan.  More beautiful than the city-state megalopolis of Singapore, more beautiful than the Dom of Cologne, or the Eiffel Tower.  

I'm sure there are a million arguments to be made for all of these places, and the hundred more man-made wonders to be found elsewhere on the planet, but this is my choice, and I'm sticking to it.  I lived in San Francisco for fifteen years, and my in-laws still live in Mill Valley, so I've driven across this bridge probably thousands of times, and every time...I'm talking EVERY TIME...even when traffic's backed up and I'm seriously late for something, even when I forgot the five bucks cover charge to enter the City from Marin County, I always think the same thing:  This is the most beautiful thing in the world.  The towers, the cables, the water below, the Farallon Islands in one direction, the Marin Headlands in another, Alcatraz and Angel Island another, and of course, the unnaturally white skyline of San Francisco in another...the fog that pours through the Gate in a variety of dramatic fashions - either above, below, or through the Bridge itself - it's enough to make you believe in the Great Spirit.  

When you walk across it, you get the full effect of its grandeur, and sometimes, you can feel its vibrations and its movement as thousands of cars pour past you in both directions, a river of humanity in every color.  Tourists, dogs, and natives stream alongside you on the wide walkway, and even the awareness that hundreds of suicides have leapt to their deaths from here adds a certain amazing vibe to the walk:  The kind of courage and the depth of the despair that it would take to make someone jump from that great height into the always dramatic water below is almost unfathomable.  Especially when you consider the intense and almost unbearable beauty in whose midst you find yourself.  I hope to see the world before I die, and I hope I see many things whose beauty rivals this spot.  But I don't think I'll ever believe a spot is more beautiful than this one.
author: Ken N.

description: It's one of the few inanimate objects in the world that just seems larger than life- like the sum of every dream you've ever had materialized in the form of a bridge. You must see it during your lifetime. Thanks, P.
author: Joe S.

description: Phenomenally breathtaking!  My great grandfather helped build this, fell off, and lived.  And to me, that's the best part.
author: Vanessa Z.

description: The most beautiful bridge in the world. I love it despite bike accidents and hate it for being more famous that the Roman bridge of Salamanca. :-)
author: Javi V.

description:
On 9/18/07, I have to say, I finally did one of the TO DO THINGS BEFORE I DIE and relived my dream... 

Yes, I am still (so what?) an undercover tourist at heart. Even yet, i live in the Marina, and I STILL GET A KICK OUT OF STARING AT THE BRIDGE ON A DAILY BASIS. Even so, it seriously brightens my day.. if only they would LIGHT UP THE INFAMOUS GOLDEN GATE @ night.. 

Def a landmark, and def what makes SF ... sahn frahnceesco ... 

So, onto reliving my dream... "Dream" meaning, I had a dream few months back prior to my move to SF that I literally jumped off the bridge, of course I didn't go to THAT extent but it was def a weird experience.

It was a gorgeous, sunny yet slightly windy day.

Took an hour, 30-35 mins each way and it was DEF well worth it!  

Approx 1.7 miles. 

If I CAN DO IT, YOU CAN DO IT!

Walking & driving the GG are TWO COMPLETE DIFFERENT EXPERIENCES!

TIP: when driving, try NOT to speed, it's HARD NOT TO, but i repeat, be careful, you will be VERY SURPRISED of those mofos who try to get you. i was SUPER LUCKY NOT GETTING PULLED OVER. i even saw a bridge patrol RIGHT BEHIND ME few times, scanning my plate, while driving and talkin to his dispatcher, but after we crossed the toll, all was good. *phew*

I have to admit, it was a lil bit scary having to walk 101N and feeling the cars driving by... at one point it felt as if you were going to be tossed into the bay since it was so windy at times. They even have an emergency fone to even help those who need crisis counseling. yes, it seriously said that on one of those signs, "Emergency Phone & Crisis Counseling..." WTH? is it for people to call right before they try to jump off the bridge??

Took 2 local fotos for your pleasure. Not of the bridge since there were TONS of yelpers who did. I took one for the clumsy folks & a memory token of GG who slipped between the cracks. 

NOW, THAT'S DEF A CRAZY FLUKE. Call me weird but it's strange how not only did GG have the same initials as the Golden Gate, but the same amount of letters.

Anyways, I'm doing this again. i'm SO doing this again...

PS. I posted some fun facts... Read below.



Golden Gate Bridge Facts - Traffic 
. Average crossings: About 40 million per year, counting both north- and southbound crossings, compared to 33 million crossing the first year it was open. 
. Fewest crossings: January, 1982, during a storm which closed U. S. 101 north of the bridge. On January 6, only 3,921 southbound vehicles passed the toll gates. 
. Most crossings: October 17, 1989, after the Loma Prieta earthquake, when Bay Bridge was closed. 162,414 vehicles (counting those going both directions) crossed the bridge that day. 
. Total crossings: Through October 30, 2002, the Golden Gate Bridge Highway District says 1,754,094,967 vehicles crossed the bridge. 
. Closures: The bridge has been closed three times for weather, for gusting winds over 70 mph. It closed briefly for visits by President Franklin D. Roosevelt and French President Charles DeGaulle. It was also closed on its fiftieth birthday

IMPORTANT DATES
. May 27, 1937: Bridge opens to pedestrians. 
. May 28, 1937: Bridge open to automobiles. The toll was 50 cents one way, $1 round trip and 5 cents surcharge if there were more than 3 passengers. 
. February 22, 1985: The one-billionth car crosses the bridge. Toll is $2 southbound on Friday and Saturday, $1 otherdays. No northbound toll. 
. May 28, 1987: Bridge closed to vehicles for its fiftieth birthday. An estimated 300,000 pedestrians jammed the bridge. 
. September 1, 2002: Toll increased to $5 southbound. No northbound toll
author: Jennifer S.

description: I want to walk across the bridge...and not just drive over it.  But until that day comes, the Golden Gate is still that amazing symbol that just screams, "California".  I've been there 3 times now...and you want to go to the hills just to the NW of it...to take in the view.  Simply amazing...and free!  Except the tolls of course.
author: Kyle R.

description: Driving over the golden Gate bridge is a must whenever I arrive at Frisco! Right after heading North on the bridge you can hang a quick right, park the car, and take some amazing pictures of the Bay, Alcatraz Island, and the bridge itself! On your way back (heading South), take a quick right just before the bridge and you'll find a sweet joyride through some historical areas of the Bay that many people miss! I'm talking history about the gun placements that were planned to guard the Bay in case of attack among many more areas of historical fun (plus some stunning views!).
author: Joshua W.

description:
gorgeous, beautiful, breathtaking. there is so much history behind this bridge. would you wanna stand here during an 8.1 earthquake ? remember it was built by men who knew the importance of engineering, quality, and craftsmanship. so yeah, I believe I would be safe on this structure during the big one, not a doubt in my mind.

suicide barrier ? pshaw ! let 'em jump, the crazy self-loathers. we're better off without them
author: Prima D.

description: I've walked it and ran it.. I visited during the day and visiting during the night. I enjoyed it alone and with a partner..  with fog and with sun..and every time it was awesome. Though I've been here for years each time I go across the bridge I'm like a tourist seeing it for the first time.  You can walk it to the Marin side and have an awesome view of SF..  or loop it on a walk to Crissy Field. It's ironic we have such an awesome bridge on one side and one of the ugliest (and in shambles) on the other.
author: Dan T.

description:
It speaks for itself.  Viewed from below at Fort Point or from above at the Marin Headlines, it speaks for itself.  Favorite times to view: pre-dawn, dawn, dusk, and under the stars.  Also best viewed on unusually warm days when the ladies are enjoying the bridge wearing their summer clothes!  Why there aren't more accidents on the bridge on those days, I'll never know.

Footnote:  The golden part?  The bridge spans The Golden Gate and is not The Golden Gate itself.
author: Brian M.

description: Its beautiful. I have one of my pics on my page that I took of it. Wow just love it.
author: Lisa P.

description: This has got to be the most beautiful bridge ever.
