Having never been to San Francisco (or California for that matter), before moving here 9 months ago, it was definitely an amazing sight to see for the very first time in person. I found myself taking picture after picture, even though they were all of pretty much the same thing, but it was just so pretty! I haven't had the pleasure of walking all the way across and then back to San Francisco, though I did walk about 1/2 way across before turning back. It was extremely windy the day we went, and we had our daughter in her stroller... and she somehow managed to fall asleep, but we decided to head back anyway. I've since been back one time, and this time I walked the trail down to Chrissy Field, and the views of the bridge from there are just as beautiful.
author: Danielle S.

description: Happy 75th Anniversary, Golden Gate Bridge! The place is great for people of all ages to walk on and view San Francisco, the bridge itself, and the Pacific Ocean. Cars use the bridge to travel, and there is a toll booth. My grandmother and my great grandparents were alive whent the Goldgen Gate Bridge was being made and when it was opened for the first time. The Golden Gate Bridge is an important part of San Francisco history and California history.
author: DJ Guan Yu M.

description: The best way to experience the GG Bridge is to bike across it!  Use the side designated for bicycles so you don't have to plow over any tourists, and watch out for the folks on rented bikes.  Let folks know if you'll be passing them on the left, and move over to the right if they're trying to pass you.  Be careful going around the towers -- shift into a lower gear before you approach, because the wind will sometimes slam you to a halt as you make that first turn.
author: Andi T.

description: I drive across this bridge every morning and evening on my long commute up to Santa Rosa.  I regularly will gasp at how beautiful it is.  Even though I see it every day, I still think it is amazing.  I usually carpool and when I am not driving I will look behind in the morning and the incredible view or the sunrise, the bridge and the city in the background.  I am so lucky to live here.
author: Kate B.

description: What a nice way to spend the afternoon...walking across the bridge, pausing to look at the expansive beautiful view and taking in all the awe.  It makes you appreciate how much time, effort and lives went into building this bridge.  The weather was picture perfect as the was the view.  It's no wonder there are so many tourists.  A must see/do when in SF.
author: Gwen A.

description: Holy, mighty moly!! Its beautiful. Ok so make sure you don't do what we did and go around 5pm, firstly, its rush hour. We were on holiday so we forgot people live and work here! So 5pm its busy but we love it! Its $6 toll, but you pay ont he way back, not the way there. We said, ok, we will drive across, take pics, and drive back. NO! We didn't realise how amazing and beautiful it is across that magical bridge. It looks as though you've hit the south of france. Its beyond amazing. Drive 2-3 miles over the bridge and hit 'saualito' and get off, go get and ice cream and watch life, pretend you live there. I loved it here. Ask someone where 'marin park is' you will find a lovely tiny park with a fountain and elephant staues and opposite is a crepe place (nothing fancy) but they do crepes/burgers everything and the crepes are amazing!!!! and cheap, like $3 for a huge crepe,plus nutella!!!! Love it!
author: Rachael S.

description: Beautiful bridge...and very entertaining to see all the tourists walking around in shorts because..."well this IS California afterall.  Always about 80 degrees!" Hahahaha
author: Robin L.

description:
the view is spectacular !!!

really enjoyed the walk on the bridge on a relaxing Sunday afternoon.

didn't expect the weather to be this windy, will make sure to bring a jacket next time.
author: Seth L.

description:
by far one of the most recognizable structures in the world and defiantly jaw dropping. 

i love when i see a movie and it opens up on the wonderful beauty of the bridge and from then on i know it's a movie filmed in s.f. and i'm soooo excited. living in the tri valley east bay i wish i were close so i could see this beauty each and every day.

the bay area is by far one of the most beautiful places to live in the world and life is great so remember that. i found the following quite interesting yet sad someone could actually want to end it all. so keep an smiling and smile often!:)

 More than 85 percent of people who jump from the bridge are Bay Area residents.
- Northern California residents account for more than 92% of the suicide jumps.
- Average jumper's age: 42. (Youngest: 14-year-old girl; oldest: 84-year-old man)
- Men outnumber women almost 3 to 1.
- Caucasians account for 83 percent of all fatalities.
- San Francisco and Marin counties had the highest number of deaths, followed by Santa Clara and Contra Costa counties.

More than 1,250 people have jumped off the bridge. This is only the number of confirmed jumps or bodies being found. Due to foggy conditions and a strong current, it is entirely possible to leap off the bridge witout a trace.

For the last 10 years, it has been running on average about 24 fatalities a year. The jump is fatal 98 percent of the time.

One last interesting note, nearly every person to jump off the Golden Gate Bridge has done so from the bay side, not the ocean side. The ocean side is considered too cold and impersonal.
author: Scotty D.

description: I see pictures of this when young. I like so much. So beautiful. So tall. So romantic.
author: Elizaveta C.

description:
Every morning I wake up. Actually, "wake up" is a bit strong. My alarm goes off, and I consider the pros and cons of chucking it out the window. 
Eventually, I fall out of bed, bringing my sheets and blankets with me, and crawl to the bathroom, where I splash water on myself, glare at my teeth, and generally do a slap-dash job of making myself acceptable for public consumption. 
I growl at my closet for a couple of minutes until it occurs to me that clothes can't be intimidated into leaping onto my body, at which point I grudgingly struggle into a pair of jeans and wonder if the shirt I slept in is still clean enough to wear to work. 
It's usually at this point that I realize I'm already late. So even though I have yet to open my eyes all the way I stumble downstairs and out into the street, vainly trying to remember where I parked my car. Then how to unlock it. Then how to drive it. 
Through the city I go, swerving to avoid pedestrians and taxis, wondering if it's entirely legal to be operating heavy machinery this early in the morning (note: 8:30 is early for me, I don't care what anyone says). 

...And then I get to the Golden Gate. Some days it's sunny and the air is so clear you'd swear it's actually just come back from the dry cleaner's. Other days the fog rolls by in a way that just doesn't happen anywhere else. My eyes open wide for the first time. My hand gets steadier on the wheel. I smile with good natured affection at my fellow man. The world is beautiful, and I am beautiful in it. 

Quite simply, this is a magical bridge.
author: Tessa B.

description:
There's something in the majesty of the Golden Gate Bridge that makes me feel like I'm in some mythical time when kings or Pharaohs built insane things to their own ego.
It is a pretty bridge and worth the walk across for great views and possibly romance! I suggest a leisurely stroll rather than a fussy hustle.
author: Daisy S.

description: Good bridge.  Nice way to get to Marin.  I like this  bridge.  It's orange.
author: Pug P.

description: the GGB is another spot i've always wanted to visit as well as drive over.. awesome !!!
author: Kev Z.

description: Walking across the bridge is an amazing experience. And if you don't do it while visiting SF, you are missing out on a quintessential attraction. Do it!
author: Britt R.

description: Maybe people are just afraid to give a bad review to California's most significant landmark because it just happens to sit in their back yard.  Or maybe there really is something cool about being able to look directly down at the water.  But I say the Golden Gate Bridge isn't all that special.  It's not architecturally impressive, not by its size nor its design; it's the location and surrounding geography that give it its grandiose.  In fact, it's a bridge that looks like it's made out of Legos.  Let's not forget about its dark side either, it being one of the most notorious suicide spots in the world --- there's nothing beautiful about a suicide every other week.  And for $5 to cross, it's a good thing that the places I Yelp are all in San Francisco.  Besides, the bridge isn't gold, it's orange.
author: Blake B.

description: overall beautiful tourist spot!!! Reminds me of John Travolta in Saturday Night Fever. hmmmmmmm
author: Desiree H.

description:
seriously what is there not to like about this place?
unless your one of those CHEAP ASIANS who don't want to pay for toll to cross the bridge (don't get me wrong, i'm asian also).

this is a must come place for scenery especially when you have relatives over from other parts of the country or from overseas. they love to get out and take millions of pictures of this place. it's also a great place to talk around. if you have a lot of time on your hands, come out here during the weekend and pick a picnic spot and sit down to relax. enjoy the scene and take a million pictures before you go home.
author: Eric Y.

description: I traverse this sublime architectural masterpiece twice daily and still always marvel at how beautious it is.  But what was really memorable for me was the day my compadre's enormous seventies-esque sunglasses went flying over the side, landing on a narrow ledge on the east side of the bridge, where they remain to this day as a little semi-permanent memorial to her (so far anyhow).
author: Rick H.

description: Finest human creation and building impossible concept back at this time.  Must see, but don't jump.   It is not recommend to bring kids there before it is very windy and can blow them away... haha
author: Ken C.

description: Loved seeing this bridge while I stayed in San Francisco. It is soo iconic that you won't want to look elsewhere for hours. It is a long walk from fishermans warf if you decide to do that. Catch a bus for a buck I would recommend. And then walk back the beach way also to see it in it's spectacular views! It's a must
author: Craig R.

description: SO BEAUTIFUL! I went for a bike ride today, across the bridge, haven't done that since i was 15. I felt 15 again today, totally stimulating, amazing  views and i cant wait to go again.
author: Rachel L.

description: Everytime I cross it my little heart soars with the same awe and wonder that it did the very first time.
author: Kyla B.

description: awww..the golden gate bridge..iconic in every way...i would recommend taking time to walking/running/biking over it. Driving into the city from Marin to SF way would cost you $5 toll fee, not very commuter-friendly. But the view is breath taking....
author: Judy P.

description: I've been underneath and on it and still, the Golden Gate never cease to take my breath away.
author: Janice P.

description: I love the Golden Gate Bridge.  It is one of the most beautiful things I've seen in my life.  The feeling you get when you just close your eyes for a few brief moments......sends chills down your spine.. or it could just be the weather....but most definitely have I all the love for this bridge!
author: ChaCha F.

description: If  all you have to do all day is take $6 from every car that passes. AT LEAST smile and say thank you. Too many times Ive passed through the toll and the toll taker just rips the money from your hand, no Thank You, no Hello, Nothing. Just today a younger white guy with balding black short hair just rips the money from my hand, with a dirty look on his face, without a greeting or thank you. F*** U!!
author: Mike G.

description:
It looks nicer than the Brooklyn Bridge, but you are forced  to walk it 2x

The bridge itself is nice, have gift shops on one end and bathrooms on both to help you prepare for the walk. But less than 1/4 of the way in, I can tell you the fun was already waning. Unlike the Brooklyn Bridge, there's just isn't as many interesting things to take pictures of while you're crossing the bridge. Alcatraz island is sort of close. Downtown San Fran, not close at all. My gf and I walked through it the first time, hoping there's some sort of public transportation on the other side to bring us back. Nope. So we had to drag ourselves back to the other side. We dragged ourselves pretty quickly and didn't stop to take any pics. Not that there's any good pics to take as SF is not a very good looking city at night viewing from the Golden Gate Bridge. We were so bored (and hungry and tired) that we ended up counting how many street lights the bridge have (we lost count after 120+). Going before sunset or else be prepare for the sudden drop in temp as night draws near.
author: Jack N.

description: It's the golden gate bridge, the most iconinc man-made landmark in California. Something everyone should see in their lifetime. Sure it's old, but the bridge has been maintained very well and looks just as beautiful as it ever has. The drive to and through the bridge is a bit uncomfortable, as there is often congestion and poor traffic flow due to the combination of commuters and tourists. When you come visit, be sure to park your car at the end of the bridge and traverse the Golden Gate by foot. Nothing like crossing a 1.7 mile long bridge by foot with the sound of water thrashing about beneath you.
author: Byron C.

description: What can I say? It's big, it's long and it's bright red. What more can you ask for as far as landmarks go? At first sight, this awe-inspiring monument appears to you as you zoom along highway 101 through the Presidio of San Francisco. Like the first time I saw the World Trade Center towers (god rest their soul) from Newark Airport, it has that "wow I've seen millions of pictures of this and suddenly here it is in all it's glory" appeal. It's a knock out for sure, and yes I have walked across this beast, and back all in the same day/week/month/never-made-it-back. Convertable car comes highly recommended although not essential, mixes well with a nice sunrise or sunset.
author: Jack G.

description: 5 stars for the view of the fog passing through the GG bridge, minus 1 star for the toll returning into the city.
author: Pickle R.

description: My, I don't usually say this to a bridge I just met, but you're quite the looker.  Hang around here often?
author: San B.

description:
does anyone else find it funny that we can review a bridge? i mean what are you supposed to do, take another bridge because the reviews were bad? 
this is a good bridge. you can use it with my approval
author: Sole A.

description: Besides Chrissy Field and ATT Park this is my favorite SF landmark and place to go when I have down time.  I remember my first day in the city in 00.  I called my friend in Oakland to tell her I was walking under the GG bridge.  I remember telling her I thought it was a different color.  She informed me I was under the Bay Bridge.  Wow Id like to relive that first day in SF.  I love walking to the bridge from the wharf.  Seeing the dogs run on the beach is so uplifting.  And damn if Safeway isn't right there for a bottle of Gatorade.  Stop at the Warming Hut (is it open again?) for a sandwich.  I'm always too tired to walk back so I catch a bus to Bart.  Yep I''m lazy like that.  Love watching the sea lions from up there.
author: Kevin G.

description: A perfect place to take a fine hunny and watch the sunset during the Fall.  Enough said.
author: Lucas N.

description: It is tiring walking from one end to another! The view is great! But looking down it is quite scary. They are having or had a event that is called "Jump the bridge" something like that and what it is, is a lot of people going to the bridge and trying to make it move or shake my jumping up and down the bridge all at the same time.
author: Janet Z.

description: I often forget how stunning the Bridge is. Imagine sailing in from open Ocean and seeing this monument welcoming you to San Francisco. Amazing...
author: Keane L.

description:
#1 most beautiful bridge in the world.
http://www.neatorama.com/2008/03/07/10-most-beautiful-bridges-in-the-world/
author: dj z.

description: Yup.. It's a bridge. Just like the picture said it would be lol. No really, this is something you need to see for yourself once in your life. There are certain american icons and this is one of them. It is simply beautiful, but a little pricey to cross. Glad this thing isn't on my way to work or home lol..I bet that costs a pretty penny.
author: Emerson F.

description: The Golden Gate Bridge is a very fun place to scare tourists, have jumping contests, and look into the foggy abyss. By scaring tourists, I mean screaming at them in a variety of languages and saying, "WELCOME TO THE BAY BRIDGE, GO HOME TOURISTS". By jumping contests, I mean jumping from one cement wall to the next.  When it's really foggy, it's fun to stand on the bridge and look into the bay.. it's all gray and your knees get weak and you lose your sense of depth. GGB rocks! Take the 28 or 29 here.
author: O K.

description:
hands down one of the most amazing landmarks in the entire world.

i don't think you need to walk across it. at least step foot on it or drive across it. i never get tired of admiring the GG bridge
author: Raj R.

description: No matter how many times I drive over the bridge, back into the city, I always get speechless of the city-line. I love driving on the bridge during sunny days because it's just fantabuloso to look out at the buildings and blue water below. On certain cloudy days it's not so great for a walk on the bridge because it feels like the wind is preventing you from taking one step more, but the view is still great.
author: Janel Y.

description: nothing like a piping hot cupful of the golden gate bridge to start off my day. i never get tired of it.
author: kristin e.

description: Number one on my list of places to jump... but the view's not bad either. They are also a client so I have some amazing pictures from the top of one of the towers. Talk about feeling heavenly.
author: Alex L.

description: LOVE HER!!! i get goose-bumps anytime i ride over her! she is beautiful and she completes San Francisco!
author: Sha A.

description:
when i'm in the headlands and i can see the tippy tops peep out through the fog... it takes my breath away... every single time.  i wasn't born here but thank my lucky stars that i have had the pleasure to be in this majestic presence for the past 12 or so years.  it makes me feel warm and fuzzy every time.

now i commute over it and yeah its expensive but i don't blame the bridge, i blame the management.
author: Elizabeth H.

description: Its such an interesting landmark and we had a lot of fun visiting it. However, I was disappointed because my husband wouldn't let me walk on it. He's convinced its dangerous ;( When in SF you must see it up close though!
author: J A M.

description: bicylcists= watch for oncoming bicyclists!!!
author: P G.

description: Drive across you all the time. When oh when will those tourists learn to wear jackets and sandals without socks? You are a beaut.
author: Sven S.

description: Beautiful, but full of tourists and, inevitably, dead bodies from the construction, and lots of deaths back in the day from the gas poisoning that occurs when descending far under the water and coming back up in the wrong conditions... though, I don't really know any great accomplishment of man that didn't include something like this.
author: Caroline C.

description: How can you NOT like the Golden Gate Bridge?  Take some picnic stuff with you, walk out to the middle and have some challenging fun trying to eat in the wind.  It's fun, trust me.  Oh, and it's called the Golden Gate because that's what the entrance to the bay was originally called before there was a bridge there.  The red color, I have no idea what inspired that, but you gotta admit it's cool.
author: Jonathan B.

description: An American classic. Brilliantly designed, meticulously maintained. Every city should be so lucky to have such a timeless icon in its midst.
author: The Other Jeff A.

description: My favorite vantage point besides the Headlands: sun roof open, at night, dead of winter (but no rain)...watch as the towers approach you...wait quietly as it soars overhead and disappears from view, silently slipping away...shhhhh (set the tone with The Boatman's Call....) ahh now that was gorgeous...
author: Simms B.

description: Gotta try it! I lost my job and I was on unemployment and I thought to myself, what have I always wanted to do that I put off because I'm stupid busy. Well after facilitating a class with other unemployed persons I suggested we go out and do SF like were tourist in between job seeking of course. We didn't make it all the way across but I did it and I am proud and thank god I'm working again!
author: sonia m.

description:
so after reading some reviews, i decided that maybe i should layer up in a tank top, long sleeve, sweatshirt, and big puffy jacket before going on the bridge despite the fact that it was a lovely saturday.  boy, was i wrong.  it was cold, yes, but if you're planning on that hike from fort point onto the bridge, walking the distance of the bridge, walk to sausalito, and make a return trip back, you barely need more than a t-shirt and a good pair of walking shows (chucks are not recommended).  

great views.  great weather.  great experience.  also, when you get 5 minutes into the bridge, there's no one walking anymore!  because everyone is scattered at the ends of the bridge, so it was pretty sweet.

also, don't walk to sausalito.  if you want to go, bike there, don't walk.  you basically walk along the 101 and then to some smaller freeway that has no walkway except for a very slopped (re: hard to walk) 1' wide shoulder, which sometimes disappears!  so you have to run along side the freeway to make sure you don't get hit!  it's also about a 2 mile walk in these conditions.  i would still suggest you go to sausalito... but i would highly recommend you doing it on a bike (or a car, i guess).
author: H. L.

description: Driving over the Golden Gate bridge after work in the sunset makes you really appreciate this glorious city we live in.  Minus one star for the expensive toll.
author: apple r.

description: When did The Mob move west and take over the bridge racket? I have to travel to Marin/Napa a few times a week for work and drinking and I recently noticed Fat Tony's working the toll booth. Although they're still smiling at the booth they now carry guns, and I get the feeling if I don't have the $5 I may not be walking straight anymore. However, it's still a gorgeous monument to modern society and a testament to 20th century architectural ingenuity.
author: Phil M.

description: One of my favorite parts of living here is sailing underneath, looking up, and facing forward (during the better weather than we are experiencing now).  Obviously, this is one of the greatest parts of living in San Francisco.
author: Yelper A.

description: It costs too damn much. I like looking at it from my rooftop but I don't like riding it. I guess its hard to modernize a suspension bridge but they should seriously do something about this bridge.
author: Andrew W.

description: This is probably the most famous bridge in the country besides the Brooklyn bridge in NYC.  It has a spectacular view of the water and the city.  I have taken many pictures from the view point off the bridge.  Great spot for tourists wanting the bridge in the background with the city and them.
author: Rob P.

description:
THIS IS A VERY RARE MUST SEE. mostpeople dont even know about it! san franciscians, you might be able to find it on a map, if you know the right streets to look for, tourists, you better find a damn good guide to see this one,

TOTALLY WORTH IT


THIS BRIDGE GOES * OVER WATER* !!!!!!
author: Raccoon S.

description: I like it a lot. It lives up to its expectations.  Also,the bay here is so much wilder than say the Hudson in NYC. It makes a good backdrop.In my mind, the brooklyn bridge is a close second now. There is just something very magical about the bridge. Is it the colors or the way it goes into the hill? I think it is perhaps the architecture which is very simple but also complex.
author: Jason W.

description: very pretty  at night day timr so so !!!!!! awesome the way it was made !!!
author: Toni O.

description: Beautiful minimalist structure that simultaneously inspires world-travelers and induces suicide. Another star for the unrivaled views.
author: Evelyn B.

description: What is there to say?  The Golden Gate Bridge is *the* icon of San Francisco.  The crazy thing is that it never gets old.  From any angle, in any weather, there's no denying its singular splendor.  It's a perfect example of how architecture can complement and even enhance nature.  And besides, what would those poor poor Marin commuters do without it?
author: Wes M.

description: Who in the hell would say the Golden Gate Bridge sucks anyways?
author: Dustin H.

description: Having reviewed the dysfunctional Bay Bridge I felt obliged to put in a few words about the Golden Gate.  Poor Bay Bridge, I would be maladjusted too if my older sister were as graceful and grandly beautiful. To me the Golden Gate is more then simply an icon of San Francisco, it is indefatigably inspirational; passing beneath it's ruddy towers never ceases to raise my spirits and remind me of how lucky I am to live here.
author: GIR ..

description: I've walked the bridge twice and I think it's a great SF experience. You can   access the bridge from San Francisco or Marin county. It takes about 1 hour to go and come back. We saw the fog roll in across the bridge and saw a huge container ship go under the bridge. Only problem is the impatient cyclists. Please, you're sharing with pedestrians who don't have eyes in the back of their heads.
author: pj n.

description: It's big.  It's red.  And it's a bridge.  There is no better icon for San Francisco than the GGB.  It always reminds me of the freedom, creativity and imagination of the West Coast.  Nothing beats the intrinsic beauty of the Golden Gate.
author: Rick K.

description: I'll never get tired of waking up to the majestic bridge. Now if only my windows were a little cleaner...
author: The Sock S.

description: To put it simply, I love it. Walking across it is an adventure. Knowing that it's just a few miles away makes me happy. Driving across it to reach Mt. Tam, Stinson, or my favorite hot tub spot in Mill Valley always makes me feel incredibly lucky.
author: Abby W.

description: This bridge is friggin sexy. Especially when your on a boat at night!!! Whoooo weeee. Talk about hot date. Lol. No really this is really a nice date a boat ride by the golden gate @  sundown. My school actually had a boat party about 2 years ago and it was so fun. We sailed past the golden gate and it was sooo damn gorgeous!
author: Meks R.

description: I've been here quite a few times and I'm still in awe of the breathtaking views every time. Coming from the central valley and it's polluted air, I can't help but enjoy the refreshing breeze. It's great to get out of the hustle and bustle of the city and view it in a somewhat serene state.
author: Linndsey A.

description: One of the great things about having friends visit from out of town is that it reminds me of the awesome parts of living in the bay area. The bridge is a perfect case in point. Sometimes it's completely clear and beautiful and you get the postcard-worthy view. Other times it's slightly overcast and other times the fog makes it impossible to even see the bridge. But regardless, the bridge is a must-see. On a less-windy day, I love walking across and taking the ferry back. Or if I don't want to get up on the bridge, I love treking up to Fort Point, touching the handprints and enjoying the view of the water along the way.
author: Megan K.

description: Very beautiful bridge with a breathtaking sight. It is an amazing place. Both sides are very cool.
author: niceuser

description: It's a bridge.  The first suspension bridge of it's kind in the Bay Area.  Much more aesthetically pleasing than the Bay Bridge.
author: Joe O.

description:
to jump or not to jump
that is the question...

no really kidding..
i rode my bike across this beotch for the first time in my life a few days ago. it was truly breathtaking. i recommend walking or biking across to everyone who has functioning legs.
i miss SF :(
author: Helen N.

description: i think i've driven this bridge like twice.  HYPE!  i prefer half moon bay.
author: Jason G.

description:
You MUST see this bridge! There's a reason it's one of the 7 wonders of the modern world.

First I want to warn that it's always cold so bring a big sweater. Even in the summer, fog can cover the bridge unexpectedly, so never underestimate the weather. That's not to say that there aren't some beautiful days though.

Anyway, you have to walk at least to the middle of the bridge and look all around you. Look up, look down! You can see the entire city, Alcatraz, everything. Also, go to the very end on the north side of the bridge and there is a little section where you can walk underneath and feel the traffic shaking everything. It's exciting!

If you live in the city, it's a great way to get into shape by running back and forth. There are different vantage points from different places on the bridge, so you can't possibly get bored or get tired of it. It's fairly easy to accomplish walking or running from one side to the other, and as you look back, you'll feel great.
author: Sean K.

description: I feel kind of silly giving a bridge a 5-star rating : P but what the hell, this is the Golden Gate Bridge. It's a great thing to marvel at from a distance or to experience directly. You can walk across, bike across (be sure to use the correct side- the side that faces the ocean), you can stand in the middle and pretend like you're in "Titanic" : P. Driving across can be fun, too, just be sure to have money for the toll coming back into SF. Navigating from the tourist area to the freeway can be tricky if you're not used to the area, so be careful. If you drive across, be sure to observe the speed limit. It's a great place and I'm glad the City takes care of it.
author: Al B.

description: this bridge is THE icon for SF. as attractive from upclose as it is from a distance. when your tourist friends come into town don't let them buy postcards of it, make them go there to walk around and take pictures. or better yet, take them there!
author: Jeff W.

description: The greatest worldwide symbol of the bay area! Wish it was free though!!
author: David P.

description: SO BEAUTIFUL. I miss seeing it around the Presidio where my hotel was. I miss the beautiful sunsets. And the bike riding. WOOT WOOT. Till we meet again. Def walk or bike the bridge if you get a chance. The view from the bridge is stellar.
author: Joann P.

description: Biking across the Golden Gate Bridge is, of course, one of the coolest things ever. However, I am afraid of heights, and it is scary. The wind can blow hard, and when you're riding around the small circles that surround the main supports, it can sort of seem to someone with a rather wild imagination like you'll lose control and plow hard into the side of the bridge, flipping yourself upside down over the bike's handlebars and careening over the protective railing to your untimely death. You won't, though. Trust me.
author: Bonnie L.

description: Gotta love it. I'd love it more if the damn fog wasn't always hanging around. And oh yeah, if the damn toll didn't just ride to what? Six freakin bucks! When you're lazy.. either driving.. or busy talking to the passenger (or YOU PASSENGER.. talking to the driver) you'll miss the last exit of SF and end up crossing this bridge and paying freakin $6 for missing the damn exit by 2 fuckin feet. Nice.. Way to go..
author: Elaine H.

description: For a slightly different perspective walk round the headland towards Ocean Beach. Follow the path then the sign to the beach (a downhill/uphill hike). Here it seems as if you are standing almost underneath the bridge. It is quieter and more impressive. The beach itself is gay nudest but not signed as such!
author: marsdenbel

description: Its big.  Its golden.  And the view is breath taking on a clear day.  Enjoy this site while its still here.
author: Chanel F.

description: Yeah, yeah, everyone sez it.  But that's cuz it's true.  Easily the most beautiful bridge anywhere around here, and possibly anywhere in the country.  I'll admit, I've never walked or biked it, but that's because my preferred way to experience it is driving across in a convertible with the top down.  Looking up as you go under the towers is awesome.  Also, the view of SF from the Marin headlands through the bridge towers is the best anywhere.
author: Don H.

description: I'm a fan :). OK, something not vacous...I used to be able to see it from my house, over the beautiful SF bay, from beautiful Berkeley. And there is no image that touches me more.
author: Anonymous P.

description: I participated in the Avon Walk, and our route gives the opportunity to walk across the bridge. It' was a picture perfect morning - in JULY no less! Moments like those remind me how lucky I am to live in such a fantastic place.
author: Rene D.

description: I'm extremely afraid of heights. I get nervous standing on a step stool in my kitchen. So when my out of town guest suggested that we walk the bridge I looked at him like he was insane. After some intense prodding and about 3 wines I was ready to tackle the bridge. As I inched my way out, feeling the cars rush past me on either side I thought "what the hell am I doing this for?!" But when I got to the middle of the bridge and saw the beautiful view, I was totally glad I did it. Of course getting me off the bridge again was another story...
author: Rebecca H.

description:
As part two of our roommate free sightseeing weekend, we went to see the golden gate bridge the other sunday. This is the symbol of San francisco, so i wanted to see it. And, i wanted to get it out of the way fast, because it's such a touristy you dont live here type of thing to do.
We took a bus up a long road and ended at the bridge. We got off, with the other tourists, and saw, the bridge. We took pictures. And that was the bridge. Really, what more can you say, it's a bridge! People drive over it, it must be constructed well, but how much time can you really spend on it? There was a bridge gift shop, which we walked through quickly, and a bridge snack shop, which we saw no need to even go near.
For the way back, matt wanted to walk back on the scenic route. So, we walked, and we saw the ocean, and the bridge from some other views, and some plants, which according to the signs were rare. We also saw a sign saying there would be birds on the trail, and guess what there were! We saw an old fort and barracks, and then a sign for a trail leading to an old battery but that sounded really boring so we skipped that. It was pretty to see the view of the city from above, and to see the sea. And then we ended up catching the bus towards home.
A very nice, roommatey day. :)
author: Merredith L.

description: Being terrified of both heights and water, I have yet to bring myself to walk across it in the six years that I've lived here.  It is very pretty to look at though.  I really hope they don't spoil its good looks with some ugly suicide barrier.  It's really not that many people a year when you compare it to the number who die in car crashes and other things like that.   We could really put the money to better use.
author: Squirrel L.

description:
they don't tell you this on the tour buses of san francisco but the golden gate bridge is the number one destination for suicides in the world... 
that's just crazy... 
saw the documentary 'the bridge' not too long ago which gave me a new view of the bridge...
http://www.thebridge-themovie.com/new/index.html

other than that, it symbolizes san francisco... when you think san francisco, you'll most likely think of the golden gate bridge :)
and san francisco is an awesome possum city!... hence the 5 stars
author: charlotte s.

description: Anticipating congestion pricing, my boyfriend and I stopped driving in the city.  I don't really remember the view so I might have to go to Sausalito next year.  I love how the orange is a contrast against the water.  I've seen a Dirty Jobs episode about the people who have to chip off the paint on the bridge because its repainted.  We've driven over this before but I haven't walked through.
author: Ai M.

description: Yay for the GGB!! It's so damn touristy, but I really have a soft spot in my heart for it... I used to be able to see it from my bedroom window as a little girl... I used to fall asleep watching the lights on top blinking... Now, I enjoy going there and misdirecting tourists or talking a stroll (hike) across it...
author: Lindsey S.

description: Such a beautiful bridge in what is quite possibly the greatest location for a bridge to be in.  It's the focal point of the entire bay area.  I never get tired of looking at it.
author: Shyam P.

description: Truly a landmark of San Francisco. If you didn't see GG Bridge in SF, you haven't visited SF at all.....so much history and fascination with this one of a type wonder. Apparently, my Portugal friend mentioned that Lisbon has a similar bridge but not quite to scale. Driven through it many many times with friends from out of town or simply making a trip to Marin and beyond. Walked on it once, breathtaking views.
author: Yan M.

description: There's not much I can say that's already been said, here and elsewhere. It's spectacular- every time, from a distance or close. Beautiful architecture and the color is just perfect. Really, can you imagine it any other way? Every time I catch a glimpse (walking down the hill near my house) it sort of thrills me, makes me remember the good things about this city (and forget about...Muni, etc.).
author: Barbs J.

description: I'm ashamed to say that I lived in the city nearly a year before I took my first walk across the Golden Gate Bridge. And needless to say, I regret it. This one of the most beautiful views in all of the city... and once you get used to the traffic behind you, one of the most calming.
author: Erin M.

description: Gorgeous, when not encased in fog. Even then it's sort of romantic, but you can't really see it then. Great for biking across!
author: Colleen B.

description: I love the Golden Gate Bridge. It's awesome to take visitors and have a walk on a windy day.
author: Betty L.

description: My oh my, what a sight! The upkeep and maintenance of the bridge is impeccable, and the view on a non-foggy day is the best there is while walking across, a definite must do for anyone.
author: Janice P.

description: How can you not love it? It is THE symbol of California! The only thing not to love is the toll price!
author: Nate M.

description: Quintessential San Fransisco.  Beautiful bridge, a fun drive to go over!  Great views and terrific photo ops!
author: Mina I.

description: A symbol of man's ablility to built anything with hope and inspiration. A ture beauty that everyone can respect, wonder, and enjoy. This is one of SF pride icon as well that always catches my eye. Try to catch a visit on a sunny day where you can see the beauty with the bay and marin county in the view. No point if it's foggy, hey what can you say it's SF for you.
author: David M.

description: Gorgeous bridge, a true SF landmark.  So shouldn't it be better lit at night than the Bay Bridge?
author: Pelle Y.

description:
i love san francisco.

i haven't walked on the bridge since i was a tot. i drive through it sometimes... thaaaaat's nice.

toll is an extra dollar. sheesh.
author: Rosalee C.

description: It's eerie seeing the bridge from various parts of the city; that looming international-orange structure that dominates everything within its radius. When I see the tops thru trees or taking the Caltrain (yes you can see it if you're on the left side of the train) I shudder. But it's simply breathtaking. I don't have a friggin boner for the bridge as my review may suggest, but it when all is said and done, the bridge really is a sight to behold. I do get a bit queasy walking over it--it's always windy as hell and freezing--but I'm glad I do. I look down into the icy waters and ponder why people would want to jump? Even as a local, it still amazes me every time I see it. Those tourists plan their whole trip around the GG Bridge, and frankly, it's worth it. I've never met anyone who's hated it.
author: Chase S. K.

description: this bridge looks cool...i always wanted to visit it instead of seeing it on Full House!  lol
author: Michael W.

description: It's a really scenic bridge, the best way to see it is to rent a bike and ride across it!  I love the nice cool breeze as I ride across this bridge, taking in all the amazing views.  Just make sure you pay attention to the road, there is a lot of bike traffic on the bridge and you wouldn't want to crash!!
author: Stephen D.

description: Probably the most beautiful bridge in the world...I go over it twice every day on my way to work in Marin...lovely...especially in the fog
author: Francis K.

description: i do not use this bridge very often unless I am going to Marin every few months, but what a spectacular landmark it is. I get very giddy whenever I am approaching it, and usually am obnoxious and take out my camera and take pictures as I cross it. I have a story to tell about the rest stop on the other side of the bridge but that will have to wait till my memoir comes out!
author: Lauren V.

description:
really people?  you really needed to yelp this?  c'mon. it's san francisco's gg bridge. are there people here who would give this fewer than five stars? seriously?  we needed to yelp this?  

ok, i give. i give.  it's effing gorgeous and i get giddy like a 7 year old every time i cross it.  are you happy now?  yeesh.  i hope you're happy.
author: Melissa Y.

description: Were rating the GG Bridge now? I need to yelp more...
author: S. L.

description: No, this is not a 5-star review of the Bridge as a fabulous work of art/engineering or the views. This is 5 stars for the Bridge because it is one of the best sites in the world for honing serious bike-handling skills. Not only do you, on occasion, get a nice wicked, gusty cross wind, that gets especially tricky as it eddies around the towers, but you get a dynamic and unpredictable obstacle course, too. Of course, you may call these obstacles "tourists," "pedestrians," "tourists on bikes," "a pain in your ass," whatever, but I revel in my rides across the span, especially the east side. The kids darting to and fro, the unpredictable "quick step back" by photographers, the massive tour-packs... all test your control and your patience like no other place in the world. Here's to you Golden Gate Bridge! May your many oblivious fans ever challenge me and my fellow cyclists!
author: Don B.

description: Great place for tourists. I get kinda bored just looking at it though. Crossing it is fun? ;)
author: Katherine C.

description: As a New Yorker it seems really hyped up about nothing, yes its red and nice, the Verazzano or Brooklyn bridges are just as big and spectacular.
author: Mark T.

description: Not my favorite bridge.. but definitely in a great location. Whatever bridge straddles the entrance to this place known as the bay.. is destined for greatness. You gotta love the fact that they haven't put up the jump-deterring netting because they wanted the aesthetic integrity to be preserved.
author: Eugene G.

description:
I walked it when I first visited the states in the early 90's and will never forget how I got stuck on the first pillar...

..Right then and there I felt the movement, slowly swinging, back and forth. ..Yes, it's a suspension bridge alright. Suddenly my fear of heights took over, yah, the rest is history..;)

Many moons later I moved here permanently and now I get to walk it whenever I feel like it, drive over it and sometimes even see whales beneath it.

I highly recommend the trek all across the bridge and back to tourists as well as locals. Not only is the GGB the entry to one of the best city's in the world but it will also open your eyes on it's northern end leading into Marin County and some of the most beautiful coast line along Highway 1. It's an engineering marvel!
author: Trinity X.

description: When I posted a search for, "Dive Bars in San Francisco", the GG Bridge appeared on the list.
author: Paul Q.

description: I agree with ahunter's review. I used to live in the Bay Area, and a great way to spend a day with out-of-town visitors was to rent a bike at Fisherman's Wharf, ride it along the shore to the Golden Gate, cross over to Marin County, and take a ferry back. Definitely stop at the visitor's center on the North (Marin County) side and check out the view looking back. If you're driving (and you're lucky enough to go on a clear day), consider driving up to the Marin Headlands, where you'll get an incredible view across the bridge to the city skyline.
author: Roger47

description:
the bridge is an absolutely stunning piece of arcitecture it just takes your breath away when you think about how hard it must have been to build and how long it must have taken!
you really need a fine and clear day to get a good photo of the bridge and if you do it will be worth it!


 the views i got of the bridge were just from beside and and they were fabulous so i can only imagine what they are like looking from the bridge.
next time i go i will deffo walk/bus across it coz it looks amazing!
author: blondi1

description: I've been to the golden gate bridge multiple times and am still thrilled each time I go! Make sure you don't cross the bridge before you park unless you want to pay 10 dollars toll on the way back. Also, check out the trail that goes below the bridge and guides you to a pier. I saw a seal lion there waiting to say hi to me. There were also lots of people fishing for crabs there. Very scenic and beautiful place!!
author: Dave Y.

description: Im prett tired of this place. For first time tourists, this place is great and a must see! But ive had to take relatives here and this place is boring. Its cold and cloudy and the walk along the bridge alwasy seems dangerous to me. Dont get me wrong though, ill come over again and again.
author: Andre W.

description:
Cool place to visit. We walked along it and back again (although you can walk up it and either cycle back or get the boat back).


 Great views.


 They even have crisis help and counselling phones on the bridge in case anyone was thinking of jumping!!
author: Pinklizard

description:
How can you not like this? It is awe-inspiring in a very strange sense. Maybe its color, but probably the good view. 

My suggestion  (assuming you can ride a bike): take a bike from the Pier 39 area to the Bridge. Go across the bridge, feel the wind, look at Alcatraz, feel alive. There's a semi-secret trail that goes under the bridge and around to a Fort of some significant history. There's also a road that will take you into Sausolito.  You'll be able to see a bunch of rich people's houses and have probably the best American bike trips possible.
author: Adam S.

description: What a awesome place - I spent ages just looking at it. It's the biggest bright i have ever seen in my life. I can't wait for next year to go again.
author: cityboy

description:
i lived in SF for several years already, and a great cheap way to spent a day with family and friends is to rent bikes together and bike through the bridge, the road there is very save, there is bike lane, and the road is not rough at all, very good for family gathering also. if you are new to the bridge, join the tour guide near in the gift shop area, but i am not sure whether the tour guide is still provided now. also visit the gift shop and buy some postcard to keep the nice memory.
And before going, i recommend to look at the weather first, because sometimes it is very misty there and you cannot take as nice photography, and sometimes is rainy and very windy. so check weather, and bring some money will be a great day spent.
author: moonight

description: Yes it is an amazing structure and you are in awe of its construction but it is a bridge and there is so much more to San Francisco than the bridge. If time is limited I wouldn't bother with it and would spend the time more wisely by going to Alcatrz. Take a sightseeing tour if time is limited to get the best of everything some even include a trip over the bridge.
author: shortz

description: You're a cliche.  Everyone's had his turn.  I still can't get enough.  Crossing or seeing you after a out of town sortee never gets old.  San Francisco here I come.
author: Nate B.

description:
just love it when the 28 stops by here to drop off the tourists heading for ggb... 
aside from that... driving across the ggb is a breeze... seeing the towers, the views from either side of the bridge... views are just filled with blue water. \
walking across the ggb is another matter. it can take from 40 minutes to however long your walking speed is to reach the end of the bridge. just stop occasionally to see where you are, look up and down and side to side to see that you've made a big accomplishment, walking across the bridge. pause to snap a few photos of the views from the bridge. once reaching the other end of the bridge, rest yourself and decide whether you want to walk the return trip on the bridge or walk to sausalito and catch the ferry. 
walking across the ggb at least once should be a requirement for every san francisco resident.  the walk is simply amazing.
author: Court L.

description: By all means avoid the boat trips to the bridge. I did it in the past and was delighted but now I do not think any of them are worth it. They use to take you around the bay , Bay Bridge and Golden Gate included. Now they will go to the Golden gate, sail around the nearest pillar (not a yard more) and head straight back.
author: CasimirVessel

description: I was born a few years after the bridge was completed and I remember my parents and grandparents talking about the building of the bridge, but my memories go back to my first conscious crossing in Mom and Dad's 4 door Kaiser on our way to visit my uncle in Ross.  I was thrilled to be crossing in a car, to do something I'd never done before, to think about how majestic this bridge is.  As a kid I had no appreciation of the fact that we had a beautiful view of the bridge, and almost everything from where Mt. Sutro now hosts THAT tower to Berkeley and Oakland including the other (gray) bridge.  The radio stations used to keep a running count on the suicides, haven't heard that in years, the closures and the weather when extreme.  I remember when so many people walked onto the bridge, I feared it would collapse.  The fare was $ .25 when I started driving my own cars back and forth and it seemed magic to me then, still does but it's expensive magic today.  It's a great symbol of a great city.
author: Stu S.

description: I walked across with my kids and it was pretty sweet.  The old fort down below is great place to take pictures  too
author: J C.

description:
came here on new years day with girlfriend in tow. a spontaneous decision we both agreed on without hesitation. yes, we walked the entire span...and back. on new years day, many people showed up to brave the cold but bright day. so many that, at mid span, near 2 o'clock, traffic in the slow lane came to a hault. everyone, including us, were attempting to park on the sausalito side of the bridge.

as we inched closer, i saw and forgot about, a smaller parking lot on the south bound side of 101 directly across from the main parking lot everyone was attempting to go to. got off at the next exit after the main parking lot, went under 101 and went into the alternate parking lot. BAM, we instantly found a parking spot. we quickly found the pathway that takes you under the bridge and to the main parking lot with bathrooms and look out spots. a bathroom break later, we were off to walk this landmark.

we dressed in layers and walked at a good pace to keep our bodies warm. we saw barges, tug boats, sail boats and a school of dolphins. the sun was out and burned most of the fog away from the bridge. sausalito on the other hand did not receive the same appreciation. to the naked eye, there was a slight haze over the entire span. when photographed, you couldn't see the said haze lol. maybe from a distance it would. when it was all over with, we jumped in my car and continued up the hill to really take in the gg bridge. there are some old military baracks/bunkers left open for the public to see about your 1st 100 yards up the hill. continue up and you have small turn-outs where you can park and take pictures of the gg and/or san fran. continue to the top you will find more parking and a higher vantage point for view the enitire bay area with the gg in the forefront. very picturesque! there's tunnels, hiking trails and more old military bunkers, baracks and structures. some of the military buildings are scary looking - something out of a hollywood scare flick....or some obscure porn movie.

i wanna go back. it was fun, but, would love to do this again in the burning hot sun - which is like 75F in this area! hahaha.

*something to note, the north bound side of the bridge is for pedestrians and cyclists. the south bound side of the bridge is for cyclists only - no pedestrians.
author: watani f.

description: you gotta see it to really appreciate it
author: eshanov

description: i watched a history special last week on the people who helped build the Golden Gate bridge. it was fascinating to see how dangerous it really was...  such a beautiful piece of architecture. many times i've walked across this bridge wondering if there is anything better than living in san francisco. the answer is always no.
author: Michelle I.

description: Ah, the Golden Gate Bridge.! Picturesc views of the bay, Marin, Oakland, and San Francisco, and wonderful old world architecture. Its always fun looking out at the bay going to and from Marin. Yes, the toles have gone up to $6.00, but such as life.! The tole agents are always nice.  I still have yet to walk it and admire the 38 painters and welders maintaining this grandiose structure that gives the bay area its recognition.
author: Brian S.

description: i've crossed this bridge nearly every day for years. it's the only bridge beautiful enough with such majestic views to merit a $5 toll.
author: lisa w.

description: This bridge is internationally known as a beautiful place to die.  The official estimate now is somewhere between 1300 and 1400 suicides enabled by this death magnet.  Those are just the bodies that have washed up on shore and no one is counting those which sank or were carried out to sea.  Likewise, no one can separate the number of accidental deaths from the intentional acts of self-destruction.  The fence is right around seat height for bicyclists, and on a windy day you can sometimes see riderless bikes leaning haphazardly against the guard rail.  It makes you wonder.   Eventually, unless a suicide barrier is built, this bridge may claim more lives than the 9/11 terrorism or the American casualties in Iraq.   San Franciscans will probably still not protest or make the obvious connection that the bridge is killing people,  because one thing they value more than life itself is a nice view.
author: David H.

description: The best thing about the toll plaza is that you can zip through it with Fastrak -- some of the time. Not talking about the bridge, just the toll plaza. It is interesting that the bridge was paid for many, many years ago but they're still charging more and more to cross it.
author: Errey S.

description: before i actually saw the ggb, i thought it was just some stupid bridge/tourist attraction.  you can't really grasp the magnificence of the bridge until you see it first hand though.  whether you watch the morning mists rise above it or watch the sun's last embers burn red at sunset, this bridge is definitely one of america's treasures.  this is one of the most picturesque spots in the entire region!!  i get a thrill every time i drive across the bridge, and that compensates for the $5 toll coming back into the city!!!
author: Roshni R.

description: This is my 50th review on Yelp. I cannot think of a better way to celebrate than writing about the GGB. The beautiful sister. This Bridge to Everywhere is spectacular from every angle. Its big, its orange it is photographed hundreds of  times each day. You leave SF and it is 60 degrees , you cross the Bridge and it is 80 degrees.  Tourists love to walk across stop and takes pics. I love to walk, run, bike, drive whatever across. I used to ride in the backseat of my parents Plymouth and look out the window in amazement.  When I was a hippie, my then boyfriend and i did not have enough money one time to pay our toll, so they took an IOU. Later in life I lived in Mill Valley and I would commute across in my older Mercedes to SFO, as a flight Attendant @ 5am.  I ran one of the SF Marathons across her. This bridge is definitley a she. I never take her for granted.  You have to respect her. She can be beautiful and she can be a danger, a lover or a complete bitch.  Everyone knows that she is never done putting on her make-up. she is constantly being groomed. She looks over @ her grey sister, (the Bay Bridge) and knows she is blessed.  Writing about her  makes me miss her. I feel like going to see her right now!
author: Donna S.

description: You HAVE TO bike across this bridge. It is amazing being so high in the air and looking at the view of the Pacific Ocean with the breeze blowing in your face. (Much less crowded than the walking side too.)
author: Retired B.

description: truly awesome. i never get tired of crossing it whether by car or by foot. every time i am struck by its beauty. probably my favorite thing about SF. but, please god, don't ever let me see a jumper!
author: Melisa B.

description: if there's one thing you have to do when you visit SF, it's the bridge. take a camera, a fleece, and sneakers, and enjoy the walk.
author: Bee H.

description: Very cool!  The parking sucks (as do the a-holes who think driving around you for that same spot is ok) and the traffic is really loud.  But if you can get around those things and walk the bridge it's really cool.  It makes you feel very tiny.
author: Phil M.

description: again, another thing i had to do before i leave such a great city, i had to go across the golden gate bridge at least once. why haven't i gone across the bridge in the year and a half i've been here you ask? well, i have no reason to... apparently i'm not cool enough to know anyone in marin or novato. i was going to walk across this marvel of modern technology, but it got really cold and i'm such a wuss when it comes to wind, so instead i was driven across by a very patient boyfriend. it was so much fun! the view of the city is incredible and the massive amounts of pedestrians was just overwhelming. people really wanted to walk this biotch :) i also can see how people would come from all over the world just to commit suicide on this puppy. you can look at a fantastic view as you fall (yes, that was mean. i'm over it). another to do crossed off the list :)
author: Aly L.

description: I'm not particularly yelping about my ride on the Bridge itself, but how beautiful the views are from underneath when you're on jet skiis.  I departed from the Berkeley Marina and entered the ocean on jet skiis and saw drop dead and up close ,gorgeous views of Tiburon Island, Alcatraz, Marina, Sausalito, Bay Bridge, Golden Gate bridge, all the piers,  Baker Beach and other places I don't know the names of.  Jet skii's are not allowed in the Marina but we went anyway and got pulled over by the ocean sherrifs. Its okay, no tickets just a warning to never come back.  All in all, you can see so much more on jet skiis than you ever would driving in car.  Of all the things I saw, The Golden Gate Bridge was overwhelmingly incredible from underneath.  We skiied from one end to the other and drank a lot of salt water too because the waves were very strong.  A word of caution, it is very very cold jet skiing in the ocean, so you must wear scuba diving like wet suits to keep from getting hypothermia.  Not only that, ocean waves are very scary and a little bit tougher and more tiring to ski in.  Be very careful and wear tons of sun screen. If you ever jet ski, don't forget to ski by the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: kim t.

description: good view, good place, and the most popualar sucide deastation in the wrold, what more could you want from the symbol of san francisco?
author: Leigh McInnis Lee G.

description: i like to ride my bike over it, it doesn't taste like amazing but it looks like it.
author: Charlie C.

description: Wow!  It took me five months of living in San Francisco before I finally walked the bridge, and it was amazing.  On a beautiful sunny non-windy day, we could perfectly see the city and enjoy our walk.  Only negative was the tourists on the first part of the bridge, luckily, they don't walk all the way to the other side.  On the other side we walked to Sausalito, the walk isn't very nice, but I really liked the town.
author: Marijke D.

description: This was our very first stop after picking up our rental car at the airport and headed north and was the one San Francisco site that we felt we absolutely had to visit on our Napa/Sonoma trip.  After realizing we were never going to find parking on the south side of the bridge, we drove across and tried again on the north side.  We didn't get to walk across, but we did finally find parking at the end of the loop/lot on the north side.  I wasn't surprised by the number of cars considering it was the week after Christmas, but it was annoying how many vehicles hovered anxiously waiting five to ten minutes or more for others to leave when there were lots of open spots at the end of the parking lot circle.  We finally got parked and spent about half an hour walking around taking pictures.  It was rainy and windy the day we were there, but you can't come to San Francisco and not see this iconic structure no matter the weather, the crowds, or the traffic.
author: Renee S.

description: we walked and talked...but mainly about the documentary The Bridge.   it never the less was a beautiful place to be even though people like to kill themselves here.
author: ML ..

description: Checking out the Golden Gate Bridge was one of the highlights of my trip to SF.  The way to see the Bridge is definitely by bike.    I would suggest parking somewhere in the Marina District and riding your bike across the bridge into Sausalito.  Be sure to explore Sausalito while you're over there.. they've got some cool shops and great views.  If you don't feel like riding your bike back, you can always take the ferry from Sausalito to SF.
author: Rick G.

description: What can be said about this?  It is so incredible.  Only wish we could build more monuments like this around our beautiful city.
author: James B.

description: I was excited to visit the golden gate bridge simply because of how often I'd seen pictures of it, and admired it from afar. There is a strange feeling when actually standing at a structure that you have never really 'seen' but feel so familiar with. As an attraction in itself I'd recommend a short trip, I don't think it can sustain hours of enjoyment! Cycling across is enjoyable and the views are great in good weather, otherwise if you have a car I'd recommend driving across the bridge from the city and seeing it from the viewing area where there is plenty of space to park the car and take your photos. With the city in the background and (hopefully) the sun shining on the golden colour of the bridge, it is a beautiful view.
author: kathfisch

description: pass underneath it on a cruise and you get a sense of how monstrous it really is.
author: simonefrances

description: A highlight of our time in the city. We hired bikes and rode accross. We had a wonderful day full of the sunshine - no fog! (When my sis visited she didnt see the top of the bridge all the time she was there due to the fog!) There are great stops for loads of photo opportunities.
author: mccak83

description: the history behind its color tells a lot about the San Franciscans; democratic and tasteful.
author: denise k.
